projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Hi≈øtorical Antiquities, IN TWO BOOKS.
The Fir≈øt Treating in General OF GREAT-BRETTAIN AND IRELAND.
The Second Containing Particular Remarks CONCERNING CHESHIRE.
Faithfully Collected out of Authentick Hi≈øtories, Old Deeds, Records, and Evidences, BY Sir PETER LEYCESTER Baronet.
Whereunto is annexed A Tran≈øcript of DOOMSDAY-BOOK, ≈øo far as it concerneth CHESHIRE, taken out of the Original Record.
div.q: Fru≈øtra fit per plura, quod pote≈øt fieri per pauciora.
div.p: LONDON, Printed by W. L. for Robert Clavell, in Cro≈øs-Key Court in Little-Britain. M.DC.LXXIII.
TO HIS Mo≈øt Serene, and Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty CHARLES II.
By the Grace of God, OF GREAT BRITAIN, FRANCE, and IRELAND KING, DEFENDER of the FAITH, &c.
THIS VOLUME OF Hi≈øtorical Antiquities Is with all Humility DEDICATED BY HIS MAJESTIES MOST LOYAL AND MOST OBEDIENT SUBJECT PETER LEYCESTER.

div.head: THE AUTHOR TO THE READER.
div.p: I Have in this Volume pre≈øented to your view two Books: The fir≈øt more general, entituled, Hi≈øtorical Antiquities of GREAT BRETTAINE and IRELAND, containing a Collection of the Chiefe≈øt Things Ob≈øervable out of our mo≈øt Ancient and Authentique Hi≈øtorians, vouching my Authorities all along to every Particular. And although it be but a Brief Ab≈øtract (which is ever be≈øt for Memory) of what others have delivered more at large; yet the diligent Reader may perhaps find ≈øome Remarkable Things, which otherwi≈øe he might not ea≈øily meet withal.

The other more Particular, entituled, Some Antiquities touching CHESHIRE: And this is divided into four Parts, whereof the three fir≈øt concern that County in general; but the fourth Part treats onely of the Antiquities of Bucklow-Hundred.

Here is al≈øo added, in the Clo≈øe of the Whole Work, A Tran≈øcript of Doom≈øday-Book, ≈øo far as it concerns Che≈øhire, taken from the Record it ≈øelf, kept in the Tally-Office at We≈øtmin≈øter: Which Book was begun and fini≈øhed between the Fourteenth and Twentieth Years of the Reign of William the Conqueror: Which I doubt not but will be very acceptable to all the Gentry of that County, and e≈øpecially to ≈øuch as love the Study of Antiquities: Wherein every Man may ≈øee who held any Lands in any of the Towns of Che≈øhire at the time of the Norman Conque≈øt, and who enjoyed the ≈øame, by vertue of the Conque≈øt, in the Time of the Conqueror. Howbeit, many Towns are now Inhabited in this County, which being at that time Wa≈øte, are not to be found in that Record. And whereas ≈øome Gentlemen of Che≈øhire have been formerly at great Charge in taking Copies of Part hereof out of the ≈øaid Record, every Man may now ≈øpare that Co≈øt and Trouble, having here the Whole at large before him.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: BEcau≈øe I intend to ≈øearch into the Beginning of Things, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øhew in the Fronti≈øpiece the Original Plantation of Nations, as we find them Recorded in Holy Scripture, the mo≈øt Ancient, True, and Perfect Hi≈øtory in the World.

I. Adam, the fir≈øt Monarch, and the fir≈øt Man; who, with Eve his Wife, were both Created by God in the Beginning of the World; to whom God gave Power of Begetting their Like, and to multiply by Generation, as he did to other Creatures.

list.item:
This Adam lived 930 Years, and had ≈øeveral Sons and Daughters; but three have their Names e≈øpecially Recorded in the Fir≈øt Book of Mo≈øes, called Gene≈øis, Chapter v.
1.
II. Cain, elde≈øt Son of Adam, was a Tiller of Ground: He ≈ølew his Brother Abel, and was therefore bani≈øhed, and dwelt in the Land of Nod, on the Ea≈øt of Eden, Gen. c. 4. He built a City, and called it (after the Name of his Son) Enoch.
III. Enoch, Son of Cain.
IV. Irad, Son of Enoch.
V. Mehujael, Son of Irad.
VI. Methu≈øael, Son of Mehujael.
VII. Lamech, Son of Methu≈øael, had two Wives, Gen. 4.
Adah,
Jabal, an Orderer of cattel; the fir≈øt Heard≈øman.
Jubal, the fir≈øt Inventour of In≈øtrumental Mu≈øick.
Zillah,
Tubal-Cain, the fir≈øt Artificer in Bra≈øs and Iron.
Naamah, a Daughter.
2. Abel, or Hebel, the ≈øecond Son of Adam, was a Feeder of Sheep; he was kill'd by his Brother Cain, Gen. 4. v. 8.
3.
II. Seth, born Anno Mundi & Adami 130: He lived 912 Years, and died Anno Mundi, 1042.
III. Enos, Son of Seth, was born Anno Mundi 235, lived 905 Years, and died Anno Mundi 1140.
IV. Kenan, Son of Enos, born Anno Mundi 325, lived 910 Years, and died Anno Mundi 1235.
V. Mahalaleel, Son of Kenan, born Anno Mundi 395, liv'd 895 Years, and died Anno Mundi 1290.
VI. Jared, Son of Mahalaleel, born Anno Mundi 460, lived 962 Years, and died Anno Mundi 1422.
VII. Enoch, Son of Jared, born Anno Mundi 622, lived 365 Years, and was then tran≈ølated into Heaven by God, Anno Mundi 987.
VIII. Methu≈øalah, Son of Enoch, born Anno Mundi 687, lived 969 Years, and died Anno Mundi 1656, in the Year of the General Deluge.
IX. Lamech, Son of Methu≈øalah, born Anno Mundi 874, lived 777 Years, and died Anno Mundi 1651. vivente Patre ejus.
X. Noah, Son of Lamech, born Anno Mundi 1056, lived 950 Years; to wit, 350 Years after the General Flood, and died Anno Mundi Conditi 2006.

div.p: ‚öú Hence it is (≈øaith Sir Walter Raleigh, in his Hi≈øtory of the World, Lib. 1. Cap. 6. Sect. 4.) that the Heathen Gods fetch their Original. Many Learned Men conceive, that Adam was the fir≈øt Saturn; Cain, the fir≈øt and ancient Jupiter; Jabal, the fir≈øt Mercury; Jubal, the fir≈øt Apollo; Tubal-Cain, the fir≈øt Vulcan, which hath ≈øome re≈øemblance in the Name: Lactantius, Lib. 4. Cap. 27.
Lamech, the ≈øeventh from Adam, had 77 Children, ≈øaith Jo≈øephus, in his Hi≈øtory of the Jews: But tho≈øe four above-named were very famous.

div.head: Of the Po≈øterity of Sem after the Flood.
div.p: Noah was an Husbandman, and Planted a Vineyard, Gen. c. 19. In the ≈øix hundredth Year of his Age, Anno Mundi Conditi 1656. hapned the General Deluge, wherein all the People of the old World were drowned, except Noah, and his three Sons, and their Wives, Gen. c. 7. And from tho≈øe three Sons was the whole Earth again repleni≈øhed.
Noah lived 950 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2006. Anno po≈øt Diluvium 350.
I. Sem, Son of Noah, had I≈ø≈øue five Sons; Elam, and A≈øhur, and Arphaxad, and Lud, and Aram.
And the Children of Aram were Uz, and Hul; and Gether, and Ma≈øh, Gen. 10, ver. 22.
Sem was born 98 Years before the Flood, lived 600 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2158, & Anno po≈øt Diluvium 502.
Cham, or Ham, younger Son of Noah.
Japhet, Son of Noah: Some think he was the elde≈øt Son.
II. Arphaxad, Son of Sem, was born the ≈øecond Year after the Flood, lived 438 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2096. po≈øt Diluvium 440.
‚öú Sem and his five Sons inhabited the Countrey of A≈øia, beginning at Euphrates, and extending to the Indian Ocean.

Of Elam came the Elamites, whence proceeded the Per≈øians. A≈øhur made his abode in Nineveh, and called his People A≈ø≈øyrians. Of Arphaxad came the Chaldeans. Of Aram came the Aramaei, called by the Greeks, Syrians: And of Lud came the Lydians.

And Uz, Son of Aram, dwelt in Trachonita, and in Dama≈øco, (a Country ≈øituate between Pale≈øtine and Syria, named Coelen:) Otrus, called al≈øo Hul, (or el≈øe he was the Son of Hul) inhabited Armenia. Gether had Bactria. From Ma≈øus came the Ma≈øians, who dwelt in a Fort called Pra≈øine. Jo≈øephus de Antiqu. Judaeorum, lib. 1. cap. 7.
III. Salah, Son of Arphaxad, born in the thirty fifth Year of his Father's age, po≈øt Diluvium 37, lived 433 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2126, po≈øt Diluvium 470.
IV. Eber, or Heber, Son of Salah, born in the thirtieth Year of his Father's age, po≈øt Diluvium 67, lived 464 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2187, po≈øt Diluvium 531.
From him were his Po≈øterity called Hebrews. He had two Sons, Peleg, and Joktan, Gen. 10.

And the Children of Joktan were, Almodad, and Sheleph, and Hazermaveth, and Jerah, and Hadoram, and Uzal, and Diklah, and Obal, and Abimael, and Sheba, and Ophir, and Havilah, and Jobab: And the≈øe inhabited from Me≈øha, to Sephar, a Mount in the Ea≈øt, Gen. 10. ver. 30.

V. Peleg, Son of Eber, born in the thirty fourth Year of his Father's age, po≈øt Diluvium 101, lived 239 Years, and died Anno Mundi 1996, po≈øt Diluvium 340. He died before Noah; and in his days was the Earth divided, Gen. 10.25.
VI. Reu, or Regeu, Son of Peleg, born in the thirtieth Year of his Father's age, po≈øt Diluvium 131, lived 239 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2026, po≈øt Diluvium 370.
VII. Serug, Son of Regeu, born in the thirty ≈øecond Year of his Father's age, po≈øt Diluvium 163, lived 230 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2050, po≈øt Diluvium 394.
VIII. Nahor, Son of Serug, born in the thirtieth Year of his Father's age, po≈øt Diluvium 193, lived 148 Years, and died Anno Mundi 1997. po≈øt Diluvium 341. He died in the Life-time of Noah.
IX. Terah, Son of Nahor, born in the twenty ninth Year of his Father's age, po≈øt Diluvium 222. He lived 205 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2083, in Haran, po≈øt Diluvium 427.

X.
Abraham, Son of Terah, born in the ≈øeventieth Year of his Father's age, po≈øt diluvium 292. He lived 175 Years, and died Anno Mundi 2123, po≈øt Diluvium 467. Gen. 25.7. Abraham had al≈øo by Hagar an Egyptian, the Handmaid of Sarah, a Son called I≈øhmael, born An. Mundi 2034. and died Anno Mundi 2171.
Sarah, fir≈øt Wife of Abraham; Daughter of Haran.
I≈øaac, born Anno Mundi 2049, and died Anno Mundi 2228. ‚Äî
1 E≈øau, the elder twin, born Anno Mund. 2108. He was Father of the Edomites
2 Jacob, the younger Twin, Son of I≈øaac, born An. Mund. 2108. call'd al≈øo I≈ørael, Gen. 35.10. Jacob died aged 130 Years, An. Mundi 2238. Gen. 47.9.
Zilpah concubine to Jacob, and handmaid to Leah.
Gad.
A≈øher.

Dan.
Nephtali.

1 Reuben.
2 Simeon.
3 Levi.
4 Judah; of him David de≈øcended.
5 I≈ø≈øachar.
6 Zabulon.
Dinah, a Daughter, defiled by Sichem, Gen. 34.
Keturah, ≈øecond Wife of Abraham. By Keturah he had I≈ø≈øue Zimran, Jerk≈øhan, Medan, Midian, I≈øhbak, and Shuah, Gen. 25.2.
Nachor, Son of Terah, had to wife Milcah Daughter of Haran.
Reumah, Concubine to Nachor, Gen. 22.24. Nachor had by Reuma the≈øe children, Tebah, and Gaham, and Thaa≈øh, and Maachah, Gen. 22.
1 Huz.
2 Buz.
3 Kemuel, Father of Aram.
4 Che≈øed.
5 Hazo.
6 Pilda≈øh. Gen. 22.22.

8 Bethuel, a Syrian, Gen. 28.5.
Rebekah, Wife of I≈øaac; ≈øhe was Married An. Mundi 2088.
Laban; he lived in Padan Aram, Gen. 28.5. &c. 31.

Jo≈øeph.

And many Sons, Gen. c. 31.

For the Children of all the≈øe, ≈øee Gene≈øis, Chapter 46. See al≈øo Chap. 49. & Lib. 1. Chronicorum, Cap. 1. ad Cap. 10.
So much touching the Po≈øterity of Sem.

div.head: Of the Po≈øterity of Cham, or Ham, younger Son of Noah, Gen. cap. 10.

list.item:
CHam, or Ham, Son of Noah, with his Po≈øterity, inhabited Egypt; P≈øalm 105. ver. 2.3.
1 Cu≈øh.
Seba.
Havila.
Sabta.
Raamah.
Sheba.
Dedan.
Sabtecha.

1 Ludim.
2 Ananim.
3 Lehabim.
4 Naphthuim.
5 Pathru≈øim.
6 Ca≈ølubim, out of whom came Phili≈øtim.
7 Caphtorim.
3 Phut.
4 Canaan, from whom his Po≈øterity were called Canaanites, and the Land Canaan, afterwards called Judaea.

div.p: The≈øe po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed all the Country from Gaza to Egypt. Ludim, Ananim, Lehabim, onely inhabited Lybia. Jo≈øephus de Antiqu. Jud. lib. 1. cap. 7.
Naphthuim, Pathru≈øim, Ca≈ølucim, and Caphtorim, the Ethiopian War overthrew their Cities long time ago, ≈øo that their Country was not known to Jo≈øephus.

Cu≈øh begatThat is, Of Cu≈øh de≈øcended Nimrod.
Nimrod, a mighty man in the Earth: And Nimrod ≈øetled the Confines of his Colony about Babylon. The beginning of his Kingdom was Babel, and Erech, and Accad, and Calneh, in the Land of Shinar. Out of that Land went forth A≈øhur, who builded Nineveh, and Rehoboth, and Cala, and Re≈øen a great City between Nineveh and Cala: Gen. cap. 10. ver. 8, 9, 10, 11, 12.

‚öú This Nimrod was al≈øo called Belus, as ≈øome conjecture. The Tower of Babel was built, and the Confu≈øion of Languages began, Anno Mundi Conditi 1787. ≈øaith I≈øaac≈øon in his Chronology: but others refer it ad Annum 1757, being the Year wherein Peleg was born, in who≈øe days the Earth was divided.

And Canaan begat Sidon his fir≈øt-born, and Heth, and the Jebu≈øite, and the Emorite, and the Girga≈øite, and the Hivite, and the Arkite, and the Sinite, and the Arvadite, and the Zemarite, and the Hamathite: And afterwards were the Families of the Canaanites ≈øpread abroad; and their Borders were from Sidon as thou come≈øt to Gerar, unto Gaza, as thou goe≈øt unto Sodom, and Gomorrah, and Admah, and Zeboim, even unto La≈øhah, Gen. 10.15.
Jo≈øhuah overcame the Canaanites, Anno Mundi 2496; and po≈øt Diluvium 840, he entred into the Land of Canaan.
Sidon, Son of Canaan, builded Sidon a City in Phoenicia.
Of the Hevaeans, Jebu≈øaeans, Chettaeans, Girga≈øenes, Eudaeans, Semaeans, Samarians, are nothing remaining, but their Names in Scripture; for the Hebrews razed down their Cities.

div.head: Of the Po≈øterity of Japhet, Gene≈øis chap. 10.

list.item:
JAphet, Son of Noah, and elde≈øt Son, as mo≈øt Men are of Opinion, had ≈øeven Sons.
1 Gomer.
1 A≈øhkenaz.
2 Riphath.
3 Tagarma.
2 Magog.
3 Madai.
4 Javan.
1 Eli≈øhah.
2 Tar≈øhi≈øh.
3 Kittim.
4 Dodanim.
5 Tubal.
6 Me≈øhech.
7 Tiras.

div.p: By the≈øe were the I≈øles of the Gentiles divided in their Lands, every one after his Tongue, after their Families, in their Nations, Gen. 10.5. So reads the Septuagint: But Junius reads,‚ÄîAb his divi≈øae ≈øunt po≈øte√† Regiones Gentium; By the≈øe were afterwards divided the Countreys of the Nations.

Gomer was the Founder of the Gomarians, the Nations anciently being called after the Names of their fir≈øt Author originally: And from Magog were the People of that Countrey called Magogaei, which the Greeks afterwards named Scythians: Madai gave name to the Madians, whom the Greeks called Medes: From Javan, the Jonians and Greeks took their Original: From Thubal the Theobelians took their Names, afterwards called Iberians: Me≈øhech gave name to the Me≈øchates, ≈øince called Cappadocians: And Tiras gave name to the Thirians, whom the Greeks called Thracians.

So A≈øhkenaz gave name to the A≈øhkenarians, after named Rhegii by the Greeks: Riphath propagated the Riphataeans, afterwards called Paphlagonians: Togarmah propagated the Tygranians, afterwards by the Greeks called Phrygians.

Eli≈øhah, Son of Javan, whom Jo≈øephus calleth Ebi≈øhah, gave name to the Ebizaei, over whom he ruled, afterwards called Aetolians: Thar≈øhi≈øh propagated the Thar≈øi, which was the ancient name of the Cilicians: Chittim obtained the I≈øland Kittim, now called Cyprus: Dodanim is omitted by Jo≈øephus, who mentions but three Sons of Javan.

The≈øe Nations were inhabited by the Po≈øterity of Japhet, who began to make their aboad from the Mountains of Taurus and Amanus, and entred A≈øia even to Tanais, and Europe unto Gades, not before inhabited. Thus Jo≈øepus, lib. 1. de Antiquitate Judaeorum, cap. 7.

Now becau≈øe it is impo≈ø≈øible to trace down exactly the Original of our Nation from the≈øe ≈øo ancient Beginnings,, in regard no ancient Hi≈øtories (which have been hitherto pre≈øerved) have recorded any thing of the≈øe more ancient Ages next following; and what Hi≈øtories are now extant of the more ancient Times, are all very Fabulous, and full of Uncertainties, except what is contained in Holy Scripture, which principally toucheth the Affairs of the Jews; I ≈øhall therefore begin from tho≈øe Times wherein we find more certain Truths recorded by the mo≈øt Authentick Hi≈øtorians, and ≈øo trace them downwards to this day.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: Of the I≈øland, and Name of Brettaine, which Originally comprehended England, Wales, and Scotland.

div.p: I. THe Ancient Geographer writeth thus concerning I≈ølands; ‚Äî „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Cambden's Britannia, ≈øub Titulo Hiberniae in ip≈øo initio: That is, The Indian Taprobane exceeds all I≈ølands in Greatne≈øs and Glory: next after it, Brettaine: the third, that other Briti≈øh I≈øland, Ireland. And hence Ptolomy called Ireland, Little-Bretaine.

Lip≈øius in his Book de Con≈øtanti√¢, lib. 2. cap. 22. (who lived Anno Domini 1600.) gives the Title of In≈øularum maxima unto Cuba in America; where immediately before ≈øpeaking of America, I conceive he onely meaneth Cuba to be the greate≈øt among the American I≈øles; alit√®r errat. And the Oriental Navigators a≈øcribe that Title unto Sumatra, taken for Ptolomy's Taprobane; or to Madaga≈øcar, called al≈øo the I≈øland of Saint Laurence; both which are near to the Equinoctial Line: So Speed on his Map of Great Brettaine and Ireland.

This Brettaine, commonly called Great Brettaine, hath on the Ea≈øt the German Ocean, dividing it from Belgium, Germany, and Denmark: On the We≈øt, Saint Georges Channel, dividing it from Ireland: On the North, the Deucalidonian Ocean: And on the South, the Engli≈øh Channel, dividing it from France. The Length from North to South is reckoned 620 Miles: the greate≈øt Breadth, from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, in a Right Line, no more than 250 of the ≈øame Italian Miles; but by the Crooks and Bendings of the Sea-coa≈øt it extendeth to 320 Miles. It is the greate≈øt I≈øland in the World, except Java, Borneo, Sumatra, and Madaga≈øcar; the three fir≈øt are among the Oriental I≈ølands, Madaga≈øcar among the African. It is ≈øituate under the eighth, ninth, tenth, eleventh, and twelfth Climates; ≈øo that the longe≈øt day at the Lizard-Point in Cornwal (which is the mo≈øt Southern part of it) containeth 16 Hours and a Quarter; and at Barwick, which is now the Border or Limit between England and Scotland, the longe≈øt Day is 17 Hours and three Quarters long, and one Hour more at Straith-by-head in the North of Scotland. where ≈øome ob≈øerve, that there is ≈øcarce any Night at all in the Summer-Sol≈øtice, but a dark Twilight. Thus Dr. Heylyn in his Co≈ømography put out by him in Anno Domini 1660. pag. 293.

Diodorus Siculus (who was Contemporary with Julius Cae≈øar) ≈øaith, Brettaine is the
greate≈øt I≈øland in Europe, lib. 5. pag. 300. which I think will not be denied: And Henry Huntington calleth it In≈øularum nobili≈ø≈øima, lib. 1. Hi≈øtor. ≈øub initio.

There are al≈øo certain le≈ø≈øer I≈ølands di≈øper≈øed in ≈øeveral Parts of the Briti≈øh Sea, adjacent and belonging to Great Brettaine, which were called Briti≈øh I≈øles; as, 1. The Orcades, or I≈øles of Orkney. 2. Schetland. 3. The Hebrides. 4. The I≈øle of Man. 5. The I≈øle of Angle≈øey. 6. The I≈ølands of the Severn-Sea. 7. The Sorlings, or I≈øles of Silley. 8, The I≈øle of Wight. 9. The I≈øle of Thanat. 10. Sunderland. 11. Holy-I≈øland.

The I≈øles of Orkney, Schetland, and the Hebrides, belonged to the Crown of Scotland; the other, to the Crown of England: But were all united in King James, who was the fir≈øt Monarch of Great-Brettaine, being King of Scotland by De≈øcent, and next Heir of Blood to the Crown of England after the death of Queen Elizabeth. He was proclaimed King of England the twenty fourth day of March, which was the la≈øt day of the Year 1602, according to the Computation of the Church of England; who≈øe Style Imperial ran,‚ÄîJacobus, Dei Grati√¢, Magnae Britanniae, Franciae, & Hiberniae Rex.

II. Henry of Huntington ≈øaith, it was fir≈øt called Albion, and afterwards Brettaine: Haec aut√®m In≈øularum nobili≈ø≈øima, cui quondam nomen Albion fuit, po≈øte√† ver√≤ Britannia. lib. 1. Hi≈øt. ≈øub initio. He lived in the Reign of King Stephen, Anno Chri≈øti 1148: So Pit≈øeus, p. 211. And Bede (who died Anno Chri≈øti 734, according to Malmesbury) begins his Hi≈øtory of England thus,‚ÄîBritannia Oceani In≈øula, cui quond√†m Albion nomen fuit. Al≈øo Dr. Heylyn, in his Co≈ømography, p. 295. ≈øaith, The whole I≈øland of Brettaine was fir≈øt called Albion, and afterwards Brettaine: Which name of Brettaine was fir≈øt found in Athenaeus among the Greek Authors, and in Lucretius and Julius Cae≈øar among the Latins; and was retained by Strabo, Pliny, and all other ancient Writers, except Ptolomy onely, by whom it is called Albion, as at fir≈øt: And the name of Brettaine continued till the time of Egbert the fir≈øt Saxon Monarch, who called the Southern part of this I≈øland by the name of England, from the Angli, who with the Juits and Saxons had conquered the ≈øame.

But contrarily, Sir John Pri≈øe (of the race of the Bretans) in his Book de Defen≈øione Hi≈øtoriae Britannicae, Printed at London 1573. p. 55. ≈øaith,‚ÄîEgo ≈øan√® Britanniam pri√πs dictam e≈ø≈øe quam Albion facil√® crediderim. And the rea≈øon whereupon he grounds his Opinion, is the Authority of Cae≈øar, who in his Commentaries always calleth it Britain, but never Albion; and that from this more Noble I≈øland, all the re≈øt of the le≈ø≈øer I≈øles adjacent, as appurtenant unto this, were al≈øo called In≈øulae Britannicae; which out of Pliny, Ptolomy, and other Authors, is manife≈øt: And then began this Brettaine to be called Albion, in di≈øtinction from the re≈øt. And he addeth the Authority of Pliny, (who lived about 80 Years after Chri≈øt) lib. 4. Naturalis Hi≈øtoriae, cap. 16. in ip≈øi≈ø≈øimis verbis; ‚ÄîAlbion ip≈øi nomen fuit, c√πm Britanniae vocarentur omnes. And herewith agreeth Learned Cambden in his Britannia, pag. 17. of the Edition Printed at London 1607. with Maps at large; who conceiveth that the Grecians gave it the name of Albion fabulou≈øly, from Albion Son of Neptune, for di≈øtinction ≈øake: For Neptune being the God of the Sea, and this an I≈øland of the Sea, they might term it by the name of Neptune's Son, in allu≈øion. But Buchanan, lib. 1. Hi≈øt. Scot. pa. 12, 13, ≈øaith, That Alpum and Album were anciently u≈øed for a Hill or Mountain; and that the Alpes were ≈øo called ab Altitudine, non Albedine; and that he thinketh our Brettaine was called Albion from the ri≈øing Shore and Hills, which on the Narrow Seas, between Ireland and our Brettaine, do appear in ≈øight; Ireland ≈øeeming low and level, and Brettaine ri≈øing up into Mountains: Which word Album in that ≈øence is common to many Nations, whereof he alledgeth many In≈øtances.
Neither doth Bede ≈øay that it was called Albion before it was called Brettaine; but that it was formerly called Albion: So that the name of Albion may ≈øeem to have been left off in Bede's time.

And whereas Heylyn affirms in his Co≈ømography, in the Place before-quoted, That the name of Brettaine was fir≈øt found in Athenaeus among the Greek Writers; It is certain, that we often find it mentioned in Diodorus Siculus, lib. 4. Bibliothecae Hi≈øtoricae, pa. 300, 301. where he writeth thus, ‚Äî „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ That is, There are many I≈ølands [in Europe] in the Ocean, whereof the greate≈øt is called Brettaine: This anciently was untouched, without the intermixture of any Foreign Force (for we never heard that either Bacchus, or Hercules, or any other of the Worthies, ever warred or fought again≈øt it) but our Caius Cae≈øar, who for his Actions was termed a God, was the fir≈øt (of all we find mentioned) who ≈øubdued this I≈øland, and fighting again≈øt it, compelled the Brettans to pay Tribute.
So that we ≈øee Diodorus was Contemporary with Caius Julius Cae≈øar, who fir≈øt attempted Brettain 55 Years before the Birth of Chri≈øt, according to the Computation commonly received.

Now Athenaeus the Hi≈øtorian lived about Anno Chri≈øti 166, ≈øomewhat after Ptolomy the Geographer; and both of them after Strabo, who died Anno Chri≈øti 25, as Helvicus computes in his Chronology: And therefore Athenaeus could not be the fir≈øt Greek Writer who mentioned Brettaine, unle≈øs there be ≈øome other Athenaeus whom Heylyn meaneth.

And if that Book de Mundo be Ari≈øtotle's, which is commonly bound up among the Works of Ari≈øtotle, then have we the name of Brettaine, and Albion too, more anciently than of any before-mentioned: For Ari≈øtotle was Tutor to Alexander the Great, and died the third Year of 114 Olympiad, 320 Years before Chri≈øt was born, at the age of 63 Years.

In which Book de Mundo, cap. 3. we read,‚Äî „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . i. e. In that Ocean are two great I≈ølands, called Briti≈øh I≈ølands, Albion, and Ireland, greater than tho≈øe before-mentioned, lying beyond the Celtae, People of Gallia. But this Book de Mundo (≈øaith Learned Cambden in his Britannia, pag. 64.) is of much later ≈øtamp than the Age wherein Ari≈øtotle lived, as the mo≈øt Learned have judged. Indeed Duvall, in his Synop≈øis on Ari≈øtotle, Tom. 1. pag. 171.In the beginning of the fir≈øt Tome before Ari≈øtotle. tells us, That Ju≈øtin Martyr Believed that Book to be Ari≈øtotles: Yet (≈øaith Duvall) it is not; as the Rea≈øon of the Doctrine, and the laxity of the Style do demon≈øtrate; being rather decked with Words of an Hi≈øtorian, or „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ratour, than a Philo≈øopher.

III. Now this Brettaine was not known to the Ancient Romans before Julius Cae≈øar's time, ≈øaith Bede de Hi≈øtori√¢ Gentis Anglorum, lib. 1. cap. 2. and by con≈øequence never Invaded by any of them, before Cae≈øar: And Cae≈øar him≈øelf,Cae≈øar de Bello Gallico, lib. 5. with his Powerful Army of the formidable Romans, was beaten back by the ≈øtout Brettans upon his fir≈øt Attempt of the I≈øland, Ca≈ø≈øibelaun being then General of the Brettans, and Commander in Chief. And Cae≈øar returning into Italy, and recruiting his Army, coming again into Brettaine the ≈øecond time, was in the fir≈øt Encounter beaten again by the Brettans; but in a ≈øecond Battel the Romans routed the Brettans, and the ≈øtrong City of the Trinobantes (which is now called London) yielded them≈øelves and their City to Cae≈øar, with Androgorius their Governor; after which Example, many other Cities al≈øo ≈øubmitted, and yielded up their Towns to the Romans: But the Town of Ca≈ø≈øibelaun, Cae≈øar took by Storm, Cae≈øar, lib. 5. pag. 163, 164. ≈øaith Bede in the ≈øame Chapter; which Town is now called St. Albans: And Cae≈øar appointing what Tribute they ≈øhould pay, returned back with his Army.

Wherefore ≈øince the name of Brettaine is nowhere to be found, either among the Greek or Latin Writers, before Cae≈øar, but was till that time unknown both to the Grecians and Romans, as Learned Cambden is of Opinion, in his Britannia, pag. 24, 25. and al≈øo Sheringham de Gentis Anglorum Origine, pag. 99. we can expect no certain Hi≈øtory of the Brettans, but from Cae≈øar downwards: For Gildas, ≈øirnamed Sapiens, is the fir≈øt Brettan that I meet withal, who hath left us any mention in writing of the Affairs of Brettaine, and that but little al≈øo: yet what he writ (as he confe≈ø≈øeth in his Prologue) was more by relation of others from beyond Sea, than from any Writings or Records
in his own Country; for if any ≈øuch were, they were either burnt by the Enemies rage, or carried away by the Bani≈øhed Natives; ≈øo that in his time none did appear: and he was born in the forty fourth Year after the Engli≈øh-Saxons came into Brettain, as he him≈øelf ≈øaith in his Book de Excidio Britanniae, reprinted at London 1568. fol. 23. and died in the Mona≈øtery of Bangor in Wales, aged 90 Years, buried the fourth of the Calends of February, about the Year of Chri≈øt 583. as Pit≈øeus ≈øaith in his Book de Illu≈øtribus Britanniae Scriptoribus.

IV. As to the name of Brettaine, the Ancient Greek Writers do con≈øtantly write it „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Brettania; not Britannia, as Cae≈øar writes it: Howbeit Cambden thinks it more truly writ by Cae≈øar than by the Greeks; but of that I make great doubt; for from the Grecians doubtles was the name of Brettaine fir≈øt impo≈øed.

„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øeems to be derived from the two Greek Words „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øignifying an Image or Picture, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , in the old Glo≈ø≈øary betokening a Region or Country: So that Brettaine ≈øoundeth as much as‚ÄîThe Country of a People painting them≈øelves with Images and Pictures: For the Ancient Brettans u≈øed to paint their Bodies with various Pictures of all manner of Living Creatures, as appears by ≈øundry good Authors Pomponius Mela, l. 3. c. 6. Cae≈øar de Bello Gall. lib. 5. pag. 159.; and you may ≈øee them quoted by Cambden in his Britannia, pag. 19. Onely let me tell you here, how Cambden fetcheth the name from two Languages; (Brith) which in the Briti≈øh Language (≈øaith he) ≈øignifies Painted
Davyes his Wel≈øh Dictionary. or Coloured; and Tania, which with the Greeks ≈øignifies a Region, pag. 20. Whereof there is no nece≈ø≈øity, ≈øince the Greek Language doth clearly bear both the Words: and we may ob≈øerve how their Druids (who were Learned Men, and Philo≈øophers) did anciently di≈øciplinate the Brettans in the Greek Tongue before Cae≈øar's time, as Cae≈øar him≈øelf doth witne≈øs, lib. 6. de Bello Gallico, p. 212. And many Greek words are retained in the ancient Briti≈øh Language, as Sheringham, de Gentis Anglorum Origine, pag. 99. doth ≈øhew; and al≈øo Cambden, in his Britannia, pag. 21. of the Edition Printed 1607. And ≈øo po≈ø≈øibly the Word (Brith) corruptly for Breth, might be by them retained from the Greeks.

Nor doth it ≈øeem rea≈øonable that the Brettans gave this Name to them≈øelves; neither at this day do they call them≈øelves Brettans in their own Language, but Kumeri: Wherefore the Grecians gave them the name of Brettans from their Painted and Carved Bodies.

However, the Fabulous Story of Brute (which many Authors ≈øeek to defend, and thence would fetch the name of the Brettans Originally) I conceive ought to be utterly exploded: Nor can any wi≈øe and learned Man, who is ver≈øed in Antiquity, ever believe for truth tho≈øe many Kings mu≈øtered up by Geoffrey of Monmouth, in ≈øo ancient Ages; who lived him≈øelf but in the days of King Henry the Second, and was by William of Newbery, in the Preface of his Book, (a Man who lived in that very Age with Geffrey) taxed for a fabulous lying Author; his words are the≈øe: Porr√≤ ad ea, quae vel ant√® eum, vel in diebus ejus evenerunt, talit√®r ≈øua, quod utiqu√® facil√® poterat, temperavit figmenta, ut congruam po≈ø≈øent interpretationem recipere: Praetere√† in libro ≈øuo, quem Britonum Hi≈øtoriam vocat, qu√†m petulant√®r & impudent√®r fer√® per omnia mentiatur, nemo ni≈øi veterum Hi≈øtoriarum ignarus, c√πm in librum illum incidit, ambigere ≈øinitur: That is, Moreover, as to tho≈øe things which hapned either before him, or in his days, he ≈øo tempered his Lies, (which he knew very well how to do) that they might receive a congruous Interpretation: And furthermore, in his Book which he calleth The Hi≈øtory of the Britans, how frowardly and impudently he lieth almo≈øt in all things, none but he that is ignorant of the Ancient Hi≈øtories, when he falls upon that Book, may be ≈øuffered to doubt.

V. As to the ancient Inhabitants of Brettaine, Cambden conceiveth they were originally ≈øprung from Gomer the elde≈øt Son of Japhet, Son of Noah, in his Britannia, pag. 7. For ask we any of the Brettans of Wales (who are the Remnant of our Ancient Brettans) how they call them≈øelves, they tell us Kumero, or Kumroh, and in the Plural Number Kumeri; a Briti≈øh Woman, Kumeraes; and the Briti≈øh Tongue, Kumeraeg: as we ≈øhould ≈øay, a Kumerite, or Gumerite, as ≈øprung from Gomer. For Jo≈øephus ≈øaith, lib. 1. de Antiqu. Judaeorum, cap. 7. That the Po≈øterity of Gomer were called Gomari. And the≈øe (≈øaith Cambden) were formed ≈øometimes into Gomoraei, and Gomeritae, and afterwards
into Cymerii, then to Cimbri, and afterwards into Cambri; whence we call a Wel≈øhman, Cambro-Britannus: And the≈øe Cimbri did not onely plant Germany, but the ancient Gallia likewi≈øe, and this part of the World: And from the≈øe Galli, or Gaules, it is mo≈øt probable our Brettaine was fir≈øt planted, it being an I≈øland next adjacent to the Gauls: And from Galli, the French word Galles, and the Bretton's Gales, and the Saxon Wales, are all derived: For our Saxon Ance≈øtors did u≈øually in their Pronunciation and Dialect turn G into W, as we ≈øee in many other of their Words, as Warre for Guerre, Ward for Gard, &c. And ≈øince the≈øe Ancient Galles in France, who planted Brettaine, were originally called Cimbri, and Cimmerii, they could have no better a Di≈øtinction than by the Painting and Carving of their Bodies; whence this I≈øland gained the name of Brettaine. So Cambden, ibid. pag. 19.

But Sheringham, de Gentis Anglorum Origine, pag. 51. will not allow the Cimmerii to come from Gomer; which he ≈øeems to prove by good Authorities; for that the Grecians impo≈øed that name on the People of Moeotia, long time after the death of Gomer, yet very ancient too: For that Kimmerii, or Cimmerii,
Sheringham, pag. 425. is a word framed out of the Greek Tongue, and not from the Hebrew, as the ancient Greek Writers do affirm; and that the Kimmerians were Scythians originally, and therefore ≈øhould rather be de≈øcended from Magog (the ≈øecond Son of Japhet, and not from Gomer) who were anciently called Magogaei: Jo≈øephus lib. 1. de Antiq. Jud. cap. 7. But the Getae (expelling tho≈øe Scythians called Magogaei originally, but at this day called Turks and Tartars) were al≈øo called Scythians, after they had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of Scythia: And that the≈øe Getes,
Sheringham, p. 42,, & 424. after called Scythians, were the Progeny of Hul or Chul, Son of Aram, Son of Sem, whom Pliny calleth Aramaei originally, lib. 6. Natur. Hi≈øt. cap. 17. The≈øe Getae-Scythici were called al≈øo Ma≈ø≈øagetae before they came into Scandia.

The name of Kimmerii was frequent in the time of Herodotus, who lived about 440 Years before Chri≈øt, Anno Mundi 3508. which name is very ancient. They were called Cerberii, before Cimmerii; and their City called Cerberium, before it was called Cimmerium: Pliny lib. 6. cap. 6. Sheringham pag. 50.

Afterwards the≈øe Kimmerii, or Cimmerii, were called Cimbri, or Kimbri. Vide Plutarchum, Tom. 2. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , pag. 75 ‚Ä¢ . Diod Siculus, lib 5. pa. 309. Cimmerii were called Cimbri by the Graecians: Strabo, li. 7 p. 293. D. The name of Cimbri was fir≈øt known to the Romans, Anno Urbis Conditae 640. ant√® Chri≈øtum Natum 110. which in the Language of the Ancient Gauls (≈øcilicet, Lingu√¢ Gallic√¢) ≈øignifies Robbers, or Stout Warriers: Thy≈øius upon Ju≈øtin, pag. 391. And all tho≈øe People, whom the Romans generally called Cimbri, part of them the Germans called Saxons, Sheringham, pag. 46. Quamvis en√¨m Saxones ant√® Ptolomaeum, ≈øolo Cimbrorum nomine √† Graecis & Romanis ≈øcriptoribus appellantur; initio igitur Saxones pars tant√πm Cimbrorum fuerunt: Reliquis autem Cimbris ab ei≈ødem Caecis vict√≠≈øque, aut fact√¢ Deditione in amicitiam receptis, Omnes mutato nomine Saxones dici coeperint: atque it√† Cimbrorum nomen paulat√¨m exolevit. Sheringham, pag. 47.
So the Cambro-Brettan's name ≈øeems rather to ≈øavor of the Kimmerii, than of the Gomari. The Town Cimmerium was ≈øituate in Taurica-Cher≈øone≈øo, near the Sea called Bo≈øphorus.

After the Eruptions and Tran≈ømigrations of the≈øe Cimerii, afterwards called Cimbri, Diodorus Siculus tells us, lib. 5. pag. 308. (who lived in the time of Julius Cae≈øar, a little before the Birth of Chri≈øt) tho≈øe who po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the inward parts above Ma≈ø≈øilia, and inhabited about the Alpes, and on that ≈øide the Pyrenaean Mountains, were called Celtae; and tho≈øe who inhabited that Celtica toward the South Parts, and the Sea, and the Hercynian Mountain, and all tho≈øe People ≈øcattered even to Scythia, were called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that is, Galli, or Gaules: But the Romans called all the≈øe Nations by the name of Galli onely. See al≈øo Stephanus his Latin Dictionary, voces Celtae, and Galli.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
graece;
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ So Suidas, and He≈øychius.

But I am of Opinion, That no Nation at this day is ≈øo entire, by rea≈øon of continual Warrs one with another ≈øince the fir≈øt Plantation of the World after the Flood, and the infinite intermingling one with another occa≈øioned thereby, and expelling one another out of their own ancient Countrys over and over again, in ≈øo long Tract of Time, can be properly ≈øaid to be de≈øcended from any one of
the Sons of Noah entirely; but rather from them all, by rea≈øon of a univer≈øal Commixture of their Po≈øterities at this day.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the Time when the Romans fir≈øt attempted Brettaine, and how long it remained under the Roman Servitude,

div.p: I. Cae≈øar's fir≈øt Attempt upon Brettaine was 55 Years before the Birth of Chri≈øt, according to the vulgar Computation, which falls in An. Mundi Conditi 3895. Cae≈øar de Bello Gallico, lib. 4. & 5. tells us, His fir≈øt Expedition into Brettaine was when M. Cra≈ø≈øus and Cneius Pompeius were Con≈øuls; which was Anno Urbis Conditae 699. & Anno Mundi 3895. & ant√® Chri≈øtum 55. But Cae≈øar did not ≈øubdue Brettaine, ≈øo as to make it Tributary, till his ≈øecond Expedition into this I≈øland, and that was the Year following; and at this ≈øecond coming, the ≈øtrong City of the Trinobants (now called London) yielded them≈øelves, and ≈øubmitted to the Romans, as not able to ≈øu≈øtain their Force; and ≈øoon after al≈øo many other Towns ≈øubmitted: And ≈øo Cae≈øar having received Pledges from Ca≈ø≈øibelan for his Submi≈ø≈øion to the Government of the Romans, and appointed what Tribute yearly Brettain ≈øhould pay, departed out of Brettaine. Cae≈øar lib. 5. pag. 164. The Tribute impo≈øed on the Brettains was 3000 l. yearly, if we may believe Speed in his Hi≈øtory at large, pag. 187. a. al≈øo Ponticus Virunnius, pag. 25. out of the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory.

Now the City of Rome being taken by Alaricus King of the Gothes, Anno Chri≈øti 410. the Roman Empire began to decline: Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. lib. 1. cap. 11. So as the Rule and Sovereignty of the Romans over Brettaine continued almo≈øt 470 Years from the fir≈øt coming of Caius Julius Cae≈øar into this I≈øland, as Bede him≈øelf computeth in the ≈øame Chapter: But Cambden ≈øaith, it continued 476 Years, computing to the time of Valentinian the Third, in his Britannia Printed 1607. pag. 60.
