Cambden ≈øuppo≈øeth the≈øe to be ≈øeated about Che≈øter, in his Britannia, Tit. Che≈øhire.

div.p: Brettaine, being made a Member of the Roman Empire, was at fir≈øt divided into three Provinces onely; viz.

1. Britannia Prima: So called, becau≈øe it was fir≈øt ≈øubdued; comprehending the Counties on the South ≈øide of the River Thames, and tho≈øe inhabited by the Trinobantes, Iceni, and Cattieuchlani: The chief City, London.
2. Britannia Secunda; compri≈øing all the Countries on the further ≈øide of the River Severn; who≈øe chief Seat was Caer-leon upon Usk in the County of Monmouth.
3. Maxima Cae≈øarien≈øis; including all the re≈øt to the Northern Border; whereof the Metropolis was York.
And in this ≈øtate it ≈øtood till the time of Con≈øtantine, who made two more out of the former; to wit,
4. Valentia; containing all the Country from the Frith of Solway, and the Picts Wall in Cumberland, to the Friths of Edenburough and Dunbritton Northward.

5. Flavia Cae≈øarien≈øis; comprehending all between the Rivers of Thames and Humber: The re≈øt between Humber and the Bounds of Valentia, continuing under the old name of Maxima Cae≈øarien≈øis, though now made le≈øs than any of the other four: So Dr. Heylyn in his Co≈ømography, pag. 309. Maginus upon Ptolomy, Pars ≈øecunda, pag. 39.

The Forces which the Romans kept in continual Pay in Brettaine, as well to keep their Coa≈øts and Frontiers again≈øt the Enemy, as to keep the Brettans in obedience, amounted in all (if Pancirol be not mi≈øtaken in the Account) unto 23000 Foot, and 2000 Hor≈øe; three Legions keeping here their con≈øtant and continual Re≈øidence: that is to ≈øay, The ≈øixth Legion, Sirnamed Victrix, at York; the twentieth Legion, Victrix, at We≈øtche≈øter; the ≈øecond Legion, ≈øometimes at I≈øca Dannioniorum, now called Exceter, and ≈øometimes at I≈øca Silurum, now Caer-leon, upon Usk: But this was about the time of Claudius the Emperor, or later under Ve≈øpatian.

div.head: Romani in Britannia.
div.p:
‚öú CAius Julius Cae≈øar landed his Army in Kent, at Dover: Montanus in his Commentary on Cae≈øar de Bello Gallico, li. 4. p. 135. This was about 55 Years before Chri≈øt was born, according to our common Computation of his Birth. Paulus Oro≈øius, lib 6. c. 9. In his fir≈øt Encounter he was beaten by the Brettans, ibid. pag. 137. but Landing more Men in Longboats, he put the Brettans to flight: Then the Brettans ≈øent Emba≈ø≈øadors for a Peace. Not long after, the Brettans fell upon the Romans, and di≈øordered them, under≈øtanding the Romans were di≈øtre≈ø≈øed for want of Provi≈øion; and after that, in another Battel, they
were routed, and ≈øore pur≈øued by the Romans: And after this, about September, Cae≈øar in the night having landed more Men, the Brettans gather together about ≈øix thou≈øand Men, and enclo≈øe the Enemy round, and wor≈øted the Romans. Thus out of Cae≈øar him≈øelf, lib. 4. we find Fortune various in her Victories: Labienus being then Chief Commander under Cae≈øar, and Ca≈ø≈øibelaun General of the Brettans. And this was the effect of the fir≈øt Expedition of Cae≈øar, who ≈øetling the Winter-Quarters of his Soldiers in Belgis, that is, in Hant≈øhire, Wilt≈øhire, and Somer≈øet≈øhire; and having received Pledges onely from two Cities of Brettaine, in order to a Peace, (for the re≈øt would ≈øend no Pledges) Cae≈øar went into Italy: Lib. 4. de Bello Gallico, in ip≈øo fine.

Cae≈øar departed out of his Winter-Quarters into Italy, Lucius Domitius and Appian Claudius being Con≈øuls, commanding his Deputies over his Legions in Brettaine, that they make as many new Ships as they can that Winter, and repair the old ones; Lib. 5. de Bello Gallico, in ip≈øo initio. Now the≈øe were Con≈øuls of Rome, Anno Urbis Conditae 700, ≈øaith Montanus: But Helvicus placeth their Con≈øul≈øhip Anno Urbis Romae Conditae 699, Ann√≥que Mundi 3896, & ant√® Chri≈øtum Natum, quo√†d Vulgarem Computationem, 54.

The next Summer Cae≈øar returned again into Brettaine: Mandubratius King of the Trinobants (Son of Imanuentius) with their chief Town, now called London, ≈øubmitted to the Romans. Cae≈øar demanded forty Pledges, and Corn for his Army, which were forthwith ≈øent him by the Trinobants: After which Example, many others ≈øubmitted al≈øo. Cae≈øar a≈ø≈øaulted the Town of Ca≈ø≈øibelaun, now called St. Albons, and takes it: The Brettans not enduring the Storm long, ran away out of the Town at another part thereof, and many of them were taken and ≈ølain as they fled. But the la≈øt great Battel between the Brettans and the Romans was a little before, when the Romans were bu≈øied in fortifying of their Tents and Holds, the Brettans entring forth of the Woods, (where they u≈øed to ≈øculk) fell upon them, and ≈øharply a≈ø≈øaulted the Romans; and that day was ≈ølain Q. Laberius Durus Tribunus militum: And the day following the Brettans ≈øhewing them≈øelves on Hills not far from the Roman Tents, provoked the Romans to Battel; but at Noon, when Cae≈øar had ≈øent three Legions, and all his Hor≈øe, with Caius Trebonius his Lieutenant, to bait, ≈øuddenly the Brettans fell upon them on all ≈øides as they baited; but the Romans killed a great number of them, ≈øo as the Brettans could not get together, nor ≈øtand together, nor had liberty of leaping out of their ChariotsEx E≈ø≈øedis. to fight: And upon this Flight, their Auxilliaries (which were met on every ≈øide) went away: Neither after this time did the Brettans ever encounter the Romans with their chief Forces; Lib. 5. de Bello Gallico, pag. 160. & deinceps ad pag. 165. And after the taking of St. Albons, as is before-mentioned, Ca≈ø≈øibelaun, by means of Comius the Atrebatian, ≈øends Emba≈ø≈øadors to Cae≈øar, concerning his ≈øubmitting to the Romans. Cae≈øar demands Pledges, and appoints what Tribute ≈øhould be paid yearly to the People of Rome from Brettaine, and chargeth Ca≈ø≈øibelaun that he do no harm to Mandubratius, nor to the Trinobants: And ≈øo having received Pledges, Cae≈øar carries back his Army to the Sea, and departed out of Brettaine: Cae≈øar de Bello Gallico, lib. 5. pag. 164. of the Edition Printed at Leyden, with Montanus Notes, 1651. Nor do I read that Cae≈øar came again into Brettaine ever after.
div.q: Divus Julius Cae≈øar c√πm Exercitu Britanniam ingre≈ø≈øus, Quanqu√†m Pro≈øper√¢ Pugn√¢ terruerit incolas, ac littore potitus ≈øit, pote≈øt videri [Britanniam] o≈øtendi≈ø≈øe Po≈øteris, non tradidi≈ø≈øe. Cornelius Tacitus de Vita Agricolae, cap. 13.
div.p: And by and by Civil Wars growing, and ≈øeveral Princes rebelling again≈øt the Roman State, Brettaine remained in Peace, as forgotten by the Romans, (Schidius upon Suetonius Tranquillus, Printed 1656. pag. 36.) until the time of the Emperour Claudius.

div.head: Propraetores ceu Legati Romanorum in Brettania.
div.p: 1. AUlus Plautius, Lieutenant of Brettaine under the Con≈øuls of Rome, An. Chr. nati. 43. was in the time of Claudius the Emperor ≈øent with Forces into Brettaine; and ≈øoon after came Claudius him≈øelf into Brettaine, and took Maldon in E≈ø≈øex, the Palace of Cunobelin. Plautius overcame Caratacus, and after Togodunus, in Battel, two Sons of Cunobelin, after their Father's death: Cambden's Britannia, pag. 30. Brettaine being attempted by none before, ≈øince Julius Cae≈øar: So that before the time of Claudius, Brettaine was not perfectly ≈øubdued. Ve≈øpatian the Father (before he was Emperour) was ≈øent by Claudius Legate of a Legion into Germany, and thence tran≈ølated into Brettaine, where he had thirty Conflicts or Skirmi≈øhes with the Brettans, and ≈øubdued two ≈øtrong Nations, and had above twenty Towns, and the I≈øle of Wight ≈øurrendred to him, partly by the Conduct of Aulus Plautius Con≈øularis Legati, and partly by the Conduct of Claudius him≈øelf: Suetonius with Schildius Comment, pag. 734.

2. Publius O≈øtorius Scapula, Propraetor, Lieutenant of Brettaine, ≈øubdued the Commotions of the Iceni, Cangi, Brigantes, Silures, and Ordovices: Al≈øo he took Caractacus King of the Silures Pri≈øoner, with his Wife and Children.
Some Cities were given to Cogidunus, by an ancient Cu≈øtom of the Romans, that they might have even Kings In≈øtruments of Servitude: Tacitus de Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 14. & Annalium, lib. 12. cap. 33.
3. A. Didius Gallus, Propraetor, on the death of O≈øtorius, was made Lieutenant of Brettaine: Tacitus lib. 12. Annalium, cap. 39.
4. Verannius, Succe≈ø≈øor to Didius, died in Brettaine within a Year: Tacitus de Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 14.

5. Paulinus Suetonius, Propraetor: He took the I≈øle of Angle≈øey in Wales:
I≈øaac ≈øon's Chronology: Cornelius Tacitus lib. 14. Annalium, cap. 29. Pra≈øutagus King of the Iceni dying, made Nero his Heir; but the Romans ≈øpoil'd the Iceni, and did beat Boadicia Widow of Pra≈øutagus, and deflowred both her and her Daughter: Tacitus ibidem, cap. 31. biennio res Pro≈øperas habuit. Tacitus de Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 14.

6. Petronius Turpilianus ≈øucceeded Suetonius: Tacitus lib. 14. Annal. cap. 39. in the time of Nero the Emperor. The words of Tacitus are,‚ÄîDetent√∫≈øque rebus gerundis Suetonius tradere Exercitum Petronio Turpiliano, qui jam Con≈øulatu ab√Æerat, jubetur. Now Suetonius was Con≈øul Anno Chri≈øti 66.
Et Tacitus de Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 16.‚ÄîPetronius Turpilianus, Compo≈øitis Prioribus, nihil ultr√† au≈øus, Trebellio Maximo Provinciam tradidit.
7. Trebellius Maximus, Lieutenant of Brettaine in the time of Nero: Tacitus ut ≈øupr√†.
8. Vectius Bolanus, Lieutenant in the time of Vitellius: Stow's Annals.

9. Petilius Cerialis, ≈øub Ve≈øpatiano Imperatore, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed a great part of the Province of the Brigantes in Brettaine, aut Victori√¢ aut Bello: Tacitus de Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 17. al≈øo I≈øaac≈øon in his Chronology.
10. Julius Frontinus, in the time of Ve≈øpatian ≈øubdued the valiant Nation of the Silures in Brettaine by force of Arms: Tacitus de Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 17. al≈øo I≈øaac≈øon.

11. Julius Agricola, in the time of Titus Ve≈øpa≈øian and Domitian: He perfecteth the Conque≈øt of North-Wales and Angle≈øey, Anno Chri≈øti 78. I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology. Tacitus de Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 18. & deinceps. The Brettans making Head under Galgacus (King of the Caledonians in Brettaine, ≈øaith Cambden's Britannia, pag. 702.) were defeated by Agricola, and lo≈øt ten thou≈øand Men, Anno Chri≈øti 86. I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology: al≈øo Tacitus de Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 27. & deinceps; & cap. 37, & 38. and is rewarded by Domitian, who gave him the Province of Syria. Tacitus ibidem, cap. 40.
‚öú Sub Anno Chri≈øti 88. Brettaine was reduced into a Province, at the Emperour Domitian's ≈øole di≈øpo≈øe, and not at the Senators, as other Provinces were. I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology.

12. Salu≈øtius Lucullus, ≈øent Lieutenant into Brettaine, and in Anno Chri≈øti 92. was put to
death by Domitian, becau≈øe he made new kind of Lances, and called them Lucullians: Cambden's Britannia, pag. 43. About this time flouri≈øhed Arviragus in Brettaine; and al≈øo at Rome flouri≈øhed Claudia Ruffina a Briti≈øh Woman, whom ≈øome think to be the ≈øame with her whom the Apo≈øtle mentioneth, 2 Tim. 4. ver. 21. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 43.
An Chr. nati.‚öú What Lieutenants were under Nerva and Trajan, I find not.
13. Cneius Trebellius, ≈øent into Brettaine under Adrian the Emperour, as I≈øaac≈øon placeth it in his Chronology. His Soldiers mutiny, and the Brettans rebel.

14. Julius Severus, Lieutenant of Brettaine under Adrian; Cambden's Britannia, pag. 45. who being recalled to quell the rebellious Jews, Adrian went him≈øelf into Brettaine, and erected a Turf-wall, or Mud-wall, from the River Eden in Cumberland, to Tine in Northumberland, as a Limit of the Roman Confines, and reduced the Brettans to Obedience, Anno Chri≈øti 124. as Cambden in his Britannia placeth it, pag. 45. and I≈øaac≈øon in his Chronology.
15. Cl. Pri≈øcus Licinius, Propraetor Brettaniae ≈øub Adriano: He was with Adrian in his Expedition again≈øt the Jews: Cambden's Britannia, pag. 46.

16. Lollius Urbicus, Propraetor ≈øub Antonino Pio; and Sejus Saturnius was Archigubernus ex Cla≈ø≈øe Brettanic√¢: Cambden's Britannia, pag. 46. Lollius re≈øtrained the barbarous Scots and Picts, by making another Mud-wall further upon them, called Murus Brettanicus.
17. Calphurnius Agricola, ≈øub Antonino Philo≈øopho Imperatore: And Helvius Pertinax Warred then in Brettaine, ≈øent hither from the Parthian War.

18. Ulpius Marcellus, Propraetor under Commodus the Emperor: But he being recalled, Helvius Pertinax was ≈øent Propraetor, who appea≈øed the tumultuous Soldiers in Brettaine, but was ≈øore wounded: Cambden's Britannia, pag. 46, 47.
19. Helvius Pertinax ≈øent into Brettaine by Commodus: His Soldiers mutiny. I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology.

20. Clodius Albinus: He received Brettaine quieted, under Commodus; and for his brave Acts done in Brettaine, obtained the name of Cae≈øar: But becau≈øe he had more freely impeached the Government of the Emperors in an Oration, Severus was ≈øent to ≈øucceed in Brettaine: Cambden's Britannia, pag. 47. and I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology.

21. Junius Severus ≈øucceeded Clodius Albinus: But Commodus the Emperor being ≈ølain Anno Chri≈øti 193. Pertinax was made Emperor: And Pertinax, after he had reigned 87 days, was ≈ølain by the Soldiers: And then Didius Julianus was Emperor 66 days, ≈ølain al≈øo by the Soldiers: And then Pe≈øcennius Niger a≈ø≈øumed the Goverment in Syria, Clodius Albinus in Brettaine, and Septimius Severus in Pannonia, all at a time: Cambden's Britannia, pag. 48. Helvici Chronologia, ≈øub Anno 193.
22. Clodius Albinus, ≈øent back again into Brettaine by Pertinax: But Pertinax being ≈ølain, Albinus a≈ø≈øumes the Government of Brettaine.

23. Septimius Severus being now Emperor, and Albinus ≈ølain in Battel near Lyons in France, ≈øends Heraclianus into Brettaine, ≈øub Anno 198. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 48. and I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology.

24. Virius Lupus, Propraetor, or Lieutenant of Brettaine, ≈øucceeded Heraclianus, Anno Chri≈øti 199: I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology. He ≈øends for Septimius Severus the Emperor, who came into Brettaine above ≈øixty Years old, with his two Sons, Anno Chri≈øti 206. I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology. The Brettans de≈øire Peace, he refu≈øeth to grant it: He cuts down Woods in Brettaine, which were a ≈øhelter to the Brettans: He a≈ø≈øumed the Sirname of Brettanicus Maximus, and his Son Geta was ≈øtiled Brettanicus. He waged no War, yet lo≈øt 50000 Men by Treachery and Di≈øea≈øes. He made a Wall in the North of England, cro≈øs the I≈øland, from Sea to Sea; and ≈øtamped Money, with the≈øe Words thereon,‚ÄîVictoria Britannica. He died at York in Brettaine, 4 die Februarii, Anno Chri≈øti 210. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 48, 49. and Helvicus in his Chronology: not ≈øo much by the di≈øtemper of his Body, as of his Mind, for the di≈ø≈øolute Cour≈øes of his Son Ba≈ø≈øian, whom he called Antonine; and dying, is ≈øaid to expire in the≈øe words,‚ÄîTurbatam Rempublicam ub√≠que accepi, Pacatam eti√†m Britannis relinquo.
25. Antoninus Ba≈ø≈øianus, Son of Severus, and called Caracalla, An. Chr. nati. 211. is ≈øaid to pro≈øecute the reliques of the War in Brettaine a little while; but he quickly made a Peace.
Here the Writers have pa≈ø≈øed over the Affairs of Brettaine with long ≈øilence.
26. Nonius Philippus was Lieutenant or Propraetor of Brettaine under Gordianus the Younger, as appeareth by an Ancient Stone, ≈øaith Cambden in his Britannia, pag. 50.

Under Gallien the Emperor, who began his Reign Anno Chri≈øti 260, there aro≈øe 30 Tyrants, who in ≈øeveral Places a≈ø≈øumed the Rule to them≈øelves; among whom, Marius u≈øurped the Government in Brettaine, with Lollianus, Victorinus, Po≈øthumus, and Tetricus. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 50.
Under Aurelian, Bono≈øus the Great Drinker, by De≈øcent a Brettan, invaded the Empire with Proculus; but being overcome by Probus, was hanged. Cambden ibid.

27. Probus found new Troubles in Brettaine: He brought hither Burgundians and Vandals, whom he had ≈øubdued, and granted them Places to live in. At this time Brettaine is called by Porphyrius,‚ÄîFertilis Provincia Tyrannorum. One Laelianus a Tyrant in Brettaine about this time ≈øtamped Money, which is found here, and no where el≈øe. Cambden ibidem.
28. Carinus, Son of Carus the Emperor, Governor of Brettaine, France, Spain, and Illyricum. Cambden.
29. Carau≈øius, a Man meanly born, of the City of Menapia, u≈øurped in Brettaine, in the time of Diocletian and Maximinian: Stowe ≈øaith, he was Admiral of the Briti≈øh Seas.

30. Alectus, the Principal Officer under Carau≈øius, ≈ølew Carau≈øius, and u≈øurped the Rule of Brettaine. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 51. and Stowe, pag. 42. b. But I≈øaac≈øon in his Chronology placeth this ≈øub Anno 222. which cannot be under Diocletian.

31. A≈øclepiodotus, whom Cambden ≈øtiles Praefectus-Praetorio, and Stowe calleth Lord Great Ma≈øter of the Emperor's Hou≈øe, and I≈øaac≈øon ≈øtileth Duke of Cornwal: He ≈ølew Alectus, as he fled from the Forces of Con≈øtantius now landed in Brettaine. In this Encounter were ≈ølain a great number of Alectus his Soldiers; and this Victory and Recovery of Brettaine was had after this Province had been enjoyed ≈øeven Years by Carau≈øius, and three Years by Alectus. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 51.
St. Albon, the fir≈øt Martyr of the Brettans, ≈øuffered Martyrdom in the Place where now the Town of St. Albons is builded, Anno Domini 293. Stow, pag. 43. b.

32. Con≈øtantius Chlorus Emperor. When Diocletian and Maximinian gave up their Government, they de≈øigned Con≈øtantius the Title of Augu≈øtus, that is, Emperor; who had Italy, Africk, Spain, France, and Brettaine; for before he Governed by the name of Cae≈øar, that is, King: But Africk and Italy yielded them≈øelves to Galerius.
About this time the Emperors a≈ø≈øum'd Cae≈øars to rule under them. Cambd. Brit. p. 51.
Con≈øtantius (a Good Emperor) died at York in Brettaine, in an Expedition again≈øt the Calidonians, and other Picts, Anno Domini 305. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 52.

33. Con≈øtantine the Great, Son and Succe≈ø≈øor to Con≈øtantius, re≈øtored Peace and Quiet to the Chri≈øtians. He pro≈øecuted his Father's War again≈øt the Calidonians, and other Picts in Brettaine, and ≈øubdued them, and the le≈ø≈øer I≈ølands. Cambden.

34. Pacatianus was made Vicarius Britanniae under Con≈øtantine, Anno 13 Con≈øtantini Magni. Cambden in his Britannia, pag. 53. For now the Chief Governors of Brettaine were no more called Legats or Propraetors, which, according to our Engli≈øh manner, we term Lord Lieutenants; but in ≈øtead of that Title, they were now termed Vicarii Brettaniae, that is, Lord Deputies.

‚öú For the Form of Government was now changed: There were four Per≈øons con≈øtituted by Con≈øtantine, called Praefecti-Praetorio. One Praefectus-Praetorio for the Ea≈øt, another of Illyricum, a third of Italy, and a fourth Galliarum: And two Magi≈øtri Militum, or Ma≈øters of the Soldiers, one of the Foot, another of the Hor≈øe of the We≈øt, which the Romans called Prae≈øentales.

As to the Civil Government of Brettaine, it was under the Praefectus-Praetorio Galliarum; and under him Vicarius Brettaniae, or Deputy, honoured with the Title of Spectabilis, or Famous; to whom belonged two Provinciarum Con≈øulares, and three Prae≈øides, who heard the Civil and Criminal Cau≈øes.

As to the Military Affairs, the Ma≈øter of the Foot of the We≈øt Ruled; under who≈øe di≈øpo≈øal there was a Comes Brettaniarum, a Comes Littoris Saxonici per Brettaniam, and a Dux Brettaniarum, all ≈øtiled Spectabiles. Comes Brettaniarum was he that Commanded the inward Parts of the I≈øland, and he had ≈øeven Companies of Foot, and nine Colours of Hor≈øe. Comes Littoris Saxonici, was he that defended the Sea-coa≈øts again≈øt the Saxons, by Ammianus ≈øtiled Comes Tract√ªs Maritimi, and he had ≈øeven Companies of Foot, and two Colours of Hor≈øe, and the ≈øecond Legion, and unam Cohortem. Dux Brettaniarum, was he that defended the Out-Borders again≈øt the Picts and Scots: He Commanded 38 Garri≈øons, in which were placed 14000 Foot, and 900 Hor≈øe; ≈øo as in that Age (if Pancirol account right) Brettaine maintained 19200 Foot, and 1700 Hor≈øe, encamped Soldiers. Be≈øides Comes Sacrarum Largitionum, who had the Care of the Gifts and Liberality of the Emperor, he had under him in Brettaine a Receiver of the Revenues of Brettaine, a Trea≈øurer of the Emperor in Brettaine, and an Over≈øeer of the Work-hou≈øes in Brettaine, wherein were woven the Clothes of the Prince and Soldiers; and al≈øo Comes Rerum Privatarum, that is, one who had the care of the Privy Pur≈øe; and he had al≈øo his Receiver in Brettaine: To ≈øay nothing of the Over≈øeer of the Fencing-Schools through Brettaine, whereof an ancient In≈øcription maketh mention; and other inferiour Offices. Cambd. Brit. pag. 53, 54.
Con≈øtantine the Great died Anno Domini 336. He made his two Sons, Con≈øtantine and Cri≈øpus, and Licinius (Son of Licinius) Cae≈øars, Anno Domini 314. I≈øaac≈øon in his Chronology.An. Chr. nati.
35. Con≈øtantine the younger (Son of Con≈øtantine the Great) ≈øucceeded Emperor of the We≈øt.

36. Con≈øtans, having killed his Brother Con≈øtantine, occupied Brettaine, and the other Provinces: And after this Victory of his Soldiers again≈øt Con≈øtantine, he and his Brother Con≈øtantius come into Brettaine.

37. Magnentius, qui & Taporus dicitur, General to Con≈øtans, being born apud Laetos in Gallia, and his Father a Brettaine, was Comes Joviorum & Herculeorum. He circumvented Con≈øtans as he went on Hunting, and ≈ølew him in a Town called St. Hellens, and ≈øo u≈øurped his Empire; and after three Years ≈øharp War with Con≈øtantius Emperor of the Ea≈øt, he killed him≈øelf upon a defeat of his Army.
About this time was Gratianus, ≈øirnamed Funarius, Commander of the Military Forces in Brettaine. He was Father of Valentinian the Emperor. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 54.

38. Con≈øtantius Emperor of the Ea≈øt, and Brother to Con≈øtantine the younger, and Con≈øtans, after the death of Magnentius was now ≈øole Emperor both of the Ea≈øt and We≈øt; unto whom Brettaine ≈øubmitted. Con≈øtantius forthwith ≈øends Paulus, ≈øirnamed Catena, a Spaniard, into Brettaine, to fetch certain Soldiers to the Emperor for daring to con≈øpire again≈øt Magnentius; but Paulus falling upon the E≈øtates of many, and Impri≈øoning and Fettering of them, and other cruel u≈øage, Martinus then Deputy of Brettaine (wi≈øhing him not to be ≈øo cruel) was by Paulus threatned to be brought al≈øo unto the Emperor: whereupon Martinus drawing his Sword, ≈ømote at Paulus; but becau≈øe he could not kill him, pre≈øently he ≈ølew him≈øelf: And this Paulus was afterwards burned alive in the time of Julian. Ammianus Marcellinus, lib. 14.

The Scots and Picts now making Excur≈øions into Brettaine, Julian (whom Con≈øtantius had declared Cae≈øar, and Collegue in the Empire, Anno 355.) ≈øent Lupicinus, a great Solder, into Brettaine, for compo≈øing of things there.
39. Julian the Apo≈øtate made Emperor: He bani≈øhed Palladius into Brettaine, and ≈øent Alipius (who had been as Governor in Brettaine) to repair Jeru≈øalem.
This ≈ølothful Emperor was afraid to help the poor Bretans, whiles yet he tran≈øported hence yearly great ≈øtore of Corn to relieve the German Armies. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 55
40. Jovinian was Emperor ≈øeven Months.

41. Valentinian became Emperor, and he made Gratianus his Son Cae≈øar, 24 Augu≈øti,
Anno 367. Helvicus. In this Emperors Reign, the Picts, Saxons, Scots, and Attacotti, did with continual Spoils afflict the Brettans. Fraomarius King of the Almains was ≈øent hither with an Army of Almains, to re≈øtrain their Inva≈øions.

Nectaridius, Comes, or Chief Commander of the Sea-coa≈øt, was ≈ølain; and Belchobandes, a Captain, was circumvented by the Snares of the Enemy: Thereupon Valentinian ≈øent Severus, then Dome≈øticorum Comes, or Steward of the Emperors Hou≈øhold, to correct their In≈øolency; who being recalled, Jovinus was ≈øent thither; and la≈øtly, Theodo≈øius came hither with a brave Army.
At this time the Picts were divided into two Nations, Deucalidones & Vecturiones. An. Chr. nati.

‚ÄîTheodo≈øius landed at Richborow near Sandwich, and marching to the old London, (which the Romans called Augu≈øta) ≈øet upon tho≈øe Robbers by the way, and recovered the Spoil, and ≈øo entred London Triumphantly; and the Year after went into the North, and recovered the Province, repaired the Places of Defence, and re≈øtored this I≈øland; then returned to Rome, and for his famous Actings was honoured with the honour of an Eque≈øtris Statua. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 55, & 57. He nameth Brettaine, Valentia. I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology.

42. Gratianus, Son of Valentinian, is made Emperor; and he declared Theodo≈øius, Son of Theodo≈øius afore≈øaid, to be Emperor: which Maximus a Spaniard, ≈øprung from the Stock of Con≈øtantine the Great, took ≈øo ill, that he (being now Governor of the Briti≈øh Army) takes upon him to be Emperor, and victoriou≈øly conquered the Picts and Scots, and then went into Germany, with the Prime Youth and Strength of all Brettaine almo≈øt, and ≈øo got all the German Forces on his ≈øide.

43. Maximus u≈øurpeth the Provinces of the We≈øt, and creates Victor his Son Cae≈øar. He kept his Court at Triers, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Spain, Africk, France, and Brettaine. He killeth Gratian treacherou≈øly at Lyons, Anno 383. For having ≈øent Andragathius in a clo≈øe Litter or Caroch, giving out that therein was Gratian's Wife brought out of Brettaine, Gratian came to it, out of love to his Wife, and opening the Litter, out leaped Andragathius with his Men, and forthwith ≈ølew Gratian. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 57.

But Maximus by his own Soldiers was taken and brought to Theodo≈øius, then Emperor of the Ea≈øtern Provinces, who put him to death after he had worn the Purple Robes five Years, Anno ≈øcilic√®t 388. And Andragathius (who≈øe Condition was now de≈øperate) ca≈øt him≈øelf out of the Ship into the Sea: And Victor, the Son of Maximus, was overcome in France by Valentinian, and there taken, and ≈ølain.
But tho≈øe Brettans whom Maximus carried out of Brettaine, forcibly invaded Armorica in France, (as ≈øome Writers deliver) and there planted them≈øelves. Cambd. pag. 58.
44. Theodo≈øius, upon the Victory over Maximus, re≈øtoreth to Valentinian II. Son of Valentinian the Emperor, what Maximus took from him: And Theodo≈øius, and Honorius his Son, enter Rome in Triumph.

45. Valentinian II. is ≈øtrangled at Vienna by Arboga≈øtes a great Courtier; who not daring to U≈øurp him≈øelf, ≈øets up Eugenius, a ba≈øe Fellow, who of a School-ma≈øter became an Officer to the Emperor.

46. Theodo≈øius, Emperor of the Ea≈øt, defeateth Eugenius; and Theodo≈øius dies of a Drop≈øie at Millaine, Anno 395. and Arcadius his elde≈øt Son ≈øucceeds Emperor of the Ea≈øt, and his Son Honorius ≈øucceeds Emperor of the We≈øt.

47. Honorius, Son of Theodo≈øius, a Child of ten Years of age, ≈øucceeds Emperor of the We≈øt; who≈øe Tuition is commended to the care of Flavius Stilico, who defended Brettaine (now called England) from the Inva≈øions of the Picts, Scots, and Saxons. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 58. and Claudian the Poet, lib. 2. de Laudibus Stiliconis: eti√†m in Panegyri de quarto Con≈øulatu Honorii; [Anno 398.]
The Roman Power now declining, and the Brettans finding a nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øome General or Commander to defend them from their Barbarous Neighbours, fall to chu≈øing of Emperors or Kings.
48. Marcus is elected Emperor, or Chief Ruler of Brettaine, about 405. who was afterwards killed.

An. Chr. nati. 407. 49. Gratianus Municeps was elected Emperor, or Chief Governor of Brettaine; whom after four Months they reject, and take away his Life, Anno 407. Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. cap. 11. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 59.

50. Con≈øtantine, a mean ordinary Soldier, after the death of Gratian, is cho≈øen Emperor or Chief Governor of Brettaine by the Army, for his Names ≈øake; hoping he would Rule happily, as Con≈øtantine the Great had done. I≈øaac≈øon's Chronology; and Cambden, pag. 59. Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. cap. 11.
Honorius a≈ø≈øociates Con≈øtantine the U≈øurper in the Empire, Anno 409. I≈øaac≈øon.

Gerontius, Con≈øtantine's General, creates Maximus (one of his Servants) Emperor at Arragon, and killeth Con≈øtans, Son of Con≈øtantine, at Vienna, where he intercepted him, and Be≈øieged Con≈øtantine him≈øelf at Arelate.

Con≈øtantius, one ≈øent by Honorius, defeats Gerontius; who cowardly running away, the Soldiers be≈øet his Hou≈øe, and reduced him to ≈øuch a ≈øtrait, that fir≈øt he killeth his faithful Friend Alanus, and then Nunnichia his Wife, who de≈øired to die with her Husband; and la≈øt of all he killeth him≈øelf.

But Con≈øtantine, after four Months Siege, and the fourth Year of his Empire, laying a≈øide his Imperial Robes, was made Prie≈øt; and Arelate yielded up, he was brought into Italy by Con≈øtantius, unto Honorius, who cau≈øed Con≈øtantine to be Beheaded, with his two Sons, Julian whom he ≈øtiled Nobili≈ø≈øimum, that is, Mo≈øt Noble Julian, and Seba≈øtian the other Son, Anno 410.
And from this time Brettaine returned to the Government of Honorius. Cambden, pag. 59.
51. Victorinus ≈øent Governor into Brettaine by Honorius, did repre≈øs the Excur≈øions of the Picts and Scots with great Wi≈ødom and Valour.
Honorius the Emperor dieth of a Drop≈øie, Anno 423. and Valentinian the Third was Emperor of the We≈øt.

But after that Rome was taken by Alaricus King of the Gothes, and Victorinus called back out of Brettaine by Honorius, pre≈øently the Brettans take up Arms, and provide for their own ≈øafety; and al≈øo the Brettans of Armorica in France, and other Provinces, ≈øet up Governors of their own, rejecting the Roman Governors: And this was in the time of Con≈øtantine, by who≈øe ≈øloth the Picts and Scots over-ran this I≈øland: But a little after, the Brettans pray that Honorius would ≈øend them Aid to defend their Cities; but ≈øending no Forces, he admoni≈øhed them by Letters, that they ≈øhould have a care to defend them≈øelves. The Brettans, upon the≈øe Letters, take up Arms; and finding them≈øelves unable to re≈øi≈øt their Barbarous Enemies, they earne≈øtly be≈øeech Honorius to ≈øend a Legion hither for their ≈øafety, and obtained it; which upon their coming hither, overthrew a great multitude of their Enemies, and drove the re≈øt out of the Borders of their Province, and built a Mud-wall between Edenborough-Frith and Cluid, which was of little u≈øe: For after that Legion was called back to defend France, the Picts and Scots ea≈øily broke over the Bounds, and mo≈øt mi≈øerably ≈øpoiled the Brettans on every ≈øide. Again Me≈ø≈øengers are ≈øent, with rent and torn Garments, and their Heads covered with Sand thereon, lamentably craving Aid from the Romans: Whereupon Forces were a≈ø≈øigned by the Command of Valentinian the Third, under Gallio of Ravenna, who valiantly beat back the Picts and Scots, and did a little revive their wa≈øted Province. Mi≈øerable now and deplorable was the Face of Things: The Roman Empire, as it were, expiring; and the Church (by rea≈øon of the great Turmoil of Wars) much pe≈øtered with Heretiques. Pelagius now taught in our Brettaine, That we might attain to Perfect Righteou≈øne≈øs by our own Works: And one Timothy al≈øo impiou≈øly di≈øputed among our Brettans, again≈øt the Divine and Humane Nature of Chri≈øt. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 59, 60.

Now ended the Rule of the Romans in Brettaine, being the four hundred ≈øeventy and ≈øixth Year from Cae≈øar's entrance into Brettaine; ≈øo accounts Cambden: But I take it to be from the fir≈øt entrance of Cae≈øar, to the time of Valentinian III. 479 Years at lea≈øt: when in the time of Valentinian, the Roman Forces under the
Command of Gallio were called back to defend France, and Brettaine left naked without Arms, and deprived of their Prime Military Men, and their Trea≈øure exhau≈øted, without any Defence again≈øt the Cruelty of the Picts and Scots.

Be≈øides tho≈øe Brettans (≈øaith Cambden) carried away by Maximus, and the la≈øt Con≈øtantine; by Ancient In≈øcriptions, and the Book of the Provinces called Notitia Provinciarum, it appears, that the≈øe underwritten did ≈øerve the Romans in their Wars, di≈øper≈øed through the Provinces, which al≈øo were from time to time ≈øupplied out of Brettaine: Viz.

list.item: Ala IV Britonum in Egypto.
Cohors III Britonum.
Cohors VII Britonum.
Cohors XXVI Britonum in Armeni√¢.

item.hi: Invicti Juniores Britanniciani. Inter Auxilia Palatina.
Exculcatores Jun. Britan. Inter Auxilia Palatina.

div.p: Thus have I briefly run through the Romans in Brettaine, with the Times when they ruled there, as near as I can; but ≈øometimes I cannot trace them ≈øo exactly as I could wi≈øh, becau≈øe the Ancient Authors are defective, e≈øpecially not exact in ≈øhewing the Times punctually, and oft times a great ≈øpace omitted in their Hi≈øtories, is skipped over.
Of the State of the Brettans, after the Roman Yoke cea≈øed, I ≈øhall ≈øpeak when I come to Wales.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Time when the Saxons came into Brettaine, and how long their Power continued there.

div.p: 1. UPon the declination of the Roman Empire, Brettaine was left naked of Men and Arms, as I have ≈øhewed before; whereby the poor Brettans became a Prey to the Picts and Scots, two cruel Nations, from beyond the Sea; the Scots from the South, and the Picts from the North. Gildas, cap. 11. pag. 13.

Tran≈ømarinas dicimus has Gentes, non qu√≤d extr√† Bretanniam ≈øunt Po≈øitae, ≈øed qui√† √† parte Britonum erant remotae; duobus finibus Mari interjacentibus, quorum unus ab Orientali Mari, alter ab Occidentali, Britanniae terras long√® lat√©que irrumpit, quamvis ad ≈øe invic√®m pertingere po≈ø≈øint: Orientalis habet in medio ≈øui Urbem Guidi: Occidentalis ≈øupra ≈øe, hoc e≈øt, ad dextram ≈øui habet Urbem Alcluith; qu√≤d Lingu√¢ eorum ≈øignificat [Petram Cluith:] E≈øt enim juxt√† Fluvium nominis illius: So Bede de Hi≈øt. Angl. lib. 1. cap. 12.
Who the≈øe Scots were, I ≈øhall ≈øpeak of in Scotland, and whence they came. I ≈øhall note here onely, that they inhabited the North part of Scotland, Anno Domini circiter 400.

The Pihts, or Picts, Cambden ≈øuppo≈øeth to be very Brettans, who before the coming of the Romans inhabited the Northern part of this I≈øland; and al≈øo tho≈øe other Brettans who fled to them from this other part of Brettaine which the Romans conquered, as refu≈øing to ≈øubmit to the Servitude of the Romans: Cambden's Britannia, pag. 82. But Bede ≈øaith, It is ≈øaid that the Nation of the Picts came out of Scythia into Ireland, and thence into the North of Bretta√Æne: Lib. 1. de Hi≈øt. Angl. cap. 1. But more of the≈øe hereafter in Scotland.

2. The time of the Saxons coming into England, upon the invitation of Vortiger then King of Brettaine, is by Bede ≈øaid to be in Anno Domini 449. Lib. 1. de Hi≈øt. Ang. cap. 15. and had a Place appointed out by the Brettans for their Habitation, conditionally that they would fight and defend them from the Picts and Scots; and the Brettans al≈øo did promi≈øe them Pay: But Cambden ≈øaith, The fir≈øt coming of the Saxons hither was Anno Domini 428. and thinks the Number 449 in Bede to be corrupted and mi≈øprinted; in his Britannia, pag. 95. ≈øee his Rea≈øons.

But the≈øe Saxons having expelled the Picts and Scots, did afterwards by degrees root out the Brettans al≈øo, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of all the South part of Brettaine, now called England: But falling out among them≈øelves, each contending for Superiority one again≈øt another, as it commonly happens in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, England became a Heptarchy, and was divided into ≈øeven Kingdoms, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew by and by.

They had the Ea≈øtern part of this I≈øland to Land in, appointed by Vortiger. Tho≈øe that came, were of the mo≈øt Valiant People of Germany; that is to ≈øay, Saxons, Angli or Engli≈øh, and Juites, called by Bede, Vitae: Lib. 1. de Hi≈øt. Ang. cap. 15.
From the≈øe Juites (the ancient Inhabitants of Juitland, now belonging to the King of Denmark) are planted the Kenti≈øh-men, and the People of the I≈øle of Wight and Hant≈øhire.

The Engli≈øh came out of Old England, which lieth between Juitland and Hol≈øatia, and was anciently po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Saxons, who being expul≈øed thence by the Danes, it hath ever ≈øince remained in the Danes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Of the≈øe Engli≈øh, were planted the Ea≈øt-Angles, Middle-Angles, Mercians, and all the Nation of the Northumbrians, that is, all the North part from the River Humber in York≈øhire.

The Saxons came out of Saxony (a Province and Dukedom in Germany, formerly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Longobards, who being overcome by the Saxons, it became their Countrey, and took their Name:) And from the≈øe Saxons were planted the Ea≈øt-Saxons, South-Saxons, and We≈øt-Saxons in England. Bede lib. 1. de Hi≈øt. Ang. cap. 15. Ver≈øtegan, pag. 123. and Dr. Heylyn in his Co≈ømography, pag. 489.

But the≈øe being all generally called Saxons, contending for Superiority among them≈øelves, fell to Di≈øcords and Wars one with another, and ≈øet up ≈øeven Kingdoms in that part of Brettaine which they obtained, at this day called England: A ≈øhort View whereof followeth in the en≈øuing Table.

table.head: A Scheme of the Seven Kingdoms in England.

row.cell: 1. The Kingdom of Kent it began under Hengi≈øt, An. Dom. 455.
2. The Kingdom of the South Saxons it began under Ella, Anno Dom. 488.
3. The Kingdom of the We≈øt-Saxons it began under Cerdic, Anno 522. But Huntington ≈øaith, Anno 519. lib. 2. Hi≈øt. pag. 313.
4. The Kingdom of the Ea≈øt-Saxons it began under Erchenwin, about Anno 527.
5. The Kingdom of the Northumbrians it began under Ida, Anno Dom. 547.
Called ≈øometimes the Kingdom of the Deiri.
Northumberland, and Part of Scotland, from the River Tine to Edenborough-Frith. called ≈øometimes Bernicia.
6. The Kingdom of the Ea≈øt-Angles it began under Uffa, Anno Dom. 575. But Stowe ≈øaith, 492.
7. The Kingdom of Mercia it began under Creodda, An. Dom. 582.

div.p: But that of the We≈øt-Saxons at la≈øt prevailed over all the re≈øt; and Egbert King of the We≈øt-Saxons was the fir≈øt Sole Monarch of all England among the Saxons. He was Crowned King of all England at Winche≈øter, about Anno Domini 823. Polychronicon: and ≈øoon after commanded, That all that Part of Brettaine, whereof he had now the Sovereignty, ≈øhould be called England; and ever ≈øince it hath retained the name of England: Polychronicon, lib. 5. cap. 28. See al≈øo Ver≈øtegan, pag. 148, 149. He was the fir≈øt al≈øo, or his Son Ethelwolfe, who divided England into Shires, as at this day they ≈øtand divided; the Names whereof you have in the Table preceding: And King Alfred afterwards divided them into Hundreds and Tithings; ≈øo Malmesbury: Yet Ingulphus ≈øaith, That Alfred divided both the Shires and the Hundreds; but is mi≈øtaken, el≈øe Malmesbury would not have left that out.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: How the Saxons derive their Pedegree from Sem, as I find it Regi≈øtred by A≈ø≈øer Meneven≈øis, pag. 1. in the Pedegree of Alfred: Al≈øo by Ailredus Abbas Rievallis, in his Pedegree of King Henry the Second: Al≈øo Florentius, pag. 294. And al≈øo by Matthew Paris, in the Edition put out by Dr. Wats, Anno Chri≈øti 1640. pag. 94. as followeth.

2. Wala.
3. Hathra.
4. Itermod.
5. Heremod.
6. Celdwa.
7. Beu.
8. Garwa, or Cetwa.
9. Geta, pro Deo habitus.
10. Fingondulf.
11. Frederwolf.

13. Fredwald.
14. Woden.
15. Bealdag.
16. Brand.
17. Freodgar. The≈øe three are omitted by A≈ø≈øer, as it is Printed from Cambden's Copy, 1603. al≈øo by Simon Dunelmen≈øis, pag. 119.
18. Frewin. The≈øe three are omitted by A≈ø≈øer, as it is Printed from Cambden's Copy, 1603. al≈øo by Simon Dunelmen≈øis, pag. 119.
19. Wigg. The≈øe three are omitted by A≈ø≈øer, as it is Printed from Cambden's Copy, 1603. al≈øo by Simon Dunelmen≈øis, pag. 119.

item.p: 20. Gewis: I≈øte fuit Caput Gentis ≈øuae: √† quo & tota Gens illa nomen accepit √† Britonibus: Gewi≈ø≈øorum Gens fuit Hant≈øhire, ≈øive Regio Wintoniae: Ordericus lib. 4. pag. 512. See al≈øo Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. lib. 4. cap. 15.
Gewis is omitted in Mat. Paris Copy.

list.item: 21. Edda: omitted by A≈ø≈øer, and called Egla by Mat. Paris.
22. Ele≈øa.
23. Ceordwic. He lived Anno 520.
24. Creoda.
25. Chenric, or Kenrick.
26. Cheulin.
27. Cuthwin.
28. Cutha, Son of Cuthwin.

30. Ceonred.
31. Ingels: cujus Frater fuit Ina Rex famo≈øi≈ø≈øimus Occidentalium Saxonum.
32. Eoppa.
33. Offa, ce√π Eafa.
34. Alcmund.
35. Egbert, or Egbricht, the fir≈øt Saxon Monarch of all England. Obiit Anno Chri≈øti 836.
36. Ethelwolf. Obiit Anno 856.
37. Alfred. He Reigned not till 872. becau≈øe his Brothers Reigned before him. Obiit 899.
38. Edward the Elder. Obiit Anno Chri≈øti 924.
39. Edmund. Obiit Anno Chri≈øti 946.
40. Edgar the Peaceable. Obiit Anno Chri≈øti 975.
41. Ethelred. He plotted to kill all the Danes in their Beds on the 12th of November at night, An. 1012. Obiit Anno. Chri≈øti 1016.
42. Edmund Iron≈øide. He died Anno Chri≈øti 1017.
43. Edward the Outlaw. He was never King, though Right Heir: Cnut the Dane di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him.

44.
Margaret, Wife of Malcolme the third, King of Scotland.
Chri≈øtian, a Nun at Ram≈øey in Huntington-≈øhire, 1086. Si. Dunelmen≈øis.
Edgar Atheling, Right Heir to the Crown, created Earl of Oxford 1065 Stowe and Cambden.
45. Maud, Wife of Henry the Fir≈øt, King of England.
46. Maud the Empre≈øs, Daughter and Heir. She was after married to Geffrey Plantagenet, Earl of Anjou in France, 1127.
47. Henry the Second, King of England, Son of Geffrey and Maud. &c.

div.p: ‚öú This De≈øcent carrieth great uncertainty, both for the defect of time wherein each lived, and al≈øo for want of Authority vouched; but chiefly, for that Bedwig, the fir≈øt here named, is made the Son of Sem: Howbeit the later part of it is very true; but the making of Bedwig Son of Sem, is either foi≈øted into the Copy by ≈øome ignorant Per≈øon, or el≈øe is to be under≈øtood as de≈øcended from Sem originally, not immediately; as Chri≈øt is called the Son of David, the Son of Abraham, Matthew, cap. 1. ver. 1. For Sem the Son of Noah died Anno Mundi 2158. & Anno po≈øt Diluvium 502. which was 1790 Years before Chri≈øt was born: And no Learned Man, ver≈øed in Antiquities, can imagine the De≈øcents here reckoned up to Bedwig from King Alfred, to exceed 1000 Years: So that reckoning from Alfred's death, which was in Anno 899. it cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed that the≈øe De≈øcents can reach much above the time of Chri≈øt's Birth, if they reach ≈øo high, admitting them to be exactly true ≈øo far as they reach; which would yet fall ≈øhort 1700 Years from the death of Sem.

Be≈øides we find no ≈øuch Son of Sem, as Bedwig, mentioned in the Sacred Scriptures: And if we well ob≈øerve the third Chapter of S. Luke, we ≈øhall find 66 De≈øcents reckoned up between Sem and Chri≈øt, containing the Revolution of 2000 Years and more, if we account the Age wherein Sem lived: And S. Matthew reckons up onely 52 De≈øcents to that time by another Line, be≈øides three Kings omitted by him between Joram and Ozias, for ≈øome Rea≈øons be≈øt known to the Holy Spirit of God; which will better appear by comparing S. Matth. 1. ver. 8. with 1 Chron. cap. 3. ver. 11, 12. So as the whole De≈øcents therein make up onely 55. And although ≈øome Mens Lives are longer, and ≈øome ≈øhorter, yet the Generations carry ≈øome proportion one with another, as we may ea≈øily ob≈øerve in others where the De≈øcents are exactly put down.

But now between Sem and Alfred are onely 37 De≈øcents here reckoned up, which cannot comprehend above 1000 Years; and between Sem and Alfred are effluxed
2690 Years, accounting from both their deaths: So that unle≈øs ≈øome De≈øcents be here skipped over in many places, it is impo≈ø≈øible that any of the≈øe ≈øhould reach the Age of Sem; and then the≈øe cannot be exact and true De≈øcents through. Be≈øides, tho≈øe more ancient De≈øcents between Bedwig and Gewis, not having been proved by ≈øome good Authority, may yield them uncertain to relie upon.
So much for the De≈øcent of the Saxons before-mentioned.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Containing a Brief Catalogue of all the Saxon Kings in England from the fir≈øt beginning of the Heptarchy, and when they Reigned.

A.C. 512. 3. Otta 20 Years.
A.C. 532. 4. Imirik 29 Years.

div.p: Before this time it remained in the Power of the We≈øt-Saxons a good while; and upon the death of Edelwach, Berthan and Authun, two Brothers, took upon them the Government of the South-Saxons with the Title of Dux, and held it for a little while; but Ina, Succe≈ø≈øor of Cedwall, King of the We≈øt-Saxons, ≈øubdued it, and united it to that Crown.

div.p: And after the Interregnum of 33 years, Egbert King of the We≈øt-Saxons enjoyed this Kingdom, Anno 827. In that Interregnum it was invaded on the one hand by the Danes, and on the other by the Picts and Scots.

list.head: The Kings of the We≈øt-Saxons.
list.item: A.C. 522. 1. Cerdic, the fir≈øt King of the We≈øt-Saxons Yea. 17
He killed 5000 Brettans, Anno 509. Hen. Huntington pag. 312. and routed Nazaleod the Great King of the Brettans, at Certicsford.
A.C. 539. 2. Kenric, Son of Cerdic Yea. 26
A.C. 565. 3. Ceaulin, Son of Cenric, with Cuthwin his Son Yea. 30
A.C. 595. 4. Celric, Son of Ceaulin Yea. 5
A.C. 600. 5. Ceolwolfe, Son of Cutha, Son of Kenric, Son of Cerdic Yea. 14

A.C. 645. 7. Cenwald, or Kenwalchin, Son of Kingils Yea. 31

A.C. 677. 9. E≈øcwine, Son of Cenwald Yea. 2
A.C. 679. 10. Centwin, or Kentwin, Co≈øin of E≈øcwin Yea. 9
A.C. 688. 11. Ceadwall, with Mull his Brother, took the I≈øle of Wight. Huntington. Yea. 2

A.C. 690. 12. Ine, Son of Cenred, Son of Ceoldwold, Son of Cuthwin, Son of Kenric. Anno Regni ≈øui 21. he fought with Gerent king of Wales, and routed him. Huntington, pag. 337. He fir≈øt gave the Peter-Pence to the Pope. Yea. 37
