list.head: The Monarchs of England of the Saxon Blood.
list.item: Anno Chr. 823 1. Egbert, the Fir≈øt Saxon Monarch of England, was Crowned King of all England at Winche≈øter, about Anno Chri≈øti 823, and commanded that all that part of Brettaine (whereof he had now the Sovereignty) ≈øhould be called England; ≈øince which time it hath been called England. Polychronicon. He began his Reign over the We≈øt-Saxons, Anno Chri≈øti 800. But over England, in Anno 823. or thereabouts. He Reigned 14 Years.
2. Ethelwolfe, elde≈øt Son of Egbert. He Reigned 20 Years.
3. Ethelbald, elde≈øt Son of Ethelwolfe. Huntington ≈øaith he Reigned five Years, p. 349. He Reigned one Year.
4. Ethelbert, ≈øecond Son of Ethelwolfe. He Reigned five Years.
5. Ethelred, third Son of Ethelwolfe. Huntington ≈øaith, he Reigned but five Years, pag. 349. He Reigned nine Years.

6. Alfred, fourth Son of Ethelwolfe, a Learned Prince. He totally united the Heptarchy into one Kingdom; vanqui≈øhed the Danes, and ≈øubdued them, though he could not quite expel them. He divided the Shires of England into Hundreds and Tythings, as Egbert his Grandfather had before divided England into Shires, as now they ≈øtand at this day, ≈øome few having been new modelled ≈øince. He erected a Univer≈øity at Oxford, and Reigned 29 Years.
Anno Chr. 901 7. Edward, ≈øirnamed The Elder, Son of Alfred; he recovered the Countrey of the Ea≈øt-Angles from the Danes, whom he ≈øhut up in Northumberland. He Reigned 24. years.
8. Athel≈øtan, Ba≈øtard-Son of Edward, ≈øubdued the Brettans of Cumberland and Cornwall, and made the Danes to ≈øubmit to his Government. He Reigned 16 years.
9. Edmund, legitimate Son of Edward, ≈øubdued the Danes in Northumberland, and utterly ≈øubverted the Kingdom of the Brettans in Cumberland. He Reigned 6 years.
10. Ethelred, Brother of Edmund. He Reigned 9 years.
11. Edwy, Son of Edmund. He Reigned 3 Years and 9 Months.

12. Edgar, ≈øirnamed The Peaceable, Brother to Edwyn, was the mo≈øt ab≈øolute Monarch of England ≈øince the time of the Saxons, by whom the Tribute-money, impo≈øed on the Wel≈øh by Athel≈øtan, was exchang'd into a Tribute of Wolfs. This Edgar in the thirteenth Year of his Reign, is ≈øaid to have been Rowed on the River Dee at Che≈øter by eight Kings, who ≈øwore Fealty to him, Anno 972. their Names were Kunud or Rynad, King of the Scots; Malcolme, King of Cumberland; Maccu≈øius, the Arch-Pyrat; and all the Kings of Wales, who≈øe Names were Du≈øwall, Griffith, Huvall, Jacob, and Judethil, or Inchil. Malmesbury, pag. 56. Huntington, pag. 356. and Hoveden, pag. 426. He Reigned 16 Years.
13. Edward II. ≈øirnamed The Martyr, Son of Edgar, was treacherou≈øly murthered by his Step-mother, to make way for her Son Ethelred to ≈øucceed. He Reigned 3 Years.

item.p: 14. Ethelred II. younger Son of Edgar, was oppre≈ø≈øed and broken by the Danes, and to buy his own Peace, was forc'd to pay them a yearly Sum of 10000 l. which at la≈øt was enhanced to 48000 l. This Tax was impo≈øed on his Subjects, and called Dane-geld; but weary of this great Taxation, he Plotted warily with his Subjects, to kill all the Danes in their Beds; which was put in Execution on the Eve of Saint Britius, being the twelfth of November 1012, in the night-time: But ≈øoon after Swane, King of Denmark, Landed Forces in England, and forced Ethelred to flie out of England into Normandy. He Reigned 38 years.

p.hi: Ethelredus i≈øte bapti≈ømum ≈øtercore foedavit.

item.p: 15. Edmund II. ≈øirnamed Iron≈øide, Son of Ethelred, having in vain attempted to recover the Kingdom, at la≈øt divided it with Cnut [or Canutus] the Dane, Son of Swane; and not long after was this Edmund ba≈øely murthered 1017. This was the common Fame, ≈øaith Malmesbury; but Florentius and Hoveden tell us, that he died at London about the Fea≈øt of Saint Andrew the Apo≈øtle. He Reigned nine Months.
By the Coun≈øel of Edrick de Streon, Cnut bani≈øhed Edwin, Brother to Edmund Iron≈øide, and al≈øo Edward and Edmund, Sons of King Edmund Iron≈øide.

Edward, ≈øirnamed The Outlaw, Son of Edmund Iron≈øide, had i≈ø≈øue Edgar Atheling, the right Heir of the Crown, and Margaret, Married to the third Malcolme, King of Scotland, and Chri≈øtian, a Nun of Ram≈øey in Huntington≈øhire, 1086. Simeon Dunelmen≈øis.

list.head: Kings of England of the Dani≈øh Blood.
list.item: 1. Canutus or Cnut, King of Denmark and Norway, after the death of Edmund Iron≈øide, was ≈øole King of England: He Married Emme the Widow of King Ethelred, and Daughter of Richard, Duke of Normandy. He Reigned 20 years.
2. Harold, Ba≈øtard Son of Cnut, ≈øirnamed Harfuger. He Reigned four years.
3. Canutus II. commonly called Hardy-Cnut, the lawful Son of Cnut. He Reigned two years.

item.p:
16. Edward III. ≈øirnamed The Confe≈ø≈øor, (Son of Ethelred II. by Emme, Daughter of Richard; Duke of Normandy, and half Brother to Edmund Iron≈øide, and to Hardy-Cnut the Dane) was now advanced to the Throne of England, and the Danes utterly expelled
the Countrey, having tytannized here above 200 years, whereof they Reigned onely 26 years. He Reigned 24 years.

He was the fir≈øt of the Kings of England who cured the Di≈øea≈øe call'd The Kings Evil, a Prerogative continuing hereditary to the Kings of England; and after his Death he was Canonized for a Saint; Dr. Heylins Co≈ømography pag. 318.

Anno Chr. 1066 17.Harold, Son of Godwin Earl of Kent, was cho≈øen King of England, (in the Nonage of Edgar Atheling, Grandchild to Edmund Iron≈øide, and true Heir of the Kingdom) he was Crowned the ≈øixth of January 1065. He Reigned nine Months and eight days.

But before I pa≈øs farther, I would remember you of one thing mentioned by Dr. Heylin, how in memory of the joyful clearing of the Countrey from the cruel Danes in the time of Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, the Engli≈øh did in≈øtitute the Merriment of the annual Sports of Hock-Tide, and from their barbarous ≈øtabbing of the Engli≈øh at the time of their Drinking; to avoid ≈øuch villany, the Party who was to Drink reque≈øted ≈øome of the next to him to be his Pledge or Surety whil≈øt he was Drinking; and hence came our Cu≈øtom of Pledging one another, a Phra≈øe u≈øed in time of Drinking even to this day.
Harold was ≈ølain in Battel the fourteenth of October 1066, by William Duke of Normandy; upon which Victory William was Crowned King of England, and ≈øo cea≈øed the Rule of the Saxons.

div.p: Thus have I briefly run over the Saxon Kings of England out of the mo≈øt authentick Hi≈øtorians; ≈øo that putting all together, if we reckon the coming in of the Saxons with Cambden, to be in Anno Domini 428, to the time of the Norman Conque≈øt, and including the ≈ømall time of the Rule of the Dani≈øh Kings in the Account, the whole time of the Saxons Rule in England was 638 years.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Of the time of the Danes in England.

div.p:
1. ANno Domini 800. the Danes fir≈øt arriv'd in England, to wit, in the I≈øle of Portland, which belongeth to Dor≈øet≈øhire, Brithric being then King of the We≈øt-Saxons; Stowe's Annals; but were after driven out of the Land. The≈øe Danes did much infe≈øt England for a long ≈øpace, burning Towns and Temples, and making woful de≈øtruction. Osbert and Ella, Kings of Northumberland, were ≈ølain at York by the Danes, Anno 867. Matth. of We≈øtmin≈øter. And in Anno 870. the Danes, under the Command of Hinguar and Hubba, ≈ølew Edmund, King of the Ea≈øt-Angles, and ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of that Kingdom; Florentius Wigornien≈øis and Stowe. And in Anno 874. the Danes forced Beorhred, King of Mercia, to flie out of England; and after his Expul≈øion they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed all the Kingdom of the Mercians. Florentius. Infinite other Battels of them we meet with; ≈øo that now they had the Kingdoms of the Mercians and of the Ea≈øt-Angles, and a great part of Northumberland: And in the time of Ethelred, King of England, Anno Domini 991. the Tribute call'd Danegeld was fir≈øt Collected, to appea≈øe the fury of the Danes and their Depopulations, which continued a long time after. See Spelman's Glo≈ø≈øary on the word Danegeldum. Anno Domini 1012. on the twelfth of November at Night, Anno Regni Ethelredi 35. the Engli≈øh, to free them≈øelves from the great Oppre≈ø≈øion of the Tax called Danegeld, did by a general Con≈øpiracy ≈øtrangle all the Danes in their Beds. Heylin's Co≈ømography pag. 317. To revenge which Fact, Swane, King of Denmark, came into England with a Fleet of 350 Ships, Anno 1013. and cea≈øed not to ≈øpoil many parts of the Kingdom, and at la≈øt ≈øo
far prevailed, and ≈øubdued England, that Cnut his Son was made King thereof, after the death of Edmund Iron≈øide, to wit, Anno 1017. and Cnut and his Sons enjoyed the Crown 26 years, to the Year 1043. and then was the Saxon Blood re≈øtored to the Crown in Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor; but ala≈øs! ≈øoon after Edward's Death, were both the Danes and Saxons conquered by William Duke of Normandy, to wit, Anno 1066.

So that we ≈øee the Ju≈øtice of God, how he ≈øet the Danes as a Scourge to the Saxons, who had ≈øo perfidiou≈øly and cruelly u≈øed the poor Brettans, and at la≈øt were driven out of their Lands by the Normans, as they before had driven out the Brettans.

2. The whole time that the Danes ≈øo mi≈øerably afflicted the Saxons in England, was 266 years, if we reckon to the Norman Conque≈øt, from the fir≈øt coming of them into England, Anno Domini 800. but if we reckon to the time of Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, ≈øub Anno 1043. then it containeth onely 242 years.

But Matth. of We≈øtmin≈øter computeth onely from the beginning of King Ethelwolfe's Reign to the Norman Conque≈øt; which I wonder at, ≈øince the ≈øame Author tells us, that in Anno 800. the Danes ≈øpoiled Tinmouth Church, and after they had Robbed thereabouts, they returned with their Spoils; and be≈øides, he tells us of ≈øeveral Battels in England, between King Egbert and the Danes: But his words are the≈øe, pag. 302. Mi≈øit erg√≤ eis Deus Omnipotens Gentes Paganas crudeli≈ø≈øimas, velut Apum Examina, quae n√® quidem Sexui muliebri, aut Parvulorum parceret aetati, Danos ≈øcilicet, & Norwegen≈øes, Gothos, Swathedos, Vandalos, & Fri≈øios, qui ab exordio Regis Ethelwolfi ≈øupradicti u≈øque ad Normannorum Adventum, per annos ferm√® 230, terram hanc peccatricem, √† mari u≈øqu√® ad mare, & ab homine u≈øqu√® ad Pecus, deleverunt,‚Äînon eam po≈ø≈øidere & ≈øubjugare, ≈øed praedari ac perdere ≈øatagebant: So that there was a long time of intermixture, with various Nations and ≈øorts of People.

Cambden ≈øaith, That the Name of Danes was not known to the World before the time of Ju≈øtinian the Emperor, about the Year of Chri≈øt 570. Tunc enim Galliam va≈øtare caeperunt, & Rerum Anglicarum Latinis Hi≈øtoricis Wiccingi dicti ≈øunt: Wiccinga Saxonic√® Piratam denotat. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 101. And Dudo Sancti Quinti Decanus ≈øaith, That out of Scanza (that is, Scandia) the Danes, Getes or Gothes, Amarobii, Tragoditae, Alani, & Sarmatae, came out like Swarms of Bees. Lib. 1. ≈øub initio. Al≈øo Gemeticen≈øis, lib. 1. cap. 2.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Of the coming of the Normans into England, and whence they are de≈øcended.

div.p: 1. THe Normans invaded England, Anno Domini 1066. when William, ≈øirnamed The Ba≈øtard, Duke of Normandy, commonly called William the Conqueror, Landed with a great Army at Pem≈øey near Ha≈øtings in Su≈ø≈øex, and overcame Harold, King of England, in Battel, which was fought the fourteenth day of October, being Saturday, Anno Domini 1066. about nine Miles from Ha≈øtings in Su≈ø≈øex; upon which Victory the Engli≈øh ≈øubmitted to him.

And in the Race of the Norman Blood hath the Kingdom of England ≈øince continued to this day 1670. by Maude the Empre≈øs, Daughter and Heir to King Henry I. and Wife of Geffrey Planagenet, Earl of Anjou in France, Married to him Anno Domini 1127. Mother of King Henry the Second, from whom the ≈øucceeding Kings are de≈øcended.

The Engli≈øh continued their native Language, notwith≈øtanding the great and long commixture with the Normans; but much altered ≈øince Chaucer's time, who lived under
King Richard the Second, e≈øpecially ≈øince Henry the Eighth's time downward, it is ≈øo intermingled with Latine, be≈øides ≈øome old words, retained from the Norman-French anciently, that it is now become a new Language, and much of the ancient Engli≈øh Tongue quite lo≈øt and peri≈øh'd; and daily in our Age creep in many Latine and French words, to the utter decay of the Engli≈øh Tongue.

The Conqueror gave away the Lands of the Engli≈øh to his Friends and Soldiers, who a≈ø≈øi≈øted him in the Conque≈øt; ≈øome few he ≈øuffered to en ‚Ä¢ oy their own E≈øtates, and but very few. Mo≈øt of the ancient Gentry now in England, of great and ancient E≈øtates, are De≈øcended from the Normans, who came into England with the Conqueror; yet doubtle≈øs are there many of the Saxon Blood now remaining; and by rea≈øon of a long intermixture by intermarrying one with another, have incorporated our Nation into a Hotchpot of ≈øeveral Nations: for the Normans them≈øelves were a People intermingled of Norwegians, Swedes, and Danes.

It is ob≈øerved of the People of England, that they are ≈øo naturally given to Faction and Rebellion, that ≈øince the Norman Conque≈øt, we ≈øcarcely read of any of our Kings to this day, who have not met with the di≈øturbance of ≈øome rebellious and trea≈øonable Practi≈øes of their own Subjects, and that in open Arms too, King James onely excepted; and yet he wanted not a Gunpowder Trea≈øon, miraculou≈øly di≈øcovered and prevented, Anno 1605. nor a Gowries Con≈øpiracy in Scotland, 1600. and his Son King Charles the Fir≈øt mo≈øt mi≈øerably murthered in our Days by his own Subjects, through the Puritan Factions in England, Anno 1648. the thirtieth day of January.

div.head: A ≈øhort Table of the Norman Kings, and when they began their Reigns.
div.p: Anno Chr. 1066. 1. William the Conqueror, Ba≈øtard-Son of Robert Duke of Normandy, by one Arlet, a Skinner's Daughter of Faloys in Normandy. He cau≈øed Domes-day Book to be made, which was begun and fini≈øhed between the fourteenth and twentieth Year of his Reign. He died the ninth day of September, aged 64 Years, Anno Domini 1087. He Reigned 20 Years, 10 Months, and 26 Days.

2. William, ≈øirnamed Rufus, third Son of William the Conqueror, ≈øucceeded in the Kingdom of England. Robert the elde≈øt Son was Duke of Normandy. William Rufus died ≈øecundo die Augu≈øti 1100. in the thirteenth Year of his Reign, being ≈ølain with an Arrow, which was ≈øhot by Sir Walter Tirrel, a Frenchman, at a Deer in New-Forre≈øt in Hamp≈øhire, and hitting a Bough of a Tree, glanced a≈øide and hit the King. He Reigned 12 Years, 11 Months fer√®.

3. Henry, for his Learning ≈øirnamed Beauclerk, the fourth Son of the Conqueror, (but the third Son that lived to be a Man) and younger Brother to William Rufus, in the ab≈øence of Robert Duke of Normandy his elde≈øt Brother, then in the Holy Land, ≈øucceeded King of England, and afterwards took from his Brother Robert the Dukedom of Normandy al≈øo: he died primo die Decembris 1135. He Reigned 35 Years and four Months.

4. Stephen, ≈øecond Son of Stephen Earl of Blois, by Adela, Daughter of William the Conqueror, u≈øurped the Kingdom of England, and was in continual War with Maude the Empre≈øs: he died the twenty fifth day of October, 1154. He Reigned 18 Years, 10 Months, and odd Days.

5. Henry II. Son of Geffrey Plantagenet, Earl of Anjou in France, by Maude the Empre≈øs, Daughter and ≈øole Heir of Henry I. King of England: he added to the Engli≈øh Empire, Anjou, Touraine, and Main, which were his Fathers, and al≈øo the Dutchy of Aquitain, and the Earldom of Poictu, by Elianor his Wife, and conquered Ireland: he died the ≈øixth day of July, 1189. aged 61 Years. He Reigned 34 Years and 9 Months, wanting 18 Days.

6. Richard I. Son of Henry II. ≈øirnamed Ceur de Lyon, Warred in the Holy Land, and in
his return was taken Pri≈øoner in the Dominions of the Duke of Au≈øtria: He was ≈ølain at the Siege of the Battel of Chaluz in the Province of Limoges in France, and died of his Wound the ≈øixth day of April, 1199. He Reigned 9 Years, and 9 Months.Anno Chr. 1199.
7. John, Brother to Richard I. lo≈øt Normandy, Aquitaine, and Angeau, to the French, 1204. He died the 19 of October, 1216. at the age of 51 Years. He Reigned 17 Years, and 6 Months.
8. Henry III. Son of King John, was but nine Years old when he was Crowned. He died the 16 of November 1272. aged 65 Years. He reigned 56 Years and one Month.
9. Edward I. Son of Henry III. ≈øubdued Wales, and brought Scotland into ≈øubjection. He died the ≈øeventh of July, 1307. aged 68 Years. He Reigned 34 Years, 7 Months, and 22 Days.

10. Edward II. Son of Edward I. was Barbarou≈øly and Traiterou≈øly depo≈øed through a ≈øtrong Faction rai≈øed again≈øt him by his Queen, and afterwards murthered in Barkley-Ca≈øtle. He was depo≈øed the 25 of January, 1326. and murthered September 21. 1327. He Reigned 19 Years, 6 Months, and 18 Days.

11. Edward III. Son of Edward II. a Valorous Prince, overthrew the French in two great Battels, took Caliz, and many other Places in that Kingdom, and Quartered the Arms of France in his Coat, which the ≈øucceeding Kings of England have ever ≈øince imitated and retained. He died at Richmond the 21 day of June, 1377. in the 56 Year of his Age. He Reigned 50 Years and almo≈øt 5 Months.

12. Richard II. Son of Prince Edward called The Black Prince, and Grand≈øon of Edward III. was Traiterou≈øly depo≈øed by his Co≈øin Henry Duke of Hereford and Lanca≈øter, the 29 of September, 1399. and after murthered in Pri≈øon the 14 day of February following, in Pomfret Ca≈øtle. He Reigned 22 Years, 3 Months, and 8 Days.

div.head: The Lanca≈øtrian Line.
div.p: 13. Henry IV. Duke of Lanca≈øter, (Son of John of Gant, fourth Son of King Edward the Third) traiterou≈øly and villainou≈øly taking up Arms again≈øt his Prince, cau≈øed Richard the Second to be depo≈øed, and made him≈øelf King. He ≈øpent his whole Reign in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of home-bred Rebellions. He died the 20 of March, 1412. in the 46 Year of his Age. He Reigned 13 Years, and 6 Months, wanting 10 Days.

14. Henry V. Son of Henry IV. the Mirror of Magnificence, and pa≈ø≈øing ≈øwift in running. He was of New-College in Oxford, under the Government of Henry de Beaufort his Uncle on the Fathers ≈øide, then Chancellor of Oxford. He Conquered France, and died in the Ca≈øtle of Boys de Vincennes, not far from Paris, the la≈øt day of Augu≈øt, 1422. He Reigned 9 Years, 5 Months, and 10 Days.

15. Henry VI. Son of Henry V. an Infant of 8 Months old; a Pious but Unfortunate Prince. He was Crowned King of France in Paris, 7 Decembris, 1431. which he held during the Life of his Uncle John Duke of Bedford, Regent of France: But afterwards, he did not onely lo≈øe all France again, but England al≈øo, to the Duke of York's Faction, who claimed the Crown of England in right of Anne, Grandmother to Edward IV. and Daughter to Roger Mortimer Earl of March, Son of Edmund Mortimer by Philippa Daughter and Heir of Lionel Duke of Clarence, third Son of Edward III. and Elder Brother of John of Gant. He Reigned 38 Years, 6 Months, and 4 Days.

div.head: Kings of the Duke of York's Line.
div.p:
16. Edward IV. Son of Richard Duke of York, challenged the Crown as afore≈øaid; and prevailing in ≈øeveral Battels again≈øt Henry VI. was Crowned King of England
the fourth of March, 1460. Yet Henry VI. was Crowned again, 13 die Octobris, 1470. But he enjoyed his Title of Redemption but a while; for he died about ≈øix Months after, to wit, in Anno 1471. having lived 52 Years. He Reigned 22 Years, 1 Month, and odd Days.
This Edward the Fourth died the ninth of April, 1483. aged 41 Years. He was the fir≈øt of all the Norman Kings who married his own Subject.Anno Chr. 1483.

17. Edward V. Son of Edward IV. was never Crowned, but murthered by his Uncle Richard Duke of Gloce≈øter, Protector, in June, 1483. in the thirteenth Year of his Age, in the Tower of London. He Reigned two Months.

18. Richard III. younge≈øt Brother of King Edward IV. being Protector to the late young King, and di≈øpatching him and his Brother out of the way, u≈øurpeth the Crown. He was ≈ølain at Bo≈øworth-field in Leyce≈øter≈øhire, the 22 day of Augu≈øt, 1485. He Reigned 2 Years, and 2 Months.

div.head: The Union of the Two Families, Lanca≈øter and York.
div.p: 19. Henry VII. Earl of Richmond, next Heir to the Hou≈øe of Lanca≈øter, (as Son of Edmund That Edmund was called Edmund of Haddam, Son of Owen Tudor by Queen Katharine, the Widow of Henry the Fifth. Tudor by Margaret Daughter of John Duke of Somer≈øet, de≈øcended of John of Gant Duke of Lanca≈øter) after the Overthrow given by him unto Richard the Third at Bo≈øworth, married Elizabeth Daughter and Heir to King Edward the Fourth, and ≈øo United the Families. He died at Richmond the 22 day of April, 1509. after he had Reigned 23 Years, and 8 Months.

20. Henry VIII. Son of Henry VII. Heir to both Families. He ≈øhaked off the Pope's Supremacy in this Nation, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed the Mona≈øteries, and began the Reformation of Religion in England. A Prince of great Vices, and of great Vertues. He wrote a Book again≈øt Luther, for which Pope Leo X. gave him by Charter the Title of [Defender of the Faith;] dated 1521. Herbert's Hi≈øt. of Hen. 8. pag. 95. Which Title hath ever ≈øince been u≈øed by his Succe≈ø≈øors. He died at We≈øtmin≈øter the 28. of January, 1546. having Reigned 37 Years, 9 Months, and 6 Days.

Tru≈ø≈øel's Hi≈øtory, pag. 263. ≈øaith, There peri≈øhed in the Civil Wars between the the Hou≈øes of Lanca≈øter and York,
Two Kings.
One Prince.
Ten Dukes.
Two Marque≈ø≈øes.
Twenty one Earls.
Twenty ≈øeven Lords.
Two Vi≈øcounts.
One Lord Prior of St. Johns of Jeru≈øalem.
One Judge.
139 Knights.
441 E≈øquires.
84998 Common Per≈øons.

Dr. Heylyn in his Co≈ømography, pag. 320. accounts thus:
Seventeen Pitched Fields.
Eight Kings and Princes ≈ølain.
Forty Dukes, Marque≈ø≈øes, and Earls.
200000 Common People.
Be≈øides Barons and Gentlemen.

21. Edward VI. Son of Henry VIII. by Jane Seymour; a Child. He died at Greenwich, 6 die Julii 1553. about 15 Years old. In his time Prie≈øts were allowed to Marry. See Stat. 2 & 3 Edw. 6. cap. 21. He Reigned 6 Years, 5 Months, and 8 days.

22. Queen Mary, Daughter of Henry VIII. by Katherine of Spain, his Brother Arthur's Widow, lo≈øt Caliz to the French, 1557. A Bloody Queen. She married Philip King of Spain, 25 die Julii 1554. And ≈øhe died at St. Jame≈øes Hou≈øe in London, the 17 of November, 1558. She ≈øet up Popery, and Reigned 5 Years, 4 Months, and 11 Days.

23. Queen Elizabeth, Daughter of Henry VIII. by the Lady Anne of Bullein his ≈øecond Wife: A mo≈øt Gracious Heroick Prince≈øs. She perfected and refined the Reformation of Religion begun by her Father; furni≈øhed the Royal Navy with all Warlike
Ammunitions; ≈øuccoured the Scots again≈øt the French, and the French Prote≈øtants again≈øt the Papi≈øts; defended the Netherlands again≈øt the Attempts of the Spaniards; commanded the Whole Ocean; entred League with the Mu≈øcovite; and was mo≈øt Famous in the Prudent Government of her Kingdom, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by mo≈øt Wi≈øe and Able State≈ømen and Privy-Coun≈øellors about her, as any Prince in Chri≈øtendom had; and (which is mo≈øt rare) were all Faithful and Loyal to her. She died the 24 day of March, 1602. which is the la≈øt Day of the Year, according to the Computation of the Church of England, at Richmond in Surrey, aged 70 Years. She reigned 44 Years, 4 Months, and 7 Days.

div.head: The Scotch Line, Kings and Monarchs of all Great-Brettaine and Ireland.
div.p: 24. James VI. King of Scotland (Son of Mary Queen of Scots, Anno Chr. 1602. Daughter and Heir of James V. Son of James IV. and of the Lady Margaret elde≈øt Daughter of Henry the Seventh, King of England) was Proclaimed King of England in London, March 24. 1602. as the next undoubted Heir to the Crown of England. A Learned and Religious Prince; of whom the Lord Bacon ≈øaith, in his Advancement of Learning, pa. 2. It is no Amplification, but a po≈øitive and mea≈øured Truth, That there was not ≈øo Learned a Temporal Monarch ≈øince Chri≈øt's time, in all Literature Divine and Humane, as this King James. Of whom ≈øee more in Scotland. He died at Theobalds the 27 of March, 1625. aged 60 Years. He was the fir≈øt Monarch of all Great-Brettaine. He Reigned 22 Years and 3 Days.

25. Charles I. Son of James VI. of Scotland, was overpowred by the Puritanical Faction in England, confederate with the Covenanters of Scotland, who began their Rebellion in England, Anno 1642. which continued, by the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Rebellious Parliament of England, until the Year 1660. mi≈øerably ruinating both our Church and State. And the≈øe Rebels murthered this Good King the 30 day of January 1648. in the 49 Year of his Age, and bani≈øhed his Children. He Reigned 23 Years, 10 Months, and 3 Days.

26. Charles II. Son of Charles I. was kept out of his Kingdoms till after the death of Oliver Cromwel the Traytor, ≈øtiled the Protector; but was after Re≈øtored, and Returned to his Kingdoms the 29 day of May, Anno Domini 1660. chiefly next under God (who di≈øpo≈øeth and ordereth the Hearts of all Men) by the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Colonel George Monk, who then had the Command of all the Forces in Scotland and England Principally, and was afterwards made Duke of Albemarle by this King, as well he de≈øerved.

div.head: Of the Dukes of Normandy before William the Conqueror.
div.p: II. THe Dukes of Normandy (from whence our Norman Kings of England afore≈øaid are de≈øcended) are the Progeny of Rollo the Dane, who invaded the Province of Neu≈øtria in France with a great Army; which becau≈øe they con≈øi≈øted of Men brought out of the North part of the World, they were called Normans, and that Province of France was called Normannia in Latin: For in the Saxon Language of our Ance≈øtors, Normans denotes as much as Populi Septentrionales in the Latine: And were a People (as Cambden ≈øaith) commixt of Norwegians, Swedes, and Danes.

1. This Rollo took Baieux in Normandy by Storm, and ≈ølew Berengarius Earl thereof, and after married Popa Daughter of the ≈øaid Berengarius, on whom he begot William afterwards Duke of Normandy, ≈øirnamed Longe≈øp√©e, becau≈øe of the long Sword he u≈øed to wear: And Rollo much perplexed the French by his daily Rapines, overrunning
almo≈øt all France to Burgundy: At la≈øt, for the Mediation of a Peace, Charles the Simple, King of France, gave unto him all the Land of Normandy, from the River Epta to the Sea, to be held by Homage from the Kings of France, with Gi≈øta his Daughter in Marriage, (Popa his former Wife being now either dead or divorced:) Whereupon Rollo was Bapti≈øed by Franco Archbi≈øhop of Roan, Anno Chr. 917.
Anno Domini 912. And he was the fir≈øt Duke of Normandy, and died Anno Chri≈øti nati 917. Ordericus Vitalis, lib. 3. ad initium. Will. Gemeticen≈øis, lib. 2. cap. 12, & 17.
2. William ≈øirnamed Longe≈øp√©e, Duke of Normandy, was Son of Rollo: Slain Anno Chri≈øti 942.
3. Richard I. Duke of Normandy, Son of William, was but 10 Years old when his Father was ≈ølain. He was Duke 54 Years.

4. Anno 996. Richard II. (Son of Richard I. by Gunnor, fir≈øt his Concubine, and after his Wife. Gemeticen≈øis, lib. 8. cap. 36.) ≈øucceeded Duke of Normandy, and was Duke 30 Years. He had two Sons, who ≈øucceeded Dukes one after another, Richard, and Robert, be≈øides other Children.
5. Anno 1026. Richard III. Son of Richard II. ≈øucceeded Duke of Normandy, and was Duke ≈øcarce a Year and a half.
6. Anno 1028. Robert, Brother to Richard III. ≈øucceeded Duke; and after he had been Duke ≈øeven Years and a half, he died at the City of Nice in Bithynia, Anno 1035.

7. William (Ba≈øtard Son of Robert by Arlet, or Herlue as ≈øome write her, a Skinners Daughter of Faloys in Normandy. Chronicon Joh. Bromton, pag. 910.) a Child of eight Years of Age, ≈øucceeded Duke of Normandy, and was Duke 53 Years: Ordericus, lib. 3. in initio. In the 32 Year of his Dukedom, to wit, Anno 1066. he Conquered England, and is commonly called William the Conqueror. Robert Curtho≈øe, elde≈øt Son of the Conqueror, was after his Father al≈øo Duke of Normandy.
See the re≈øt above, pag. 32. among the Norman Kings of England.
‚öú Normandy was lo≈øt to the French in the Reign of King John, Anno 1204. Mat. Paris, pag. 212.
Normandy won again from the French by Henry V. Anno 1416.
Normandy lo≈øt again by Henry VI. Anno 1449.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: Of the Name of Wales, and De≈øcription of the Countrey.

div.p: I. THe Name of Wales was impo≈øed from our Saxon Ance≈øtors: For the Ancient Brettans being beaten out of England by the Saxons, fled into the We≈øt Parts of Brettaine, being naturally fortified with great Mountains, and Overflowings of the Sea; to wit, into that Part now called Wales, and into Cornwal: But the Brettans of Cornwal, though they ≈øtoutly endeavoured to defend their Country, yet were they ≈øoon forced to leave it to the Saxons.

Cambden and Ver≈øtegan tell us, That the Saxons termed all Aliens and Strangers Wal≈øh. And hence they called the≈øe Inhabitants (becau≈øe Strangers unto them) by the name of Wal≈øh-men, and their Countrey Wales.

But more probable it is, that fora≈ømuch as they be de≈øcended from the ancient Gaules, their Neighbors, in Latin termed Galli, by the French, Galles, which the Saxons pronounce Walles, and from whence Walles-man, and now corruptly Wel≈øh-man; it ≈øeems to me to be thence called Wales, as one ≈øhould ≈øay, The Countrey of the Waules, or Walles: And in ancient Latin Authors it is many times ≈øtiled Guallia, and the Inhabitants thereof Gualli; and every Man knows how the Saxons in mo≈øt Words do u≈øe W for G; as War for Guerre, Ward for Guard, and the like: And at this day the French ≈øtile the elde≈øt Son of the King of England, Le Prince de Galles. The ancient Galli were called Cimbri, or Kimbri, und√® Cambro-Britannia is u≈øed for Wales, and Cambro-Britannus for a Wel≈øhman. And ask the≈øe Cambro-Brittans, or Wel≈øh-Brittans, how they call them≈øelves, they will pre≈øently tell you, Kimeri, or Kumeri; which ≈øounds as much as Kimbri, or Kymbry, now in Latin molded into Cambri.

How≈øoever the Name came, the Inhabitants of Wales at this day are the Remnant of the Ancient Brettans; but not without great commixture of the Engli≈øh their Neighbors, which mu≈øt needs follow in ≈øo long a Tract of time: And yet have they pre≈øerved their Native Language, but with ≈øome corruption of various Dialects.

For the De≈øcription of Wales, it was anciently bounded from England with the Rivers of Dee and Severn; all the re≈øt of it, almo≈øt, is bounded with the Iri≈øh Seas: But Offa, the Pui≈ø≈øant King of the Mercians in England, drave the Brettans from the Rivers afore≈øaid, and forced them up to the Mountains of Wales, where he cau≈øed them to be divided from England by a very great Ditch, called by the Engli≈øh, Offa's Dike, at this day. This was about the Year ≈øince Chri≈øt's Birth 760. and it began at the River Dee by Ba≈øing-werk, between Che≈øter and Ruthlan, and ≈øo ran along the ≈øides of the Hills to
the South Sea, a little from Bri≈øtow, reaching near a hundred Miles in length, and is in many places yet to be ≈øeen. The Countrey between it and England, is commonly called by the Wel≈øh,-Y Mars; though the greate≈øt part of it be now inhabited with Wel≈øhmen, namely in North-Wales, which yet keepeth the ancient Limits to the River Dee, or Dwy, and in ≈øome Places over it. Powell on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 5.
According to Cambden, it was divided into the≈øe ≈øorts of Inhabitants, in the time of the Romans, and before.
But this was long before it had the Name of Wales.

list.item:
Silures
Hereford≈øhire.
Radnor≈øhire.
Brecknock≈øhire.
Monmouth≈øhire.
Glamorgan≈øhire.

Dimetae
Caermarden≈øhire.
Pembroke≈øhire.
Cardigan≈øhire.

Ordovices
Montgomery≈øhire.
Merioneth≈øhire. North-Wales.
Caernarvan≈øhire. North-Wales.
I≈øle of Angle≈øey. North-Wales.
Denbigh≈øhire. North-Wales.
Flint≈øhire. North-Wales.

div.p: About the Year of Chri≈øt 870. Roderik the Great, then Prince of Wales, divided it into three Parts or Territories, which they called Kingdoms.

North-Wales.1. Guinedh, in Latin, Venedotia, which the Engli≈øh call North-Wales, comprehending the Counties of Merioneth, Caernarvan, The I≈øle of M√¥n or Angle≈øey, and the greate≈øt parts of Denbigh≈øhire and Flint≈øhire. This had, as it were, the Sovereignty of the other two, who≈øe Chief Seat was Aberfraw in Angle≈øey, which little I≈øland the Wel≈øh call Yir-M√¥n, that is, The Land of M√¥n. This Part Roderik gave to Anarawd his elde≈øt Son.

Powys.2. Mathraval, or Powys-land. This Territory containeth all the Country of Powys, and the Land between Wye and Severn; to wit the whole Counties (as they be now called) of Montgomery, Radnor, and all Shrop≈øhire from Severn towards Wales, and the re≈øt of Denbigh≈øhire and Flint≈øhire. The chiefe≈øt Towns herein are St. A≈øaph, Shrew≈øbury, and Matraval. This Territory Roderik gave to Mervin his third Son.

South-Wales.3. Deheubarth, in Latin, Dimetia, which the Engli≈øh call South-Wales, contained the Counties (as we now call them) of Monmouth, Glamorgan, Pembroke, Caermarden, Cardigan, and Brecknock. The Chief Seat was Caermarden, after removed to Denevowr-Ca≈øtle: The Chief Towns thereof, Caermarden, Monmouth, Landaff, and St. David's in Pembroke≈øhire, ≈øo called from St. David ≈øometime Archbi≈øhop thereof, the Metropolitan of Wales, who removed the See from Caer-Leon upon Usk to this Place. St. Davids is by the Wel≈øh called Mynyw, whence in Latin it is termed Menevia. And this Part Roderik gave to Cadelh his ≈øecond Son, who after the death of Mervin his Brother, took Powys-Land al≈øo to him≈øelf.

Of the≈øe three Parts, Roderik had North-Wales in right of his Mother E≈øylht; and Powys, in right of his Grandmother Ne≈øt, Daughter of Cadelh Prince of Powys; and South-Wales he had (as ≈øome ≈øay) by his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Meyric Prince of Cardigan. Powell on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 35.

div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p: THe Counties of Wales (as they now ≈øtand divided) were apppointed out as followeth.

1 Glamogan≈øhire.
2 Caermarthen≈øhire.
3 Pembroke≈øhire.
4 Cardigan≈øhire.
5 Flint≈øhire.
6 Caernarvon≈øhire.
7 Angle≈øey.
8 Merioneth≈øhire.
The≈øe Shires were newly appointed out Anno Domini 1283. 11 Edw. 1. ≈øaith Stow. In which Year Wales was totally ≈øubdued by Edw. 1. who built two ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles there, one at Conwey, the other at Caernarvon; and then newly divided Wales into Shires and Hundreds.

9 Monmouth≈øhire.
10 Radnor≈øhire.
11 Brecknock≈øhire.
12 Montgomery≈øhire.
13 Denbigh≈øhire.
The≈øe five were appointed by the Statute of 27 Hen. 8. ca. 26. and al≈øo divers Dominions and Lord≈øhips in the Marches of Wales, were then al≈øo annexed to Shrop≈øhire, Hereford≈øhire, and Gloce≈øter≈øhire.
And by the Statute afore≈øaid of 27 Hen. 8. cap. 26. Anno Domini 1535. the Dominion of Wales is from henceforth incorporated, united, and annexed to the Realm of England.

In the Statute of 34 Hen. 8. cap. 26. they are called The Twelve Shires of Wales, becau≈øe Monmouth was by the other Statute of 27 H. 8. ≈øubjected to the Chancery of England, and to the Kings Judges at We≈øtmin≈øter, and therefore accounted among the Counties of England, and not among the Counties of Wales.
And by the Statute of 34 & 35 Hen. 8. cap. 26. there is a Pre≈øident and Council appointed to the Principality of tho≈øe 12 Shires of Wales.
And that the Judge of Che≈øter for the time being, ≈øhall keep Se≈ø≈øions twice every Year in the Shires of Denbigh, Flint, and Montgomery.
And that there be a Judge of North-Wales, to keep Se≈ø≈øions twice every Year in the ≈øeveral Shires of Caernarvan, Merioneth, and Angle≈øey.
And another Judge, in like manner, for the Shires of Radnor, Brecknock, and Glamorgan.
And another Judge, in like manner, for the Shires of Caermarthen, Pembroke, and Cardigan.
It appears al≈øo by the ≈øame Statute, that the King had lately granted Commi≈ø≈øions out of the Chancery of England, for the Limitations of the Hundreds lately made in the ≈øaid Shires.

It is al≈øo to be remembred, That by the Statute of 33 Hen. 8. cap. 13. the Honour of Hawarden-Ca≈øtle, with its Members, to wit, certain Villages in the Pari≈øh of Hawarden (which formerly belonged to Broxton-Hundred in Che≈øhire) were now laid to Flint≈øhire by that Act of Parliament.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p: THe Wel≈øhmen embraced the Reformation of Religion according to the Church of England, in Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, and Wor≈øhip; the Liturgy whereof was by Queen Elizabeth's Command tran≈ølated into the Wel≈øh or Briti≈øh Tongue, as the BIBLE al≈øo by an Act of Parliament, 5 Eliz. 1563. But becau≈øe that Church-Bible then ≈øet forth (the Care whereof was committed to the Bi≈øhop of Hereford, and the four Bi≈øhops of Wales) was of a large Bulk, it was reduced into a more portable Volume in the beginning of the Reign of King Charles the Fir≈øt, at the Charge of Rowland Heylyn Alderman of London, who cau≈øed al≈øo a Wel≈øh Dictionary to be Printed. Dr. Heylyn's Co≈ømography, pag. 323.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p: I Come now to the Ancient De≈øcent of the Brettans and Wel≈øh. I have before ≈øpoken ≈øomething hereunto, concerning the Ancient Inhabitants of Brettaine, when I treated of England, cap. 1. ≈øect. 5. Supra, pag. 10.

I have now to add, That in the fir≈øt place I mu≈øt crave leave to note the ridiculous and fabulous Story and De≈øcent of Brute, with the long Series of Kings downwards from him to Ca≈ø≈øibelaun, to the number of 70 in a direct Line: Which Brute the≈øe Brettans would have to live when Eli Judged the People of I≈ørael, and the Ark of God was taken by the Phili≈øtines, about Anno Mundi Conditi 2849. & ant√® Chri≈øtum 1100 Years: And ≈øo Brettaine mu≈øt have a King, before the Jews had any. Where is to be ob≈øerved, That this Hi≈øtory of Brute was rather devi≈øed to amaze and mi≈øguide Po≈øterity, than po≈ø≈øibly to be believed; and that by an impudent lying Author, Geffrey of Monmouth, who lived but about the Year of Chri≈øt 1160. and 2260 Years after Brute lived, as they place the time, without ≈øo much as vouching any one Author for any thing thereof; which Geffrey was taxed for a lying Author by William of Newbury, a Man living in the ≈øame Age with him: The words of William concerning that Geffrey ≈øee before in this Book, pag. 10.. Vide eti√†m Docti≈ø≈øimum Cambdenum in Britanni√¢ ≈øu√¢, pag. 4, & 5.

And Sir John Pri≈øe, in his Book de Britannicae Hi≈øtoriae Defen≈øione, Printed fir≈øt ≈øub Anno Chri≈øti 1573. pag. 63. tells us, There were anciently various Opinions concerning this Brute, whence he was originally de≈øcended; and that there was an old Book found by him in Wales not long ago, with the name of Gildas writ upon it, which mentioned two Opinions therein. One, which was the common Opinion, That Brute was the fourth in De≈øcent from Aeneas King of the Latins, to wit, Son of Silvius Po≈øthumus, Son of A≈øcanius, Son of Aeneas. The other hath his De≈øcent up to Noah, in this ≈øort:
1 Noah.
2 Japheth.
3 Javan.
4 Jabaath.
5 Joan.
6 Baath.
7 I≈øran.
8 Ezra.
9 Ra.
10 Abir.
11 Oth.
12 Ecthecht.
13 Aurthach.
14 Mair.
15 Simeon.
16 Boib.
17 Theor, or Thoi.
18 Ougomum.
19 Fethebir.
20 Alaunius.
21 He≈ø≈øi≈øcion.
22 Brutus.
So that we ≈øee Brute mu≈øt be made a True Trojan, and to be de≈øcended from Javan Son of Japhet, from whom the Ionians and Grecians (as Jo≈øephus ≈øaith) were propagated.

Here, by the way, ob≈øerve, That St. Luke reckons up onely 66 De≈øcents between Sem and Chri≈øt, cap. 3. Yet the De≈øcent of Ca≈ø≈øibelan (who lived a little before the time of Chri≈øt's Birth) mu≈øt be made to contain 70 De≈øcents to Brute, and 22 more to Noah, in all 92 De≈øcents to Noah: So they will make ≈øure to give the Brettans De≈øcents enough. But there is no Man well ver≈øed in Hi≈øtories and Antiquities, that doth not plainly ≈øee a heap of great Uncertainties and Fal≈øities in the De≈øcents touching Brute, which ≈øome ob≈øcure Impo≈øtor hath foi≈øted in, to the delu≈øion of meaner Capacities: So that I do conceive they are meritoriou≈øly all to be exploded utterly.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: BUt ≈øo far as good Authority of Approved Authors will direct me, I ≈øhall now put down. Fir≈øt then, it is certain that the Brettans Inhabited this I≈øland in Julius Cae≈øar's Age, and before; and it is probable they inhabited here ≈øome hundreds of Years before: but when fir≈øt inhabited, appeareth not by any good Hi≈øtorian. It is agreed by the mo≈øt Learned Men, that before Cae≈øar we have no certaine Hi≈øtory of Brettain left us; and that the Druids of the Brettans (who were their mo≈øt Learned Men) never committed any thing to writing.

I ≈øhall therefore begin with what Rulers of Brettaine I find recorded in Cae≈øar's time, and downwards; I mean, of the Brettans who Ruled, (for I have already ≈øet down the Roman Rulers of Brettaine ≈øupra, pag. 13. & deinceps; who indeed ca≈øhir'd the Brettans, and their Authority) beginning with Ca≈ø≈øibellaun, and vouching my Authors all along.

1. Ca≈ø≈øivellaun: He was Chief Ruler of Brettaine, Anno ant√® Chri≈øtum Natum 54. Cae≈øar ≈øaith of him, Summa Imperii Bell√≠que admini≈øtrandi, Communi Concilio, Permi≈ø≈øa e≈øt Ca≈ø≈øivellauno; Lib. 5. de Bello Gallico, pag. 154. of the Edition with Montanus Notes, Printed 1651. So that it ≈øhould ≈øeem he was not a King born, but made. I find him not any where ≈øtiled Rex Britanniae by Cae≈øar. He is al≈øo called Ca≈ø≈øibeline; and by Dio, Suellan: So Montanus in his Notes upon Cae≈øar, pag. 154. Perhaps the Name Ca≈ø≈øibelline is derived from Ca≈ø≈øi, a People of Hartford≈øhire: The Reliques of their Name we have yet in Ca≈øhow-Hundred: And ≈øo Ca≈ø≈øibelin ≈øounds as much as Ca≈ø≈øorum Princeps, or Prince of the Ca≈ø≈øians: Cambden's Britannia, in his Preface before Buckingham≈øhire, ≈øpeaking of the Cattieuclani. The Town of Ca≈ø≈øibelaun, mentioned by Cae≈øar, was St. Albons in Hartford≈øhire, called Verulamium by Tacitus: Cambden in Hartford≈øhire.

We find al≈øo four Kings of Kent mentioned by Cae≈øar, all living at the ≈øame time with Ca≈ø≈øibelaun. Cae≈øar lib. 5. pag. 64.
Cingetorix.
Carvilius.
Taximagulus.
Segonax.
Al≈øo Mandubratius, Son of Imanuentius, King of the Trinobants, that is, of Middle≈øex and E≈ø≈øex: Cae≈øar, pag. 162. living al≈øo at the ≈øame time. He ≈øubmitted to Cae≈øar.
Al≈øo Comius King of the Atrebatii, or Bark≈øhire: Cae≈øar, pag. 133. He ≈øubmitted to Cae≈øar. Anno Chr. 30.

2. Cunobelin, or Cynbeline, King of the Ea≈øt part of Brettaine, who≈øe Seat or Palace was at Maldon in E≈ø≈øex, in Latin called Camalodunum: Cambden in E≈ø≈øex. He had three Sons: Adminius, bani≈øhed by his Father Anno Chri≈øti 38. in the time of Caligula the Emperor of Rome; Cataratacus and Togodumnus, two other Sons, overcome in Battel by Aulus Plautius the Roman Propraetor of Brettaine, after Cunobelin was dead. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 29, 30. Vide etiam pag. 323. This was about Anno Chri≈øti 43. in the time of Claudius.

Maldon was taken by O≈øtorius, Propraetor Britanniae in the time of Claudius the Emperor. It was made the fir≈øt Colony of the Romans in Brettaine, Anno Claudii 12. Ann√≥que Chri≈øti 52. Cambden in E≈ø≈øex, pag. 323.

3. Caractacus, King of the Silures. He was taken Pri≈øoner by O≈øtorius, with his Wife, Daughter, and Brethren, and brought in Triumph to Rome, to Claudius the Emperor. Tacitus, lib. 12. Annalium, cap. 35, 36.
Carthi≈ømandua was about the ≈øame time Queen of the Brigantes.

Cogidunus, another Petty King in Brettaine, living at the ≈øame time, to whom certain Towns in Brettaine were a≈ø≈øigned by the Romans; it being an ancient Cu≈øtom of the
Romans long time ago (≈øaith Tacitus) to have even Kings In≈øtruments of Servitude. De Vit√¢ Agricolae, cap. 14.

Caractacus above mentioned, is by Dio called Cataracatus; by others, Catacratus; by Zonaras, Caratacus; and by the Brettans, Caradoc. Lip≈øius in his Comment on Tacitus, lib. 12. Annalium, pag. 196. Perhaps he was the Son of Cunobeline.

4. Pra≈øutagus, King of the Iceni in Brettaine, that is, of Suffolk, Norfolk, Cambridge≈øhire, Anno Chr. 62. and Huntington≈øhire: He made Nero the Emperor, and his own two Daughters his Heirs, thinking hereby to procure favour with Nero: But the Romans after his Death did beat Boadicia his Wife, and Ravi≈øh her Daughters; whereupon the Iceni and Trinobants rebelled. Tacitus, lib. 14. Annalium cap. 31.

5. Arviragus Bretannus Floret, in the time of Domitian Emperor of Rome.
Camb. Britann. pag. 43.

6. Lucius, King of the Brettans, received the Chri≈øtian Faith. Bede de Hi≈øt. lib. Angl. cap. 4. See the Epi≈øtle of Eleutherius, dated Anno Chri≈øti 169, in the fir≈øt Tome of Spelman's Coun≈øels, pag. 34. with his Notes thereon, whereby the Letter ≈øeems to be fictitious.
This Lucius, King of the Brettans, died Anno Gratiae 201, at Gloce≈øter, ≈øaith Matth. We≈øtmin≈øter.

So much of the Briti≈øh Kings whom I find mentioned during the time of the Rule of the Romans in Brettaine; now follow the Briti≈øh Kings whom I find mentioned after the Rule of the Romans cea≈øed in Brettaine, and after the coming in of the Saxons.

Vortiger; he was King of the Brettans when the Saxons fir≈øt came into Brettaine; he began his Reign Anno Chri≈øti 425. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 95. Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. lib. 1. cap. 21. Spelman's Councels, Tom. 1. pag. 49. where he placeth the Councel again≈øt the ince≈øtuous Marriage of Vortiger with his own Daughter, in Anno 449. ≈øomewhat too late I conceive. By the Wiles of this Vortiger was Con≈øtantine ≈ølain; Homo nobilis & domi clarus; whom the Brettons made their King, a Man of their own Stock, and fetched from Little Brettaine in France. So Buchanan, Rerum Scoticarum, lib. 5. pag. 139.
Vortimer, Son of Vortiger, died Anno 463. with whom fell the hope of Brettaine. Matth. We≈øtmin≈øter.

Aurelius Conanus.
Vortipor.
Maglocunus.
Cunegla≈øus.
The≈øe Hi≈øtorians place to ≈øucceed one annother in their Rule, when it is plain in Gildas (who ≈øpeaks to every one of them) that they lived all at a time, and tyrannized in divers and ≈øeveral parts of Brettaine at once. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 81. about the Year of Chri≈øt 550 or 560.

Nazaleod, the Great King of the Brettans, routed by Cerdic, the fir≈øt King of the We≈øt-Saxons, at Certicsford, and 5000 Brettans ≈ølain. Huntington pag. 312. which Countrey or Place was before called Nazaleod, or (as ≈øome write it) Natanleod, after the King's Name; but after the Victory of Certic here, it was called Certicsford, now called contractedly Chartford, ≈øituate in Hant≈øhire. Cambden's Britannia, in Hant≈øhire, pag. 187. Vide Florentium, pag. 206.

Arthur, Bellico≈øi≈ø≈øimus Britonum Heros, buried at Gla≈ø≈øenbury. Cambden's Britannia, in Somer≈øet≈øhire; of whom the Wel≈øh Bards in their Songs have recorded ≈øuch Fables, that they have ca≈øt a doubt, whether there were ≈øuch a Man or no. Huntington calls him Dux militum & Regum Britannia, duodecies Dux Belli fuit, duodecies victor contr√† Saxones, pag. 313. This famous General lived about Anno 520. Cambden ≈øaith he was called Mab-uter, id e≈øt, Filius horribilis; qui√† √† pueriti√¢ fuit horribilis; & Artur Britannic√® ≈øonat, ur≈øum horribilem. In Britanni√¢ ≈øu√¢, pag. 167. He is called Inclitus Rex Arturius, as it is In≈øcribed on his Stone found at Gla≈ø≈øenbury.

Gerent, King of Wales, routed by Ina, King of the We≈øt-Saxons. Huntington, pag. 337. Anno Regni Inae 21, annoque Chri≈øti circiter 710. He is the fir≈øt that I find ≈øtyled King of Wales in expre≈øs terms.

Cadwallader, the la≈øt King of the Britons. Powel in his Notes upon the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, Engli≈øhed by Homfrey Lhoyd, Printed 1584, pag. 8. ≈øaith, That ≈øome do hold, that
Cadwallader and Cedwall are all one, and that whom the Saxons call Cedwall (who was King of the We≈øt-Saxons, Anno 688 to 690.) the Brittons called Cadwallader, and whom the Engli≈øh Chronicles call Ine, King of the We≈øt-Saxons, the ≈øame is called Ivor in the the Briti≈øh or Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory: And this Ivor the Brettaines call the Son of Alan, King of Little-Brettaine-Armorik in France: But the Saxons ≈øay he was the Son of Kentwyn, King of the We≈øt-Saxons.
Cadwallader had a Son called Edwall Ywrch, that is, Edwall the Roe-Buck, ≈øaith the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, who was the Father of Roderic, Pag. 23.

So much of the petty Kings of the Britons, as I find them mentioned in more ≈øub≈øtantial Authors, during the time of the Power of the Saxons in England. Now follow the Kings of the Briti≈øh Race, ≈øince they were quite expelled out of England by the Saxons, and driven into the Mountains of Wales, and began to get Head again: and herein I chiefly follow the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, put out by Powel, 1584.

Anno Chr. 720. 1. Roderike or Roderi, Son of Edwall Ywrch, began his Reign over the Britons in Wales, Anno 720. and obtained a Victory again≈øt Ethelred, King of We≈øt≈øex in Cornwall; obiit 750. He Reigned 30 Years.
2. Conan Tindaethwy, Son of Roderik, in the Year 817. cha≈øed his Brother Howel out of the I≈øle of Mon or Angle≈øey, who fled into the I≈øle of Man, and ≈øhortly after died Conan.
3. Mervin Vrych, and E≈øylht his Wife, Daughter of Conan.

Anno 841 died Idwalhon, a Nobleman of Wales; and Anno 843 Mervin was ≈ølain (as ≈øome do write) in the Battel between Beorrhed, King of Mercia, and the Brettaines at Kettell, leaving a Son called Roderi-Mawr, that is, Roderik the Great.

4. Roderik Mawr, that is, Roderik the Great. He divided Wales into three parts; Northwales, which he gave to Anarawd his elde≈øt Son, as the chief Prince; Southwales, which he gave to his ≈øecond Son; and Powy≈øland, which he gave to his third Son. But Giraldus Cambren≈øis in his De≈øcriptio Cambriae, cap. 3. ≈øaith, that Mervin was his elde≈øt Son, and had Northwales; and Anarawd had Powy≈øland, who died without I≈ø≈øue.
5. Anarawd, Son of Roderik, Prince of Wales, Obiit 913.
6. Edwal Vowel, Son of Anarawd, King or Prince of Northwales. He and his Brother Eli≈øe were ≈ølain in a Battel again≈øt the Danes and Engli≈øhmen. He was Tributary to Athel≈øtan King of England.
7. Howel Dha, Prince of Southwales and Powy≈øland, after the death of Edwal Vowel, took upon him the Rule of all Wales. He died Anno 948. and had four Sons, Owen, Run, Roderik, and Edwyn.

8. Jevaf and Jago, ≈øecond and third Sons of Edwal Vowel, Ruled Northwales; and the Sons of Howel-Dha divided Southwales and Powyis betwixt them. Anno 966. Jago impri≈øoned his Brother Jevaf. Howel, Son of Jevaf, rai≈øeth an Army to ≈øet his Father at liberty, and cha≈øed his Uncle Jago out of the Land. Howel had three Brothers, Meyric, Jevaf, and Cadwalhon.

9. Howel, Son of Jevaf, having expelled his Uncle, took upon him the Rule of Northwales, Anno 979. Edwal Vachan, Son of Edwal Vowel, was ≈ølain by this Howel his Nephew: and Anno 984. Howel entring England with an Army, was ≈ølain in Battel. He had no Son, but Cadwalhon his Brother Reigned in his place.

10. Cadwalhon, Brother of Howel, was Prince of Northwales; he fir≈øt made War with Jonaval his Co≈øin, the Son of Meyric, and right Heir to the Land, and ≈ølew him; and the year following Meredith, Son of Owen, Prince of Southwales, ≈ølew Cadwalhon in Fight, with Meyric, Brother of Cadwalhon al≈øo.

11. Meredyth ap Owen, now King of all Wales. Godfryd, Son of Harold, entred the I≈øle of Angle≈øey the third time, and having taken Lhywarch, the Son of Owen, with 2000 Pri≈øoners, cruelly put out his Eyes; whereupon Meredyth the King, with the re≈øt, e≈øcap'd to Cardigan.

Anno 987. died Jevaf Son of Edwal, who had many years led a private Life. al≈øo the ≈øame year died Owen, Son of Howel Dha, Prince of Southwales. Anno 991.
died Cadwalhon, the onely Son of Meredyth. Anno 992. the Wel≈øhmen cho≈øe Edwal, Son of Meric, the right Heir of Northwales, for their Prince. At Langwm, in a Battel between Edwal and Meredyth, was ≈ølain Theodor, or Tudor Mawr, the Nephew of Meredyth, who lo≈øt two Sons, Rees and Rytherch, and Elen a Daughter. Anno 998. died Meredyth ap Owen, Prince of Wales, leaving one onely Daughter, called Angharad, Married to Lhewelyn ap Sit≈øylht; and after his Death ≈øhe Married Conuyn Herdref, or (as others think) Conuyn ap Gweri≈øtan.

12. Edwal ap Meyric, the Son of Meredith, Anno Chr. 992. being now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Principality of Northwales, endeavored to keep it; but ≈øoon after, Swane, the Son of Harold, de≈øtroyed the I≈øle of Man, and entring into Northwales, ≈ølew Edwall the Prince thereof; which Edwall left behind him a Son called Jago.

13. Aedan, the Son of Blegored, u≈øurped Northwales, and killed Conan Son of Howel, one that then a≈øpired to the Government, Anno 1003. in open Field. He was ≈ølain with his four Sons by Lewelin in Battel, Anno 1015.
14. Lhewelyn ap Sit≈øylht, Prince of Wales: He was ≈ølain by Howel and Meredith, the Sons of Edwin, Anno 1021. leaving a Son called Griffith ap Lhewelyn.
15. Jago or James, ap Edwal, ap Meyric, ap Edwal Voel, took upon him the Government of Northwales as right Heir.
Rytherch, Son of Je≈øtyn, u≈øurped Southwales.
Jago was ≈ølain by Griffith ap Lhewelyn, 1037.
16. Griffith ap Lhewelin, ap Sit≈øylht, and Angharat. This Griffith was King of all Wales, and cha≈øed Howel and Edwin out of Southwales.

This Griffith Married Edgith This Edgith (after the Death of Griffith) Married Harold King of England. or Aldith, Daughter of Algar, Earl of Mercia in England, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Blethyn, Succe≈ø≈øor of his Dominion, and Ne≈øt a Daughter. Odericus Vitalis, lib. 3. pag. 492. & lib. 4. pag. 511. al≈øo Will. Gemeticen≈øis, lib. 7. cap. 31. He was a valiant Prince, and wa≈øted a great part of Hereford≈øhire, 1052. Sim. Dunelmen≈øis. Algar being bani≈øhed Anno 1055. he went into Ireland, where having got 18 Pyrate Ships, he came into Wales to King Griffith, who joyning Forces, routed the Engli≈øh about two Miles from Hereford, Nono Calendas Novembris. Sim. Dunelmen≈øis. Afterwards were both reconciled to the King of England.
Griffith was ≈ølain by his own Men, Nonas Augu≈øti 1064. and his Head being cut off, was ≈øent to Edward, ≈øirnamed The Confe≈ø≈øor, King of England. See al≈øo Ingulphus, pag. 899.

Anno 1070, William Fitz-Osborne, Earl of Hereford, with Walter Lacy and other ≈øtout Champions, were placed as a Curb to the Wel≈øh by William the Conqueror. The≈øe fir≈øt Invaded the People of Brecknock, and ≈ølew three Wel≈øh Kings or Princes, Rees, Cadogan, and Merydeth, and many other of the Wel≈øh. Ordericus, pag. 521. 522.

‚öú This King Griffith had two Brothers, Blethyn and Ruthyn, to whom Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor Anno 1065, gave Wales to be held of the King of England, Pro ≈øervitio debito, jurat√¢ Fidelitate. Ingulphus, pag. 899.
17. Blethyn, in Latine Blidenus, Son of Griffith, ≈øaith Ordericus; but the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory put out by Powel, pag. 103, calleth him Blethin Son of Conwin: He was King of Northwales at lea≈øt.
Meredyth ap Owen, ap Edwyn, was Prince of Southwales. But this Meredith was ≈ølain by Caradoc, ap Griffith, ap Rytherch, ap Je≈øtin, upon the River Rympyn, Anno Dom. 1068.

‚öú Blethyn was traiterou≈øly murthered by Rees, ap Owen, ap Edwyn, Anno Domini 1073. He joyned with Edwyn and Morcar, his Uncles by the Mother, again≈øt the Conqueror, Anno 1068. Ordericus, pag. 511. and in Anno 1069. the Wel≈øh and Che≈øhiremen Be≈øieged the Conqueror's Garri≈øon of Shrewsbury. See Ordericus, pag. 515.

18. Trahaern ap Caradoc, after the death of Blethyn, Prince of Northwales: He was Co≈øen-german to Blethyn; and Rees ap Owen was Prince of Southwales; which Rees was ≈ølain and outed by Trahaern ap Caradoc, about 1076.
Anno 1077. Rees ap Theodor, ap Eneon, ap Owen, ap Howel Dha, as right Inheritor to Southwales, claimed the ≈øame, and was received.

Anno Chr. 1078. 19.
Griffith up Conan, Prince of North-Wales,
Rees ap Theodor, Prince of South-Wales:
The≈øe joyning their Forces, ≈ølew Traherne and all his Co≈øins in Battel: 1078.
Anno 1079. William the Conqueror of England, entred Wales with an Army as far as St. Davids, and took Homage of the Princes of Wales.

Anno 1088. Griffith ap Conan, King of Wales, enters the Borders of England about Rothelent with an Army, and made great de≈øtruction; where Robert of Rothelent a Norman, Governor of Rothelent Ca≈øtle under William the Conqueror, was ≈ølain in a Skirmi≈øh; who≈øe Head was cut off, and carried away with King Griffith, who cau≈øed it to be hanged upon the Ma≈øt of his Ship. Ordericus, pag. 670. This Robert of Rothelent, and Robert de Malpas, (two of the Earl of Che≈øter's Barons) and other cruel Potentates, ≈øpilt much of the Wel≈øhmens Blood. Ordericus, pag. 522.

Anno 1090. Robert Fitz-Hamon, with 12 other Knights, invade Glamorgan≈øhire with an Army of Normans, and ≈øpoiled the Lands of Rees ap Theodor Prince of South-Wales, where Rees was ≈ølain in Battel near Brecknock, with whom fell and decayed the Kingdom of South-Wales. Tho≈øe al≈øo ≈ølew Je≈øtyn ap Gurgant Lord of Glamorgan≈øhire, with a great number of his Men; whereby Robert Fitz-Hamon got po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Glamorgan≈øhire, and gave certain Ca≈øtles and Manors there to his 12 Knights, and to other Gentlemen, who were the fir≈øt Strangers that inhabited Wales. Powel on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 119, & 124. Cambden's Britannia, in Glamorgan≈øhire, pag. 494.

Anno 1092. Roger de Montgomery, Earl of Shrewsbury, entred into Powys-land, and did win the Ca≈øtle and Town of Baldwine, which he fortified, and called it Montgomery, after his own Name. Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory put out by Powel, pag. 152.

Anno 1094. William Rufus entred Wales at Montgomery, which Ca≈øtle being lately demoli≈øhed by the Wel≈øhmen, he re-edified it again: But the Wel≈øh keeping the Straits of the Mountains, with the Woods and the Rivers, King William lo≈øt his Labor, and a number of his Men, and ≈øo returned. Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 153. Matt. Paris, pag. 18.

Anno 1098. Hugh de Montgomery Earl of Shrewsbury, called Hugh Gogh by the Wel≈øh, that is, Red Hugh, becau≈øe of his Red Head; and Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, called Hugh Dirgane by the Wel≈øh, that is, Gro≈øs Hugh, becau≈øe of his Fat Corpulent Body, enter Wales with an Army of Che≈øhire and Shrop≈øhire Men; but Griffith ap Conan the Prince of North-VVales, and Cadogan ap Blethyn, fled into the Mountains. Then the Earls entred the I≈øle of Angle≈øey, and by the way they built the Ca≈øtle of Abberlhiennawe over again≈øt it: They ≈ølew many of the VVel≈øh therein; but Griffith and Cadogan fled into Ireland. Hugh Earl of Shrewsbury was ≈ølain with an Arrow by Magnus Son of Olave King of Norwey. Ordericus, pag. 768. Roger Hoveden, pag. 467. al≈øo the VVel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 155. which puts this in Anno 1096. for 1098.

Anno 1108. King Henry the Fr≈øt with ≈øundry Expeditions brought under the VVel≈øhmen, and ≈øent all the Flemmings (who came over into England when a great part of Flanders was drowned) to inhabite in Ro≈øs in VVales, where Penbrooke, Tenby, and Haverford are now built; where they remain to this day, as may appear by their Speech and Conditions, far different from the re≈øt of the Countrey. VVel≈øh Hi≈øt. pag. 163.
Anno 1132. died Meredyth ap Blethyn, Chief Ruler of Powys.
Anno 1137. died Griffith ap Rees ap Theodor Prince of South-VVales, who had by his Wife Gwenlhiam (Daughter of Griffith ap Conan) Rees, commonly called Lord Rees, and others.
Anno 1137. towards the end of the Year, died Griffith ap Conan Prince of North-VVales.

20. Owen ≈øirnamed Gwineth, Son of Griffith ap Conan, is made Prince of North-VVales; and the Name of King is no further u≈øed in the Briti≈øh Book. VVel≈øh Hi≈øt. pag. 139.With Powel's Notes: Al≈øo pag. 6. Owen died Anno Domini 1169. after he had Reigned 32 Years.

21. David ap Owen, Prince of North-VVales, a≈ø≈øumed the Government, becau≈øe the
elde≈øt Son of Owen, called Jorwerth Drwyndwn, that is, Edward with the Broken No≈øe, was counted unmeet for Government.

Anno 1190. died Griffith Maylor Lord of Bromfield, a Nobleman and a Wi≈øe man. VVel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 242. He was Lord of Bromfield, Yale, Hope-Dale, Nanhewdwy, Mochnant is Rhayard, Chirke, Cynlhayth, and Glindoverdwy: Ibidem, pag. 211. (This was part of Powys Vadoc. Powys before Offa's time reached Ea≈øtward to the Rivers of Dee and Severn.) and had to Wife Angharat Daughter of Owen Guyneth Prince of North-VVales, by whom he had a Son called Madoc, who died 1236. leaving a Son called Griffith: Pag. 293.Anno Chr. 1194.

22. Lhewelyn ap Jorwerth peaceably received all North-Wales to his Subjection. He Married Joan ba≈øe Daughter of John King of England, by Agatha Daughter of William Ferrars Earl of Derby, Anno 1206. Vincent upon Brooke. pag. 204. Speed's Hi≈øtory, pag. 518. calls her Daughter of Robert Ferrers; and had I≈ø≈øue two Sons, Griffith and David; and for Daughters, he had Marret, married to John de Bru≈øe, 1219. Wel≈øh Hi≈øt. pag. 279. and Gladys another Daughter, married to Sir Rafe Mortimer: Ibid. pag. 298. And it is certain, he had another Daughter called Hellen, married to John the Scot Earl of Huntington, and afterwards Earl of Che≈øter: She was married about 1222. and this was for a Final Agreement and Peace between Randle Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, and this Lhewelyn Prince of North-Wales, who before-time had many Conflicts and Wars one again≈øt the other. Knighton, pag. 2430. Matt. Paris, pag. 380. See al≈øo my Antiquities touching Che≈øhire, in this Book. But Helen had no I≈ø≈øue by John Scot, who (≈øaith Matt. Paris) was con≈øenting to the Poy≈øoning of her Husband. After ≈øhe married Robert de Quency, third Son of Saher de Quency Earl of Winche≈øter. Vincent upon Brooke's Catalogue of Nobility, pag. 260.

About the Reign of Henry the Second,Crogen. when he made a Voyage again≈øt the Wel≈øh to the Mountains of Berwin, as he lay at O≈øwe≈øtrey, a number of his Men, who were ≈øent to try the Pa≈ø≈øages, to have pa≈ø≈øed Offa's Ditch at the Ca≈øtle of Crogen, were met withal, and ≈ølain. The Engli≈øhmen afterwards u≈øed to cry Crogen to the Wel≈øh, as much as to ≈øay, Remember Crogen; that they ≈øhould expect no favour from the Engli≈øh: But this Word in proce≈øs of time grew to be an opprobrious Word, when the Engli≈øh would in di≈øgrace call the Wel≈øh‚ÄîCrogens. Wel≈øh Hi≈øt. pag. 257, 258.

This Lhewelyn was a valiant Prince, and brought all Wales to ≈øubjection. He died tertio Id√ªs Aprilis, ≈øcilic√®t die Sancti Guthlaci, Anno Chri≈øti 1240. Matt. Paris, pag. 525. And having tamed Griffith his Son, who rebelled again≈øt him, he left the Principality of Wales unto David his younger Son. He died in the 46 Year of his Reign, and was buried at Conwey. Wel≈øh Hi≈øt. pag. 298.
23. David, younger Son of Lhewelyn, Prince of North-Wales, with all the Barons of Wales, did Homage to King Henry the Third for all the Lands which they had in Wales. Hi≈øt. of Wales, pag. 299.

This David impri≈øoned Griffith his elder Brother, alledging al≈øo that he was a Ba≈øtard: Senana, the Wife of Griffith, Petitions the King of England for the Relea≈øe of Griffith her Husband, and Owen his Son, who was impri≈øoned with his Father. Henry the Third makes an Agreement with Senana, dated 25 Hen. 3. 1241. and Roger de Monte alto, High-Steward of Che≈øhire, was a Surety or Pledge for Senana to ob≈øerve the Agreement. David con≈øents to deliver Griffith, and Owen his Son, and to ≈øtand to the Judgment of King Henry's Court about Griffith's part of the Land; and to re≈øtore to Roger de Monte alto all his Land of Moald in Flint≈øhire: And David acknowledgeth to hold his Lands of Wales of King Henry in Capite. Matt. Paris, pag. 624, 625. Griffith is ≈øent by David unto King Henry, who impri≈øoned him in the Tower of London; but Griffith endeavouring to make an E≈øcape, fell down and broke his Neck, 1 die Martii, 1244. Matt. Paris, pag. 617.
David Prince of Wales took the Ca≈øtle of Mould by Storm, 1245. Matt. Paris, pag. 655. And after it was taken and razed to the Ground by Griffith ap Gwenwynwyn, 1268. Wel≈øh Hi≈øt. pag. 326.

Anno Chr. 1246.
David died without I≈ø≈øue, 1246. Matt. Paris, pag. 695.

24. Lhewelyn ap Griffith ap Lhewelyn, was the la≈øt Prince of Wales of the Briti≈øh Blood, who with his Brother Owen Gogh divided the Principality between them. Lhewelyn ap Griffith married Elianour Daughter of Simon de Montfort Earl of Leyce≈øter, Anno 1279. 6 Edw. 1. the Marriage being Solemnized at Worce≈øter, at the Charge of the King of England. Wal≈øingham, pag. 48. Wel≈øh Hi≈øt. pag. 336. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter placeth it Anno 1278. I find mention of a Daughter he had, for whom the King of England promi≈øeth to provide honourably, and to give Lhewelyn 1000 l. Sterling, and ≈øome Honourable County in England, if Lhewelyn would upon his Submi≈ø≈øion put the King in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Snowdon. This was Anno 1281. upon a Treaty to be had. Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory with Powel's Notes, pag. 365. But what became of this Daughter, I find not; but her Mother Elianour was now dead. This Treaty took no effect.

Obiit, 1282 Concerning the Death of this Lhewelyn, it is variou≈øly reported by our Hi≈øtorians. Matt. of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øaith, He was ≈ølain in the Battel betwixt the Engli≈øh and the Wel≈øh, Anno 1282. when Edmund de Mortuo mari ru≈øhing with others into the Army of Lhewelyn, he was ≈ølain among other Wel≈øhmen, and his Head cut off, which was carried to London, and ≈øet upon the top of the Tower of London: With whom agreeth Wal≈øingham, who placeth the time one Year later. The Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 374. ≈øaith, That Lhewelyn retiring to a Grove near Buhelt, or Buelht, whiles ≈øome of the Wel≈øh were ≈øent to defend the Bridge called Pont Orewyn, ≈øuddenly there came Hor≈øemen about the Grove; and as he would have e≈øcaped, one Adam Francton pur≈øued him, and ran him through, but knew him not; and when he came to ≈øee his Face in the Spoil, he knew him well, and ≈øtruck off his Head; ≈øub Anno 1282. Yet Stow ≈øaith, That whiles Lhewelyn was ≈øpeaking di≈øgraceful Words again≈øt the Engli≈øh at Buelht-Ca≈øtle, where he was taken, Roger le Strange ran upon him, and cut off his Head.

And in Anno 1283. King Edward the Fir≈øt ≈øubdued all Wales, and annexed it to the Crown of England; and David the Brother of Lhewelyn was taken, with ≈øome of his Sons and Daughters: And David was ≈øent to the Ca≈øtle of Che≈øter, and after convicted of Trea≈øon in the Parliament at Shrewsbury, and put to death, ≈øaith our Stowe.
Giraldus Cambren≈øis in his De≈øcription of VVales, cap. 3. hath this Pedegree of the Ancient Princes of VVales, which I thought good here to in≈øert.

list.head: Roderik the Great, King of All VVales, who was ≈ølain Anno Chri≈øti 876.

2. Anandhrec, Son of Mervin.
3. Meyric, Son of Anandhrec.
4. Edwal, Son of Meyric.
5. Jago, Son of Edwal.
6. Conan, Son of Jago.

9. Jorwerth, Son of Owen.
10. Lhewelyn, Son of Jorwerth, who died Anno 1240.

Princes of Powys.
Anaraud, Son of Roderik, had no I≈ø≈øue; und√® Principes Powi≈øiae ≈øuam habent per ≈øe Generationem: So Giraldus. But this agrees not with the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, which makes Anaraud to be the Prince of North-VVales, and Father of Edwal Vowel.

Princes of South-VVales.
Cadelh, Prince of South-Wales, Son of Roderik.
Howel Dha, that is, Howel the Good, Son of Cadelh.
Owen, Son of Howel.
Aeneas, Son of Owen.
Theodor, Son of Aeneas, or Eneon.
Rees, Son of Theodor, 1077.
Griffith, Son of Rees: Obiit 1137.
Rees, Son of Griffith.

div.p: To conclude: We ≈øee how uncertain the VVel≈øh Hi≈øtory in the later Times is, not ≈øo much as vouching any Author or Record, either to prove the Deaths, or Marriages, or Children punctually, nor when; and therefore full of Errors, till of late, ≈øince the Reign of VVilliam the Conqueror: And how ≈øhould we believe any thing of the long Pedegree of Brute, in the more ancient and dark Ages?

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: Of the De≈øcription of Scotland, and the Ancient Inhabitants thereof.

div.p: I. SCOTLAND is the Northern Part of Great-Brettaine, ≈øeparated from England by the Rivers Tweed and Solway, and the Cheviot-Hills, extending from the one to the other.

It is of no great Breadth, there being no Place di≈øtant from the Sea above 60 Miles; and the Countrey ending like the ≈øharp Point of a Wedge: And the length, mea≈øuring in a ≈øtrait Line from North to South, to wit, from Solway-Frith to the Strait-by-Head, amounteth but to 310 Italian Miles; and from Barwick to Strait-by-Head, is a great deal ≈øhorter. Dr. Heylyn's Co≈ømography, pag. 330.

II. The whole North part of Brettaine, anciently inhabited by the Picts, was divided into two Nations, the Dicalidonii, and the Vecturiones. But when the Scots came into tho≈øe Parts, and were ≈øeated there, then did ≈øeven Princes divide it into ≈øeven Parts, as it is in an Ancient Book concerning the Divi≈øion of Scotland, in the≈øe words following. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 682.

list.item: Prima Pars continebat Enegas & Maern.
Secunda, Atheol & Gouerin.
Tertia, Stratheern c√πm Meneted.
Quarta, fuit Fortheuer.
Quinta, Mar c√πm Bughen.
Sexta, Muref & Ros.
Septima, Cathene≈øia, quam Mound Mons medius dividit; qui √† Mari Occidentali ad Mare Orientale procurrit.

div.p: According to the re≈øpect of the People, Scotland is divided into two Parts, the High-land-men, and the Low-land-men. The Low-land-men are more civilized; and u≈øe both the Tongue and Habit of the Engli≈øh. The Highlanders more barbarous and cruel, like the Wild Iri≈øh. The Borderers I exclude out of this Divi≈øion, as to be reckoned among the Briti≈øh People.
According to re≈øpect of Places, Scotland is divided into two Parts al≈øo; South-Scotland on this ≈øide the River Tai, and North-Scotland beyond the River Tai; be≈øides many circumjacent I≈ølands.

III. The Ancient Inhabitants of this Countrey, dwelling within the Limits of the Roman Province, about Anno Chri≈øti 100. according to Cambden de Scoti√¢, were,
The Gadeni
Tevidale.
Twedale
Merch.
Lothaine, Latine Lodeneium: The Chief City whereof was Ca≈øtrum Alatum, now called Edenborough.
The Damnii
Cluyd≈ødale,
Lennox,
Sterling,
Mentieth,
Fife.
Who≈øe Chief City was Randuara, now called Renfraw, in Cluyd≈ødale.
The Selgovae
Liddi≈ødale,
Eu≈øedale,
Eskdale,
Annand≈ødale,

Who≈øe Chief Place was Carbantorigum, now Caerlaverok in Niddi≈ødale. Lindum, now Linlithquo.
The Novantes
Galloway,

Who≈øe Principal Places were Leucopibia, now White-Herne; and Berigonium, now Bargeny.

Caledonii
Stratherne,
