IV. As the Bi≈øhops of other Parts of the World had no certain Dioce≈ø≈øes, before Diony≈øius Bi≈øhop of Rome, about Anno Chri≈øti 268. had di≈øtributed Dioce≈ø≈øes to Bi≈øhops; ≈øo the Bi≈øhops of Scotland executed their Office without di≈øtinction, till about Anno 1070. in the time of Malcolme the Third, Dioce≈ø≈øes were circum≈øcribed with theit Limits. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 683.
Afterwards, in tract of time, Scotland had two Archbi≈øhops; one of St. Andrews, who was Primate of Scotland; the other of Gla≈øco.

To the Archbi≈øhop of St. Andrews are ≈øub≈øtituted the≈øe eight Bi≈øhopricks;
Dunkeld.
Aberdene.
Murray.
Brichen.
Dumblane.
Ro≈øs.
Cathne≈øs.
Orkeney.

Under the Archbi≈øhop of Gla≈øco are onely three:
1. Candida Ca≈øa, or Galloway.
2. Li≈ømore, or Argile.
3. Of the I≈øles.

Of the I≈øles, the I≈øle of Man was the fir≈øt Cathedral Seat; but by the Inva≈øion of the Norwegians and the Engli≈øh, the ≈øame was tran≈ølated to Ilcomkill. In Man, Amphibalus was the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop. After the Tran≈ølation of the Seat to Ilcomkill, I find onely one Onacus mentioned about the Year 1289. with another called Mauritius, whom Edward I. King of England, ≈øent Pri≈øoner to London. So far to the time of the Reformation. Spot≈øwood's Hi≈øtory of the Church of Scotland, pag. 116.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the Original of the Scots in Scotland.

div.p: I. FIr≈øt, for the Etymologie of the Name of Scots, it is (as of other Nations round about) full of ob≈øcurity. Buchanan (a Man otherwi≈øe of deep In≈øight, an excellent Latin Poet, but a bad State≈øman) will have Scotland named from Scota a counterfeit Daughter of Pharaoh King of Egypt, wedded, for≈øooth, to one Gaithelus, Son of Cecrops, Founder of Athens; for which he is ju≈øtly taxed by Cambden in his Britannia, pag. 85. For no Man skilful in Antiquities can endure ≈øuch palpable Fal≈øities and Fables. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter (≈øub Anno Gratiae 77.) ≈øaith, That from the Picts and the Iri≈øh, the Scots had their Original, as it were compacted of divers Nations: For Scot (≈øaith he) is a heap made up of ≈øeveral things.

But Learned Cambden ≈øuppo≈øeth, and proveth, That the Scots inhabited Ireland, and from thence came into Scotland; and that they were originally Scythians: for as from Getae, Getici, Gothi, Gothici; ≈øo Scythae, Scythici, Scoti, Scotici, take their derivation. Hibernia propri√® Patria Scottorum e≈øt, ≈øaith Bede. And Henry of Huntington, lib. 1. Hi≈øtor. pag. 301. ≈øaith, It is certain that the Scots came out of Spain into Ireland, and from Ireland part of them came into Brettaine, and ≈øo added a third Nation in Brettaine to the Britons and Picts: For the Part which remained in Ireland, did in Huntington's time u≈øe the ≈øame Language, and were called Navarri.

II. But for the time when the Name of Scot was fir≈øt known, there is ≈øome que≈øtion. Homfrey Lhuid ≈øaith, The Name of Scots cannot be found in any Author before the time of Con≈øtantine the Great, that is, till about 310 Years after Chri≈øt's Birth. Cambden in his Ob≈øervation tells us, The fir≈øt mention of the Scots was under Aurelian the Emperor; in his Britannia, pag. 90. And that mu≈øt be about the Year of Chri≈øt 270.

The Nation of the Scots prevailed in Ireland, and began to be famous towards the declining of the Roman Empire. Oro≈øius, lib. 1. cap. 2. pag. 19. Oro≈øius ≈øaith, That in the time of Honorius and Arcadius, Emperors, Ireland was Inhabited with the Scots, about the Year of Chri≈øt 400. Whence Claudian the Poet, de Quarto Con≈øulatu Honorii, which was in Anno 398. and lived in the ≈øame Age, ≈øaith,‚Äî Scottorum cumulos flevit Glacialis Ierne. And again, in his ≈øecond Book de Laudibus Stiliconis,
‚ÄîTotam c√πm Scotus Iernam
Movit.

There were Scoti Ierni, Iri≈øh Scots; and Scoti Albini, Scots of Albin in Scotland. Buchanan, pag. 54. Hi≈øtorians called Ireland, Scotia major; and Scotland in Brettaine, Scotia minor. Cambd. Brit. pag. 90.

III. For the time when the≈øe Scots came fir≈øt out of Ireland into Brettaine, it was about the time of Valentinian the Emperor; for they a≈ø≈øi≈øted the Picts in their Wars again≈øt the Brettons, then under the Roman Yoke, in that part of Brettaine which is now called England, about Anno Chri≈øti 366. So Cambden's Britannia, pag. 55. ex Ammiano Marcellino. For at this time the Picts, Scots, Saxons, and the Attacotti, did much infe≈øt the Brettans. And Claudian the Poet, in his Panegyrick of the fourth Con≈øul≈øhip
of Honorius the Emperor, which was in the Year of Chri≈øt 398. ≈øaith thus:‚Äî
Ille, Caledoniis po≈øuit qui Ca≈øtra Pruinis,
Qui medio Libyae ≈øub Ca≈ø≈øide pertulit ae≈øtus,
Terribilis Mauro, Debellatorque Britanni
Littoris, ac parit√®r Boreae va≈øtator, & Au≈øtri;
Quid rigor aeternus, Coeli quid Sydera pro≈øunt,
Ignot√∫mque fretum? Maduerunt Saxone fu≈øo
Orcades; incaluit Pictorum ≈øanguine Thule,
Scotorum cumulos flevit glacialis Hiberne.

And it ≈øhould ≈øeem that the Romans had at this time an Officer called Comes Littoris Saxonici, in Brettaine; who, with the Soldiers allotted him, were to defend the Seacoa≈øt in Brettaine from the Inva≈øion of the Saxons. And the Scots and Picts were al≈øo beaten out of that Part of Brettaine now called England, by Stilico the Chief Governor of Brettaine under Honorius, who al≈øo expelled the Saxons: And the Scots returning back into Ireland, ≈øhortly after came again: And the Picts then fir≈øt, and afterwards, continued in the Northern Parts of Brettaine, yet cea≈øed not to mole≈øt the Brettans. Thus Bede, lib. 1. Eccle≈øia≈øticae Hi≈øtoriae Anglorum Gentis, cap. 14‚ÄîRevertuntur erg√≤ impudentes Gra≈ø≈øatores Hyberni domum: Po≈øt non longum tempus rever≈øuri. Picti in extrem√† parte In≈øulae tunc prim√πm, & deinc√®ps, quieverunt: Praedas tam√®n nonnunqu√†m exind√®, & Contritiones de Britonum Gente agere non ce≈ø≈ø√¢runt: Which Bede taketh verbatim out of Gildas, cap. 18. fol. 17. b. Now Gildas placeth this after the Brettans had ≈øent their lamentable Letter unto Aetius the Con≈øul, which was ≈øent (≈øaith Bede) Anno Chri≈øti 446. Anno Theodo≈øii Secundi, vice≈øimo tertio: Lib. 1. Hi≈øt. cap. 13. The ≈øub≈øtance of the Letter was thus:‚ÄîAetio t√®r Con≈øuli Gemitus Britannorum.
And ≈øo, po≈øt pauca,‚ÄîRepellunt Barbari ad Mare, repellit Mare ad Barbaros: Inter haec duo genera funerum, aut jugulamur, aut mergimur.
Yet for all this, the Romans ≈øent them no Aid at that time; for the Roman Power was now declining.

Now the Computation of Bede is not right, unle≈øs we under≈øtand it of the 23 Year of Theodo≈øius, after the death of Honorius: And ≈øo Bede expre≈ø≈øeth him≈øelf in the beginning of the Chapter. For Aetius was Con≈øul the fir≈øt time with Symmachus, Anno Chri≈øti 446. And thus the Scots mu≈øt return about that time into Ireland.

But Cambden ≈øaith, Liber Pa≈øleten≈øis ca≈øteth the Return of the Scots into the North of Brettaine in Anno Chri≈øti 404. Giraldus ≈øaith, That in the time of Nellus Magnus, Monarch of Ireland, ≈øix Sons of Mured King of Ul≈øter po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the North Parts of Brettaine, whence that Nation was propagated, and called Scotland: And therefore Cambden conceives, it mu≈øt fall in the Reign of Honorius.

Bede makes mention of Reuda about this time, (Lib. 1. de Hi≈øt. Ang. cap. 1.) under who≈øe Conduct the Scots out of Ireland ≈øeated them≈øelves in Brettaine, on the North ≈øide of the River Cluyd; which they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed either by force or friend≈øhip: from whom they were called Dal-Reudini, that is, The Part of Reuda: And others think, That from this Reuda we gave them the Name of Red-Shanks, ≈øaith Cambden. And the Opinion is, That about this time flouri≈øhed that Simon Brechus, whom the Scots ≈øay was the Founder of their Nation. Sinbrech is the true name of the Man: Sin ≈øignifies Pimples, or Freckles, ut apud Fordonum legitur. Perhaps this was the Brichus who in the time of St. Patrick, with Thuibaius, Macleius, and Au≈øpacus, Scotchmen, vexed Brettaine, as we read in the Life of St. Carantocus.

But why did the Scots call their Countrey in Brettaine, Alban, or Albin; and the Iri≈øh call it Allabany? Cambden ≈øuppo≈øeth from Banno, by which Name their Poets call Ireland; as it were another Ireland. Buchanan ≈øaith, That Alpum and Album (from whence comes Albin) is an ancient word for a Hill; and that upon the Sea between Ireland and Scotland, the Shore of Scotland ≈øeems to ri≈øe up into Mountains, and ≈øo gained the Name of Albin. Hi≈øt. Scot. lib. 1. pag. 12, 13.

But when the Scots came unto the Picts in Brettaine, though they ever and anon did make War and Excur≈øions upon the Brettans, yet did they not advance very ≈øoon, but lived in that Angle where they fir≈øt arrived. They continually warred again≈øt the Kings of Northumberland, for the ≈øpace of 127 Years; till Edan King of the Scots, and his Army, were totally routed by Ethelfrid King of Northumberland, Anno Domini 603. Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. lib. 1. cap. 34.

And when the Picts were almo≈øt rooted out, and the Kingdom of the Northumbrians, through Civil Di≈øcords and Incur≈øions of the Danes, About the Year 800. fell to decay; then was all the North part of Brettaine called Scotland, from Cluyd and Edenborough-Frith: And on this ≈øide Cluyd and Edenborough-Frith, was part of the Kingdom of Northumberland, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Saxons, as every man knows. But at this day Scotland is divided from England by the Rivers Tweed and Solway: And hence it is, that all tho≈øe who po≈ø≈øe≈øs the Ea≈øt part of Scotland, and are called Lowland-men, are de≈øcended of the Engli≈øh Saxons, and ≈øpeak the Engli≈øh Tongue; and tho≈øe that inhabit the We≈øtern Coa≈øt of Scotland, called Highlanders, be de≈øcended from the Scots, and ≈øpeak Iri≈øh, and are maliciou≈øly bent towards the Lowland-men who ≈øpeak Engli≈øh.

II. The People of the Scots have been noted of their be≈øt Writers for ≈øome barbarous Cu≈øtoms; one whereof was, If any two were di≈øplea≈øed, they expected no Law, but banged it out bravely, one, and his Kindred, again≈øt the other, and his Kindred. This Fighting they called their Feids. The≈øe deadly Feids King James the Sixth, in his Ba≈øilicon Doron, advi≈øeth his Son to redre≈øs with all care po≈ø≈øible: But it plea≈øed God to give this King ≈øo long a Life, as to ≈øee it remedied in his own days: An Act indeed truly Royal, and worthy him≈øelf. Dr. Heylyn's Co≈ømography, pag. 331.

Another Cu≈øtom they had of a ≈øtrange nature, never was the like heard of among the Heathens; That the Kings of Scotland ≈øhould have the Maidenhead, or fir≈øt Nights Lodging with every Woman, who was to be married to a Husband that held Land immediately from the Crown; and the Lords and Gentlemen ≈øhould have the like of all tho≈øe who≈øe Husbands were their Tenants or Homagers: And this was by a Law made by Eugenius a la≈øcivious Prince of Scotland. But this Cu≈øtom, in the time of Malcolme the Third, ≈øirnamed Cammoir, was made redeemable for half a Mark of Silver, about the Year 1070. which Pen≈øion the Scots at this day call The Marchet of the Women. Buchanan, lib. 7. pag. 214. The rea≈øon of the Name, Skene, in his Interpretation of Old Words, thinks to come from March, which in the Ancient Scotch Language ≈øignifies A Hor≈øe; and ≈øo metaphorically denotes a Pen≈øion for the Leaping of a Woman, a≈øcendere Mulierem. Spelman in his Glo≈ø≈øary ≈øaith, That Merch in the ancient Language of the Brettans ≈øignifies a Daughter, or Woman-Sex; and ≈øo denotes a Pen≈øion for a Woman's Marriage, to the Lord or King.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Picts in Scotland.

div.p:
THe Name of Pict was fir≈øt introduced by the Romans, ≈øaith Buchanan in his Hi≈øtory of Scotland, lib. 2. pag. 54. becau≈øe the≈øe People painted their Bodies with the Pictures of all manner of Living Creatures: It was not their ancient Native Name. Herodian ≈øaith, Neque ve≈øtis u≈øum cogn√¥runt; ≈øed ventrem & cervicem ferro cingunt, Ornamentum id e≈ø≈øe, ac divitiarum argumentum exi≈øtim√¢runt, perind√® ut aurum caeteri Barbari: They put Iron Plates about their Bellies and Necks, which they reputed an Ornament, and an Argument of Riches, (as other Foreign Nations e≈øteemed Gold) and painted their Bodies with the Forms of all manner of Living Creatures:
Wherefore they put on no Clothes, that they might not hide their Bodies ≈øo carved and painted.

Buchanan ≈øuppo≈øeth them to be originally Scythians, or Getes, pag. 55. Hergu≈øt their King dying about the time of Victorinus (Lord Deputy of Brettaine under Honorius the Emperor, who reduced the Picts to the Roman Province about the Year of Chri≈øt 412.) forbad them to make any new King, but what ≈øhould be given them by the Romans; and that it was prophe≈øied of old, That the Picts ≈øhould be rooted out by the Scots. Buchanan, ibid. pag. 129. And at la≈øt Brudus, King of the Picts, not able to compo≈øe the Differences already begun between the Picts and the Scots, died for grief; and Drusken his Brother (who was the la≈øt King of the Picts) was overthrown in Battel, Buchanan, li. 5. p. ‚Ä¢ 65, 166. about the Year of Chri≈øt 838. by Kenneth the Second, King of the Scots, and the Picts utterly ≈øubdued: Since which time, the Kings of the Scots have been Lords of all Scotland, who before had onely a Part of Scotland.

It is ≈øaid, That the Nation of the Picts came fir≈øt out of Scythia into Ireland, and from thence into the North Parts of our Brettaine: So Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. lib. 1. cap. 1. And this (as many will have it) about Anno Chri≈øti 78.

Judicious Cambden thinks they were very Brettans, who before the coming of the Romans were ≈øeated in the North part of our I≈øland, with ≈øuch other Brettans who fled unto them, as unwilling to ≈øubmit to the Roman Servitude: In his Britannia, pag. 82.

For my part, I think the Brettans and the Picts do ≈øignifie the ≈øame thing; one being a Greek Name, and the other Latin: This of Latin being given by the Romans in later Times, in di≈øtinction from our Brettans of England who ≈øubmitted to the Roman Government, and were ≈øtiled as formerly, and perhaps more civilized by the Romans. Tho≈øe other more rude, and flying into Scotland, and continually oppo≈øing the Romans, were by them called Picti, which Name continued afterwards, I find not the Name of Picti in any Author mentioned, till 300 Years after Chri≈øt, and more: And that as well the Brettans, as the Picts, were Peopled from the ancient Galles, and tho≈øe originally de≈øcended from the Scythians and Getes, as Sheringham de Anglorum Gentis Origine, doth probably demon≈øtrate.

There were al≈øo two other ≈øorts of People among the Picts in Scotland, in the time of the Romans; the Maiatae, and the Attacotti, as they were ≈øtiled by the Romans: Of whom ≈øee Buchanan, lib. 2. pag. 57. and al≈øo Cambden's Britannia, pag. 655. & pag. 91. The≈øe inhabited the Borders of Scotland.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: Of the Kings of Scotland.

div.p: ‚öú THe Kingdom of Scotland was never totally Conquered, either by the Romans or Saxons; for which they may thank their great Barren Mountains, whether they fled from the Enemy, as a Shelter.

It con≈øi≈øted (as you have already heard) of two ≈øorts of People, Picts, and Scots. It remains that I ≈øet down the Catalogue of their Kings, as far as truth of Hi≈øtory will bear: For the fir≈øt 39 Kings of Scotland (which ≈øome Scotch Hi≈øtorians do reckon up) are but vain and fabulous, as Dr. Heylyn truly accounts them, in his Co≈ømography, pag. 335.

div.head: Kings of Scotland before the Conque≈øt of the Picts, when the Scots had but one Part of Scotland, and the Picts the other Part.
div.p: Ann. Dom. 404 1. Fergus King of the Scots, and Dur≈øtus King of the Picts, ≈ølain in Battel again≈øt the Romans and Brettans, Anno Chri≈øti 420. Buchanan.
2. Eugenius, or Euenus, elde≈øt Son of Fergus.
3. Dongard, Brother of Eugenius.
4. Con≈øtantine, Brother of Dongard, and younge≈øt Son of Fergus.
5. Congall, Son of Dongard.
6. Goran, Brother of Congall.
7. Eugenius II. Son of Congall.
8. Congall II. Brother to Eugenius.

9. Kinnatel: In his time Aidan, Son of Gorran, came into Scotland, who two Years before came out of Ireland; and was now by St. Columba brought to Kinnatel, who left the Kingdom to Aidan, having onely Reigned 14 Months.

10. Aidan, Son of Gorran, had his Kingly Robes put on by Columba. Deadly Feuds began between him and Brudeus
Brudeus was Son of Meilocon: Ordericus, l 8. p. 702. King of the Picts. Aidan was routed by Ethelfrid King of Northumberland, Anno 603. Bede, lib. 1. cap. 34. So that he never came again into Scotland.
11. Kenneth I. was elected King. He Reigned but 4 Months, or (ut alii) 12 Months.
12. Eugenius III. Son of Aidan.
13. Ferchard I. Son of Eugenius.
14. Donaldus, Brother of Ferchard.
15. Ferchard II. Son of Ferchard. He was wounded by a Wolf.
16. Maldwine, Son of Donwald. He was ≈øtrangled by his Wife, upon ≈øu≈øpicion he had lain with a Whore; and ≈øhe was burned for it.
17. Eugenius IV. Son of Dongard.
18. Eugenius V. Son of Ferchard.
19. Amberkeleth, Son of Findanus, Son of Eugenius IV.
20. Eugenius VI. He married Spondana Daughter of Garnard, and commanded the Acts of Kings to be Regi≈øtred in Abbies.
21. Mordac, Son of Amberkeleth.
22. Etfin, Son of Eugenius VI. He forced Galloway to pay Tribute.
23. Eugenius VII. Son of Mordac, was murthered by his Nobles.
24. Fergus II. Son of Etfin, was ≈øtrangled by his Wife when he was a≈øleep.
25. Solvathius, Son of Eugenius VII. a good Prince.
26. Achaius, Son of Etfin, fir≈øt entred into a League with France. Hungus King of the Picts obtains 10000 Scots of him.
27. Congall III. Co≈øin to Achaius.
28. Dongall II. Son of Solvathius.
29. Alpin, Son of Achaius, ≈ølain in Battel by the Picts, who challenged that Kingdom in right of his Mother, Si≈øter to Hungus King of the Picts, and his Heir al≈øo.

30. Kenneth II. Son of Alpin, utterly ≈øubdued and de≈øtroyed the Picts, and ≈ølew Drusken their la≈øt King, extending thereby the Scotti≈øh Kingdom from one Sea to the other, over all the Bounds of Modern Scotland.

div.head: Kings of Scotland after the Conque≈øt of the Picts.
div.p: 1. Kenneth II. the fir≈øt ≈øole King of all Scotland, conquered the Picts, Anno 838. He promoted his Kingdom from the I≈øles of the Orcades to Adrian's Wall. Buchanan.
2. Donald II. Brother of Kenneth, died at Scone, Anno 858.
3. Con≈øtantine II. Son of Kenneth, ≈ølain by the Danes.
4. Ethus, Brother of Con≈øtantine, ≈øirnamed Alipes, √† Pedum celeritate.

5. Gregorius, Son of Dongall, a ≈øtout Prince. He overcame the Danes, Brettans, and Engli≈øh; ≈øubdued Cumberland and We≈øtmorland; entred Ireland with an Army in the time of Duncan, or Donat, or more truly Dunach, King of Ireland, a Child; and overcame Brien, and Cornelius, General of the Iri≈øh Forces.
6. Donald III. Son of Con≈øtantine II.
7. Con≈øtantine III. Son of Ethus.

8. Malcolme I. ≈øtiled Milcolumbus in Latin, Son of Donald III. had Cumberland and We≈øtmorland by the Gift of Edmund King of England, upon condition that every ≈øucceeding King of Scotland ≈øhould ≈øwear Fealty to the King of England, as the Supreme Sovereign.
9. Indulf, an Intruder.
10. Duffe, Son of Malcolme, was murthered.
11. Culen, Son of Indulfe, murthered by one Rohard a Thane or Nobleman.
12. Kenneth III. Brother of Duffe.
13. Con≈øtantine IV. Son of Culen, ≈øirnamed Calvus, or The Bald; a U≈øurper of the Crown.
14. Grime, Son of Duffe, was ≈ølain in Battel by Malcolme Prince of Cumberland.
15. Malcolme II. Son of Kinneth III. murthered by his Nobles in the Ca≈øtle of Glammis in Angus.

16. Duncan, Son of Grime, ≈øucceeded Malcolme II. Malcolme had no I≈ø≈øue Male, but two Daughters; Beatrix, Married to one Crine a Nobleman, Thane of the We≈øt-I≈ølands, and Ruler or Pre≈øident over the re≈øt of the Thanes, whom that Age called A-Thane. Doaca the other Daughter married the Thane of Angus, of whom he begat Macbeth: So Buchanan. And Duncan had by the Daughter of Siward the Great, Earl of Northumberland, two Sons; Malcolme Cammoir, and Donald ≈øirnamed Ban, that is, White.
17. Macbeth, Grand≈øon to Malcolme II. by Doaca his Daughter.

18. Malcolme III. ≈øirnamed Cammoir, that is, Great-Head, Son of Duncan. He enjoyed Cumberland and We≈øtmorland, with the Dominion of Scotland; and married Margaret the Si≈øter of Edgar Atheling (Right Heir to the Crown of England, but kept out by William the Conqueror) by whom he had I≈ø≈øue ≈øix Sons, Edward, Edgar, Alexander, David, Edmund, and Ethelred. The≈øe two la≈øt were driven into England by Donwald their Uncle, and died in Bani≈øhment, ≈øaith Buchanan. Malcolme had al≈øo two Daughters, Maud Wife to Henry the Fir≈øt, King of England, and Mary another Daughter of Malcolme, married to Eu≈øtace Earl of Boloine. Ordericus, pag. 702. Buchanan, pag. 215.

This Malcolme, with Edward his elde≈øt Son, was ≈ølain by Morell, or Morkell, an Officer under Robert de Moulbray Earl of Northumberland, the 13 day of November, 1093. near the River Alne in Northumberland. Roger Hoveden, pag. 463, 464. as he was coming home peaceably towards Scotland. Ordericus vitalis, lib. 8. pag. 701, 702.
19. Donald IV. ≈øirnamed Ban, Brother to Malcolme, was beaten out of Scotland by Duncan II. after that he had Reigned ≈øix Months.
20. Duncan II. ba≈øe Son of Malcolme III. ≈øet up by the Scots, and murthered by Macpendirus Earl of Merne. Buchanan.

21. Edgar, Son of Malcolme III. by the help of William Rufus King of England, recovered Scotland; which Forces were procured by the Mediation of Edgar Atheling his Uncle. Hoveden, pag. 466. He built an Abbey at Coldingham, con≈øecrated to Ebba the Virgin Anno 1102., afterward tran≈ølated into the Name of Cutbert: But Edgar died without I≈ø≈øue, Anno 1107. 6 Idus Januarii. Buchanan, pag. 216. Matt. Paris, pag. 63. Hoveden, pag. 471. ≈øub Anno 1108.

22. Alexander, Brother of Edgar, was ≈øirnamed Acer, or The Fierce. He built the Temple of St. Michael at Scone, and al≈øo a Temple in honour of Columbus, in the I≈øle of
Aemona. He married Sibilla Daughter of William the Conqueror, but left no Children by her: So Buchanan. But the Conqueror had no ≈øuch Daughter, that I can find, either in Ordericus or Stowe, who name all his Daughters. She was ba≈øe Daughter of Henry the Fir≈øt. Ordericus, pag. 702.

Ann. Dom. 1124 23. David, Brother of Alexander, married Maude Daughter of Waltheof Earl of Northumberland, and Widow of Simon Seintliz Earl of Northampton and Huntington. Vincent upon Brooke, pag. 367. By which Marriage he had the Counties of Northumberland and Huntington in England; and by her had I≈ø≈øue Henry a Son, who married Ada Si≈øter of William Warren Earl of Surrey in England, and half Si≈øter by the Mother to Walleran Earl of Mellent in France, and to Robert ≈øirnamed Bo≈ø≈øue, Earl of Leyce≈øter in England. Simon Dunelmen≈øis, ≈øub Anno 1139. pag. 265.

Henry had I≈ø≈øue by Ada, Malcolme, William Earl of Northumberland, David Earl of Carricht in Scotland, and of Huntington in England; al≈øo Maude a Daughter: But this Prince Henry died before his Father, Anno Domini 1152. and Maude his Daughter al≈øo.
Anno Domini 1153. nono Calendas Junii, died David King of Scotland. Hoveden, pag. 490.

24. Malcolme IV. Son of Henry, and Grand≈øon to David, a Child of the Age of twelve Years, ≈øucceeded King. He re≈øigned Northumberland to King Henry the Second of England; Cumberland and Huntington being left to Malcolme. Buchanan. He died without I≈ø≈øue, nono die Decembris, 1165. in the 25 Year of his Age, and 12 Year of his Reign, and a little more. Buchanan & Hoveden, pag. 496.

25. William, Brother to Malcolme, fetched Northumberland back again. He married Ermengard Daughter of Richard Vi≈øcount de Beaumont, Co≈øin to Henry the Second, King of England, ≈øcilicet Anno 1186. Hoveden. And in Anno 1174. this William was taken Pri≈øoner at Alnwick by Robert Stutevile Sheriff of York, William de Ve≈øcy, Randle Glanvill, Bernard Baliol, and others. Hoveden, pag. 538, 539. Henry King of England re≈øtored unto him the Earldom of Huntington, 1184. upon the death of Simon de Seintliz then Earl thereof; and King William immediately conferred it on David his younger Brother. Hoveden, pag. 622. William did Homage to John King of England, for his Lands in England, at Lincoln, Anno 1200. Hoveden & Buchanan. Fecit homagium de omni Jure ≈øuo, and after ≈øwore Fealty to him. Matth. Paris, pag. 204.

King William died Anno 1214. aged 74 Years, Annoque Regni 49. Buchanan. He had a Son by Ermengard, called Alexander, born Anno 1199. and another Son kill'd in his Infancy, with his Nur≈øe, by an Inundation. Buchanan, pag. 232. He had al≈øo two Daughters, Margaret, and I≈øabel, promi≈øed to the two Sons of King John when they ≈øhould be marriageable. Hollin≈øhed. But one of the≈øe Daughters afterward married the Earl of Flanders, 1210. Knighton, pag. 2420.

26. Alexander II. Son of William, married Joan Si≈øter to Henry the Third, King of England, 1221. Matt. Paris, pag. 313. He demands Northumberland, which King John promi≈øed him in Marriage with Joan his Daughter. Matt. Paris, pag. 432. He denieth that he holdeth any part of the Kingdom of Scotland from the Kings of England; or that he either would, or ought ≈øo to hold it: This was Anno 1244. Joan his Queen dying in England, Anno 1236. was buried in London: And ≈øoon after (for yet he had no Children) he married Mary Daughter of Ingelram de Cu≈øcy a Frenchman, Anno 1239. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Alexander a Son, who ≈øucceeded his Father. Buchanan, and Matt. Paris, pag. 638.
Anno 1244. he makes a League with the King of England his Brother-in-Law, wherein he acknowledgeth the King of England his Leige-Lord. See the Charter in Matt. Paris, pag. 646.
This Alexander the Second died Anno 1249. Anno aetatis 51. Annoque Regni 35. Buchanan, and Matt. Paris, pag. 771.

27. Alexander III. Son of Alexander II. Crowned at Scone; a Child not above eight Years old. He was Knighted at York by Henry the Third, Anno 1251. on Chri≈øtmas
day; and the day after he married Margaret Daughter of the ≈øaid King Henry. Mat. Paris, pag. 829. al≈øo Buchanan. He did Homage to the King of England at that time, for the Lands which he had in England; but refu≈øed to do Homage for Scotland, when it was tendred him according to the Cu≈øtom of his Predece≈ø≈øors, by the Te≈øtimony of Ancient Chronicles.

Robert Abbot of Fermelinodunum, Chancellor to the King of Scotland, was accu≈øed for Legitimating the Wife of Alan Durovart, Ba≈øtard-daughter of Alexander the Second, that ≈øo, if the King ≈øhould now die without I≈ø≈øue, ≈øhe might ≈øucceed as Heir. Buchanan.
Henry King of England created this Alexander Earl of Huntington by Charter, Anno 1256. to hold as freely, as any of his Predece≈ø≈øors ever held the ≈øame. Matt. Paris, pag. 931.

This Alexander overcame Acho King of Norwey in Battel, 1263. and took the I≈øle of Man, and all the We≈øtern I≈øles. Buchanan. He promi≈øed his Daughter Margaret, yet but four Years old, to Hangonan (Son of Magnus) King of Norwey, to be his Wife when ≈øhe was marriageable; which it ≈øeems was performed afterwards: for ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue by him a Daughter, called al≈øo Margaret, who died young, about Anno 1291.

Alexander in few Years being deprived of his Wife and all his Children, did after marry Iolet Daughter of the Earl of Dreux [Comitis Druidum]; but I find not that he had any Children by her: for ≈øoon after, within a Year, to wit, 14 Calendas Aprilis, Anno 1285. he was killed by a fall from his Hor≈øe, not far from Kingorne, aged 45 Years, Annoque Regni 37. Buchanan.

‚öú Now Wal≈øingham tells us, Hi≈øt. Edw. 1. pag. 54. That Alexander (the Son of this King Alexander the Third) died in his Father's life time: And Buchanan ≈øaith, That the young Alexander married the Earl of Flanders's Daughter; and that Alexander the Third had another Son called David, and a Daughter called Margaret; but all died before the King: So that now great ≈øtrife did ari≈øe who ≈øhould ≈øucceed King of Scotland. Onely give me leave to ob≈øerve here, how Wal≈øingham ≈øaith, That the Daughter of the Earl of Flanders was ≈øecond Wife of King Alexander the Third: Wherein I believe he is mi≈øtaken; for, according to Buchanan, ≈øhe was the Wife of young Alexander his Son, who died before his Father.

Here was now an Interregnum of ≈øix Years and nine Months, in which time there were twelve Competitors to the Crown of Scotland, who lay down their Claims in the Competition-Roll in the Tower, mentioned by Vincent upon Brooke, Title Huntington, pag. 253, &c. Which, for brevity, I ≈øhall give you here, in a ≈øhort Pedegree of the Kings of Scotland.

item.label: Malcolme III. ≈øirnamed Cammoir, King of Scotland, ≈ølain 1093. See Malcolme's Pedegree in Imag. Hi≈øtor. by Radulphus de Di ceto. pag 627. ‚Äî Marg√†ret Si≈øter to Edgar Atheling. Ordericus,pag. 701, 702.

2 Edgar King of Scotland, died without I≈ø≈øue, 1107.

3 Alexander, al≈øo King, 1107. Obiit ≈øine prole, 1124.
Melcofus, a ba≈øtard. Ordericus, pag. 702.

4 David, al≈øo King, 1124 Obiit 1153 ‚Äî Maud, Daughter of Waltheof, Earl of Northumberland.
Another Son, the elde≈øt, kill'd by a Varlet in his Nur≈øes arms. Ordericus, pag. 702.
Henry Prince of Scotland, died before his Father, viz. Anno 1152. ‚Äî Ada, Si≈øter to the third William Earl Warren and Surrey, 1139.
Margaret, married to Conan Earl of Little-Brettain; after to Bohuis. She died 1201. Hoveden, p. 822.
1 Malcolme IV. Obiit ≈øine prole, 1165.
2 William King of Scotland, died 1214. ‚Äî Ermengard, Daughter of Richard Vi≈øcount Beaumont, 1186.
2 Henry.
Patrick de Galightly, one of the Competitors.
1 Alexander II. King of Scotland. Obiit 1249. ‚Äî Joan, Si≈øter to H 3. King of England, 1221.
Alexander III. King of Scotland, killed by a fall from his Hor≈øe, A. 1285. ‚Äî Margaret, Daughter of Hen. 3. King of England, 1251.
David Son of Alexander III. died before his Father without I≈ø≈øue.
Alexander married the Daughter of the Earl of Flanders; but he died before his Father, leaving no I≈ø≈øue.
Margaret Wife of the King of Norwey.
Margaret, a Daughter, died young, without I≈ø≈øue, about 1291. Ericus King of Norwey became a Competitor for the Crown of Scotland, on behalf of Margaret his Daughter, now decea≈øed, as Admini≈øtrator to her, Anno 1292. Wal≈øingham's Hi≈øt. pag. 58.
I≈øabel, Wife of Roger le Bigot Earl Mar≈øhal; no I≈ø≈øue: But ≈øhe married Robert Lord Roos, fir≈øt Hus.
William L. Roos, another Competitor.
Margaret Wife of Hubert de Burgo Earl of Kent, 1221. M. Paris.
Margaret Wife of Richard de Clare: No I≈ø≈øue.
Margerita Wife unto Eu≈øtace de Ve≈øcy
William de Ve≈øcy
