2 William Ve≈øcy, another Competitor. 1291.
Ada, Wife of Patrick de Dunbarre. ‚Äî Patrick.
Patric E. of Dunbar, another Competitor. 1291.
Au≈øtrio, or Aufrica, Wife of William de Say of ∆≤l≈øter.
A quo Roger de Mandevil, another Competitor.
3 David Earl of Huntington, 1184. ‚Äî Maud, elde≈øt Si≈øter to Randle Blundevil Earl of Che≈øter, and a Coheir.
1 Margaret, elde≈øt daughter of David Earl of Huntington, was Second wife to Alan de Galloway, Con≈øtable of Scotland.
Dervergoile, married to John Baliol of Bernards Ca≈øtle in the Bi≈øhoprick of Durham, the Founder of Baliol-College in Oxford. He died Anno 1269. aut paulo ante.
1 Hugh Baliol, Son and Heir. Obiit ≈øine prole. Balio-fergus, pag. 2.
2 Alan, ≈øecond Son. Obiit ≈øine prole.
3 Alexander, third Son. Obiit ≈øine prole.
4 John Baliol, another Competitor, who was adjudged King of Scotland by the Award of King Edward the Fir≈øt, Anno 1292.
Thomas died without I≈ø≈øue.
Chri≈øtian, elde≈øt Daughter, died without I≈ø≈øue.
2 I≈øabel married Robert de Bru≈øe. ‚Äî Ro. de Bru≈øe Lord of Anandale, another Competitor. 1291.
3 Maud died without I≈ø≈øue.
4 Ada married Henry Ha≈øtings.
Knighton, pag. 2431.
John Ha≈øtings Lord of Berguenny, another Competitor. 1291.
1 Henry died young.
2 David died young.
3 John Scot Earl of Che≈øter, married Hellen, Daughter of Lhewellyn Prince of North-Wales.
John died without I≈ø≈øue, Anno 1237. Helen his Widow after married Robert Quency, third Son of Saher de Quency Earl of Winche≈øter.
Ada Wife of Florence Earl of Holland. She died 1208. Hi≈øt. of the Netherlands, p. 16.
Florence.
William.
Florence, a Competitor to the Crown of Scotland; An Do. 1291. Pryn's Hi≈øt. p. 513.
1 Claricia.
2 Hodierna.
Ordericus, pa. 702.
5 & 6 Edmund, and Ethelred, bani≈øht by their Uncle Donwald.
1 Edith, after called Maude, uxor H. 1. Regis Angliae.
2 Mary, wife of Eu≈øtace, Comitis Boloniae.

div.p: Quare, Whether Margaret Wife of Hubert de Burgo, were not the Widow of Eu≈øtace Ve≈øcy; for Eu≈øtace died 1216. Mat Paris
‚öú See the Claims of the Competitors to the Crown of Scotland, Anno Domini 1291. from the Record it ≈øelf, ≈øet down in Pryn's Hi≈øtory of King John, Hen. 3. and Edw. 1. pag. 513, 514, &c.
‚öú See the Record in Pryn's Hi≈øtory of K. John, H. 3. & Edw. 1. Pa. 515, 516.

28. John Balioll, Son of John Balioll of Bernards-Ca≈øtell in the Bi≈øhoprick of Durham, after the Interregnum of ≈øix Years and nine Months, was by Edward the Fir≈øt adjudged right Heir to the Crown of Scotland, and was thereupon Crowned King at Scone on St. Andrew's Day, being the la≈øt of November, in the Year of Chri≈øt 1292. and pre≈øently after he came to Newca≈øtle upon Tyne, and did Homage to the King of England there, and acknowledged King Edward to be his Liege Lord of all the Kingdom of Scotland, to be held hereditarily of the Kings of England. Wal≈øingham's Hypodigma Neu≈øtriae, pag. 480.

For Edward the Fir≈øt, King of England, being appointed Judge of the Right to the Crown of Scotland, by con≈øent of all the Competitors (of whom onely the Que≈øtion was moved between John Balioll and Robert Bru≈øe, for all the re≈øt of the Competitors were excluded as inferior Titles) gave Sentence for John Balioll by the common A≈ø≈øent, who was De≈øcended from the elde≈øt Daughter of David Earl of Huntington, Brother of William King of Scotland, and Bru≈øe from the younger Daughter; where by the way I mu≈øt note Wal≈øingham's Book mi≈øprinted, which calleth David here mentioned King of Scotland, for Brother of the King of Scotland.

Anno 1295. this John Balioll de≈øired to Marry Edward Balioll his Son, unto Joan, Daughter of Charles, Brother to the King of France, promi≈øing his Aid again≈øt the King of England. And in Anno 1296. the Scots Be≈øiege Carli≈øle; King Edward ≈øubdues the Scots, and makes them ≈øwear Fealty to him, takes John Balioll, King of Scotland, Pri≈øoner, and leaves John Warren, Earl of Surrey, Protector of Scotland, and Hugh Cre≈ø≈øingham, Trea≈øurer, and William de Ormesby, Ju≈øtice, and ≈øo returns to London. Wal≈øingham.

29. Robert Bru≈øe was Crowned King of Scotland at Scone, in April 1306. He was Son of Robert Bru≈øe, Lord of Annan≈ødale, Competitor with John Balioll, in Right of I≈øabell his Mother, the ≈øecond Daughter, though a Degree nearer than Balioll to the decea≈øed King, and Son of the ≈øecond Daughter, whereas Balioll was De≈øcended of the elde≈øt Si≈øter, but of a Daughter of that Si≈øter; which Robert Bru≈øe the Father, relea≈øed his Title to this Robert Bru≈øe his Son, then Earl of Carrick, but now King of Scotland, Dated at Barwick, die Veneris in Cra≈øtino Sancti Leonardi (the ≈øeventh of November) Anno Gratiae 1292. Vincent upon Brook, pag. 255. but it being adjudged to Balioll, he ≈øeeks to get it by force, and was Crown'd 1306. confirmed therein by the great Defeat given to Edward the Second's Forces at Banocksburn, not far from Sterling.

‚öú One Hamilton flying from the Engli≈øh Court to this King Robert (who gave him Lands juxta Glottam Fluvium) his Po≈øtetity afterward came to be ranked among the Nobility of Scotland, and the Hou≈øe and Land which the King gave him, was called Hamilton. This was the original of the Hamiltons in Scotland. Buchanan, lib. 8. pag. 271, 272.

Anno 1318. Edward Bru≈øe, Brother to this King Robert, was taken Pri≈øoner and Beheaded at Dundalk: He had infe≈øted Ireland three Years, and cau≈øed him≈øelf to be Crowned King thereof. Wal≈øingham, pag. 111.
This King Robert Married to his fir≈øt Wife, I≈øabel, Daughter of Donald, of whom he begot Marjory, Mother of Robert Stewart, afterwards King of Scotland. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 713.

Robert Bru≈øe died the ninth of July 1329. Anno Regni 24. Buchanan, pag. 280. But Wal≈øingham, pag. 129. ≈øaith‚ÄîAnno 1328, Hoc anno Robertus Bruis Rex Scotiae, lepr√¢ percu≈ø≈øus obiit, 7 Idus Junii, not Julii. The Scots then cho≈øe Thomas Randulf Earl of Murray, Protector of David Bru≈øe (Son of Robert) a Child about eight Years old. Randulf died 1331, 13 Calendas Augu≈øti; and Duncan Earl of Marre was then cho≈øen Protector of Scotland.

30. Edward Balioll, Son of John Balioll, King, entred Scotland with an Army, and was ≈øo pro≈øperous, that he was Crowned at Scone, 8 Calendas Septembris 1332. Buchanan, pag. 285. But Wal≈øingham ≈øaith he was Crowned 5 Calendas Octobris, that is the 27. of September.

31. David Bru≈øe, Son of King Robert Bru≈øe, called David II. He was re≈øtored to his Father's
Throne by the Power of the Scots. He Married Jane, Si≈øter to King Edward the Third, at Barwick, 18 Julii 1329. She died in England 1357. and he died at Edenborough, 7 Maii 1370. anno aetatis 47, annoque Regni prop√® 39, leaving no I≈ø≈øue. Buchanan. For he was Crowned 1330, 23 Novembris: So that this was a tumultuous Age in Scotland.

Ann. Dom. 1370. 32. Robert II. of the Family of the Stewarts, King of Scotland, by De≈øcent from the elde≈øt Si≈øter of David Bru≈øe. He Married Euphemia, Daughter of Hugh Earl of Ro≈ø≈øe, and by her had I≈ø≈øue Walter, Earl of Athol, and David, Comes Ierniae; which David had onely one Daughter, Married to Patrick Gramus. Buchanan, pag. 353. al≈øo Euphemia a Daughter, Married to James Duglas. Euphemia the Queen died 1373. Buchanan, pag. 307. Soon after he Married Elizabeth Moor, Daughter of Sir Adam Moor, his old Concubine, of whom he had formerly begot three Sons, and two Daughters, and had placed her to be kept with with one Giffard, a Nobleman of Lothaine, whom he Married, to make tho≈øe Children legitimate; John the elde≈øt he made Earl of Carrict, Robert he made Earl of Mentith and Fife, and Alexander he made Earl of Buqhan, who had a Ba≈øtard called al≈øo Alexander, Earl of Marre. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 713.
This Robert II. died Anno 1390. about the thirteenth of the Calends of May, aged 74 Years, and having Reigned 19 Years and 24 Days. Buchanan, lib. 9. pag. 323.

Note.Of the original of the Family of Stewart in Scotland there is a Fable mentioned by Dr. Heylin, in his Co≈ømography, pag. 336, which you may read there at large: The ≈øum of the truth (if yet it be a Truth) is this: In the days of Malcolme Cammoir, King of Scotland, about Anno 1090, one Walter (Son of Fleanch, Son of Bancho) was ≈øent by the King again≈øt the Gallowidians in Scotland, who ≈ølew their Commander, and ≈øo quelled the Rebellion: The King upon his Return, for his good Service made him Stewart of Scotland, an Office of Collecting all the King's Revenues. In former Times ≈øuch were called Thanes: And the Thanes of Countreys in many Places are now called Stewarts, the Engli≈øh Speech over≈øpreading that Countrey, Et qui illis erat ab Thanus, nunc Stuartus Scotiae nominatur. And from this Walter the Family of the Stewarts took their Name and Original, who have for a long time flouri≈øhed in Scotland. Thus Buchanan, Rerum Scoticarum, lib. 7. pag. 212.

But Powel on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 97. tells us, That the ≈øaid Fleanch, a Nobleman of Scotland, fled for ≈øafety to Griffith ap Lhewellyn, Prince of Wales, where he fell in Love with Griffith's Daughter (who≈øe Name I find to be Ne≈øt,) and got her with Child: whereupon Griffith cau≈øed Fleanch to be killed. At la≈øt ≈øhe was Delivered of a Son called Walter, who went into Scotland, and at la≈øt became Stewart of Scotland, as is above rehear≈øed.

33. Robert III. Son of Robert II. who≈øe right Name was John, but changed into Robert after his coming to the Crown: He was Crowned the Ides of Augu≈øt 1390. Buchanan, lib. 10. pag. 324. ≈øub initio. He Married Annabill, Daughter of Sir John Drommond of Stobhall, Knight, and had I≈ø≈øue two Sons, David and James; David died in Falkland, fami≈øhed (≈øaith Buchanan) by his perfidious Uncle, Robert Earl of Fife, and Governor of Scotland, Anno 1401. This David had before betrothed Elizabeth, Daughter of George Earl of Narne, Pag. 326.

Robert III. was buried the fir≈øt of April 1406. annoque Regni 16. Buchanan, lib. 10. pag. 333. He died for grief that James his young Son was taken and kept Pri≈øoner by the King of England. At a Parliament at Perth, Anno Dom. 1399. this King Robert created his Son David (then aged 18 Years) Duke of Roth≈øay; and Robert Earl of Fife was made Duke of Albany. The≈øe were the fir≈øt Dukes of Scotland.

34. James I. Son of Robert III. was taken upon the Seas going for France, and brought to the King of England a little before his Father's death, where he was kept Pri≈øoner 18 Years, and then ≈øet free in February 1423. and Crowned in Scotland the 21 of April following. He Married Jane, Daughter of John Beaufort, Earl of Somer≈øet in England, 1423. Stow; and had two Sons Twins, Alezander and James; Alexander
died young, and James ≈øucceeded King, born the fourteenth of October 1430. Buchanan, pag. 347. al≈øo ≈øix Daughters; Margaret, one Daughter, Contracted to Lewis, Son of Charles the Seventh, King of France, 1425. Buchanan, pag. 342.
James the Fir≈øt died in the beginning of the Year 1437. aged 44 Years, and Reigned 13 Years. Buchanan, pag. 361.

35. James II. Son of James the Fir≈øt, ≈øcarce ≈øeven Years old, Crowned King at Edenborough in Caenobio Sanctae Crucis, about the ≈øixth of the Calends of April, 1437. Buchanan, pag. 362. Alexander Levi≈øton made Protector, and William Crihton Lord Chancellor.

He Married Mary, Daughter of Arnold Duke of Gelderland, Anno 1448. Hollin≈øhed calleth her Margaret, pag. 248. and had I≈ø≈øue by her three Sons and two Daughters; James the elde≈øt. Alexander the ≈øecond Son, Duke of Albany, Married the Earl of Orkney's Daughter, and got on her Alexander Bi≈øhop of Murray; and then parting with her, went into France, and Married the Counte≈øs of Boloigne, by whom he had Sir John Steward, Duke of Albany, Governor of Scotland many Years in the Minority of James the Fifth. The third Son was John Stewart, Earl of Marre. Mary the elder Daughter Married the Lord Boyd, and after to James Lord Hamilton. Buchanan, pag. 420. So was the Blood Royal mingled with the Family of Hamilton. The younger Daughter Married the Lord Crihton. Hollin≈øhed, pag. 248.
James the Second was ≈ølain at the Siege of Roxborough Ca≈øtle, 1460. Anno aetatis 29, & Regni 23. Buchanan, lib. 11. ad finem pag. 399.

36. James III. Son of James the Second, Married Margaret, Daughter of Chri≈øtiern, King of Denmark, Anno 1470. Buchanan, lib. 12. pag. 420. of whom he begat a Son called James, born in March, Anno 1473. Chri≈øtern, King of Denmark, relea≈øed unto this James all his Right to the I≈øles of Orcades, in favour of his Daughter.
James the Third was ≈ølain by his own rebellious Subjects in Battel, Anno Chri≈øti 1488. Regni 28. aetatis 35. Buchanan, lib. 12. the la≈øt words, pag. 440.

37. James IV. Son of James the Third, Married Margaret, Daughter of Henry the Seventh, King of England, Anno 1501. Buchanan, pag. 454. But Stow ≈øaith ≈øhe was Betrothed 1502. and Married at Edenborough the eighth of Augu≈øt, Anno 1503. and had I≈ø≈øue James, Arthur, Alexander, and a Daughter, which la≈øt three died all young. Speed's Hi≈øt. pag. 763.

James the Fourth was ≈ølain at the Battel of Floden-Field, fought between the Engli≈øh and the Scotch on the ninth of September 1513. Anno Regni 25. aetatis 40. in the flower of his Youth, Thomas Howard, Earl of Surrey, being then General of the Engli≈øh Forces.
Queen Margaret afterwards Married Archibald Duglas, Earl of Angus, Anno 1514. unto whom ≈øhe bore Margaret a Daughter, afterwards Married to Matthew Stewart, Earl of Lennox.

In this King's Reign, about Anno 1490. was born in Scotland, a Man-child from the Navel downward, and two Men upward; he lived 28 Years, and learned Mu≈øick and Languages; he had two di≈øtinct Wills, one part oftentimes falling out with the other. Buchanan, Hi≈øt. Scot. lib. 13. pag. 444.

38. James V. Son of James the Fourth, Married Mary, Daughter of the Duke of Gui≈øe, and Dutche≈øs of Longevil, then Widow to the Duke of Longevil, Married at St. Andrews, in July 1538. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue two Sons, who died Infants, and Mary a Daughter, ≈øole Heir to the Crown of Scotland. He had a former Wife named Magdalene, Daughter to the King of France; but ≈øhe had no I≈ø≈øue: for ≈øhe was Married on New-years-day 1536. and died the ≈øeventh of July 1537.

James the Fifth died the thirteenth of December 1542. aged 33 Years, and in the thirtieth of his Reign. He had a ba≈øe Son called James, commonly ≈øtyled Prior of St. Andrews; who was fir≈øt made Earl of Marre, and after of Murray. Cambden's Annals of Eliz. in Latine, pag. 112.

39. Mary, Queen of Scots, Daughter and ≈øole Heir of James the Fifth, was but eight days old when her Father died, James Hamilton, Earl of Arran, being made Protector.
She was de≈øired in Marriage for Edward the Sixth, King of England; but the Faction of Lennox, ≈øupported by the French King, prevailed ≈øo, that the Queen Mother ≈øent her at ≈øix Years of Age to the French King, and to the Duke of Gui≈øe, for Breeding. In the end ≈øhe was Married to Francis the Dolphin of France, who≈øe Nuptials were celebrated at Paris with great Pomp, the 28. of April, Anno 1558. Godwin's Annals: But the Dolphin died Anno 1560. not fully 18 Years old, leaving no I≈ø≈øue by her. Cambden's Annals.
Afterwards Queen Mary Married Henry Stewart, Lord Darley, Son of Matthew Stewart, Earl of Lennox, in Anno 1565. and by him had I≈ø≈øue her onely Son, born in June 1566. called James.

But this Henry Lord Darley, about a Month or two after the Chri≈øtening of the young Prince of Scotland, was Strangled in his Bed, in the dead time of the Night, and thrown out into an Orchard (the Hou≈øe being blown up with Gunpowder) Anno 1566. in the one and twentieth Year of his Age. The common Report was, that this dete≈øtable Fact was cau≈øed by Morton and Murray. So Cambden in his Annals.

Afterwards the Queen Married the Earl Bothwel, now made Duke of Orkney, Anno 1567. whereunto the Lords implored the Queen. The Scots rebell; Bothwel and the Queen were wor≈øted; Bothwel flies, and the Queen is taken Pri≈øoner. Queen Mary is forced to re≈øign her Crown to her young Son, ≈øcarce 13 Months old, Anno 1567. The Earl of Murray is made Regent the twentieth of Augu≈øt. The Queen e≈øcapes out of Pri≈øon, and flies into England, and after 18 Years Impri≈øonment in England, ≈øhe is accu≈øed of High-Trea≈øon again≈øt Queen Elizabeth, for con≈øpiring her Death, and inviting foreign Forces to Invade England; of which ≈øhe was Arraigned, Convicted, and Sentenced to die, and afterwards Beheaded at Fotheringay Ca≈øtle in Northampton≈øhire, on Wedne≈øday the eighth of February, Anno 1586. aged 46 Years, or rather in the 45. Year of her Age. Sander≈øon in the Life of Queen Mary.
Bothwel wandring up and down, at la≈øt came to Naples, where he lived, and died very poor about the Year 1624.

40. James VI. Son of Henry Stewart Lord Darley, and Queen Mary, was Crowned King of Scotland, quarto Calendas Augu≈øti 1567. Buchanan, pag. 669. and Cambden's Annals. He Married Anne, Daughter of Frederick the Second, King of Denmark, Anno 1589. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Prince Henry, born at Sterling in Scotland the nineteenth of February 1593. who died at St. Jame's Hou≈øe in London, the ≈øixth of November 1612. Charles the ≈øecond Son, born at Dunferne in Scotland, the nineteenth of November, Anno 1600. he was King of Great Britain after his Father. The Lady Elizabeth, born the ≈øixteenth of Augu≈øt 1596. She Married Frederick, Prince Elector Palatine of Germany, in February 1612. afterwards King of Bohemia 1619. and al≈øo two other Daughters by Queen Anne, born in England, the Lady Mary, and the Lady Sophia; but the≈øe both died young.

This James the Sixth, upon the death of Queen Elizabeth, was Proclaimed the next undoubted Heir to the Crown of England, in London, March 24. being Thur≈øday, which was the la≈øt Day of the Year 1602. according to the Computation of the Church of England, as lineally De≈øcended from Margaret, elde≈øt Daughter of Henry the Seventh, King of England; ≈øo that in the thirty ≈øixth Year of his Reign over Scotland, and the thirty ≈øeventh of his Age, he was now Proclaimed King of Great Britain and Ireland. Thus were the Crowns of England and Scotland united in this King James, who≈øe continual Jars had ≈øpilt formerly an infinite deal of Blood, both of the Scotch and Engli≈øh.

‚öú He was the fir≈øt Monarch of all Great Britain, and fir≈øt u≈øed the Title of King of Great Britain and Ireland, in all In≈øtruments of State and Writings; which his Succe≈ø≈øors have ever ≈øince retained, ≈øometimes in Records mentioning them in particular thus‚ÄîKing of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.

Two great Deliverances had this King by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the King of Kings: One from the trea≈øonable Con≈øpiracy of Earl Gowry, before he was King of England; the principal Actors were John Ruthen, Earl of Gowry in Scotland, and Alexander Ruthen his Brother, Andrew Hender≈øon, and John Cran≈øton, Plotted in revenge of the Death of William Ruthen, Earl Gowry, Father of the ≈øaid John; which William for his Rebellion at Dundee, ≈øuffered de≈øervedly at Sterling, Anno 1584. The manner of the Con≈øpiracy was thus: John Earl Gowry ≈øends Alexander his Brother, from his Hou≈øe at St. John≈øtons in Scotland, Augu≈øt the fourth, Anno 1600. to the King, then at Falkland, to entice the King thither as privately as might be; he tells the King, there was a Man taken with much Gold Coin and ≈øu≈øpicious Letters, now at his Brothers Hou≈øe at St. John≈øtons, de≈øiring the King to come thither to Examine the Man with all ≈øpeed and privacy. The King promi≈øeth to be there the next day at Noon, and to do it whiles his Noblemen and Train ≈øhould be at Dinner. Alexander ≈øends Hender≈øon to his Brother John Earl Gowry with all ≈øpeed, to adverti≈øe him of the King's coming. The next day, being the fifth of Augu≈øt, the King came; and towards the end of his Dinner Alexander de≈øires the King to di≈øpatch the Bu≈øine≈øs: The King ari≈øing from the Table, Alexander leads him through four or five Rooms, locking each Door after him, till he came into the round Chamber, where Hender≈øon ≈øtood Armed; Alexander plucking out Hender≈øon's Dagger, points it to the King's Brea≈øt, ≈øaying, You mu≈øt die; for my Father's Blood calls for vengeance. The King deals gently with his Fury, and worked ≈øo upon him with words, that Alexander left him, and went to his Brother, leaving Hender≈øon with the King, who trembled at the Reverence of his Soveraign. The King asked Hender≈øon whether he would kill him? to whom Hender≈øon replied, Not for a World. By and by Alexander comes again with a Garter in his Hand, ≈øwearing that the King ≈øhould die; and then endeavoring to bind the King, the King and Alexander ≈øtrugling together, the King dragged him to the Window, holding him fa≈øt, as he could not ≈øtir; the King cried out Trea≈øon into a back Court; they ha≈øten up, and John Ram≈øey (formerly the King's Page) forced the Door at a back Way, and finding the King and Alexander panting (for the King having clo≈øed with him, never let loo≈øe his hold) the King bid Ram≈øey ≈øtrike low; whereupon Ram≈øey wounds Alexander mortally in the Belly with his Faucheon; then came others into the Room: They ca≈øt the King's Coat upon the dead Body, advi≈øing the King to withdraw into another Room. Pre≈øently enters John Earl Gowry with a Ca≈øe of Rapiers ready drawn, with ≈øeven Servants; then ≈øeeing the King's Coat on the dead Body, ≈øuppo≈øed the King was ≈ølain, and let fall the Points of his Weapons; and ≈øuddenly Herres a≈ø≈øails him with his ru≈øty Sword, and Ram≈øey ≈øtepping in, ≈øtrikes the Earl to the Heart. Thus was the King delivered by the Providence of God, Augu≈øt the fifth 1600, and Ram≈øey was Knighted for his Service, and had an addition given him to his Coat of Arms, to wit, of a Hand holding forth a Dagger, mounted proper, and piercing a bloody Heart, with this Motto‚ÄîHaec Dextra vindex Principis & Patriae, and after had other Honors conferred upon him.

The other miraculous Deliverance was from the mo≈øt bloody Plot of the Papi≈øts, commonly called The Gunpowder Trea≈øon, which ≈øhould have been executed the fifth day of November, Anno 1605. in the third Year after he was King of England; in memory of which Deliverance we have now a Form of Thank≈øgiving in our Common-Prayer-Book, to be u≈øed yearly on the fifth of November, and a Statute made 3 Jacobi cap. 1. for keeping that Day Holy-day, to be ≈øet apart yearly for a Thank≈øgiving to God for this great Deliverance, which ought never to be forgotten, but to be Recorded to all Po≈øterity; and the manner was thus:

A little before the beginning of that Parliament at We≈øtmin≈øter, ≈øome Welwiller to William Parker, Lord Monteagle, ≈øends him a Letter, to advi≈øe him to ≈øhift off his Attendance this Parliament, as he tendred his Life; ‚ÄîFor though there be no appearance of any Stir, yet they ≈øhall receive a terrible Blow this Parliament, and yet ≈øhall not ≈øee who hurts them, &c.

This Letter was given by an unknown Fellow, to a Footman of the Lord Monteagles,
with a charge to give it to his Lord's own Hands; which having neither Date nor Sub≈øcription, the Lord Monteagle (not knowing what to make of it) brings it to the Earl of Salisbury, then Secretary of State: But the King not being then in Town, the Secretary ≈øhews it to the Earl of Suffolk, and others; and upon the King's coming back on the Thur≈øday following, Salisbury ≈øhews it to the King, who, as it were by Divine In≈øtinct, conceived the Letter ought not to be contemned, and judged the words of the Letter to be meant of Gunpowder: But upon the meeting of the Council, order was given for the ≈øearching of all Rooms about the Parliament-Hou≈øe by the Lord Chamberlain; where a Vault was found under the Lords Hou≈øe ≈øtuffed with Wood and Coals; which Room was hired by Mr. Thomas Percy, a violent Papi≈øt, Kin≈øman to the Earl of Northumberland: But the care of a farther Search being committed to Sir Thomas Knevet, a Ju≈øtice of Peace for We≈øtmin≈øter, who the Night before the Parliament was to ≈øit, about twelve of the Clock in the Night, with competent A≈ø≈øi≈øtance with him, ≈øeized one Guido Faux, calling him≈øelf John John≈øon, and Percy's Man, at the Door of the Lodgings, ready Booted and Dre≈ø≈øed ≈øo late; and ≈øearching the Vault by removing ≈øome Billets, they found 36 Barrels of Powder, and in Faux's Pockets three Matches, a dark Lantern, and other Implements, nay, a Watch wherewith to tell the Minutes for Execution: All which he confe≈ø≈øed upon his Examination. There were other Contrivers of the Plot, Thomas Winter, Robert Catesby, Thomas Percy, John Wright, Chri≈øtopher Wright, and Robert Winter. Concerning which Plot, and the Confe≈ø≈øions of the Parties in their Examinations before the Privy Council, King James him≈øelf took pains to note it; which you may find among≈øt his Works in Print.

Anno Chr. 1625. This King James (as my Lord Bacon ob≈øerves in his Advancement of Learning, pag. 2.) was the mo≈øt Learned Temporal Monarch ≈øince Chri≈øt's time, in all Literature, Divine and Humane. He died at Theobalds on Sunday Morning the 27. of March 1625. in the 59. Year of his Age, and in the 58. of his Reign over Scotland, and having Reigned 22 Years compleat over England: who≈øe Son Charles I. a≈øcended his Father's Throne, and was the ≈øecond Monarch of all Great Britain and Ireland; who≈øe Subjects, as well of England as Scotland, are the mo≈øt rebellious People in the World, ever Factious, and perfidious towards their Prince. See the re≈øt in England.
So much of Scotland, the Revenues of which Kingdom Boterus e≈øtimateth at 100000 Crowns, or 30000 l. Sterling. Dr. Heylin's Co≈ømography, pag. 338.

div.head: A Table of the chief Battels between the Engli≈øh and the Scots, ≈øince the Norman Conque≈øt.
div.p: Ann. Dom. 1139. 4 Steph.AT Conton or Couton in York≈øhire, about four Miles from Alverton, Augu≈øt 22. 1139. where were ≈ølain above 10000 Scots, by Thur≈øtan, Archbi≈øhop of York. Stow. This is commonly called Standard-Field. Mat. Paris puts it Anno 1138. and onely among the Hor≈øemen of the Engli≈øh of any note, the Brother of Gilbert Lacy was found ≈ølain.
1174. 20 Hen. 2.At Alnwick in Northumberland, July 7. 1174. where William King of Scotland was taken Pri≈øoner by Robert de Stotevil, Rafe Mandevil, Bernard Baliol, and William Ve≈øcy.

1296. 24 Ed. 1.At Barwick the Engli≈øh ≈ølew 25000 Scots, and did win Barwick and Dunbar, and conquered Edenborough, where Edward the fir≈øt found the Regal En≈øigns of Scotland. In his Return he called a Parliament at Barwick, where he received the Homages and Fealty of the Nobility of Scotland. Stow.
1298. 26 Ed. 1.At Flowkirk in Scotland, July 22. 1298. where were ≈ølain more than 20000 Scots. Stow.

1313. 7 Edw. 2.At Sterling in Scotland, June 24. 1313. where the Engli≈øh were beaten. Wal≈øingham and Stow. Buchanan, pag. 264, 265, ≈øaith there fell 200 of the Nobility of England, or
thereabout, and near as many more of the Nobility taken Pri≈øoners, and 50000 common Soldiers were ≈ølain, as ≈øome Scots relate; and on the part of the Scots were ≈ølain about 4000. and onely two Knights; James Duglas then General of the Scotch Forces.

At a Place by Barwick called Bothul, near Halydown, 1332. 6 Edw. 3. where were ≈ølain on the part of the Scots, 8 Earls, 1300 Hor≈øe, and 35000 common Soldiers; and Turnebull the Scotch Champion was overcome in Combat by Sir Robert Nenale, a Norfolk Gentleman. Stow. This is called The Battel of Halydown Hill.

At Durham, the 27. of October 1346.1346. 20 Ed. 3. whiles King Edward the Third Be≈øieged Calice in France, David Bru≈øe, King of Scotland, (by the procurement of Philip, King of France) entered Northumberland with an Army of 60000 Men, and pitched near Durham, in a Park called Beverpeir; where the Archbi≈øhop of York, the Lord Zouch, Percy, Mowbray, and other Lords, and Sir Robert Bertram, Sheriff of Northumberland, with an Army of 30000 Men, met the Scots at Durham, and did beat them. In which Battel John Coupeland took David the King of Scotland Pri≈øoner, with three Scotch Earls. So Wal≈øingham. This John Coupeland of Northumberland had 500 l. per annum given him during his Life, for this Service, and was made a Banneret.

At Otterborn in Northumberland, the Scots under the Command of James Duglas, 1388. 12 Rich. 2. took Henry Percy the younger, and Rafe his Brother, Pri≈øoners, ≈ølew 1100 Engli≈øh, put to flight 30000 more. Stow. This was Fought about the 12. of the Calends of Augu≈øt, 1388. Buchanan ≈øaith the two Generals, Henry Percy of the Engli≈øh, and James Duglas of the Scots, ≈øingled them≈øelves out from the Army, and Fought apart; and Percy was unhor≈øed, but the Engli≈øh relieved him; and tells us, that there fell on the Engli≈øh ≈øide 1840, and about 1000 wounded, and 1040 taken Pri≈øoners, pag. 319.

At Hallydown, near the Town of Wollar, Sept. 14. 1402. where the Engli≈øh, 1402. 3 Hen. 4. conducted by Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland, and Henry his Son, took Earl Duglas, the Scotch General, Pri≈øoner, with divers others of the Flower of the Scotch Chivalry. Stow.

At Flodden-Field in Northumberland, September 9. 1513. wherein James IV.1513. 5. Hen. 8. King of Scotland, was ≈ølain at Bram≈øton on Piperd-Hill. Stow. Wherefore by ≈øome this is called Bram≈øton Field; by others, Flodden Field; and though the Day fell to the Engli≈øh, yet there was taken and ≈ølain of the Engli≈øh 1500. Thomas Howard, Earl of Surrey, being then General of the Engli≈øh.
At Solomo≈ø≈øe beyond Carli≈øle, November 24. 1542. where 15000 Scots, 1542. 34 Hen. 8. under the Command of the Lord Maxwell, were overthrown.

Mu≈øcleborough Field in Scotland, Fought September 10. 1547. where Edward Seymour, 1547. 1 Edw. 6. Duke of Somer≈øet, and Lord Protector, was General of the Engli≈øh Forces: 14000 Scots ≈ølain, and 1500 taken Pri≈øoners, and not above 60 Engli≈øh ≈ølain. Stow.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: Of the Name, Situation, and ancient Inhabitants of Ireland.

div.p:
I. IRELAND is called by Orpheus, Ari≈øtotle, and Claudian, IERNE; by Juvenal and Mela, IWERNA; by Diodorus Siculus, IRIS; by Martianus of Heracleota,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ by Eu≈øtathius,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ and BEP'NIA; by the Natives, ERIN; by the Brettans, YUERDON; and by the Engli≈øh, IRELAND; and Cambden mo≈øt probably concludes, that Hibernia, and Iwerna, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , flow from Ari≈øtotle's and Orpheus's Ierne, and that Ierna, Iuerhdon, Iris, and Ireland, do all ≈øpring from Erin, as the Inhabitants them≈øelves do call it; which Cambden conjectureth to come from the Iri≈øh word Hier, which in that Language ≈øignifies The We≈øt Point; ≈øo that Erin denotes as much as The We≈øt Countrey, or We≈øtern Land.

The Iri≈øh Bards in their Songs called it Tirvolac, Toridanan, and Banno, as by much the mo≈øt ancient Names of that I≈øland; but why (≈øaith Cambden) I cannot tell, unle≈øs Banno be that Bannomanna which Pliny mentions out of Timaeus, whiles he relates the utmo≈øt Parts of Europe, and the Shore of the North Ocean on the left Hand, from Scythia even to the Gades. What that Bannomanna was, is not yet known to Geographers: But Biaun in Iri≈øh, is Holy in Engli≈øh; and Fe≈øtus Avienus calleth this of Ireland, The Holy I≈øland.

If that Ogygia, which Plutarch placeth at the We≈øt of our Brettaine, be no Dream, but a true Vi≈øion, he may ≈øeem to point out Ireland by that Name; howbeit, the things which he ≈øpeaks of are meer Poetical Fictions, and Mile≈øian Fables: nor can any tell why they named it Ogygia, unle≈øs perhaps from the Antiquity; for the Grecians call nothing Ogygia, but what is very ancient.

II. It containeth 300 Miles in length, and ≈øcarce 120 in breadth, and hath England on the Ea≈øt, from whence it is ≈øevered by a boi≈øterous Sea, called The Channel of St. George, or The Iri≈øh Sea. On the We≈øt part it is environed with the va≈øt Ocean, called The We≈øtern Ocean; on the North, with the Deucalidonian Ocean; and on the South, with the Vergivian Ocean; ≈øituate under the eighth and tenth Climates; the longe≈øt Day being 16 Hours and a half in the Southern Parts, and 17 Hours and 3 quarters in the Northern.

III. It is ob≈øerved among other things, that in this I≈øland there is neither Snake nor Toad, nor any venomous Creature, neither will any ≈øuch live in that Soil, if brought
from other Places. And all living Creatures in Ireland are of a le≈ø≈øer ≈øize in their Kind than tho≈øe in England, except Women and Greyhounds, and tho≈øe are bigger than with us in England. It abounds with Sheep and Cattel, but much infe≈øted with Wolves. The Kernes, or wild Iri≈øh, are extremely barbarous.

IV. To omit the many Fables devi≈øed by the ancient Iri≈øh Hi≈øtorians, as that Cae≈øarea, the Neece of Noah, ≈øhould inhabit here before the Flood, with many other of the like ≈øtamp. It ≈øeems to be Peopled very anciently by the Brettans, for that many ancient words in the Iri≈øh Language do ≈øavour of the Briti≈øh Original; and that the Iri≈øh and the Brettans were not much different in their Di≈øpo≈øitions and Manners, as Tacitus ≈øaith; and that by all ancient Writers, as Diodorus Siculus, Ptolemy, and Strabo, it is reckoned among the Briti≈øh I≈ølands. And there is no Nation (by rea≈øon of the nearne≈øs) whence they may pa≈øs more commodiou≈øly to Ireland, than out of our Brettain, from whence they may be as ≈øoon wafted into Ireland, as out of France into Brettain.

We read not that ever the Romans ≈øubdued Ireland; but in the declining State of the Roman Empire, the Nation of the Scots or Scythians (Celto Scythae, ut habet Strabo, omnes ol√¨m ad occa≈øum Populi dicti) waxed ≈øtrong in Ireland. Oro≈øius writes, That in the time of Honorius and Arcadius, Emperors, Ireland was inhabited by the Scots about Anno Chri≈øti 400.

The≈øe Scots came out of Spain into Ireland, and part of them going again out of Ireland into the North of Brettain (≈øub Duce Reud√¢, √† quo Dal-Reudini vocantur; Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. lib. 1. cap. 1.) Seated them≈øelves there, and added a third Nation in Brettaine to the Picts and Brettans, and afterwards from tho≈øe Scots the whole North of Brettain was called Scotland even to this day.
And from tho≈øe Scots inhabitng Ireland, that Kingdom was by I≈øidore and Bede called Scotia; Haec propri√® Patria Scottorum e≈øt, ≈øaith Bede of Ireland, l. 1. de Hi≈øt. Ang. c. 1.
Anno Chri≈øti 684. Egfrid, King of Northumberland, wa≈øted Ireland. Bede, ib. l. 4. c. 26.

Anno Chri≈øti 838. the Norwegians, under the Command of Turge≈øius, for 30 Years mi≈øerably wa≈øted Ireland; but he being ≈ølain by Treachery, the Inhabitants ≈ølew all the Norwegians. Giraldus Topogram. Hiberniae, Di≈øtinct. 3. cap. 37. The≈øe Norwegians without doubt were tho≈øe Normans, who (as Rhegino ≈øaith) in the Times of Charles the Great ≈øetting upon Ireland, the I≈øland of the Scots, were put to flight by the Scots.
Afterwards the Ou≈øtmanni, that is, The Ea≈øtern Men, came from the Sea-coa≈øt of Germany into Ireland, under pretence of Merchandize, and ≈øoon after rai≈øed a great War.
About the ≈øame time almo≈øt, Edgar, King of England, overcame a great part of Ireland, and ≈øubjected it under his Dominion. Cambden's Britannia, pag. 731.

But be≈øides the≈øe, there aro≈øe great Di≈ø≈øention among the Iri≈øh them≈øelves, which made way to the conquering of Ireland: for the King of England, Hen. II. taking notice of the≈øe Jars, Treated ≈øeriou≈øly with his Nobles of England, about the Year 1155. concerning the conquering of Ireland, for the u≈øe of his Brother William of Angeau; but by the Advice of his Mother Maude, the Empre≈øs, the Matter was at that time deferred. Not many Years after, Dermot Mac Morrog, King of Lein≈øter, (being driven out of his Kingdom by Rodoric, King of Connaught, and Monarch of Ireland) implores the Aid of Hen. II. who conde≈øcending thereunto, Dermot prevailed with Richard de Clare, Earl of Pembroke, ≈øirnamed Strongbow (Son of Gilbert de Clare, Earl of Pembroke, which Gilbert was a younger Son of Gilbert, Earl of Clare in Suffolk) to rai≈øe Forces for his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, Covenanting to make Strongbow his Succe≈ø≈øor in the Kingdom of Lein≈øter, and to give unto him Eva his Daughter in Marriage. Hereupon Strongbow gathers an Army of ≈øelect Soldiers in Wales and England, accompanied with Fitz-Gerald, Fitz-Stephen, and other Gentlemen, and in few Years obtained ≈øo great a part of Ireland, that Hen. II. fearing his Power, ≈øends out his Proclamation in Anno 1171. That Strongbow and other his A≈ø≈øociates ≈øhould return back out of Ireland by Ea≈øter next, or el≈øe be utterly Di≈øinherited for ever. Strongbow returns into England; the King is pacified with him, Conditionally, that he ≈øurrender Dublin to the King, with the Cantreds adjoyning, and al≈øo all the Maritime Towns and Ca≈øtles; the re≈øidue of his Conque≈øt he mu≈øt acknowledge to hold from the King of England and his Heirs. So Giraldus.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the chief Per≈øons in the Conque≈øt of Ireland.

div.p: I. RIchard Strongbow, Earl of Pembroke, a Man much in Debt, had large Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, but had much le≈øned his E≈øtate by his profu≈øene≈øs, and therefore more ea≈øily drawn in to the getting of new Territories. Chron. Joh. Brompton, pag. 1069. Vir plus nominis hacten√πs habens, quam hominis: plus ≈øenii, qu√†m ingenii. Giraldus Hib. Expug. li. 1. cap. 12. Of a ruddy Complexion, Freckled, great Eyes, a womanly Face, a ≈ømall Voice, a ≈øhort Neck, Bountiful, and of a mild Nature; being fixed in Battel, was a Standard for his Forces to re≈øort unto; not puffed up with a Victory, nor dejected with a Defeat. Giraldus Hib. Expug. lib. 1. cap. 27. He was ≈øirnamed Strongbow from the ≈øtrong Bowe which he u≈øed to draw, having Arms of an extraordinary length; of whom it is reported, that ≈øtanding upright, he could touch his own Knees with the Palms of his Hands. Brooke in his Catalogue of Nobility, Title Pembroke. The King of England, Hen. II. gave him what accrued unto him in Right of Eva his Wife, and what he had got in War, and gave him the Counties of We≈øhford, O≈ø≈øery, Caterlogh, and Kildare, to hold of the Kings of England. Cambd. Britan. pag. 731. Ireland. He died An. Chr. 1176. and Dermot King of Lein≈øter, his Father-in-law, died at Fernys, about the Calends of May, Anno 1171. full of Days. Annales Hiberniae, at the end of Camb. Britan.

II. Hugh Lacy was al≈øo very in≈øtrumental in the Conque≈øt of Ireland; to whom Hen. II. gave all the Land of Meath in Ireland, with the Apurtenances, by Charter, to hold of him and his Son John, for the Service of 100 Knights Fees: He gave him al≈øo in cu≈øtody, the City of Dublin, with its Apurtenances, and appointed the≈øe following to belong to the Service of Dublin, ‚Äîall the Land of Offlan, with its Apurtenances, and Wilkechelon with its Apurtenances, and the Service of Meath, and the Service of four Knights Fees, which Robert Poer ought to do for the Ca≈øtle of Dunavet. Hoveden, pag. 528. & 566. He was De≈øcended of Walter Lacy, a great Baron, who Founded Lanthony-Abby in the Valley of Ewyas, in the Borders of Monmouth≈øhire; to which Walter, William Earl of Hereford gave great Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions in tho≈øe Parts. Cambden in Monmouth≈øhire. This Hugh was of a black Complexion, hollow Eyes; the right ≈øide of his Face even to his Chin, was disfigured by Burning, which hapned in his Youth; a ≈øhort Neck, a hairy Body, ≈øtrong Sinews, of a little Stature, and a deformed Shape; firm to his Tru≈øt, intent on his own Bu≈øine≈øs, and very vigilant in the Affairs of Government, a good Soldier, much tru≈øted by his Prince, who made him Lord Ju≈øtice of Ireland, 1172. Hoveden, pag. 528. He Fortified Lein≈øter and Meath, with many Ca≈øtles; and had his Head chopt off with a Hatchet by an Iri≈øhman treacherou≈øly, as he ≈øtooped down, Anno 1186. at Dernath, where he intended to have built a Ca≈øtle. Hoveden, pag. 631. al≈øo Annales Hiberniae. He left two Sons of great eminency in Ireland, Walter de Lacy, Lord of Meath, and Hugh Lacy, Earl of Ul≈øter afterwards.

III. Robert Fitz-Stephen was the fir≈øt of Strong-bow's Forces, who entred Ireland with three Ships, containing about 130 Soldiers of his Friends and Allies, Landing at Banvan about May, Anno 1167. be≈øides 60 other Hor≈øe, and 300 Foot Archers, among whom Hervey de Mont-Morice: The Day after, Maurice de Prenderge≈øt followed with two Ships of Soldiers more, rai≈øed out of Cardigan≈øhire, or thereabouts [De Ro≈øen≈øi Walliae Demetiae Provinci√¢.] The≈øe with 500 Soldiers more, ≈øent by Dermot out of his own Countrey, under the Command of his Ba≈øtard Son Donwald, A≈ø≈øaulted We≈øhford, but were beaten back, and the next Day it was ≈øurrendred to Dermot, who gave We≈øhford with its Apurtenances, to Robert Fitz-Stephen, and to Maurice, and to their Heirs, according to his former Agreement; and to Hervey de Mont-Morice, he gave two Cantreds of Land, lying after the Sea between We≈øhford and Waterford. Girald. Hib. Exp. l. 1. c. 3.

The Annals of Ireland ≈øay, That Fitz-Stephen entred Ireland Anno 1168. and that Strongbow followed 1169. with about 1200 Soldiers, Landing at Waterford the 23. of Augu≈øt, and on the 25. of Augu≈øt he took Waterford; and there Eva, the Daughter of Dermot, was Married to Strongbow, given by her Father. But Roger Hoveden ≈øaith, That Strongbow came into Ireland Anno 1168. and then Fitz-Stephen, who went before him, entred Ireland 1167.

Thus Robert Fitz-Stephen prepared way for Earl Strongbow, and Strongbow for the King of England, to the Dominion of Ireland. We≈øhford was the fir≈øt Colony Planted by this Fitz-Stephen with the Engli≈øh in Ireland, which to this day retains the ancient Engli≈øh Attire, and much of their Language, as a Badge of their Conque≈øt, and which by the Natives there is yet known and called by the Name of We≈øhford-Speach.

To Robert Fitz-Stephen and Milo Coggan, King Hen. II. gave the Kingdom of Cork, for the Service of 60 Knights Fees, 1177. except the City of Cork, with one Cantred, which the King retained to him≈øelf and his Heirs. Hoveden, pag. 567.

This Robert Fitz-Stephen was the onely Example of Valour and Indu≈øtry; one that had often ta≈øted the various turnings of Fortune, as well in Ireland as in Wales; like Marius Secundus, if you look back upon his Felicity, none more pro≈øperous and happy; if upon his Mi≈øery, none more unfortunate and mi≈øerable: A Man of a large and ≈øound Body, of a comely Countenance, of little more than a middle Stature, ≈øumptuous and plentiful in his Diet, bountiful and plea≈øant, but immoderately given to Wine and Women. Giraldus Hib. Expug. lib. 1. cap. 26.

About Anno Chri≈øti 1165, or 1164. Rees ap Griffin, Prince of Southwales, Be≈øieged Aber-Tivy Ca≈øtle, and took it, and demoli≈øhed the ≈øame; where Robert Fitz-Stephen was taken Pri≈øoner by Rees his Co≈øin-german, and after three Years Impri≈øonment he was relea≈øed by Rees, upon Condition that he would joyn with Rees again≈øt the King of England: But he cho≈øe rather to go into Ireland with Dermot, than to be perfidious to his Prince. Giraldus. But Cambden in Cardigan≈øhire ≈øaith, he was relea≈øed on Condition that he would relinqui≈øh his Right to his Lands in Wales. He was the Son of Stephen, High Con≈øtable of Southwales, and Governor of Aber-Tivy, that is Cardigan in Wales, Cambden; called Con≈øtable of Aber-Tivy in the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory put out by Powel.

This Stephen Married Ne≈øt, Daughter of Rees the Great, Prince of Southwales, and the Widow of Gerald of Wind≈øor. By Gerald ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Maurice Fitz-Gerald, a principal A≈ø≈øi≈øtant in the Conque≈øt of Ireland. By Stephen ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue this Robert Fitz-Stephen, who had no lawful I≈ø≈øue by his Wife, ≈øaith Giraldus, Hib. Expug. lib. 2. cap. 17. He then had a Ba≈øtard; for Giraldus in another place, lib. 1. cap. 40. makes mention of Radulfus, Stephanidae filius, who de≈øerved very well for his Valour, when O-Roric, King of Meath was killed; which O-Roric had like to have killed Hugh Lacy by Treachery.

This Rafe, Son of Robert Fitz-Stephen, was ≈ølain with his Father-in-law Milo de Coggan, between Waterford and Li≈ømore, Anno 1179. by one Machtyrus treacherou≈øly. Annales Hiberniae. al≈øo Giraldus, Hib. Expug. lib. 2. cap. 18. Robert Fitz-Stephen had al≈øo another Ba≈øtard Son called Mereducius. Giraldus ibidem.

IV. Maurice Fitz-Gerald, another A≈ø≈øi≈øtant in the Conque≈øt of Ireland, a Man well modelled in Mind and Body, of an innate Goodne≈øs, of little Speech, but full of weight, circum≈øpect in Dangers, not ra≈øh, but re≈øolute when once re≈øolved on by him; a ≈øober, mode≈øt, and cha≈øte Man; Valiant, and Faithful; not altogether without Faults, yet without any notorious Crime. He died at We≈øhford about Augu≈øt 1176. and had three Sons; William the elde≈øt Married Ellen, Daughter of Earl Strongbow. Giraldus another Son, Alexander another Son, and Ne≈øt a Daughter, Married to Hervey. Giraldus, Hib. Expug. lib. 1. cap. 42. & cap. 23. lib. 2. cap. 5. & cap. 15.

V. Reymund, another principal Per≈øon, was Son of William Fitz-Gerald, and Nephew to Maurice Fitz-Gerald, and to Robert Fitz-Stephen, by the elde≈øt Brother. He Married Ba≈øilia, Si≈øter of Earl Strongbow, about the Year 1174. but had no I≈ø≈øue by her. He was Con≈øtable to Strongbow, to wit, Praefectus Familiae, The Governor or Lord Mar≈øhal of his Hou≈øhold. Of a yellow Hair, ≈øomewhat curling, great Eyes, grey and round, a high No≈øe, a chearful Countenance, and good Complexion; Provident and Prudent.

VI. John Curcy was a gallant Man at Arms.Ann. Dom. 1177. He was the fir≈øt of all the Engli≈øh who ≈øubdued Ul≈øter in Ireland, Anno 1177, not till then ≈øubdued. He Married Africa, the Daughter of Gotred, King of the I≈øle of Man. It is ob≈øerved of the≈øe four Props of Ireland, Fitz-Stephen, Hervey, Reymund, and this Curcy, Girald. Hib. Expug. lib 2. cap. 17. that they had no I≈ø≈øue by their Wives. Hoveden, pag. 561.

This John was the fir≈øt Earl of Ul≈øter, and of the Family of the Curcyes of Stoke-Curcy in Somer≈øet≈øhire. Cambden. In the Year 1204. he had a great Battel at Down in Ireland, with Hugh Lacy (Son of the fir≈øt Hugh) and got the Day, but afterwards by Treachery was delivered to Hugh Lacy, who brought him to King John; and the King gave the Earldom of Ul≈øter, and the Dominion of Connaught, to the ≈øaid Hugh Lacy, Annales Hiberniae, and Curcy never got his Right again.

It is ≈øaid of this John Curcy, that he ≈øhould have fought a Duel for the King again≈øt the King of France's Champion; but that Champion dur≈øt not meddle with him. He ≈øtrook his Sword through a Head-piece ≈øo deep into a Block, that none could pull it out but him≈øelf. Annales Hiberniae, ≈øub Anno 1204. put in the end of Cambden's Britannia after Ireland.

There were al≈øo ≈øome others, as Robert le Poer, the King's Mar≈øhal in Ireland, to whom Henry the Second gave Waterford Town in cu≈øtody, with all the Apurtenances. And he appointed all the Land between Waterford and the Water beyond Li≈ømores, and all the Land of Oi≈øeric, with its Apurtenances, to belong to the Service of Waterford. Hoveden, pag. 567.

And al≈øo afterwards at Marleberge, the King gave to Philip de Breos all the Kingdom of Limrick, for the Service of 60 Knights Fees: for Herbert and William, Brothers of Reginald Earl of Cornwal, and Jo≈ølan de la Pumerai their Nephew, would not have that Kingdom (though given them before by the King) becau≈øe it was not yet gotten: for Monoderus, King of Limrick, being ≈ølain by the Engli≈øh, after he had ≈øworn Fealty to the King of England, there aro≈øe up another of his Progeny, who would not ≈øubmit, becau≈øe of the infidelity of the Engli≈øh: al≈øo the King of Cork, and divers others of the better ≈øort of the Iri≈øh rebelled again≈øt the King of England. Hoveden, pag. 567. Joh. Bromton, pag. 1128.

list.item:
The Princes of Ireland who ≈øubmitted to the Rule of the King of England, Henry the Second, Anno 1172. Chartis ≈øub≈øignatis, & Romam tran≈ømi≈ø≈øis. Cambd. Britan. pag. 731.
ROtheric O-Conor-Dun, Fu≈øcus Hiberniae Monarcha.
Dermot Mac-Carty, King of Cork.
Donald O-Bren, King of Limrick.
O-Carel, King of Uriel.
Mac-Shaglin, Rex Ophaliae.
O-Roric, King of Meath.
O-Nele, King of Ul≈øter; and the chief Noblemen of them all.

div.p: Now followeth a Catalogue of all the Lord Deputies of Ireland

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: A Catalogue of the Chief Governors of Ireland, under the Sovereignty of the Kings of England, ≈øince the Conque≈øt thereof by Henry the Second, to the Year 1670. Stiled ≈øometimes Lord Ju≈øtices, ≈øometimes Lord Lieutenants, ≈øometimes Lord Deputies of Ireland.

div.p: Ann. Dom. 1171 HEnry the Second, King of England, landed at Croch in Ireland, eight Miles from Waterford, the 17 of October, 1171. and ≈øtaid there till Ea≈øter following: In which ≈øpace the Princes of Ireland ≈øubmit, and ≈øwore Fealty to him; Roderik King of Connaught being as it were the Chief Head and Monarch of Ireland. Hoveden and Giraldus.
The Conque≈øt of Ireland was before prepared for him, Anno 1168. by Richard Strongbow, who then entred Ireland with his Forces, and very victoriou≈øly winning one Place after another. Hoveden.

The King of Connaught agreeth to hold all his Lands under the King of England,‚Äî Ut Rodericus ≈øit Rex ≈øub Henrico paratus ad Servitium ≈øuum; and to pay him Tribute, as the words of the Deed run, which you may ≈øee at large in Hoveden's Hi≈øtory, or Annals, bearing date in the Octaves of St. Michael, 1175. made at the Parliament at Wind≈øor in England.
1. Hugh Lacy, Lord Ju≈øtice of Ireland.
2. Richard Strongbow, Lord Ju≈øtice. Obiit 1176. Hoveden.
3. William Fitz-Aldelme, Ju≈øtice of Ireland. Hoveden.

But Giraldus, Hiber. Expug. lib. 2. cap. 15. ≈øaith, Reymund was elected Governor of Ireland, while Me≈ø≈øengers were ≈øent to the King of England to certifie him of Strongbow's death; who forthwith ≈øent William Fitz-Aldelme Procuratorem in Hiberniam, joyning with him John Curcy, Robert Fitz-Stephen, and Milo de Coggan, in Commi≈ø≈øion.

4. Hugh Lacy again, made Generalis Hiberniae Procurator; Robert le Poer the King's Mar≈øhal, being joyned as an A≈ø≈øi≈øtant to him: which Robert was then Governor both of Waterford and We≈øhford. Giraldus.

5. John Lacy, Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and Baron of Halton, with Richard Peche Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, were ≈øent into Ireland about the Calends of May, 1181. and made Governors of Dublin; for the King had ≈øent for Hugh Lacy, as jealous of his Strength and Power in Ireland, having now married the Daughter of Roderik King of Connaught, without the King of England's Licence fir≈øt obtained. Hoveden.
6. Hugh Lacy again, in the Winter following, eodem Anno; Robert of Shrewsbury, a Clergy-man, being joyned with him.
7. Philip of Worce≈øter, vir Dap≈øilis & Militaris. Hib. Expug. lib. 2. cap. 24. (called by Hoveden, Philip de Breos) ≈øent Governor into Ireland about the Calends of September.

8. John the King's Son (afterwards King John) went into Ireland, but ≈øoon returned, after he had appointed Ju≈øtices, and ≈øettled the Garri≈øons there. Hoveden. But who tho≈øe Ju≈øtices were, he mentions not.

Hoveden ≈øaith, That Anno 1176. the King of England gave Ireland to his Son John; and then after at a Parliament at Oxford, Anno 1177. the King did con≈øtitute him Regem in Hiberni√¢, Conce≈ø≈øione & Confirmatione Alexandri ≈øummi Pontificis: And Anno 1185. 31 Hen. 2. the King Knighted him at Wind≈øor the la≈øt day of March, and
≈øends him forthwith into Ireland (where he ≈øtaid not long) & ind√® eum Regem con≈øtituit.

Certain it is, That this John (after he became King of England) a≈ø≈øumed the Title of Dominus Hiberniae to his other Titles; which al≈øo the ≈øucceeding Kings of England ever ≈øince retained, until the Year 1542. 33 Hen. 8. at which time, by a Parliament in Ireland, King Henry the Eighth was declared King of Ireland, as a Title of greater Maje≈øty; which Title of Rex Hiberniae, the Kings of England have u≈øed ever ≈øince.

Probably when the King gave unto his Son John, Dominium Hiberniae, 1176, it was as much as King of Ireland in effect, whereby the Supreme Power was implied; and from thence we ≈øee he a≈ø≈øumed the Title of Dominus Hiberniae afterwards: But it is not probable, that the King did create him Regem Hiberniae by Charter (though po≈ø≈øibly he might ≈øometimes be ≈øo called) for then he would have a≈ø≈øumed the Title of Rex Hiberniae, and not of Dominus Hiberniae, which afterwards we find he a≈ø≈øumed; but never Rex Hiberniae.
Ann. Dom. 1211
9. John Grey Bi≈øhop of Norwich, Lord Ju≈øtice. Matt. Paris. King John went then into Ireland.
10. Henry Londers Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, Lord Ju≈øtice. Annales Hiberniae.

list.head: Sub Henrico Tertio.
list.item: 1224. ‚Äî The ≈øame Archbi≈øhop of Dublin. Fuller's Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. lib. 3. pag. 58.

The≈øe following are Collected out of the Annals of Ireland, apud Cambdenum in Britannia ≈øua, to the Year 1420.

1281. 24. Stephen de Fulborne, Archiepi≈øcopus Turonen≈øis, Lord Ju≈øtice eodem Anno. Ufford goes into England; and Fulborne dieth, Anno 1287.

list.item: Ann. Dom. 1312. 30. Sir Edmund le Butler is made Deputy to Sir John Wogan. Both died 1321.
1314. 31. Sir Theobald de Verdon, Lord Ju≈øtice. He came into Ireland the 20 of June.
1314. 32. Sir Edmund le Butler, Lord Ju≈øtice. He received his Commi≈ø≈øion on Friday after St. Matthew's day.

1317. 33. Sir Roger de Mortimer, Lord Ju≈øtice; but going into England to the King, makes William Archiepi≈øcopum Ca≈ø≈øilien≈øem, Cu≈øtodem Hiberniae; who was Lord Ju≈øtice, Chancellor, and Archbi≈øhop, all at a time, 1318. And in Anno 1319. Sir Roger returns, and is Lord Ju≈øtice.

1328. 38. Roger Outlaw, Prior of Kilmaynan, Lord Ju≈øtice. He was Prior of the Ho≈øpital of St. John of Jeru≈øalem in Ireland, and Chancellor of Ireland: Nicolas Fa≈øtoll, and Elias A≈øhburne, Ju≈øticiarrii de Banco.
1329. 39. John Darcy, ≈øecond time Lord Ju≈øtice. Darcy going into England 1330. Roger Outlaw is deputed Ju≈øtice.
1331. 40. Sir Anthony Lucy comes Chief Ju≈øtice, 3 die Junii.
1333. 41. Sir John Darcy, third time Ju≈øtice.

1337. 42. Sir John Charleton (Miles & Baro) came Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, in Fe≈øto Calixti Papae. Thomas Charleton Bi≈øhop of Hereford, Brother to Sir John, Chancellor of Ireland; and John Rees Trea≈øurer.

1338. 43. Thomas Charleton Bi≈øhop of Hereford, Lord Ju≈øtice and Governor, Anno 1340. The Bi≈øhop of Hereford called into England by the King, Roger Outlaw again was made Lord Ju≈øtice; who died Lord Ju≈øtice, and Chancellor of Ireland, 13 die Februarii.
1341. 44. Sir John Darcy, the fourth time, now made Lord Ju≈øtice for his Life.
Sir John Morrice comes into Ireland, men≈øe Maii, 1341. Deputy to John Darcy.
1343. 45. 13 die Julii, Sir Rafe Ufford, with his Con≈øort the Counte≈øs of Ul≈øter, came into Ireland Lord Chief Ju≈øtice. He died on Palm-Sunday, the 9 of April, 1346.

1346. 46. Sir Roger Darcy, Lord Ju≈øtice ad tempus, de a≈ø≈øen≈øu & Ordinatione Regalium & aliorum in Hiberni√¢: And Sir John Morris comes Lord Chief Ju≈øtice May 15. 1346. who being put out by the King, Sir Walter Bermingham was in≈øtituted; men≈øe Junii he came into Ireland.

1348. 47. John Archprior of Kilmaynan, Deputy to Sir Walter in his ab≈øence; but Sir Walter returns out of England Lord Ju≈øtice, as before; to whom the King gave the Barony of Kenlys in O≈ø≈øery, which belonged to Eu≈øtace le Poer, who was attainted and hanged. Obiit Bermingham, quond√†m Optimus Ju≈øticiarius Hiberniae, in Vigili√¢ Margaretae Virginis, 1350. in Angli√¢.
1349. 48. Dominus de Carew, Miles & Baro, Lord Ju≈øtice.
1350. 49. Sir Thomas Rokesby, Lord Ju≈øtice.

1355. 50. Sir Thomas went out of his Ju≈øtice-≈øhip July 26. and Maurice Fitz-Thomas, Earl of De≈ømond, is made Lord Ju≈øtice. He continued as long as he lived, which was not long; for he died in Dublin-Ca≈øtle die Conver≈øionis Sancti Pauli following.
1356. 51. 31 Edw. 3. Sir Thomas Rokesby again Lord Ju≈øtice. Obiit eodem Anno.
1357. 52. Sir Almaric de Sancto Amando, Lord Ju≈øtice.
1359. 53. James Butler Earl of Ormond, Lord Chief Ju≈øtice.

1360. 54. 35 Edw. 3. the Earl of Ormond coming into England, Maurice Fitz-Thomas, Earl of Kildare, is made Chief Ju≈øtice, ut ≈øequitur. OMnibus ad quos hae Literae pervenerint, Salutem. Sciatis, qu√≤d Commi≈øimus dilecto & fideli no≈øtro Mauritio Comiti de Kildare, Officium Ju≈øticiarii no≈øtri Terrae no≈øtrae Hiberniae, & Terram no≈øtram Hiberniam, c√πm Ca≈øtris & omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis Cu≈øtodiendam, Quamdiu nobis placuerit: Recipiendo ad Scaccarium no≈øtrum Dubliniae per Annum, quamdi√π in Officio illo ≈øic ≈øteterit, quingentas Libras: Pro quibus Officium illud & terram Cu≈øtodiet; & erit vic ‚Ä¢ ≈øimus de hominibus ad arma c√πm tot equis Coopertis continu√® durante Commi≈ø≈øione no≈øtr√¢ ≈øupradict√¢. In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium, &c. Datum per manus dilecti no≈øtri in Chri≈øto Fratris Thomae de Burgey, Prioris Ho≈øpitalis Sancti Johannis Hieru≈øalem in Hibernia, Cancellarii no≈øtri Hiberniae; apud Dubliniam, 30 die Martii, 35 Edw. 3.
And after the Return of the Earl of Ormond into Ireland, Ormond was Ju≈øtice as before, and the Earl of Kildare ≈øurcea≈øed.

1361. 55. Lionel Duke of Clarence, third Son of King Edward the Third, and Earl of Ul≈øter in Right of Elizabeth his Wife, Daughter and Heir of William de Burgo Earl of Ul≈øter, venit in Hiberniam Locumtenens Domini Regis, in Octavis Nativitatis Beatae Mariae. Here was the fir≈øt Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. Anno 1364. April 22. Lionel went into England, leaving Ormond his Deputy of Ireland. Lionel returned the eighth of December. He was ≈øent for again into England, 1365. and then leaves Sir Thomas Dale, his Servant, Governor and Ju≈øtice of Ireland. Lionel died at Languvil in Italy, 1368. Cambden, apud Albam in Piemont.
1367. 56. Gerald Fitz-Maurice, Earl of De≈ømond, Lord Ju≈øtice.
1369. 57. Sir William de Wind≈øore came into Ireland the 12 of July, Lord Lieutenant.
1372. 58. Sir Robert (alii Richard) de A≈øhton, Lord Ju≈øtice of Ireland.
59. Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March and Ul≈øter, Lord Lieutenant. He died at Cork, 1381. 5 Rich. 2.

And after that, the King granted him the Kingdom and Sovereignty of Ireland by Letters Patents, (≈øaith Brook the York-Herald) and to bear for his Arms, Azure, three Crowns Gold, in a Border Argent, to be quartered before his own Coat. Obiit in Lovani√¢, 1392.

Rex Anglia contr√† Juramentum, quod prae≈øtiterat, revocavit de Hiberni√¢ Ju≈øticiarios, quos ol√¨m de Con≈øen≈øu ≈øuo Proceres propter defectus eorum notabiles Con≈øtitu√™runt exulare: So Wal≈øingham, ≈øub Anno 1397. 20 Rich. 2. pag. 353.

list.head: Sub Henrico Quarto.
list.item: 1400. 62. Sir John Stanley, Lord Lieutenant.

1401. 63. In May Sir John went into England, leaving Sir William Stanley in his Place: And on St. Bartholomew's Eve, eodem Anno, Stephen Scroope entred Ireland, Deputy to Thomas of Lanca≈øter, the King's Son, Lord Lieutenant, who came into Ireland in die Sancti Bricii (November 13.) eodem Anno.

div.p: Anno 1403. about the eleventh of November, Thomas the King's Son going into England, left Stephen Scroope his Deputy; and Scroope going into England the fir≈øt day of Lent, the Noblemen of Ireland chu≈øe the Earl of Ormond Lord Ju≈øtice.
Anno 1405. Scroope (the Deputy of Thomas of Lanca≈øter) returns into Ireland; but going again into England, the Earl of Ormond is Ju≈øtice.
Anno 1406. Scroope returning after Michaelmas into Ireland, is Deputy, as before.
Anno 1407. Scroope going this Year al≈øo into England, James Butler Earl of Ormond is elected Lord Ju≈øtice.

Anno 1408. Thomas of Lanca≈øter, Lord Lieutenant, lands at Carlingford in Ireland, the ≈øecond of Augu≈øt. In this Year died Stephen Scroope at Tri≈øtel-Dermot, 16 die Januarii: And the third of the Ides of March following, Sir Thomas de Lanca≈øter, Lord Lieutenant, going for England, leaves the Prior of Kilmaynan his Deputy in Ireland.
Thomas of Lanca≈øter was ≈ølain at the Battel of Bangy by the Duke of Alan≈øon, 22 Martii, being Ea≈øter Eve, Anno Domini 1421. 9 Hen. 5. Stow.

list.head: Sub Henrico Quinto.
list.item: Ann. Dom. 1413. The Prior of Kilmaynan continued Ju≈øtice to 1413.
64. 7 die Octobris, Sir John Stanley lands at Cloncarfe in Ireland, the ≈øecond time Lord Lieutenant of Ireland; and died the ≈øixth of January following.
1413. 65. The eleventh of February, Thomas Cranley, Archbi≈øhop of Dublin, is elected Lord Ju≈øtice of Ireland.

1414. 66. Sir John Talbot Lord Furnival lands at Dalkey in Ireland, the tenth of November, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. Anno 1419. July 22. Sir John Talbot went into England, much in debt, and left the Archbi≈øhop of Dublin his Deputy. This was the Famous John Talbot, Mar≈øhal of France under Hen. 6. who was Earl of Shrewsbury, and al≈øo created Earl of Waterford in Ireland, 1446. 24 Hen. 6. and al≈øo Sene≈øchal or High Steward of Ireland, to him and his Heirs, after the manner of the High Stewards of England in their Office. He was killed at the Battel of Burdeaux in France, 1453. Vincent upon Brooke, Title Shrewsbury.
1420. 67. James Butler, Earl of Ormond, lands at Waterford the fourth of April, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.

div.p: So far out of the Annals of Ireland.

148. Sir VVilliam Par≈øons,‚Äî Sir John Borlace, Ma≈øter of the Ordnance, February 9. Lord Ju≈øtices. 1640.
149. Sir John Borlace,‚Äî Sir Henry Tichborn, May 1. Lord Ju≈øtices. 1643.

150. James Butler, Marque≈øs of Ormond, February 21. Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. The Rebellion of the Parliament of England was now broken out, by rai≈øing Arms and Forces again≈øt the King; and great Troubles aro≈øe both in England and Ireland. 1643.

Anno 1649. Oliver Cromwel Voted General of all the Forces ≈øent again≈øt Ireland by the Parliament of England, March 30. On the 20 of June following, Dublin was Be≈øieged by the Marque≈øs of Ormond; and on Augu≈øt 2. he was defeated before Dublin by Colonel Jones and his Party, who i≈ø≈øued out of the Town; and Ireland reduced by Cromwel ≈øoon after.

list.head: Sub Carolo Secundo.
list.item: 151. King Charles the Second being re≈øtored to his Kingdoms, 1660. makes James Butler (now Duke of Ormond) Lord Liutenant of Ireland, 1662. who landed in Ireland 28 die Julii, eodem Anno. 1662.
152. The Duke of Ormond is de≈øired by the King to ≈øurrender his Commi≈ø≈øion; and the Lord Roberts, Lord Privy Seal, is made Lieutenant of Ireland in February. 1668.
153. Roberts is recalled, and John Lord Barkley came Lord Lieutenant. 1670.
