div.p: SOME ANTIQUITIES TOUCHING CHESHIRE.
Faithfully Collected out of Authentique Hi≈øtories, Old Deeds, Records, and Evidences.
BY Sir PETER LEYCESTER Baronet, A Member of the ≈øame County.

q.l: Ne≈øcio qua Natale Solum dulcedine cunctos
ducit, & immemores non ≈øinit e≈ø≈øe ≈øui.

div.p: LONDON, Printed Anno Domini M.DC.LXXII.

div.head: THE CONTENTS OF THIS BOOK.
div.p: THe fir≈øt Part treateth of the Governors and Earls of Mercia, from the time of King Alfred, to the time of the Norman Conque≈øt.

The ≈øecond Part comprehendeth the Hi≈øtory of the Earls of Che≈øter from the Norman Conque≈øt, till that Earldom was Inve≈øted in the Crown of England under King Henry the Third; with a ≈øhort Catalogue of all ≈øuch Princes of England, as have been created Princes of Wales and Earls of Che≈øter, ever ≈øince to this day.

The third Part treateth of the ancient Barons to the Earls of Che≈øter, with ≈øeveral Catalogues of all the Bi≈øhops, Deans, Chamberlains, Judges, Sheriffs, and E≈øcheatours of Che≈øhire, and al≈øo of the Recorders of the City of Che≈øter.
The fourth and la≈øt Part comprehendeth the Antiquities of Bucklow Hundred in Che≈øhire.

div.head: CHAP. I.
div.p: I. OUr I≈øland of Great Brettaine was altogether unknown both to the ancient Grecians and Romans, until the Days of Caius Julius Cae≈øar. Bede de Hi≈øtori√¢ Gentis Anglorum, lib. 1. cap. 2. Learned Cambden, in his Britannia Printed 1607. pag. 24, 25. Al≈øo Sheringham de Gentis Anglorum Origine, pag. 99. For the Name of Brettaine is not to be found in any Author, Greek or Latine, before that time, as far forth as I have ever ≈øeen or heard of, Diodorus Siculus being the fir≈øt among the Greek Authors, and Lucretius among the Latines, who made mention thereof; and both the≈øe lived about the ≈øame Age with Cae≈øar, or a little ≈øooner.

Wherefore we have no certain Hi≈øtory of this I≈øland but from Cae≈øar downwards. The ancient Brettans were a barbarous People, and left no Writing or Hi≈øtory of their Countrey to Po≈øterity. Gildas, called Sapiens, is the fir≈øt among the Brettans who hath left us any mention in Writing hereof, and tho≈øe very ≈øhort and imperfect. Now Gildas writ about the Year of Chri≈øt 540. and what he writ (as he confe≈ø≈øeth in his Prologue) was by Relation from beyond Sea, more than out of ancient Records and Writings of his own Countrey: for tho≈øe (if any ≈øuch were at all) were either burned by the Enemy's rage, or carried away by the bani≈øhed Natives; ≈øo that in his time there was no ≈øuch extant.

II. Now Julius Cae≈øar, upon his ≈øecond Expedition into Brettaine, Anno ant√® Chri≈øtum natum 54. or thereabout, ≈øubdued part of Brettain, and many Cities ≈øubmitted, and
yielded up them≈øelves to the Romans. Cae≈øar de Bello Gallico, lib. 5. in ip≈øo initio. And the Rule of the Romans in Brettaine cea≈øed upon the declination of the Roman Empire, after that Alaric, King of the Gothes, had taken Rome, which hapned in the Year of Chri≈øt 410. according to our vulgar Computation. So Helvicus in his Chronology; al≈øo Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. lib. 1. cap. 11. So that the Rule or Soveraignty of the Romans over Brettaine continued almo≈øt 470 Years, as Bede computeth in the ≈øame Chapter. But Cambden in his Britannia, pag. 60. computing to Valentinian the Third, ≈øaith 476 Years.

III. But now the poor Brettans, upon the Romans withdrawing of their Forces out of Brettaine, to defend them≈øelves, were mi≈øerably devoured by the Scots and Picts: And therefore they called in, and invited the Saxons to aid them; who came fir≈øt into Brettaine Anno Chri≈øti 449. ≈øaith Bede and Malmesbury. But the Brettans (to u≈øe Gildas's own words) perceiving the Saxons, Qua≈øi pro patri√¢ pugnaturos, ≈øed eam certi√πs impugnaturos, defended them≈øelves as well as they could. But the Saxons, after they had expelled the Scots and Picts, did al≈øo by degrees root out the Brettans al≈øo; and the Saxons at la≈øt ≈øolely po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of all the South part of Brettaine, which we now call England; but di≈øagreeing among them≈øelves, and contending for Superiority, each Party would ≈øet up them≈øelves (as it commonly falls out in ≈øuch Ca≈øes,) and ≈øo had a Heptarchy, or ≈øeven di≈øtinct Kingdoms in England, till at la≈øt they were all ≈øwallowed up into one by that of the We≈øt-Saxons, the poor Brettans being driven into Wales and Cornwall.

IV. Egbert King of the We≈øt-Saxons, being now ≈øole Monarch of all England, (for ≈øo Hoveden calls him, pag. 414.) and having routed Wilaf King of Mercia, and made him Tributary, (which Kingdom of Mercia was the large≈øt in compa≈øs of all the ≈øeven, and the la≈øt of the ≈øix un≈øubdued) ordained, That this part of Brettaine, whereof he had now the Soveraignty, ≈øhould be called England; ≈øince which time it hath gained the Name of England. Ver≈øtegan's Saxon Antiquities, p. 123. And this Edict, ≈øaith Trevi≈øa in his Tran≈ølation of Polychronicon, was when Egbert was Crowned King of all England at Winche≈øter, after the Battel of Ellindon, Fol. 275. Now the Battel of Ellindon is placed in Anno Chri≈øti 823. by Florentius Wigornien≈øis and Stowe.

This Egbert al≈øo is ≈øaid to have new modelled England into Shires; the word Share we u≈øe at this day for a Part or Divi≈øion. Huntington, lib. 1. Hi≈øt. pag. 298. Po≈øtqu√†m Reges We≈øt-Sexe caeteris praevaluerunt, & Monarchiam obtinuerunt, terras in 35 Provincias dividebant. This might be Ethelwolfe, Son of Egbert: yet Egbert was the fir≈øt Monarch. Ingulphus ≈øaith, Alfred (the fourth Son of Ethelwolfe) divided England into Counties, Hundreds, and Tythings, pag. 870. But Selden ≈øuppo≈øeth Ingulphus is herein mi≈øtaken, otherwi≈øe Malmesbury would have attributed the Divi≈øion of Shires unto Alfred as well as Hundreds and Tythings, which he omitteth altogether, pag. 44. Therefore Shires were di≈øtingui≈øhed ≈øomewhat ≈øooner, to wit, by Egbert; Hundreds and Tythings by Alfred. This Alfred al≈øo ordained Judges and Sheriffs, making two Officers for the Governing of a Shire, whereof before was but one Officer, called Vice-Dominus.
This was but a new Model by Egbert and Alfred: for without doubt the ancient Brettans had their Divi≈øions of Counties, Cities and Towns, as Cook upon Littleton well ob≈øerves, Sect. 248.

V. As to this new Divi≈øion of Shires, Huntington in the place cited, reckons up 35. where he reckons Cornwall, Northumberland, and Cumberland, to make up the Account. But Malmesbury De Ge≈øtis Regum, lib. 2. cap. 10. pag. 63. ≈øaith, That under King Ethelred, Anno Domini 1016. there were but 32 Shires in England: and the Record of the two Dooms-day Books hath onely 33 Shires under William the Conqueror, Anno Chri≈øti 1086. unle≈øs we take the Ea≈øt-Ryding, North-Ryding and We≈øt-Ryding, there mentioned, for Shires. See Splelman's Glo≈ø≈øary on the word Dooms-day; which three do now make up but one Shire, called York≈øhire, as it now ≈øtands divided.

Nor do we find in Dooms-day Book any mention at all of Northumberland, Cumberland, We≈øtmorland, Durham, or Lanca≈øhire; howbeit part of Lanca≈øhire, as it now ≈øtands di≈øtingui≈øhed, is put under the Title of Ce≈øter≈øhire in that Book, to wit, all that part
between the two Rivers of Ribbell and Mer≈øey; and the re≈øt of it I conceive was put under Euruic-Scire: So that Lanca≈øhire ≈øeems to have got and gained a di≈øtinct Name of a County or Shire ≈øince the Norman Conque≈øt; but of later time it was made a County Palatine by the King's Charter to his Son John of Gaunt, Dated 28 die Februarii, 51 Edw. 3. 1376. with all Priviledges ≈øic√πt Comes Ce≈øtriae infr√¢ Comitatum Ce≈øtriae digno≈øcitur habere: Confirmed by Parliament, 13 Rich. 2. 1389. Durham al≈øo hath not his Title in Dooms-day Book, but may ≈øeem there to be comprehended under Euric-Scire, or York≈øhire. So likewi≈øe Northumberland, Cumberland, and We≈øtmorland, are either there omitted, or comprehended under York≈øhire. But ≈øoon after the≈øe were all accounted for di≈øtinct Counties or Shires; which ≈øix (as they now ≈øtand divided) Northumberland, Cumberland, We≈øtmorland, Durham, York≈øhire, and Lanca≈øhire, were by the Romans, during their Rule in Brettaine, ≈øtiled Brigantes, that is, Robbers. In the fir≈øt Age of the Saxons Rule in Brettaine, the≈øe all made up the Kingdom of Deira, as it was then called; which afterwards the Saxons called The Kingdom of the Northumbrians, ≈øo called, becau≈øe they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed all the North of England, from the River Humber in York≈øhire, to Scotland. So Cambden's Britannia, in the Preface to York≈øhire.

Polychronicon, lib. 1. cap. 49. ≈øaith thus: That if Northumberland be counted for one Shire, which reached ≈øometime from the River Humber to the River Twede, then are in England but 32 Shires, over and above Cornwall: But if it be parted into ≈øix Shires, that is to ≈øay, Evoric-≈øhire, or York≈øhire, Durham-≈øhire, Northumberland, Carli≈øle-≈øhire; or Cumberland, Appleby-≈øhire, or We≈øtmorland, and Lanca≈øhire, then are there 36 Shires be≈øides Cornwall.

In the Conqueror's time, who De≈øcribed all the Provinces of England, were found 36 Shires, and half a Shire, 52080 Towns, 45002 Pari≈øh Churches, 75000 Knights Fees, whereof Hou≈øes of Religion had 28015. But now are more Towns and Villages inclo≈øed and inhabited then were at that time; and whereas before it was written, that Cornwall was not ≈øet in the Shires of England, it may ≈øtand among them well enough; for it is not in Wales, nor in Scotland, but it is in England; and ≈øo reckoning Cornwall, be 37 Shires in England. Thus the Monk of Che≈øter in his Polychronicon, who writ under Edward the Third.

But the Monk erreth in his Account; for there are 33 Shires named in Dooms-day Book, with Cornwall; and if York≈øhire in Dooms-day Book have five other Shires taken out of it, and be added to the re≈øt, then there mu≈øt be in all 38 Shires, and not 37. as the Monk counteth.

And if we add Rutland≈øhire (which was formerly part of Northampton≈øhire, but ≈øince Edward Plantagenet, Son and Heir to Edmund of Langley Duke of York, was made Earl of Rutland under King Richard the Second, it hath been reckoned for a County) and al≈øo Richmond≈øhire, which is part of York≈øhire, being now al≈øo put into the number of our Counties, then have we ju≈øt 40 Counties in England at this pre≈øent.

VI. Wales was newly divided into Shires and Hundreds, Anno Domini 1283. 11 Edw. 3. ≈øaith Stow in his Annals; in which Year Wales was totally ≈øubdued by Edward the Fir≈øt, who then built two ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles there, one at Conway, the other at Caernarvan.

Cambden ≈øaith there were onely ≈øix Shires in Wales in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, con≈øtituted; and the re≈øt were ordained by Parliamentary Authority under Henry the Eighth; in his Britannia Printed 1607. pag. 115. But the Statute of 34 & 35 Hen. 8. cap. 26. tells us, That eight Shires were of ancient and long time, to wit, the Shires of Glamorgan, Caermarthen, Pembroke, Cardigan, Flint, Caernarvan, Angle≈øey, and Merioneth; but other four were made and appointed by the Statute of 27 Hen. 8. cap. 26. be≈øides Monmouth≈øhire, to wit Radnor, Brecknock, Montgomery, and Denbigh; and divers Dominions and Lord≈øhips in the Marches of Wales, were then al≈øo united and annexed to Shrop≈øhire, Hereford≈øhire, and Glouce≈øter≈øhire; ≈øo that there were five Shires newly made under Henry the Eighth, and eight Shires under Edward the Fir≈øt, but ≈øome now account Monmouth among the Shires of England, as Cambden and Speed, and ≈øo make 41 Counties in England, becau≈øe in that Statute of 27 Hen. 8. cap. 26. it is made ≈øubject to
the Chancery of England, and to the King's Judges of We≈øtmin≈øter, as all other the King's Subjects be within every Shire of the Realm of England. By the ≈øame rea≈øon we may now account all the 13 Shires of Wales for Counties of England, becau≈øe by the ≈øame Statute of 27 Hen. 8. the Dominion of Wales is from thenceforth incorporated, united, and annexed to the Realm of England.

Yet it ≈øeems to me more proper, that Monmouth be placed among the Shires of Wales, in regard it was formerly part of Wales, to pre≈øerve the memory thereof; and ≈øo we have at this day 13 Shires in Wales.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the Kingdom of Mercia.

div.p: I. FOr my better method and clearer pa≈ø≈øage to the Earls of Che≈øter, it will not be ami≈øs briefly to ≈øet down the Kings of Mercia, during the Heptarchy of the Saxons in England, under which our County of Che≈øhire is compri≈øed.

This Kingdom of Mercia began Anno Domini 626. under Penda ≈øirnamed The Strong, Son of Wibba: Howbeit Huntington brings it ≈øomewhat higher, even to begin under Crida, who died Anno Domini 596. lib. 2. pag. 315. who≈øe De≈øcent he al≈øo ≈øets down out of the ancient Saxons Chronicle to Woden, pag. 316. and the De≈øcent of Woden, Malmesbury reckons up, Al≈øo Matth. Paris de H. 2. and A≈ø≈øer Meneven≈øis de Alfredo pa. 1. (lib. 2. de Ge≈øtis Regum, cap. 2. ad initium) out of the Engli≈øh Chronicles, to Noah. Al≈øo Hoved. Annal. pars prior, p. 414. brings it up to Adam: Which De≈øcent, although we may conceive it true, as far as is ≈øet down, yet it carries great improbabilities along with it, in re≈øpect of the long Tract of Time it contains: for Woden is but the tenth Ance≈øtor from Crida inclu≈øively, and Noah but the ≈øixteenth from Woden, according to Malmesbury: So all the Generations from Noah to Crida are but 26. which in all probability cannot contain much above 600 Years; and ≈øo Crida living after Chri≈øt 550 Years, as Huntington clearly expre≈ø≈øeth, the Generation where Noah is placed cannot exceed 100 Years before Chri≈øt, or thereabouts. Now Noah lived above 2000 Years before Chri≈øt, as is evident by the Scripture: and the Generations from Noah to Chri≈øt are reckoned up 68, Luke cap. 3. and according to Matthew, from Noah to Chri≈øt are reckoned up 52 Generations, which far exceed the proportion and number here ≈øet down by Malmesbury: Be≈øides this, that Bedwegius ≈øhould be the Son of Sem (as Hoveden hath it) is much to be ≈øu≈øpected; or (as Malmesbury ≈øets it down) that he ≈øhould be the Son of Stre≈øaeus, and Stre≈øaeus reported to be the Son of Noah, ≈øeems likewi≈øe incredible, fora≈ømuch as no ≈øuch Son is recorded in the Text, Gene≈øis cap. 10. either to Noah or Sem. But to return.

II. The Kingdom of Mercia was otherwi≈øe called Midel-Engle, or Mediterranea Anglia, Huntington, lib. 2. Hi≈øtor. pag. 317. and was di≈øtingui≈øhed into the Northern and Southern Mercians. The South-Mercians were 5000 Families, and were ≈øevered by the River Trent from the North-Mercians, who contained 7000 Families: and this di≈øtinction was in the time of Peda, Son of Penda. Huntington, lib. 3. pag. 332.

It was called Mercia, not from the River Mer≈øey, running from the corner of Wirral in Che≈øhire, becau≈øe that River was the utmo≈øt Limit thereof We≈øtward; but I rather believe that River took Denomination from this Kingdom, which it Bounded on that ≈øide; and was called Mercia, becau≈øe it abutted or bordered upon part of all or mo≈øt of the other Kingdoms of the Heptarchy: for Marche in the Saxon Tongue ≈øignifieth A Border or Limit: Hence we call the parts of Wales next bordering upon England, The Marches of Wales; and at this day we call the utmo≈øt Border of a piece of Land, A Land-March, now pronounced Land-Mark, which is as much as A Mere or Boundary.
III. I ≈øhall now briefly run over the Kings of Mercia ≈øince the Saxons fir≈øt ≈øet up their Rule here, with the Years of their ≈øeveral Reigns.
1. Crida died about the Year of Chri≈øt 596. He began his Reign Anno Domini 586. and Reigned ten Years.
2. VVibba, Son of Crida. He began his Reign Anno 596. and Reigned twenty Years.
3. Ceorlus, Son of VVibba. He began his Reign Anno 616. and Reigned ten Years.

4. Penda, ≈øirnamed The Strong, Son of VVibba, ≈ølew Edwin and O≈øwald, Bede de Hi≈øt. Angl. lib. 3. cap. 9. Kings of Northumberland, in ≈øeveral Battels. O≈øwald was ≈ølain the fifth day of Augu≈øt, Anno Domini 642. O≈øwald was a holy Man, and many Churches and Chappels were Con≈øecrated and Founded in honour of him. This Penda was ≈ølain by O≈øwy, Brother of O≈øwald in the Year 656. in Battel. He began his Reign Anno 626. and Reigned thirty Years.

5. Peda, or Weda, Son of Penda, Married Alflede, Daughter of O≈øwy King of Northumberland, and was the fir≈øt King of Mercia that received the Chri≈øtian Faith. He received half of Mercia by the Gift of O≈øwy his Father-in-law, to wit, South-Mercia. This O≈øwy Founded Lichfield Church, and made Dwina a Scotchman Bi≈øhop thereof, Anno Domini 656. He was the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Mercia. Stow. pag. 67. This Peda began his Reign Anno 656. and Reigned three Years.

6. Wulfere, Son of Penda, after the Death of his Brother Peda, ≈øucceeded King of Mercia: for the Nobility of Mercia, Jumin, Eaba, and Eadbert, did rebell again≈øt O≈øwy, and ≈øet up Wulfere, who Married Ermenhild, Daughter of Erconbert King of Kent, and had I≈ø≈øue by her, Kenred a Son, and Werburge a Daughter, that holy Virgin, who died at Che≈øter, and there buried. Will. de Malmesbury, lib. 1. de Ge≈øtis Regum, cap. 4. This Wulfere was the fir≈øt of the Engli≈øh Kings who committed Simony, and ≈øold the Bi≈øhoprick of London to one VVina. He killed two of his own Sons, Ulfade and Rufin, becau≈øe they went to be in≈øtructed in the Chri≈øtian Faith by St. Chad Bi≈øhop of Lichfield, who≈øe Bodies Ermenhild the Queen buried in a Sepulchre of Stone, where after ≈øhe Founded a Priory, called The Priory of Stones, in Stafford≈øhire. Stow. pag. 69. He began his Reign Anno 659. and Reigned ≈øeventeen Years.
7. Ethelred, Brother to VVulfere, erected a Bi≈øhoprick at VVorce≈øter. He began his Reign Anno 675. and Reigned twenty nine Years.

8. Kenred, Son of VVulfere, in the fifth Year of his Reign went to Rome, and became a Monk in St. Peters Church in Rome, where he continued all his Life. He began his Reign Anno 704. and Reigned five Years.
9. Ceolred, Son of Ethelred, Fought ≈øtoutly again≈øt Ina, King of the VVe≈øt-Saxons. Ceolred was buried at Lichfield. He began his Reign Anno 708. and Reigned eight Years.

10. Ethelbald the Proud, whom Malmesbury ≈øtiles Pronepos Pendae ex Alwio fratre, Reigned peaceably one and forty Years. This Ethelbald, and almo≈øt all the Nobility of Mercia, were much addicted to Adultery, rejecting their Wives, as appears by the Letter of Boniface, Archbi≈øhop of Mentz and German Legate, to Ethelbald, about Anno 747. He Founded the Abbey of Crowland, and was ≈ølain by his own Subjects, by the procurement of Berared, at the Battel of Segi≈øwold, within three Miles of Tamworth, as he was Fighting again≈øt Cuthred King of the VVe≈øt-Saxons, Anno 757. Stow. and his Body was Interred at Ripedon or Ripon. He was Son of Alwy, Son of Eoppa, Son of VVibba. Matth. VVe≈øtmin≈øt. pag. 264. He began his Reign Anno 716. and Reigned one and forty Years.
11. Berared, an U≈øurper, was ≈ølain by Offa, and had an end meet for a Traytor. He began his Reign Anno 757. and Reigned one Year.

12. Offa was Co≈øin to Ethelbald, ≈øcilicet Son of Dingferth, Son of Eanulf, Son of O≈ømod, Son of Eoppa, Son of VVibba. Florentius VVigornien≈øis, pag. 274. He overcame in Battel Kinulf King of the VVe≈øt-Saxons. He built the famous Mona≈øtery of black Monks at St. Albans, Anno 793. in the three and thirtieth Year of
his Reign, and Endowed it with Lands, witne≈ø≈øed by him≈øelf, Egfrid his Son, nine Kings, fifteen Bi≈øhops, ten Dukes, &c. He tran≈ølated the Arch-bi≈øhop's See from Canterbury to Lichfield, and Founded the Abbey of Bathe. He made a great Dike or Ditch between VVales and the Kingdom of Mercia, which is called Offa's Dike, and whereof part is yet to be ≈øeen. Stow. pag. 71. He gave to the Pope a yearly Rent out of every Hou≈øe in his Kingdom, ≈øtiled The Charter of Peter-Pence. Polychron. lib. 5. cap. 25. His Wifes Name was Quendrida; who≈øe Daughter ≈øhe was, I find not: By whom he had I≈ø≈øue, Egfrid a Son; Ethelburge a Daughter Married Brictric, King of the VVe≈øt-Saxons, Anno 787. whom Florentius calleth Eadburge, pag. 280. Elfled another Daughter, was ≈øecond Wife to Ethelred King of Northumberland. Speed's Hi≈øt. pa. 362. and Elfrid another Daughter, betook her ≈øelf to the Mona≈øtery of Croyland. He died at Ofley, ≈øaith Stow (Quaere if not mi≈øtaken for Ocley,) the twenty ninth day of July, and was buried at a Chappel without the Town of Bedford. He began his Reign Anno 758. and Reigned thirty nine Years.
13. Egfrid, Son of Offa, died young. He Reigned but 141 Days, ≈øaith Florentius, pag. 281. and was buried at St. Albans. He began to Reign Anno 796.

14. Kenulfe, an heroick and noble Prince, ≈øucceeded King of Mercia. He was Son of Cuthbert, and Trinepos VVibba, that is, The Sixth in De≈øcent from VVibbae, ≈øaith Matthew of VVe≈øtmin≈øter, pag. 291. He took Eadbert, (or Egbert as others call him) ≈øirnamed Pren, King of Kent, whom he carried away Pri≈øoner triumphantly, An. 798. and not long after, when he had built VVinchelcombe Church, on the Day of the Dedication thereof, he ≈øet his Pri≈øoner free at the Altar of that Church, and made Cuthred King of Kent in his ≈øtead. So VVe≈øtmin≈øter and others. He al≈øo Founded the Church of St. Ethelbert in Hereford, the Bi≈øhop's See; and by Elfride his Wife had I≈ø≈øue Kenelm a Son, and two Daughters, Quendrede and Burgenhild. He died Anno Chri≈øti 819. ≈øaith Florentius; Anno 821. ≈øaith We≈øtmin≈øter, and buried at Winchelcome Abbey. He began his Reign Anno 796. and Reigned twenty four Years.

15. Kenelm, Son of Kenulfe, a Boy of ≈øeven Years old, was murthered within few Months after his Father's Death by one A≈øcebert his Governor, who taking him into a Wood, cut off his Head, and buried him under a Thorn Tree. This was done by the procurement of Quendrede his Si≈øter; whereby Kenelm obtained the Name of a Martyr. His Body being found, was buried at Winchelcombe. He began to Reign Anno 819.

16. Ceolwulfe, Brother of Kenulfe, ≈øucceeded King. He was depo≈øed by Bernulfe, and driven out of the Kingdom, and had a Daughter called Cenedrith. Spelman's Councels, pag. 333. He began to Reign Anno 820. and Reigned one Year.

17. Beornulfe, elected King Anno 821. who in the third Year of his Reign was overcome in Battel at Ellandon, by Egbert King of the We≈øt-Saxons, Anno 823. but as We≈øtmin≈øter puts it, Anno 825. and was ≈ølain in Battel again≈øt the Ea≈øt-Angles, Anno 824. He began his Reign Anno 821. and Reigned three Years.
18. Ludecan, Co≈øin to Bernulfe, waging War with the Ea≈øt-Angles, in revenge of Bernulfe, was him≈øelf killed, with five Captains of his Army, 826. He began to Reign Anno 824. and Reigned two Years.

19. Wilafe, or Wiglafe, ≈øucceeded King; but was ≈øubdued by Egbert King of the We≈øt-Saxons, Anno 827. under whom he enjoyed his Kingdom, paying Tribute. Wimund, Son of Wilafe, Married Elflede, Daughter of Ceolwulfe King of Mercia, and had a Son called Wil≈øtan. Ingulphus, pag. 858. ≈ølain by Berfert. This Wilafe began his Reign Anno 826. and Reigned thirteen Years.

20. Berthulfe, Brother to Wilafe, was al≈øo Tributary to the King of the We≈øt-Saxons, till at la≈øt he was cha≈øed beyond the Seas, by the Sea-Rovers of Denmark. He had a Son called Berfert, who killed his Co≈øin Wil≈øtan, June 1. Vigili√¢ Penteco≈øtes, Anno 850. Florentius, pag. 295. He began his Reign Anno 839. and Reigned thirteen Years.

21. Burdred, or Burhred, paying Tribute, enjoyed it twenty Years, and then being
driven out of his Countrey, fled to Rome. The Danes deliver his Kingdom to Ceolwulfe, ≈øometime Servant to Burhred, on Condition that he ≈øhould re≈øign it when≈øoever the Danes ≈øhould demand it, Anno 874. but not long after King Alfred got it. This Burdred began his Reign Anno 852. and Reigned twenty Years.

So that King Alfred prevailing over the Danes, united the Kingdom of Mercia unto that of the We≈øt-Saxons, in≈øeparably from this time, and was ab≈øolute Monarch of all England; and ≈øo the Kingdom of Mercia failed Anno Domini 875. which, if we reckon from King Penda, had ≈øtood about 250 Years; but if we reckon from Crida, about 290 Years.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Governors of Mercia, Sub≈øtituted by King Alfred and his Succe≈ø≈øors.

div.p: TO pa≈øs by tho≈øe former Earls of Che≈øter, namely Edol, or Edolfe, who lived in the time of King Vortiger the Briton, about the Year of Chri≈øt 471. ≈øtiled Earl of Caerlegion, or Che≈øter, by Fabian in his Chronicle, Part 5. cap. 89. and al≈øo Curfale, or, as by ≈øome he is written, Sur≈øalem Earl of Che≈øter, in the time of King Arthur, Anno Domini 616. as Geffrey Monmouth affirms, one of Arthur's Knights of the Round Table; I ≈øhall now ≈øpeak of tho≈øe Earls, who are more certainly recorded in our Hi≈øtories of credit, but not yet Earls of particular Places.

I find in Florentius, ≈øub Anno Domini 800. that Ethelmundus Dux Merciorum, coming out of Mercia, and pa≈ø≈øing Kimeresford with an Army, was met with by Weolh≈øtan Dax Wiltonien≈øium, and had a cruel Battel, Amboque Duces
Tr ‚Ä¢ vi≈øa, the Tran≈ølator of Polychronicon, calls them Dukes, fol. 275. occi≈øi; but the Victory fell to the Wilt≈øhiremen: by which words, I conceive, the Author means no more than a General, expre≈ø≈øed by the word Dux. The two Generals of the Armies met and Fought, and were both ≈ølain.

I. I now proceed to the chief Governors of Mercia from the time of King Alfred. The fir≈øt I meet with (who under Alfred Governed Mercia) is ≈øtiled Ethered, or Ethelred, who Married Elflede, Daughter to King Alfred. His Title I find variou≈øly delivered: by Higden, the Monk of Che≈øter, he is ≈øtiled Ethelredus Dux & Subregulus Merciorum. So likewi≈øe by Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter. Al≈øo by Hoveden and Huntington, ≈øometimes Dux, ≈øometimes Subregulus, ≈øometimes Dominus Merciorum. Malmesbury, De Ge≈øtis Regum, lib. 2. cap. 4. calls him Comes Merciorum. The mo≈øt u≈øual Title in all tho≈øe ancient Authors is Dux; which in tho≈øe Times ≈øeems to be all one with an Earl, or Comes. By all it is apparent, that he was then the chief Governor of Mercia under the King; and he lived in the Reigns of King Alfred and Edward the Elder. I de≈øire I may have liberty to render the≈øe Titles by the Name of Earl.

div.head: The Acts of Earl Ethelred, and of Elflede his Counte≈øs.
div.p: Ethelred and his Counte≈øs re≈øtored Caerleon, that is, Legece≈øtria, now called Che≈øter, Anno Chr. 908. after it was de≈øtroyed by the Danes, and enclo≈øed it with new Walls, and made it nigh ≈øuch two as it was before; ≈øo that the Ca≈øtle that was ≈øometime by the Water without the Walls, is now in the Town within the Walls. So Trevi≈øa in his Tran≈ølation of Polychronicon, lib. 6. cap. 4. whereunto agreeth Florentius and Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter. But Hoveden placeth it in Anno 905. Which Town of Che≈øter remained in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Britons or Wel≈øhmen, till it was taken by Egbert, the Saxon Monarch of England, about the Year 824. Trevi≈øa, lib. 5. cap. 28.
Ann. Chr. 910. Al≈øo he and his Counte≈øs tran≈ølated the Bones of St. O≈øwald, King and Martyr, from Bardeny to Gloce≈øter, where they built an Abbey in honour of St. Peter. Polychronicon.

The Danes breaking their Truce with King Edward and this Ethelred, wa≈øted Mercia, and were beaten by the Engli≈øh at Totenhale in Stafford≈øhire; and afterwards at Wodene≈øfield, within a Mile of Wolverhampton in Stafford≈øhire, was a great Battel Fought on the fifth day of Augu≈øt in the ≈øame Year, wherein the Danes were routed, and three of their Kings ≈ølain, Healfdene, Eywy≈øle, and Igwar. Stow. Ethelwerd in Chronico ≈øuo, lib. 4. cap. 4. and Trevi≈øa, fol. 287.

Ethelred Eximiae vir Probitatis, Dux & Patricius, Dominus & Subregulus Merciorum, dece≈ø≈øit, Anno 912. So Florentius; who≈øe Death is placed by Hoveden ≈øub Anno 908. He had onely one Daughter, called Elfwine or Algiva; at who≈øe Birth Elflede her Mother was ≈øo much a≈øtoni≈øhed with the pain, that ever after ≈øhe refrained the Embraces of her Husband for almo≈øt 40 Years, ≈øaith Matth. We≈øtmin≈øt. pag 359. prote≈øting often, That it was not fit for a King's Daughter to be given to a Plea≈øure that brought ≈øo much pain along with it; and thereupon grew an heroick Virago, like the ancient Amazons, as if ≈øhe had changed her Sex as well as her Mind. Ingulphus, pag. 871. Malmesbury, pag. 46.

This Lady Elflede is variou≈øly written by our ancient Hi≈øtorians, as Edelfled, Ethelfled, Egelfled, and Elflede; and from the time of her Husbands Death ≈øhe Governed all Mercia excellently, except London and Oxford, which King Edward her Brother retained to him≈øelf.
She built a Fort at Sceargete, and another at Bridge upon Severn, which I conceive is now called Bridgenorth.
She repaired Tamworth nigh Lichfield, and built a Fort at Stafford.
She built the Town of Eadsbury in the Forre≈øt of Che≈øhire, whereof now nothing remains, but that we now call The Chamber of the Forre≈øt. And the ≈øame Year ≈øhe built Warwick.

She built al≈øo Ciricbyrig, now called Monkes-Kirkby in Warwick≈øhire, ≈øaith Dugdale in his Warwick≈øhire, pag. 50. a. and another called Weadbirig; and a third called Runcovan, but now called Runcorne, in Che≈øhire. This was long ≈øince demoli≈øhed. Polychronicon. Florentius.
She took Brecannemere, or Brecknock, and carried away the Queen of Wales, and 33 of her Men, Pri≈øoners into Mercia.
She took the Town of Darby from the Danes, and the whole Province thereof. In Storming of which Town ≈øhe lo≈øt four of her chiefe≈øt Officers, ant√® Calendas Augu≈øti.

Elfled died at Tamworth the twelfth day of June, Anno 919. and was buried in St. Peter's Church at Gloce≈øter. Florentius, We≈øtmin≈øter, Polychronicon, and Huntington. But Hoveden placeth her Death ≈øub Anno 915. And ≈øo Ethelwerd, lib. 4. cap. 4. So much do Writers vary for the time.

In the ≈øame Year wherein ≈øhe died, King Edward built a Fort or Town at Thelwall in Che≈øhire, and Garri≈øon'd it; and al≈øo made another Garri≈øon at Manche≈øter, which was then in the outmo≈øt Border of the Kingdom of Northumberland this way; and took Mercia from his Neece Elfwin into his own Hands. Florentius. Polychronicon.

I cannot here pa≈øs by Henry Huntington's, contradiction of him≈øelf, Lib. quinto Hi≈øtor. pag. 353. where he tells us, That Edred Dux Merciae died Anno 8 Edwardi Regis Angliae, which falls Anno Chri≈øti 908. And in the ≈øame Page a little after he ≈øays, That Ethered Dux Merciae, Father of Edelfled, died in the eighteenth Year of King Edward's Reign; which mu≈øt needs be a mi≈øtake, unle≈øs there were two Ethereds Governors of Mercia ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, and two Elfledes, Mother and Daughter; of which I find no mention in other Authors.

The Counte≈øs Elflede was a prudent Woman, and of a manly Spirit. She much a≈ø≈øi≈øted King Edward her Brother, as well by Councel as by her Actions. She was beloved of her Friends, and feared by her Enemies. Of whom Huntington hath the≈øe Ver≈øes, lib. 5. Hi≈øt. pag. 354.

q.l: O Elfleda Potens, O terror Virgo Virorum,
Victrix Naturae, nomine digna Viri!
Tu quo Splendidior fieres, Natura Puellam,
Te probitas fecit nomen habere viri:
Te mutare decet ≈øed ≈øol√πm nomina Sex√ªs:
Tu Regina Potens, R√©xque Trophaea parans.
Jam n√®c Cae≈øarei tantum meru√™re Triumphi:
Cae≈øare Splendidior Virgo, Virago, Vale.

div.p: II. Alfere is the next Governor of Mercia: He is al≈øo ≈øtiled Dux Merciae. He is Witne≈øs to a Charter of King Edgar's, made to the Abbey of Croyland, Anno 966. Ingulphus, pag. 882. & 888.
Anno 975. he de≈øtroyed many Abbeys, turning out the Abbots with their Monks, and bringing in Clergy-men with their Wives. Hoveden, pag. 427. Florentius, pag. 361.

Anno 983. Alfere Dux Merciorum, and Co≈øin to King Edgar, died; and Alfric his Son ≈øucceeded in that Government. Florentius, pag. 363. And if we may believe Malmesbury, pag. 61. he was eaten to death with Lice.Ann. Dom. 983.

III. Alfric, Son of Alfere, ≈øucceeded his Father, and was Dux Merciae by Succe≈ø≈øion, Anno 983. Huntington calls him Con≈øul Alfricus, Earl Alfric, lib. 5. Hi≈øt. pag. 357. For Dux and Con≈øul in the≈øe Ages were Synonima.

He was bani≈øhed England, Anno 986. Florentius. and not long after was received again into favor, contrary to the Rule of State-Policy; for, Quem ≈øemel gravit√®r lae≈øeris, non facil√® tibi fidelem credideris: Never think that Man will be faithful to you, whom you have before greatly injured and di≈øta≈øted.

Wherefore, Anno 992. this Alfric being made Chief Governor of the Forces which King Ethelred had collected, and preparing a great Navy again≈øt the Danes, gave private Intelligence to the Enemy; and the Night before the Navy was to Engage, he privily conveyed him≈øelf to the Dani≈øh Fleet, and fled away with the Enemy. But the Engli≈øh Ships pur≈øuing, ≈ølew many of the Danes, and took the Ship wherein Alfric was, he him≈øelf by flight ≈øcarcely e≈øcaping. Florentius, pag. 365, 366.

Anno 993. King Ethelred commanded that the Eyes of Algar, Son of Alfric, ≈øhould be put out; which was effected. Florentius. Howbeit, Huntington ≈øaith, pag. 358. that Algar's Eyes were cau≈øed to be pluck'd out by one Edwyn; which may ≈øtand with the other, as employed by the King to ≈øee it done.
Anno 1003. this Traytor Alfric feigned him≈øelf ≈øick, when he ≈øhould have fought with the Danes.
Anno 1016. Alfricus Dux was ≈ølain in Battel again≈øt the Danes, with many other Noblemen of England. Florentius, pag. 388.

IV. Edric, ≈øirnamed Streon, a mo≈øt perfidious Man, was made Duke or Governor of Mercia by King Ethelred, Anno 1007. in which Year the King of England agreed to pay thirty ≈øix thou≈øand Pounds Tribute-money to the Danes, ≈øo as they would de≈øi≈øt from their Rapines. Florentius, pag. 373. with whom al≈øo agrees Huntington, Hoveden, and Polychronicon. Onely We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øaith, he was made Duke of Mercia, Anno 1003.

He was the Son of Egelricus, of low Kindred, and to whom neverthele≈øs his eloquent Tongue and crafty Wit procured great Riches and Honor; and for Envy, Florentius, pag. 373. Fal≈øhood, Pride, and Cruelty, exceeded all Men at that time.
He had to his Brothers, Brihtric, Alfric, Goda, Agelwin, Agelward, and Agelmer, See Hoveden, pag. 450. Father of Wulnoth, Father of Godwin Earl of the We≈øt-Saxons.
He married Edgitha, Daughter of King Ethelred. Hoveden, pag. 430. Stow calls her Edina, pag. 90. b. and had I≈ø≈øue Wulfege, and Wegete, two Sons.

p.hi: His unworthy Acts Hi≈øtorians Record thus.

div.p:
Anno 1006. he murthered Duke Alfhelme (whom VVe≈øtmin≈øter calls Ethel≈øtane) by a Wile; for having invited him to a Banquet at Shrewsbury, about the third or fourth
day of his Entertainment, he took him along with him on Hunting, and led him into a Wood, where he had laid in ambu≈øh a Butcher of Shrewsbury, called Godwin Porthund, whom he had hired to kill Alfhelme. This Godwin, ≈øpying his opportunity, when all the re≈øt of the Company were bu≈øied in Hunting, fell upon Alfhelme, and murthered him: And ≈øhortly after, King Ethelred cau≈øed the Eyes of Edric's two Sons, VVulfeage and VVegate, to be put out at Cocham, or Co≈øham, where the King then lived. Florentius, pag. 372.

Anno 1015. he guilefully got Sigeferth and Morcar, Sons of Earngrime, into his Chamber, where he cau≈øed them to be killed ≈øecretly; and al≈øo endeavored ≈øecretly to have ≈ølain Edmund Prince of England: And not long after, having gotten forty Ships well Manned with Dani≈øh Soldiers, he revolted to Canutus King of the Danes. Florentius, pag. 382. Hoveden, pag. 433.
Sigeferth and Morcar are ≈øtiled Earls of Northumberland by VVe≈øtmin≈øter; who≈øe Lands the King ≈øei≈øed, as forfeited by their Trea≈øon.

To omit many other of his Treacheries, Anno 1016. Edric mo≈øt perfidiou≈øly cau≈øed King Edmund, ≈øirnamed Iron≈øide, to be murthered: for he cau≈øed his Son to thru≈øt a ≈øharp Knife into the King's Fundament, as he was at the Hou≈øe of Office exonerating him≈øelf: And this was done when the King lodged at Oxford, on the la≈øt day of November. Matt. VVe≈øtmin≈øter, pag. 401. But Malmesbury, pag. 72. ≈øaith, Edric corrupted two of the King's Bed-chamber to thru≈øt an Iron Hook into his Fundament, as he was exonerating him≈øelf; ≈øo was the common Fame, ≈øaith he. Howbeit, Florentius and Hoveden both tell us, That King Edmund died at London, about the Fea≈øt of St. Andrew the Apo≈øtle.

At la≈øt this Edric had a ju≈øt Reward for all his Villanies; for Anno 1017. Cnut, the Dani≈øh King, cau≈øed him to be Beheaded, after he had told him what he had done to King Edmund, and ≈øet his Head upon the Tower of London; for he ≈øaid he would make him higher than all the Noblemen of England. Others ≈øay, That for fear of Tumult, he was privately ≈øtrangled, and his Body thrown into Thames: So VVe≈øtmin≈øter, pag. 402. Vide Ingulphum, pag. 892.
By Edric's Coun≈øel, Cnut bani≈øhed Edwine, Brother to Edmund Iron≈øide; and al≈øo Edward and Edmund, Sons to King Edmund Iron≈øide.

V. Leofric is the next Governor of Mercia I meet with. He is the fir≈øt that I find ≈øtiled Earl of Che≈øter in expre≈øs words. Henry Huntington, lib. 6. pag. 366. Leofricus Con≈øul Nobili≈ø≈øimus Ce≈øtriae. He is al≈øo ≈øtiled Earl of Leyce≈øter by Ingulphus, pag. 891. Howbeit in truth he was now Earl of all Mercia, whereof tho≈øe Counties were Members or Branches; and was one of the Prime≈øt Coun≈øellors among all the Nobles of England, and very gracious with his Prince. He lived in the ≈øeveral Reigns of King Cnut, Harald ≈øirnamed Harefoot, Hardy-Cnut, and Edward ≈øirnamed The Confe≈ø≈øor.

But give me leave here, by way of Digre≈ø≈øion, to explain the Title of Earl, which we give unto them; for hitherto, before this Leofric, they have mo≈øt u≈øually by ancient Authors been ≈øtiled Duces Merciae: But from Leofric downwards, they are u≈øually ≈øtiled Comites Merciae.

Wherefore it is to be ob≈øerved, That under the Saxons, the ≈øubordinate Titles of Temporal Honour, were tho≈øe of Ethelinge, Ealdorman, and Thane, or Theigne. The Thanes were an≈øwerable to our Barons: The Ealdormen, u≈øually ≈øtiled Aldermanni in the old Latin Tran≈ølations of the Saxon Laws, were ≈øuch as had Provinces or Counties under their Government, and ≈øignifies as much as Senior, or Senator, in Latin; expre≈ø≈øed ≈øometimes by Subregulus, Regulus, Patricius, Princeps, Dux; and in Saxon, by Heretoga; ≈øometimes by Comes, and Con≈øul. Selden's Tit. Hon. pag. 605. Ethelinge was a Title attributed to tho≈øe of the Blood-Royal, Sons and Brothers to the King; and ≈øignifies as much as Nobly Born: which, in the times of the Saxons, was in Latin expre≈ø≈øed Clyto, from the Greek Word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which ≈øignifies Famous, Noble, or Eminent.

About King Ethel≈øtan's Reign, the Word Earl was received in England, as a Syncnima
to Etheling; and ≈øo denoted the Sons or Brothers of the King, and not an Earl, as at this day it is u≈øed for a Special Dignity. Selden, Tit. Hon. pag. 604. The word Earl coming into England with the Danes, in who≈øe Language Erlig at this day ≈øignifies as much as Noble, or Honourable. And after the Dani≈øh Power encrea≈øed in England under King Cnut, the Name of Earl was fixed on tho≈øe who before were by the Saxons called Ealdormen; and the Saxon Title Ethelinge, no more expre≈ø≈øed by the word Earl. The Title of Ealdorman continued until about the Year 1020. expre≈ø≈øed by the≈øe words in Latin, Duces, Principes, Comites, &c. Selden, Tit. Hon. pag. 609. But from the Norman Conque≈øt, Earl and Comes, mo≈øt u≈øually have tran≈ølated each other: And therefore becau≈øe the≈øe Governors of Mercia, fir≈øt ≈øtiled Duces, were al≈øo afterwards ≈øtiled Comites, and Con≈øules, I give them the Title of Earls.

Howbeit, in truth, the Titles of Dux and Comes, u≈øed by the ancient Hi≈øtorians of our Nation, and al≈øo frequently found in old Latin Charters under our Saxon Kings about 800 Years after Chri≈øt, did then ≈øignifie with us no other than Chief Governors of Provinces and Counties under the King, and promi≈øcuou≈øly u≈øed in that Age for the ≈øame Title. So were al≈øo Con≈øul, and Subregulus.

But though Dux and Comes were promi≈øcuou≈øly u≈øed by Florentius, Huntington, Hoveden, and other old Authors; yet I find in Latin Chartes of tho≈øe Ages, many ≈øtiled Duces, and others Comites, in the ≈øame Charters; as we find in Ingulphus: Nay, you may ob≈øerve in the Sub≈øcriptions of tho≈øe Ages, this Order;‚ÄîFir≈øt Bi≈øhops, then Abbots, then Duces, then Comites, then Mini≈øter, which in tho≈øe Chartes denotes a Thane or Lord Baron, &c. And this, as it were, by a con≈øtant Cour≈øe and Order: So that by Duces, ≈øomewhat more than by Comites ≈øeems to be under≈øtood. Comes ≈øine dubio de Provinciarum Comitibus dicitur, qui Populum & judiciari√¢ Pote≈øtate gubernabant, & armat√¢ manu tuebantur, ≈øaith Spelman on the word Comes, which properly and commonly was of old time u≈øed for A Governor; and ≈øuch Provinces as were under the Juri≈ødiction of ≈øuch Comes, were called Comitatus, or Counties. The Comes had al≈øo his Vice-Comes, or Sheriff, ≈øometimes al≈øo called Vice-Dominus, which was ≈øub≈øtituted under the Comes, for the Rule of his County, in tho≈øe elder Ages.

Qu√¢ aut√®m differebat munus Ducis & Comitis, qu√¢ Territorium, non habeo quod a≈ø≈øeram, ≈øaith Spelman in his Glo≈ø≈øary, on the word Dux, pag. 233. a. For the opinion (as there he addeth) of tho≈øe Men who conceive the Title Dux to be given to ≈øuch as Governed many Shires or Counties, and that of Comes to be attributed to ≈øuch as Governed but one County, is not clearly proved, nor allowed of; neither of tho≈øe who make Dux to be meant only of ≈øuch who were Chief Commanders over ≈øuch Provinces in Military Affairs, and Comes onely of the Chief Magi≈øtrate in the Civil and Judiciary Government, according to the Laws within his County.

Certain it is, the≈øe Titles were Officiary in tho≈øe Ages, and were ≈øometimes Feudal, and ≈øometimes conferred at the Plea≈øure of the Prince. Selden, Tit. Hon. pag. 615. But the Title Dux, or Duke, became not a peculiar Title of Place and Dignity with us in England, as it is now u≈øed, before 11 Edw. 3. 1337. when the Black Prince was created Duke of Cornwal. And now to return to Leofric.

Concerning the De≈øcent of this Earl Leofric, Cambden in his Britannia, at the end of Leyce≈øter≈øhire, reckons it up in this Order.‚ÄîLeofric Earl of Leyce≈øter in the time of Ethelbald King of Mercia, Anno Salutis 716. to whom ≈øucceeded in a direct Line, Algar the Fir≈øt, Algar the Second, Leofric the Second, Leof≈øtan or Leofwine, Leofric the Third (Earl of Mercia) of whom I now ≈øpeak: Which De≈øcent Cambden there profe≈ø≈øeth to have received from a great Antiquary, Thomas Talbot, who had collected the ≈øame out of the King's Records. See this De≈øcent al≈øo in Mona≈øticon, 1 Part, pag. 304. and in Burton's De≈øcription of Leyce≈øter≈øhire, pag. 167. The ≈øame followed by Dugdale in his VVarwick≈øhire, pag. 87. So ea≈øily doth Error ≈øpread, being once broached.
I will now ≈øhew where that De≈øcent is defective.

Leucitus, mi≈ø-writ for Leuricus, or Leofric, Comes Leyce≈øtriae, Anno Domini 716. tempore Ethelbaldi Regis Merciorum. This appears by the Charter of the ≈øaid Ethelbald made
to the Abbey of Croyland, as you may find it at large in the Hi≈øtory of Ingulphus, pag. 852. But for this Leofric's Wife, I≈ø≈øue, or Succe≈ø≈øor, no Hi≈øtory or Record (which I have hitherto met withal) makes up the wide breach of De≈øcents to the time of Algar the Fir≈øt above-mentioned, containing the Revolution of 120 Years, or thereabouts: So that this Leofric cannot be the Father of Algar the Fir≈øt there mentioned.

Vide Ingulphum, p. 857. Algar the Fir≈øt, ≈øtiled Algarus Comes Leyce≈øtriae Senior, ≈øub Regno Wiglafi Regis Merciorum. Ingulphus, pag. 860. about the Year 836. He was a great Benefactor to the Abbey of Croyland.

Algar the Second, ≈øtiled Algarus Comes Leyce≈øtriae Junior, Filius Algari Comitis, lived in the time of Beorred King of Mercia, Anno Domini 860. Ingulphus, pag. 863. He was ≈ølain by the Danes in Battel at Ke≈øteven in Lincoln-≈øhire, Anno Domini 870. Ingulphus, pag. 865, 866. Nor doth Ingulphus call them Earls of Leyce≈øter, though I ≈øuppo≈øe them ≈øo; but onely Algarus Comes Senior, and Junior: Of what Family, he mentions not.

Here likewi≈øe is another great Interruption, from Anno 870. to Anno 1000. when Leofwine lived, containing about 120 Years more, which the De≈øcent above fills up very improbably, onely one De≈øcent of Leofric the Second, to fill up 120 Years.
‚öú The De≈øcents from Algar the Second, to Leofwine here, are much de≈øired to be filled up, and proved by good Authority.

Leofwine Earl of Leyce≈øter flouri≈øhed under King Ethelred, about the Year of Chri≈øt 1000. He was Son of _____ and Married _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Leofric Earl of Mercia, and Normannus, one of the Prime Nobles to Edric Streon Ducis Merciae, which Norman became Protector of Croyland Abbey by Covenant during his Life; for which he had the Mannor of Badby given him for 100 Years, Anno 1017. Ingulphus, pag. 891, & 898. Hoveden, pag. 437, & 442. Al≈øo Edwine, another Son, ≈ølain by Griffith King of Wales, Anno Domini 1039. Mona≈øticon, 1 Pars, pag. 134. And Godwin, another Son. Mona≈øticon, 1 Pars, pag. 130.

Leofric, Son of Earl Leofwin, was the fifth Earl or Governor of Mercia: He is ≈øometimes ≈øtiled Earl of Leyce≈øter, and ≈øometimes Earl of Che≈øter, as I have before ≈øhewed. He was Witne≈øs to a Charter made by King Cnut to the Abbey of Croyland, Anno Domini 1032. when Cnut al≈øo gave to that Abbey a Golden Cup, ≈øub≈øcribed in the≈øe words,‚Äî‚úö Ego Leofricus Comes Conce≈ø≈øi. ‚úö Ego Algarus Filius Leofrici Comitis a≈øtiti,
&c. Ingulphus, pag. 893. Hoveden tells us, pa. 437. That in Anno Chri≈øti 1018. when the Traytor Edric Streon was put to death by King Cnut, then al≈øo were put to death with him Dux Normannus Filius Leofwini Ducis, Frater ≈øcilicet Leofrici Comitis, & Ethelwaudus Filius Agelmari Ducis,
Damnonia, id e≈øt, Cornwal and Devon≈øhire. Alfegus was Earl of Devon≈øhire & Cornwal.
& Brictricus Filius Alfegi Damnonien≈øis Satrapae: Leofricum pro Normanno Germano ≈øuo Rex Con≈øtituit Ducem, & cum po≈øt modum valde charum habuit. I know not what he means here by Con≈øtituit Ducem, unle≈øs he means General or Governor over all Mercia, or el≈øe, that he now had the Earldom of his Brother Norman added, whom Ingulphus, pag. 912. ≈øtiles Vice-Comes Edrice, id e≈øt, Sub≈øtitute of Mercia.

This Leofric is ≈øaid to have a Si≈øter called Ermenhild, Mother to Hugh Lupus Earl of Che≈øter: So the Record cited in Mona≈øticon, 1 Pars, pag. 305. b. Sed quaere: For that Record is mo≈øt gro≈øly mi≈øtaken in many Places of it.

This Leofric married Godiva Si≈øter of Thorold de Bukenhale. Sheriff of Lincoln≈øhire. Ingulphus, pag. 913, 914. Po≈ø≈øibly he was de≈øcended from that Thorold whom Ingulphus ≈øtiles Vice-Dominus Lincolnien≈øis, ≈øub Anno 851. pag. 861.

He and his Counte≈øs Godiva built or enriched the≈øe Mona≈øteries, viz. Coventry, Leon, Wenloke, Worce≈øter, Eve≈øham, and two Mona≈øteries of St. John Bapti≈øt, and St. Werburge in Che≈øter, and the Church of St. Mary-Stow, which Eadnothus Bi≈øhop of Lincoln built. Florentius, pag. 419. Hoveden, pag. 444.

The ≈øame Godiva, or, as Florentius writes her, Godgiva, freed the Town of Coventry from all Toll, except the Toll of Hor≈øes, by riding naked through the Town, without
any thing to cover her but her Hair; which Condition performed, Earl Leofric granted the Town≈ømen a Freedom by Charter. Polychronicon, lib. 6. cap. 26. We≈øtmin≈øter, pag. 424. which Charter Mr. Dugdale (in his Warwick≈øhire, pag. 86.) conceives rather a Freedom from Servile Tenure, than onely Toll.

This Illu≈øtrious Leofric died at his own Town of Bromley, the la≈øt day of Augu≈øt,
Obiit 1057 Anno Domini 1057. So Florentius, and Hoveden, pag. 444. and al≈øo Matt. We≈øtmin≈øter; and was buried at Coventry, in the Mona≈øtery which he had built there, the riche≈øt Mona≈øtery then in England.

VI. Algar, Son of Earl Leofric, ≈øucceeded his Father in the Earldom of Mercia, Anno Domini 1057. Hoveden, pag. 444. and is ≈øtiled Earl of Che≈øter by Huntington, pag. 366. and al≈øo Earl of Leyce≈øter by Ingulphus, pag. 898.

Anno Domini 1053. the Earldom of the Ea≈øt-Saxons (which before Harold Son of Earl Godwin held) was given to this Algar. And in the Year 1056. he was bani≈øhed by Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor; but by the aid of Griffith King of Wales, after the Slaughter of many, he was reconciled to his Prince, and received his Earldom.
In the Year 1058. being the Year after his Father's death, he was again bani≈øhed for Trea≈øon; but by the help of King Griffith, and the Norwey Navy, he recovered his Earldom by force.

He had to Wife the Si≈øter of William Mallet, as Burton in his Antiquities of Leyce≈øter≈øhire affirmeth, pag. 168. and had two Sons, Edwine Earl of Mercia, and Morcar Earl of Northumberland; and two Daughters, Aldith, fir≈øt married to Griffith King of Wales, and after to Harold King of England; and Lucio, who had three Husbands, Ivo Talbois Earl of Angeau, the fir≈øt Husband of Lucy; Roger de Romara, Son of Gerold, the Second Hu≈øband of Lucy, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue William de Romara Earl of Lincoln. Randle de Me≈øchines Vi≈øcount Baieux in Normandy, Lord of Cumberland in England, and afterwards Earl of Che≈øter, was the third Husband of Lucy, by whom ≈øhe had al≈øo I≈ø≈øue: But ≈øhe ≈øurvived all her Husbands. Ingulphus, pag. 898. Hoveden, pag. 443, 444. Ingul. pag. 902, 903. Ordericus vitalis, pag. 511. & 871. Cambden's Britannia in Leyce≈øter≈øhire.
Obiit 1059
Anno Domini 1059. Algar died, and was buried at Coventry. Ingulphus, pag. 898.

VII. Edwine, Son of Algar, ≈øucceeded Earl of Mercia, Anno Domini 1059. He and his Brother Morcar ≈øtoutly oppo≈øed William the Conqueror, Anno 1066. But the Conqueror prevailing, he lo≈øt his Earldom.

He lived to the fourth Year of the Conqueror's Reign, Anno 1070. Obiit 1070 When fearing to be impri≈øoned, he conveyed him≈øelf ≈øecretly from the Court of William the Conqueror, and rebelled again≈øt him; and unable to with≈øtand, he intended to have gone to Malcolme then King of Scotland: but being betrayed by his own Men, was ≈ølain by the way. Ordericus, pag. 521. Florentius, pag. 437, 438. Some ≈øay Morcar was taken by the Conqueror, and died in Pri≈øon: Howbeit Ingulphus, pag. 901. ≈øaith, Comites Edwinus & Morcarius ambo √† ≈øuis per in≈øidias trucidati.
I find no mention of any I≈ø≈øue, either of Edwine or Morcar.

div.head: Of the Earls of CHESTER Since the Norman Conque≈øt.
PART II.
CHAP. I.
div.p: I. AFter that William Duke of Normandy had vanqui≈øhed King Harold in Battel, and obtained the Crown of England, which hapned Anno Chri≈øti 1066. as all our Hi≈øtories unanimou≈øly declare, he by degrees conferred many great Patrimonies and large Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions upon his more noble Barons, as ju≈øt Rewards for their Service, by who≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øtance he had got a new Kingdom. So Ordericus Vitalis (a Writer who lived near to tho≈øe Times) lib. 4. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. pag. 521, 522. as it is ≈øet out with other Hi≈øtories by Andrew du Che≈øne, and Printed at Paris Anno Domini 1619. tells us in the≈øe words,‚ÄîRex Guillielmus dejectis Merciorum maximis con≈øulibus, Edwino ≈øcilic√®t interfecto, & Morcaro in vinculis con≈øtricto, Adjutoribus ≈øuis inclytas Angliae Regiones di≈øtribuit: & ex infimit Normannorum Clientibus, Tribunos & Centuriones diti≈ø≈øimos erexit. Among≈øt tho≈øe of the meaner ≈øort newly rai≈øed, the principal were Geffrey de Clinton, Rafe Ba≈ø≈øet, with ≈øome others, which Ordericus expre≈ø≈øeth more at large, pag. 805.

II. But concerning the di≈øtribution of his Counties in England to his greater ≈øort of Nobles and Barons who accompanied him in this Service, ≈øee Ordericus, pag. 522. Among others, Anno 1070. the King gave to William Fitz-Ozberne Dapifero Normanniae, that is, High Steward of Normandy, the I≈øle of Wight, and the County of Hereford. Which William, with Walter Lacy and other tried Champions, the King ≈øet as a Curb to the Wel≈øh, who≈øe boldne≈øs fir≈øt Invaded Brachavianos, or Brecknock≈øhire, and ≈ølew Ri≈øen and Caducan, and Mariadoth, three Wel≈øh Kings, with many others. Che≈øter and the County thereof the King had but lately given to one Gherbod,
Gherbod, fir≈øt Earl of Che≈øter after the Norman Conque≈øt. a Nobleman of Flanders, who had gallantly behaved him≈øelf as well again≈øt the Engli≈øh as Wel≈øh, and afterwards being ≈øent for by his Friends, whom he had left in Flanders, and to whom he had committed his hereditary Honour there, he obtained liberty of King William the Conqueror to go thither, and to return very quickly again; but by misfortune he fell into the
Hands of his Enemies when he came into Flanders, and there endured a long and tedious Impri≈øonment. In the mean time, that is to ≈øay, ≈øub Anno Domini 1070. King William gave the Earldom of Che≈øter to Hugh de Auranges, Son of Richard ≈øirnamed Goz. This Hugh with Robert of Rothelent, and Robert of Malpas, and other cruel Potentates, ≈øpilt much of the Wel≈øhmens Blood. And the Ca≈øtle of Stutesbury, now called Tutbury, in Stafford≈øhire, which Hugh de Auranges held before, was given to Henry Son of Walceline de Ferrars. And divers other Lands were conferred on other Per≈øons, as you may ≈øee more at large in Ordericus.

III. But before I proceed to our Norman Earls of Che≈øter, it will not be ami≈øs to note out of Ordericus, who that Robert of Rothelent was, whom I mentioned before with Earl Hugh; for both he and the above mentioned Robert of Malpas, were of the prime of the Noblemen and Barons belonging to Hugh Earl of Che≈øter.

This Robert of Rothelent, or Ruthelan, is de≈øcribed by Ordericus; pag. 669. thus‚Äî He was a valiant and an active Soldier, eloquent, Facundus & formidabilis, but of a ≈øtern Countenance, liberal, and commendable for many Vertues. Hic Edwardi Regis Armiger fuit. He was one of tho≈øe who attended the Per≈øon of King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, from whom he received the Honor of Knighthood. Touching his De≈øcent, his Father was Umfrid de Telliolo, Son of Amfrid of the Progeny of the Danes: His Mothers Name was Adeliza, Si≈øter of Hugh de Grentemai≈ønill, of the famous Family of the Geroians. He was Commander in Chief at the Siege at Roche≈øter, 1 Willielmi Rufi. At which time Griffith King of Wales Invaded the Coa≈øts of England, and had made a great De≈øtruction about Rothelent. For his Works of Piety, he gave to the Abbey of Utica in Normandy (where his Brothers Ernald and Roger were Monks, and his Father and Mother, aliique Parentes ejus, were buried) the Church of Tellioles, and the Tythe of his Mills, Lands, and Beer in his Cellar: And he gave in England two Carucates of Land, and twenty Villanes, and the Church of Cumbivel, all the Town, Tythe, and Church of Kirkby in Wirrall within the County of Che≈øhire, and the Church of the I≈øland, and the Church of St. Peters in Che≈øter City.

In the Charter of Confirmation of all the Lands given unto the Abbey of Utica by many Noblemen in England, made by William the Conqueror, An. 1081. we read among other things thus‚ÄîRobertus ver√≤ de Rodelento, Praefato Hugone Ce≈øtren≈øi Comite Domino ≈øuo concedente, dedit Sancto Ebrulfo Cherchebiam c√πm duabus Eccle≈øiis; unam ≈øcilic√®t quae in ip≈ø√¢ vill√¢ e≈øt, & aliam prop√® illum Manerium in in≈øul√¢ maris: & Eccle≈øiam Sancti Petri Apo≈øtoli, & quicquid ad eam pertinebat, in Ce≈øtren≈øi urbe: & in Mere≈øton√¢ (quae e≈øt in Northampton≈øhire) Eccle≈øiam Sancti Laurentii & quicquid ad eam pertinet, & in e√¢dem Provinci√¢ Eccle≈øiam de Bivell√¢ c√πm duabus terrae Carucatis, &c. This Charter is ≈øet down at large in Ordericus, pag. 602. So that Kirkby with the two Churches, I conceive, is Kirkby in Wirrall within Che≈øhire, one Church then ≈øtanding in the ≈øaid Town, and the other near thereunto in the I≈øland of the Sea, which I conceive is meant of the I≈øland now called Ilbree.

Robert of Rothelent came very young into England with his Father, and Served King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor both in his Hou≈øe and in his Wars, till at la≈øt the King Knighted him; afterwards, having been trained up in Arms here, he got leave of King Edward to go ≈øee his Friends in his own Countrey of Normandy: and after the Battel of Senlace he came again into England with his Co≈øin Hugh, Son of Richard de Auranches, ≈øirnamed Goz, and was a very principal Man in all Military Employments. And after many Conflicts, the ≈øaid Hugh was made Earl of Che≈øter, and Robert of Rothelent was the chief Commander of all the Forces under Earl Hugh, and made Governor of all Che≈øhire. And William the Conquerour cau≈øed Rothelent Ca≈øtle and Town to be built, and gave it to this Robert, that he might make it a Defence to England, by curbing the Excur≈øions of the Wel≈øh: And this ≈øtout Champion Seating on their Borders, had many Skirmi≈øhes with the Wel≈øh, and ≈ølew many of them, and enlarged his Territories; and on the Mount Dagaunoth, clo≈øe by the Sea, he built a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle, and for fifteen years ≈øore afflicted the Britons or Wel≈øhmen. But at la≈øt Griffith King of Wales, on the third day of July Anno Chri≈øti 1088. Obiit 1088 Landed with three Ships under the Hill called Hormaheva; and when he had pillaged the Countrey, returned back to his Ships. But as ≈øoon as
Robert had notice, he calls his Soldiers together, and with a few Soldiers coming to the top of the Hill, he ≈øaw them Shipping the Men and Cattel which the Wel≈øh had taken; and being incen≈øed thereat, him≈øelf runs violently down the Steep Hill, attended onely with one Soldier, called Osberne de Orgiers, towards the Enemy; but they perceiving him ≈øo ≈ølenderly Guarded, returned back upon him, and with their Darts or Arrows mortally wounded him: yet whil≈øt he ≈øtood and had his Buckler, none dur≈øt approach ≈øo near as to Encounter him with a Sword; but as ≈øoon as he fell, the Enemy ru≈øhed upon him and cut off his Head, which they hanged upon the Ma≈øt of the Ship in triumph: Aftewards with great lamentation both of the Engli≈øh and Normans, his Soldiers brought his Body to Che≈øter, and it was Interred in the Mona≈øtery of St. Werburge in that City: which Mona≈øtery Hugh Earl of Che≈øter had built, and had made Richard, a Monk of Becke in Normandy, the fir≈øt Abbot thereof. Thus Ordericus, pag. 670, 671. So much of Robert of Rothelent; I ≈øhall now proceed to the the Earls of Che≈øter.

IV. The Title of Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øince the coming in of the Normans, is more properly and peculiarly applied than before: for although in the time of the Saxons, Leofric, Algar, and Edwine, who was Earl when the Conqueror invaded England, had all of them ≈øucce≈ø≈øively that Appellation or Title; yet they were not onely Earls of Che≈øter, but were ≈øometimes denominated from other Places al≈øo, as Leofric and Algar, both many times ≈øtiled Earls of Leice≈øter: And indeed they were not ≈øo much Earls of either of tho≈øe two Counties, as of all Mercia, whereof tho≈øe were but ≈ømall Branches or Members.

But now more particularly, the Conqueror gives to Hugh ≈øirnamed Lupus, the whole County and Earldom of Che≈øter, to hold of him T√¢m liber√® ad gladium, ≈øic√πt ip≈øe Rex tenebat Angliam ad Coronam, as the very words of the Charter do run, ≈øaith Cambden. Which words ≈øome Expound to be the Tenure of being Sword-bearer of England, at the Coronations of the Kings of England: whence we read in Matthew Paris, that when King Henry the Third Married Queen Elinour, Anno Domini 1236. the Marriage was pompou≈øly ≈øolemnized, and all the great Men of the Kingdom u≈øed tho≈øe Offices and Places, which had of ancient Right belonged to their Ance≈øtors at the Coronation of the Kings. The Earl of Che≈øter then carried the Sword of St. Edward, which is called Curtein, before the King, in token that he was an Earl Palatine, and had Power by Right to re≈øtrain the King if he ≈øhould do ami≈øs, his Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire attending on him, and beating back the People with a Rod or Staff when they pre≈ø≈øed di≈øorderly upon him. This Paris voucheth, an Author who lived in that very Age, pag. 421.

But although this Office might have of ancient Right belonged to the Earls of Che≈øter ever ≈øince the time of Hugh Lupus, yet I believe there is ≈øomething more magnificent couched in tho≈øe words of the fir≈øt Charter or Donation; namely, a Dignity inherent in the Sword, as purcha≈øed by it, and to be kept by it al≈øo: For as in the Crown of England there is an inherent Right of Regality annexed, ≈øo here is given an inherent Right of Dignity in the Sword. This is to hold as freely by the Sword, as the King holds by the Crown, onely inferiour to his King. Hence was it, that what≈øoever we ≈øay concerning the Pleas of the Crown, or to be done again≈øt the King's Crown and Dignity, the ≈øame is al≈øo ≈øaid (but in a more limited cour≈øe) concerning the Pleas of the Sword of Che≈øter, or to be done again≈øt the Sword and Dignity of the Earl of Che≈øter, as is mo≈øt evident out of the Records and Endictments of tho≈øe Times.

V. I come now to Hugh ≈øirnamed Lupus, howbeit in truth he was not the fir≈øt Earl of Che≈øter after the Norman Conque≈øt: for I have before ≈øhewed, that Gherbod, a Nobleman of Flanders, had it fir≈øt given to him by the Conqueror, who enjoying it but a little while, is commonly omitted without any notice at all. But this Hugh was the fir≈øt Earl of Che≈øter of the Norman Race ≈øince the Conque≈øt.
The De≈øcription of Earl Hugh out of Ordericus, Lib. 4. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øtor. pag. 522.

Hic non Dap≈øilis, ≈øed prodigus, &c. He was not abundantly liberall, but profu≈øely prodigal, and carried not ≈øo much a Family as an Army ≈øtill along with him: He took no account either of his Receipts or Disbur≈øements: He daily wa≈øted his E≈øtate, and
delighted more in Falconers and Hunt≈ømen, than in the Tillers of his Land, or Heavens Orators, the Mini≈øters: He was given much to his Belly, whereby in time he grew ≈øo fat that he could ≈øcarce crawle: He had many Ba≈øtard Sons, and Ba≈øtard Daughters, but they were almo≈øt all ≈øwept away by ≈øundry Misfortunes.

q.p: Ex his Hugo Abrincaten≈øis, Richardi cognomento Goz filius, inter caeteros Magnates efful≈øit: Cui, Po≈øtqu√†m Gherbodus Flandren≈øis ad ≈øuos rece≈ø≈øit, Rex Comitatum Ce≈øtren≈øem con≈øilio Prudentum conce≈ø≈øit: Hic nimir√πm Amator Saeculi Saeculariumque Pomparum fuit; quas maximam beatitudinum putabat e≈ø≈øe portionem humanarum: erat en√¨m in militi√¢ Promptus, in dando nim√¨s prodigus, gaudens ludis & luxibus, mimis, equis, & canibus, alii≈øque huju≈ømodi vanitatibus: Huic maxima ≈øemper adhaerebat Familia, in quibus nobilium ignobiliumque puerorum numero≈øa per≈øtrepebat Copia: C√πm eodem Con≈øule commorabantur viri honorabiles, Clerici & milites, quos t√†m laborum qu√†m divitiarum gratulabatur e≈ø≈øe ≈øuarum Participes: In Capell√¢ ejus Serviebat Abrincaten≈øis Clericus, nomine Geroldus, religione & hone≈øtate periti√¢que literarum praeditus.

figure.head: Azure, a Wolves Head era≈øed Ar.

div.p: He had Land in twenty Counties in England: for in the Catalogue of the Counties wherein certain Great Men held Lands in the twentieth Year of William the Conqueror, as it is put in the Appendix to the ancient Norman Writers, ≈øet out by Andrew du Che≈øne, and Printed at Paris, Ann. Dom. 1619. we read thus:

Comes Hugo, Hamp≈øhire, Berk≈øhire, Dor≈øet, Somer≈øet, Devon≈øhire, Buckingham, Oxford, Gloce≈øter, Huntington, Northampton, Warwick, Shrop≈øhire, Derby≈øhire, Che≈øhire, Nottingham, Rutland, York≈øhire, Lincoln, Norfolk, and Suffolk.

Concerning certain Lands in Oxford≈øhire, which he gave to the Mona≈øtery of Abbington, I find in an old Lieger Book of that Mona≈øtery remaining in Cotton's Library (noted Claudius C. 9.) fol. 137. of the whole Book; but lib. 2. fol. 35. of that particular part of the Hi≈øtory of the Church of Abbington, as followeth:

q.p: Viculus e≈øt Burgo Abendonen≈øi contiguus, Scipena dictus: hunc de Abbati√¢ tempore Edwardi Regis quidam ip≈øius con≈øtabulus nomine Eadnotus, tenebat: Cujus viri terrarum metas po≈øte√† Hugo Ce≈øtren≈øis Comes adeptus, c√πm didici≈ø≈øet praedictum viculum hujus Abbatiae Juri pertinere, commonitu Rainoldi Abbatis & Baronum ≈øuorum con≈øultu, tertio Regni Willielmi Junioris Regis anno, & pridi√® Calendarum Aprilium, ip≈øe Comes in Sanctuario Eccle≈øiae i≈øtius con≈øi≈øtens toto conventu Fratrum ibi prae≈øidente, quicquid in illo loco po≈ø≈øe videbatur habere, Deo & Genetrici ejus id obtulit, manu cultellum Altari ≈øupponendo: & ut in perpetu√πm ratum con≈øtet, verbis illud pro≈øequendo: Affuere illo c√πm Comite Engenulphus & Willielmus, uterque nepos ip≈øius, Godardus eti√†m de Boiavill√¢ c√πm Engerardo, & alii plures.

div.head: Charta de Scipena.
div.p: DE h√¢c, ut dictum e≈øt, re determinat√¢ c√πm primo apud eundem Comitem oriretur Sermo, literas Abbati ind√® direxit. Quarum huju≈ømodi extitit Textus.

Hugo Ce≈øtren≈øis Comes, Rainoldo Venerando Abbati & chari≈ø≈øimo Amico ≈øuo, Salutem.
Mando tibi, qu√≤d de terr√¢, quam erg√† me petii≈øti, locutus ≈øum c√πm uxore me√¢ & cum meis Baronibus; & inveni in meo Con≈øilio qu√≤d concedam eam Deo & Sanctae Eccle≈øiae, de qu√¢ Pa≈øtoralis Cura ≈øuper te impo≈øita e≈øt: Tali Pacto, qu√≤d dones mihi XXX. libras denariorum de tu√¢ Pecuni√¢; & ut frater ve≈øter ≈øim, & uxor mea, & pater meus, & mater mea, in orationibus ve≈øtris; & it√† ut ≈øimus ≈øcripti omnes in Libro commemorationum, & ut ≈øit factum tale ob≈øequium pro nobis (quale debet fieri pro uno fratre de Eccle≈øi√¢) ubicunque moriamur: Quicquid itaque pro ill√¢ terr√¢ exactum est, nil fieri relictum: nam & pecunia data & caetera quae≈øita omnin√≤ impen≈øa.

What Lands this Earl Hugh held in Demaine in Che≈øhire, appears in the Record of Dooms-day Book, Title Ce≈øtre-Scire; where in the beginning of the ≈øame after the Laws of Che≈øter it is ≈øaid‚ÄîThe Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter holds of the King the Lands in Che≈øhire which belong to his Bi≈øhoprick [and tho≈øe Lands are immediately reckoned up and ≈øet down:] All the re≈øt of the Lands of the County Earl Hugh held of the King c√πm ≈øuis hominibus; where c√πm ≈øuis hominibus, I conceive, is not there meant, that the Earl and his Tenants held their Lands of the King, but that the Earl held all Che≈øhire of the King, with his Tenants al≈øo; that is, and the Tenure and Services of all his Tenants in Che≈øhire he holdeth of the King al≈øo: for every Per≈øon in Che≈øhire, except the Bi≈øhop, held what Lands he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of immediately from the Earl, and the Earl held all from the King.

div.head: The De≈øcent of Earl Hugh.

list.item:
Ansfrid or Amfrid, a Dane.
Umfrid de Telliolo Governor of Ha≈øtings in England, 1068. Ordericus, pag. 512. Son of Amfred the Dane. Ordericus, pag. 669. Married Adeliza, Si≈øter of Hugh de Grentemai≈ønill, Governor of Leice≈øter, and had I≈ø≈øue Robert of Tothelent Ca≈øtle in Wales; al≈øo Ernald and Roger, both Monks of Utica in Normandy; and William Abbas Sanctae Euphemiae. Ordericus, pag. 671.
Robert of Rothelent, Son of Umfrid, whom Ordericus, pag. 670. calls Con≈øobrinum Hugonis Comitis Ce≈øtriae, Co≈øin to Earl Hugh. He was ≈ølain Anno 1088. Of whom ≈øee more ≈øupr√†, pag. 24.
Tur≈øtine, ≈øirnamed Goz, Son of Amfrid, ≈øometime Governor of Oxima, kept the Ca≈øtle of Faloys in Normandy, again≈øt Duke William, being yet a Child: But Rodulfus Waceien≈øis, who Commanded the Forces for the young Duke, be≈øieged him therein. Tur≈øtine not able to hold out long, ≈øurrenders it, on Condition that he may depart quietly; and ≈øo he was bani≈øhed from his Countrey. Willielmus Gemeticen≈øis, lib. 7. cap. 6.
Richard, ≈øirnamed Goz, Son of Tur≈øtine, was Vice-Comes de Abrincis, that is, Auranches in Normandy. He reconciled his Father to the Duke of Normandy by his good Carriage, and got far more than his Father lo≈øt. Gemeticen≈øis, ibid. lib. 7. cap. 6.

div.p: This Richard had I≈ø≈øue, Hugh Earl of Che≈øter; Ordericus, pag. 522. al≈øo Judith a Daughter, Married to Richard de Aquila, Son of Engenulfe; Ordericus, lib. 8. pag. 703. & 649. of whom he begot Gilbert de Aquil√¢, and Engenulfe, and Maude, and many other Sons and Daughters. This Richard de Aquil√¢ was killed with an Arrow, ≈øhot into his Eye by a Boy hid in a Bu≈øh, 14. Calendas Decembris, Anno Chri≈øti 1085. Ordericus, pag. 649. Another Si≈øter of Hugh Earl of Che≈øter Married William Earl of Ewe in Normandy, who being openly convicted of Trea≈øon, had his Eyes put out, and his Stones cut off, by the command of William Rufus, Anno 1093. This was done by the in≈øtigation of Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, who≈øe Si≈øter he had Married, but had broken his Faith with her: for he had three Ba≈øtards by a common Strumpet. Ordericus, pag. 704. Maude, another Si≈øter to Earl Hugh, was Mother of Randle de Brica≈øard in Normandy, afterwards Earl of Che≈øter, and Wife of Rafe de Micaenis, or Me≈øchines. Ordericus, pag. 871. Milles and Brooks, two late Writers and Heralds, have foi≈øted in the Name of Margaret for this Maude, vouching no Authority.

div.head: The Acts of Earl Hugh.
div.p: HE made Robert (one of his Ba≈øtard Sons) a Monk of Utica in Normandy, An. 1081. Ordericus, lib. 6. pag. 602.

He Founded the Mona≈øtery of St. Werburge in Che≈øter: In urbe (Ce≈øtriae ≈øcilicet) fuit ex Antiquo Sanctimonialium Mona≈øterium, nunc per Hugonem Ce≈øtren≈øem Comitem Monachis repletum. Will. Malmesbury, lib. 4. de Ge≈øtis Pontificum, pag. 288. And Learned Cambden thus‚ÄîEccle≈øiam, ‚Ä¢ quam Leofricus Comes in honorem Werburgae Virginis po≈øuerat, Hugo primus √® Normannico Genere Comes Ce≈øtriae re≈øtauravit, & Authore An≈øelmo Monachis Conce≈ø≈øit: in Britanni√¢ ≈øu√¢. Title Che≈øhire.

Anno Domini 1093. An≈øelm Abbot of Becci in Normandy, came into England at the Entreaty of Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, then ≈øick; by who≈øe help the Earl Founded a Mona≈øtery at Che≈øter, and wherein An≈øelm placed Richard his Chaplain the fir≈øt Abbot, and turned the Secular Canons into Regular Monk. Trevi≈øa in his Tran≈ølation of Polychronicon, lib. 7. cap. 7. fol. 335. b.

And indeed this agrees in time with the Original Charter of the Foundation, which I tran≈øcribed out about 1644. as followeth, then remaining among the Evidences of that Church, which were then kept in a certain Room within St. Werburge Church in Chester.

q.p: Omnibus Chri≈øti Fidelibus prae≈øens Tran≈øcriptum vi≈øuris vel audituris, Guncelmus de Badele≈ømere Ju≈øticiarus Ce≈øtriae Salutem in Domino. Noveritis me die Sabbati proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum A≈ø≈øumptionis Beatae Mariae, Anno Edwardi Primi octavo, in≈øpexi≈ø≈øe, vidi≈ø≈øe, & propriis manibus tract√¢≈ø≈øe Chartas Abbatis & Convent√ªs Sanctae Werburgae Ce≈øtriae ≈øup√®r Fundatione Mona≈øterii ≈øui, ac juribus & libertatibus ip≈øius, & ≈øuo Mona≈øterio √† Comitibus Ce≈øtriae, & aliis, Conce≈ø≈øas, in plen√¢ Curi√¢ Comitatus Ce≈øtriae exhibitas, non Cancellatas, non vitiatas, non in aliqu√¢ ≈øu√¢ parte abolitas aut deletas, in haec verba.

div.head: Charta Domini Hugonis Comitis, Fundatoris Mona≈øterii Sanctae Werburgae Virginis.
div.p:
SAnctorum pri≈øc√¢ Authoritate Patrum, qui in Nomine Patris. & Filii, & Spiritus Sancti, in Sanct√¢ Eccle≈øi√¢ Regiminis Gubernacula hacten√πs tenuerunt, qu√≠que ≈øuos Adjutores Sanctaeque Fundatores Eccle≈øiae ≈øu√¢ nobis indu≈øtri√¢ ≈øuor√∫mque ≈øcriptorum long√¢ Traditione cognitos reddiderunt, Admoneri videmur, ut ea quae √† temporaneis no≈øtris in Sanctae Eccle≈øiae matris exaltatione facta ≈øunt, prae≈øentibus per nos manifestentur, Po≈øter√≠≈øque dino≈øcenda nobis ≈øcribentibus re≈øerventur: Nos igitur Majorum imitantes exempla, j√†m quaedam Pietatis Opera referamus quae in Anglica Terr√¢ ge≈øta ≈øunt √† Hugone Ce≈øtren≈øi Comite, Anno ab Incarnatione Domini 1093. Regnante Potenti≈ø≈øimo Rege Willielmo, atque in Archiepi≈øcopatu Cantuarien≈øi Pontificante An≈øelmo, atque in Eboracen≈øi Pontificante Thoma, Volumus ver√≤ ut Religio≈øi atque fideles Christiani cogno≈øcant qui√† idcirc√≤ nobis i≈øta de≈øcribere placuit, ut qui ea relegerent vel audirent, Deum ≈øupplicabiliori affectu pro Sanctae Eccle≈øiae Fundatoris ≈øalute implorent, & √πt prae≈øentes ad Regna Coele≈øtia tendentes, eti√†m inter aetatis hujus Primates qui ≈øequantur, inveniant. Igitur ad Honorem & Gloriam Sanctae & Individuae Trinitatis, atque Incomprehen≈øibilis Divinitatis, j√†m proferemus quae nos dicere Spo≈øpondimus. Hugo Comes Ce≈øtren≈øis, atque Ermentrude Comiti≈ø≈øa, Devotioni Religio≈øae pi√¢ mente ≈øubditi, piil≈øim√¢que Dei vi≈øitatione in≈øpirati, in qu√¢dam Eccle≈øi√¢ quae Constructa est in Honorem Sanctae Werburgae Virginis in Civitate Ce≈øtriae monachos religios√® viventes po≈øuerunt, Concedente Rege Willielmo, qui Dominum a≈ø≈øidu√® exorarent t√†m pro utilitate animae Regis Willielmi, & Willielmi Patris ejus nobili≈ø≈øimi Regis, & Matris ejus Matildis Reginae, Fratr√∫mque & Sororum ejus, atque Regis Edwardi, qu√†m pro animarum ≈øuarum ≈øalute, & pro animabus Patrum, & Matrum, & Antece≈ø≈øorum, Haered√∫mque, & Parentum, & Baronum ≈øuorum, omni√∫mque Chri≈øtianorum tam vivorum qu√†m defunctorum. Huic ver√≤ Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Werburgae, Hugo ≈øupradictus Comes, & Ermentrude Comiti≈ø≈øa, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øiones Priores liberas in perpetu√πm & quietas conce≈ø≈øerunt, & de ≈øuis augmentaverunt: Habitation√©mque Monachorum habilem reddiderunt: E√°mque Abbatiam nulli omnin√≤ Abbatiae ≈øubditam fecerunt: Poste√† in e√¢ Monachos & Abbatem, Deo Donante & ≈øupradicto Rege Willielmo concedente, constituerunt: Hanc eti√†m, & quicquid ad eam pertinet, Abbati & Monachis dederunt; videlicet, Ince, Salhtonam, Suttonam, Cheveleiam, Huntintonam, Boghtonam, Wervenam, Croghtonam, Trofford, Cliftonam, E≈øtonam, Wi≈ødeleth, Hode≈øleiam, Wepram, & dimidium Rabie, & tertiam partem de Ne≈øton, & tertiam partem de Salghale, & tertiam partem de Stanney, & dimidiam pariem de Leech, & unam Carucam Terrae ad Pulford, & tertiam partem de Berdward≈øley, & Edenchale, & Shotowicam. In≈øup√®r eti√†m dederunt huic Eccle≈øiae in ip≈ø√¢ Civitate de ≈øuo Dominico, Vicum √† Port√¢ de North u≈øqu√® ad Eccle≈øiam; & locum unius Molendini ad Pontem Civitatis, & duo Maneria in Angle≈øey; unum aut√®m in Ros; & unum in Wirhalle, Erbeiam; & in Linde≈øei terram decem boum; & post obitum C√≥mitis vel Comiti≈ø≈øae, We≈øtonam c√πm appenditiis in Derby≈øhira; & ad prae≈øens Decimam ip≈øius Manerii; & Eccle≈øiam de E≈øtona, &
terram duarum Carucarum; & rectam decimam non ≈øol√πm de Annon√¢ ver√πm eti√†m de Pullis & Vitulis, de Porcis & Agnis, de Butyro & Ca≈øeo, & de omnibus rebus de quibus Decima debeat dari in his meis Maneriis, ≈øcilic√®t, Eltona, Frod≈øham, Weverham, Lech, Roece≈øtra, Haurdina, Cole≈øhull, Bi≈øhop≈øtreet, Uptuna, Campedena, E≈øtham; Et Rectam Decimam Pi≈øcatoriam de Frode≈øham, de Rodelent, & de Angle≈øeia, non ≈øolum de Dominico ≈øuo, ≈øcd eti√†m de Navibus ibi, & in omnibus aquis ≈øuis Pi≈øcantibus: & decimam de Pi≈øcatori√¢ Etone, & de omni Pi≈øce qui accipitur in Dee, & unum Batellum ab omni re liberum. Adh√πc ver√≤ dederunt Eccle≈øiam, & Terram Eccle≈øiae, & Decimam de Molendinis, & de omnibus rebus quae Decimari debent in Denefordia. Quineti√†m Baronibus ≈øuis Principalibus Conce≈ø≈øerunt, qu√≤d unu≈øqui≈øque daret praefata Abbatiae Centum ≈øolidatas Terrae; alii aut√®m ≈øecundum Po≈ø≈øe & Velle. In≈øuper conce≈ø≈øerunt, ut ≈øinguli Barones & Milites darent Deo & Sanctae Werburgae, post obitum ≈øuum, ≈øua Corpora & tertiam partem totius ≈øubstantiae ≈øuae: & non ≈øol√πm haec constituerunt de Baronibus & Militibus, ≈øed eti√†m de Burgen≈øibus, & aliis hominibus liberis ≈øuis. Hamone de Ma≈øcy, Gilberto de Venables, Ricardo de Vernon, Ricardo de Rullos, Bigot de Loges, Ricardo Filio Nigelli, Roberto Filio Serli, Ranulpho Venatore, Ernei≈øo Venatore, alii≈øque quamplurimis.

Willielmus Malbedeng dedit huic Abbatiae Sanctae Werburgae, Witebiam, & tertiam de Wepre, & Eccle≈øiam & Decimam de Tattenhale, & unam Salinam in Wich, & terram de duobus bobus, & decimam de Salchale, & de Claitona, & de Yraduc. Robertus Filius Hugonis dedit Capellam de Chri≈øtleton, & terram Capellae, & terram cuju≈ødam Rustici & ip≈øum Rusticum, & quoddam Molendinum terr√°mque ip≈øius Molendini, & Chotam Ordrici, ip≈ø√∫mque Ordricum, & quendam Campum junctum huic Chotae & Cryn; & quandam Salinam in Fulewich, & duas man≈øuras in Civitate, & paululum terrae juxt√† Botechetune≈øtan; Hoc donum conce≈ø≈øit Hugo Comes. Hugo Filius Normanni, & Radulfus Frater ejus, dederunt partem ≈øuam de Lo≈øtocke, & Eccle≈øiam de Contintuna, & terram Eccle≈øiae, & decimam illius Villae, & de Lay ≈øimilit√®r. Teste Willielmo Malbedeng, mult√≠≈øque aliis.

Item Hugo Comes, dum habuit in Dominico ≈øuo Calders, dedit ind√® Decimam de omnibus quae Decimari debent, ≈øicut ante√† dederat, quod eti√†m Conce≈ø≈øit & Confirmavit Robertus Filius Serlonis, quand√≤ Villa data est ei.

It√®m Radulfus Ermiwini filius, & uxor ejus Claricia, dederunt terram ad octo Boves in Wudechurch, & Decimam de Berle≈øtona in Wirhale, & de Wervele≈øtona in Wy≈øchesfeld, de equabus omnibus ubicunque ≈øint, & de omnibus quae decimari po≈ø≈øint. Ricardus de Me≈ønilwaren dedit Decimam de Blachenot de Annona, de Pi≈øcari√¢, & de omnibus de quibus Decima dari debet. Te≈øte Rogero fratre ≈øuo, & Ranulfo Bruello, & Ranulfo de Walbruno.
