Comes dedit Navem unam c√πm decem Retibus ad Pi≈øcandum in Angle≈øei in perpetu√πm liberam & quietam. Te≈øte Comiti≈øs√¢, Willielmo Pincerna, Hugone Camerario.

Item ad Fe≈øtum Sanctae Werburgae in Ae≈øtate dedit Comes Hugo, Theoloneum omne≈øque redditus & exitus Nundinarum trium dierum, praecipiens ut ≈øi aliquis forisfecerit in Nundinis, omnia Placita pertractentur in Curi√¢ Sanctae Werburgae ad opus Monachorum. Conce≈ø≈øit eti√†m ad honorem Virginis, √πt ≈øiv√® latro, ≈øiv√® aliquis Malefactor venerit ad Solennitatem, habeat firmam Pacem d√πm fuerit in Nundinis, ni ≈øi fort√® in illis aliquid fori≈øfecerit. Haec ≈øunt it√°que Dona data Abbatiae Sanctae Werburgae, quae omnia ego Comes Hugo, & Ricardus filius meus, & Ermentrudis Comiti≈øsa, & mei Barones, & mei Homines, Dedimus Abbatiae Sanctae Werburgae, & Conce≈ø≈øimus ut haec omnia praedicta, & Abbatia, & omnia ad eam pertinentia, e≈ø≈øent libera, & pacata, & quieta ab omni con≈øuetudine, & ab omnire, nihil retinentes in his omnibus nis√¨ Orationes & beneficio Monachorum in hoc loco commanentium: & tam liberum & quietum honorem Sanctae Werburgae dedimus & con≈øtituimus, pro Salute Animae Regis Willielmi, & omnium no≈øtr√ªm, √πt nullus po≈øt nos aliquid libertatis vel quietis addere po≈ø≈øit: Et quand√≤ nos hanc Chartam confirmavimus, nullum opus, nullum ≈øervitium, nullam con≈øuetudinem, nullam rem omnin√≤ praeter Orationes in terr√¢ Sanctae Werburgae retinuimus praeter hoc ≈øol√πm, qu√≤d ≈øi Abbas hujus loci ≈øuperbi√¢ inflatus nollet facere rectum Vicinis ≈øuis, Comes con≈øtringeret eum ad rectum faciendum, & hoc in Curi√¢ Sanctae Werburgae. Ide√≥que volumus qu√≤d Sancta Werburga habeat per omnia Curiam ≈øuam, ≈øicut Comes ≈øuam. Et ut haec omnia rata e≈ø≈øent & ≈øtabilia in perpetu√πm, Ego Comes Hugo, & Barones mei, confirmavimuus i≈øta omnia cor√†m An≈øelmo Archiepi≈øcopo, non ≈øol√πm Sigillo meo, ≈øed eti√†m Sigillo Dei Omnipotentis, id est, Signo Sanctae Crucis ‚úö: it√† qu√≤d ≈øinguli nostr√ªm propri√¢ manu in te≈øtimonium Po≈øteris Signum in modum Crucis facerent. ‚úö Signum Hugonis Comitis. ‚úö Signum Ricardi filii ejus. ‚úö Signum Hervei Epi≈øcopi. ‚úö Signum Ranulfi Nepotis Comitis. ‚úö Signum Rogeri Bigod. ‚úö Signum Alani de Percey. ‚úö Signum Willielmi Con≈øtabularii. ‚úö Signum Ranulfi Dapiferi. ‚úö Signum Willielmi Malbedeng. ‚úö Signum Roberti filii Hugonis. ‚úö Signum Hugonis filii Normanni. ‚úö Signum Hamonis de Ma≈ø≈øy. ‚úö Signum Alii Bigot de Loges hic legunt: Vide Mona≈øticon, pars 1. pag. 200, & 202. Roberti de Loges.

Anno Domini 1098. 11 Willielmi Rufi, this Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, and Hugh de Montgomery Earl of Shrewsbury, took Angle≈øey. They ≈ølew many of the Wel≈øh; ≈øome they gelded, and put out their Eyes. Hoveden. al≈øo Brompton, pag. 994. The Wel≈øhmen called Hugh Earl of Shrewsbury, Hugh Gogh, that is, Hugh the Red, becau≈øe of his red Head; and Hugh Earl of Che≈øter they called Hugh Vras, that is, Hugh the Fat. Powel's Notes on the Hi≈øtory of Wales, pag. 155.

Some refer the Structure of the Ca≈øtle and Walls of the City of Che≈øter to Hugh Lupus. Cambden in his Britannia, in Che≈øhire, ≈øaith thus: Cum j√†m Templum Conditum e≈ø≈øet, Normannici Comites moenia (Ce≈øtriae ≈øcilicet) & Ca≈øtrum adjecerunt. But I ≈øee not how this agrees with Ordericus, pag. 516. for there we find, that in Anno Chri≈øti 1069. (which was one Year before Hugh Lupus was made Earl of Chester) the Che≈øhire Men and the Wel≈øh Be≈øieged Shrewsbury; at which time William the Conqueror brings his Army to Chester, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing all the Commotions through Mercia: He then built a Fort or Ca≈øtle at Che≈øter [Munitionem condidit] and in his Return, another at Stafford, both which he Garri≈øon'd with ≈øtore of Men and Victuals; unle≈øs by Munitionem we under≈øtand onely a Garri≈øon of Men: But condere Munitionem ≈øignifies to erect a Fortification, which mu≈øt be either a Ca≈øtle, or Walls, or both; for the Garri≈øonning thereof with Men and Victuals, he ≈øpeaks of afterwards.

Again, we find that Elflede the Counte≈øs of Mercia, with Ethelred her Husband, repaired the City of Chester, Anno 908. which the Danes had demoli≈øhed; and erected new Walls there, enlarging the Town very much; ≈øo that the Ca≈øtle ≈øituated near to the River, (which before ≈øtood without the old Walls) was now within the compa≈øs of the new Walls. Polychronicon. So before this, there was a Ca≈øtle, and Walls: So that the Norman Earls did not fir≈øt erect the Ca≈øtle and Walls of Che≈øter. Probably the Conqueror might re-edifie the Ca≈øtle, according to Ordericus: And it is likely that Hugh Lupus, and the ≈øucceeding Earls, have by degrees beautified, and added to the Structure both of the Walls and Ca≈øtle.

div.head: The Wife and I≈ø≈øue of Hugh Lupus.
div.p: HE Married Ermentrude, Daughter of Hugh de Clarimont Earl of Beavoys in France, by whom he had onely one Child, called Richard, who ≈øucceeded Earl of Chester after his Father's death. Ordericus, pag. 522. & pag. 787.

div.head: His Ba≈øe I≈ø≈øue.
div.p: Robert, made Monk of Utica in Normandy, Anno Chri≈øti 1081. Ordericus, pag. 602. and afterwards made Abbot of Edmundsbury in Suffolk in England, Anno 1100. Ordericus, pag. 783.

Othuerus, or Ottiwell, Tutor to the King's Children; to wit, the Children of Henry the Fir≈øt. Malmesbury calls him, Frater nutricius Richardi Comitis Ce≈øtriae, pag. 165. that is, Ba≈øtard-Brother For that ≈øuch were educated with legitimate Children u≈øually in tho≈øe Ages.; which Phra≈øe I have often ≈øeen u≈øed in Old Deeds for the ≈øame. He was drowned with his Brother Richard Earl of Che≈øter, Anno 1119. ≈øaith Ordericus; but mo≈øt other of our Hi≈øtorians do place that unfortunate Accident Anno 1120. When he ≈øaw the Ship ≈øinking, he clips the young Earl of Che≈øter in his Arms, and ≈øo both were drowned together. Ordericus, pag. 870.
Philip, another Ba≈øe Son, whom Miles in his Catalogue of Honor affirms he hath ≈øeen mentioned as a Witne≈øs to a Charter of William the Conqueror.

Geva, a Ba≈øe Daughter, married Geffrey Riddell; to whom Earl Hugh her Father gave Drayton-Ba≈ø≈øet in Stafford≈øhire, as appears by this Deed, taken out of a Manu≈øcript in Arundel-hou≈øe in London, Anno 1638. wherein the old Deed belonging to the Ba≈ø≈øets of Drayton-Ba≈ø≈øet in Stafford≈øhire, about the Reign of King Richard the Second, were enrolled. Ibid. fol. 67. a.

q.p:
RAnulphus Comes Ce≈øtriae, Willielmo Con≈øtabulario, & Roberto Dapifero, & omnibus Baronibus ≈øuis, & Hominibus Francis & Anglicis totius Angliae, Salutem. Sciatis me dedi≈ø≈øe & conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe Gevae Riddel, Filiae Comitis Hughes, Draitunam, c√πm pertinentiis in libero Conjugio, ≈øicut Comes Hughes ei in libero Conjugio dedit & conce≈ø≈øit; & teneat ben√® & in pace, honorific√® & liber√®, ut meli√πs & liberi√πs tenuit tempore Hugonis
Comitis, & aliorum meorum Antece≈ø≈øorum, ei≈ødem con≈øuetudinibus & libertatibus. Testibus Gilberto filio Ricardi, & Adeliza Sorore mea, & Willielmo Blundo, & Alexandro de Tre≈øgor, & Regero de Bello Campo, & Willielmo de Sais, & Roberto de Sais, & Ricardo Filio Aluredi, & Hugone Filio Osberti, & Henrico de Chalder, apud Saintonam.

div.p: She Founded the Mona≈øtery of Canwell in Stafford≈øhire, within four Miles of Lichfield, as appears by this Tran≈øcript, which I received from Mr. Dugdale: The Original remained with Sir William Pe≈øhale of Suggenhill in Stafford≈øhire, Anno 1638. It is al≈øo in Mona≈øticon, 1 Pars, pag. 439.

q.p: UNiver≈øis Sanctae Dei Eccle≈øiae fidelibus, Geva Filia Hugonis Comitis Ce≈øtriae, & Uxor Gaufridi Ridelli, Salutem. Noverint t√†m po≈øteri qu√†m prae≈øentes, qu√≤d ego Geva Concilio Religio≈øarum Per≈øonarum, & Authoritate Rogeri Epi≈øcopi Ce≈øtriae, & A≈ø≈øen≈øu Ranulfi Comitis Ce≈øtriae Cognati mei, pro ≈øalute Animae meae & omnium Antece≈ø≈øorum & Parentum meorum, Fundavi quandam Eccle≈øiam in honorem Sanctae Mariae & Sancti Egidii, & omnium Sanctorum, in loco qui dicitur Canwell, ad opus Monachorum ibid√®m Deo Servientium: Et Concedo eis in Elemo≈øynam terram de Stiche≈øleia, & unum pratum quod vocatur Little-Mer≈øi, & molendinum de Fare≈ølei. Praetere√† concedo eis in Duntona Manerio meo quatuor Virgatas terrae, & unam Virgatam ex dono Osberti Capellani mei, c√πm omnibus quae ad eas pertinent; & in e√¢dem Vill√¢ unum Molendinum quod dicitur Le Corre. Et volo & concedo, ut praedicti Monachi teneant haec omnia ben√® & in pace, liber√® & quiet√® ab omni Servitio Seculari ad me, vel ad Haeredes meos pertinente. Et habeant omnes con≈øuetudines & libertates ≈øuas in nemore & plano, pratis & Pa≈øcuis, it√† qu√≤d nullus eis nequ√® pro Pannagio, nequ√® pro aliqu√¢, occa≈øione, molestiam vel injuriam faciat. Hanc quoqu√® Donationem feci conce≈ø≈øione Haeredum meorum, ≈øcilic√®t Gaufridi Ridelli & Radulfi Ba≈ø≈øet. Hujus Conce≈ø≈øionis ≈øunt Testes, Radulfus Decanus de Blabi, Gaufridus Decanus de Butne≈øwella, Gubertus Canonicus de Legerce≈øtria,‚Äî&c.

div.p: This Deed was made about the Year 1120. or ≈øoon after: And though ≈øhe here writes her ≈øelf Uxor Gaufridi Ridel, yet truly was her Husband then lately drowned: Ordericus, pag. 870. with many others of the Nobility: Neither could ≈øhe have made a Deed legally without her Husband, had he been alive.

And becau≈øe of the Civility of tho≈øe Ages, ≈øhe was ≈øtiled onely Daughter of Earl Hugh, not Ba≈øe Daughter; whence ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe her a Legitimate Daughter: But if ≈øhe had been Legitimate, then mu≈øt her I≈ø≈øue have inherited the Earldom of Chester, and not Earl Randle; for as much as a Si≈øter is inheritable before an Aunt. Be≈øides, Ordericus tells us in expre≈øs Words, That Earl Hugh had no other Child by Ermentrude but onely Richard; nor doth it appear by any Record, or Ancient Hi≈øtorian, that he ever had any other Wife, be≈øides Ermentrude: But Ordericus ≈øaith, E Pellicibus plurimam ≈øobolem utriu≈øque Sex√ªs genuit; quae diver≈øis infortuniis ab≈øorpta pen√® tota periit, pag. 522. But the≈øe before-named are ≈øo many of them as I haue hitherto collected, or met withal.

As for the u≈øual Cu≈øtom in ancient Times, of omitting that infamous Title of Ba≈øtard, Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter, Ba≈øe Son of Henry the Fir≈øt, is termed onely Brother of Maud the Empre≈øs, by Hoveden, pag. 553. Al≈øo in a Charter made by Maud the Empre≈øs her ≈øelf, he is ≈øtiled Brother, not Ba≈øtard-Brother. Selden, Tit. Hon. pag. 649. Reginald Earl of Cornwal, another Ba≈øtard of Hen. 1. is called Uncle to Henry the Second, not Ba≈øe Uncle, by Hoveden, pag. 536. Infinite other ≈øuch Examples we meet with.

div.head: The Death of Hugh Lupus.
div.p: THis Hugh Earl of Che≈øter died the 27 day of July, Anno Chri≈øti 1101. Obiit 1101 in the fir≈øt Year of the Reign of King Henry I. almo≈øt expired. So Ordericus Vitalis, p. 787.

Anno 1101.‚ÄîIntere√† Hugo Comes Ce≈øtriae in lectum decidit, & po≈øt diuturnum languorem Monachatum in Caenobio, quod idem Ce≈øtrae con≈øtruxerat, ≈øu≈øcepit: atqu√® p√≤≈øt triduum ≈øexto Calendas Augu≈øti obiit.

Polychronicon thus:‚ÄîAnno 1102. Hugo Comes Ce≈øtren≈øis, Nepos Regis Willielmi Conque≈øtoris ex parte Sororis, obiit. But for the mo≈øt part the Year is very uncertainly put down in the Margent, and many times omitted by him.
He was Earl of Che≈øter one and thirty Years.

This Hugh had Whitby in York≈øhire given him by the Conqueror, and he gave the ≈øame to William de Percy, who Founded an Abbey there. Mona≈øticon, vol. 1. pag. 172. Earl Hugh gave al≈øo to the Prior of Whitby, the Church of St. Peters of Whitby, and al≈øo the Church of Flemesburgh. Mona≈øticon. vol. 1. pag. 73.

This Earl al≈øo Founded the Abbey of St. Severus, in the Bi≈øhoprick of Con≈øtance in Normandy. Mona≈øticon, vol. 2. pag. 950. He gave al≈øo to the Abbey of Bek in Normandy, the Mannor of Ather≈øtone in England in Warwick≈øhire. Ibid. vol. 2. pag. 954.
Robert de Beaumont Earl of Mellent in France, and this Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, were the principal Supporters of Henry the Fir≈øt, in advancing him to the Crown of England. Ordericus, pag. 783.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of Richard Earl of Che≈øter.

figure.head: G. Cru≈øilly Or, a Wolfs Head era≈øed Ar.

div.p: He was but ≈øeven years old when his Father died, ≈øaith the Monk of Che≈øter in his Polychronicon, lib. 7. cap. 13. with whom agrees Knighton the Monk of Leyce≈øter, pag. 2376. And I find in an old Leiger Book of the Mona≈øtery of Abbington, a Manu≈øcript in Cotton's Library at We≈øtmin≈øter in London, noted‚ÄîClaudius c. 9. fol. 147. of the whole Book; but lib. 2. fol. 45. of that particular part De Hi≈øtori√¢ Eccle≈øiae Abbendonen≈øis, ≈øpeaking of this Richard's Grant of Wudmund≈øley to the ≈øaid Abbey and Church of Abbington, ‚ÄîIp≈øe Comes benefactum extulit & ≈øuo de≈øcripto roboravit: quod de≈øcriptum Sigillo quidem matris Signari con≈øtitit: nond√πm enim militari Baltheo cinctus, materno Sigillo literae quaelibet ab eo directae includebantur: h√¢c de re, quod e√≤ annotatur, Comiti≈ø≈øae poti√πs qu√†m Comitis Sigillo Signatur. Cujus Forma haec fuit.‚Äî

Ricardus Ce≈øtren≈øis Comes, & Ermentrudis Comiti≈ø≈øa mater ejus, Nigello de Oilli, & Rogero filio Radulfi, & omnibus Baronibus de Oxenford Scir√¢, Salutem & Amicitiam. Sciatis qui√† pro amore Dei, & anim√¢ Patris mei, & remi≈ø≈øione no≈øtrorum Peccatorum, Concedimus hidam illam, quam Droco de Andelei√¢ dedit Eccle≈øiae Abbendonen≈øi, quae e≈øt in loco qui dicitur Wudemunde≈ølai: Nos eidem Eccle≈øiae Concedimus & auctorizamus perpetu√≤ habendam, ≈øolidam & quietam ab omni no≈øtro ≈øervitio: Et Rogerus filius Radulfi & Succe≈ø≈øores ejus ≈øint quieti in no≈øtro ≈øervitio, quantum ad illam hidam pertinet: Et defendimus, √πt nullo modo Rogerus, vel alius per eum, inquietet habitantes in terr√¢ ill√¢: Hoc aut√®m fecimus & te≈øtimonio
no≈øtrorum Baronum; ≈øcilic√®t Willielmi filii Nigelli, & Hugonis filii Normanni, & Ricardi Bala≈øte, & Willielmi filii Auskitilli, & Ricardi filii Nigelli, & Domini Goisfridi Capellani, & aliorum. Hoc actum e≈øt in ≈øexto Anno Regni Henrici Regis, in men≈øe Maii, 6 Hen. 1. 1106. in die Penteco≈øtes. This was in May, Anno Chri≈øti 1106. Earl Richard being then about twelve years old.

By the words [nond√πm militari Baltheo cinctus] I ≈øuppo≈øe the Monk meaneth, that the Earl was a Child, and under the Tuition of his Mother; and for that rea≈øon u≈øed her Seal to this Charter, and al≈øo to other his Letters. Of which opinion likewi≈øe is Selden, in his Titles of Honor, pag. 786. The Law, ≈øaith he, being ≈øuch, that who≈øoever was Knighted, though before the Age of one and twenty, he was e≈øteemed as of full Age in regard of any Ward≈øhip or other Tuition: and the U≈øe being, that ≈øuch Great Lords were often Knighted before they were of full Age. Now this Earl as yet not having received that Honour of Knighthood, but being under Age, u≈øed the Seal of his Guardian to make the Act more authentick and valid; and that he was but a Child when his Father died, take the Authority of Ordericus, lib. 10. pag. 787. Richardus autem pulcherrimus Puer, amabilis omnibus, Con≈øulatum [Ce≈øtriae ≈øcilic√®t] tenuit.

II. He Married Maude, Daughter of Stephen Earl of Bloys in France, by his Wife Adela, Daughter of William the Conqueror; and had no ≈øooner ta≈øted the Plea≈øures of his Marriage Bed, but he with his young Counte≈øs were by the churli≈øh Waves, not onely prohibited their mutual Love Embraces, and hopes of future Po≈øterity to ≈øucceed them, but were deprived of their Lives al≈øo, as they were Sailing for England, Anno Domini 1119. Ordericus, pag. 787. So that he was about the Age of twenty five years when he was drowned.
Milles in his Catalogue of Honour hath clearly mi≈øtaken the Name of this Earl's Wife, calling her Lucy in ≈øtead of Maude, vouching no Authority; a gro≈øs Ab≈øurdity in a Herald.

III. But becau≈øe this lamentable Accident is memorable for the de≈øtructive influence it had upon many of the Nobility of England, I will collect the whole Story out of Ordericus, and as briefly as I may, lib. 12. pag. 868, 869, 870. The Ma≈øter of the Ship was Thomas the Son of Stephen, who came to King Henry the Fir≈øt, then in Normandy, and ready to take Shipping for England, and offered him a Mark of Gold (in elder Ages valued at ≈øix Pound in Silver, Rot. Mag. Pipae de Anno 1 Hen. 2. and as others ≈øay, ten Marks of Silver, 6 l. 13 s. 4 d. ) de≈øiring, that as Stephen his Father had Tran≈øported the Conqueror when he Fought again≈øt King Harold in England, and was his con≈øtant Mariner in all his Pa≈ø≈øages between England and Normandy, ≈øo that he him≈øelf likewi≈øe might now have the Tran≈øportation of King Henry with all his Attendance, as it were in Fee: for he had a very good Ship called Candida Navis, or The White Ship, well furni≈øhed for that purpo≈øe. The King thanked him, but withal told him, he had already made choice of another Ship, which he would not change; yet he would commend him to his two Sons, William and Richard, with many others of his Nobility: whereat the Mariners much rejoiced, and de≈øired the Prince to be≈øtow ≈øome Wine upon them to drink: He gave them Tres Modios Vini, three Hog≈øheads of Wine, wherewith they made them≈øelves ≈øufficiently Drunk. There were almo≈øt three hundred in this unfortunate Ship: for there were fifty skilful Oars or Galleymen, had they not been intoxicated with Wine, which belonged to the Ship, be≈øides the young Gallants which were to be Tran≈øported: but now being neither able to govern them≈øelves nor the Ship, they ≈øuffered it to be ≈øplit on a Rock, and ≈øo all were drowned, except one Be ‚Ä¢ olde, a Butcher of Roan in Normandy, who was took up the next Morning by three Fi≈øhermen into their Boat, after a cold fro≈øty Nights Shipwrack, and with much ado recovered and lived twenty years after.
There were, ≈øaith Hoveden, in this Ship Militaris numeri 140. Nautarum 50. c√πm tribus Gubernatoribus, with many Noblemen and Women.

The Names of the more eminent Per≈øons who then peri≈øhed [of whom Huntington thus,‚ÄîOmnes, velfer√® Omnes, Sodomitic√¢ labe dicebantur irretiti,] I have here collected out of Ordericus, viz. pag. 869. William and Richard, two Sons of King Henry the Fir≈øt;
Rafe Rufus, and Gilbert de Oximis; & pag. 870. Maude, Daughter of Henry the Fir≈øt Wife of Rotron Earl of Morton; Richard Earl of Che≈øter juvenis mult√¢ probitate & benignitate laudabilis, with Maude his Wife, Si≈øter to Tedbald Earl Palatine of Blois; Othuerus al≈øo, Brother to Richard, Hugonis Ce≈øtriae Comitis filius, Tutor Regiae Prolis & Paedagogus, ut fertur, d√πm repentina fieret ratis Subver≈øio, nobiliumque irreparabilis dimer≈øio; adole≈øcentulum (meaning Richard Earl of Che≈øter) illic√≤ amplexatus e≈øt, & c√πm ip≈øo in profundum irremeabilit√®r prolap≈øus e≈øt; al≈øo Theodoricus Puer, Henrici Nepos Imperatoris Almannorum; al≈øo two brave Sons of Ivo de Grentemai≈ønill, and William of Rothelent their Co≈øin, who by the King's Command were coming to receive their Father's Inheritances in England; William ≈øirnamed Bigod, with William de Prior the King's Steward; Geffrey Ridell, and Hugh de Molinis; Robert Malconductus or Malduit, and Nequam Gi≈øulfus Semba Regis: aliique plures multae ingenuitatis. And in Page 649. he names two more, Engenulfe and Goisfred, Sons of Gilbert de Aquil√¢: And in Stowe we find named Walter de Curcy, and Geffrey Archdeacon of Hereford; in all 160 Per≈øons.
Of which Shipwrack an excellent Rhimer of tho≈øe Times compo≈øed the≈øe Ver≈øes. Ordericus, pag. 869.

q.l: Accidit Hora gravis, Thomaequ√® mi≈øerrima navis,
qu√†m mal√® rect aterit, rupe Soluta perit.
Flebilis Eventus, d√πm nobilis illa Juventus
e≈øt immer≈øa mari Perditione pari.
Jactatur Pelago Regum Genero≈øa Propago:
quo≈øque Duces plorant, mon≈øtra marina vorant.
O Dolor immen≈øus! nec Nobilitas, nequ√® Cen≈øus
ad vitam revocat, quos maris unda necat.
Purpura c√πm by≈ø≈øo liquido putre≈øcit aby≈ø≈øo,
Rex quoqu√® quem genuit, Pi≈øcibus E≈øca fuit.
Sic ≈øibi fidentes ludit fortuna Potentes:
nunc dat: nunc demit: hinc levat, ind√® premit.
Quid numerus Procerum, quia Opes, quid Gloria Rerum?
quid, Guillelme, tibi forma valebat ibi?
Marcuit ille Decor Regalis, & ab≈øtulit aequor
quod fact ‚Ä¢ s fueras, quodque futurus eras.
Inter Aquas i≈øtis in≈øtat Damnatio tri≈øtis,
n√Æ Pietas grat√¨s caelica parcat eis:
Corporibus mer≈øis animae ≈øi dona Salutis
nactae gauderent, moe≈øta procul fierent:
Certa ≈øalus animae ver√πm dat tripudiare
his, ben√® qui charos Commemorant Proprios.
Hinc Dolor e≈øt ingens, humana qu√≤d in≈øcia fit mens,
An Requies ≈øit eis, quos capit uda Thetis.

div.p: The Place or Haven where they took Shipping is called Barbaflat, that is, Harefleet in Normandy; the time 7 Calend. Decemb. 1119. So Ordericus. But Hoveden, Huntington, Paris, and Judicious Cambden, do all place it in Anno 1120. Hoveden expre≈ø≈øeth the very Day of the Week,‚ÄîAnno 1120. in Scopulos, dictos Chatera≈øe, fracta e≈øt Navis 6 Calendas Decembris, feri√¢ quint√¢, noctis initio apud Barbefleet: where he computes the Night to the Day following; Ordericus, to the Day pa≈øt.

IV. I cannot but take notice here of the Printer's Error in Ordericus, as it is ≈øet out by Andrew du Che≈øne with other Authors, and Printed 1619. We read Page 787. ‚ÄîRicardus autem pulcherrimus Puer, quem Solum ex Ermentrude fili√¢ Hugonis de Claromonte genuit, Con≈øulatum ejus fer√® 12 annis Amabilis omnibus tenuit: where the number 12 ≈øhould have been 19. for if this place be conferred with Page 870. then Richard, by exact computation out of Ordericus, was Earl of Che≈øter ju≈øt eighteen Years and four Months: But if you place the time of this Shipwrack in Anno 1120. as mo≈øt
Authors do, then mu≈øt he have held the Earldom nineteen Years and four Months.

I ≈øhall clo≈øe all concerning this Earl, with his Charter of Confirmation to the Abbey of St. Werburge, which remained among the Evidences of that Church Anno 1644. but were after removed thence in the late War, 1648.

ANno ab Incarnatione Domini, Mille≈øimo cente≈øimo decimo nono, Regnante Potenti≈ø≈øimo Rege Henrico, Ego Comes Ricardus meique homines Communi Concilio confirmavimus Sigillo meo omnes Donationes, quae datae ≈øunt √† me vel √† meis in meo tempore Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Werburgae Ce≈øtriae: Ego itaque Comes Ricardus po≈øt obitum Patris mei dedi, pro ≈øalute Animae meae & ≈øuae, terram quae fuit Wulfrici Praepo≈øiti foris Portam de North, pri√πs per unam Spicam frumenti, deind√® per unum Cultellum ≈øup√®r Altare Sanctae Werburgae; & Molendinum de Bache, & tres Man≈øuras quietas & ab omni re liberas, duas in Civitate, & unam extra Portam de North. Te≈øtibus Willielmo Con≈øtabulario, Waltero de Vernon, Radulfo Dapifero, & multis aliis. Willielmus Con≈øtabularius dedit Neutonam ≈øimul c√πm Servitio Hugonis Filii Udardi de quatuor Bovatis; & Servitium Wicelini de duabus Bovatis. Hugo Filius Normanni dedit Go≈øtrey & Lawton. Te≈øtibus Hugone de Lacy, & Radulfo & Rogero Filiis Normanni, mult√≠≈øque aliis. Ricardus de Praers dedit Knoctirum. Te≈øtibus Willielmo & Ada, Filiis ejus. Corbinus dedit unam Carucam Terrae in Werewel. Hamundus de Ma≈øcy conce≈ø≈øu Haeredum ≈øuorum, & Ro≈øa Uxor Pigoti conce≈ø≈øu Rogeri Fratris ejus, dederunt Norwordinam & Eccle≈øiam, c√πm omnibus quae ad eam pertinent: Concedentibus & Te≈øtibus Filiis eorum. Rogerus de Menilgarin dedit Plumleiam c√πm Widone Filio ≈øuo quando factus e≈øt Monachus. Te≈øte Ranulfo & Willielmo Filiis. Ranulfus Venator dedit Bre≈ø≈øeford, & unam Salinam in Northwich, conce≈ø≈øu Ricardi Comitis, & Hugonis de Vernon Domini ≈øui. Item Ricardus Comes dedit Decimum Salmonem de Ponte, & locum unius Molendini citr√† Pontem, & Decimam illius Molendini ultr√† Pontem. Burel dedit Eccle≈øiam de Haliwella, & Decimam de Molendino ≈øuo, & de omnibus rebus ≈øuis. Herebertus Wambar≈øarius dedit Terram quatuor Boum in Hole. Ricardus Pincerna dedit Eccle≈øiam Sancti Olavi, & Terram juxt√† Eccle≈øiam, & duas Man≈øuras in foro. Rogerus de Sancto Martino dedit Terram duorum Boum in Bebington. Willielmus de Punterling dedit Buttanari, c√πm omnibus Appendiciis ≈øuis, id e≈øt, Eccle≈øiam & totum Manerium ≈øolutum & quietum, & Silvam Lectone ad rogum faciendum & ad communem u≈øum Dome≈øtici Operis; Con≈øen≈øu & Te≈øtimonio Hereberti Filii ≈øui, & Aluredi Domini ≈øui, & Ricardi Comitis. Hugo de Vernon conce≈ø≈øu Ricardi Comitis dedit unam Man≈øuram in Civitate ≈øolutam & quietam ab omni re & con≈øuet√πdine. His it√† de≈øcriptis, Ego Comes Ricardus, meique Barones, & mei Homines, Confirmavimus non ≈øol√πm i≈øta, ≈øed eti√†m illa omnia quae Comes Hugo Pater meus, & Barones ≈øui, confirmaverunt, &c. It√† liber√® ut nihil libertatis po≈ø≈øit eis addi ulteri√πs; nihil en√¨m retinemus praeter Orationes in rebus Sanctae Werburgae. Concedimus eti√†m, ut Beata Virgo Werburga habeat ≈øuam Curiam de cunctis placitis & forisfactis, ≈øicut Comes habet ≈øuam. It√† ver√≤ qu√≤d Abbas illius loci non exeat nequ√® Placitet contr√† aliquem de aliquo Placito, vel de aliqu√¢ re extr√† Curiam ≈øuam. Te≈øtibus Ranulfo de Me≈øchines, & Willielmo Fratre ≈øuo, Willielmo Con≈øtabulario, & Ricardo Fratre ≈øuo, Hugone Malbanck, Osberno de Me≈øchines, Hugone Filio Osberni, & Willielmo Fratre ejus, mult√≠≈øque aliis: Apud Graham.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Fir≈øt Randle, Earl of Che≈øter.

div.p: He is al≈øo ≈øtiled Randle of Brica≈øard, who ≈øtuck faithfully to King Henry the Fir≈øt, in the mid≈øt of a tumultuous Rebellion in Normandy, ≈øub Anno 1119. with others of the Nobility, ≈øcorning to be di≈øgraced with the Name of a Traytor. Ordericus, lib. 12. pag. 851, & 879.
In an ancient Roll of Knights Fees due to the Duke of Normandy, I find‚Äî

Comes Ce≈øtriae Servitium X Militum de S. Severio, & de Brica≈øart; & ad ≈øuum ≈øervitium LI Milites, & dimidium, & quartam partem, & octavam unius Militis: In the Appendix added by Andrew du Che≈øne to the Norman Writers, at the end thereof, pag. 1045.

This Earl Randle was Lord of Cumberland and Carli≈øle by De≈øcent from his Father: For after the Normans had invaded England, Cumberland fell to the ≈øhare of Raufe de Me≈øchines; Cujus Filius natu maximus Ranulfus fuit Cumbriae Dominus; & materno jure, Princip√≠≈øque grati√¢ eti√†m Ce≈øtriae Comes; ≈øaith Cambden in Cumberland.

II. But King Stephen willing to gain the Favour of the Scots, gave Cumberland away to them again, to be held of the Kings of England as by a Right of Protection: For the elde≈øt Sons of the Kings of Scotland, before the Norman Conque≈øt, were Governors of Cumberland for a certain ≈øpace. But King Henry the Second brought back the Liberality of Stephen to him≈øelf, and took from the Scots, Northumberland, Cumberland, and Westmorland, as Cambden in the ≈øame place addeth.

III. Raufe de Me≈øchines had by Maude his Wife, Si≈øter of Hugh Lupus, two Sons: Randle the Elde≈øt, Earl of Che≈øter; and William de Me≈øchines, to whom King Henry the Fir≈øt gave the Ca≈øtle of Egremont in Cumberland, per Servitium unius Militis, utque iret ad Praeceptum Regis in Exercitu Scotiae & Walliae, as Cambden my Author informs me Geffrey, a third Son, to whom his brother Randle gave Gille≈øland in Cumberland; and to William, Coupland in Cumberland. An old Parchment Roll, in Cu≈øtody of Henry Ferrars of Badsley in Warwick-≈øhire. See al≈øo Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 400..

This William gave the Church of Di≈ø≈øart to the Abbey of St. Werburge in the City of Che≈øter, as appears by an ancient Charter among the Evidences of that Church, and confirmed by this Randle Earl of Chester; which for better ≈øatisfaction I think fit here to in≈øert.

UNiver≈øis Matris Eccle≈øiae Filiis Ranulfus Comes Ce≈øtriae, Salutem. Notum ≈øit vobis pariter me Conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe, Quand√≤ feci transferri Corpus Hugonis Comitis mei Avunculi
√† Coemeterio in Capitulum, ut in die mortis meae darem ≈øimul cum Corpore meo Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Werburgae, Uptunam ≈øolutam & quietam ab omni re, ut Elemo≈øynam liberam, ≈øicut ego ip≈øe in ill√¢ die haberem eam, in Terris, in Hominibus, in Planis, in Pa≈øcuis, in Pratis, in Placitis, & in omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis, pro Anim√¢ ip≈øius Hugonis Comitis, & pro ≈øalute Animae meae, & Animarum omnium Parentum meorum. It√®m qui√† Comes Hugo conce≈ø≈øerat ante√† Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Werburgae Theoloneum, & omnes reditus Nundinarum trium dierum, id e≈øt, √† Non√¢ Vigiliae Sanctae Werburgae u≈øqu√® ad ve≈øperam ≈øequentis diei po≈øt Solennitatem: Ego Comes Ranulfus illud idem Concedo & confirmo, con≈øtituens ≈øic√πt ip≈øe con≈øtituerat, ut ≈øiv√® latro, ≈øiv√® Robbator, ≈øive aliquis malefactor venerit ad ≈øolennitatem, habeat firmam pacem d√πm fuerit in Nundinis, ni≈øi fort√® forisfecit in illis: Et ≈øi fort√® aliquis forisfecerit in Nundinis, omne Placitum & forisfactum & ju≈øtitia, √† Mini≈øtris Abbatis & √† Vice-Comite Civitatis, tractabuntur in Curi√† Sanctae Werburgae Virginis: Et √πt Vicecomes intenti√πs & fideli√πs hoc agat, Computetur & Tallietur ei √† meis Camerariis in ≈øuam firmam, quicquid Monachi, ex his omnibus acceperunt. Willielmus Me≈øchines, Frater meus, dedit Deo & Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Werburgae Eccle≈øiam de Di≈ø≈øard, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis, Con≈øen≈øu Ranulphi Comitis, & Ranulphi Filii ≈øui. Te≈øte Willielmo Clerico de Roelent, Willielmo Flandren≈øi, multi≈øque aliis. Mattheus de Ruelent dedit Eccle≈øiam de Tur≈øtani≈øton c√πm ≈øuis pertinentiis, quand√≤ Simon Frater ejus factus e≈øt Monachus. Te≈øtibus Roberto de Petroponte, multi≈øque aliis. Hugo Filius Osberni dedit unam Man≈øuram in Ce≈øtria, & unum Pratum quod vocatur Kings-eye. Suuein de Watenhale factus Monachus, dedit duas Bovatas in Watenhale, concedentibus Filiis ejus. Ricardus de Cruce dedit unam Man≈øuram in Ce≈øtria in Vico apud Pontem, & partem Terrae quam habuit in Morcetone & vellet Monachus fieri. Te≈øte Normanno Filio ≈øuo, multi≈øque aliis. Letitia de Malpas dedit Deo & Sanctae Werburgae unam Man≈øuram vers√πs Portam Clippe. Te≈øte & Concedente Ricardo Domino ≈øuo, & Fratre ≈øuo Ricardo Mailard, Nigello Chaldell, mult√≠≈øque aliis. Willielmus Filius Andreae dedit c√πm Filio ≈øuo Monacho facto unam magnam Shoppam inter Domum Winebalt & Hamundi in foro. Haec ≈øunt itaqu√® Dona, quae data ≈øunt √† me & √† meis hominibus Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Werburgae in meo tempore: Quapropt√®r concedimus & confirmamus, t√†m ego qu√†m homines mei, non ≈øol√πm haec ≈øupradicta, ≈øed & ea omnia, quae Comes Hugo meus Avunculus, vel Ricardus Comes ejus Filius, aut eorum homines, dederunt Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Werburgae; Deprecantes & praecipientes cunctis no≈øtris amicis & hominibus, t√†m prae≈øentibus quam futuris, quatenus ea omnia ≈øint ≈øtabilia, ≈øoluta, & quieta, & ut Elemo≈øyna ab omni re it√† libera, ut nihil libertatis po≈ø≈øit eis addi ulteri√πs, qui√† nihil retinemus in his exceptis Orationibus. Adh√πc eti√†m concedimus & confirmamus, ≈øic√πt praedicti Comites & eorum homines ante√† confirmaverunt, ut Beata Werburga habeat de cunctis rebus Curiam ≈øuam, it√† qu√≤d Abbas illius loci non placitet u≈øqu√†m contr√† aliquem de aliqu√¢ re ad Eccle≈øiam pertinente extr√† Curiam ≈øuam.

Et ut ego Comes Ranulfus darem exemplum po≈øteris, veni ip≈øe propter unum Placitum in Curiam Abbatis, audiens & ≈øu≈øcipiens ibi meum judicium, non √† meis ≈øed √† judicibus Abbatis, ut in omnibus haberet Beata Werburga jus ≈øuae dignitatis in perpetuum. Et ut igit√πr s√¨c ≈øint omnia, ≈øicut praedictum e≈øt, libera, confirmamus ea h√¨nc Sanctae Crucis Signo, ‚úö. hinc meo Sigillo, hinc horum virorum te≈øtimonio; ≈øcilic√®t Willielmi Me≈øchini, Willielmi Con≈øtabularii, & Radulfi Dapiferi, Hugonis Malbanc, Ricardi Bana≈øter, Hugonis Filii Osberni, Osberni Filii Hugonis, Roberti de Ma≈øcy, Roberti Filii Bigot, Adae de Praers, Gaufridi Capellani, Turgicii Doctoris, Ricardi Filii Nigelli. Signum ‚úö Ranulfi Comitis. Signum ‚úö Willielmi Me≈øchini. Signum ‚úö Willielmi Con≈øtabularii. Signum ‚úö Roberti de Palmas. Signum ‚úö Radulfi Dapiferi. Signum ‚úö Hugonis Malbanc. Signum ‚úö Ricardi Bana≈øter. Signum ‚úö Hugonis Filii Osberni, Signum ‚úö Osberni Filii Hugonis. Signum ‚úö Roberti de Ma≈øcy.

div.head: IV. The Wife of Randle the Fir≈øt.
div.p:
HE Married Lucy, the Widow of Roger de Romara, Son of Geroldus. Ordericus, pag. 871. She was the Daughter of Algar the Saxon, Earl of Mercia, and
Si≈øter to the two great Earls, Edwine Earl of Mercia, and Morcar Earl of Northumberland, who ≈øtoutly oppo≈øed William the Conqueror. This Lucy had three Husbands, and ≈øurvived them all: The fir≈øt was Ivo de Talbois Earl of Angeau: The ≈øecond was Roger de Romara, Son of Gerold, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue William de Romara Earl of Lincoln: The third was this Earl of Che≈øter. Cambden in his Britannia, at the end of Leyce≈øter≈øhire.

This Lady Lucy, Counte≈øs of Che≈øter and Lincoln, Founded the Priory of Spalding in Lincoln≈øhire, where in times pa≈øt were Monks of Anjou in France. So Leland, a Manu≈øcript in Oxford Library, pag. 86. See Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 307, 308. & Vol. 2. pag. 871.

The ≈øame Lucy, with her two Sons, Randle Earl of Che≈øter, and William de Romara Earl of Lincoln, Founded a Priory of Nuns at Stike≈øwold, of the Order of Ci≈øtertians, in the County of Lincoln. Idem Leland ibidem, pag. 87. See Mona≈øticon, Vol. 2. pag. 809.

div.head: V. The I≈ø≈øue of Randle the Fir≈øt, by Lucy.
div.p: THis Randle the Fir≈øt had I≈ø≈øue by Lucy, Randle the Second, who ≈øucceeded Earl of Che≈øter. Ordericus, pag. 871. William, another Son, Earl of Cambridge, who was Witne≈øs, with his Brother Randle the Second, to a Charter of Alexander Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, of the I≈øland of Haferholm to the Nuns of St. Maries, of the Order of Ci≈øtercians, dated 1139. 4 Stephani. Al≈øo Agnes a Daughter, the fir≈øt Wife of Robert de Grentemai≈ønil. Ordericus, pag. 692. Afterwards he married Emme, Daughter of Robert de Stotevill; and his third Wife was Lucy, Daughter of Savaricus Son of Canus.

Adeliza, another Daughter of this Randle, Married Richard Son of Gilbert de Clare, of whom he begot three Sons; which Richard was ≈ølain by the Wel≈øh. Will. Gemeticen≈øis, lib. 8. cap. 38. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 118.

Obiit 1128 Matt. We≈øtm. ≈øub Anno 1073. calls him Comes Ranulfus de Micenis. Randle the Fir≈øt died Anno Domini 1128. after he had been Earl eight Years. Polychronicon, lib. 7. cap. 17. He is called Comes Cumbriae, Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 397. but erroneou≈øly, and by mi≈øtake; for they were ≈øtiled Domini Cumbriae, not Comites, as Cambden ob≈øerves. And I doubt whether in the≈øe elder Ages there was any Earl of Cumberland at all, properly to be under≈øtood.

This Randle the Fir≈øt gave to the Abbey of St. Mary's at York, the Church of St. Michael, and the Church of St. Laurence of his Ca≈øtle of Apelby, with all their Appurtenances, id e≈øt, which belonged to his Ca≈øtle of Apelby in We≈øtmorland. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 399. in the Reign of King Henry the Fir≈øt.

‚öú Randle Me≈øchin gave al≈øo to the Abbey of Kaldra in Cumberland, that Land of Kaldra wherein the Abbey was Founded, and Bemertone, & Holgate, & unam Man≈øuram in Burgo de Egremunt, & duas Salinas de Withane, & Pi≈øcariam de Derewent, & Pi≈øcariam de Egre, & Pa≈øcua ad omnia Animalia in Fore≈øt√¢ ip≈øius Ranulphi. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 774. But quaere, whether this were not Randle de Micenis, Son of William de Me≈øchin Lord of Coupland, who Founded the Cell of St. Beges in Cumberland, belonging to St. Mary's of York; ≈øee Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 395, 396. and not our Earl of Che≈øter here ≈øpoken of; for that the Page 774. before-cited ≈øhews, that the Abbey of Kaldra was Founded Anno Domini 1134. which was after the Death of this Randle Earl of Che≈øter; and it ≈øeems not to be meant of our ≈øecond Randle Earl of Che≈øter, becau≈øe then he would probably have been ≈øtiled Earl, and not barely Randle Me≈øchin, as there he is ≈øtiled.

Pipe-Roll. 5 Stephani. Lincoln≈øhire. Lucia, the Widow of this fir≈øt Randle Earl of Che≈øter, gave 266 l. 13 s. 4 d. for Livery of her Father's Lands; and al≈øo 500 Marks Fine, that ≈øhe might not be compelled to Marry within five Years.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: Of Randle the Second.

div.p: Anno Domini 1139. King Stephen made Henry, Son of David King of Scotland, Earl of Northumberland, at Durham; and gave him Carli≈øle and Cumberland, upon a Peace then concluded between Stephen and the King of Scotland: Which incen≈øed this Randle Earl of Che≈øter more vehemently again≈øt Stephen; howbeit in re≈øpect of his Alliance to Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter, who≈øe Daughter he had Married, Randle was more apt to be drawn unto the Part of Maude the Empre≈øs: So that John Prior of Hagul≈øted, in his Continuation of the Hi≈øtory of Simon of Durham, pa. 268. tells us, That in Anno 1140. Henry Son of the King of Scotland, with his Wife, coming to vi≈øit King Stephen in England, this Earl of Che≈øter was much di≈øplea≈øed at him; for Randle required Carli≈øle and Cumberland as his rightful Patrimony, and would have fought the ≈øaid Henry in his Return to Scotland: But Stephen having notice of Randle's intentions, ≈øent Henry back into his Countrey ≈øafe from all danger; and afterwards was the Earl of Che≈øter's indignation bent again≈øt King Stephen, and the Earl ≈øurpri≈øed the Ca≈øtle of Lincoln, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of all the Strong Holds in Lincoln≈øhire.

II. This Randle was a gallant Man at Arms, and took King Stephen Pri≈øoner at the Battel near Lincoln, on Candlemas-day, Anno Domini 1141. Ordericus, Huntington, and Hoveden. But Mat. Paris placeth this Battel in Anno 1140. The Story is ≈øet down at large by Ordericus, lib. 13. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. pag. 921, 922, as followeth.

Anno Domini 1141. Anno ≈øexto Stephani Regis, Randle Earl of Che≈øter, and William de Romara his half-Brother by the Mother, Earl of Lincoln, rebelled again≈øt Stephen, and fraudulently ≈øurpri≈øed the Ca≈øtle of Lincoln, wherein King Stephen had placed a Garri≈øon of Soldiers for Defence of the Town; which Ca≈øtle was taken thus. Spying the Opportunity, when the Ca≈øtle-Soldiers were di≈øper≈øed abroad, the Earl of Che≈øter unarmed, and without a Cloke or Coat, (as if he meant to fetch home his Wife, whom he had before ≈øent thither, accompanied with the Counte≈øs of Lincoln, Wife of the ≈øaid William de Romara, as walking abroad for their Recreation) enters the Ca≈øtle with three Soldiers, which followed him not far off, no Man ≈øu≈øpecting any Treachery. They pre≈øently ≈øei≈øed the Port or Gate, and took all the Arms which they found, letting in William de Romara, with a Company of armed Soldiers, who ha≈øted after, according to the contrivement of the Plot; and ≈øo turning all out that remained in the Ca≈øtle, which were of the King's part, the two Brothers po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves both of the Town and Ca≈øtle.

Bi≈øhop Alexander, and the Town≈ømen, willing to in≈øinuate them≈øelves into the favor
of King Stephen, gave him notice of what had hapned. The news much incen≈øed the King, and ≈øo much the more, by how much the Fact was committed by tho≈øe whom he took for his ≈øpecial Friends, and on whom he had conferred many Favors. Stephen forthwith gathereth an Army, and after Chri≈øtmas-day, which was in the ≈øeventh Year of Stephen's Reign, Anno 1141. marcheth towards Lincoln; where by his ≈øudden and unexpected coming in the Night, and the Intelligence of ≈øome of the Town≈ømen, he ≈øurprized ≈øeventeen of the Earls Soldiers which were in the Town.

The two Earls with their Wives and Friends were Be≈øieged in the Ca≈øtle, and knew not how to e≈øcape this pre≈øent Danger. At la≈øt Randle Earl of Che≈øter (who was the younger and more courageous Earl) adventures out by Night, attended onely with a few, and went to Che≈øhire as among≈øt his own Men: He makes known his Condition to Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter his Father-in-law, and to others of his Friends: The Di≈øinherited Wel≈øh and many others he exa≈øperates again≈øt the King, and rai≈øeth all the Forces he can, to help his Friends that were Be≈øieged in the Ca≈øtle of Lincoln; e≈øpecially he implores the Aid of Maude the Empre≈øs and Counte≈øs of Anjou, ≈øwearing Fealty unto her, who≈øe Favour he obtained. Having now gathered a numerous Army, the two Earls, Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter, and Randle Earl of Che≈øter, march ≈øpeedily to Lincoln. The King hearing of their approach, advi≈øeth what is to be done: Some coun≈øel him to leave a competent Strength to defend the Town, and to go away him≈øelf, and rai≈øe a potent Army through all the parts of the Kingdom, whereby in due time he might be able to di≈øper≈øe them, if they ≈øhould continue before that Town. Others advi≈øe him to ≈øend a Parley to the Enemy, to put off the Battel, ≈øince that Day (being Candlemas-day) was ≈øacred, and to be ≈øet apart in commemoration of the Purification of the Virgin Mary. But the ob≈øtinate King not willing to delay the Matter, draws forth all his Forces immediately; both Armies meet near the Town of Lincoln, and being put in order, joyn Battel. The King divides his Army into three Bodies; ≈øo did the Earls likewi≈øe divide their Army on the contrary part. In the Front of the King's Army were the Flemmings and the Britons, Commanded by William de Ipro and Alan de Dinan. On the oppo≈øite part to them ≈øtood a furious Company of the Wel≈øh, Commanded by two Brothers, Mariadoth and Kaladrius.

The Earl of Che≈øter alights from his Hor≈øe, re≈øolving to Fight on foot. The ≈øtout Earl bravely encouraged his courageous Che≈øhire Regiment of Foot, and made this ≈øhort Speech to the Earl of Gloce≈øter, and the re≈øt of his Army‚Äî

p.note: This Speech is not in Ordericus; but is taken out of Huntington, pag. 390. It is al≈øo in Hoveden and others.
p.q: I humbly thank you, mo≈øt invincible General, and you the re≈øt of my fellow Soldiers, that you have ≈øo faithfully and courageou≈øly expre≈ø≈øed your Affection to me, even to the hazard of your own Lives: And ≈øince I have been the cau≈øe of this your danger, it is but rea≈øon I ≈øhould lead the Way, and give the fir≈øt On≈øet to the Army of the perfidious King, who hath broken the Truce he made; and onely out of the confidence of your Valour, and the King's Inju≈øtice, I doubt not to di≈ø≈øipate his Forces, and with my Sword to make way through the mid≈øt of my Enemies: Methinks I ≈øee them run already.

div.p: Then Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter, who Commanded in Chief, encouraged his Soldiers, and told the Ba≈ø≈øians and others who were Di≈øinherited, That now they ≈øhould have one Bout for the recovery of their Right and Inheritance.

King Stephen on the other part alights from his Hor≈øe, and Fought on foot very ≈øtoutly both for his Life and Kingdom; but having no audible Voice, commanded Baldwin de Clare, a Man of great Honour and Prowe≈øs, to make known his mind to the Army:Henry Huntington, li. 8. who made an Oration to encourage the Soldiers; Impeaching the Earl of Che≈øter, as a Man audacious, but without Judgment; heady to plot a Trea≈øon, but ≈øtill wavering in the pur≈øuit of it; ready to run into Battel, but uncircum≈øpect of any danger; aiming beyond his reach, and conceiting things meerly impo≈ø≈øible; and therefore hath but few with him that know him, leading onely a Rout of vagrant and tumultuous Pe≈øants: So there is nothing in him to be feared; for what≈øoever he begins like a Man, he ends like a Woman; unfortunate in all his Undertakings: In his Encounters he hath either been vanqui≈øhed, or if by chance he rarely a obtain Victory, it is with greater lo≈øs on his part then the Conquered.

But as ≈øoon as he had ended his Oration, the Fight began; which was very fierce and terrible, many ≈ølain on both parts. In the Head of the King's Army were very ≈øtout Soldiers; but his Enemies outvying him in number, prevailed. William de Ipro with the Flemmings, and Alan with the Britons, fir≈øt turn their Backs; Huntington and Hoveden ≈øay they beat the Wel≈øh, but the Earl of Che≈øter coming up with his Forces, quite routed them. which much di≈øcouraged the King's Friends, but encouraged the Enemy. The King was ill betrayed: for ≈øome of his Nobles accompanied him in Per≈øon, whiles they ≈øent whole Troops to the other ≈øide.

Waleran Earl of Mellent, and William de Warren his Brother, Gilbert de Clare, and other famous Knights both of England and Normandy, ran away as ≈øoon as they ≈øaw their own ≈øide ≈øhrink: But Baldwin de Clare, and Richard, Son of Ur≈øi, Engelram de Say, and Ildebert Lacy, ≈øtuck ≈øtoutly to the King, and Fought it to the la≈øt Man: Stephen him≈øelf, like a noble Branch of an heroick Family, Fought ≈øo gallantly, that when his Sword was broken, taking a Battel-Axe from a young Gentleman which ≈øtood near him, he cea≈øed not to Encounter with his over-powerful Enemies; but at la≈øt was con≈øtrained to yield him≈øelf Pri≈øoner to Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter, his Co≈øin, who ≈øent him to Maude the Empre≈øs at Bri≈øtow, where he was impri≈øoned. Baldwine de Clare likewi≈øe, and other excellent Champions on the King's part, were taken Pri≈øoners.

Thus by the voluble Wheel of Fortune was King Stephen taken Pri≈øoner at the Battel of Lincoln, on Candlemas-day, Anno Domini 1141. according to Ordericus, who lived in that very Age; which was principally occa≈øioned by the Valour and A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Randle Earl of Che≈øter.

III. Alan Earl of Brettaine, a treacherous and cruel Man,Ge≈øta Steph. pag. 953. lying in Ambu≈øh for the Earl of Che≈øter, to revenge the Di≈øhonor of taking his Lord and King Pri≈øoner, was him≈øelf taken and impri≈øoned till he did Homage to Randle Earl of Che≈øter, and had delivered up his Ca≈øtles unto him. Others ≈øay, Alan Earl of Richmond and Little-Britain, was ≈øent for by Randle to ≈øpeak with him, and ≈øo was Apprehended by him, Anno 1141. John Hagu≈øtalden≈øis, pag. 269.

Not long after this, Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter was taken Pri≈øoner in another Battel, by ≈øome others of Stephen's Party; and ≈øo immediately King Stephen and Earl Robert were exchanged each for other.

Anno 1143. Stephen being relea≈øed out of Pri≈øon, Be≈øieged Lincoln, and would have built a Fort over again≈øt the Ca≈øtle, which Randle Earl of Che≈øter kept; but the Earl killed almo≈øt eighty of his Workmen, and ≈øo he was forced to give it off. Mat. Paris and Hen. Huntington. But Hoveden placeth this 1144. 9 Stephani.

Anno Domini 1145. King Stephen gathering a great Army, built a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle over again≈øt Wallingford; whither Randle Earl of Che≈øter accompanied him with great Forces, and was re≈øtored unto his Favour: But afterwards the Earl coming to the King's Court at Northampton, was ≈øurprized, little dreaming of any ≈øuch matter, and ca≈øt into Pri≈øon, untill he re≈øtored the Ca≈øtle of Lincoln, which he had fraudulently taken, and all other Ca≈øtles which he injuriou≈øly had taken from the King. Chronica Normanniae, put out by Du Che≈øne with other Hi≈øtories, pag. 982. Al≈øo Polychronicon addeth, That the Wel≈øhmen then wa≈øted Che≈øhire, but were intercepted at Nantwich, ‚öú lib. 7. cap. 19. Mona≈øticon, vol. 1. pag. 890.

But for the Reconcilement of Stephen and Randle, it is more fully ≈øet down in Ge≈øta Stephani, pag 968. thus‚ÄîThe Earl of Che≈øter (who had got almo≈øt a third part of the Kingdom by his Sword) comes to the King, and de≈øires Pardon for his Rebellion at Lincoln, and for the ≈øeizing of his Soveraign's Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and thereupon was received into Favour: And in farther te≈øtimony of his Obedience, he helped the King's Forces, and gallantly A≈ø≈øaulted the Town of Bedford, which had much weakned and ≈øhattered the King's Army; and having taken it, delivers it into Stephen's Hands. After this he accompanied King Stephen to Wallingford, attended with three hundred gallant Hor≈øe, till the King had erected a ≈øtately Ca≈øtle in pro≈øpect thereof, to ≈øtop the Incur≈øions of the Enemy, which were wont to i≈ø≈øue out of Wallingford, and prey upon the Countrey. But for all this Friend≈øhip, Randle was ≈øu≈øpected of Stephen, becau≈øe he ≈øurrendred not the Ca≈øtles and Rents which he had violently taken from him; and becau≈øe of the
Earls wavering and un≈øtable Mind, not having put in Pledges of his Fidelity; ≈øo that neither the King nor his prime Councellors dur≈øt rely upon him, unle≈øs he would ≈øurrender all the King's Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions: and if he refu≈øed this, then the King ought to clap him up at his be≈øt opportunity. Ibidem, pag. 970, 971.

Randle Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øeeing he was thus ≈øu≈øpected, turns him≈øelf to his wonted cour≈øe of Trea≈øon, plotting how he might more ea≈øily without Infamy deliver the King into the Hands of his Enemies: and coming to the Court with ≈øome Attendance, whereby he might be the freer from ≈øu≈øpicion, he complained how he was be≈øet with a barbarous multitude of Wel≈øh, who made great ≈øpoil and wa≈øte of his Lands; ≈øo that he and all his Tenants bordering on the Confines of his County, would be quite extirpated, unle≈øs the King gave him ≈øpeedy A≈ø≈øi≈øtance; telling him, that his Pre≈øence would do more by the very Name of a King, than many thou≈øands of Soldiers without him. The King cheerfully promi≈øeth his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance; but the Councel about his Royal Per≈øon would not ≈øuffer it: for they wi≈øhed the King to con≈øider, lea≈øt the Earl had a De≈øign to en≈ønare him, telling him, That it was not ≈øafe for him to bring his Army into the mid≈øt of ≈øo barbarous a Countrey, through mountainous and ≈øteepy places, where he might be entraped on every ≈øide: be≈øides it were a very ra≈øh part, to go into his Countrey who had taken from him the greate≈øt part of his Kingdom: for although he might ≈øeem to incline to the King, yet there was no certainty of his Fidelity, nor Pledges of A≈ø≈øurance: And that if he would have the King's A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, he ≈øhould fir≈øt deliver up what he had unju≈øtly taken; which if he refu≈øed, then pre≈øently he ≈øhould be ≈øeized on as the King's Enemy, and be impri≈øoned till he made Re≈øtitution. But Randle, when he heard the Conditions which he was to perform before he could have the King's Aid, an≈øwer'd, That he came not to the Court for that purpo≈øe, neither had he any notice of this beforehand, whereby he might have advi≈øed thereon; and uttering many high words, he was laid hold on by the King's Officers and impri≈øoned. The Nobles who took part with Earl Randle, Petitioned the King for his Enlargement, and offered Sureties, or any Security the King ≈øhould demand, for the delivering up of tho≈øe Ca≈øtles which were of Right belonging to the King, ≈øo that the Earl might be relea≈øed. And thereupon Randle Earl of Che≈øter (having given Pledges, and taken a ≈øolemn Oath, that he would never hereafter take up Arms again≈øt the King) was re≈øtored to his Liberty.

But as ≈øoon as he was relea≈øed, he violated his Oath, and rai≈øed an Army again≈øt the King, pro≈øecuting his wrathful indignation with revenge of Fire and Sword where≈øoever he came; and, as my Author ≈øaith, In omnem aetatem, in omnem Sexum, Herodianam Tyrannidem, Neronianam truculentiam exercebat. He came often with a Party of Soldiers in view of the Town of Lincoln (where now the King had placed the Flower of his Soldiery) and had many Skirmi≈øhes with them; ≈øometimes he was put to the wor≈øe, ≈øometimes by the ≈ømiling Succe≈øs of Fortune he victoriou≈øly triumphed over the King's Party. He likewi≈øe blockt up the Ca≈øtle of Coventrey, (which al≈øo he had delivered up to the King) till Stephen came to relieve it with Victuals, whereof it was in ≈øome di≈øtre≈øs; and that was done with great difficulty to the King, by forcing his Pa≈ø≈øage through Randle's Army; where by the Way he had many Conflicts. In the fir≈øt Skirmi≈øh the King having received ≈øome ≈ølight Wound, was forced to retreat; but as ≈øoon as he was recovered, he fell upon the Earls Army, took many, wounded others, and the Earl him≈øelf put to flight, and almo≈øt ≈ølain. The King then pulls down the Ca≈øtle of Coventrey, which had been delivered to him before, and victoriou≈øly proceeds to other Ca≈øtles in Randle's po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ≈øometimes blocking them up, ≈øometimes burning and de≈øtroying all about them, and ever after became a ≈øore Enemy to Randle and his Adherents. Thus much ex Ge≈øtis Stephani.

Anno Domini 1150. David King of Scotland, Entertained Henry, Son of Maude the Empre≈øs, at Carli≈øle very magnificently about Whit≈øuntide, and Knighted him there in the Pre≈øence of Henry, Son of King David, and Randle Earl of Che≈øter; which Randle was then appea≈øed concerning his Claim of Carli≈øle and Cumberland as his Patrimony, and did Homage to King David; for there was ≈øome Speech among≈øt them, that for
Carli≈øle, Randle ≈øhould have the Honour of Lanca≈øter, and that Earl Randle's Son ≈øhould Marry one of the Daughters of Henry Prince of Scotland: And ≈øo King David, and Henry Duke of Normandy, and Earl Randle were agreed to unite their Forces again≈øt King Stephen. And King David, with his Son Henry, came to Lanca≈øter with their Forces, where Earl Randle promi≈øed to meet them with his; but Randle failing of his Promi≈øe, they returned back. Johannes Prior Hagu≈øtalden≈øis, pag. 277, 278.

Anno 1151. Randle Earl of Che≈øter having been impri≈øoned (which Impri≈øonment Radulfus de Diceto, Chronica Gerva≈øii, John Bromton, Chronica Normanniae, Mat. Paris, and Mat. We≈øtmin≈øter, do all place in Anno 1145. but Hoveden in Anno 1146.) and having given his Nephew Gilbert de Clare for his Ho≈øtage, was relea≈øed: But fal≈øifying his Word, and endangering his Ho≈øtage, he ≈øendeth for Henry Duke of Normandy into England, promi≈øing him all A≈ø≈øi≈øtance. Whereupon Henry came into England; to whom Robert Earl of Leyce≈øter, and many of the wi≈øe≈øt Noblemen of England then re≈øorted. Idem Johannes, pag. 278.

What a tumultuous Age this was, and how the Great Men of the Kingdom divided the Spoils, may appear by the Agreement made between this Randle Earl of Che≈øter, and Robert, ≈øirnamed Bo≈ø≈øu, Earl of Leyce≈øter, about the Year 1151. the Original whereof remains in Cotton's Library in We≈øtmin≈øtsr.

Haec e≈øt Conventio int√®r Ranulfum Comitem Ce≈øtriae, & Robertum Comitem Legrece≈øtriae; & finalis Pax & Concordia quae fuit Conce≈ø≈øa & divi≈øa ab eis, cor√†m Secundo Roberto Epi≈øcopo Lincolniae, & hominibus eorum; ex parte Comitis Ce≈øtriae, Ricardo de Lovetot, Willielmo filio Nigelli, Ranulfo Vice-Comite: Ex parte Comitis Legrece≈øtriae, Ernaldo de Bo≈øco, Gaufrido Abbate, Reginaldo de Bordineio: Scilic√®t, qu√≤d Comes Ranulfus dedit & Conce≈ø≈øit Roberto Comiti Legrece≈øtriae ca≈øtrum de Mount≈øorell, ≈øibi & haeredibus ≈øuis. Tenendum de eo & haeredibus ≈øuis haereditari√® & ≈øic√πt Charta ip≈øius Comitis Ranulfi te≈øtatur: Et it√† qu√≤d Comes Leyce≈øtriae receptare debet ip≈øum Comitem Ranulfum & familiam ≈øuam in Burgo & Ball ‚Ä¢ s de Mount≈øorell, ad guerrandum quemcunque voluerit ut de feodo ≈øuo: Et it√† qu√≤d Comes Leyce≈øtriae non pote≈øt ind√® forisfacere Comiti Ranulfo pro aliquo: Et ≈øi nece≈ø≈øe ≈øit Comiti Ranulfo, corpus ip≈øius receptabitur in Dominico Ca≈øtro de Mount≈øorell: Et it√† qu√≤d Comes Leyce≈øtriae portabit ei fidem, ≈øalv√† fide Ligei Domini ≈øui: Et ≈øi oportuerit Comitem Leyce≈øtriae ire ≈øuper Comitem Ce≈øtriae c√πm Ligeo Domino ≈øuo, non pote≈øt ducere ≈øecum plus qu√†m viginti milites: Et ≈øi Comes Leyce≈øtriae, vel i≈øti viginti milites aliquid ceperint de rebus Comitis Ce≈øtriae, totum reddetur. Nec Ligius Dominus, Comes Leyce≈øtriae, nec aliquis alius pote≈øt forisfacere Comiti Ce≈øtriae, nec ≈øuis, de Ca≈øtris ip≈øius Comitis Leyce≈øtriae, n√®c de terr√¢ ≈øu√¢: Et it√† qu√≤d Comes Leyce≈øtriae nec pote≈øt propt√®r aliquam Cau≈øam, vel propt√®r aliquem Ca≈øum, impedire Corpus Comitis Ce≈øtriae, ni≈øi eum de≈øidaverit quindecem dies ante√†: Et Comes Lyce≈øtriae debet juvare Comitem Ce≈øtriae contr√† omnes homines, praet√®r Ligium Dominum ip≈øius Comitis Leyce≈øtriae, & Comitem Simonem: Comitem Simonem pote≈øt juvare hoc modo, quod ≈øi Comes Ranulfus forisfecerit Comiti Simoni, & ip≈ø ‚Ä¢ Comes Ranulfus noluerit Corrigere forisfactum propt√®r Comitem Leyce≈øtriae, tunc pote≈øt eum juvare: Et ≈øi Comes Simon forisfecerit Comiti Ce≈øtriae, & noluerit Corrigere ≈øe propt√®r Comitem Leyce≈øtriae, non juvabit eum Comes Leyce≈øtriae: Et Comes Leyce≈øtriae debet cu≈øtodire terras & res Comitis Ce≈øtriae, quae in pote≈øtate ip≈øius Comitis Leyce≈øtriae ≈øunt, ≈øin√® malo ingenio. Et Comes Leyce≈øtriae pepigit Comiti Ranulfo, qu√≤d Ca≈øtrum de Raven≈øtona cadet, ni≈øi conce≈ø≈øu Comitis Ranulfi reman≈øerit: Et it√† qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis vellet illud Ca≈øtrum tenere contr√† Comitem Leyce≈øtriae, Comes Ranulfus auxiliabitur ab≈øqu√® malo ingenio ad diruendum Ca≈øtrum illud: Et ≈øi Comes Ranulfus fecerit clamorem de Willielmo de Alneto, Comes Leyce≈øtriae in ≈øu√¢ Curi√¢ habebit eum ad rectum quamdiu ip≈øe Willielmus man≈øerit homo Comitis Leyce≈øtriae & terram tenebit de eo: Et it√† quod ≈øi Willielmus vel ≈øui rece≈ø≈øerint √† fidelitate Comitis Leyce≈øtriae propt√®r Ca≈øtrum Pro≈øtratum, vel qui√† rectum noluerit facere in Curi√¢ Comitis Leyce≈øtriae, non receptabuntur in pote≈øtate Comitis Ce≈øtriae, nequ√® Willielmus nequ√® ≈øui, ad malum faciendum Comiti Leyce≈øtriae: In h√¢c Conventione remanet Comiti Leyce≈øtriae Ca≈øtrum de Witewic firmatum c√πm caeteris Ca≈øtris ≈øuis.

Et e Conver≈øo, Comes Ranulfus portabit fidem Comiti Leyce≈øtriae, ≈øalv√¢ fide Ligii Domini ≈øui: Et ≈øi oportuerit Comitem Ce≈øtriae ire ≈øup√®r Comitem Leyce≈øtriae, c√πm Ligio Domino ≈øuo, non pote≈øt ducere ≈øecum plus qu√†m viginti milites: Et ≈øi Comes Ce≈øtriae, vel i≈øti viginti milites, aliquid ceperint de rebus Comitis Leyce≈øtriae, totum reddetur: Nec Ligius Dominus, Comes Ce≈øtriae, aut aliquis alius pote≈øt forisfacere Comiti Leyce≈øtriae nec ≈øuis, de Ca≈øtris ip≈øius Comitis Ce≈øtriae, n√®c de terr√¢ ≈øu√¢: Et it√† quod Comes Ce≈øtriae non pote≈øt propt√®r aliquam Cau≈øam, vel aliquem Ca≈øum, impedire Corpus Comitis Leyce≈øtriae, ni≈øi eum defidaverit quindecem dies ant√®. Et Comes Ce≈øtriae debet juvare Comitem Leyce≈øtriae contr√† omnes Homines, praet√®r Ligium Dominum ip≈øius Comitis Ce≈øtriae, & Comitem Robertum de Ferrariis. Comitem Robertum pote≈øt juvare hoc modo, ≈øi Comes Leyce≈øtriae forisfecerit Comiti de Ferrariis, & ip≈øe Comes Leyce≈øtriae noluerit corrigere forisfactum propt√®r Comitem Ce≈øtriae, tunc pote≈øt eum juvare Comes Ce≈øtriae: Et ≈øi Comes Robertus de Ferrariis forisfecit Comiti Leyce≈øtriae, & noluerit ≈øe corrigere propter Comitem Ce≈øtriae, non juvabit eum Comes Ce≈øtriae. Et Comes Ce≈øtriae debet cu≈øtodire terras & res Comitis Leyce≈øtriae, quae in pote≈øtate ip≈øius Comitis Ce≈øtriae ≈øunt, ≈øin√® malo ingenio. Et Comes Ce≈øtriae pepigit Comiti Leyce≈øtriae, qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis vellet Ca≈øtrum de Rave≈øtona tenere contr√† Comitem Leyce≈øtriae, Comes Ranulfus auxiliabitur ≈øin√® malo ingenio ad diruendum Ca≈øtrum illud: Nec Comes Ce≈øtriae, nec Comes Leyce≈øtriae debent firmare Ca≈øtrum aliquod novum inter Hinckley & Coventrey, nec inter Hinckley & Hardrede≈øhellam, nec int√®r Coventrey & Donintonam: nec inter Donintonam & Leyce≈øtriam, nec ad Grataham, nec ad Chenelde≈øtam, & Belvier, nec inter Belveer & Hocham, nec inter Hocham & Rockingham, nec propi√πs, ni≈øi communi a≈ø≈øen≈øu utriu≈øque: Et ≈øi aliquis in praedictis locis, vel infr√† praedictos Terminos, firmaret Ca≈øtrum, uterque alteri erit auxilio ≈øin√® malo ingenio donec Ca≈øtrum diruatur. E ‚Ä¢ hanc Conventionem, ≈øicut in h√¢c Chart√¢ continetur, affidavit uterque Comes, videlic√®t Ce≈øtren≈øis & Leyce≈øtren≈øis, in manu Roberti Secundi, Lincolnien≈øis Epi≈øcopi, Tenendam: Et po≈øuerunt eundem Epi≈øcopum ob≈øidem hujus Conventionis ≈øup√®r Chri≈øtianitatem ≈øuam: It√† qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis exiret ab h√¢c Conventione, & nollet ≈øe corrigere infra 15 dies po≈øtqu√†m inde requi≈øitus fuerit ≈øin√® malo ingenio, t√πnc Epi≈øcopus Lincolnien≈øis, & Epi≈øcopus Ce≈øtren≈øis facient ju≈øtitiam de eo tanqu√†m de fide mentit√¢. Et Epi≈øcopus Lincolniae, & Epi≈øcopus Ce≈øtriae tradent ob≈øides uterque duos, quos receperunt propt√®r Conventiones i≈øtas Tenendas, illi videlic√®t qui Conventiones i≈øtas praedictas tenebit.

How Randle Earl of Che≈øter was rewarded for taking part with Henry Fitz-Empre≈øs, being yet but Duke of Normandy, and Earl of Angeau, may appear by this Deed following, which I conjecture was made about the Year 1152. when Stephen and Henry made an Agreement: The Original hereof is in Cotton's Library: It is al≈øo upon Record in one of the great Couchir Books in the Dutchy Office at Gray's-Inne in London, Tom. 2. Honor ≈øiv√® Soca de Bolingbroke, num. 7. pag. 498, 499.

HEnricus Dux Normanniae, & Comes Andegaviae, omnibus Archiepi≈øcopis, Epi≈øcopis, Comitibus, Baronibus, Vice-Comitibus & omnibus Amicis & fidelibus ≈øuis, Normannis & Anglis, Salutem. Sciatis me dedi≈ø≈øe & conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe Ranulfo Comiti Ce≈øtriae omnem haereditatem ≈øuam Normanniae & Angliae, ≈øicut unqu√†m aliquis Antece≈ø≈øorum ≈øuorum eam meli√πs & liberi√πs tenuit: & nominatim Ca≈øtellum de Vira & Barbifluvium c√πm tali libertate, qu√≤d per totam baleugam po≈ø≈øit capere forisfactum ≈øuum: Et Brullium de fo≈ø≈øis, & Alebec, & hoc (und√® erat Vice-Comes) de Abrinciis, & in Sancto Jacobo, de hoc feci eum Comitem: & quicquid habui in Abrinches ei dedi praet√®r Epi≈øcopatum, & Abbatiam de monte Sancti Michaelis, & quod eis pertinet: In≈øuper Dedi & conce≈ø≈øi ei totum honorem Comitis Rogeri Pictavien≈øis ubicunque aliquid habet: & totum honorem de Eia, ≈øicut Robertus Mallet, avunculus Matris ≈øuae illum meli√πs & plenius unqu√†m tenuit: In≈øup√®r dedi ei Stafford & Stafford≈øhire, & Comitatum Staffordiae totum, quicquid ego ibi habui in feodo & haereditate, Excepto feodo Epi≈øcopi Ce≈øtriae, & Comitis Roberti de Ferrars, & Hugonis de Mortuo Mari, & Gerva≈øii Pagani, & except√¢ Fore≈øt√¢ de Canok quam in manu me√¢ retineo: Et feodum Alani de Lincolne ei dedi, qui fuit Avunculus Matris ≈øuae: Et feodum Erni≈øii de Burun, ≈øicut ≈øuam haereditatem: Et feodum Hugonis de Scoteneio ei dedi, ubicunqu√® ≈øit e
Et feodum Roberti de Chalz, ubicunqu√® ≈øit: Et totum feodum Radulfi Filii Odonis: Et totum feodum Normanni de Verdun: Et feodum Roberti de Stafford, ubicunqu√® ≈øit: Et triginta libratas terrae, quas habui in Grimesbeia,King Stephen gave to Randle Gernouns the Ca≈øtle and City of Lincoln, till he ≈øhould be re≈øtored to all his Lands in Nomandy and his Ca≈øtles there, and thereupon gave him liberty to fortifie one of the Towers of Lincoln Ca≈øtle, to have Command thereof till the King ≈øhould deliver the Ca≈øtle of Tickill, and then to deliver up Lincoln Ca≈øtle, excepting the Earls own Tower, which his Mother had fortified, and the Con≈øtable≈øhip of that Ca≈øtle, and the whole County, which was his ancient Inheritance; and al≈øo the Ca≈øtle of Belvoir, with all the Barony, and all the Land of William de Albiney, then Lord of Belvoir; and Graham (vulgo Grantham) with Sok: And if the Heirs of Graham ≈øhould Compound with the King, yet the Barony to remain till the King gave other Lands for it. By the ≈øame Charter the King gave him New-Ca≈øtle in Stafford≈øhire, & Socam de Roeley, Tork≈øey, Derby, Mansfield, Stoneley, the Wapentack of Orwardebek, and all the Lands of Roger de Bu≈øley, with all the Honour of Blithe nigh Tickhill, and all the Lands of Roger de Poictu from Northampton to Scotland, except what belongs to Roger de Montbegon in Lincoln≈øhire; al≈øo all the Lands between Ribbell and Mer≈øey; and the Land which the King had in Demaine in Grimsby in Lincoln≈øhire, and all the Land which the Earl of Gloce≈øter had in Demaine in that Mannor of Grimsby. And al≈øo he re≈øtored, for Randle's ≈øake, unto Adelize de Condy, all her Lands, viz. Hornca≈øtle in Lincoln≈øhire, when the Ca≈øtle was demoli≈øhed. And all his own other Lands the King re≈øtored unto him. Ex Charta Originali nuper in Ca≈øtro de Pomfret. Which Note I had from Mr. Dugdale.
ei dedi: Et Nottingham Ca≈øtle, & Burgum, & quicquid habui in Nottingham, in feodo & haereditate ≈øibi & haeredibus ≈øuis: Dedi & totum feodum Willielmi Peverelli ubicunque ≈øit, ni≈øi poterit ≈øe dirationare in me√¢ Curi√¢ de ≈øcelere & Proditione, except√¢ Hecham: Et ≈øi Engelramus de Albemarle non voluerit ≈øe capere mecum, neque Comes Simon, & illud vi capere potero, praedictam Hecham reddo Comiti Ranulfo, ≈øi eam habere voluerit: Et Torche≈øeiam, & O≈øwardebek Wapentack, & Derbeiam c√πm omnibus Pertinentiis: Et Maunsfield c√πm Soca, & Roelay c√πm Soca, & Stanleiam juxt√† Coventreiam c√πm Soca, & de Belvario tenebo ei rectum qu√†m citi√πs potero, ≈øicut de ≈øu√¢ haereditate: Et ≈øex Baronibus ≈øuis, quos elegerit, cuique centum libratas terrae dabo, de his quae mihi ex ho≈øtibus meis adqui≈øita acciderint, de me tenendas: Et omnibus Parentibus ≈øuis ≈øuam reddo haereditatem und√® potens ≈øum, & de hoc und√® ad prae≈øens potens non ≈øum, rectum Plenarium tenebo ex quo potens ero. Con≈øtabulario, Guarino Filio Ger. Roberto de Curcy Dapifero, Mana≈ø≈øero By≈ø≈øet Dapifero, Philippo de Columbe. Ex parte Comitis Ranulfi, Willielmo Comite Lincolniae, Hugone Wac. G. Ca≈øtell de Fines, Simone Filio Willielmi, Thur≈øtano de Monteforti, Gaufrido de Co≈øtentyn, Willielmo de Verdon, Ricardo de Pincerna, Rogero Wac. Simone Filio Osberti. Apud Divi≈øas.

And here I cannot pa≈øs by Vincent's Error in the Review of the ≈øecond Edition of Brooks's Catalogue of Nobility, pag. 662. where he ≈øaith thus: That the Barons of the Earls of Che≈øter were cho≈øen in the time of Hugh Lupus, I doubt: for what ≈øhould move Henry the Second (when he was but yet Duke of Normandy and Earl of Anjou) among divers Grants that he made to Randle de Gernouns Earl of Che≈øter, to ≈øay in his Charter‚ÄîEt ≈øex Baronibus ≈øuis, quos elegerit, cuique centum libratas terrae dabo: That he would give to the ≈øix Barons, quos elegerit, which he ≈øhall chu≈øe, not quos eligerit, which he hath already, cho≈øen, a hundred pound Land apiece, &c. if they had been cho≈øe in Hugh Lupus's time? Thus Vincent.

But to pa≈øs by his gro≈øs Di≈øtinction of Elegerit and Eligerit; for it is Elegerit in both Ten≈øes, Future and Preterperfect Ten≈øe: nor is Eligerit any true Latin word at all. Methinks he reads not the Engli≈øh to a proper and genuine Sence; for I conceive the meaning to be plainly thus,‚ÄîEt ≈øex Baronibus ≈øuis, quos elegerit, cuique centum libratas terrae, &c. that is, To ≈øix of his Barons, whom he ≈øhall chu≈øe or appoint out, he will give to every one of them a hundred Pounds-worth of Land apiece. So that there might be many more Barons at that time for all this: And indeed the Charter of Hugh Lupus of the Foundation of the Mona≈øtery of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, Anno 1093. mentions Barons at that time; which you may ≈øee at large ≈øupr√†, pag. 109, 110, 111. In the Sub≈øcription whereof it is ≈øaid‚ÄîEgo Comes Hugo & Barones mei confirmavimus: And I pray you, how comes the Duke here to know Randle's mind to elect Barons, if they were yet to be cho≈øen?

But where he renders it‚ÄîAnd to the ≈øix Barons which he ≈øhall chu≈øe, I ≈øhould render it, And to ≈øix of his Barons whom he ≈øhall chu≈øe, or cull out: For the Grant being made to Earl Randle, there was ≈øo much to be given to ≈øix of his Barons, but left to the appointment and nomination of Earl Randle, which ≈øix Barons he would have to be the Men to enjoy tho≈øe Lands: for if we ≈øhould render it‚ÄîAnd to his ≈øix Barons, &c. implying onely
that ≈øet number, and no more, the following words (quos elegerit) would be ≈øuperfluous; for being given to ≈øix Barons equally, there is no choice left at all to the Earl, where there be no more Barons: unle≈øs we ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øix Barons to be made, and that there were none before; which evidently appears to the contrary: Therefore indeed the≈øe words, rightly under≈øtood, do imply, there were more Barons at that time, out of which Randle had the nomination of the ≈øix here intended left unto him.
But of the≈øe Barons I ≈øhall ≈øpeak more particularly in the third Part of this Book.

Take here a Deed or two of this Randles, which are in one of the great Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office at Grays-Inn: The fir≈øt being of certain wa≈øte Lands in Leyce≈øter≈øhire, which this Randle gave to Henry the Second, and the King gave them to Robert Bo≈ø≈øue Earl of Leyce≈øter.

Et volo & firmit√®r praecipio, ut ben√® & quiet√® & honorific√® teneat c√πm omnibus con≈øuetudinibus ≈øuis. div.head: The Wife and I≈ø≈øue of Randle the Second.
div.p: HE Married Maude, Daughter of Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter, Ba≈øtard Son of King Henry the Fir≈øt, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, and Richard. Gemeticen≈øis, lib. 8. cap. 38. Ordericus, pag. 921.

Powell in his Notes on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 295. calls this Counte≈øs Alice, for Maud; and ≈øo doth Ferne in his Lacy's Nobility, pag. 43. in his mo≈øt ab≈øurd Pedegree of the Earls of Che≈øter there. Both the≈øe Authors are gro≈øly mi≈øtaken herein. See her Name proved by the Deed infra, pag. 130, & 131.

div.head: The Death of Randle the Second.
div.p: ANno Domini 1153.The 16 day of December. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 2. pa. 280. Ranulfus ille Nobilis & Famo≈øus Comes Ce≈øtriae,Oblit 1153. 18 Stephani Regis. vir admod√πm Militaris, Per quendam Willielmum Peverellum (ut fama fuit) veneno infectus po≈øt multos Agones Militaris Gloriae, vir in≈øuperabilis audaciae vix ≈øol√¢ morte territus & devictus, vitam finivit temporalem. Chronica Gerva≈øii. Which John Prior of Hagu≈øtald placeth in Anno 1154. Chronica Normanniae ≈øay, Anno 1152.

Anno 1155. Willielmum Peverell caus√¢ Veneficii, qu√≤d Ranulfo Comiti Ce≈øtriae fuerat propinatum, Rex Anglorum Henricus exhaeredavit. In cujus Pe≈øtis Con≈øortio plures con≈øcii extiti≈ø≈øe dicuntur, ≈øaith Matthew Paris.

He was Earl of Che≈øter 25 Years, and founded the Nunnery in Che≈øter City. Mona≈øticon, 1 Pars, pag. 507. He died Excommunicated by Walter Durdant Bi≈øhop of Lichfield; for who≈øe Ab≈øolution, Maud his Wife, and Hugh his Son, gave the Town of Sty≈øhall near Coventry to the Bi≈øhop and his Succe≈ø≈øors: Ex vetu≈øto Exemplari in Baggo de diver≈øis Inqui≈øitionibus pen√®s The≈øaurarium & Camerarium Scaccarii We≈øtmona≈øterien≈øis, Londini.
Maud his Widow Founded the Priory of Holy Trinity at Ripendon in Derby≈øhire, Anno Domini 1172. 18 Hen. 2. And ≈øhe died the 29 day of July, 1189. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 2. pag. 280.

Randle the Second Founded the Priory of Trentham in Stafford≈øhire,‚ÄîSciatis me dedi≈ø≈øe centum Solidatas terrae meae Staffordie≈øire Deo, & Sanctae Mariae, & omnibus Sanctis, ad re≈øtaurandam quandam Abbathiam Canonicorum in Eccle≈øi√¢ de Trentham‚Äî& eas a≈ø≈øigno de Trenteham, und√® Rex Henricus habuit centum Solidos: So run the Words of the Grant. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 2. pag. 260. He gave al≈øo Cumbe to the Abby of Borde≈øly in Worce≈øter≈øhire, which his Counte≈øs Maude and Hugh his Son did afterwards confirm, Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 805. And al≈øo to the Abby of Ba≈øingwerk in Flint≈øhire, Holes, and half of Lecche, and five Pound Rent in Che≈øter. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 720.

Al≈øo he Founded the Priory of Mentings in Lincoln≈øhire, a Cell of the Abbey of St. Benedict ≈øuper Leyre. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 592. He gave al≈øo the Town of Canoc
(vulg√≤ Kank) to the Abbey of Stoneley in Warwick≈øhire. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 820.

Al≈øo he gave liberty to the Monks of Coventry to have two Carts going to and fro, twice every day, except Holy-days, unto his Woods there, for Fewel, and other Nece≈ø≈øaries. Char. 22 Edw. 3. per In≈øpeximus, Num. 6.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Of Hugh the Second, Sirnamed Cyveliok, becau≈øe he was born in the Commote or Province of Cyveliok, ≈øituate in that part of Wales anciently called Powys.

div.p: He performed many valiant Acts, and by his Sword made Purcha≈øe of the Land called Bromfield, from the Wel≈øh, his mo≈øt harmful Neighbors.
Anno 1172. Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, with the King of Scotland, and Robert Earl of Leyce≈øter, rebelled again≈øt Henry the Second: The≈øe took part with the King's Son again≈øt the King.

And in Anno 1173. 19 Hen. 2. Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, and Rafe de Filgiers in Normandy, had almo≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of all the Province of Little-Britain in France, but were overcome in Battel by Henry the Second; at which time the≈øe, with many others of the Nobility of Britain, were forced to retreat to the Ca≈øtle of Dole: But the Braibants, whereon King Henry relied, be≈øieged them on every ≈øide, the 13 of the Calends of September, being Tue≈øday. The King hereof being certified, came to Dole on the Friday following: So the Earl of Che≈øter, and the re≈øt that were in the Ca≈øtle, ≈øeeing them≈øelves unable to defend it, ≈øurrendred both them≈øelves and it to the King on the Sunday following, being the 7 of the Calends of September, or the 26 of our Augu≈øt. The Names of ≈øuch as were taken Pri≈øoners in that Ca≈øtle, are more at large ≈øet down by Hoveden, pag. 535, 536. So was Hugh Earl of Che≈øter taken Pri≈øoner, 1173.
But in Anno 1177. at a Parliament at Northampton, in January, both Robert Earl of Leyce≈øter, and Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, were re≈øtored to all their Lands by the King. Hoveden, pag. 560.

div.head: III. The Wife of Hugh Cyveliok.
div.p: HE Married Bertred, Daughter of Simon Earl of Evereux in Normandy. Vincent upon Brook, pag. 105.

That her Name was Bertred, and that ≈øhe ≈øurvived her Husband, take this Deed to prove it, in the Couchir Book in the Dutchy-office in Grays-Inn, London, Tom. 2. Honor ≈øiv√® Soca de Bolingbroke, num. 7. pag. 112.

q.p: OMnibus hoc ≈øcriptum audituris & vi≈øuris, Bertreya Comiti≈ø≈øa Ce≈øtriae, Salutem. Noverit univer≈øitas vestra, me Conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe & h√¢c me√¢ prae≈øenti Chart√¢ confirm√¢≈ø≈øe Radulfo Carbunel de Haltuna & Haeredibus ≈øuis, pro Homugio & Servitio ≈øuo, Feodum dimidii Militis quod tenet de me in Haltona Halton in Lincoln≈øhire., pro tribus Solidis annuat√¨m mihi & Haeredibus meis ad duos terminos reddendis, de illo & de Haeredibus ≈øuis, pro omni Servitio & Exactione; ≈øcilic√®t ad Nativitatem Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae decem & octo denarios, & ad Natale decem & octo denarios. Hiis Testibus, Radulfo Filio Simonis, Simone de Seis, Andrea Filio Willielmi, Willielmo de Maletoft, Willielmo de Haghe, Ricardo de Bunington, Ricardo de Harderna, Alano Filio Ramgoti, & aliis.

div.head: The I≈ø≈øue of Hugh Cyveliok by Bertred.
div.p: The Legitimate Children of Hugh. 1. RAndle the Third, ≈øirnamed Blundevill: He died without I≈ø≈øue, and his four Si≈øters ≈øhared his Inheritance.

2. Maude, elde≈øt Daughter of Hugh, Married David Earl of Huntingdon, Brother to William King of Scotland; of whom he begot John, ≈øirnamed The Scot, Earl of Chester in his Mother's Right: She had the Earldom of Chester, and the Lands in North-Wales to her ≈øhare.
3. Mabill, ≈øecond Daughter of Hugh by Bertred, Married William d' Albiney Earl of Arundel. She had the Manor of Barow, with 500 l. Lands. This was Barow in Leycester≈øhire.

4. Agnes, third Daughter of Earl Hugh by Bertred, Married William Ferrers Earl of Derby. She had the Ca≈øtle of Chartley
Chartley in Stafford≈øhire, with the Ca≈øtle and Manor of We≈øt-Derby, and all Earl Randle's Lands between the Rivers of Ribbel and Mer≈øey in Lanca≈øhire, Buckbroc in Northampton≈øhire, and Navenby in Lincoln≈øhire, Clau≈ø 17 Hen. 3. Memb. 1., and the Lands in that part of Wales anciently called Powys. She confirmed to the Church of St. Mary at Mirival the Manor of Great-Hole, and part of the Wood of Alteker, which William her Husband had before given. One of the Couchir Books in the Dutchy-Office, Tom. 1. fol. 133.

Clau≈ø. 17 He ‚Ä¢ . 3. memb. 17. Pipe-Rolls, 17 Hen. 3. Lincoln≈øhire.5. Hawi≈øe, fourth Daughter of Earl Hugh by Bertred, Married Robert Quency, Son and Heir of Saher de Quency Earl of Winchester. She had the Earldom of Lincoln, to wit, the Ca≈øtle and Honour of Bolingbroke, and all the Lands of Earl Randle in Lind≈øey and Holland in Lincoln≈øhire; for which ≈øhe gave 50 l. for Relief.

On Hawi≈øe was E≈øtated for Joynture, Bukby, Grante≈ø≈øet, Bradeham, and Herdwick, as appears by this Deed in the Couchir Book of the Dutchy-Office. Tom. 2. Honor ≈øiv√® Soca de Bolingbroke, num. 26. pag. 508.

SAherus de Quency Comes Wintoniae, omnibus Hominibus & Amicis ≈øuis, prae≈øentibus & futuris, ≈øalutem. Sciatis, me conce≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe & dedi≈ø≈øe & prae≈øenti Chart√¢ me√¢ confirm√¢≈ø≈øe Roberto de Quency Filio meo & Haeredi ad dandum in liberum Donarium Hawi≈øiae Sorori Comitis Ce≈øtriae, Uxori eju≈ødem Roberti, Bucehebeiam, & Grante≈ø≈øet, & Bradeham, & Herdewich, c√πm omnibus earundem terrarum pertinentiis, pro centum Libratis terrae: Et ≈øi hae praedictae terrae non valeant per Annum centum Libras, Ego in aliis terris meis de propri√¢ Haereditate me√¢ in Anglia, ei tantum perficiam, qu√≤d plenari√® habeat centum Libratas terrae per vi≈øum & con≈øiderationem legalium Militum hominum, videlicet, Comitis Ce≈øtriae & meorum. Et praetere√† Dedi eidem Roberto Feoda duorum Militum, ≈øcilicet Feedum Matthei Turpin in Winter≈ølawa in Wilte≈øhire, pro ≈øervitio Feodi unius Militis, ad dandum ≈øimul c√πm terris nominatis praedictae Hawi≈øiae Uxori ≈øuae in liberum donarium. Testibus his, Comite Davide, Willielmo Comite de Ferrars, Philippo de Orreby, Roberto de Ba≈øingham, Ricardo de Linde≈øeia, Willielmo de Grumpington, Henrico de Braibroc, Willielmo de Syelford, David Giffard, Willielmo Picot, Hugone & Thoma & Henrico Di≈øpen≈øariis, Waltero de Coventrey, Waltero Daivilla, & multis aliis.

This Hawi≈øe had the County of Lincoln To wit, all the Lands of Earl Randle in Lincoln≈øhire. given unto her by her Brother Randle, a little before his death, about 16 Hen. 3. 1232. in the≈øe words: which Deed is tran≈øcribed in one of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, Tom. 2. Honor ≈øive Soca de Bolingbroke, pag. 500. num. 11. It is al≈øo tran≈øcribed by Vincent, in his Corrections upon Brooke, pag. 317. which he affirmeth he took from the Original it ≈øelf in Cotton's Library, thus:‚Äî

RANULFUS Comes Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae, omnibus prae≈øentibus & futuris, prae≈øentem Chartam in≈øpecturis vel audituris, Salutem in Domino. Ad univer≈øitatis vestrae notitiam volo pervenire, me dedi≈ø≈øe, conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe, & h√¢c prae≈øenti Chart√¢ me√¢ confirm√¢≈ø≈øe, Dominae Hawi≈øiae de Quency Sorori meae Chari≈ø≈øimae Comitatum Lincolniae, ≈øcilicet quantum ad me pertinuit, ut ind√® Comiti≈ø≈øa existat. Habendum & tenendum de Domino meo Rege Angliae, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, liber√®, quiet√®, plen√®, pacific√®, & integr√® jure Haereditario, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis, & c√πm omnibus libertatibus ad praedictum Comitatum pertinentibus. Et ut prae≈øens ≈øcriptum Perpetuitatis robur obtineat, illud Sigilli mei appo≈øitione roborare dignum duxi. Hiis Testibus, Venerabilibus Patribus P. Wintoniae, & Alexandro Coventriae & Lichfeldiae Epi≈øcopis, R. Mare≈øcallo Comite Pembroke, Willielmo de Ferrars Comite Derbiae, Stephano de Segrave Justiciario Angliae, Simone de Monteforti, Willielmo de Ferrariis, Philippo de Abiniaco, Henrico de Aldith, Willielmo de Cantilupo, & aliis.

Hawi≈øe transfers the Earldom of Lincoln to John Lacy, and the Heirs of his Body which he ≈øhall beget on Margaret his Wife, Daughter of the ≈øame Hawi≈øe. 1 Patent, Anno 17 Hen. 3. memb. 9. num. 35. It is al≈øo in the Regi≈øter of the Dutchy of Lancaster. Honor ≈øive Soca de Bolingbroke, pag. 500. num. 10.

HENRICUS Dei Grati√¢ Rex Angliae, Dominus Hiberniae, Dux Normanniae & Aquitaniae, Comes Andegaviae, Omnibus ad quos prae≈øentes Literae pervenerint, Salutem.
