Sciatis, qu√≤d ad Instantiam Hawi≈øiae de Quency dedimus, & conce≈ø≈øimus dilecto & fideli nostro Johanni de Lacy Constabulario Ce≈øtriae, illas viginti Libras, quas Ranulphus quond√†m Comes Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae recepit pro tertio Denario Comitatus Lincolniae, nomine Comitis Lincolniae; & quas praedictus Comes in vit√¢ ≈øu√¢ dedit praedictae Hawi≈øiae Sorori ≈øuae: Habendas & tenendas, nomine Comitis Lincolniae, de nobis & Haeredibus nostris, ip≈øi Johanni, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, qui exibunt de Margareta Uxore ≈øu√¢, Fili√¢ praedictae Hawi≈øiae, in perpetuum. Et in hujus rei Testimonium has Literas nostras Patentes ei fieri fecimus. Teste meip≈øo apud Northampton, 23 die Novembris, Anno Regni nostri 17.

div.head: IV. The ba≈øe I≈ø≈øue of Hugh Cyveliok.
div.p: PAganus, Dominus de Milton, whom I have ≈øeen Witne≈øs to a Deed, Sub≈øcribed thus,‚ÄîFilius Ba≈øtardus Hugonis Comitis Ce≈øtriae.
Roger, Witne≈øs to a Deed of his Brother Randles, to the Abbey of St. Werburge, whom I conceive was a Ba≈øtard.

Amicia, the Wife of Raufe Manwaring, ≈øometime Judge of Che≈øter; to whom Hugh Cyveliok Earl of Che≈øter, her Father, gave in libero maritagio ≈øervitium Willielmi Filii Rogeri: ≈øcilic√®t ≈øervitium trium militum; faciendo ≈øibi ≈øervitium duorum militum, as the words of the original Deed do run, now in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Thomas Manwaring of Over Pever, Baronet.

Al≈øo another ba≈øe Daughter, as I conceive, Married one Bacun, and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Bacun, Founder of the Priory of Rouce≈øter in Stafford≈øhire, about the Reign of King John, for the ≈øafety of his Soul, and the Soul of his Uncle, Randle Earl of Che≈øter. Mona≈øticon, Part 2. pag. 267.

And here I cannot but mi≈ølike the boldne≈øs and ignorance of that Herald, who gave to Manwaring of Pever the Quartering of the Earl of Che≈øter's Coat of Arms: which Device was never done before the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, in the time of Sir Randle Manwaring, late of Pever, the elder, my Grandfather by the Mother: for if he ought of right to Quarter that Coat, then mu≈øt he be De≈øcended from a Coheir to the Earl of Che≈øter; but that he was not: for the Coheirs of Earl Hugh, as you ≈øee before, were Married to four of the greate≈øt Peers of the Kingdom, the Earl of Huntington, the Earl of Arundel, the Earl of Derby, and the Earl of Winche≈øter's Son and Heir, who lived not to be Earl: Neither was Manwaring then an equal Competitor, to have Married a Coheir to the Earl of Che≈øter. And it is plain, ex placitis 18 Hen. 3. Rot. 14. in the Tower of London, where the Coheirs Implead John the Scot, Earl of Che≈øter, for their part, there is no mention of Amice claiming any part, or any from or under her, in the Record. Be≈øides, all ancient Authors of tho≈øe Times, as Polychronicon, Matthew Paris, Knighton, Stowe, and others, would not have omitted her among the re≈øt which they have ≈øet down, had ≈øhe been a Coheir; which al≈øo ≈øhe mu≈øt needs have been, had ≈øhe been legitimate: for Hugh Cyvelioc never had any other Wife but Bertred, and ≈øhe ≈øurvived him.

And though Amice in the Deed before mentioned is ≈øtiled‚ÄîFilia Hugonis Comitis, without the addition or note of Ba≈øtard, it was very u≈øual in tho≈øe elder Ages ≈øo to do. The like we find of Geva, ba≈øe Daughter of Hugh Lupus, and ≈øeveral others.

V. Concerning this Bertred, the Wife of Hugh Cyveliok, I cannot omit the Fal≈øities and Ab≈øurdities of ≈øome Authors, as Powel on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 295. and Ferne in his Lacy's Nobility, pag. 53. both of them calling this Bertred by the Name of Beatrix, and ≈øaying ≈øhe was the Daughter of Richard Lucy, Chief Ju≈øtice of England; a mo≈øt gro≈øs Fal≈øity. I am very certain that Hugh Cyvelioc's Wife was not Daughter of Lucy, nor ever called Beatrix in any old Deed or Record; though I find by good Authority that there was a Woman called Beatrix Lucy, but never Wife of Earl Hugh.

div.head: The Death of Hugh Cyveliok.
div.p: Obiit 1181 THis Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, died at Leeke in Stafford≈øhire, and was buried at Che≈øter, Anno Domini 1181. 27 Hen. 2. Hoveden, pag. 615. with whom We≈øtmin≈øter, Polychronicon, and Cambden inter Comites Ce≈øtriae, do all agree.

He was Earl of Che≈øter 28 Years, and gave the Church of Bettesford to the Prior and Canons of Trentham after the Death of William Barba, who at the time of this Grant po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the ≈øame; a Copy of which Deed I received from Sir Simon Dewes, Baronet.

Now becau≈øe I find that ≈øome are di≈øplea≈øed at my placing of Amice, ≈øometime the Wife of Raufe Manwaring, Iudge of Che≈øter, among the ba≈øe I≈ø≈øue of Hugh Cyveliok Earl of Che≈øter, and al≈øo that I am informed, that three eminent Judges and four Heralds are of opinion that ≈øhe was legitimate, and not a ba≈øe Daughter of Earl Hugh, it is very nece≈ø≈øary that I put down here my Rea≈øons why I have ≈øo placed her, prote≈øting withal, that I have not done it out of any prejudicate Opinion or Calumny intended in the lea≈øt, but onely for the Truths ≈øake, according to the be≈øt of my Judgment, and that after a long and diligent ≈øcrutiny made herein: for I mu≈øt ever acknowledge my ≈øelf to be Extracted out of the Loyns of this Amice by my own Mother; but you know the old Saying of Ari≈øtotle, Amicus Plato, Amicus Socrates, ≈øed magis amica veritas. Neither were Ba≈øtards in tho≈øe elder Ages of ≈øuch Di≈ørepute as now in our Days: Memini me alicubi legi≈ø≈øe (≈øaith Spelman in his Glo≈ø≈øary on the word Ba≈øtardus) Pri≈øcos Septentrionales Populos etiam Spurios admi≈øi≈ø≈øe in ≈øucce≈ø≈øionem: And where he farther tells us, That King William the Conqueror began his Letter to Alan Earl of Little Britain, as he did many other more, in the≈øe words,‚ÄîEgo Willielmus cognomento Ba≈øtardus: of which Title it ≈øeems he was not a≈øhamed, otherwi≈øe he would never have u≈øed it him≈øelf.

And therefore the Que≈øtion being no more than this, Whether Amice was a ba≈øe Daughter, or no? I will fir≈øt an≈øwer tho≈øe Rea≈øons which ≈øeem to be the chief ground of tho≈øe worthy Per≈øons above≈øaid, who think Amice was no Ba≈øtard, and then in order ≈øet down my own Rea≈øons why I conceive her to be a Ba≈øtard, ≈øubmitting my ≈øelf wholly to the Judgment of all Learned Per≈øons herein.

div.head: The Rea≈øons that ≈øhe was no Ba≈øtard.
div.p: I. OUr Common Law alloweth not, that any Lands can pa≈øs in libero maritagio with a Ba≈øtard Daughter, Coke upon Littleton, Fol. 21. b. and therefore Amice having Land given with her, in libero maritagio, by the Deed, it mu≈øt be pre≈øumed that ≈øhe was no Ba≈øtard.

An≈øw. To which I an≈øwer, That it is true, the Law is ≈øo taken at this day with us, but that the Law was ≈øo taken in the elder Ages of Henry the Second, when Hugh Cyveliok lived, and upwards, I very much doubt: And if we mark well this Grant, it is the Grant of Earl Hugh to Rafe Manwaring, with Amice his Daughter, in Frank-Marriage of the Service of Gilbert Son of Roger, to wit, the Service of three Knights Fees, by doing the Service of two Knights Fees to the ≈øaid Earl and his Heirs; which is rather a Relea≈øe of the Service of one Knights Fee, than the Grant of any Land. But to pa≈øs by this.‚ÄîI ≈øay that the Common Law in ≈øundry things is altered at this day from what it was in former Ages long after Henry II. Cook upon Littleton, fol. 34. Sect. 39. Cook, ibid. fol. 3. a. fol. 8. a. at the bottom of the Page, and on the other ≈øide (b) at the bottom, fol. 26. b. Sect. 29. and infinite other Particulars may be cited. And that in this Particular al≈øo of Pa≈ø≈øing Land in libero maritagio with Ba≈øtards, the Law ≈øeems clearly to be altered herein ≈øince the Reign of Henry the Second: for the common Practice I take to be the Common Law, and I ≈øhall give you here one Precedent, made about the Reign of King Stephen, (and doubtle≈øs many others might be mu≈øtered up from tho≈øe elder Ages, if any curious Per≈øon would take pains to ≈øearch old Deeds and Records) which Deed I received from Sir Simon Dewes, tran≈øcribed out of a Manu≈øcript in Arundel-Hou≈øe in London, belonging anciently to the Barons of Stafford, wherein the old Charts belonging to the Ba≈ø≈øets of Drayton-Ba≈ø≈øet in Stafford≈øhire were Enrolled about Richard the Second's time. Ibid. fol. 67. a.

p.hi:
Ranulfus Comes Ce≈øtriae Willielmo Con≈øtabulario, & Roberto Dapifero, & omnibus Baronibus ≈øuis, & Hominibus Francis & Anglicis totius Angliae, Salutem. Sciatis me dedi≈ø≈øe & conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe Gevae Ridell Filiae Comitis Hughes, Draitunam cum Pertinentiis in libero Conjugio,
Sicuti Comes Hughes et in libero conjugio dedit & conce≈ø≈øit: Et teneat bene & in pace, honorifice & libere, ut melius & liberius tenuit tempore Hugonis Comitis, & aliorum meorum Antece≈ø≈øorum, ei≈ødem con≈øuetudinibus & libertatibus. Te≈øtibus Gilberto Filio Ricardi, & Adeliz√¢ ≈øorore me√¢, & Willielmo Blundo, & Alexandro de Tre≈øgor, & Rogero de Bello Campo, & Willielmo de Sais, & Roberto de Sais, & Ricardo Filio Aluredi, & Hugone Filio Osberti, & Henrico de Chalder: Apud Saintonam.

div.p: Wherein Geva is called Daughter of Earl Hugh Lupus, as Amice in that other Deed is termed Daughter of Earl Hugh Cyveliok. Now that Geva was a Ba≈øtard, is very plain out of Ordericus, a Man that lived in that very Age: He tells us, lib. 10. pag. 787. ≈øpeaking of Hugh Lupus his Death‚ÄîRicardus pulcherrimus puer quem ≈øol√πm ex Ermentrude Filia Hugonis de Claro-monte genuit, &c. Richard, a brave Youth, whom onely Hugh Lupus begot on Ermentrude, Daughter of Hugh de Claremonte, &c. Nor can this be re≈øtrained to the onely Son, for then it mu≈øt have been otherwi≈øe expre≈ø≈øed: And if Hugh Lupus had any other Son or Daughter by Ermentrude, then cannot Richard be ≈øaid onely to be begotten on her by Earl Hugh; and ≈øo Geva was a Ba≈øtard, or el≈øe Ordericus lyes. Al≈øo the ≈øame Author tells us, lib. 4. pag. 522. that Hugh Lupus had al≈øo many ba≈øe Sons and Daughters by ≈øeveral Strumpets, who were almo≈øt all ≈øwept away by ≈øundry Misfortunes; and very probably, if Hugh Lupus had any more legitimate Children by his Wife be≈øides Earl Richard, either Son or Daughter, Ordericus would have Recorded them as well as he hath put down others in like nature, being indeed his u≈øual method through the whole cour≈øe of his Hi≈øtory: And had Geva been legitimate, then her I≈ø≈øue ought rather to have ≈øucceeded into the Earldom of Che≈øter, than Randle de Me≈øchines, after the Death of Richard Earl of Che≈øter, fora≈ømuch as the Si≈øter and her Heirs ought to Inherit before the Aunt and her Heirs: And howbeit many Earldoms have De≈øcended to the Heirs Males, and not to the Heirs general; yet in this Ca≈øe were no Heirs Male, but two Females, an Aunt legitimate, who had it, and a Si≈øter not legitimate: And ≈øhew me a Precedent whereever the Heirs of an Aunt Inherited before the Heirs of a Si≈øter, both legally born, and no Heirs Male left, unle≈øs in ca≈øe of Forfeiture by Trea≈øon, or ≈øome other great Cau≈øe to hinder the ≈øame.

Secondly, add to the≈øe the words of Glanvill, Chief Ju≈øtice of England, who lived under Hen. II. in that very Age with Amice, lib. 7. cap. 1. Quilibet liber Homo quandam partem terrae ≈øuae cum Fili√¢ ≈øu√¢, vel cum aliqu√¢ ali√¢ qu√¢libet muliere, dare pote≈øt in maritagium, ≈øive habuerit haeredem ≈øive non, velit haeres vel non, imo & eo contradicente: And if a Man might give Land then in Free Marriage with any Woman what≈øoever, then he might give it to his Ba≈øtard; and then the Law is now changed: for now it mu≈øt be of the Donors Blood; and a Ba≈øtard is now ≈øaid not to be of the Donors Blood qua≈øi nullius filius. And it ≈øeems to me, that in tho≈øe elder Ages Ba≈øtards were reputed of the Blood, by the frequent Appellation of them by the Names of Uncle, Brother, Daughter, Son, and Co≈øin. Be≈øides, our Laws were then imperfect, dark, and ob≈øcure in mo≈øt things, till Bracton under King Henry the Third compiled the Body of our Laws, and brought them into a Method.

And now I have done concerning this chief Rea≈øon, whereupon tho≈øe worthy Judges grounded their Opinions; and we daily ≈øee Opinions of Lawyers follow the putting of the Ca≈øe, which many times upon mature deliberation, and hearing of the Ca≈øe well argued; may then be of another Opinion.
Now follow the Arguments of le≈ø≈øer moment, which I per≈øwade my ≈øelf were no Grounds for the Judges afore≈øaid.

II The di≈øparity of the Years between Hugh Cyveliok and Bertred his Wife, may ≈øuppo≈øe he had a former Wife; for Bertred was but 26 Years old at the Death of Earl Hugh 1181, as appears by the Inqui≈øition taken 30 Hen. 2. 1183. after the Death of Hugh Cyveliok, and Hugh was Earl of Che≈øter 28 Years, which was one or two Years before Bertred was horn, be≈øides what Years were run up of his Age before his Father Randle died, which may be
≈øuppo≈øed to be a competent term of Years; and then it is probable he had a former Wife, and that he ≈øtayed not unmarried ≈øo long as till Bertred was fit for Marriage.

An≈øw. Now let us examine the Matter a little, it will give us ≈øome light: Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter Married Mabill, Daughter and Heir of Robert Fitz-Haimon, Anno Domini 1110. So Stowe in his Chronicle. See al≈øo Seldin's Tit. Hon. pag. 647. By her he had I≈ø≈øue four Sons and two Daughters. Maude the younger Daughter Married Randle de Gernoniis Earl of Che≈øter, Father to Hugh Cyveliok. Vincent upon Brook, pag. 216. Now ≈øuppo≈øe we Maude to be the fourth Child: probably ≈øhe was not born till about the Year 1117. or thereabout, and that about the Year 1139. ≈øhe was Married to Earl Randle, whereby Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter ≈øtrengthned his Party for Maude the Empre≈øs. At that time ≈øhe cannot well be ≈øuppo≈øed to be above 22 Years old, if ≈øhe were ≈øo much. Now Earl Randle died 1153. So that Hugh Cyveliok could not po≈ø≈øibly be above twelve Years old at his Father's Death; he might be much le≈øs: but ≈øuppo≈øe we in a middle way, that he was ≈øix Years old at his Father's Death, which is more than can be well affirmed, then could not Earl Hugh be above ≈øeven or eight Years older than Bertred his Wife: and what great matter is this? I my ≈øelf was eight years older than my Wife when I was Married; but it is much more probable that he never had any other Wife, becau≈øe he had many Ba≈øtard Sons and Daughters, who≈øe heat of Youth might by a very timely Marriage have been po≈ø≈øibly prevented, or at lea≈øt a≈ø≈øwaged in ≈øome mea≈øure.

III. Bertred, the Wife of Hugh Cyveliok was a Witne≈øs to the Deed in Frank-Marriage with Amice; and Amice had a Daughter called Bertred, after the Name of the Counte≈øs, ergo probably Amice was no Ba≈øtard.
An≈øw. Truly this is of ≈øo little weight, that it will need no An≈øwer; for I yet apprehend no Rea≈øon in it.

IV. Roger Manwaring, Son of Raufe Manwaring, calls Randle Blundevill Earl of Che≈øter and Lincoln, his Uncle in another Deed; wherefore it is to be ≈øuppo≈øed that Amice was no Ba≈øtard, otherwi≈øe Roger dur≈øt not have pre≈øumed to have called the Earl Uncle.

An≈øw. Hi≈øtories, Deeds, and Records, are full of Examples in this nature, where we find Ba≈øtards frequently called Co≈øin, Brother, Uncle, Son, and Daughter: for example, Robert Earl of Gloce≈øter, ba≈øe Son of King Henry the Fir≈øt, is frequently called in Hi≈øtories, Brother to Maude the Empre≈øs. Hoveden, pag. 553. He is al≈øo ≈øo ≈øtiled in a Deed made by Maude Empre≈øs her ≈øelf. Selden's Tit. Hon. pag. 649. called al≈øo Co≈øin to King Stephen. Ordericus, pag. 922. Reginald Earl of Cornwall, another ba≈øe Son of Henry the Fir≈øt, ≈øtiled Avunculus Regis Henrici Secundi by Hoveden, pag. 536. Robert and Ottiwell, two Ba≈øtard Sons of Hugh Lupus, frequently called Filii Hugonis Comitis Ce≈øtriae; and Ottiwell ≈øtiled Frater Ricardi Comitis Ce≈øtriae. Ordericus, pag. 602 & 783. & 870. Geva, a ba≈øe Daughter of Hugh Lupus, ≈øtiled in old Deeds Filia Hugonis Comitis; and there al≈øo ≈øhe calls Earl Randle her Co≈øin. Mona≈øticon, par. 1. pag. 439. Al≈øo Richard Bacon, Son of another ba≈øe Daughter of Hugh Cyveliok, calls Randle Blundevill Earl of Che≈øter his Uncle in another Deed, as Manwaring in like manner here ≈øtiles him in this Deed. Mona≈øticon, par. 2. pag. 267. Every Man that is but the lea≈øt ver≈øed in Antiquities, knows the≈øe things to be very u≈øual.

div.head: The Rea≈øons that Amice was a Ba≈øtard.
div.p: I. IF Hugh Cyveliok had no other Wife but Bertred, then Amice mu≈øt certainly be a Ba≈øtard; for ≈øhe was not a Daughter by Bertred, as is granted on all ≈øides.
But Hugh Cyveliok never had any other Wife but Bertred; Ergo Amice was a Ba≈øtard.

Now the Minor is to be proved by the Affirmer, Oportet affirmantem probare: for as yet I never ≈øaw the lea≈øt proof thereof, either by Deed, Record, or any ancient Hi≈øtorian, nor yet any inducement of good Rea≈øon to incline my belief of it: And till this be done, it is unrea≈øonable to impo≈øe it upon any Man's Belief, by ≈øuppo≈øing that he had another Wife: for Suppo≈øitions are no proof at all. It is not enough to ≈øuppo≈øe Amice might be by a former Wife, but it mu≈øt be clearly proved, or ≈øtrongly inferred from ≈øolid Rea≈øon, that it is ≈øo, and that Hugh had a former Wife.

Neither is it a ≈øufficient An≈øwer hereunto to ≈øay, That it is unrea≈øonable to conclude all Children Ba≈øtards, who≈øe Mothers cannot be proved; God forbid. But in this Ca≈øe we find a Wife certainly Recorded, and a Son and four Daughters (who were afterwards Coheirs, and carried away all Earl Hugh's Lands) clearly proved by Records and ancient Hi≈øtorians. And al≈øo Earl Hugh is certainly known to have had many Ba≈øtards, both Sons and Daughters; which gives occa≈øion of ≈øtrong ≈øu≈øpicion, that Amice was a Ba≈øtard, ≈øhe being neither Recorded by any Hi≈øtorian, nor ever had or claimed any Land as a Coheir; and therefore here is a nece≈ø≈øity of proving a former Wife, which for my part I believe firmly Earl Hugh never had.

II. What≈øoever is given in Frank-Marriage, is given as a Portion: now the Relea≈øe of the Service of one Knights Fee in Frank-Marriage, ≈øeems not a competent Portion for a legitimate Daughter of the Earl of Che≈øter, e≈øpecially for the elde≈øt Daughter: for ≈øo ≈øhe mu≈øt be, being of the fir≈øt Venter, which always is more worthy than the ≈øecond, if ≈øhe were at all legitimate; and we find the other Daughters Married to four of the greate≈øt Earls in England: all which is a ≈øtrong pre≈øumption that Amice was a Ba≈øtard, and no legitimate Daughter.

To this it may be an≈øwered, That po≈ø≈øibly Earl Hugh might give Amice a great Portion in Money, though ≈øhe had no Lands. And I ≈øay po≈ø≈øibly too, he might give her no Money, or at lea≈øt nothing con≈øiderable; which great Portion in Money, when it ≈øhall appear to be true, may take off the ≈øtrength of this Argument or ≈øecond Rea≈øon, till then it mu≈øt be very pre≈ø≈øing.

III. The ancient Hi≈øtorians of our Nation, as Polychronicon, writ by the Monk of Che≈øter, Henry Knighton, the Monk of Leyce≈øter, and others; al≈øo Stowe and Cambden have Recorded the lawful Daughters and Coheirs of Earl Hugh, and ≈øo the Record of 18 Hen. 3. And had Amice been a legitimate Daughter, it is likely that the≈øe Hi≈øtorians would not all have omitted her; but of her there is Altum ≈øilentium among all the Hi≈øtorians and Records which I have yet ≈øeen; though indeed I look upon this onely as a probable, not as a ≈øure evincing Argument.

The≈øe were the Rea≈øons which inclined my Opinion to place Amice in that Order as I have done: But ≈øince there are ≈øome Learned Men of another Opinion, I mu≈øt leave every Per≈øon to the dictate of his own Rea≈øon.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Of Randle the Third, ≈øirnamed Blundevill.

div.p: King Henry the ≈øecond Knighted him, and gave him to Wife Con≈øtance, the Widow of Geffrey his fourth Son, Daughter and Heir of Conan Duke of Little Britain, and Earl of Richmond, Anno 1188. 34 Hen. 2. Polychronicon, lib. 7. cap. 24. But Hoveden placeth it Anno 1187. 33 Hen. 2. for Geffrey died 1186. and left Con≈øtance great with Child, who bore Arthur a Son eodem Anno. Hoveden.
This Randle confirms to the Abbey of St. Werburge, all the Grants of his Predece≈ø≈øors, in the≈øe words:

q.p: RAnulfus Comes Ce≈øtriae, Con≈øtabulario, Dapifero, Ju≈øtitiario, Baronibus, Mini≈øtris & Ballivis, & omnibus Hominibus ≈øuis, Francis & Anglis, Clericis & Laicis, t√†m prae≈øentibus qu√†m futuris, Salutem. Sciatis me conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe‚ÄîOmnes donationes & libertates, quas Comites Antece≈ø≈øores mei, ≈øcilic√®t Hugo Comes & Ricardus Filius ejus; & Ranulfus Comes, & alius Ranulfus Avus meus, & Hugo Pater meus, & Barones tempore illorum, vel in meo, eidem Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Werburgae dederunt, &c. Te≈øtibus Bertrey√¢ Comiti≈ø≈ø√¢ Matre me√¢, Radulfo de Me≈ønilwaringe, Hugone de Bo≈øco-ale, Radulfo Filio Simonis, Rogero Fratre Comitis, Rogero Con≈øtabulario, Gaufrido de Buxeri√¢, Stephano de longo Campo, Alano de Bo≈øco-Ale, Bertramo Camerario, Alexandro Filio Radulfi, Johanne Clerico, Bech Di≈øpen≈øatore, Petro Clerico, & aliis multis: Apud Ce≈øtriam in Capitulo Monachorum in Anniver≈øario die Hugonis Comitis Patris mei.

div.p: II. I will begin fir≈øt with the Acts of this Randle, then with his Titles, then with his Wives.

For his Acts. Anno 1194. 5 Rich. 1. Earl David, Brother of the King of Scotland, Randle Earl of Che≈øter, and the Earl Ferrars; with a great Army Be≈øieged Nottingham Ca≈øtle, which John the King's Brother had cau≈øed to be Garri≈øon'd again≈øt the King in his ab≈øence, whiles he was detained Pri≈øoner by the Roman Emperor. Hoveden, pag. 735. but the Ca≈øtle was not taken till the King came in Per≈øon to A≈ø≈øault it.

Anno 1216. after the Death of King John, on the Fea≈øt-day of Simon and Jude the Apo≈øtles, the twenty eighth day of October, Henry the Third, being then but nine Years old, elde≈øt Son of King John, was Crowned at Gloce≈øter, principally by the Power of Walo the Pope's Legat, Peter Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, Randle Earl of Che≈øter, and William Mar≈øhall Earl of Pembroke, and ≈øome others. Paris and Polychronicon.

Anno Domini 1217. after Ea≈øter, Randle Earl of Che≈øter, with many others, met about the be≈øieging of the Ca≈øtle of Mount≈øorell, by the procurement of William Mar≈øhall Regent of England for the young King, which they fiercely a≈ø≈øaulted. But Lewis King of France, and the Barons of England, ≈øent Forces from London in the very beginning of May, to rai≈øe the Siege. Randle Earl of Che≈øter hearing thereof, with others, came to
Nottingham: The Barons march on and Be≈øiege Lincoln Ca≈øtle. In the interim William Mar≈øhall, Guardian of the young King and Kingdom, Commanded all the Forces out of his ≈øeveral Garri≈øons, to meet at Newark on Tue≈øday in Whit≈øun-week, for the rai≈øing of the Siege at Lincoln; among whom Randle Earl of Che≈øter was the Prime Commander: and in the beginning of the Week following they routed the Barons at Lincoln. Mat. Paris, pag. 294, 295. And the Monk of Che≈øter in his Polychronicon ≈øaith, That Randle Earl of Che≈øter ≈ølew many of the French; ≈øo that Lewis the French King ≈øeeing his Party much weakned, for a Sum of Money ≈øurrenders up all his Garri≈øons, and returns to France.
Anno 1158. the Abbey of Pulton in Che≈øhire was Founded.
Anno 1214. that Convent was removed to Deulacre≈ø≈øe in Stafford≈øhire, 10 Calendas Maii, by this Earl Randis. Mona≈øticon, vol. 1. pag. 891.

Anno 1218. 2 Hen. 3. Randle Earl of Che≈øter, after he was accorded with Lhewellin Prince of Northwales, took a Voyage to Jeru≈øalem. In which Year Damieta was taken by the Chri≈øtians. Mat Paris, pag. 303.

Anno 1220. 4 Hen. 3. Randle returning out of the Holy Land, built Bee≈øton Ca≈øtle in Che≈øhire, and Chartley Ca≈øtle in Stafford≈øhire, and the Abbey of Delacre≈ø≈øe near Leeke in Stafford≈øhire, of the Order of white Monks De ordine Ci≈øtercien≈øi. To which Abbey he gave Leeke and Rudeyard in Stafford≈øhire. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 891, 892. Bivelegh, vulgo Byley, near to Middlewich in Che≈øhire, was a Grange belonging to the Monks of Delacre≈ø≈øe. Mona≈øticon, Vol. 2. pag. 919.. Towards the Charge of the Ca≈øtles he Levied a Tax through all his Lands and Tenants. Polychronicon. Al≈øo Knighton, pag. 24. 30.
Nor can I here pa≈øs by the Mi≈øtake of Bale de Scriptoribus Britanniae, Cent. 3. num. 93. where he writes thus:‚Äî

q.p: Ranulfus de Glaunvyle Ce≈øtriae Comes, vir nobili≈ø≈øimi Generis & in utroque jure eruditus, in Albo illu≈øtrium virorum √† me merit√≤ ponendus venit, it√† prob√® omnes adole≈øcentiae ≈øuae annos, Legibus t√πm humanis t√πm divinis con≈øecravit: ut non pri√πs in hominem per aetatem eva≈øerit, qu√†m nomen decu≈øque ab in≈øigni eruditione ≈øibi comparaverit: C√πm Profecti e≈ø≈øent Francorum heroes Ptolemaidem, inito c√πm Johanne Brenno Hiero≈øolymorum Rege concilio, Damiatam Egypti urbem ob≈øidendam con≈øtituebant; Anno Salutis humanae 1218. mi≈øit ill√πc Henricus Rex, ab Honorio tertio Romanorum Pontifice Rogatus, c√πm magn√¢ Armatorum manu Ranulfum ad rem Chri≈øtianam juvandam: Cujus virtus, Polydoro te≈øte, in eo bello miris omnium laudibus celebrata fuit: Quo confecto negotio, Ranulfus in patriam rever≈øus ≈øcrip≈øit unum librum de Legibus Angliae: Fertur praetere√† & alia quaedam ≈øcrip≈øi≈ø≈øe: ≈øed tempus Edax rerum ea nobis ab≈øtulit. Anno 1230. claruit, confectus Senio dum Henricus tertius ≈øub Antichri≈øti Tyrannide in Angli√¢ regnaret. So Bale; and from him Pit≈øeus thus:‚Äî

div.p: Ranulfus Glanvillus ex Splendi≈ø≈øim√¢ famili√¢ Ce≈øtriae Comitum in Angli√¢ natus, &c. in his Book De illu≈øtribus Angliae Scriptoribus.

The≈øe are both mi≈øtaken in the Name, confounding Randle Blundevill and Randle Glaunvill together. Randle Glaunvill indeed was Chief Ju≈øtice of England under Henry II. and writ a Book De Legibus Angliae, yet extant among≈øt us. He died at the Siege of Accon, Anno Chri≈øti 1190. Hoveden, pag. 685. But this Randle Blundevill Earl of Che≈øter is of later time a little, and died Anno Chri≈øti 1232. This Earl was at the Siege of Damiata, but writ no Book De Legibus: Glaunvill writ the Book, but was neither Earl of Che≈øter, nor of the Race of the Earls of Che≈øter. So much of Bale. See Spelman's Glo≈ø≈øary, pag. 338. b.

Anno 1224. Randle Earl of Che≈øter, John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and others of the Nobility were much di≈øplea≈øed with Hubert de Burgo, Chief Ju≈øtice of England, alledging, that he did exa≈øperate the King again≈øt them, and did not well Execute the Laws; in≈øomuch that the Earl of Che≈øter with his Complices at Leyce≈øter, in ≈øtead of ≈øurrendring up the Ca≈øtles which the King demanded from him, as belonging to the Crown, had thought to have ≈øent threatning Me≈ø≈øages both again≈øt the King and his Chief Ju≈øtice; but upon more deliberate Advice ≈øurrendred them. Paris, pag. 318, 319, & 320.

Anno 1229. the King having gathered a great Army together at Port≈ømouth, thought to Tran≈øport them beyond Sea, to recover tho≈øe Lands which his Father had lo≈øt; but not finding ≈øufficient Shipping for half his Army, he imputed the fault to the Treachery of Hubert de Burgo, that he ≈øhould have been Bribed thereunto by the Queen of France; and drawing his Sword to have killed Hubert, Randle Earl of Che≈øter interpo≈øed and ≈øaved him, that he got out of the King's ≈øight till his fury was pa≈øt. Paris, pag. 363. And in the ≈øame Year Randle Earl of Che≈øter refu≈øeth to pay Tythes to the Pope. Paris ibidem.

Anno 1230. Randle Earl of Chester marched through Anjou, and took certain Ca≈øtles, and ≈øo returned into Little Britain, where the King had made him Commander in Chief of his Forces, together with William Mar≈øhall and William Albemarle. Paris, pag. 367.

Anno 1232. in the Parliament a≈ø≈øembled at London, the King demanded Money for the Di≈øcharge of his Debts occa≈øioned by the Wars. The Earl of Che≈øter an≈øwering for the Nobility of the Kingdom, told him, That the Earls, Barons, and Knights, which hold of him in Capite, were per≈øonally with him in the Service, and had exhau≈øted their own Money in that Service, and therefore ought not to pay any thing, and ≈øo nothing was Granted. Paris, pag. 372.

In this Year Randle Earl of Che≈øter did a ≈øecond time ≈øave the Life of Hubert de Burgo, when the King being exa≈øperated with Hubert, ≈øent to the Mayor of London to ≈øend away all the Armed he could rai≈øe, immediately to put him to Death; who in one Nights ≈øpace were encrea≈øed to 20000. willing of the occa≈øion: But the King by the per≈øwa≈øion of Randle Earl of Che≈øter, telling how dangerous it might be to rai≈øe ≈øuch a ≈øeditious Tumult, which perhaps could not be allayed when he would, and be≈øides the rumor of the World for ≈øuch a Fact would be much to his prejudice, Me≈ø≈øengers were ≈øent to ≈øtop the fury of the People; and ≈øo he e≈øcaped.

This Randle among the many Conflicts he had with the Wel≈øh, ‚öú as I find in an ancient Parchment Roll, written above two hundred Years ago, wherein the Barons of Halton with their I≈ø≈øue were carefully collected, was di≈øtre≈ø≈øed by the Wel≈øh, Lib. C. Fol. 85. b. and forced to retreat to the Ca≈øtle of Rothelent in Flint≈øhire, about the Reign of King John, where they Be≈øieged him: He pre≈øently ≈øent to his Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Roger Lacy, ≈øirnamed Hell, for his fierce Spirit, that he would come with all ≈øpeed, and bring what Forces he could towards his Relief. Roger having gathered a tumultuous Rout of Fidlers, Players, Coblers, debauched per≈øons, both Men and Women, out of the City of Che≈øter (for 'twas then the Fair-time in that City,) marcheth immediately towards the Earl. The Wel≈øh perceiving a great multitude coming, rai≈øed their Siege and fled. The Earl coming back with his Con≈øtable to Che≈øter, gave him Power over all the Fidlers and Shoemakers in Che≈øter, in reward and memory of this Service. The Con≈øtable retained to him≈øelf and his Heirs, the Authority and Donation of the Shoemakers, but conferred the Authority of the Fidlers and Players on his Steward, which then was Dutton of Dutton; who≈øe Heirs enjoy the ≈øame Power and Authority over the Min≈øtralcy of Che≈øhire even to this day; who in memory hereof keep a yearly Court upon the Fea≈øt of St. John Bapti≈øt at Che≈øter, where all the Min≈øtrels of the County and City are to attend and Play before the Lord of Dutton: And none ought to u≈øe their Min≈øtralcy but by Order and Licence of that Court, under the Hand and Seal of the Lord Dutton or his Steward, either within Che≈øhire or the City of Che≈øter. And to this day the Heirs of Dutton, or their Deputies, do in a ≈øolemn manner yearly upon Mid≈øummer-day, being Che≈øter Fair, Ride attended through the City of Che≈øter, with all the Min≈øtralcy of Che≈øhire playing before them on their ≈øeveral In≈øtruments, to the Church of St. Johns, and at the Court renew their Licences yearly.

I cannot here pa≈øs by the gro≈øs mi≈øtake of Powel on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 296. whom Cambden in his Britania ≈øeems to follow; where Raufe de Dutton is ≈øaid to have gathered this Army, and to have re≈øcued the Earl: whereupon he had the Power over the Min≈øtralcy granted immediately from the Earl.

For fir≈øt, there was never any ≈øuch an Heir of Dutton of Dutton, that was called Rafe de Dutton. But I ≈øhall, for more ≈øatisfaction, tran≈øcribe the Original Deed made to Dutton, remaining among the Evidences of that Family, which now by a Daughter and Heir is devolved to the Lord Gerard of Gerards Bromley in Stafford≈øhire.

q.p: Lib. C. fol 139. SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, qu√≤d ego Johannes Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae, dedi & conce≈ø≈øi, & h√¢c prae≈øenti Chart√¢ me√¢ confirmavi, Hugoni de Dutton, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, Magi≈øtratum omnium Leccatorum & Meretricum totius Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, ≈øic√πt liberi√πs illum Magistratum teneo de Comite; Salvo jure meo mihi & Heredibus meis. Hiis Testibus, Hugone de Boidele, Alano Fratre ejus, Petro de Goenet, Liulfo de Twamlow, Ada de Dutton, Gilberto de A≈øton, Radulfo de King≈øley, Hamone de Bordington, Alano de Waleie, Alano de Mulinton, Willielmo Filio Ricardi, Martino Angevin, Willielmo de Savill, Galfrido & Roberto Filiis meis BletherisIt is either thus, as I have put it; or, Galfrido & Roberto Filiis meis, Blethero Herberd de Waleton, &c. I leave it to the Reader to judge., Herdberd de Waleton, Galfrido de Dutton.

div.p: In which Deed it is, John Constable of Che≈øhire (not the Earl of Chester) grants to Hugh de Dutton (not to Raufe de Dutton) the Authority over all the Letchers and Whores of all Che≈øhire; Salvo jure meo. So as the Right was the Con≈øtables, which he held of the Earl; but now transfers it over to Hugh Dutton, about the end of King John's Reign. By the ancient Roll it ≈øhould ≈øeem Roger Lacy re≈øcued the Earl, and now John his Son transferrs this Power to Dutton: Which Original Grant mentioneth nothing of the Rule of Fidlers or Min≈øtrels; but ancient Cu≈øtom hath now brought it onely to the Min≈øtrel≈øie: For anciently I ≈øuppo≈øe the Ro ‚Ä¢ t which the Con≈øtable brought to the Re≈øcuing of the Earl, were debauched Per≈øons drinking with their Sweet-hearts in the Fair, Fidlers, and ≈øuch loo≈øe kind of Per≈øons as he could get; which tract of time hath reduced onely to the Min≈øtrels.

I find in the Records at Che≈øter, inter Placita 14 Hen. 7. a Quo Warranto brought again≈øt Laurence Dutton of Dutton; E≈øq why he claimed all the Min≈øtrels of Che≈øhire, and in the City of Che≈øter, to meet before him at Che≈øter yearly, at the Fea≈øt of Saint John Baptist, and to give unto him at the ≈øaid Fea≈øt quatuor Lagenas Vini, & unam Lanceam; that is, four Bottles of Wine, and a Lance: and al≈øo every Min≈øtrel to pay unto him at the ≈øaid Fea≈øt four Pence half-penny: And why he claimed from every Whore in Che≈øhire, and in the City of Che≈øter, Officium ≈øuum exercente, four Pence to be paid yearly at the Fea≈øt afore≈øaid, &c. Whereunto he pleaded Pre≈øcription.

And whereas by the Statute of 39 Eliz. cap. 4. Fidlers are declared to be Rogues; yet there is an e≈øpecial Provi≈øo in the Statute, for the exempting of tho≈øe in Che≈øhire, Licen≈øed by Dutton of Dutton, as belonging to his ancient Cu≈øtom and Privilege: So that the Fidlers of Che≈øhire, Licen≈øed by the Heirs of Dutton of Dutton, are no Rogues. But enough of this.

This Randle Earl of Che≈øter purcha≈øed all the Lands of Roger de Mere≈øey, which he had between the Rivers of Ribble and Mer≈øey in Lanca≈øhire, about the 15 Year of the Reign of Henry the Third, 1230. as appears by the Deeds following.

div.head: Couchir Book of the Dutchy-Office at Grays-Inn, London: Tom. 1. Comitatus Lanca≈øtriae, fol. 77. num. 70.
div.p:
Haec e≈øt Conventio facta inter Dominum Ranulfum Comitem Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae, & Rogerum de Mare≈øey: Videlic√®t, quod dicti Comes & Rogerus tradiderunt Domino Radulfo de Bray in aequali manu quadraginta Marcas Argenti, & Chartam quam dictus Rogerus fecit Domino Comiti de venditione & dimi≈ø≈øione omnium terrarum ≈øuarum, quas habuit vel habere potuit inter Ribble & Mer≈øey: It√† ≈øcilic√®t qu√≤d idem Rogerus ≈øin√® dilatione iturus e≈øt inter Ribbel & Mer≈øey ad deponendum ≈øe de dict√¢ terr√¢, & ad faciendum omnes illos (qui de ip≈øo ibidem tenuerunt) Homagia ≈øua facere dicto Domino Comiti, vel fidelitatem ejus Ballivis loco ≈øuo Con≈øtitutis: & eti√†m ad Sai≈øinam de Boulton c√πm omnibus
pertinentiis dicto Comiti faciendam: Quo facto dictus Radulfus de Bray ≈øaepe-dicto Comiti Chartam j√†m dictam reddet, & eidem Rogero dictas quadraginta Marcas: Et ≈øi contingat, qu√≤d Tenentes de dictis Tenuris ad hoc, quod praedictum e≈øt, Domino Comiti faciendum per ip≈øum Rogerum ade≈ø≈øe noluerint, ≈øaep√®-dictus Comes, vel Ballivi ≈øui, ip≈øos compellent ad hoc faciendum. Et dictus Rogerus ad ≈øumptus Domini Comitis itinerabit un√† c√πm Ballivis Comitis, quo√∫≈øque negotium istud, ≈øecund√πm quod praedictum e≈øt, fuerit Con≈øummatum. Et ad majorem hujus rei ≈øecuritatem ut√©rque illorum prae≈øenti ≈øcripto, more Cheirographi, Sigillum ≈øuum appo≈øuit. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Domino Waltero Abbate Ce≈øtriae, Domino Willielmo de Vernon Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Radulfo de Bray, Waltero Dayvill, Ricardo de Biron, Johanne de Lexington, Simone & Johanne Clericis.

div.head: Charta Rogeri de Mare≈øheia; ex eodem Libro. Comitatus Lanca≈øtriae, Num. 79.
div.p: OMnibus prae≈øentibus & futuris,‚ÄîRogerus Filius Ranulfi de Mare≈øheya, Salutem. Sciatis me vendidi≈ø≈øe & in perpetu√πm de me & Haeredibus meis dimi≈øi≈ø≈øe Domino Ranulpho Comiti Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae, Manerium de Boulton, cum omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis: ≈øcilic√®t quicquid habui,13. Hen. 3. the King granted a Confirmation to Randle Earl of Che≈øter, of all his Lands between the Rivers of Ribbell and Mer≈øey in Lanca≈øhire; to wit, the Town and Wapentake of We≈øt-Derby, the Burrough of Lever-pool, the Town and Wapentake of Salford, and al≈øo the Wapentake of Leland, with all Fore≈øts and Appurtenances. Clau≈ø. 13 Hen. 3. memb. 2. vel ad me vel ad Haeredes meos accidere potuit, in dicto Manerio de Bolton, & in Parva Bolton, in Tonge, in Halghe, in Brethmete, in Ratecliffe, in Orme≈øton, in Weffeleg, in Sharplis, in Haghe, in Fanedi≈øch, in Longeere, in Sevington, in Chernoc, & in Hedchernoc, in Dokesbury, in Adelvinton, in Whitall, in Hirelton, in Skaresbreck, in Heton juxt√† Lanca≈øter, in Melner, in Derwente, & in Eccle≈øhill, & in omnibus aliis locis ad dictas terras pertinentibus: in Homagiis, Feodis, Servitiis, Con≈øuetudinibus, Dominicis, Cu≈øtodiis, Releviis, Redditibus, E≈øcaetis, Advocationibus Eccle≈øiarum, & in omnibus aliis rebus‚Äî: Reddendo ind√® annuat√¨m‚Äî qua≈ødam Cheirothecas albas, vel unum Denarium, ad Pa≈øcha, pro omnibus Servitiis & demandis univer≈øis, ≈øalvo forin≈øeco Servitio. Et pro hac venditione & dimi≈ø≈øione mihi dedit praedictus Comes ducentas Marcas Argenti, &c. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Domino Waltero Abbate Ce≈øtriae, Domino Willielmo Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Radulfo de Bray, Ricardo de Burun, Galfrido de Dutton, Galfrido de Appelby, Johanne de Lexington, Magi≈øtro Gilberto de We≈øton, Rogero de Derbey, Simone & Johanne Clericis, & multis aliis.

III. Now for his Titles. After that he Married with Con≈øtance the Widow of Geffrey, fourth Son of King Henry the Second, and Daughter and Heir of Conan Duke of Little-Britain and Earl of Richmond, which Marriage by the King's Con≈øent was Solemnized in Anno 1187. 33 Hen. 2. as Hoveden informs us, pag. 637. then did he al≈øo a≈ø≈øume tho≈øe Titles, and writ him≈øelf thus:‚ÄîRanulphus Dux Britanniae, & Comes Ce≈øtriae & Richmondiae.
A Deed or two I ≈øhall produce for Proof hereof: One from the Original, which I ≈øaw in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Peter Daniel of Over-Tabley E≈øq 10 die Junii, 1650. as followeth.

RANULPHUS Dux Britanniae, & Comes Ce≈øtriae & Richmondiae, Omnibus t√†m prae≈øentibus qu√†m futuris qui Chartam i≈øtam viderint & audierint, Salutem. Sciatis qu√≤d ego dedi & conce≈ø≈øi Andreae Filio Mabiliae, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, ut ≈øint liberi & quieti de me & meis Haeredibus de Teloneo per totam terram meam, & in aqu√¢, & in terr√¢, & in Civitate Ce≈øtriae & extr√†, & √† Brevibus portandis, & √† Pri≈øonibus capiendis & cu≈øtodienis, & √† Namis capiendis, & √† Vigiliis faciendis nocte vel die, & √† caeteris huju≈ømodi con≈øuetudinibus & exactionibus, n√®c de querel√¢ aliqu√¢ in Civitate Ce≈øtriae, vel extr√†, re≈øpondeant in prae≈øenti√¢ me√¢, vel ≈øummi Ju≈øtitiae mei: Et ≈øuper forisfacturam meam X Librarum prohibeo, ne aliquis eos de ≈øupradictis libertatibus impediat vel inquietet, ≈øed eas liber√® & quiet√® teneant, Reddendo mihi & Haeredibus meis annuat√¨m VI Denarios ad Festum Sancti Michaelis. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Bertre Comiti≈ø≈øa Ce≈øtrae, Radulfo de Meinewarin, Radulfo Sene≈øchallo, Hugone de Boidele, & Alano Fratre ejus, Roaldo, Roberto Cam ‚Ä¢ ,
Roberto Saraceno, Ranulfo Dubeldai, Nicolao Filio Roberti, Thoma Fratre ≈øuo, Willielmo Marmiun, Ricardo Poibel, Rogero Clerico, & multis aliis. Apud Ce≈øtriam.
A large Seal of Pa≈øte, or kind of White Wax, with the Impre≈ø≈øion of the Earl on Hor≈øeback on both ≈øides.
Al≈øo another taken ex majori Libro de Whalley & Stanlaw, Penes Radulfum A≈øhton Militem, 1649. Tit. Num. 8. fol. 33.

RANULFUS Dux Britanniae, Comes Ce≈øtriae & Richmondiae, Con≈øtabulario, Dapifero, Camerario, & omnibus Mini≈øtris ejus, & omnibus Baronibus & Militibus ≈øuis, & omnibus Hominibus ≈øuis, Francis & Anglicis, Clericis & Laicis, t√†m prae≈øentibus qu√†m futuris, Salutem. Notum ≈øit vobis omnibus, me conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe & h√¢c Chart√¢ me√¢ confirm√¢≈ø≈øe Deo & Abbatiae de loco benedicto de Stanlaw, & Monachis ibidem Deo ≈øervientibus, omnes illas libertates & donationes, quas eis fecit Comes Hugo Pater meus; & pro√πt Charta ≈øua, quam habent Monachi praedicti, te≈øtatur.‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Johanne Con≈øtabulario Ce≈øtriae, Petro Cancellario, Radulfo de Maynilwaringe, Hugone de Boidell, Ranulfo de Praers,Apud Ce≈øtriam.

But after his Divorce from Con≈øtance, which hapned Anno Domini 1200. he relinqui≈øhed the Titles of Dux Britanniae and Comes Richmondiae, having no I≈ø≈øue by her. She after her Divorce Married Guy Vi≈øcount of Thouars, and ≈øhe died 3 Johannis Regis 1201. Hoveden, pag. 822. leaving I≈ø≈øue by Guy a Daughter called Alice, given afterwards by the King of France in Marriage to Peter Mauclere Militi ≈øuo cum Britanni√¢. Vincent upon Brooke, pag. 62, 63. And howbeit Milles in his Catalogue of Honour tells us, That this Randle had the Earldom of Richmond given him, with all the Fees and Priviledges belonging thereunto, the which Geffrey, ≈øometimes Earl of Britain, held in Richmond≈øhire, except certain Knights Fees, which Roald Con≈øtable of Richmond, and Henry Son of Harvey, held in the ≈øame: The Charter dated at York, 6 die Martii, 6 Johannis Regis, 1204. Yet was he never ≈øtiled Comes Richmondiae after his Divorce, though perhaps he enjoyed the Profits thereof for ≈øome ≈øpace; but only Comes Cestriae was his Style, as appears by the≈øe following Chartes.

The Originals of the≈øe two following Deeds were in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Mr. Townelay of Carre in Lanca≈øhire, June 23. 1657. both of them made in the Reign of King John, as appears by the Witne≈ø≈øes.

OMnibus Sanctae Matris Eccle≈øiae Filiis,‚ÄîRanulfus Comes Ce≈øtriae, Salutem. Notum ≈øit vobis me dedi≈ø≈øe‚ÄîDeo & Beatae Mariae, & Monachis de Stanlaw, quietantiam de Bestiis Sylvestribus occi≈øis, vel attinctis in terra ip≈øorum Monachorum, portandis u≈øque ad Ce≈øtriam: & quod dicti Monachi & eorum homines non ideo cau≈øentur propter aliquam Bestiam aliquo ca≈øu mortuam & inventam in terra eorum, ni≈øi fuerit aliquis Sakerbor qui de hoc loqui voluerit adver≈øus dictos Monachos, aut eorum homines: & quod ≈øint quieti de ≈øervientibus & Forestariis. Te≈øtibus hiis, Rogero Constabulario Ce≈øtriae, Warino de Vernon, Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, Philippo de Orreby, Willielmo de Venables, Ricardo de Aldford, Adam & Hugone de Dutton, Petro Clerico, Thoma Di≈øpen≈øatore, Collino de Quatuor-Maris, Radulfo de Munfichet, Gaufrido de Dutton, Adam de Byri, & multis aliis. Apud Frod≈øham.

RANULFUS Comes Ce≈øtriae, Con≈øtabulario ≈øuo, & Dapifero, Ju≈øtitiae, & Vicecomiti, Baronibus, & Ballivis ≈øuis, Salutem. Sciatis me pro Dei amore, & pro ≈øalute Animae meae, dedi≈ø≈øe‚Äîin perpetuam & puram Elemo≈øynam Deo, & Sanctae Mariae, & Monachis loci Benedicti de Stanlaw, quietantiam de Tolneio per totam terram meam, de Sale & de omnibus aliis rebus quas emerint vel vendiderint ad u≈øus ≈øuos proprios, t√†m per aquam qu√†m per terram,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus hiis, Rogero Con≈øtabulario Ce≈øtriae,
Philippo de Orreby t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Warino de Vernon, Willielmo de Venables, Petro Clerico, Adam & Hugone de Dutton, Liulpho Vicecomite, Alexandro Filio Radulfi, Bertramo Camerario, Jo≈øceramo de Hellesby, & multis aliis. Apud Ce≈øtriam.
Both the≈øe Deeds afore≈øaid were Sealed with the Impre≈ø≈øion of a Lion in an E≈øcocheon, or rather a Triangular form, like a Heart.

div.head: Couchir Book in the Dutchy-Office, Tom. 2. Honor ≈øive Soca de Bolingbroke, pag. 116. num. 17.
div.p: OMnibus t√†m futuris qu√†m prae≈øentibus,‚ÄîPetrus Cantor de Quarendona, Salutem. Sciatis me remi≈øi≈ø≈øe & quietum clam√¢≈ø≈øe de me & de Haeredibus meis Domino meo Ranulfo Comiti Ce≈øtriae, totam terram meam quam habebam in Weinflet, & aliam terram meam totam in Lind≈øeia, quae pertinet ad terram praedictam de Weinflet: Tenendas praedicto Comiti Ce≈øtriae, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, Haereditari√® in Dominico ≈øuo, &c. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Thoma Di≈øpen≈øario, Willielmo Picot, Waltero de Coventreya, Juhello de Loningneio, Johanne de Pratell, Helya Pincerna, Gaufrido de Sancto Bricio. Engeramo Pi≈øce, Henrico Di≈øpen≈øario, Willielmo Filio Hamonis, Henrico de Civile, & multis aliis. Apud Baronam.

But when Gilbert de Gant, Earl of Lincoln, was taken Pri≈øoner, who had then forfeited both his Lands and Honour in taking part with the Rebellious Barons again≈øt the King of England, which Title Lewis King of France conferred upon him a little before, to wit, Anno 1216. then was Randle Earl of Che≈øter made Earl of Lincoln by King Henry third, 1217. 1 Hen. 3. for ≈øo was the Writ directed to the Sheriff of Lincoln, dated at Lincoln, 23 Maii, 1 Hen. 3. Clau≈ø. 1 Hen. 3. Memb. 17. commanding him qu√≤d habere faciat Comiti Ce≈øtriae tertium Denarium de Comitatu Lincolniae, qui eum contingit jure Haereditario ex parte Ranulphi patris ≈øui. Where, if Vincent hath not mi≈øwrit the Record, it ≈øhould have been Avi ≈øui, not Patris: For Randle the Second, ≈øirnamed Gernons, Earl of Che≈øter, was half-Brother by the Mother to William de Romara Earl of Lincoln; as who≈øe Heir, upon this Forfeiture, Henry the Third now grants the Earldom of Lincoln to Randle Blundevill.

Another Writ was dated at Worcester, 15 Martii,
Clau≈ø. 2 Hen. 3. memb. 9. 2 Hen. 3. directed to the ≈øame Officer:‚ÄîPraecipimus tibi, qu√≤d recipias Clericum illum, quem fidelis no≈øter & dilectus Ranulphus Comes Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae ad te mi≈øerat per Literas ≈øuas, ad eundum tecum per Comitatum Lincolniae, & ad recipiendum tertium Denarium de Placitis Comitatus eju≈ødem, nomine Comitis Lincolniae, ad opus ip≈øius Comitis, ≈øic√πt eidem illum tertium Denarium conce≈ø≈øimus. Vincent upon Brooke, pag. 316. Mat. Paris, pag. 296.
And from this time, to the time of his death, he was u≈øually ≈øtiled in all his Charters,‚ÄîRanulphus Comes Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae. Some Deeds I ≈øhall in≈øert here, proving the ≈øame.

div.head: Couchir Book in the Dutchy-Office, Tom 2. Honor ≈øiv√® Soca de Bolingbroke, pag. 111. num. 5. of Lands in Lincoln≈øhire.
div.p: OMnibus prae≈øentibus,‚ÄîGilbertus de Beningeworth, Salutem. Noverit univer≈øitas ve≈øtra me dedi≈ø≈øe‚ÄîRanulpho Comiti Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae, & Haeredibus ≈øuis,‚Äîtotum Manerium meum de Halton, in Dominicis, in Hominibus, &c. & homahomagium Radulfi de Gou≈øle de Feodo unius Militis in Yreby, &c. & totum Manerium meum de Kynthorp, &c. Pro h√¢c ver√≤ donatione dedit mihi praedictus Ranulphus Comes ducentas Libras Sterlingorum: Et adquietavit me vers√πs Elyam Filium Martrinae Judaeum Lincolniae de octi√®s viginti & decem Marcis Argenti, &c. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Radulfo Filio Simonis, Gilberto Cu≈øyn tunc Sene≈øchallo, &c.

div.head: Ibidem, pag. 111. num. 6.
div.p: SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, quod ego Gilbertus de Beningworth quiet√® clamavi‚ÄîRanulpho Comiti Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae & haeredibus ≈øuis, totum Manerium de Stepinge, quod e≈øt de feodo ip≈øius Comitis, cum tota terra de Halton, & cum Advocatione Eccle≈øiae de Stepinge, &c. Pro h√¢c ver√≤ donatione & quiet√¢ Clamatione dedit mihi praedictus Ranulfus Comes ducentas marcas E≈øterlingorum, &c.
Many other of his Charters might be produced, but let the≈øe ≈øuffice.

IV. Now for his Wives. His fir≈øt Wife, as you have already heard, was Con≈øtance the Widow of Geffrey, fourth Son of King Henry the Second, and Daughter and Heir of Conan, Duke of Little Britain and Earl of Richmond. She was Married to Randle, Anno 1187. 33 Hen. 2. as is before proved.

But upon the Divorce of Con≈øtance, Anno ≈øcilicet Chri≈øti 1200. 2 Johannis Regis, he Married Clemence, Si≈øter of Geffrey de Filgiers in Normandy, and Widow to Alan de Dinnam. Ferne in his Lacy's Nobility, pag. 58. and Powel on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 296. mo≈øt ab≈øurdly call her the Daughter of Ferrers Earl of Derby: And the Tran≈ølator of Polychronicon, lib. 7. cap. 32. calls her Daughter of Rafe de Filgiers, who in truth was her Grandfather. But ≈øhe was Daughter of William de Filgiers, and Si≈øter to Geffrey. See Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 997. And for farther proof hereof take the≈øe two ≈øub≈øequent Deeds.

div.head: Couchir Book in the Dutchy Office at Gray's Inne, Tom. 2. Comitatus Northampton, num. 3.
div.p: OMnibus tam futuris quam prae≈øentibus, ad quos literae prae≈øentes pervenerint, Gaufridus de Filgeriis Salutem. Notum ≈øit vobis, me conce≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe & dedi≈ø≈øe Ranulfo Comiti Ce≈øtriae cum Clementia Sorore mea in liberum Maritagium, totum Maritagium quod cum ip≈øa datum fuit Alano de Dinnamo priore marito ≈øuo: Scilicet totam terram, quam Antece≈ø≈øores mei habuerunt in valle Moretoniae cum omnibus pertinentiis & libertatibus eju≈ødem terrae: & unum Manerium in Anglia, quod vocatur Belingtona cum omnibus pertinentiis & libertatibus ≈øuis, tam liber√® & quiet√® & integr√® ut Willielmus de Sancto Johanne illud habuit & tenuit Anno & die quo fuit vivus & mortuus: Qui ≈øcilicet Willielmus Manerium illud habuit in Maritagio cum Oliva Matre Radulfi de Filgeriis Avi mei: Et ≈øi aliqua occa≈øione interveniente non po≈ø≈øum ei terras praedictas deliberare, in aliis terris meis de haereditate me√¢ in Anglia & in Normannia illi perficiam trecent as libratas terrae ad Monetam Andegaviae: Quod ≈øi facere non po≈ø≈øum, in aliis terris meis de haereditate me√¢, Competentem faciam Gratum praedicti Comitis de trecentis libratis terrae ei Perficiendis. Praeterea Dedi praenominato Comiti in liberum Maritagium cum praedicta Sorore me√¢ totam dotem Matris meae, habendam praedicto Comiti, po≈øt dece≈ø≈øum Matris meae, integr√® & plenari√® cum omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis, ≈øicut Pater meus eam dedit Matri meae in dotem: Et ut hoc ratum & inconcu≈ø≈øum permaneat in po≈øterum, prae≈øenti Scripto & Sigillo meo ad ip≈øum confirmavi: Et Willielmus de Humetto Con≈øtabularius Normanniae juravit hoc legitim√® tenendum, & Sigillo ≈øuo confirmavit. Hiis Te≈øtibus Willielmo Con≈øtantiae Epi≈øcopo, Johanne Abbate Alneti, Angoto Abbate de Lu≈øerna, Willielmo Abbate Hambeiae. Testibus etiam & juratis his, Fulcone Paganello, Willielmo Bac', Hugone de Colonc', Har≈øtulpho de Salingneio, Petro de Sancto Hilario, Henrico de Humetto, Jordano de Humet, Thoma de Humetto, Petro Roaud, Rauno de Per', Juhello de Lavingneia, Juhello Beringen, Johanne de Humetto, Bartholomaeo Abbate, Radulpho de Agnis, & multis aliis.

div.head: Ex Originali Penes Simonem Dewes, Militem & Baronettum; Notato EE. num. 12. Anno 1649.
div.p:
SCiant omnes ad quos prae≈øentes literae pervenerint, quod contentio,This Deed bears Date Anno 1200. quae fuit inter Ranulfum Comitem Ce≈øtriae, & Willielmum de Filgeriis ≈øuper maritagio Clementiae de Filgeriis uxoris praedicti Comitis & Proneptis praedicti Willielmi, hoc modo pacificata est: Scilicet, quod praedictus Willielmus reddidit Gaufrido de Filgeriis Pronepoti ≈øuo, ad dandum in maritagio cum Clementia ≈øorore ≈øu√¢ praedicto Comiti, totam terram quam Radulfus de Filgeriis habuit in valle Moretonii, & ≈øicut de ea Sei≈øitus fuit anno & die quo eam dedit Alano de Dinnam in maritagio cum praedicta Clementia, excepto Dominio Abbatiae Savierguen, & exceptis LX ≈øolidis Andegaven≈øium, quos idem Radulfus dedit Aeliciae nepti ≈øuae (quae e≈øt Monialis apud Moreton) habendos quamdiu ip≈øa vixerit per manum Servientis de Romei ergeneio; & po≈øt dece≈ø≈øum ip≈øius Monialis revertentur praedictae Clementiae, & haeredibus ≈øuis: Et praeterea dabit praedictus Willielmus praedicto Comiti centum libras Andegaven≈øes annuatim √† Natali Domini, quod e≈øt anno verbi incarnati 1201. u≈øque ad quinque annos, in nativitate Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae ≈øolvendas: Praeterea conce≈ø≈øit praedictus Willielmus praedicto Comiti unum maritagium in denariis Par Tailliae de Augu≈øto, habendum per totam terram Filgerii, excepta villa Filgeria quae Combu≈øta erat: Inter praedictum vero Willielmum de Filgeriis & Gaufridum pronepotem ≈øuum haec e≈øt Conventio per Con≈øilium amicorum eju≈ødem Gaufridi facta: videlicet, quod praedictus Willielmus totam terram de Filgiers, ≈øicut Radulfus de Filgeriis eam illi commi≈øit fideliter custodiendam, tenebit √† praedicto Natali u≈øque in quinque annos: Et ≈øi quis ei ≈øuper hoc contraire aut eum vexare voluerit, praedictus Comes & Willielmus de Humet & alii Amici Gaufridi & homines terrae Filgiers (qui hanc Conventionem fideliter tenendam juraverunt) praedicto Willielmo erunt auxiliantes & con≈øulentes pro Po≈ø≈øe ≈øuo‚ñ™ Completis autem quinque annis praedictis, praefatus Willielmus reddet praedicto Gaufrido Pronepoti ≈øuo totam terram Filgerii ≈øine contradictione, ≈øicut Radulfus de Filgeriis eam illi commi≈øit cu≈øtodiendam fideliter: Quam cum reddiderit, idem Galfridus (qui √† praedicto Willielmo requi≈øitus fuerit) de jure ≈øuo terrae Filgiers per con≈øilium Amicorum utriu≈øque Partis, & hominum terrae Filgerii, faciet quod facere debebit: Et ≈øi per con≈øilium amicorum ≈øuorum, & hominum terrae, inter ≈øe concordari non poterint, per judicium Guriae Domini Britanniae ≈øine dilatione illi faciet quod facere debebit. Et ≈øi alter uter illorum contra hoc venire voluerit, tam homines terrae Filgerii quam Amici utriu≈øque partis auxiliantes erunt illi, qui hanc Conventionem tenere voluit; & nocentes ei, qui eam tenere recu≈øavit: Si autem contigerit, Clementiam uxorem praedicti Comitis Ce≈øtriae decedere infra quinque annos praedictos, ip≈øe Comes dicto Willielmo de Filgeriis terram de valle Moritonii quiet√® reddet, ≈øi de Clementia haeredem non habuerit: Et ≈øi Gaufridus de Filgeriis infra praedictos quinque annos dece≈ø≈øerit, idem Willielmus terram Filgerii integr√® & ≈øine contradictione aliqu√¢, & ab≈øque termino, Clementia & haeredibus ejus reddet: Et ip≈øa Clementia & Spon≈øus ejus tenebunt praedicto Willielmo Conventionem, quam Gaufridus de Filgeriis & Amici ≈øui ei tenere debebant: Amplius Willielmus de Filgeriis de omnibus, quo≈øcunque po≈øuerit in Ca≈øtello Filgerii infra quinque annos, jurare faciet, quod ≈øi ip≈øum in fata quie≈øcere contigerit, ip≈øi _____ Gaufrido de Filgeriis, vel praedictae Clementiae ≈øorori ≈øuae ≈øi ip≈øa ei ≈øuper≈øtes fuerit: Et in hac Conventione reman≈øerunt Willielmo de Filgeriis praedicto Maneria in Anglia, ≈øoilicet Tuiford & Watkinton, quae Radulfus de Filgeriis frater ejus illi dedit pro homagio ≈øuo & Servitio, ≈øicut Chartae dicti Radulfi legitime te≈øtantur: Et in≈øuper eidem Willielmo remanet Manerium de Belington, quod fuit maritagium _____ & eum contingit jure haereditario ex parte matris ≈øuae: Has Conventiones fecit Willielmus de Filgeriis ad Scaccarium apud _____ cum Ranulfo Comite Cestriae & Clementia uxore ejus,The Deed is torn out in the≈øe places. & cum Willielmo de Humet quem idem Comes & Clementia uxor ≈øua loco ≈øuo a≈ø≈øignaverunt _____ ≈øuper hoc ageret ratum habituri; in prae≈øentia Sam≈øonis Abbatis Cadomi, & Hugonis de Chaucumb, & _____ Guiterii de Motyr, & Decani Sancti Juliani tunc Justitiariorum Domini Regis: Has Conventiones _____ tam praedictus Com√®s Ce≈øtria, quam Willielmus de Filgeriis: Et ex parte Comitis Juraverunt i≈øti, Hugo _____ Praer, Petrus de Sancto Hilario, Petrus Roaud: Ex parte Willielmi de Filgeriis juraverunt
_____ Henricus de Viterio, Gaufridus de Sancto Bricio, Willielmus de Sancto Bricio: Et hoc ip≈øum juraverunt _____ Fontenai: ut autem hae Conventiones firmae & inconcu≈ø≈øae permaneant, _____ Sigillorum Comitis Ce≈øtriae, & Con≈øtabularii Normanniae, & Willielmi de Filgeriis, & Alani filii Comitis, & Guidonis de Avall, confirmatae. Actum e≈øt autem hoc Nonis Octobris, Anno Incarnationis Domini 1200.
Three large Seals of green Wax appendant.

Anno 1230. Ranulfus Comes Ce≈øtren≈øis munivit Ca≈øtellum apud Sanctum Johannem de Beveron√¢, quod ad jus uxoris ≈øuae Comiti≈ø≈øae jure haereditario pertinebat, militibus, alimentis, & Armis: Reddiderat illi Ca≈øtrum illud Comes Britanniae Henricus quando confaederatus Regi Angliae omnia jura ≈øua in Regno Angliae, Rege Concedente, recepit. Mat. Paris. p. 367.

Some have added here a third Wife to Randle, namely Margaret, Daughter of Humfrey Bohun Con≈øtable of England. So Ferne and Powel, and Brooks in his Catalogue of Nobility, who for this his Error is ju≈øtly Corrected by Vincent. The≈øe Per≈øons are full of ab≈øolute Fal≈øities.

It is plain, that Clemence Counte≈øs of Che≈øter ≈øurvived her Husband Randle Blundevill; for ≈øhe Sued out her Dower. In the Clo≈øe Rolls, Clau≈ø. 16 Hen. 3. memb. 1. A Writ is directed to the Sheriff of Lincoln‚ÄîQuod de Maneriis de Beminton & de Luneberge, quae ≈øunt maritagium Clementiae Comiti≈ø≈øae Ce≈øtriae, quae fuit uxor Ranulfi Comitis Ce≈øtriae, plenam Sei≈øinam eidem Clementiae habere faciat: faciat etiam eidem Clementiae plenam Sei≈øinam habere de omnibus terris, quas Bertreia quondam Comiti≈ø≈øa Ce≈øtriae habuit nomine dotis in Maneriis de Wadinton, Normanby, &c. quas quidem Rex a≈ø≈øignavit eidem Clementiae loco dotis ad ≈øu≈øtinendum: eo tamen Salvo dictae Comiti≈ø≈øae, quod plus po≈ø≈øit petere in dotem, ≈øi non fuerit ≈øufficienter dotata.
How could Randle now have any Wife after Clemence, unle≈øs he could Marry when he is dead? away with the≈øe Lyes.
But Randle had no I≈ø≈øue by either of his Wives, leaving his whole Inheritance to be ≈øhared by his four Si≈øters and Coheirs, as is before mentioned in Hugh Cyveliok.

div.head: V. The Death of Randle the Third, ≈øirnamed Blundevill.
div.p: Obiit 1232 16 Hen. 3. Anno 1232. Ranulfus Comes Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae apud Wallingford diem clau≈øit extremum quinto Calendas Novembris [that is the 28. day of our October] cujus Corpus delatum e≈øt apud Ce≈øtriam tumulandum, vi≈øcera apud Wallingford tumulabantur. Mat. Paris, pag. 380.
The Book of Teuksbury thus‚ÄîAnno 1232. obiit Ranulphus Comes Ce≈øtriae 7 Calendas Novembris apud Wallingford, ubi po≈øita ≈øunt vi≈øcera ≈øua: Cor apud Delacres: Corpus apud Ce≈øtriam.

Agreeing herewith take this Deed, which I found tran≈øcribed in a Paper Book belonging to Sir Thomas Delves of Dodington in Che≈øhire, Baronet, Anno 1668. vouching the Original to have been in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Mr. Thomas Rudyard of Rudyard; and to be Sealed with three Garbs or Wheat≈øheafs, as followeth, made a little before Randle's Death, about the 16 Hen. 3. 1232.

q.p: UNiver≈øis‚ÄîRanulfus Comes Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae, Salutem. Sciatis me dedi≈ø≈øe Deo, & Sanctae Mariae de Delacres, & Monachis ibidem Deo Servientibus, Cor meum post obitum meum ibi Sepeliendum, ubicunque Corpus meum Sepeliri contigerit: Quare volo & firmiter praecipio, quod ubicunque vitam meam finiri contigerit, aut ubicunque Corpus meum tumulatam fuerit, quod haeredes mei & homines mei Cor meum ad Abbatiam meam de Delacres, quam ego ip≈øe fundavi, ab≈øque omni impedimento & contradictione a≈øportent, Condendum ibidem, ‚Äî&c. Testibus W. Abbate Ce≈øtriae, Willielmo de Vernon tunc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae,‚Äî&c.

div.p: The Monk of Che≈øter in his Polychronicon thus:‚ÄîAnno 1232. Ranulphus Comes Cestriae, Lincolniae, & Huntindoniae, obiit apud Wallingford, & ≈øepultus est apud Cestriam in Capitulo Monachorum, c√πm Progenitoribus ≈øuis.
Certainly the Monk is mi≈øtaken here in the Title of Huntindoniae; for Randle was never Earl of Huntindon: John the Scot, who next ≈øucceeded Earl of Chester, was al≈øo Earl of Huntindon.
I find that Randle Earl of Che≈øter and Lincoln, had the Earldom of Leycester given him by Henry the Third, as Cambden in Leycester≈øhire informs us.

For Simon Montfort, Earl of Leycester in Right of his Wife, took part with the French King, and for his Rebellion was expelled England. He was ≈ølain at the Siege of Tholou≈øe in France, Anno 1219. Mat. Paris. After who≈øe Death, Henry the Third gave Simon Montfort's Lands in England to Randle Earl of Chester. Howbeit, I find not that Randle ever a≈ø≈øumed or u≈øed the Title of Earl of Leycester at any time. But Almaric de Montfort, Son and Heir of the ≈øaid Simon, Petitions Henry the Third, thus,‚Äî

div.head: Couchir Book in the Dutchy-Office at Grays-Inn, Tom. 2. Comitatus Leyce≈øtriae, num. 4.
div.p: EXcellenti≈ø≈øimo Domino ≈øuo, Henrico Dei Grati√¢ Illu≈øtri Anglorum Regi Almaricus Comes Montisfortis & Leyce≈øtriae, Salutem, in eo qui dat ≈øalutem Regibus; & c√πm omni ≈øubjectione t√†m debitum qu√†m devotum ad ob≈øequia famulatum: Ve≈øtrae Regiae Maje≈øtati multoti√®s ≈øupplicavi humilit√®r & devot√®, ut mihi terram meam & jus meum, quod habeo & habere debeo in Anglia, quod bonae memoriae Pater meus de ve≈øtro tenuit, & tenebat (d√πm dece≈ø≈øit) pacific√® & quiet√®, mihi ve≈øtro Militi redderetis: Qu√≤d qui√† Dominationi ve≈øtrae non placuit hucu≈øqu√® facere, adhuc ve≈øtrae Maje≈øtati ≈øupplico humilitate qu√¢ po≈ø≈øum, quaten√πs h√¢c vice mihi vobis ≈øervire parato (≈øicut decuit) reddere dignemini terram. Et ≈øi hoc vobis non placuerit, ego ad pedes Dominationis ve≈øtrae tran≈ømitto Simonem Fratrem meum, qui de Domino Regae Franciae nihil tenet, cui ≈øi eam reddideritis, me pro bene pacato tenerem. Datum Pari≈øiis Men≈øe Februario.

Whereupon King Henry, 6 Februarii, 14 Hen. 3. Anno 1229. engageth him≈øelf to re≈øtore all the Lands in England, which were parcel of the Honour of Leyce≈øter, c√πm tertio Denario Comitatus Leyce≈øtriae, to this Simon younger Brother of Almarick afore≈øaid, ≈øo ≈øoon as he could get them out of the Hands of Randle Earl of Che≈øter and Lincoln; for to him he had formerly granted them.
And afterwards Almarick ≈øurrendred up his Right to his Brother Simon, 23 Hen. 3. in the≈øe words following.

div.head: Couchir Book in the Dutchy-Office, Tom. 2. Com. Leyce≈øtriae, num. 5.
div.p: SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, qu√≤d ego Almaricus Comes Montisfortis, Franciae Con≈øtabularius, √¨n prae≈øenti√¢ Henrici Illu≈øtris Regis Angliae, Filii Regis Johannis, apud We≈øtmona≈øterium die Lunae proxim√® po≈øt Quindenam Pa≈øchae, Anno Regni ip≈øius Henrici vice≈øimo tertio, recognovi, conce≈ø≈øi, & quietum clamavi de me & Haeredibus meis, dilecto Fratri meo Simoni de Monteforti, Comiti Leyce≈øtriae, totam partem Honoris Leyce≈øtriae, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis in Regno Angliae, ade√≤ plen√® & integr√® ≈øicut Comes Simon Pater no≈øter, vel Robertus Comes Leyce≈øtren≈øis, illam unqu√†m meli√πs, pleni√πs, & liberi√πs tenuerunt. Habendum & tenendum eidem Simoni Fratri meo, & Haredibus ≈øuit de Corpore ≈øuo procreatis, de praedicto Domino Henrico Rege, & Haeredibus ≈øuis in perpetu√πm,‚Äî&c. Actum apud We≈øtmona≈øterium, Anno & Die praenominatis. 1239.

Which the King at that very in≈øtant confirmed unto him: But this was after the death of Randle Earl of Che≈øter and Lincoln. Howbeit this Simon lo≈øt the ≈øame again by his Rebellion, and was ≈ølain at the Battel of Eve≈øham, 4 Augu≈øti, 49 Hen. 3. 1265.
Randle, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, was Earl of Che≈øter 51 Years.

div.head: The≈øe followidg Notes I received from Mr. Dugdale.
div.p: This Earl of Perch was ≈ølain at the Battel of Lincoln, 1217. Mat. Paris, pag. 296. of the Edition put out by Wats, A. Dom. 1640.THis Earl Randle was but of low ≈øtature, as we may ob≈øerve by the Earl of Perch his words to him at Lincoln: What (≈øaid he) have we ≈øtaid all this while for ≈øuch a Little Man, ≈øuch a Dwarfe? To whom Earl Randle replied, I vow to God and our Lady (who≈øe Church this is) that before to Morrow Evening I will ≈øeem to thee to be higher than that Steeple. So Walter de Wittle≈øey a Monk of Peterborough; a Manu≈øcript now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Dean and Chapter of Peterborough.

King John gave to this Randle, Newca≈øtle-under-Lyme in Stafford≈øhire, to hold by the Service of one Knights Fee. Chart. 17 Johannis, num. 25. and al≈øo the Cu≈øtody of all Simon Montfort's Lands, with the Fore≈øts, to the u≈øe of the ≈øaid Simon. Ibidem, Membrane 19.
Pat. 1 Hen. 3. mem. 4 & mem. 7. Pat. 2 Hen. 3. mem 10. 1 Hen. 3. the King gave to this Randle the Cu≈øtody of the Honour of Lanca≈øter, and the Ca≈øtle of Mont≈øorrel, which Randle demoli≈øhed.

2 Hen. 3. the King gave him the Cu≈øtody of the Honour of Brittany, in the Counties of Cambridge, Norfolk, and Suffolk: And he executed the Office of Sheriff by his Deputies in the Counties of Salop and Stafford, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7 Hen. 3. and in the County of Lanca≈øter, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 Hen. 3. as by the Pipe-Rolls of tho≈øe Years appeareth.

Pat. 11. H. 3. mem. 6.11 Hen. 3. the King gave him all that part of the Honour of Richmond, which he formerly had of the Grant of King John, to hold for Randle's Life, upon condition that he ≈øhould make no Agreement with the Earl of Brittany to ≈øurrender the ≈øame up to him, unle≈øs the Earl of Brittany could obtain tho≈øe Lands in Normandy which the Earl of Che≈øter had lo≈øt in the Service of King John.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Of John ≈øirnamed The Scot, Earl of Che≈øter.

div.p: His Father David, Brother of William King of Scotland, was Knighted by King Henry the Second, 1170. Hoveden, pag. 518. and made Earl of Huntington, 1184. Hoveden, pag. 622. and David died about Anno 1219. So that John Scot was Earl of Che≈øter and Huntington.
Take here the Charte remaining among the Evidences of St. Werburge Church in Che≈øter, as followeth.

OMnibus Christi fidelibus prae≈øens ≈øcriptum vi≈øuris vel audituris, Johannes de Scotia Comes Ce≈øtriae & Huntindoniae ≈øalutem in Domino. Sciatis me conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe & confirma≈ø≈øe Deo & Domni Sanctae Werburgae de Ce≈øtria, & Abbati & Monachis ibidem Deo ≈øervientibus, in puram & perpetuam Elemo≈øynam pro ≈øalute me√¢ & Comiti≈ø≈øae meae, & pro
Anim√¢ Comitis Davidis Patris mei, & Comiti≈ø≈øae Matildae Matris meae, & pro Anim√¢ Ranulfi Comitis Avunculi mei, & pro Animabus omnium Antece≈ø≈øorum meorum, omnes Donationes, & Dignitates, & Libertates, quas Comites Antece≈ø≈øores mei & Barones eis dederunt. In≈øup√®r ego ip≈øe do, concedo, & prae≈øenti ≈øcripto confirmo praedictis Abbati & Monachis quietantiam de tribus Panibus, quos aliquando ≈øolebant dare diurn√® ad Turrim Castelli mei de Ce≈øtria; & quietantiam de Putura ≈øervientium in Villis ≈øuis, ≈øcilic√®t Huntington, Cheveley, Idinchale, Wyrvin, tempore Pacis; & Pre≈øtbury & Go≈øtrey in perpetu√πm,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Domino Ricardo Phiton t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Domino Warino de Vernon, Willielmo de Venables, Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, Hamone de Phitton, Willielmo de Malo-pa≈ø≈øu, Willielmo de Boydell, Ricardo de Sonbach, Ricardo de Wibinberie t√πnc Vice-Comite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, & aliis. This was made about 18 Hen. 3. 1233.

II. This John Earl of Che≈øter and Huntington, conceiving that an Earl might not lawfully be Summoned in any other County than that whereof he was Earl, did except again≈øt the Summons in Northampton≈øhire upon a Writ De rationabili parte, brought again≈øt him there, by the other Co-heirs to Randle Blundevill; but was ordered to an≈øwer. The Record I have here tran≈øcribed, as it is cited by Selden in his Titles of Honour, pag. 643. ex Fragmentis tempore Hen. 3. quae in Archivis Arcis Londinen≈øis ≈øervantur: Orta est ista lis in 18 Hen. 3. quod ≈øat√¨s constat ex placitis 18 Hen. 3. Rot. 14.

NOrthampton‚ÄîJohannes Comes Ce≈øtriae & Huntingdoaiae, ≈øummonitus fuit ad re≈øpondendum Hugoni de Albiniaco, Willielmo Comiti de Ferrariis, & Agneti Uxori ejus, & Hawi≈øiae Comiti≈ø≈øae Lincolniae, quar√® deforciat eis rationabilem partem ≈øuam, quae eos contingit de Haereditate Ranulfi quond√†m Comitis Ce≈øtriae, & und√® ip≈øe obiit Sei≈øitus in Comitatu Ce≈øtriae; comput√¢ c√πm ei≈ødem Hugone, Willielmo & Agnete, & Hawi≈øia, parte ≈øu√¢ rationabili de Terr√¢ quam n√πnc tenet alib√¨ de e√¢dem Haereditate. Et Comes ali√†s re≈øpondit, qu√≤d noluit re≈øpondere ad hoc Breve nis√¨ Curia con≈øideraverit, & con≈øideratione Parium ≈øuorum, per ≈øummonitionem factam in Comitatu Northamptoniae de Terris & Tenementis in Comitatu Ce≈øtriae ubi Brevia Domini Regis non currunt. Et qui√† u≈øitatum e≈øt h√πc u≈øqu√®, qu√≤d Pares ≈øui, & alii qui libertates habent con≈øimiles (≈øic√πt Epi≈øcopus Dunelmen≈øis, & Comes Mare≈øchallus) re≈øpondent de Terris & Tenementis infr√† libertates ≈øuas per ≈øummonitionem factam ad Terras & Tenementa extr√† libertates ≈øuas: Ide√≤ con≈øideratum e≈øt, qu√≤d re≈øpondeat.

III. This John Scot Earl of Che≈øter carried the Sword before King Henry the Third at the Marriage of Queen Elianour, Anno Domini 1236. 20 Hen. 3. at which time all the Great Men of this Kingdom u≈øed tho≈øe Offices and Places which had of ancient Right belonged to their Ance≈øtors at the Coronation of the Kings; and is mentioned by Matthew Paris in the≈øe words, ≈øub Anno 1236.‚ÄîComite Ce≈øtriae Gladium Sancti Edwardi, qui Curtein dicitur, ant√® Regem baiulante in ≈øignum qu√≤d Comes e≈øt Palatii, & Regem (≈øi oberret) habeat de jure pote≈øtatem cohibendi; ≈øuo ≈øibi, ≈øcilicet Ce≈øtren≈øi, Con≈øtabulario mini≈øtrante, & Virg√¢ Populum (c√πm ≈øe inordinat√® ingereret) ≈øubtrahente.

This is the fir≈øt time, ≈øaith Selden in his Titles of Honour, pag. 641. ≈øpeaking of the Title of Earl-Palatine in England, that in expre≈øs words he found the Earl of Chester called Earl-Palatine; nor hath he ob≈øerved the word Palatine to be applied ≈øo with us, before Henry the Second's time, or thereabout.

For although the County of Che≈øter be frequently called a County Palatine, as well in our Laws, as in common Language, as Comitatus Palatinus, or Palantinus, or Counter-Paleys, corruptly for County-Paleis, as ≈øometimes it is in our Law-Books. And although indeed it be truly a County-Palatine, and hath ≈øo continued ever ≈øince the fir≈øt Gift to Hugh Lupus, unle≈øs we except the ≈øhort time whiles it was a Principality, Statute 21 Rich. 2. cap. 9. which was repealed 1 Hen. 4. cap. 3. Yet neither in their Summons to Parliament, nor in any other Writ directed to them, were they ≈øtiled Earl-Palatines: Neither do I ≈øee te≈øtimony to per≈øwade me, that when the fir≈øt Grant was made to Hugh Lupus, it was granted to him by the Name of Earl-Palatine.

But this Earldom being given him with ≈øuch Liberties and kind of Regal Juri≈ødiction, as Count Palatines of Territories in Foreign Parts had, it hath therefore ≈øince been called a County Palatine, and the Earls thereof Palatines. Now to be Earl Palatine, was to have the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a County or Earldom ad Regalem pote≈øtatem in omnibus under the King, as Bracton well expre≈ø≈øeth the ≈øame.

And to this day the County Palatine of Chester hath had a Chamberlain, who ≈øupplieth the Place of Chancellor; and al≈øo Ju≈øtices, before whom the Cau≈øes, which of their nature ≈øhould otherwi≈øe belong re≈øpectively to the Kings Bench and Common Pleas, are triable; a Baron of the Exchequer, a Sheriff, and other Officers, proportionable to tho≈øe of the Crown at We≈øtmin≈øter. See more of this County Palatine in my Lord Cook's Juri≈ødiction of Courts.

div.head: IV. The Wife of John Scot.
div.p: HE Married Helen Daughter of Lhewellin Prince of North-Wales, about Anno Domini 1222. 6 Hen. 3. This Marriage was concluded on, as a final Peace between Lhewellin and Randle ≈øirnamed Blundevill, Earl of Che≈øter. Knighton, pag. 2430.
Take here the Agreement about this Marriage, the original Deed whereof remained in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Somerford Oldfield E≈øquire, at Somerford in Che≈øhire, Anno Domini 1653.‚Äî

Haec e≈øt Conventio facta inter Dominum Ranulfum Comitem Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae, & Dominum Lhewellinum Principem Northwalliae; Qu√≤d Johannes do Scoti√¢, Nepos praedicti Comitis de Sorore ≈øu√¢ primogenit√¢, ducet in Uxorem Helenam Filiam ip≈øius Lhewelini: it√† qu√≤d dictus Lhewelinus dabit dicto Johanni in libero Maritagio totum Manerium de Budeford in Warewic√¢, & Manerium de Suttehele in Comitatu Wigorniae c√πm omnibus pertinentiis, ≈øic√πt Dominus Johannes Rex ea illi dedit in libero Maritagio: Et totum Manerium de Welneton in Comitatu Salopesburiae cum omnibus pertinentiis infr√† villam & extr√†. Habendum dicto Johanni, & haeredibus ≈øuis ex dict√¢ Helen√¢ provenientibus, ≈øic√πt idem Lhewelinus ea aliquo tempore meli√πs & integri√πs tenuit. Et praetere√† dabit eidem Johanni mille marcas Argenti, &c. Te≈øtibus Domino Reverendo Epi≈øcopo de Sancto A≈øaph, Domino H. Abbate Ce≈øtriae, Domino Hugone de La≈øci Comite Ultoniae, Philippo de Orreby t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, H. de Aldideley, Gualtero de Daivill, Ricardo Fitton, Edrevet Liagham, Edmundo Filio Righerit, Goronon Filio Edrevet, Helin Idhit, Magi≈øtro E≈øtruit, Magi≈øtro Ad√¢, Davide Clerico Lhewelini, Magi≈øtro H. & Clericis Domini Comitis Ce≈øtriae, & multis aliis.

div.head: V. The Death of John Scot.
div.p: THis John Scot, Earl of Che≈øter and Huntingdon, died without I≈ø≈øue, at the Abbey of Dernhale in Che≈øhire, the ≈øeventh day of June, Anno Domini 1237. 21 Hen. 3. not without ≈øu≈øpicion of being poy≈øoned by the contrivance of Helene his Wife, and was buried at Che≈øter, having been Earl of Che≈øter almo≈øt five years: for Matthew Paris ≈øaith, Anno 1237. 21 Hen. 3. Johannes Comes Cestriae, Uxore ≈øu√¢ Fili√¢ Leolini machinante, Potionatus diem clau≈øit extremum circ√† Penteco≈øten. With whom agrees Polychronicon, Wal≈øingham, and Knighton, pag. 2431.

Helene, the Widow of this John, ≈øirnamed The Scot, did afterwards Marry Robert de Quincy, third Son of Saher de Quincy Earl of Winchester. See Vincent upon Brook, pag. 260. Which Robert de Quincy died Anno Domini 1257. 41 Hen. 3. at the Ju≈øts or Torneament at Blie. Matth. Paris, put out by Wats 1640. pag. 942. And I find that Saher de Quincy, Earl of Winchester, had two Sons called Robert; Robert de Quincy, elde≈øt Son, Married Hawi≈øe, fourth Si≈øter and Coheir to Randle Earl of Che≈øter and Lincoln, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, by whom he had a Daughter called Margaret, Married to John Lacy, Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire and Baron of Halton, and after Earl of Lincoln in his Wifes
Right, as is before more fully proved in the I≈ø≈øue of Hugh Cyveliok Earl of Che≈øter. This Robert died in the Life-time of Saher his Father; which Saher died 1220. as Matthew Paris recordeth. Roger de Quincy, ≈øecond Son of Saher, ≈øucceeded his Father in the Earldom of Winche≈øter; and this Robert, third Son of Saher, who Married the Widow of John Scot.

VI. But this John the Scot having no I≈ø≈øue, King Henry the Third took the Earldom of Che≈øter into his own hands, and laid it to the Demaine of his Crown; and gave unto the Si≈øters of John the Scot other Lands, unwilling that ≈øo great an Inheritance as the Earldom of Che≈øter was, ≈øhould be divided (as the King him≈øelf ≈øaid) among Di≈øtaffs, Cambden's Britannia Printed 1607. pag. 464.

Now the Si≈øters were the≈øe; Margaret the elde≈øt, was the ≈øecond Wife of Alan de Galloway, Con≈øtable of Scotland, of whom he begot Derbergoille, Married to John Baliol of Bernards-Ca≈øtle in the Bi≈øhoprick of Durham, Founder of Baliol Colledge in Oxford, and died 1269. and was Father to John Baliol, ≈øometime King of Scotland, in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, King of England. I≈øabel, ≈øecond Si≈øter to John the Scot, Married Robert de Bruis. Maud, the third Si≈øter, died without I≈ø≈øue: and Alda or Ada, the fourth Si≈øter, Married Henry Ha≈øtings. Knighton, pag. 2431.

But the fir≈øt Wife of Alan de Galloway afore≈øaid, was the Daughter of Hugh Lacy of Ireland, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue three Daughters; Helen Married Roger de Quincy Earl of Winche≈øter, in who≈øe Right he was afterward Con≈øtable of Scotland, but had no I≈ø≈øue Male, onely three Daughters; Chri≈øtian, ≈øecond Daughter of Alan de Galloway by his fir≈øt Wife, Married William de Fortibus Earl of Albemarle; and Mary, third Daughter, died without I≈ø≈øue. Cambden's Britannia Printed 1607‚ñ™ pag. 693. Matthew Paris, put out by Wats 1764. pag. 430. where al≈øo it appears, that in Anno 1236. Alan had a Brother named Thomas, and al≈øo a Ba≈øtard Son called Thomas, who by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of their great Allies ≈øought by force to po≈ø≈øe≈øs them≈øelves of Galloway in Scotland, which the King of Scotland had di≈øtributed to the three Daughters and Heirs of Alan; but the≈øe Rebels were beaten and di≈øper≈øed by the King of Scotland, Anno 1236.

But to return to our Earls of Che≈øter. The Line of the ancient Earls of Che≈øter now failing, this Earldom was by King Henry the Third taken into his own hands, Anno Domini 1237. 21 Hen. 3. It remains that I now ≈øhew the Earls of Che≈øter of the Royal Blood ≈øince this time, which in the next Chapter I ≈øhall briefly reckon up.

And ob≈øerve, that the County of Flint appertaineth to the Dignity of the Sword of the Earls of Che≈øter; and that the County Palatine of Che≈øter is ≈øtill pre≈øerved in the Crown, as a County Palatine, if there be no Creation of the Prince into the Title of Earl of Che≈øter. If the King's elde≈øt Son be created Prince of Wales, then u≈øually is the Title of Earl of Che≈øter al≈øo conferred with it; but upon the death of every Prince ≈øo created, the≈øe Titles are pre≈øerved in the Crown till a new Creation.

div.head: The≈øe Notes following I had from Mr. Dugdale.
div.p: HElen, the Widow of John the Scot, held the≈øe Lands following, till a Dower was a≈ø≈øigned out, viz. Fotheringhay and Jarwell in Northampton≈øhire; Kewe≈øton, in Bedford≈øhire; Totnam in Middle≈øex; Bramton, Conington, and Limpays, in Huntington≈øhire; Bado in E≈ø≈øex; and Exton in Rutland≈øhire Clau≈ø. 22 Hen. 3. memb. 20.

div.head: The Sisters of John Scot had the≈øe Lands following.
div.p: Devergoil, Daughter of Margaret, elde≈øt Si≈øter of John, had the Mannors of Luddington and Tork≈øey in Lincoln≈øhire, with the Farm of Yarmouth in Norfolk. Tower of London Pat. 22 Hen. 3. memb. 11.
I≈øabel had Writtell and Hathfield in E≈ø≈øex. Maude, the third Si≈øter, died without i≈ø≈øue. Pat. 22 Hen. 3. mem. 4.

Ada, the fourth Si≈øter, had Brom≈øgrove in Worcester≈øhire, Bol≈øover in Derby≈øhire, the
Mannor and Ca≈øtle,O≈øwaldesbeck in Nottingham≈øhire. See Stat. 32 H 8. cap. 29. the Mannor and Sok of Maunsfield in Nottingham≈øhire, and O≈øwardbeck Wapentake; and Wurfield, Stratton, and Cundover in Shrop≈øhire; Wigginton and Wolverhampton in Stafford≈øhire. Pat. 22 Hen. 3. memb. 4. Clau≈ø. 22 Hen. 3. mem. 12.

After this, to wit 31 Hen. 3. the Earldom of Che≈øter, with the Ca≈øtles of Gannok and Di≈øart
Di≈øart Ca≈øtle is in Denhigh≈øhire. , in the Borders of Wales, were annexed to the Crown for ever. Pat. 31 Hen. 3. mem. 7.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: Of the Titles of Prince of Wales and Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øince they were inve≈øted in the Crown of England, and who have been ≈øo created, with the time of their Creation.

div.p: I. KIng Henry the Third brought Lhewellin, Prince of North-Wales, into Subjection, and made Peace with Lhewellin, Anno Domini 1228. 12 Hen. 3. upon Condition that Lhewellin and his Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhould be called Princes, and do Homage to the Kings of England: Whereupon King Henry received from him three thou≈øand Marks. Knighton, pag. 2436. And then King Henry made a Charter to Lhewellin, which was confirmed by the Pope.

Anno 25 Hen. 3. 1241. David the Son of Lhewellin obligeth him≈øelf to King Henry, to hold all his Lands in Capite of the King, and to free his elder Brother Griffith
Stowe ≈øaith Griffith was a Ba≈øtard Son of Lhewellin, pag. 185., and Owen the elde≈øt Son of Griffith, out of Pri≈øon, whom he had unju≈øtly detained; and that the Land of Engle≈ømere ≈øhould remain to King Henry and his Heirs.
