Mat. Paris, put out by Wats, pag. 625 and yet did this David acknowledge to hold his Lands in Wales of the Pope, endeavouring to ≈øhake off the Yoke of his Fealty to the Kings of England: and Griffith promi≈øed by Sureties, if he obtained his portion of the Lands due unto him, to pay 300 Marks yearly to King Henry and to his Heirs for ever.
Now David rebelled, and after much perplexity and de≈øtruction of his Lands in Wales by King Henry, he died Anno 1246.

King Henry the Third, Anno Domini 1254. 38 Hen. 3. gave Wales to his elde≈øt Son Prince Edward, by the Name of‚Äîun√† c√πm Conque≈øtu no≈øtro Walliae; as al≈øo Ga≈øcony, Ireland, and ≈øome other Territories recited in the Charter: This was upon the Marriage of Prince Edward with Elinour, Si≈øter to Alphon≈øo King of Spain: Yet (≈øaith Selden) notwith≈øtanding the Grant of Wales, I find no warrant that therefore the ≈øpecial Title of Prince of Wales, as it belongs to the Son and Heir Apparent, began in this Prince Edward. Selden's Tit. Hon. pag. 594. Matthew We≈øtmin≈øter, ≈øub Anno 1254. Al≈øo Matthew Paris, put out by Wats 1640. pag 890. Nor were the ancient Princes of Wales of the Briti≈øh Blood at this time quite extinct: for Wales was not ab≈øolutely ≈øubdued till this Prince Edward was King of England; Scilic√®t 1283. 11 Edw. 1. So Stowe. Neither did this Edward, whiles he was Prince, ever a≈ø≈øume the Title of Prince of Wales, as far forth as I can find.

And for the Earldom of Che≈øter, Cambden ≈øaith it was given by Henry the Third to this Prince Edward, who, being taken Pri≈øoner by the Barons, ≈øurrendred it up to Simon de Monifort Earl of Leyce≈øter, that he the Prince might be redeemed; Sed Simone ≈øtatim interfecto, ad Regiam Familiam cit√≤ rediit. Cambden's Britannia, Tit. Che≈øhire, ad finem.

And indeed by the Charter of Maxfield, Dated 45 Hen. 3. 1261. This Prince Edward ≈øeems to be po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the County of Che≈øter. Howbeit, in this Charter, and all others that I have ≈øeen, he u≈øeth onely the Title of‚ÄîEdwardus illu≈øtris Regis Angliae Primogenitus, and not at all the Title of Comes Ce≈øtriae,

The Charter made to Simon de Montfort of the Earldom of Che≈øter, bears Date 24 die Decembris, 49 Hen. 3. 1264. at Wood≈øtock. Vincent upon Brook, pag 108. whereunto the King was forced to make his Peace: for both the King, and Prince Edward his Son, were then Pri≈øoners to Simon, taken at the Battel of Lewis in Su≈ø≈øex, 12 die Maii, 48 Hen. 3. 1264. See Stowe. Yet Simon enjoyed it but a little ≈øpace; for he was ≈ølain at the Battel of Eve≈øham, the fourth day of Augu≈øt, 49 Hen. 3. 1265. and then all Montfort's E≈øtate was forfeited by his Rebellion; and ≈øo the Earldom of Che≈øter reverted back to Henry the Third: And I have ≈øeen the Copy of the Deed whereby Prince Edward confirms to the Barons of Che≈øhire, all the Liberties which Randle, ≈øometime Earl of Chester, had formerly granted unto them by his Charter; and in this he is onely ≈øtiled‚ÄîEdwardus illustris Regis Angliae Primogenitus, Dated 27 die Augu≈øti, 49 Hen. 3. which is but 23 Days after the Battel of Eve≈øham: ≈øo that the Prince ≈øoon had the Earldom again; but I find not that he ever u≈øed the Title of Earl of Che≈øter.

div.head: II. A Catalogue of all ≈øuch Princes of England, as have been created Princes of Wales and Earls of Che≈øter, and u≈øed the≈øe Titles.
div.p: 1. EDward of Caernarven, fourth Son of King Edward the Fir≈øt, born at Caernarven in Wales, the twenly fifth of April 1284. was Summoned to the Parliament, Anno 1303. 32 Edw. 1. being now the King's elde≈øt Son living, by the Name of Edward Prince of Wales and Earl of Chester, Our mo≈øt dear Son. Selden's Tit. Hon. pag. 594. and was afterwards King of England, by the Name of King Edward the Second.

2. Edward of Wind≈øor, elde≈øt Son of King Edward the Second, born at Wind≈øor Ca≈øtle, 13 die Novembris 1312. 6 Edw. 2. had onely the Title of Earl of Che≈øter and Flint in his Summons to the Parliament, 1322. 15 Edw. 2. being then ≈øcarce ten years old. Cambden's Britannia, Edita 1607. pag. 118. He was al≈øo Duke of Aquitain, and Earl of Pontive, created 19 Edw. 2. 1325. Selden's Tit. Hon. pag. 599. and Stowe; and was (after he had depo≈øed his Father) King of England, by the Name of King Edward the Third; Crowned February 1. 1326.

3. Edward of Wood≈øtock, commonly called The Black Prince, elde≈øt Son of King Edward the Third, born 15 Junii, 1330. 4 Edw. 3. was made Earl of Che≈øter 7 Edw. 3. I find him ≈øtiled‚ÄîEdwardus illu≈øtris Regis Angliae Filius, Comes Ce≈øtriae, in a Writ at Che≈øter, Dated 13 die Aprilis. 9 Edw. 3. 1335. R. num. 18.

He was created Duke of Cornwall by Patent, Dated 17 die Martii, 11 Edw. 3. 1336. Habendum ≈øibi, & haeredum ≈øuorum Regum Angliae Filiis Primogenitis:
Per ip≈øum Regem, & totum Con≈øilium in Parliamento. Selden's Tit. Hon. pag. 752. And he was the fir≈øt Duke in England, as that Title was now made a di≈øtinct Dignity; and by this Creation, not onely the fir≈øt-born Son of the Kings of England, but the elde≈øt living, are always Dukes of Cornwall, neither needed any new Creation of this Title, although ≈øometimes we find it joyned with the Creation of the Title of Prince of Wales and Earl of Che≈øter. Selden's Tit. Hon. qag. 754.

He was al≈øo created Prince of Wales by Patent, Dated 12 die Maii, 17 Edw. 3. 1343. Habendum ≈øibi, & haeredibus ≈øuis Regibus Angliae in perpetu√πm: Per ip≈øum Regem.
Selden's Tit. Hon. pag. 595. And ≈øince this time the Title of Earl of Che≈øter hath been u≈øually joyned with that of Prince of Wales in the Patent. Selden ibidem, pag. 598.
So that now the Black Prince was Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornwall, and Earl of Che≈øter.
In the 40. of Edward the Third, his Stile was ‚ÄîPrinceps Aquitaniae & Walliae, Dux Cornubiae, & Comes Ce≈øtriae, Lib. C. fol. 181. w. He died June 8. 1376. 50 Ed. 3. in the Life-time of his Father.

4. Richard of Burdeaux, Son and Heir to the Black Prince, was created Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornwall, and Earl of Che≈øter, by his Grandfather King Edward the Third, in Fe≈øto Sancti Michaelis, 1376. 50 Edw. 3. Stowe. But Wal≈øingham names onely the
Title of Earl of Che≈øter in Parliament, 1376. pag. 190. Others ≈øay he was after created Prince of Wales at Haveringe, 20 Novembris, 50 Edw. 3. Powel on the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 385. He had a ≈øpecial Charter for Duke of Cornwall, Anno 50 Edw. 3. Cooks Reports, lib. 8. fol. 30. for he was not elde≈øt Son of the King, his Father dying before he enjoyed the Crown. This Richard was afterwards King of England, by the Name of King Richard the Second. And in Anno 1397. he erected the Earldom of Che≈øter into a Principality, and ordained that no Grant ≈øhould be made thereof to any Per≈øon but to the King's elde≈øt Son onely, if it plea≈øe the King to make him. See Stat. 21 Rich. 2. cap. 9. But this Parliament was wholly Repealed, 1 Hen. 4. cap. 3. which Henry depo≈øed Richard the Second, and made him≈øelf King, 1399.

5. Henry, elde≈øt Son of Henry the Fourth, born at Monmouth Anno 1388. was created Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornwall, and Earl of Che≈øter, about October 1 Hen. 4. 1399. in Parliament; and not long after was created Duke of Aquitain in the ≈øame Parliament, Stowe; and was afterwards King of England, by the Name of King Henry the Fifth. F. num. 99.

6. Edward, onely Child of King Henry the Sixth, born at We≈øtmin≈øter, 13 Octobris 1452. 31 Hen. 6. Fabian, pag. 456. He was created Prince of Wales and Earl of Che≈øter in Parliament, March 15. 31 Hen. 6. 1452. and was murthered at the Battel of Teuksbery, May 4. 1471. 11 Edw. 4. See Vincent upon Brook, pag. 143, He was al≈øo Duke of Cornwall by De≈øcent.
King Henry the Sixth was never created Prince of Wales, nor Earl of Che≈øter; he was King whiles he was but an Infant of eight Months old.

7. Edward, elde≈øt Son of King Edward the Fourth, born at We≈øtmin≈øter November 4. 1470. 10 Edw. 4. was created Prince of Wales, and Earl of Che≈øter, July 26. 1471. 11 Edw. 4. Vincent upon Brook, pag. 115. and in Anno 19 Edw. 4. He was made Earl of Pembroke and March. He was al≈øo Duke of Cornwall, and ≈øo Entituled; and was afterwards King Edward the Fifth, but was mo≈øt barbarou≈øly murthered in the Tower by the procurement of his Uncle Richard Duke of Gloce≈øter, Anno 1483. who u≈øurped the Crown to him≈øelf.

8. Edward, the onely Child of King Richard the Third, created Earl of Salisbury, 1477. 17 Edw. 4. was al≈øo created Prince of Wales and Earl of Che≈øter, by his Father, Augu≈øt 24. 1483. 1 Rich. 3. being then about ten years old, and died about March 1484. in the Life-time of his Father.

9. Arthur, elde≈øt Son of King Henry the Seventh, created Prince of Wales, and Earl of Che≈øter,
November 30. in 1489. 5 Hen. 7. and died without I≈ø≈øue at Ludlow, in April 1502. 17 Hen. 7. about the Age of ≈øixteen Years, in the Life-time of his Father. He was al≈øo Duke of Cornwall by Birth.

10. Henry Duke of York, ≈øecond Son of King Henry the Seventh, after the Death of his Brother Arthur, was created Prince of Wales and Earl of Che≈øter, February 18. 1502. 18 Hen. 7. at the Age of eleven Years; and was afterwards King of England by the Name of King Henry the Eighth.

11. Henry Stewart, elde≈øt Son of James King of Great Britain, was created Prince of Wales and Earl of Che≈øter, in Parliament, June 4. 1610. 8 Jacobi, and died November 6. 1612. 10 Jacobi, without I≈ø≈øue, in the Life-time of King James his Father. He was al≈øo Duke of Cornwall by Birth.

list.head: A ≈øummary Collection of the Earls of Che≈øter contained in this ≈øecond Part.
list.item: 1. GHerbod, a Nobleman of Flanders, had the Earldom of Che≈øter given him by the Conqueror about the Year of Chri≈øt 1068. but going into Flanders, was there taken Pri≈øoner. And then did William the Conqueror give the Earldom of Che≈øter to Hugh, ≈øirnamed Lupus, Anno Domini 1070.
2. Hugh, ≈øirnamed Lupus, Earl of Auranches in Normandy, was made Earl of Che≈øter, Anno 1070. He died July 27. 1101. after he had held the Earldom of Che≈øter 31 Years.

3. Richard, the onely Child of Hugh Lupus by his Wife, was but ≈øeven Years old when his Father died. He was drowned with many others, as he was Sailing from Normandy towards England, Anno 1120. after he had been Earl 18 Years; but had no I≈ø≈øue.
4. Randle de Mecinis, or Me≈øchines, Son of Maud, Si≈øter to Hugh Lupus, ≈øucceeded Earl of Che≈øter, as Co≈øin and next Heir to Richard: And he died Anno 1128. having been Earl eight Years.
5. Randle the Second, ≈øirnamed Gernouns, Son of Randle de Me≈øchines, ≈øucceeded his Father. He died Anno Domini 1153, having been Earl 25 Years.
6. Hugh the Second, ≈øirnamed Cyveliok, Son of Randle the Second, ≈øucceeded his Father: And he died Anno Domini 1181. having been Earl 28 Years.

7. Randle the Third, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, Son of Hugh the Second, ≈øucceeded his Father in the Earldom of Che≈øter. He was al≈øo made Earl of Lincoln 1217. and died at Wallingford in the latter end of October, Anno Domini 1232. without I≈ø≈øue, and was Earl of Che≈øter 51 Years.

8. John, ≈øirnamed The Scot, Earl of Huntingdon, Son of Maud, elde≈øt Si≈øter and Coheir to Randle the Third, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, ≈øucceeded Earl of Che≈øter, and died at Dernhale Abbey without I≈ø≈øue, June 7. 1237. having been Earl of Che≈øter almo≈øt five Years: from which time this Earldom was ≈øeized to the Crown of England.

argument.p: Treating of the ancient Barons to the Earls of Che≈øter, with ≈øeveral Catalogues of all the Bi≈øhops, Deans, Chamberlains, Judges, Sheriffs, and E≈øcheators of Che≈øhire, and al≈øo of the Recorders of the City of Che≈øter.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.p: Of the ancient Barons to the Earls of Che≈øter.

div.p: I. COncerning the ancient Barons to the Earls of Che≈øter, of whom I promi≈øed before to ≈øpeak in this third Part of my Book, the≈øe things I have principally to Di≈øcu≈øs and Illu≈øtrate; the true notion of their Title, the time of their In≈øtitution, their Office, Place, and number.

II. For the true notion of their Title, Selden tells us in his Titles of Honour, pag. 688. that the noble≈øt and greate≈øt Tenants to the greater ≈øort of Subjects, had anciently the Appellation of Barons a≈øcribed to them, e≈øpecially tho≈øe to the Earls of Che≈øter.

Spelman in his Glo≈ø≈øary deriveth the word Baro from the old Engli≈øh-Saxon Per or Wer, and of later Times written Par; Francis Antiquis, Ber, ≈øignifying the ≈øame with the Latine word Vir; Glo≈ø≈øarium Latino-Gallicum, Ber, Bara, Vir; ≈øo that the Latine word Vir ≈øeems to be the original Fountain whence it ≈øprings. And both the≈øe words Baro, by ≈øome written Varo, and Vir, do agree in their ≈øeveral ≈øignifications; ≈øometimes for a Man barely and ab≈øolutely; ≈øometimes for a Man of Worth, Power, or Prowe≈øs; ≈øometimes for a Husband.

For the notion of the word here, it denotes as much as Magnates or Optimates: where we may ob≈øerve, That Noblemen, or Barons, ≈øeem to be a nece≈ø≈øary Supplement, as e≈ø≈øential to the Royalty of a Count Palatine: for the Earl of Che≈øter having Royal Authority within him≈øelf, we may not unfitly ≈øtile him a petty King: And that the Maje≈øty of his Palace may be an≈øwerable to a King, he mu≈øt have Noblemen about him, in imitation of the Barons of the Kingdom. Hence al≈øo the Earls of Che≈øter ≈øubtuted Offices, making the Baron of Halton Con≈øtable in Che≈øhire in Fee, in imitation of the Lord High-Con≈øtable of England; and making the Baron of Montalt Steward of Che≈øhire in Fee, after the example of the Lord High-Steward of England. The≈øe Barons under the Earl Ruled and Governed the County; and from their great Power and Sway, had the Appellation of Barons.

III. As to the time of their fir≈øt In≈øtitution, I find the Great Men of Che≈øhire about
the Earl, ≈øtiled Barons in the time of Hugh Lupus: In the Charter of his Foundation of the Mona≈øtery of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, Anno 1093. 6 Willielmi Rufi, in the conclu≈øion thereof it is ≈øaid,‚ÄîEgo Comes Hugo & mei Barones confirmavimus i≈øta omnia cor√†m An≈øelmo Archiepi≈øcopo, &c. Neither mu≈øt we fondly imagine or expect any formal Creation of them, either by Patent (for ≈øuch are of later Times by much,) or any ≈øolemn Inve≈øture. But (as I conceive) upon the conferring of the Earldom of Che≈øter on Hugh Lupus by the Conqueror, Anno Domini 1070. the principal Gentlemen and Commanders under Earl Hugh, being called to advi≈øe and a≈ø≈øi≈øt the ≈øaid Earl (either in any time of imminent danger, or in regulating and ordering the more weighty Affairs of the County) were of cour≈øe ≈øo ≈øtiled: and thus I conceive they retained the Name of Barons by little and little, after the manner of the Great Nobles of the Realm.
IV. And hence may we gue≈ø≈øe their Office, Ade≈ø≈øe Comiti in Concilio, as Cambden hath it, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Earl in Council upon all grand De≈øigns and Affairs.
V. Concerning their Place of Precedence and Dignity, we mu≈øt con≈øider them either in relation to others, or among them≈øelves.

In relation to others out of the County, I conceive them inferior to the rank of the Barons of our Realm; for the≈øe are but titularly or analogically Barons (as I may ≈øo ≈øpeak) to tho≈øe of the Kingdom; nay, in Place beneath all Knights: but they were the greate≈øt Men in the County under the Earl for Power and E≈øtate.

Their Priority or Dignity among them≈øelves we ≈øhall trace as exactly as we can, in ≈øo remote and ob≈øcure a Path. Some would have the Baron of Malpas to be the prime Baron, fora≈ømuch as Robert Fitz-Hugh (who was Baron of Malpas under Hugh Lupus in the Conqueror's time) hath for the mo≈øt part the preeminence in the Sub≈øcription of old Charts of tho≈øe ancient Times, as al≈øo in the Record of Dooms-day Book, where among all the re≈øt of the Barons he is put down fir≈øt next after the Earl; and by which it appears al≈øo that he held more Land in this County than any one of the re≈øt, except William Malbedenge. But this Difficulty is ea≈øily removed, if we con≈øider the uncertainty of Sub≈øcription of Witne≈ø≈øes; but e≈øpecially admitting him to be the prime Baron, till certain Offices were annexed to other Barons: After which time the matter is without controver≈øie; for William Fitz-Nigell, Baron of Halton, being made Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire in Fee, carries it clear by his Office annexed to his Barony. And for further ≈øatisfaction take this Charter, remaining in one of the Couchir Books in the Dutchy-Office at Gray's-Inne, London; Scilic√®t Tom. 1. Comitatus Ce≈øtriae, num. 2. fol. 41. which Deed was made in the Reign of King Stephen by Randle the Second, ≈øirnamed Gernouns, to Eu≈øtace Fitz-John, who Married the elder Daughter and Coheir to William Fitz-Nigell: for William the younger died without I≈ø≈øue.

RANULFUS Comes Ce≈øtriae, Epi≈øcopo Ce≈øtriae, Dapifero, Baronibus, Ju≈øticiariis, Ca≈øtellanis, Vice-comitibus, Mini≈øtris & Ballivis, & omnibus hominibus ≈øuis Francis & Anglis, Clericis & Laicis, Salutem. Proculdubi√≤ Scitote me reddidi≈ø≈øe & dedi≈ø≈øe Eu≈øtachio Filio Johannis totum honorem qui fuit Willielmi Filii Nigelli Con≈øtabularii Ce≈øtriae, in rebus & dignitatibus omnibus: Et ip≈øum Eu≈øtachium con≈øtitui≈ø≈øe haereditari√® Con≈øtabularium, & Supremum Con≈øiliarium po≈øt me ≈øup√®r omnes Optimates & Barones totius terrae meae: Ea propt√®r volo & firmit√®r praecipio, de ≈øic√πt ei rectum ≈øuum reddidi & donavi, & conce≈ø≈øi Con≈øtabulariam & honorem integrum Con≈øtabulariae Ce≈øtriae & totius terrae meae; qu√≤d in omnibus rationabilit√®r ei intendatis ≈øicut Corpori meo: Proind√® Praecipio, qu√≤d ip≈øe Eu≈øtachius & haeredes ≈øui de me & de haeredibus meis praedictum honorem & terram, & tenuram totam pertinentem eidem honori ≈øcilic√®t Con≈øtabulariae, teneat it√† ben√® & honorific√®, & liber√® & quiet√®, ≈øic√πt unqu√†m Willielmus Nigelli Filius meli√πs & liberi√πs tenuit, & ≈øic√πt Willielmus Con≈øtabularius ejus Filius in vit√¢ ≈øu√¢ honorabili√πs tenuit, & die qu√¢ fuit vivus & mortuus: Teneat eti√†m it√† liber√® & quiet√®, ≈øic√πt unqu√†m Willelmus Filius Nigelli tenebat in tempore Comitis Hugonis, & Comitis Ricardi, & tempore Patris mei Ranulfi, in vill√¢ & extr√†, in foro & mercato, in bo≈øco & plano, in pratis & pa≈øcuis, in viis & Semitis, in Forestis, in molendinis
& aquis, in Pi≈øcariis & Stagnis, & in omnibus aliis locis, c√πm Socc√¢ & Sacc√¢, & Tol & Theam, Infangetheof, & c√πm Sciris & Hundredis, & c√πm omnibus con≈øuetudinibus, & libertatibus omnibus & quietantiis. Te≈øtibus Willielmo Comite Lincolniae, & Willielmo de Percei, & Tur≈øtano Bane≈øter, & Simone Filio Willielmi, & Normanno de Verdon, & Ricardo Pincern√¢, & Roberto Ba≈ø≈øet, & Simone de Tu≈øchet, & Gaufrido Di≈øpen≈øatore, & Ivone Con≈øtabulario de Coventri√¢, Ricardo de Vernon, Walchelino Mamicoc, Hugone de Nueris, Rogero de Maletoc, & VVillielmo Malebenge, Hugone de Sancto Paulo, & VVillielmo de Vecy, & Huberto de Muntehan, & Rogero Flamiagvill, & VVillielmo Filio Guerii, Reginaldo Ba≈ø≈øet, & VVillielmo Capellano & Herveo Filio VVillielmi, & VVillielmo Capellano Comitis Ce≈øtriae, & Rogero Filio Ricardi, & Gi≈øleberto de Aquil√¢. Apud Coventriam.

By this Charter you find fir≈øt the words Optimates & Barones explaining and expounding one another. Next you have the Preheminence given to the Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire (who was the Baron of Halton) above all the other Barons of the Earl: and this appears al≈øo in the form of all the Charters made by the Earls of Che≈øter in tho≈øe ancient Times, where the Stile runs‚ÄîRanulfus Comes Ce≈øtriae Con≈øtabulario, Dapifero, Baronibus, &c. Salutem: where the Con≈øtable is fir≈øt named, then the Steward, then the Barons in general; onely in this Chart above≈øaid the Con≈øtable is omitted, in regard he was Party to the Deed, and in who≈øe room it is directed to the Bi≈øhop; But Dapifero follows in his proper place: So that the Con≈øtable had the fir≈øt place, the Steward next after him, and then the other Barons followed in their order. And in this order they are ranked by Cambden and Spelman:
1. Baro de Halton. He was High-Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire in Fee.
2. Baro de Monte alto. He was High-Steward of Che≈øhire in Fee.
3. Baro de VVich-Maldebeng (id e≈øt) Nant-wich.
4. Baro de Malpas.
5. Baro de Shibbroke.
6. Baro de Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øie.
7. Baro de Kinderton.
8. Baro de Stockport.

According to this order I think little ≈øcruple can be made, unle≈øs it be for the Barony of Malpas, why he ≈øhould not precede the Baron of VVich-Malbeng, notwith≈øtanding the Offices annexed to the two fir≈øt Barons. Now the I≈ø≈øue of Robert Fitz-Hugh failing (who was the fir≈øt Baron of Malpas,) another came in his room of as di≈øtinct a Stock and Linage; but where or how to be placed, let the more curious determine, I have here placed him next after the Baron of VVich-Malbeng.

VI For the number of the≈øe Che≈øhire Barons, it is not yet ≈øufficiently agreed. Spelman in his Glo≈ø≈øary on the word Baro, with its ≈øeveral Notions, ≈øaith thus:‚ÄîAb Hugone Lupo in≈øtitutos e≈ø≈øe Barones certum e≈øt: Sed de numero non it√† convenit: Quidam XII a≈ø≈øerunt, ip≈øumqu√® Conque≈øtorem Hugoni Per≈øua≈øi≈ø≈øe ut pauciores non crearet; Pollicitus ≈øe largiturum eis idonea Patrimonia in Angli√¢, ≈øi Comes hoc nequivit in ≈øu√¢ Patri√¢: Reperiuntur ver√≤ (de quibus praecipu√® con≈øtat) octo tant√πm. Nam quos alii Suggerunt, ≈øu≈øpecti habentur.

item.hi: Nigellus‚ÄîBaro de Halton: [≈øeu poti√πs VVillielmus Filius Nigelli.]

list.item: Robert de Monte alto was not Baron till the end of Hen. 1. or beginning of King Stephen; but the re≈øt, except Stockport, were Barons in the Conqueror's time, and ≈øo was the Ance≈øtor of this Robert. Robertus‚ÄîBaro de Monte alto.

div.p: But for the better clearing of this Point, it is certain that in the Conquerour's time there were ≈øome other Barons and Men of eminency about the Earl, than what are here reckoned up; but the≈øe are all, who≈øe Heirs and Po≈øterity have been certainly known, and accounted Barons by long continuance to the ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Earls of Che≈øter: And of all the≈øe, their Names and Families were long ≈øince extinct, except the Line of Gilbert Venables, who≈øe Name and Family continueth at this day, and is yet commonly ≈øtiled Baron of Kinderton; all the re≈øt, with their whole Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, are devolved to other Per≈øons and Families, by Marriage of their ≈øeveral Daughters and Heirs, and ≈øo became extinct long time ago.

And if any ask me what other Barons were in the time of Hugh Lupus? I an≈øwer: Robert of Rothelent was one of Earl Hugh's Barons, and not the meane≈øt; for he was the principal Commander of all the Forces in Che≈øhire, and the prime Governour of the County under Earl Hugh his Co≈øin. Ordericus, pag. 670. But we find no mention of his Po≈øterity in ≈øucceeding Ages among us, and therefore not reckoned as a Baron among tho≈øe, who≈øe Heirs and Po≈øterity have by long continuance obtained the Title and Honour, as it were hereditarily, under the ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Earls: And the like perhaps may be ≈øaid of ≈øome others.

Neither mu≈øt I here forget a touch of Vincent (who≈øe Corrections need a Corrector) in his Review of York's ≈øecond Edition, pag. 661, 662, where he ≈øaith, That he believes the Barons of Che≈øhire are not ≈øo ancient as the time of Hugh Lupus. But whether he believe it or no, it is mo≈øt certain they were ≈øtiled Barons in the Charter of Hugh Lupus, of the Foundation of the Mona≈øtery of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, Anno 1093. which Charter I have at large tran≈øcribed above in the ≈øecond Part of this Book.

VII. As to the Baron of Stockport, mentioned in the la≈øt place by Spelman, it is much to be doubted whether he were any of the ancient Barons to the Earls of Che≈øter; howbeit his Arms are put up in the Exchequer at Che≈øter among the Barons: but all tho≈øe Arms were but of late times put up there, and where the Baron of Monte-alto is mo≈øt unju≈øtly placed above the Baron of Halton.

It is certain, that in Dooms-day Book we find not any Per≈øon that held Stockport; whereby it may ≈øeem then to be wa≈øte and not inhabited. And as concerning Sir Richard de Stockport and his Family, we find little or no mention before the Reign of Henry the Third, in which King's Reign the ancient Earls of Che≈øter were extinct: So that the Family of Stockport could be none of the ancient Barons.

VIII. I ≈øhall conclude this Chapter with the Charter of Randle the Third, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, to his Barons of Che≈øhire, made about the Year of Chri≈øt 1218. granting them many Priviledges, tran≈øcribed by me out of a little Parchment Book in Quarto, remaining among the Records in the Dutchy-Office at Gray's-Inne, London, Fol. 107.

RANULFUS Comes Ce≈øtriae, Con≈øtabulario, Dapifero, Ju≈øticiario, Vicecomiti, Baronibus, Ballivis, & omnibus Hominibus ≈øuis & Amicis, prae≈øentibus & futuris, prae≈øentem Chartam in≈øpecturis & audituris, Salutem. Sciatis me Cruce ≈øignatum pro amore Dei, & ad Petitionem Baronum meorum Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe eis & haeredibus ≈øuis, de me & haeredibus meis, omnes libertates in prae≈øenti Chart√¢ ≈øub≈øcriptas in perpetu√πm tenendas & habendas: Scilic√®t, quod unusqui≈øque eorum Curiam ≈øuam habeat liberam de omnibus Placitis & quaerelis in Curi√¢ me√¢ motis, Exceptis Placitis ad Gladium meum Pertinentibus: Et qu√≤d ≈øi quis hominum ≈øuorum pro aliquo delicto captus fuerit per Dominium ≈øuum, ≈øin√® redemptione replegietur: It√† qu√≤d Dominus ≈øuus eum perducat ad tres Comitatus; & eum quietum reducat, ni≈øi Sacraber eum Sequatur: Et ≈øi aliquis Adventitius (qui fidelis ≈øit) in terras eorum venerit, & ei placuerit ibid√®m morari, liceat Baroni ip≈øum habere & retinere, ≈øalvis mihi Advocariis qui Sponte ad me venerint, & aliis qui pro Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øu aliund√® ad Dognitatem meam venerint, & non eis: Et unu≈øqui≈øque Baronum, d√πm opus fuerit, in Werr√¢ plenari√® faciat Servitium tot Feodorum militum quot tenet: Et eorum milites & liber√® tenentes loricas aut Haubergella habeant, & Feoda ≈øua per Corpora ≈øua defendant, lic√®t milites non ≈øint: Et ≈øi aliquis
eorum talis ≈øit, quod terram ≈øuam per Corpus ≈øuum defendere non po≈ø≈øit, alium ≈øufficientem in loco ≈øuo ponere po≈ø≈øet: Nec ego Nativos eorum ad arma jurare faciam, ≈øed Nativos ≈øuos qui p√®r Ranulfum de Davenham ad advocationem meam venerint, & alios Nativos ≈øuos (qu√≥s ≈øuos e≈ø≈øe rationabilit√®r mon≈øtrare poterant) ip≈øos quietos Concedo: Et ≈øi Vicecomes meus, aut aliquis Serviens, in Curi√¢ me√¢ aliquem Hominum ≈øuorum inculpaverit, Per Thiertnic ≈øe defendere poterit propt√®r Shirife-Tooth, quod reddunt ni≈øi Secta eum ≈øequatur: Concedo eti√†m eis quietantiam de Garbis & Oblationibus, quas Servientes mei & Bedelli exigere ≈øolebant: Et qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis Judex aut Sectarius Hundredi aut Comitatus in Curi√¢ me√¢ Mi≈øericordiam inciderit, per duos ≈øolidos quietus ≈øit Judex de Mi≈øericordi√¢, & Sectarius per duodecem denarios: Concedo eti√†m eis libertatem a≈ø≈øertandi terras ≈øuas infr√† divi≈øas Agriculturae ≈øuae in Fore≈øt√¢: Et ≈øi Landa aut Terra infra divi≈øas villae ≈øuae fuerit, quae pri√πs culta fuit ubi nemus non cre≈øcat, Liceat eis illam colere ≈øin√® herbergatione: Et liceat eis Housbote & Haybote in nemore ≈øuo Capere de omni genere Bo≈øci ≈øin√® vi≈øu Fore≈øtarii: Et mortuum ≈øuum Bo≈øcum dare aut vendere cui voluerint: Et Homines eorum non implacitentur de Fore≈øt√¢ de ≈øuperdicto, ni≈øi c√πm manuopere inveniantur: Et unu≈øqui≈øque omnia Maneria ≈øua Dominica in Comitatu & Hundredo, per unum Sene≈øchallum prae≈øentem defendere po≈ø≈øit: Concedo eti√†m qu√≤d mortuo viro Uxor ≈øua per quadraginta dies pacem habeat in Domo ≈øu√¢, & haeres ≈øuus (≈øi aetatem habuerit) per rationabile relevium haereditatem ≈øuam habeat; ≈øcilic√®t feodum militis per centum ≈øolidos; neque Domina, neque Haeres maritetur, ubi di≈øparagetur; ≈øed per gratum & a≈ø≈øen≈øum Generis ≈øui maritetur: Et eorum Legata teneantur: Et nullus eorum nativum ≈øuum amittat occa≈øione ≈øi in Civitate Ce≈øtriae venerit, ni≈øi ibi man≈øerit per unum annum & unum diem ≈øin√® Calumni√¢: Et propt√®r grave Servitium quod in Ce≈øter≈øhiria faciunt, nullus eorum extr√† Limam Servitium mihi faciat ni≈øi per Gratum ≈øuum & ad Cu≈øtum meum. Et ≈øi milites mei de Anglia Summoniti fuerint, qui mihi Wardam apud Ce≈øtriam debent, & venti ≈øunt ad Wardam ≈øuam faciendam, & exercitus aliund√® inimicorum meorum non ≈øit in prae≈øenti, n√®c opus fuerit, ben√® liceat Baronibus meis inter√¨m ad Domos ≈øuas redire & requie≈øcere: Et ≈øi exercitus inimicorum meorum promptus fuerit de veniendo in Terram meam in Ce≈øter≈øhire, vel ≈øi Ca≈øtellum a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øum fuerit, praedicti Barones c√πm toto exercitu ≈øuo avi≈øu ≈øuo ≈øtat√¨m ad Summonitionem meam venient ad removendum exercitum illum ad po≈ø≈øe ≈øuum: Et c√πm exercitus ille de Terr√¢ me√¢ rece≈ø≈øus fuerit, praedicti Barones c√πm exercitu ≈øuo ad Terras ≈øuas redire poterint & quie≈øcere, d√πm milites de Anglia VVardam ≈øuam facient, & ad opus de eis non fuerit, Salvis mihi Servitiis ≈øuis quae facere debent. Concedo eti√†m eis, qu√≤d in tempore Pacis tant√πm duodecem Servientes itinerantes habeant in terr√¢ me√¢ c√πm uno equo qui ≈øit Magi≈øtri Servientis, qui eti√†m Prebendam non habeat √† Pa≈øcha u≈øqu√® ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Michaelis, ni≈øi per gratum: Et ut ip≈øi Servientes Comedant Cibum, qualem in Domibus Hominum invenerint, ≈øin√® emptione alterius Cibi ad opus eorum: n√®c in aliquibus Dominicis Baronum Comedant: Et tempore Guerrae p√®r Con≈øilium meum, aut Ju≈øticiarii mei, & ip≈øorum, Ponantur Servientes ≈øufficientes ad terram meam Cu≈øtodiendam, prout opus fuerit: Et ≈øciendum e≈øt, qu√≤d praedicti Barones Petitiones Sub≈øcriptas, quas √† me requirebant, omnin√≤ mihi & haeredibus meis de ≈øe & haeredibus ≈øuis remi≈øerunt: it√† qu√≤d nihil de eis de caetero clamare poterint, ni≈øi per Gratiam & Mi≈øericordiam meam: Scilic√®t Sene≈øchallus Petitionem de Wrec & de Pi≈øce in terram ≈øuam per mare dejecto: & de Ber≈øare in Fore≈øt√¢ me√¢ ad tres Arcus; & de percur≈øu Canium ≈øuorum: Et alii Petitionem de Agi≈øtamento Porcorum in Fore≈øt√¢ me√¢, & de Ber≈øhare ad tres Arcus in Fore≈øt√¢ me√¢, vel ad cur≈øus Leporariorum ≈øuorum in Fore≈øt√¢ in eundo ver≈ø√πs Ce≈øtriam per Summonitionem, vel in redeundo: & Petitionem de Mi≈øericordi√¢ Judicum de Wich triginta Bullionibus Salis: ≈øed erunt Mi≈øericordia & Leges in Wich tales, quales prius fuerint. Concedo igit√πr, & prae≈øenti Chart√¢ me√¢ confirmo de me & haeredibus meis, Communibus Militibus omnibus & liber√® Tenentibus totius Ce≈øter≈øhire & eorum haeredibus, omnes praedictas libertates habendas & tenendas de Baronibus meis & de caeteris Dominis ≈øuis, quicunque ≈øint, ≈øicut ip≈øi Barones & Milites & caeteri liber√® Tenentes eas de me tenent. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Hugone, Abbate Sanctae Werburgae Ce≈øtriae, Philippo Orreby t√πnc temporis Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Henrico de Aldithley, Waltero Deyvell, Hugone Di≈øpen≈øario, Thoma Di≈øpen≈øario, Willielmo Pincerna, Waltero de Coventrey, Ricardo Phitton, Roberto de Cowdrey, Ivone de Caletoft, Roberto de Say, Normanno le Painter, Roberto Di≈øpen≈øario, Roberto Deyvell, Mattheo de Vernon, Hamone de Venables, Roberto de Ma≈ø≈øy, Alano de Waley,
Hugone de Columbe, Roberto de Pulford, Petro Clerico, Hugone de Pa≈øey, Joceralino de Hellesby, Ricardo de Bresby, Ricardo de King≈øley, Philippo de Terven, Liulfo de Twamlowe, Ricardo de Perpoint, & toto Comitatu Ce≈øtriae.
This Charter I have here, for the ≈øatifaction of ≈øome, tran≈ølated al≈øo into Engli≈øh, as followeth, with the expo≈øition of the harde≈øt words.

RANDLE Earl of Che≈øter, To his Con≈øtable, Steward, Judge, Sheriff, Barons, Bailiffs, and to all his Tenants and Friends, pre≈øent and to come, that ≈øhall ≈øee or hear this Charter, Sendeth Greeting. Know ye, that I being Signed with the Cro≈øs Tho≈øe were ≈øaid to be Signed with the Cro≈øs in the≈øe Ages, who had undertaken a Voyage to Jeru≈øalem in defence of the Holy Land; and as a Badge of their Warfare they wore a Cro≈øs on their right Shoulder. So Spelman.
for the love of God, and at the Reque≈øt of my Barons of Che≈øhire, have granted to them and their Heirs, from me and my Heirs, all the Liberties in this pre≈øent Charter underwritten, to have and to hold for ever: to wit, That every one of them may have his own Court free from all Pleas and Plaints moved in my Court, except ≈øuch Pleas as belong to my Sword The Pleas of the Sword were the Pleas of the Dignity of the Earl of Che≈øter, who held that Earldom as freely to the Sword, as the King held England to the Crown.: And if any of their Tenants ≈øhall be taken for any Offence within their Fee or Lord≈øhip, he ≈øhall be Replevied without any Ran≈øom, ≈øo as his Lord bring him to three County Courts; and then he may carry him back as acquit, unle≈øs
Sakerboth, Sakber, and Sacraber, is as much as a Pledge to Sue: one that puts in Surety to Pro≈øecute another. Spelman. Sakerborh do follow him. And if any Stranger (who is faithful) ≈øhall come upon their Land, and de≈øires to dwell there, it ≈øhall be lawful for the Baron of that Fee to have and retain him, ≈øaving to me the Advowries who ≈øhall come to me on their own accord, and others who for any Tre≈øpa≈øs el≈øewhere ≈øhall come unto my Dignity, and not to them. And every one of my Barons, when need requireth, ≈øhall in time of War do the full Service of ≈øo many Knights Fees as he holdeth: And their Knights and Freeholders ≈øhall have their Coats of Mayle and Haubergeons; and may defend their own Land by their Bodies, although they be not Knights: And if any of them be ≈øuch a one, that he cannot defend his own Land by his Body, he may put another ≈øufficient Per≈øon in his Place: Neither will I compell their Villanes to take Arms; but I do hereby acquit their Villanes, which by Randle of Davenham ≈øhall come to my Protection, and other their Villanes, whom they can rea≈øonably ≈øhew to be their own. And if my Sheriff, or any Officer, ≈øhall Implead any of their Tenants in my Court, he may defend him≈øelf by Thirtnic Thiertnic, or Thirdnicht, is Trium Noctium ho≈øpes. Hoveden, pag. 606. Here it ≈øeemeth to ≈øignifie three Nights Charges for the Sheriffs-Tooth. Sheriffs-Tooth was a common Tax Levied for the Sheriffs Diet. for the Sheriffs-Tooth, which they do pay, unle≈øs fre≈øh Suit do follow him. I do al≈øo grant unto them acquittance from the Corn and Oblations, which my Serjeants and Bedells were wont to require; and that if any Judger It is in the Deed Judex, which is ≈øometimes taken for a Judge, ≈øometimes for a Jury-man or Freeholder; which Freeholders are by Law the Judges of a Court-Baron., or Suitor of the Hundred or County-Court, ≈øhall be Amerced in my Court, the Judger ≈øhall be quit from his Amercement for Two ≈øhillings, and the Suitor for Twelve pence. I do al≈øo grant unto them liberty of Inclo≈øing their Lands within the Boundaries of their Tillage in the Forre≈øt: And if there ≈øhall be a Land or parcel of Ground within the Boundary of their Town≈øhip, which hath been formerly Manured, where no Wood groweth, it ≈øhall be lawful to Till the ≈øame without Graizing: And they may al≈øo take Hou≈øebote and Haybote in their VVoods, of all manner of VVood, without the view of my Fore≈øter; and may give or ≈øell their dead VVood to whom they plea≈øe, and their Tenants ≈øhall not be Impleaded for the ≈øame in the Fore≈øt Court, unle≈øs they be found in the manner or very act. And every one of my Barons may defend all his Mannors and Lord≈øhips in the County or Hundred Court, by having a Steward pre≈øent. I do al≈øo grant, That the Wife, upon the Death of her Husband, ≈øhall remain peaceably in her Hou≈øe forty Days: And the Heir (if he be at Age) ≈øhall have his Heritage for rea≈øonable Relief, to wit, Five Pounds for a Knights Fee: Nor ≈øhall the VVidow, nor the Heir, be Married where they may be di≈øparaged, but ≈øhall be Married by the free a≈ø≈øent of their Kindred. None of them ≈øhall lo≈øe his Villane by rea≈øon of his coming into the City of Che≈øter, unle≈øs the ≈øame hath remained there a Year and a Day without claim. And in regard of the great Service which my Barons do me in Che≈øhire, none of them ≈øhall do me Service beyond the LimeThat is, out of the Limits of the County, as I conceive, Lima being an old word for Limes., but at their own free will, and at my Co≈øt. And if my Knights from England ≈øhall be Summoned, which ought to VVard at Che≈øter, and are come to keep their VVard, and that there be no Army of my
Enemies at pre≈øent from ≈øome other Place, and that there be no need, then my Barons may in the mean time return unto their own Hou≈øes, and take their ea≈øe: And if an Army of my Enemies be ready to come into my Land in Che≈øhire, or if the Ca≈øtle be Be≈øieged, the afore≈øaid Barons, upon my Summons, ≈øhall immediately come with all their Army, to remove the Enemy according to their Power: And when that Army of the Enemy ≈øhall retreat out of my Land, the ≈øaid Barons may return to their own Homes and Re≈øt, while my Knights from England keep the Guard, and that there ≈øhall be no need of my Barons, ≈øaving unto me the Services which the Barons ought to do. I do al≈øo grant unto them, that in time of Peace they may have onely twelve Sergeants itinerant in my Land, with one Hor≈øe of the Ma≈øter Sergeant, which ≈øhall have no Provend from Ea≈øter to Michaelmas, but by curte≈øie: And that the Sergeants eat ≈øuch Meat as they ≈øhall find in Mens Hou≈øes, without buying any other Provi≈øion for their u≈øe: Nor ≈øhall they eat in any Mannor-Hou≈øes of the Barons. And in the time of War ≈øhall be appointed Sergeants ≈øufficient for the keeping of my Land, by my Advice, and by the Advice of my Judge and Barons, as need ≈øhall require. And you are to know, that my Barons afore≈øaid have for them and their Heirs, relea≈øed to me and my Heirs, the Petitions under written, which they de≈øired from me; ≈øo that they can challenge nothing hereafter of them, but by my free Favour and Mercy:

To wit, my Steward hath relea≈øed his Petition of Wrec, and of Fi≈øh ca≈øt upon his Land by the Sea, and liberty of ≈øhooting Deer in my Forre≈øt for three Shoots The Deed runs thus, Et de Ber≈øhare in Fore≈øta mea ad tres Arcus. Bir≈øare, i. e. Telo configere: a Germ. Bir≈øen; So Spelman; To ≈øhoot an Arrow or Dart,, and for the running of his Dogs.

Others their Petition for Lay of their Swine in my Forre≈øt, and ≈øhooting at Deer for three Shoots, and for running their Greyhounds in the Forre≈øt going to Che≈øter upon Summons, or in returning; and al≈øo the Petition of the Amercement of the Judgers of the Wich of thirty Walms of Salt: But the Amercements and Laws of the Wich ≈øhall be ≈øuch as they were before.

I do therefore grant, and by this pre≈øent Deed confirm, from me and my Heirs, to all my common Knights and Gentlemen of Che≈øhire, and their Heirs, all the afore≈øaid Liberties, to have and to hold of my Barons, and of other their Lords, who≈øoever they be, as the ≈øame Barons and Knights, and other Gentlemen, hold the ≈øame of me; The≈øe being Witne≈ø≈øes, Hugh, Abbot of St. Werburge of Che≈øter, Philip Orreby, then Judge of Che≈øter, &c.
Prince Edward, Son of King Henry the Third, confirmed the afore≈øaid Liberties in the≈øe words:‚Äî

q.p: EDWARDUS Illu≈øtris Regis Angliae Primogenitus, Omnibus‚ÄîSalutem. Sciatis, quod conce≈ø≈øum e≈øt, pro nobis & haeredibus no≈øtris, Baronibus, Militibus, liber√® Tenentibus & aliis, ac toti Communitati Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, qu√≤d ip≈øi in perpetu√πm habeant & gaudeant omnibus Libertatibus & Con≈øuetudinibus, ei≈ødem & Progenitoribus ≈øuis dud√πm conce≈ø≈øis √† Domino Ranulpho quond√†m Comite Ce≈øtriae per Chartam ≈øuam, prout in e√¢dem Chart√¢ pleni√πs continetur. Conce≈ø≈øimus aut√®m ei≈ødem, qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis tenens Terram in Comitatu Ce≈øtriae de qu√¢cunque Feloni√¢ convictus fuerit, ubicunqu√® locorum fuerit, Dominus Feodi Feodum ≈øuum habeat & recipiat po≈øt Annum & Diem ≈øin√® contradictione alicujus: Volumus eti√†m, qu√≤d Servitia (quae praedicti haeredes Ce≈øter≈øhiriae nobis ad opus & rogatum no≈øtrum extr√† Comitatum praedictum fecerunt) in po≈øter√πm non trahentur in Con≈øuetudinem. Et ut omnia haec rata & firma in perpetuum remaneant, prae≈øentibus Literis Sigillum no≈øtrum duximus apponi. Datum Ce≈øtriae 27 die Augu≈øti, Anno Regni Domini Regis Patris no≈øtri 49.49 Hen. 3.

div.p: Which afterwards he confirmed al≈øo when he was King, Dated March 30. 28 Ed. 1. as appears by the Exemplifications of all the≈øe Charters in Rotulo Recognitionum, 3 Edw. 4.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the Bi≈øhops of Che≈øter.

div.p: I Find no mention of a Bi≈øhop at Che≈øter before the Norman Conque≈øt; onely we read that Dwina a Scotchman was made Bi≈øhop of Mercia by King O≈øwy, whereof Che≈øhire was a ≈ømall Parcel; and that he had his Seat at Lichfield, Anno Chri≈øti 656. from which time there remained a Succe≈ø≈øion of Bi≈øhops in that See, until by doom of Canon Law all Bi≈øhops were to remove to the greate≈øt Cities in their Dioce≈øe. Polychronicon, lib. 1. cap. 52. And thereupon Peter Bi≈øhop of Lichfield, Anno Domini 1075. removed his Seat from Lichfield to Che≈øter, and was then commonly ≈øtiled Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter. But Robert de Lim≈øey, next Succe≈ø≈øor to Peter, leaving Che≈øter, fixed his Seat at Coventrey, Anno 1095. which was brought back to Lichfield by Roger Clinton in the Reign of Henry the Fir≈øt, but ≈øo as his Title was Bi≈øhop of Lichfield and Coventrey. From which time downwards, the Bi≈øhops here were ≈øometimes ≈øtiled of Che≈øter, ≈øometimes of Lichfield, and ≈øometimes of Coventrey, from the Place where they fixed their Re≈øidence, having then three Sees, one at Lichfield, another at Coventrey, and a third at Che≈øter, yet all one and the ≈øame Bi≈øhoprick.

At la≈øt King Henry the Eighth made Che≈øter an entire Epi≈øcopal Dignity, Anno Regni ≈øui 33. turning the Mona≈øtery of St. VVerburge in Che≈øter, into the Bi≈øhop's Palace: unto which Juri≈ødiction was allotted Che≈øhire, Lanca≈øhire, Richmond≈øhire, and part of Cumberland, and was appointed to be within the Province of York. See Stat. 33 Hen. 8. cap. 31.

div.head: A Catalogue of the Bi≈øhops of Che≈øter ≈øince 33 Hen. 8. 1541. which Bi≈øhoprick was erected upon the di≈ø≈øolution of the Abbeys.
div.p: I. JOhn Bird, Doctor of Divinity of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, having been formerly a Fryer of the Order of the Carmelites, was the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of this new Foundation. He was born in Coventrey, and made Bi≈øhop of Bangor, Anno 1539. thence tran≈ølated to Che≈øter 1541. 33 Hen. 8. He was preferred for ≈øome Sermons Preached before the King again≈øt the Pope's Supremacy, Anno Chri≈øti 1537. He was deprived of his Bi≈øhoprick of Che≈øter by Queen Mary, Anno 1554. becau≈øe he was Married, and died at Che≈øter, Anno 1556.

II. George Cotes, one of the Prebends of Che≈øter, ≈øometime of Magdalen Colledge in Oxford, and afterwards Ma≈øter of Baliol Colledge, made Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter 1 Mariae 1554. He ≈øurvived his Con≈øecration not two Years. Some mi≈øtake this Bi≈øhop's Name, calling him John for George: It plainly appears by the Regi≈øter Book of the Con≈øi≈øtory Court at Che≈øter, that his Name was George Cotes.

III. Cutbert Scot, Doctor of Divinity, and Ma≈øter of Chri≈øtchurch Colledge in Cambridge, made Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter by Queen Mary, 1556. He was after put out by Queen Elizabeth; a froward Per≈øon, who being put into the Pri≈øon of the Fleet in London, made an e≈øcape, and fled to Lovain, where he died.

IV. VVilliam Downeham, Chaplain to Queen Elizabeth before ≈øhe came to the
Crown, Doctor of Divinity, and ≈øometime of Magdalen Colledge in Oxford, was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter May 4. 1561. 3 Elizabethae. He died in November 1577. and was buried in the Quire of the Cathedral Church at Che≈øter, having ≈øat Bi≈øhop there ≈øixteen years and a half. He had two famous Sons, George, Bi≈øhop of London-Derry in Ireland, and John, Batchelour of Divinity, a Learned and painful Writer.

V. William Chaderton, Doctor of Divinity, Fellow of Chri≈øts Colledge in Cambridge, and after Pre≈øident of Queens Colledge in Cambridge, and ≈øometime the King's Profe≈ø≈øor of Divinity in that Univer≈øity, was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter 9 Novembris, 1579. thence tran≈ølated to Lincoln 1595. He was Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ≈øixteen years; and had onely one Daughter and Heir, called Jone, the fir≈øt Wife of Sir Richard Brooke of Norton in Che≈øhire; but the≈øe after parted and lived a≈øunder. This Bi≈øhop was a Learned and witty Man, and died in April 1608.

VI. Hugh Bellot, Doctor of Divinity and Bi≈øhop of Bangor, brought up in St. John's Colledge in Cambridge, was tran≈ølated to Che≈øter 1557. 37 Elizabethae. He lived ≈øcarce one year after his Tran≈ølation, and died about Whit≈øuntide 1596. buried at Wrixham in Denbigh≈øhire. His Funeral was ≈øolemnized at Che≈øter 22 Junii.

VII. Richard Vaughan, Doctor of Divinity, the Queens Chaplain and Bi≈øhop of Bangor, brought up in St. John's Colledge in Cambridge, ≈øucceeded Bellot both in the Bi≈øhoprick of Bangor and Che≈øter. He was tran≈ølated to Che≈øter in June 1597. Lee ≈øaith he was tran≈ølated May 16. 1596. and En≈øtalled November 10. 1597. and continued there ≈øix years and more; and was tran≈ølated hence to London about the end of December 1604. and died March 30. 1607. He was a Man of a prompt and ready Utterance; the beginning of who≈øe Advancement was under the Lord-Keeper Puckering, who de≈øigned him to Examine ≈øuch as ≈øued to him for Benefices in his Gift. So Lee, pag. 45. of the Vale-Royal of England.

VIII. George Lloyd, Doctor of Divinity, Bi≈øhop of the I≈øle of Mann, ≈øometime Fellow of Magdalen Colledge in Cambridge, was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter 14 die Januarii 1604. He died the fir≈øt of Augu≈øt 1615. in the 55. year of his Age, at his Par≈øonage of Thornton, and was buried in the Quire of the Cathedral Church at Che≈øter near to Bi≈øhop Downeham; and was Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ten years.

IX. Thomas Moreton, Son of Richard Moreton of York City, Mercer, Doctor of Divinity, brought up in St. John's Colledge in Cambridge, and ≈øometime Dean of Winche≈øter, was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter 7 die Julii 1616. tran≈ølated hence to Lichfield and Coventrey 6 Martii 1618. and thence to Durham 1632. He died 22 die Septembris 1659. anno aetatis 95. after he had written many Learned Tractates, and was never Maried. See this Bi≈øhop's Life and Death in Daniel Lloyd's Memoires, Printed 1668.

X. John Bridgeman, Son of Thomas Bridgeman of Greenway in Devon≈øhire, Doctor of Divinity, brought up in Cambridge, the King's Chaplain, and Par≈øon of Wiggan in Lanca≈øhire, was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Chester 1619. He lived till the Parliament pulled down all Bi≈øhops in a Puritannical Frenzy of Rebellion, and had Beheaded King Charles the Fir≈øt, and after died at Morton, not far from O≈øwalde≈øtrey in Shrop≈øhire, He Married Elizabeth, Daughter of Doctor Helyar, Canon of Exce≈øter, and Arcdeacon of Bar≈øtable, and had I≈ø≈øue Sir Orlando Bridgeman, made Lord-Keeper 1667. Dove, Henry, now Dean of Che≈øter, Sir James Bridgeman, and Richard.

XI. Brian Walton, born at Cleaveland in York≈øhire, Doctor of Divinity, brought up in Peterhou≈øe in Cambridge, was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter 2 die Decembris 1660. upon the Re≈øtoration of King Charles the Second. He died November 29. in Vigiliis Sancti
Andreae 1661. anno aetatis 62. buried in the Cathedral of St. Paul at London. He had a principal Hand in ≈øetting out the Great Bible of many Languages; and Married Jane, Daughter of Doctor William Fuller, Dean of Durham.

XII. Henry Ferne, Doctor of Divinity, Ma≈øter of Trinity Colledge in Cambridge, was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter 9 die Februarii 1661. He died very ≈øoon after, and never lived to come to Che≈øter, and was buried at We≈øtmin≈øter. He writ clear Re≈øolutions of certain Ca≈øes of Con≈øcience, relating to the Differences between the late King and his rebellious Parliament.

XIII. George Hall, one of the Sons of Doctor Jo≈øeph Hall Bi≈øhop of Exce≈øter, was ≈øometime of Exce≈øter Colledge in Oxford, and Doctor of Divinity, and con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, Anno Chri≈øti 1662. He was al≈øo Par≈øon of Wiggan in Lanca≈øhire by the Gift of Sir Orlando Bridgeman, then Chief Ju≈øtice of the Common-Pleas. This Bi≈øhop Married Gartred, Si≈øter to Sir Amos Meredith, now of A≈øhley in Che≈øhire. He died at Wiggan Augu≈øt 23. 1668. without any I≈ø≈øue of his Body; and Gartrede his Lady al≈øo died at Wiggan in March following.

XIV. John Wilkins, Doctor of Divinity, Son of Walter Wilkins, a Gold≈ømith in the City of Oxford, was fir≈øt Student of Chri≈øtchurch in Oxford, and after made Warden of Wadham Colledge in the ≈øame Univer≈øity, about the Year of our Lord 1651. He Married Robina, Si≈øter to Oliver Cromwel the late Lord Protector, but hath no I≈ø≈øue as yet. He was made Ma≈øter of Trinity Colledge in Cambridge about the Year 1659. and after the Re≈øtoration of King Charles the Second he was made Dean of Rippon in York≈øhire; and was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, Anno Domini 1668. He was al≈øo Par≈øon of Wiggan by the Gift of Sir Orlando Bridgeman Baronet, now Lord-Keeper of England.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: A Catalogue of the Deans of Che≈øter.

div.p: I. THomas Clerke, who before had been the la≈øt Abbot of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, was made the fir≈øt Dean of Che≈øter after the erection of the new Bi≈øhoprick here 1541. 33 Hen. 8.
II. Henry Mann, Doctor of Divinity, afterwards Bi≈øhop of the I≈øle of Mann. He died 1556.
III. William Clyve, Doctor of both Laws.
IV. Roger Walker, Ma≈øter of Arts.

Note.V. John Piers, Doctor of Divinity, made Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter 1576. thence tran≈ølated to Salisbury 1578. thence to York 1588. He was ≈øometime Dean of Chri≈øtchurch in Oxford. Twine. But quaere whether ever Dean of Che≈øter, whereof I doubt.
VI. Richard Longworth, Doctor of Divinity.
VII. Robert Dor≈øell, Doctor of Divinity, living 1580. 22 Elizabethae.
VIII. Thomas Mode≈øley, Batchelor of Divinity.

IX. John Nuttall, Batchelor of Divinity, was fir≈øt Prebend, then Sub-Dean of Che≈øter; and afterwards was En≈øtalled Dean of Che≈øter 1589. 31 Elizabethae. He continued Dean about 13 years. He was al≈øo Par≈øon of Sefton in Lanca≈øhire, and of Bebington in Che≈øhire; a Man of great Wealth: Queen Elizabeth tearmed him A Golden A≈øs. He died ≈øuddenly, as he was at Supper at Sefton, Anno Domini 1603. where he was buried.

X. William Barlow, Doctor of Divinity, and Prebend of We≈øtmin≈øter, was made Dean of Che≈øter 1 Jacobi 1603. He was made Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter 1605. and thence tran≈ølated to Lincoln 1508, and died about 1612.
XI. Doctor Parry was En≈øtalled Dean of Che≈øter, 1 die Augu≈øti 1605.

XII. Thomas Mallory, Batchelor of Divinity, younger Son of Sir William Mallory of Studeley in York≈øhire, Archdeacon of Richmond, and Par≈øon of Mobberley and Davenham in Che≈øhire, was En≈øtalled Dean of Che≈øter, Anno Domini 1606. He continued Dean about 38 years; and Married Elizabeth, Daughter of Richard Vaughan Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, and had many Children. He died at the Dean's Hou≈øe in Che≈øter, 3 Aprilis 1644. and was buried in the Quire of the Cathedral Church at Che≈øter. He was Educated in Cambridge.

XIII. Doctor William Nicols, Par≈øon of Chedell in Che≈øhire, ≈øucceeded Dean of Che≈øter 1644. He was of a good Family in the County of Middle≈øex, and Married Katharine, the Widow of William Tatton of Witthen≈øhaw E≈øquire, and ≈øecond Daughter of Sir George Leyce≈øter of Toft in Che≈øhire Knight. He died without I≈ø≈øue at Etchells, Anno Chri≈øti 1658. and was buried at Norden Church in Che≈øhire. He was Educated in Trinity Colledge in Cambridge.

XIV. Doctor Henry Bridgeman, younger Son of John Bridgeman late Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, was ≈øometime of Bra≈øen-No≈øe Colledge in Oxford, and made Dean of Che≈øter, Anno 1660. He hath beautified and repaired the Dean's Hou≈øe in the Abbey Court at Che≈øter very much; and is al≈øo Par≈øon of Bangor in Flint≈øhire, and of Barrow in Che≈øhire. He hath onely one Child, called Elizabeth, Married to Captain Thomas Greenough of Lanca≈øhire, who was Sheriff of Lanca≈øhire, Anno 1668. This Henry Bridgeman was made Bi≈øhop of the I≈øle of Mann, Anno Domini 1671. con≈øecrated at Che≈øter, 1 die Octobris eodem anno.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: A Catalogue of the Chamberlains of Che≈øter.

div.p: PHilippus Camerarius, in the time of Randle ≈øirnamed Gernouns, Earl of Che≈øter.
Spilem' Camerarius, in the time of the ≈øame Randle. Vide ≈øupr√† pag. 128.

Bertramus de Verdon, Chamberlain in the time of Hugh Cyveliok, and al≈øo in the time of Randle Blundevill. This Bertram was Sheriff 31 & 33 Hen. 2. 1187. He lived in the Reigns of Henry the Second, Richard the Fir≈øt, and King John.

p.hi: Ricardus Orreby Camerarius.

div.p: 56 H. 3. 1261. Willielmus Bruchull Camerarius: Ille fuit Decanus Eccle≈øiae Sancti Johannis Ce≈øtriae. Lib. H. fol. 117. e. John Boooth of Twamlow's Book.

p.hi: Quae ≈øequuntur ex Recordis (≈øcilic√®t inter Recognitiones Scaccarii Ce≈øtriae apud Ce≈øtriam) propri√¢ manu collecta ≈øunt.

6 Ed. 1. 1278. Stephanus Che≈ønut; & 8 Edw. 1.

9, 10, 11 E. 1. William Bur≈øtow ‚Ä¢
1281.
12 E. 1. 1284. Robert Hemington.
29 E. 1. 1300. Willelmus Molton.
3 Edw. 2. William Stonehall.

15 E. 2. 1321. Ricardus de Sancto Edmundo.
18, 19. Ed. 2. 1324. Willielmus E≈ø≈øington Ju≈øticiarius.
20 E. 2. 1326. John Paynell; eti√†m 1 Edw. 3.
2 Ed. 3. 1328. Thomas Bla≈øton.
3 Ed. 3. 1329. John Stonehall, Par≈øon of Plem≈øton.
4 Ed. 3. 1330. Simon Ruggeley.
5 Ed. 3. 1331. John Paynell.
Sir John Wendour was Chamberlain when Adam Parker was Sheriff of Che≈øhire, about 9 Ed. 3.
10 E. 3. 1336. B. Paynell.
12 E. 3. 1338. John Perye; eti√†m 14 Edw. 3.
15 E. 3. 1341. John Brunham, Par≈øon of Eccle≈øton.
16 E. 3. 1342. John Perye; eti√†m 17 Edw. 3.
18 E. 3. 1344. William Linford.
20 E. 3. 1346. John Brunham Junior. He was Chamberlain to the 41 Edw. 3. but how long after, I find not preci≈øely.
50 E. 3. 1376. John Woodhou≈øe. He was Chamberlain to the 17 Rich. 2. 1393.
17 R. 2. 1393. Robert Paris, from the 17 Rich. 2. 1393. to the 23 Rich. 2. 1399. about five Years.
23 R. 2. 1399. John Trever Bi≈øhop of St. A≈øaph, made Chamberlain 23 Rich. 2. He continued to 6 Hen. 4. about five Years.
6 H. 4. 1404. Thomas Barnaby, Chamberlain 6 Hen. 4. He continued to the 14 Hen. 4. eight Years.
14 H. 4. 1412. William Troutback E≈øquire, made Chamberlain of Che≈øter 14 Hen. 4. He continued to the 17 Hen. 6. about twenty ≈øix Years.

17 H. 6. 1438. John Troutback, made Chamberlain in Rever≈øion after his Father's Death, by Patent Dated the fifteenth day of Augu≈øt, 15 Hen. 6. howbeit he ≈øat not as Chamberlain till 17 Hen. 6. when his Father died: which Year he was al≈øo Sheriff of Che≈øhire. He continued Chamberlain to the 35 Hen. 6. about eighteen Years.
35 H. 6. 1457. Sir Richard Tun≈øtall, part of 35 Hen. 6. He continued the remainder of Henry the Sixth's Reign, about four Years.
1 Ed. 4. 1461. Sir William Stanley, (of Hooton, as I conceive) Chamberlain 1 Edw. 4. to the 10. of Hen. 7. about thirty four Years.
10 H. 7. 1495. Sir Reginald Bray, made Chamberlain the tenth of April, 10 Hen. 7. He continued to the 15 Hen. 7. about four Years.

15 H. 7. 1499. Sir Richard Pool, made Chamberlain of Che≈øhire (quamdi√π nobis placuerit) 14 Januarii, 15 Hen. 7. He had another Patent (durante beneplacito) Dated 3 Aprilis,
19 Hen. 7. Sir Randle Brereton was Vice-chamberlain 19 Hen. 7. & 20. Hen. 7. William Tatton al≈øo Vice-Chamberlain, 20 Hen. 7. Pool was Chamberlain to 21 Hen. 7. about ≈øix Years.

21 H. 7. 1505. Sir Randle Brereton, made Chamberlain 21 Hen. 7. In the ≈øame Year before this Patent was another made of the ≈øame Office, unto Sir John Longford Knight. This Sir Randle Brereton of Malpas, was one of the Knights of the Body to Henry the Seventh, 19 Hen. 7. He continued Chamberlain to 23 Hen. 8. about twenty ≈øix Years. In the Year 21 Hen. 8. Reciting where before he had given Officium Clerici Scaccarii Ce≈øtriae, vulgarit√®r nuncupatum Officium Baronis Scaccarii Ce≈øtriae Comitatus Palatini Ce≈øtriae, Johanni Tatton, & Nicolao Farrington, &c. and that Nicolas Farrington was dead, and John Tatton living. The King granted the Rever≈øion of the ≈øame Office, after the death of John Tatton, to Randle Brereton, per nomen Officii Clerici Scaccarii Ce≈øtriae, & vulgarit√®r nuncupati Baronis Scaccarii Ce≈øtriae. This Randle Brereton Baron of the Exchequer, I take it, was Ba≈øtard Brother to the Chamberlain.

23 H. 8. 1331. William Brereton E≈øqire, made Chamberlain 23 Hen. 8. He continued to 28 Hen. 8. about five Years. He was of the King's Privy Chamber, and Beheaded May 17. 1536. 28 Hen. 8. for matters touching Queen Anne. Stow.
28 H. 8. 1536. Rees Manxell, 28 Hen. 8. He continued to 1 Eliz. about twenty three Years.
1 Eliz. 1559. Edward Stanley Earl of Derby Chamberlain of Che≈øter, 1 Eliz. William Glazier
Vice-Chamberlain eodem anno. Earl Edward, Chamberlain ≈øix Years.
7 Eliz. 1565. Robert Dudley Earl of Leyce≈øter, 7 Eliz. He continued to 30 Eliz. about twenty three Years. William Glazier, Vice-Chamberlain 17 & 22 Eliz.
30 Eliz. 1588. Henry Stanley Earl of Derby, 30 Eliz. He continued Chamberlain to 35 Eliz. about five Years.
35 Eliz. 1593. Sir Thomas Egerton, after Lord-Keeper, was Chamberlain 35 Eliz. He continued to the fir≈øt Year of King James; about ten Years.

1 Jacobi 1603. William Stanley Earl of Derby, made Chamberlain of Che≈øter for his Life, October 30. 1603. 1 Jacobi. He makes Henry Towne≈øend E≈øq his Vice-Chamberlain (durante beneplacito) as freely as ever Sir Peter Warburton, one of the Judges of the Common-Pleas, or any other Vice-Chamberlain held the ≈øame Office before. Dated 13 Januarii, 1 Jacobi.
After this there was another Patent, joyning James Lord Strange with William his Father, for both their Lives, and to the Survivor.
To Towne≈øend ≈øucceeded Sir Thomas Ireland of Beau≈øy in Lanca≈øhire, Vice-Chamberlain.
To Ireland, Roger Downs of Wardley in Lanca≈øhire.
To Downs, Orlando Bridgeman (Son of John Lord Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter) Vice-Chamberlain 1640.
William Earl of Derby died 1642. and James his Son continued Chamberlain, till the Parliament put in their Speakers.

23 C. 1. 1647. Edward Earl of Manche≈øter, Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Lords, and William Lenthall, Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Commons, were made Chamberlains of Che≈øter by the Parliament, 23 Car. 1. 1647. Homfrey Macworth of Shrop≈øhire Vice-Chamberlan.
1654. John Glinne, made Chamberlain 1654; Philip Younge of Shrop≈øhire his Vice-Chamberlain.
This Glinne purcha≈øed Harden Ca≈øtle from Charles Earl of Derby, about 1654.

12 C. 2. 1660. Charles Earl of Derby, made Chamberlain of Che≈øter by the King, for the Lives of him≈øelf and William his Son, 12 Car. 2. 1660. Edward Rigby of Pre≈øton in Lanca≈øhire, ≈øat Vice-Chamberlain 1662.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: A Catalogue of the Judges of Che≈øter, collected out of the old Deeds and Charters to the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, and from thence downwards, out of the Fines at Che≈øter, and out of the Recognizances in the Exchequer.

div.p: Johannes Adams Ju≈øticiarius Comitis, Witne≈øs to a Deed of William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire the younger, made to the Abbey of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, of Raby in Wirrall, about the beginning of King Stephen's Reign.
Raufe Manwaring, Judge of Che≈øter towards the end of Henry the Second, and Richard the Fir≈øt.

Philip Orreby, Judge of Che≈øter in the time of Roger Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire about the tenth Year of King John's Reign, Anno 1209: for Roger Lacy died 1211. 12 Johannis, ≈øaith Matthew Paris. He was Judge to 13 Hen. 3. 1228. above twenty Years.

John Holland, made Judge of Che≈øter for his Life. His Patent in the Exchequer is Dated 5 Rich. 2. and he made Thomas Molineux his Lieutenant-Ju≈øtice, Dated eodem anno. 5 Ric. 2. 1381.

Edmund Duke of York, the King's Uncle, made Judge of Che≈øter ad terminum vitae, eo modo quo Johannes Holland habuit, by the King's Patent, Dated 28 Septembris, 9 Rich. 2. He had another Patent, giving him power to make a Lieutenant, Dated 9 Rich. 2. and he makes Thomas Abbot of Vale-Royal his Lieutenant-Ju≈øtice, with forty Marks Fee yearly, Dated on St. Martin's Eve, 9 Rich. 2. div.p: Soon after Edward the Fourth had obtained the Crown, he created a new Sheriff of Che≈øhire, notwith≈øtanding the Patent for Lives granted to Booth by Hen. 6. This appears by Stanley's fir≈øt Patent, as followeth:
div.q: EDWARDUS, &c. Salutem. C√πm 16 die Decembris 1460. humilis & fidelis Ligeus no≈øter Willielmus Stanley de Hooton Sen. retentus fuerit pro termino vitae c√πm Excellenti≈ø≈øimo & Praepotenti≈ø≈øimo Principe beatae memoriae Ricardo Duce Eboracen≈øi Patre no≈øtro, quem Deus ab≈øolvat, facturus fidele & diligens Servitium praefato Patri no≈øtro & nobis erg√† omnes terrenas creaturas; pro quibus retentione & Servitio, praefatus Pater no≈øter promi≈øit & conce≈ø≈øit, qu√≤d tali tempore quo Officium Vicecomitis no≈øtri Comitatus Palatini Ce≈øtriae perveniret, vel pertineret conce≈ø≈øioni ip≈øius Patris no≈øtri, qu√≤d t√πnc ip≈øe concederet praefato Willielmo idem Officium,‚Äî&c. Habendum pro termino vitae, prout in quibu≈ødam Indenturis ≈øub Sigillo praedicti Patris no≈øtri, quas habet demon≈øtrare: Nos conce≈ø≈øimus eidem Willielmo idem Officium Vicecomitis,‚Äî&c. Habendum & occupandum per eundem Willielmum, & per ≈øuum Deputatum ≈øufficientem, quamdi√π nobis placuerit,‚Äî&c. Te≈øte meip≈øo apud Ce≈øtriam, 16 die Januarii, Anno Regni no≈øtri Secundo, 1462.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: A Catalogue of the E≈øcheators of Che≈øhire to the Reign of King James.

div.p: IN ancient time there were but two E≈øcheators in England, the one on this ≈øide of Trent, and the other beyond Trent; at which time they had Sub-E≈øcheators: But in the Reign of Edward the Second the Offices were divided, and ≈øeveral E≈øcheators made in every County for Life, &c. and ≈øo continued till the Reign of Edward the Third. And afterwards by the Statute of 14 Edw. 3. it was Enacted, that there ≈øhould be as many E≈øcheators a≈ø≈øigned, as when Edward the Third came to the Crown, and that was one in every County, and that no E≈øcheator ≈øhould tarry in his Office above a year: and by another Statute, to be in Office but once in three years: The Lord-Trea≈øurer nameth him. Cook upon Littleton, fol. 13. b.
But Che≈øter, and other County-Palatines made their own E≈øcheators, long time before the Statute of 14 Edw. 3. and their Priviledges for making E≈øcheators are allowed by the ≈øaid Statute.
45 E. 3. 1261. Thomas de Orreby, 1261. as appears by the original Deed of the Liberties of Maxfield.
Hugo le Mercer, ≈øub Edw. 1.

10 E. 1. 1282. Adam de Chetwine. Mr. Holms's Book, Lib. B. pag. 124. Ex placitis Ce≈øtriae die Martis proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Sancti Nicolai, 10 Edw. 1. de cu≈øtodi√¢ & maritagio Johannis Filii & haeredis Hugonis de Hatton.
22 E. 1. 1294. Frater Robertus de valle Regali: per Inqui≈øitionem po≈øt mortem Hugonis de Dutton, Lib. C. fol. 156. bb.

24 E. 1. 1296. Peter of Newca≈øtle under Lime, as appears by the Writ for the Office of Vrian de Sancto Petro, vulg√≤ Sampier, in the Pleas at Che≈øter proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Sancti Augu≈øtini Epi≈øcopi, 28 Edw. 1.
27 E. 1. 1299. Hugh Bu≈øhy, per Inqui≈øitionem concerning Sampier, in Placitis ibid√®m in Fe≈øto Tran≈ølationis Sancti Thomae Apo≈øtoli, 27 Edw. 1.
6 Ed. 2. 1312. Matthew de Hulgrave.
Edward de la Mare, al≈øo 6 Edw. 2. Mr. Holms's Book B. pag. 114.
1 Ed. 3. 1327. William de Swetenham; ut per Inqui≈øitionem po≈øt mortem Hugonis de Dutton, 1 Ed. 3. Lieger Book of Vale-Royal, fol. 46.
2 Ed. 3. 1328. 5 Ed. 3. 1331. 6 Ed. 3. 1332. John de Wetenhale. Mr. Holms's Book E. fol. 256.
Thomas Daniers; ut per Inqui≈øitionem pen√®s me. V. num. 11.

Hamo Ma≈ø≈øy de Tatton. O. num. 1. He was younger Son to Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton in Che≈øhire, and Married Katharine, Daughter and Heir of Alan Rixton of Rixton in Lanca≈øhire, 6 Edw. 3. 1332. from whom the Ma≈ø≈øyes of Rixton. He was afterwards Sir Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy Knight, 1347. Lib. C. fol. 105. num. 42. & fol. 292. num. 1.
7 Ed. 3. 1333. Peter Arderne, made E≈øcheator 7 Edw. 3. Mr. Holms's Book E, fol. 77. Quamdi√π ben√® ≈øe ge≈ø≈øerit. This Peter had Lands in Over-Alderley.

19 E. 3. 1345. Hugh de Hopwas, as appears by an Inqui≈øition Ex Officio, for the Bondary of Stubs ≈øup√®r Rudheath, quae tenetur de Fratribus Sancti Johannis Hiero≈øolymitani; in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Thomas Delves of Dodington Baronet, Anno 1664. He was al≈øo E≈øcheator 23 & 26 Edw. 3.
Quae ≈øequuntur, ex Recordis (≈øcilic√®t int√®r Recognitiones Scaccarii Ce≈øtriae ap√πd Ce≈øtriam) propri√¢ manu collecta ≈øunt.
35 E. 3. 1361. Adam de King≈øley; & 36 Edw. 3.
39 E. 3. 1365. John Scolehall, made E≈øcheator (quamdi√π nobis placuerit) 26 Martii, 39 Edw. 3. He was al≈øo Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 42 Edw. 3. I find him al≈øo E≈øcheator, 2 Ri. 2. & 6 & 7 Rich. 2.

11, 12, 13 R. 2. Adam King≈øley.

21 R. 2. 1398. Hugh Leigh (id e≈øt, of High-Legh of the Ea≈øt-Hall) made E≈øcheator quamdi√π nobis placuerit, 23 Octobris, 21 Rich. 2. The Original is among the Evidences of Mr. Legh of High-Legh of the We≈øt-hall, Anno 1664.

Idem Roger made E≈øcheator durante beneplacito, and to have the whole Profits thereof. Dated 4 Aprilis, 19 Hen. 7. He was al≈øo E≈øcheator 24 Hen. 7. and was a younger Son to Manwaring of Carincham.

1 H. 8. 1509. Sir Raufe Egerton, and Roger Manwaring, made E≈øcheators of Che≈øhire for their Lives, and to the Survivor of them, 7 Julii, 1 Hen. 8. It appears Manwaring was dead 6 Hen. 8. and the ≈øaid Sir Raufe Egerton (one of the Gentlemen-U≈øhers of the King's Chamber) was made Ranger of the King's Fore≈øt of Delamere in Che≈øhire, during his Life, 6 Hen. 8.

This Sir Raufe (as I take it) was younger Son to Egerton of Egerton, and the fir≈øt Egerton of Ridley. He died 1528. The Egertons of Ridley in ≈øhort time attained to a great E≈øtate, but is all now ≈øold and gone, except ≈øome ≈ømall part in York≈øhire, called Allerton, c√πm pertinentiis.

Vrian Brereton, one of the Grooms of the Privy-Chamber, made E≈øcheator, and Ranger of Delamere Forre≈øt, pro termino vitae, after the Death of Sir Raufe Egerton, with 10 l. Fee per annum. Dated 1 Aprilis, 18 Hen. 8. He was after Brereton of Honford in Right of his Wife, and younger Son of Brereton of Malpas.

32 H. 8. 1540. Vrian Brereton Armiger, unus Gromettorum Privatae Camerae Regis, E≈øcheator 32 & 35 Hen. 8. Et Vrianus Brereton Senior Miles, E≈øcheator 2 Edw. 6. ut patet per inqui≈øitionem captam apud Northwich, 18 Junii, 2 Edw. 6. po≈øt mortem Johannis Carington de Carington Armigeri. Sir Vrian died 19 Eliz. 1577.
19 Eliz. 1577. John Cotton E≈øquire.
22 Eliz. 1580. John Nutthall, made E≈øcheator pro termino vitae, 17 Junii, 22 Elizabethae; eti√†m 25 Eliz.
This was Nutthall of Catenhall nigh Dutton. Obiit 28 Eliz.
33 Eliz. 1590. Sir Hugh Cholmeley of Cholmeley the younger. He died 43 Eliz.
13 Jac. 1615. Henry Manwaring of Carincham E≈øquire.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: A Catalogue of the Recorders of the City of Che≈øter, ≈øince the Charter of 21 Hen. 7. 1506. when this City was made a di≈øtinct County of it ≈øelf, to have a Mayor, Recorder, and twenty four Aldermen, with two Sheriffs, and forty of the Common-Council.

div.p: 1506. RAufe Birkenhead is ≈øaid to be the fir≈øt Recorder.
1518. 10 H. 8. Richard Sneyd E≈øquire, was Recorder 1518, 10 Hen. 8. from whom the Sneyds of Bradwell and Keele in Stafford≈øhire are de≈øcended.
1535. 27 H. 8. Raufe Wrine, Son of William Wrine, ≈øucceeded Recorder 1535.

1563 & 1574. William Gerard E≈øquire: I find him mentioned Recorder 5 & 16 Eliz. He was made Chancellor of Ireland, and died in May 1580. buried at the Cathedral of St. Werburge in Che≈øter. Lib D. pag. 174. n.
1575. 17 Eliz. Richard Birkenhead E≈øquire, cho≈øen Recorder of Che≈øter 13 Martii, 17 Eliz. He ≈øurrendred this Office to Thomas Lawton 1601. in regard of his old Age, not able to Execute the ≈øame.

This Richard was ba≈øe Son of John Birkenhead of Crowton, ut dicitur, and purcha≈øed Manley at the ≈øide of Delamere Fore≈øt; and had to Wife Margaret, Daughter of Piers Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire, and had I≈ø≈øue
1601. 44 Eliz. Thomas Lawton E≈øquire, cho≈øen Recorder of Che≈øter, 12 Januarii, 44 Eliz. 1601.
1606. Thomas Gamull, a Citizen born, Son to Alderman Edmund Gamull of Che≈øter, cho≈øen Recorder 7 Februarii, 3 Jacobi 1605. He died Augu≈øt 11. 1613.
1613. Edward Whitby, Son of Robert Whitby, then Mayor of Che≈øter, was cho≈øen Recorder 13 Augu≈øti, 1613, 11 Jacobi. He died April 8. 1639. at the Bache.

1639. Robert Brierwood, a Citizen born, was cho≈øen Recorder of Che≈øter April 9. 15 Car. 1. 1639. He was Son of John Brierwood, Sheriff of this City: which John was Son of Robert Brierwood Wet-Glover, thrice Mayor of Che≈øter. John had a younger Brother called Edward Brierwood, the famous Schollar of Bra≈øen-No≈øe Colledge in Oxford, and afterwards Profe≈ø≈øor of A≈øtronomy at Gre≈øham Colledge in London, who writ many Learned Books; ≈øcilic√®t, a Treati≈øe of the Sabbath, 1631. The Enquiry of Languages, Printed 1635. De Nummis, Printed 1614. be≈øides his Logical Notes, and Tractate De Oculo, publi≈øhed by Six≈ømith of Bra≈øen-No≈øe.

Robert the Recorder had two Wives; the fir≈øt was Anne, Daughter of Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever the younger; the ≈øecond was Katharine, Daughter of Sir Richard Lea of Lea and Dernhall in Che≈øhire; and had ≈øeveral Children by each of them. He was Sergeant at Law, Judge of three Shires in Wales, and was made Judge of the Common-Pleas, and Knighted at Oxford 1643. He died the eighth of September 1654. at Che≈øter, aged 67 years, and buried in St. Maries Church at Che≈øter.

1646. John Ratcliffe, a Citizen born, Son of Alderman John Ratcliffe, was cho≈øen Recorder 17 Novembris, 1646. in the time of the late Rebellion, after the Surrender of Che≈øter to the Parliament. He was put out, becau≈øe he refu≈øed the Negative Oath; and Richard Haworth of Manche≈øter Lawyer, was cho≈øen Recorder 1651. and becau≈øe Haworth would not re≈øide con≈øtantly at Che≈øter, he ≈øurrendred it to John Ratcliffe afore≈øaid; who was again cho≈øen Recorder 1656. but was put out by the Commi≈ø≈øioners for Regulating the Corporations of the City and County-Palatine of Che≈øter, Anno Domini 1662. becau≈øe he refu≈øed to take the Oath enjoyned by Act of Parliament in that behalf.
1662. Richard Lieving of Parridge in Derby≈øhire E≈øquire, was cho≈øen Recorder by the Commi≈ø≈øioners afore≈øaid, 1662, He died in the beginning of April 1667.
1667. William Williams, Son of Doctor Williams of Angle≈øey, was elected Recorder with the King's Approbation, 1667. a very acute young Gentleman.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE Fourth Part.
div.p: HUndreds and Tythings were appointed by King Alfred, who began his Reign over England about the Year of Chri≈øt 872. Malmesbury de Ge≈øtis Regum, lib. 2. cap. 4. The≈øe were ordained for the better ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of Robberies: for every free born Man was now to be ranked, or put into ≈øome Hundred and Tything; and if there were any Per≈øon of ≈øuch di≈ø≈øolute Carriage, that he could find no Pledge or Surety in the Hundred and Tything for his good Demeanour, he was to be Impri≈øoned, as a Man unworthy to be at liberty. And if any Per≈øon guilty of a Robbery (whether before ≈øuch Pledge found, or after) ≈øhould flie and make an e≈øcape, all the Inhabitants of the Hundred and Tything were to be Amerced by the King: So that by this means there was ≈øuch a Calm of Peace in the Nation in a ≈øhort ≈øpace, that if any Man had left Bracelets of Gold, or Bags of Money in the High-way, there was none dur≈øt take them away, as both Malmesbury and Ingulphus do inform us.

Now the≈øe Freeholders, or free-born Men, were ca≈øt into ≈øeveral Companies, by ten in each Company, whence in the We≈øtern parts of the Realm they were called Tythingmen. And every of the≈øe Pledges or Sureties were yearly pre≈øented and brought forth by their chief Pledge, at a general A≈ø≈øembly for that purpo≈øe, which we yet in remembrance thereof do call The View of the Frank Pledge, or The Leet-Court: and as ten times ten do make a hundred, ≈øo becau≈øe it was then al≈øo appointed that ten of the≈øe Companies ≈øhould at certain times meet together for Matters of greater weight; therefore that A≈ø≈øembly or Court was called The Hundred-Court. Lamberd in his Book of the Duties of Con≈øtables, Bor≈øholders, and Tythingmen, pag. 7, 8, 9. as it is commonly added at the end of his Eirenarcha.
In this County of Che≈øhire we had formerly twelve Hundreds, as we find them in the Record of Dooms-day Book, viz.

list.item: Atti≈øcros Hundred.
Ere≈øtan Hundred.
Che≈øter Hundred.
Wilawe≈øton Hundred.
Dude≈øtan Hundred.
Warmunde≈øtreau Hundred.
Ri≈øeton Hundred.
Roelay Hundrrd.
Milde≈øtric Hundred.
Ham≈øtan Hundred.
Bucklow Hundred.
Tunendon Hundred.

div.p:
But the≈øe Hundreds were reduced by a later Divi≈øion into ≈øeven Hundreds, as at this day they ≈øtand divided and called, to wit,
Bucklow Hundred.
Maxfield Hundred.
Northwich Hundred.
Nantwich Hundred.
Broxton Hundred.
Edesbery Hundred.
Wirrhall Hundred.
Which new Divi≈øion I conjecture doth not exceed the Reign of King Edward the Third.

And as there mu≈øt needs be an enlargement of the number of the Towns in each Hundred of the new Divi≈øion above the old, becau≈øe the whole is contracted to a le≈ø≈øer number of Hundreds, ≈øo they have all begot new Names, except this of Bucklow Hundred, which both retains its old Name, and hath now the Towns of the other old Hundred of Tunendon annexed to it.

For the proportion of the old Hundreds to the new, it is to be ob≈øerved, that the Towns comprehended in the old Hundreds of Atti≈øcros and Ere≈øtan, were by the Statute of 33 Hen. 8. cap. 13. taken from Che≈øhire, and annexed to Flint≈øhire, onely Dodle≈øton yet remains to Che≈øhire, belonging to Broxton Hundred. And for Che≈øter Hundred, the City of Che≈øter was made a di≈øtinct County of it ≈øelf (except the Ca≈øtle onely, c√πm pertinentiis) by the King's Charter, Dated 6 Aprilis, 21 Hen. 7. 1506.

list.item: Milde≈øt-vich Hundred, is now, called Northwich Hundred.
Wilawe≈øton Hundred, now called Wirrhall Hundred.
Dude≈øtan Hundred, now called Broxton Hundred.
Warmunde≈øtreu Hundred, now called Nantwich Hundred.
Ham≈øtan Hundred, now called Maxfield Hundred.
Ri≈øeton and Roelay Hundreds, now comprehended in Edesbery Hundred.

div.p: Many more Towns are now in Che≈øhire than we find in Dooms-day Book; for many were then wa≈øte, which have been ≈øince improved and inhabited.

The Hundred of Bucklow now comprehendeth the≈øe Town≈øhips following, which I have placed Alphabetically, for the more ready finding of any in particular, and containeth two Divi≈øions; the Ea≈øt Divi≈øion comprehending the old Bucklow Hundred, and the We≈øt Divi≈øion comprehending the old Tunendon Hundred; either Divi≈øion having a Head Con≈øtable yearly elected re≈øpectively.

Such as are marked thus [E.] belong to the Ea≈øt Divi≈øion; ≈øuch as remain unmarked, belong to the We≈øt Divi≈øion; onely ob≈øerve, that Cog≈øhull, now belonging to the Ea≈øt Divi≈øion, was anciently part of the old Hundred of Tunendon; and Limme, now belonging to the We≈øt Divi≈øion, was anciently within the old Bucklow Hundred.

div.p: The Abbot of Salop for Fi≈øhing in Thelwall, ≈øtood Charged with 3 s. the Mize in the ancient Mize-Book, but this is now lo≈øt, and is not known where to be Charged.

The Method I propo≈øe to my ≈øelf in this Fourth Part, is to take the particular Town≈øhips of this Hundred of Bucklow in order according to the Alphabet, to the end I might ≈øpare the labor of an Index or Table; and ≈øo ob≈øerve in them particularly what I can di≈øcover from old Deeds or Records, concerning the Owners of tho≈øe Places ≈øince the Norman Conque≈øt; adding al≈øo the Pedegrees of many of the better ≈øort of the Gentry in this Hundred (≈øo many as my lei≈øure will permit me to go through, and for which I have ≈øeen good Deeds and Records proving the ≈øame) placed at the end of ≈øuch Towns where ≈øuch Families have been re≈øpectively Seated in ancient time.

And as Speed calls our County-Palatine of Che≈øter, The Seedplot of Gentility, and Learned Cambden in his Britannia ≈øtiles it, The mo≈øt ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing Nur≈øery of ancient Gentry above any other County in England, ≈øo I may not unfitly call this Hundred of Bucklow, The prime Border of that Nur≈øery, as having a more numerous company of Gentry therein, proportionably to its compa≈øs, above any other Hundred in our County.

Concerning the Churches and Chappels of this Hundred, I ≈øhall add what I can gather concerning them in tho≈øe particular Towns where I find them ≈øituated; and my Authorities, as well for the≈øe as all the re≈øt of this Fourth Part of my Book, ≈øhall either be put down verbatim (where it is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, and of mo≈øt concern) or el≈øe be referred unto, and in who≈øe Hands the Original remaineth.

Tho≈øe Books quoted and referred unto in this Treati≈øe following, ≈øtiled Lib. A. or Liber B. or Liber C. are Books of Collections of Deeds taken by me from the Originals, ≈øome more largely, ≈øome extracted in brief.

In the mean time I ≈øhall here give you a Catalogue of all the Pari≈øh Churches, Parochial Chappels, Chappels of Ea≈øe, and Dome≈øtick Chappels, as well within every Hundred of this County, as in the City of Che≈øter. The Letter R. denotes a Rectory or Par≈øonage; the Letter V. ≈øtands for Vicarage.
