div.p: Concerning the Churches and Chappels of Bucklow Hundred, I ≈øhall ≈øpeak more particularly in their due place and order, as within the compa≈øs of my intended Task; onely we may take notice here, that Pari≈øhes were fir≈øt di≈øtingui≈øhed in England under Honorius Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, about the Year of Chri≈øt 636. Cambden's Britannia Printed 1607. pag. 116. Parker's Hi≈øtoria Cantuarien≈øis, pag. 52.

Ridley, in his View of the Civil and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Law, tells us, pa. 176, 177. that Fonts in the Primitive Times, were not in the Churches; but the Cu≈øtom of tho≈øe elder Ages, was to Baptize in Rivers and Fountains; and that Cu≈øtom being di≈øcontinued through Per≈øecution, Fonts were erected in private Hou≈øes; and in more peaceable Ages they made bold to build their Fonts a little di≈øtance from the Church: afterwards they obtained to ≈øet them in the Church Porch; at la≈øt they got them into the Church: But they were not at fir≈øt placed in every Church immediately; for at the fir≈øt they were found onely in the Cathedral Church where the Bi≈øhop re≈øided: and though Service might be ≈øaid in the le≈ø≈øer Min≈øters and Rural Churches, yet the Right of Sepulture and Bapti≈øm belonged to the Cathedral Church, unle≈øs it were in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity; and it was therefore called The Mother-Church, becau≈øe as People in their Mothers Womb were born Men, ≈øo in the Fonts of Bapti≈øm, as in the Churches Womb, they were born Chri≈øtians. In ≈øucceeding Ages, when it was found that the Mother-Church was too far di≈øtant from ≈øome Villages, and ≈øo ≈øituated, that in the Winter the People could not repair thither, con≈øideration was had of this Inconvenience, and the Bi≈øhop took occa≈øion hence to transfer the Rite of Bapti≈øm and Sepulture to the Rural Churches, and this, together with the Rite of Tythes, made it a Pari≈øh Church of that kind which we now have. But becau≈øe al≈øo in many Pari≈øhes ≈øome Families lived ≈øo remote from the Church, that they could not conveniently frequent the ≈øame, it was indulged to ≈øuch, that they might build a private Oratory in or near their Man≈øion-places, re≈øerving for the mo≈øt part the Rite of Bapti≈øm and Sepulture to the Pari≈øh Church, which, in re≈øpect of the≈øe le≈ø≈øer Oratories, was to be accounted the Bapti≈ømal or Mother-Church. It was al≈øo provided, that the≈øe Families (notwith≈øtanding their Grant from the Bi≈øhop for a private Oratory) ≈øhould upon more ≈øolemn Fea≈øt-days, repair to their Pari≈øh Church, as it ≈øeems by the Council held at Agatha. The≈øe private Oratories were afterwards called Capellae, Chappels; and tho≈øe that did Exerci≈øe in them the Mini≈øterial Function, were called Capellani, Chaplains. Thus Ridley.

Now the word Capella, qua≈øi Cap≈øella, is a Diminutive from Cap≈øa, which ≈øignifies a Che≈øt or Coffer, becau≈øe the Relicks of Saints or holy Per≈øons were kept in ≈øuch a
Che≈øt; and the place, where ≈øuch Che≈øt was kept, was ≈øo called al≈øo; und√® Nomen Capella, Capellanus, &c. So Spelman in his Glo≈ø≈øary upon that word.

Beatus Rhenanus, with Durand, do derive the word Capella from Capa or Cappa, St. Martin's Hood being ≈øo called barbarou≈øly, and carried about for good luck by Lewis the French King in all his Wars. But others derive it √† Pellibus Caprarum, wherewith ≈øuch portable Tents for God's Service, as were to be removed in their warlike Expeditions, were covered. Dr. Prideaux, in his Con≈øecration Sermon of Exce≈øter Colledge Chappel in Oxford, pag. 26.
None might of right build Oratories without Licence from the Bi≈øhop, at lea≈øt none might Admini≈øter Divine Service there without the Bi≈øhop's ≈øpecial Licence.
Oratories erected in the Hou≈øes of Great Per≈øons, for the u≈øe of a private Family, I call ≈øuch Dome≈øtick Chappels.

When built by one, or ≈øeveral Per≈øons, in ≈øome convenient place, for the u≈øe of ≈øeveral Families, or of a Town≈øhip or Town≈øhips, not having liberty of Bapti≈øm or Burial, I call ≈øuch Chappels of Ea≈øe.

When built by a more numerous multitude of the Neighborhood, con≈øi≈øting of one or more Villages, having got liberty for Bapti≈øm and Burial, with Con≈øecration thereof by the Bi≈øhop, and ≈øometimes an Allowance in Money or Tythes from the Mother-Church, I call ≈øuch Parochial Chappels: for the≈øe have all the Rites and Ceremonies as the Mother-Church or Pari≈øh Church hath, except the Tythes; ≈øo that indeed they are as le≈ø≈øer Pari≈øhes created within the greater for the benefit of the Neighborhood.
As to the Con≈øecration of Churches, we find the Jews had their Encaenia, or Fea≈øts of Dedication of their Temple, John 10. ver. 22.1 Maccabaeorum, cap. 4. ver. 59.

But there was no Dedication of our Chri≈øtian Churches to Saints, until Praying to Saints was in u≈øe; and after Churches began to be Dedicated to Saints, their Dedication Fea≈øts were u≈øually kept on that Day, which was the Fea≈øt-day appointed in the Kalendar for commemoration of that Saint, to whom ≈øuch Church was particularly Dedicated. This time was called with us, The Wakes, from Waking, as the Latine word Vigiliae, √† vigilando, becau≈øe at ≈øuch times the People Prayed mo≈øt of the Night before ≈øuch Fea≈øt-day in the Churches. And though the Primitive Cu≈øtom herein was ≈øacred, yet how it was abu≈øed in the Reign of King Edgar, Anno Domini 967. aut circit√®r, appears by the Canons of the Church in his Reign, Num. 28.‚ÄîDocemus, ut in Eccle≈øiarum Encaeniis unusqui≈øque ≈øe mode≈øtum exhibeat, & orationi incumbat diligent√®r, non poculis, non luxui deditus. Spelman's Councils, Pars 1. pag. 451. And at la≈øt it turned to Fea≈øting and Merriment of Neighbors.

Now Invocation of Saints for three hundred years after Chri≈øt cannot be found among any of the Fathers: None did teach Invocation of Saints, till by Rhetorical Expre≈ø≈øions, and Poetical Fancies, like Invocating of the Mu≈øes, Ba≈øil, Ny≈ø≈øen, and Nazianzen had led the way. Dr. Prideaux, Lecture 15. pag. 243.

div.head: Ampli≈øsimo clari≈øsimoque viro Domino Petro Leyce≈øter Baronetto, Patriae Antiquitatis In≈øtauratori faelici≈ø≈øimo.
div.l: Qua latus Hiberno Regina Britannia Ponto
Emicat hos inter Proceres clari≈øsimus Heros
Et quicquid Romae Pagina docta probat,
Quic quid condiderit praeclaris Anglia fa≈øtis,
Leyce≈øter va≈øto pectoris or be tenet:
In≈øtat edax Rerum tempus, mor≈øuque maligno

closer.signed: Robertus Hunter Knotsfordien≈øis Eccle≈øiae Pa≈øtor in Agro Ce≈øtren≈øi; Po≈øtea vero Maxfelden≈øis.

div.head: The Fourth Part, Comprehending the ANTIQUITIES OF Bucklow Hundred IN CHESHIRE.
Acton Grange.
div.p: H Find no mention of this Hamlet, or Village in Dooms-day Book; ≈øo that in the time of the Conqueror it ≈øeemeth to be wa≈øte: and many other al≈øo in this Hundred be now inhabited, which are not ≈øo much as named in that ancient Record.
All that I ob≈øerve concerning this little Hamlet is, That it anciently belonged to the Priory of Norton; of the Foundation of which Priory I ≈øhall ≈øpeak more fully when I come to Norton.

Soon after the di≈ø≈øolution of Abbeys and religious Hou≈øes by King Henry the Eighth, it was purcha≈øed, together with the Mannor of Norton, and other Lands, by Richard Brooke E≈øquire, from the King: the Charter under the Broad Seal bearing Date the tenth of December, 37 Hen. 8. 1545. Since which time it hath continued entire, not having any Charterer within the ≈øame, unto his ≈øucceeding Po≈øterity; and is now, Anno Domini 1669. in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Richard Brooke of Norton Baronet, and his Tenants.

div.head: Agden.
div.p:
THis ≈ømall Town of Agden al≈øo is not found in Dooms-day Book; it is in old Deeds written Aketon, and ≈øometimes Acton, but now commonly called Agden. It ≈øeems William, Son of Simon de Lee, was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Agden in the Reign of Henry
the Third, who gave unto William Rag his Son-in-law one half thereof in the≈øe words:‚Äî

q.p: SCiant prae≈øentes‚ÄîEgo Willielmus, Filius Simonis de Lee, dedi‚ÄîWillielmo Rag genero meo, & haeredibus ≈øuis de Agnete Fili√¢ me√¢ procreatis, pro Homagio & Servitio ≈øuo, totam dimidietatem Terrae meae de Acton, quam tenui de Henrico de Trafford: Scilic√®t totam Terram illam quam idem Willielmus Rag pri√πs habuit & Tenuit:‚ÄîTenendum c√πm omnibus libertatibus & ay≈øiamentis praedictae dimidietati Villae de Acton ubiqu√® pertinentibus: Reddendo ind√® annuat√¨m mihi & haeredibus meis unum par albarum Cheirothecarum vel unum Denarium, ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Martini in hyeme pro omnibus Servitiis‚ÄîSalvo forin≈øeco Domini Terrae Servitio. Et ego Willielmus & Haeredes mei totam praedictam dimidietatem‚Äîin perpetu√πm Warrantizabimus: Et Sciendum e≈øt, qu√≤d acquietabimus praedictum Willielmum Rag, & Haeredes ≈øuos de praedict√¢ Agnete, de Homagio & contr√† Matthaeum de Alpraham & Haeredes ≈øuos in perpetu√πm.‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Domino Thoma de Manwaring, Domino Willielmo de Ma≈ø≈øy, Roberto de Moldeworth, Thoma del Broom, Alano de Limme, Aytropo de Mulinton, Rogero de Northwich Clerico, & multis aliis. Lib. C. fol. 265. a. The Original Penes Venables of Agden.

div.p: Originals penes Venables de Agden.This William Rag was afterwards called William de Aketon, from his Re≈øidence here: and by that Name Matthew Somervyle, Lord of Alpraham, relea≈øeth unto him and his Heirs, the Impleading of him or his Tenants in his Court of Alpraham, but mu≈øt appear at his Court of Davenham. This was ≈øub Anno Domini 1270. Lib. C. fol. 265. b.

This Moiety of Agden came afterwards to one John Daniel of Agden, Son of William Daniel, in Marriage with Ellen, Daughter of the la≈øt William de Aketon, or Agden, by Entail, 38 Edw. 3. which Ellen Married after one Thomas Warburton to her ≈øecond Husband, and had three other Si≈øters, Elizabeth, Agatha, and Alice. Lib. C. fol. 266. m.

Ellen (after the Death of Thomas Warburton) Covenants to Settle all her Lands in Agden on William Venables, Brother to Roger Venables, then Par≈øon of Ro≈øthorn Church (both of them Sons to Thomas Venables of Horton, Son of Hugh Venables of Kinderton) and on Ellen his Wife, Daughter of Thomas Daniel, Son of John Daniel and Ellen his Wife afore≈øaid, by Deed dated 2 Hen. 4. 1401. Lib. C. fol. 265. f. k. The I≈ø≈øue of which William Venables and Ellen his Wife, did enjoy the Moiety of Agden, and who≈øe ≈øucceeding Po≈øterity have enjoyed the ≈øame ever ≈øince to this day, 1669.

‚öúThe other Moiety of Agden was held of the Barony of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy: for in an old Rentall of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of George Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, Dated 3 Hen. 4. I find that Robert Warburton then held medietatem Villae de Acton, nup√®r Johannis Acton, per Servitium tertiae partis unius Feodi Militis, & reddendo unum Denar√¨um termino Johannis Bapti≈øtae. Lib. B. pag. 209.

This other Moiety Agnes the Widow of John Leech of Altrincham, and Daughter and Heir of Robert de Aketon and Jone his Wife, ≈øold unto Sir J. Savage of Clifton, 6 H. 5. 1418. and Sir Thomas Savage Baronet, being ≈øeized of the Rever≈øion of this Moiety, ≈øold the ≈øame to George Venables of Agden the elder, 17 Jacobi, 1619. Lib. C. fol. 265. g. So that now Venables of Agden hath the whole Mannor of Agden, ≈øave onely Ou≈øingcroft Farm, c√πm pertinentiis formerly granted away out of Savage's Moiety.

Hugh Venables of Agden, 23 Hen. 8. Sued for all the Lands belonging to the Barony of Kinderton, as next rightful Heir, again≈øt Sir William Venables of Golborne, but could never get the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof. Afterwards William Venables of Agden relea≈øed all his Right to Kinderton Lands, 30 Elizabethae, 1588. unto Thomas Venables of Kinderton E≈øquire, Father of Peter Venables now Baron of Kinderton.

div.head: Altrincham.
div.p: ALtrincham is of the ancient Fee of the Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy. In the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy, Lord of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, In≈øtituted Burge≈ø≈øes in this Town, and granted them a Gild-Mercatory here, that is, a Society for free Traffick and Merchandize, about the Year of Chri≈øt 1290. as appears by this following Deed, the Original whereof is now in the cu≈øtody of John Coe, the pre≈øent Mayor of Altrincham, Anno Domini 1667.

OMnibus Christi fidelibus hanc prae≈øentem Chartam in≈øpecturis vel audituris, Hamundus de Ma≈ø≈øy Dominus de Doneham ≈øalutem ≈øempiternam in Domino: Noveritis me dedi≈ø≈øe, ac h√¢c prae≈øenti Chart√¢ me√¢ pro me & Haeredibus meis confirm√¢≈ø≈øe Burgen≈øibus meis de Altringham, qu√≤d Villa mea de Altringham ≈øit Liber Burgus & qu√≤d Burgen≈øes mei eju≈ødem Burgi habeant Gildam Mercatoriam in eodem Burgo c√πm omnibus Libertatibus, & Liberis Con≈øuetudinibus ad huju≈ømodi Gildam pertinentibus, ≈øecund√πm Con≈øuetudines Burgi de Macclesfield: Et qu√≤d quieti ≈øint per totam Terram meam, t√†m per aquam qu√†m per Terram, de Tolneto, Pa≈ø≈øagio, Pontagio, Stallagio, La≈øtagio, & omnibus aliis Servis Id e≈øt, Slavi≈øh Cu≈øtoms. con≈øuetudinibus: Conce≈ø≈øi eti√†m praedictis Burgen≈øibus meis Communam Pa≈øturamCommon of Pa≈øture, and Flaw-Turf, or Heath-Turf., Turbariam bruariam, infr√† Limites de Doneham, Altringham, & Tymperlegh; ≈øalvis mihi & Haeredibus meis approviamentis no≈øtris, & ≈øalv√¢ mihi & Haeredibus meis Clau≈øtur√¢ de Sunderland ad voluntatem no≈øtram ≈øin√® contradictione aliquorum, quandocunqu√® illud claudere voluerimus: It√† qu√≤d praedicti Burgen≈øes mei habeant Communam Pasturam ≈øemp√®r & ubique ad omnia animalia ≈øua infr√† metas de Sunderland, dummodo praedictus locus de Sunderland non clau≈øus fuerit, ≈øalvo mihi & Haeredibus meis toto tempore Pe≈ø≈øonis in praedicto Sunderland: It√† qu√≤d eodem tempore praedictum Sunderland in defen≈øionem ad voluntatem no≈øtram habere poterimus ≈øin√® contradictione aliquorum: Et c√πm clau≈øum fuerit praedictum Sunderland, praedicti Burgen≈øes mei ha-Beant Communam ≈øuam u≈øqu√® ad hayam praedicti Sunderland, & non ultr√†. Volo eti√†m, qu√≤d omnes Burgen≈øes mei, qui porcos habuerint tempore Pe≈ø≈øonis, in Burgo meo vel infra Fe≈øtum beati Jacobi & tempore Pe≈øsonis dent rectum Takcum quand√≤ Pasturant infr√† praedictas Communas, & alib√¨ c√πm porcis ≈øuis eju≈ødem Burgi tempore Pe≈ø≈øonis non ibunt: Conce≈ø≈øi eti√†m praedictis Burgen≈øibus meis Hou≈øebold & Haybold in omnibus bo≈øcis praedictorum locorum, exceptis Hayis & defen≈øis bo≈øcis meis: Concedo eti√†m praedictis Burgen≈øibus meis, qu√≤d non implacitentur extr√† Portimotum eju≈ødem Burgi, n√®c in aliquo Placito extr√† Burgum ≈øuum tractentur de tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionibus infr√† Burgum factis: Et ≈øi aliquis eorum in mi≈øericordi√¢ pro aliquo forisfacto incidit, amercietur per Pares ≈øuos; & hoc ≈øecund√πm quantitatem delicti. Volo eti√†m qu√≤d Burgen≈øes mei molent omnia blada ≈øua ≈øup√®r Terram de Altringham cre≈øcentia, vel in e√¢dem Vill√¢ HerburgataId e≈øt, Ho≈øpitio Expen≈øa., ad molendina mea pro octavo-decimo va≈øe multurae: Concedo eti√†m qu√≤d praedicti Burgen≈øes mei faciant ≈øibi Praepo≈øitos & Ballivos per Commune Concilium mei, vel Ballivorum meorum & ip≈øorum: Et nullum Placitum in dicto Burgo teneatur, n√®c determinetur, ni≈øi cor√†m me vel Ballivo meo: Et quod unu≈øqui≈øque Burgen≈øis ten√®at ≈øingulum Burgagium ≈øuum duarum Perticarum Terrae in latitudine, & quinque in longitunine, c√πm un√† Acr√¢ Terrae integr√¢ in Campis, pro duodecem Denariis ad tres Terminos anni mihi & Haeredibus meis annual√¨m Solvendis per aequales Portiones; videlic√®t ad Nativitatem Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae, ad Fe≈øtum omnium Sanctorum, & ad Annunciationem beatae Mariae; liber√®, quiet√®, pacific√®, & integr√®, c√πm omnibus libertatibus prae≈øcriptis: Et qu√≤d ≈øingulus Burgen≈øis Burgagium ≈øuum po≈ø≈øit vendere, invadiare, dare, vel in Te≈øtamento a≈ø≈øignare cuicunqu√® vel quibu≈øcunque voluerit, exceptis Mini≈øtris Domini Regis & Viris Religio≈øis, ≈øin√® contradictione alicujus vel aliquorum; ≈øalv√¢ mihi & Haeredibus meis libertate Furni no≈øtri in eodem Burgo: Ego ver√≤ praedictus Haniundus & Haeredes mei praedicta Burgagia, c√πm acris Terrae eis adjacentibus, & omnibus libertatibus ≈øupra≈øcriptis, praedictis Burgen≈øibus meis, & Haeredibus ≈øuis & a≈ø≈øignatis, contr√† omnes Gentes in perpetu√πm Warrantizabimus: In hujus rei te≈øtimonium huic prae≈øenti Chartae Sigillum meum appo≈øui. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Dominis Reginaldo de Grey t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Humfrido de Bello campo, Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy Militibus, Gilberto de A≈øton, Thom√¢ de Actone, Hugone de Baggelegh, Matthaeo de Hale, Henrico de Doneham, Johanne de Bowdon, & aliis.

Charta 18 Edw. 1. memb. 3. Rex conce≈ø≈øit Hamoni de Ma≈ø≈øy unum Mercatum per diem Martis apud Manerium ≈øuum de Altringham, & unam Feriam per tres dies duraturam, videlic√®t, in Vigilia, die, & cra≈øtino Fe≈øti A≈ø≈øumptionis beatae Mariae 15 Die Augu≈øti.. Lib. C. fol. 260. q.
The Tue≈øday Market continueth at this day; but the Fair is kept now on the twenty fifth day of July, and the later Fair-day on the eleventh day of November.
Although we u≈øually ≈øtile the chief Officer here, Mayor of Altrincham, yet in truth he is no more than a principal Officer, without any Magi≈øterial Authority.

In a Rentall of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, dated 3 Hen. 4. 1402. I find there were about forty Freeholders or Charterers in Altrincham, the re≈øt of the Tenants of Altrincham, then not above eighteen in number, were Tenants at Will. And it appears by that Rentall, as well as by another of my own in Henry the Seventh's time, that in tho≈øe Ages till Hen. 8. the ancient Tenants in our County had generally no Lea≈øes for Lives, as now they have: and the Rents which at this day we call Old Rents, were in tho≈øe former Ages the utmo≈øt value of ≈øuch Tenements on the Rack, ≈øo much have the≈øe late Ages out≈øtripped the former for value, as well for Land as other Commodities.

At this day, 1669. there are above twenty Charterers in this Town, whereof Robert Parker 's of Oldfield-Hall in Altrincham Gentleman is of greate≈øt value, next to which is that belonging to William Leyce≈øter of Hale-Lowe Gentleman. Mo≈øt of all the re≈øt are very ≈ømall Parcels, not worth the reckoning up; the chief Lord being George Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, Lord Delamere.
There are ≈øo very many ≈ømall Cottages erected here by the permi≈ø≈øion of the Lords of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, that it is now become a Ne≈øt of Beggars.

div.head: Anderton.
div.p: The Town≈øhip of Anderton is not in Dooms-day Book. Inqui≈øitio capta po≈øt mortem Vriani de Sancto Petro, 23 Edw. 1. (int√®r alia) praedictus Vrianus tenuit Manerium de Anderton in Dominico ≈øuo ut de Feodo, de Domino Rege in Capite per Servitium unius Librae Piperis ≈øolvendi ad Scaccarium Ce≈øtriae, &c. as I find it in W. Vernon's Notes: So that Vrian de Sampier held Anderton in the time of E. 1. but when fir≈øt granted to the Family of Sampier, or how long it continued in that Family, or how and when it devolved to Sutton of Sutton nigh Maxfield in Che≈øhire, is yet unknown to me. Certain it is, that Sir Peter Warburton, one of the Judges of the Common-Pleas at We≈øtmin≈øter, purcha≈øed this Mannor from Richard Sutton, Son of Francis Sutton of Sutton nigh Maxfield E≈øquire, by Deed, dated the twenty ninth of November, 43 Eliz. 1600. from whom it de≈øcended unto Sir Thomas Stanley of Nether-Alderley Baronet, now Owner thereof, 1669. to wit, Son of Sir Thomas Stanley Knight, by Elizabeth his Wife, Daughter and Heir of the ≈øaid Sir Peter Warburton.

‚öúIt is now commonly ≈øaid of this Village by the Neighborhood, as it were proverbially, That here is neither Gentleman nor Beggar, Charterer, Cottager, nor Alehou≈øe, but a Common without end: for that the Common is circular, lying round about the Town≈øhip; and the Demaine hath been ≈øet to Derry-men and Tenants, ≈øo as no Gentleman of long time hath lived there.

div.head: Appleton & Hull.
div.p: THis Town of Appleton and Hull, in William the Conqueror's time, belonged to Osbern Son of Tezzon, the Ance≈øtor to the Boydels of Dodle≈øton, as appears by the Record of Dooms-day Book.

Among the Evidences of Thomas Merbury of Merbury nigh Comberbach E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1666. I found this following Deed copied out in a loo≈øe Paper, the Original whereof is there underwritten to be in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Thomas Stanley, being ≈øo atte≈øted under his own Hand. Lib. C. fol. 286. d.

q.p: HUgo de Boydel omnibus t√†m prae≈øentibus qu√†m futuris, ad quorum notitiam prae≈øens Pagina pervenerit, ≈øalutem. Noverit univer≈øitas ve≈øtra, me conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe‚ÄîRoberto Lancelyn pro Homagio & Servitio ≈øuo, totam Terram & Tenementum, quod Ricardus Lancelyn Pater praefati Roberti tenuit de Antece≈ø≈øoribus meis; videlic√®t, Pulton & Bebington, Appleton & Hull, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis, illi & Haeredibus ≈øuis‚ÄîFaciendo mihi & Haeredibus meis Servitium duorum Militum; videlic√®t c√πm duobus Armatis apud Dodle≈øton in Werr√¢ quadraginta diebus: Scilic√®t Servitium unius Hominis pro Pulton & Bebington; & Servitium alterius Hominis pro Appleton & Hull, pro omni Servitio: Salvo Servitio quatuor Hominum quolibet tertio Anno per ≈øex dies ad meum HeimineumTo make his Hayment or Hedging. faciendum apud Dodle≈øton: Pro h√¢c Donatione & Confirmatione idem Robertus Lancelyn dedit mihi viginti marcas Argenti, &c. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Radulpho de Manwaring, Radulpho de Monte-alto, Willielmo de Pall', Thom√¢ Filio Willielmi, Roberto de Fulford, &c. about the end of Henry the Second's Reign.

div.p: I find Geffrey Son of Adam de Dutton (Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley) po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this Town≈øhip in the beginning of Henry the Third's Reign, and is at this pre≈øent belonging to Warburton of Arley, 1669.

q.p: Placita Ce≈øtriae, die Martis proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Sancti Lucae, 10 Edw. 3.

GAlfridus de Warburton opponit ≈øe vers√πs Hugonem de Audley de Placito qu√≤d ju≈øt√® & ≈øin√® dilatione acquietet eum de Servitiis, quae Willielmus de Boydel Senior ab eo exigit de libero Tenemento ≈øuo, quod de praefato Hugone tenet in Hull & Appleton: und√® idem Hugo, qui medius e≈øt inter eos, acquietare debet, &c. V√¨cecomes returnavit, qu√≤d praedictus Hugo nihil habuit in Balliv√¢ ≈øu√¢ di≈øtringere, &c. Lib. C. fol. 287. k. The Original among the Evidences of Thomas Merbury of Merbury E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1666.

div.head: A≈øhley.
div.p: HAmo de Ma≈ø≈øy, the fir≈øt Baron of Dunham Ma≈ø≈øy, held A≈øhley in the Conqueror's time, as appears by Dooms-day Book.
And in the Reign of Henry the Third, or ≈øooner, another Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy, then Baron of Dunham Ma≈ø≈øy, gave half of A≈øhley unto Robert de Ma≈ø≈øy. Lib. C. fol 150. d. e.

Richard, Son of Robert Ma≈ø≈øy, gives the Mannor of A≈øhley (that is, the Moiety of A≈øhley) unto Geffrey Dutton of Chedle, in exchange for Dutton of Chedle's Land in Walton (to wit, the Moiety of Nether-Walton) and for eight Shillings Rent from William, Son of Kenewret of Newton near Che≈øter. Lib. C. fol. 150 f.

Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy the Son, confirms the Grant which Richard de Ma≈ø≈øy, Son of Robert de Ma≈ø≈øy, made to Sir Geffrey Dutton of Chedle, of all his Land in A≈øhley, doing tho≈øe Services which Robert Ma≈ø≈øy, Father of the ≈øaid Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, did u≈øe to do to Sir Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy the Father. Lib. C. fol. 149. z. the Original among the Evidences of George Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.

Geffrey Dutton of Chedle gives to Hamon Dutton his younger Son, totum Manerium ≈øuum de A≈øhley, about 14 Edw. 1. 1286. Lib. C. fol. 150. I. and Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale, Son and Heir of Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, relea≈øeth unto the ≈øaid Hamon Dutton, Son of Geffrey Dutton Lord of Chedle, all his Right in the Mannor of A≈øhley. Lib, C. fol. 150. g.

‚öúThis Hamon, Seating him≈øelf at A≈øhley, was ≈øirnamed De A≈øhley, as the manner of tho≈øe Ages was, to ≈øtile Men from the Places where they lived; and his Po≈øterity afterwards wholly retained the Sirname of A≈øhley: which Family continued in the Name of the A≈øhleys at A≈øhley, till about the end of the Reign of Henry the Eighth.

Lib. B. pag. 208. In an old Rentall of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 3 Hen. 4. I read thus: ‚Äî Georgius A≈øhley tenet medietatem de A≈øhley, videlic√®t duas bovatas terrae in Dominico, & in Servitio dimidii Feodi Militis, & faciendo liberum Servitium unius Militis per octo dies tempore Guerrae ad Ca≈øtrum Ce≈øtriae ≈øumptibus propriis, & per redditum duodecem Denariorum per annum: (this was the Moiety, which Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy gave to Hugh Ma≈ø≈øy in the Reign of Henry the Third, Lib. C. fol. 151. n.) alteram medietatem tenet de Dutton de Chedle, reddendo unum Denarium per annum, & faciendo Hamoni de Ma≈ø≈øy Domino de Doneham redditum & Servitia de antiquo tempore debita; that was, Reddendo unum Circulum Ro≈øarum termino Johannis Sapti≈øtae, as appears by another Rentall de anno 21 Edw. 3.

figure.head: Ar, two Bars Sable, a Cre≈øcent of the fir≈øt.

div.p:
II. George Brereton of A≈øhley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, Married Sibill, Daughter and Heir of William Arderne of Timperley Gentleman, and had I≈ø≈øue William Brereton, elde≈øt Son; Richard, ≈øecond Son; George Brereton, third Son, Baptized at Bowdon the eighth day of November 1570. who was buried at Bowdon the nineteenth of November following; Ottiwell another Son, buried 4 Octobris 1571. al≈øo another Son called George Brereton Baptized at Bowdon 7 Junii, 1573. he had a Son called John Brereton, Baptized at Bowdon Augu≈øt 20. 1593. Edward another Son, Baptized at Bowdon the ≈øixth of September 1574. John Brereton another Son, died young, buried at Bowdon 27 Junii 1575. Thomas another Son, Baptized at Bowdon 5 Decembris, 1577. Randle another Son, Baptized at Bowdon the tenth of May, 1585. Lucretia a Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon the
twelfth of November 1579. Jane Brereton another Daughter, buried at Bowdon 9 Novembris 1581.
This George Brereton E≈øquire was buried at Bowdon the twelfth of October 1587. and Sibill his Wife was buried at Bowdon 16 Junii, 1583.

III. William Brereton of A≈øhley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of George and Sibill, Married Jane, one of the Daughters and Coheirs of Peter Warburton of Arley E≈øquire3 Decembris 1589., Anno Domini 1589. and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Brereton elde≈øt Son, Baptized in December
Decemb. 30. 1590. Regi≈øter of Great Budworth. 1590. Thomas ≈øecond Son, Baptized at Bowdon 26 Martii 1594. William third Son, Baptized at Bowdon 23 Decembris 1596. he died unmarried, and was buried at Bowdon 4 Aprilis 1632. Peter fourth Son, Baptized at Bowdon 26 Augu≈øti 1601, he died unmarried at Gray's-Inn in London 1659. Frances elde≈øt Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon 26 Augu≈øti 1592. ≈øhe Married Alexander Barlow of Barlow in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire. Mary ≈øecond Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon 20 Octobris 1595. ≈øhe died unmarried. Anne third Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon 6 Januarii 1597. ≈øhe Married Robert Tatton of Withen≈øhaw in Che≈øhire E≈øquire, 8 Januarii 1628. Katharine fourth Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon 16 Martii 1598. ≈øhe Married Raufe A≈øhton of Kirkby in York≈øhire, younger Son of Sir Richard A≈øhton of Middleton in Lanca≈øhire.

This William Brereton of A≈øhley, was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 1609. and died Augu≈øt 29. 1630. aged ≈øixty three years. Jane his Wife was buried at Bowdon 5 Martii 1627. who≈øe Monument, with her Husbands, remains in Bowdon Church.

IV. Richard Brereton of A≈øhley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of William and Jane, was never Married, but had an illegitimate Son, begot of one Ellin Higgin≈øon his Servant, called William Brereton, living at Che≈øter Anno Domini 1653.
This Richard was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 1632. and was buried at Bowdon 14 Septembris 1649. in the fifty ninth year of his Age.

V. Thomas Brereton of A≈øhley E≈øquire, Brother and Heir to Richard, Married Theodo≈øia, Daughter of Sir Thomas Tirrell of Ca≈øtlethorp in Buckingham≈øhire, but had no I≈ø≈øue, leaving his whole Inheritance to be ≈øhared by his three Si≈øters above≈øaid, and their Heirs.
This Thomas built the Dome≈øtick Chappel at A≈øhley, and a fair Dining-room there, Anno Domini 1653. and was buried at Bowdon in the Year of Chri≈øt 1660. aged ≈øixty ≈øix years.

list.head: Charterers in A≈øhley 1666.
list.item: 1. George Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, hath part of Arthur Wor≈øeley's Tenement.
2. Daniel of Over-Tabley hath one Tenement.
3. Buckley of Chedle hath part of Edward Hill's Tenement, the other part is now the Lady Whitmores, purcha≈øed from Savage of Clifton in Che≈øhire.
4. Ma≈ø≈øy of Lea-Hall in Mottram-Andrew; ≈øcilic√®t pro Harper's Hou≈øe.
5. Robert Heskith of A≈øhley.
6. Richard Wright of A≈øhley.
7. Thomas Wor≈øeley of A≈øhley.

div.head: A≈øhton ≈øuper Mer≈øey.
div.p: IN an old Rentall of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, dated 3 Hen. 4. 1402. I find it thus,‚Äî

Georgius Carington Chivaler tenet Manerium ≈øuum de Carington, & medietatem Villae de A≈øhton, & tertiam partem Villae de Partington, faciendo liberum Servitium pro duabus partibus Feodi Militis; ut per Chartam Antece≈ø≈øoribus dicti Georgii per Hamonem Ma≈ø≈øy Militem factam: & reddendo per annum de Stothe, ali√†s dictum Sheriffs-Tooth, ≈øeptem Denarios: Et ip≈øe faciet Sectam Curiae, quae vocatur Judger, de quinden√¢ in quindenam:
it√† qu√≤d pro qu√¢libet defalt√¢ dabit per viam amerciamenti duos ≈øolidos pro certo; & ip≈øe, & quatuor Tenentium ≈øuorum de villat√¢ de Carington, venient ad vi≈øum Franci-Plegii.

In the Notes collected by Will. Vernon I read, Po≈øt mortem Willielmi Boydell, 23 Edw. 3. int√®r Feoda dicti Willielmi: (inter alia) Robertus A≈øhton, Ricardus Diken≈øon, & Johannes Deane tenent medietatem Maneriorum de Sale & A≈øhton per Servitium unius Feodi Militis, & quilibet eorum tertio anno tres Denarios.

This Robert A≈øhton was Rector Eccle≈øiae de A≈øhton 23 Edw. 3. The≈øe were Feoffees in Tru≈øt; ≈øo that one Moiety of A≈øhton ≈øeems to be of the Fee of Boydell of Dodle≈øton, and the other Moiety of the Fee of the Barons of Dunham Ma≈ø≈øy.

It is plain the Pari≈øh Church here was a Rectory in the beginning of Edward the Third's Reign; which now hath Brereton of Honford for its Patron, 1666. and was inve≈øted in Sir Vrian Brereton, younger Son of Randle Brereton of Malpas, in the Right of Margaret his Wife, Daughter and Heir of William Honford of Honford E≈øquire, and Widow of Sir John Stanley; which Sir Vrian was living 1566.

p.hi: The Church here comprehendeth within its Pari≈øh,

div.p: The greate≈øt part of A≈øhton ≈øuper Mer≈øey at this day 1666. belongs to Brereton of Honford. The Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy hath about an eighth part thereof.

div.head: A≈øton juxta Sutton.
div.p: THis Town of A≈øton gave Name to the Family of the A≈øtons, who have been Seated here for a long time.

In the Record of Dooms-day Book we find, that Odard held this Town und ‚Ä¢ r William Fitz Nigell, Baron of Halton, ≈øub Anno Chri≈øti 1086. where we find onely one A≈øton named: for A≈øton juxt√† Sutton, and A≈øton-Grange, as now they be ≈øevered and di≈øtingui≈øhed, I conceive were then but one Town.

The ≈øame Odard held part of Dutton al≈øo from Hugh Lupus Earl of Che≈øter, as appears by the ≈øame Record; which Odard was the undoubted Ance≈øtor to the Duttons of Dutton, as appears by ≈øeveral Deeds of great antiquity among the Evidences of Dutton of Dutton, which I have ≈øeen.

About the Reign of Henry the Second, I find one Gilbert de A≈øton certainly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this Town of A≈øton juxta Sutton: In which Line and Family it hath continued ever ≈øince to this day, Sir Willoughby A≈øton of A≈øton Baronet being now Owner of the ≈øame, who hath built a ≈øumptuous Hou≈øe here a little di≈øtance from the old one, Anno Chri≈øti 1668.
Whether that Gilbert de A≈øton be De≈øcended from Odard, let the more curious make ≈øtrict enquiry; I am ≈øure I never yet ≈øaw any thing to prove it.

‚öúIn this Town is now onely one Charterer 1666. which ≈ømall Freehold Richard Morris of A≈øton is now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of: It belonged to one Higgin≈øon, who≈øe Daughter and Heir Married the ≈øaid Rich. Morris, and was formerly bought by one J. Higgin≈øon, the Le≈ø≈øee of this Land, from Thomas Paver of Lo≈øtock, John Thoma≈øon of Harpesford, and Richard Taylor, joynt Tenants thereof, 25 Hen. 8. This I conceive was part of that Oxgange of Land, which Richard de A≈øton gave away to Raufe, Son of Richard de Kingsley, in the Reign of Henry the Third.

In this A≈øton lieth a certain parcel of Land, called Middleton-Grange, as the ≈øame ≈øtands Mized by it ≈øelf in our common Mize-Book of Che≈øhire, and now belongeth to Sir Willoughby A≈øton Lord of this Town. I conceive it is the ≈øame with that called
Mid-Eston in Doome≈øday-Book, which then belonged to the Church of St. Werburge in Che≈øter; and was held by William Fit-Nigell Baron of Halton, as Tenant to St. Werburge: So called, as it were, Middle of A≈øton, when the Town was yet undivided, and lieth between A≈øton-Grange, and A≈øton juxt√† Sutton; howbeit it is now wholly taken to lie in Aston juxt√† Sutton. This Middle-Eston was confirmed to the Priory of Norton by John Lacy Earl of Lincoln and Baron of Halton, about the twentieth Year of Henry the Third, Anno Domini 1236. as I find the Deed tran≈øcribed in a long I archment Roll among the Evidences of Dutton of Dutton, at Dutton, wherein ≈øundry other Deeds belonging to the Priory of Norton are al≈øo tran≈øcribed, by the name of Middel-Estonam c√πm omnibus pertinentiis, quam habent ex Dono Dominae Matildae, quond√†m Uxoris Domini Collini de Loches: And al≈øo the Earl quits the ≈øame from Ward≈øhip and Relief, for him and his Heirs, which was due for that Land.

This Middleton-Grange, called al≈øo ≈øometimes Middle-Aston-Grange, was purcha≈øed from the King, after the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbeys, by Thomas Aston of Aston E≈øquire, 37 Hen. 8. for the Sum of 270 l. 11 s. 5 d. paying the yearly Rent of 1 l. 1 s. 9 d.
So I find in the Chartulary of Aston-Deeds, pag. 66. num. 537.

Here was anciently a Chappel called Middleton-Chappel, where the Prior and Convent of Norton were bound to find a Prie≈øt, in former Ages, to ≈øay Ma≈øs on Sundays, Wedne≈ødays, and Fridays, Weekly, for ever: Which Chappel being out of Repair, and Service ≈øaid there onely on Sundays for forty Years then la≈øt pa≈øt, it was complained of by Richard Aston, Son of Sir Robert Aston, at a Vi≈øitation 3 Hen. 6. 1425. and an Order was made by Richard Stanley then Arch-Deacon of Chester, the twentieth of August, 3 Hen. 6. That whereas the Prior and Convent of Norton, long before the ≈øame was an Abbey, did Covenant with the Abbot of Vale-Royal, to find at their own proper Co≈øt a fit Chaplain to Officiate here three days a week, as afore≈øaid; It was ordered, That the ≈øaid Agreement ≈øhould be kept and ob≈øerved. But the≈øe Variances concerning Middleton-Chappel, between Robert Abbot of the Mona≈øtery of St. Mary of Norton, and Richard Aston of Aston E≈øquire, were compo≈øed by the mediation of Thomas Dutton E≈øquire, and Anne his Wife, Dame I≈øabel late Wife of Sir John Carrington, and Jenkin of Leycester: Dated the tenth of November, 32 Hen. 6. The ≈øame Chartulary, pag. 23. num. 501. & pag. 21. num. 503. & pag. 216. num. 504.

But after that Middleton-Chappel fell into decay, another Chappel was erected in later Ages, ≈øomewhat nearer to the Hall of Aston, called Aston-Chappel, ≈øituate within the Pari≈øh of Runcorne; and in lieu of finding a Prie≈øt to Officiate here by the Abbot of Norton, the King (after tho≈øe Lands came into his Hands) gave five Pounds yearly Rent to the Maintenance of a Mini≈øter here at Aston-Chappel, i≈ø≈øuing out of the Lands late belonging to Norton-Abby, by a Decree in the Court of Augmentations at London, dated the 28 of January, 33 Hen. 8. Which Decree was Exemplified and Confirmed in the 13 Year of Queen Elizabeth, inter les Chartes de Aston, Num. 505. Which Sum of Five Pounds is yearly paid at this day, 1671. by the Kings Auditor at his Office at Chester.

And this Aston-Chappel was lately made a Parochial-Chappel in our days by the Grant of John Bridgeman Bi≈øhop of Chester, dated the ≈øixteenth of April, 11 Car. 1. 1635. by the procurement of Sir Thomas Aston of Aston Baronet; and ≈øo it is now become a Parochial Chappel for Burial, Bapti≈øm, and other Rites, for the≈øe adjacent Villages,‚Äî
