Now followeth the Pedegree of this Ancient Family of A≈øton of A≈øton juxt√† Sutton, with all care and fidelity taken by me from the Evidences of this Family, and in≈øerted in the Sumptuous Genealogy now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Willoughby A≈øton of A≈øton Baronet, 1671. wherein ≈øome more De≈øcents are put down than I conceive can be warranted by the Deeds, and exact Computation of Times; from which I mu≈øt crave leave to vary in ≈øome of the more Ancient De≈øcents.

II. Richard de A≈øton, by the Name of Richard de A≈øton, Son of Gilbert de A≈øton, gave unto Hugh Dutton of Dutton ≈øex Bovatas Terrae in A≈øton, in the beginning of the Reign of Henry the Third, about 1230. for then lived Geffrey Son of Adam de Dutton, who is one of the Witne≈ø≈øes, Lib. C. fol. 155. q. which Lands belong now to the Demain of Dutton, 1671. wherein the Chappel of Poo≈øey (now in decay) was ≈øituate within the Pari≈øh of Runcorne, and had its Name from the ≈øituation, being ≈øeated between the Park-Pool and the River; thence called Poo≈øey-Chappel: For Ee, or Ey, ≈øignifies a Brook in the old Saxon Language. And ≈øo much of the Park of Dutton, lying from Poo≈øey-Chappel towards A≈øton, with the little Fields above lying up to A≈øton-Town-Field, I take to be the Lands here granted to Dutton.

The ≈øame Richard al≈øo, by the Name of Ricardus de A≈øton, Filius Gilberti de A≈øton gave unto the Priory of Norton a certain place called Hendley (or Endley) which is now belonging to the Demain of Norton, and known by the Name of Endley-Wood. Lib. B. pag. 200. num. 8.

He gave al≈øo to Randle, Son of Richard de King≈øley, one Oxgange of Land in A≈øton, which John Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and Baron of Halton, confirmed; and was afterwards given to Hugh de Camera, by the Daughters and Heirs of Richard de King≈øley; and Hugh de Camera gave the ≈øame to Adam le Turner of Frod≈øham, as appears by Sir Willoughby A≈øton's Deeds.
This Richard had a Wife called Joan, and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Son and Heir.

III. Richard A≈øton of A≈øton, Son and Heir of Richard, had I≈ø≈øue Richard, and Robert; which Robert had I≈ø≈øue Richard, to whom Sir Robert Dutton of Mere in Stafford≈øhire gave a Parcel of Land in Radward, in the Fee of Mere and A≈øton in Stafford≈øhire; to wit, that Land which the ≈øaid Richard, Son of Robert, formerly held: The Original in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Willoughby A≈øton of A≈øton juxt√† Sutton, in Che≈øhire, Baronet, 1671.

I find al≈øo one Simon de A≈øton, who married Agnes, one of the Daughters and Coheirs of Adam Hatton of Hatton, nigh Daresbery in Che≈øhire, living 1290. Lib. C. fol. 4. which may fall out for the time to be a younger Son of this Richard A≈øton; but I cannot certainly affirm it.
This Richard A≈øton of A≈øton is ≈øaid to marry Maude, Daughter of William, Son of Herberd de Walton; and had I≈ø≈øue, Richard Son and Heir, and Margery, married to William Son of Hugh de Frod≈øham.

IV. Richard A≈øton of A≈øton, Son and Heir of Richard A≈øton, gave to his Brother
Robert two Oxganges of Land in A≈øton; one whereof Domina Johanna quond√†m tenuit, Mrs. Joane formerly held. This Deed was made tempore Edwardi Primi; and this Joane ≈øeems to be a Gentlewoman, probably the Wife of Richard Son of Gilbert de A≈øton afore≈øaid.

This Richard A≈øton married Ro≈øe, the fourth and younge≈øt Daughter, and after Coheir of Roger Thro≈ø≈øell of Maxfi√®ld in Che≈øhire, in the Reign of King Edward the Fir≈øt; and had I≈ø≈øue Richard A≈øton Son and Heir, and Hugh Prior of Birkenhed-Abby in Wirral-Hundred.
Ro≈øe was Widow, and living 18 Edw. 3. Placita apud Ce≈øtriam, 18 Edw. 3. in Vigili√¢ Beatae Mariae.

V. Richard A≈øton of A≈øton, Son and Heir of Richard, married Anabilla Daughter of Eva de Rode, and Si≈øter to William Rode of Rode in Che≈øhire, in the Reign of Edward the Second: The Chartulary of A≈øton-Deeds, pag. 2. and had I≈ø≈øue Robert A≈øton, living 7 Edw. 3. but then very young: Thomas, another Son, living al≈øo 7 Edw. 3. and Margery Or Margaret. a Daughter, married to William Son of William Walen≈øis de Halton, id e≈øt, Son of William the Wel≈øhman of Halton.

I find among Sir Willoughby A≈øton's Deeds, Num. 78. a Record under the Seals of 24. Per≈øons, dated the fourth of July, Anno Domini 1354. 29 Edw. 3. which Per≈øons are all named in the Deed of Record, and witne≈ø≈øing, That Sir Richard A≈øton of A≈øton Knight, Hugh and Richard Sons to the ≈øaid Sir Richard, and al≈øo Sir Robert of A≈øton Knight, Father of Richard A≈øton now Lord of A≈øton, were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a certain Corrody in the Abby of Norton; ≈øo as each of them ≈øhould have, and have had by them≈øelves, for finding a Yeoman, a Page, three Hor≈øes, a Brace of Grey-hounds, and a Go≈øhawke, according to their E≈øtate, with their Chambers, and ≈øuch Ea≈øment that belongeth to their Degree: Whereunto the Priors and Abbots of the ≈øaid Mona≈øtery in all their time (con≈øidering the great Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions given out of the Lord≈øhip of A≈øton to the ≈øaid Hou≈øe) were con≈øenting, granting, and yielding, as for their Right of old time granted and had.

VI. Sir Robert A≈øton of A≈øton Knight, Son and Heir of Richard A≈øton, married Felice Daughter of John Hawarden Citizen of Che≈øter, about 1338. and had I≈ø≈øue Richard A≈øton Son and Heir, Hugh ≈øecond Son, Lawrence, and James living 49 Edw. 3.

By the French Deed, Num. 57. it appears, That Richard A≈øton, Lord of A≈øton, did Covenant with John Hawarden Citizen of Che≈øter, That Robert, Son of the ≈øaid Richard, ≈øhould take to Wife Felice, Daughter of the ≈øaid John; and if Robert die before Marriage, then Thomas, another Son of the ≈øaid Richard, ≈øhould have her to Wife; with other Covenants, in ca≈øe Robert ≈øhould die before he attained unto fourteen Years of Age, or Matrimony had. Dated 7 Edw. 3. So that Robert was then very young.
This Sir Robert was dead before 29 Edw. 3. as appears by the Record afore≈øaid, dated 29 Edw. 3. and had I≈ø≈øue Richard A≈øton Lord of A≈øton, living 29 Edw. 3.
VII. Richard A≈øton of A≈øton, Son and Heir of Sir Robert, was Lord of A≈øton 29 Ed. 3. who died without I≈ø≈øue about 42 or 43 Edw. 3. or ≈øooner.

And the Right Line now failing, the E≈øtate came to Sir Richard A≈øton, If Fillote and Felice be here meant of the ≈øame Woman, and Daughter of the ≈øame John Hawarden, then is here ≈øome contradiction in the Evidences, and the two Robert A≈øtons confounded. Son of Robert A≈øton of Ringey in A≈øton, Son of Hugh A≈øton, Brother and Heir to Richard who died without I≈ø≈øue. It appears by the Te≈øtimony of Robin Hocan, 5 Hen. 5. 1417. then aged 70 Years, [Deed Num, 121.] That he knew Robin of A≈øton, Son and Heir of Hugh, to be married by Hugh his Father to Fillote Daughter of Black John Hawarden, at that time Steward of Hawarden; and that Robin and Fillote were Enfeoffed of a parcel of Land called Ringey, and had I≈ø≈øue Sir Richard A≈øton, and other Children; and afterwards Robin died in Spain in the life-time of Hugh his Father. This Hugh had to Wife Cicely, afterwards married to Hoknell; and Hugh married Richard his Grand≈øon, Son of Robert A≈øton of Ringey, unto Jonet Daughter of John Hoknell of Hurley, and had I≈ø≈øue: but Jonet, and all her Children, and Fillote Mother of Richard, died all of
the Pe≈øtilence at Ringey; and after Sir Richard A≈øton married Ellen Daughter of Geffrey Dutton; and that Hocan knew Sir Richard A≈øton occupying the whole Mannor of A≈øton for forty Years and more, and Sir Robert his Son occupying it for ≈øeven Years and more.

‚öúVIII. Sir Richard A≈øton of A≈øton Knight, (Son and Heir of Robert A≈øton of Ringey in A≈øton, From this Sir Richard downwards the Pedegree is very clear. Son of Hugh of A≈øton) married Jonet Daughter of John Hoknell of Huxley, and had divers Children by her, who died all of the Plague at Ringey, with their Mother al≈øo: Afterwards Sir Richard married Ellen Daughter and Heir of Geffrey Dutton, 9. Rich. 2. (which Geffrey was third Son of Sir Hugh Dutton of Dutton) by whom he had Lands in Listark and Halton. Ibidem, pag. 5. g. & pag. 8. a. 22 Rich. 2.

By Ellen he had I≈ø≈øue, Robert, Son and Heir; Henry, living 10 Hen. 5. Elianour married Richard Priestland of Priestland; Elizabeth married Thomas, Son of Thomas Boydell of Gaterich in Gropenhall, in Bucklow-Hundred, 17 Rich. 2. but had no I≈ø≈øue by him: After ≈øhe married Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Hale, 21 Rich. 2. And la≈øtly ≈øhe married Thomas Danyel of Over-Tabley, in the ≈øame Hundred of Bucklow; and ≈øhe died 11 Hen. 4. 1410. Lib. C. fol. 283. g. & fol. 281. f.

This Sir Richard was Trea≈øurer to Queen Philip, Wife of Edward the Third, of her Lands and Rents in Ambrage in Wales, 32 Edw. 3. and Steward of Hope≈ødale. He was a Soldier in Spain, 12 Rich. 2. and Steward of Halton, 10 Hen. 4.
Ellen, Wife of Sir Richard, after his death married John Rycroft.

IX. Sir Robert Aston of Aston Knight, Son and Heir of Sir Richard, married I≈øabel Daughter and Heir of John Beeston of _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Son and Heir, David Aston, living 23 Hen. 6. and Alice Wife of John Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale in this Hundred, 24 Hen. 6.

Sir Robert died 5 Hen 5. 1417. Afterwards I≈øabel his Widow married John Carington of Carington in this Hundred, 9 Hen. 5. He was afterwards Sir John Carington Knight. I≈øabel had the Ward≈øhip of Richard Aston her Son, pag. 7. c.

X. Sir Richard Aston of Aston Knight, Son and Heir of Sir Robert, married Maude Daughter and Heir of Peter Ma≈ø≈øy of Horton in Che≈øhire, by Margaret his Wife, Daughter and Heir of William de Horton, 9 Hen. 5. This Peter Ma≈ø≈øy was younger Son of Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Rixton in Lanca≈øhire, E≈øq

Sir Richard had I≈ø≈øue by Maude, Thomas Aston, Son and Heir; John, ≈øecond Son, living 7 Edw. 4. Geffrey Aston, third Son, living 19 Hen. 7. William, fourth Son, died without I≈ø≈øue 20 Hen. 7. Maude, married to John Done of Flax-yoards in Che≈øhire; Joan, Wife of Roger Dutton, afterwards Heir to all Dutton-Lands; which Joan, after the death of Roger, married Sir Richard Strangewaies: and Margery, another Daughter, married John Wood of Sutton, 2 Hen. 7.
Sir Richard died 8 Hen. 7. 1492.

XI. Thomas Aston of Aston E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Sir Richard, married Margaret, one of the Daughters of Sir Thomas Dutton of Dutton in this Hundred, 7 Edw. 4. 1467. She afterwards became a Co-heir to Dutton-Lands, and had Kekwick and Aston-Mondrem to her ≈øhare.
This Thomas died in the Life-time of Sir Richard his Father, about 1484. Margaret his Widow afterwards married Raufe Vernon of Ha≈ølington in Che≈øhire, E≈øq

XII. Richard Aston of Aston E≈øq Son and Heir of Thomas, married Dow≈øe, Daughter of Piers Warburton of Arley in this Hundred, E≈øq 1 Rich. 3. 1484. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, Son and Heir; Richard, a Prie≈øt, 26 Hen. 8. Robert Aston of Grange in Stafford≈øhire; John Aston of Grange, fourth Son; Katharine, Wife of Richard Broughton of Broughton in Stafford≈øhire; Alice married Randle, Son and Heir of Randle Manwaringe of Karincham in Che≈øhire, E≈øq 23 Hen. 7. and Anne married to William Ma≈ø≈øy of Rixton in Lanca≈øhire, E≈øq 10 Hen. 8. This Richard Aston died 20 Hen. 8. 1529.

XIII. Thomas A≈øton of A≈øton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, married Bridget, one of the Daughters of John Harewell, and Si≈øter and Co-heir to Thomas Harewell of Shotery in Warwick≈øhire, 4 Hen. 8. 1512. and had I≈ø≈øue, John, Son and Heir; Richard; Peter, third Son, 38 Hen. 8. who had a Ba≈øtard called Thomas A≈øton, then living at London; William, fourth Son, married Anne Daughter of Thomas Ireland of the Hutt in Lanca≈øhire, E≈øquire, and had I≈ø≈øue; and Francis, fifth Son.

He had al≈øo a Ba≈øtard ≈øon called Roger, afterwards Sir Roger A≈øton, Gentleman of the Bedchamber to King James, who marred Mary Stewart Daughter to Alexander Lord Oghiltrey, being lineally de≈øcended from Duncan Earl of Lenox in Scotland; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue, Margaret, married to Sir Gilbert Houghton of Houghton-Tower in Lanca≈øhire, Baronet; Mary, married to Sir Samuel Peyton of Knowlton in Kent, Baronet; Elizabeth, Wife of Sir Robert Winkfield or Upton in Northampton≈øhire; and Anne, Wife of Sir Thomas Perient of Colche≈øter in E≈ø≈øex: The≈øe were his four Daughters and Heirs. Afterwards Sir Roger A≈øton had to Wife Cordelia Si≈øter to the Earl of Che≈øterfield, but had no I≈ø≈øue by her.
Thomas A≈øton of A≈øton was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 1551. 4 Edw. 6. and died 6 Edw. 6.

XIV. John A≈øton of A≈øton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas, married Margaret Daughter of Thomas Ireland of the Hutt in Lanca≈øhire, E≈øquire, 38 Hen. 8. 1546. and had I≈ø≈øue, Thomas, Son and Heir; John, a Lawyer, died without I≈ø≈øue; Edward, another Son, died without I≈ø≈øue; Brigit, married Thomas Bunbury of Stanney in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire; Elizabeth, Wife of John Ma≈ø≈øy of Coughow, younger Brother to George Ma≈ø≈øy of Podington, E≈øquire, and afterwards Heir to his Brother; Margaret, Wife of Thomas Egerton of Walgreve, after of Sir Edward Tirrel of Thornton in Buckingham≈øhire; Mary, died without I≈ø≈øue; Elianour married James Whitlok; Winifrid, Wife of Peter Derby near Leverpool in Lanca≈øhire; Ellen, Wife of George Manwaring of Ightfield in Shrop≈øhire, Gentleman, a younger Brother; Ur≈øula, Wife of Geffrey Holcroft of Hur≈øt in Lanca≈øhire; al≈øo Richard, a Ba≈øtard-≈øon, who lived at Rock-Savage, and died at Halton 1616.
This John exchanged certain Lands in Whitley with Richard Starky of Stretton E≈øq for Lands in A≈øton, 1 Elizabethae: He died 5 Augu≈øti, 15 Eliz. 1573.
Margaret his Widow married Hugh Bee≈øton of Torperley in Che≈øhire, E≈øq 27 Eliz.

XV. Sir Thomas A≈øton of A≈øton, Son and Heir of John, was Knighted 1603. and married Elizabeth Daughter of Sir Arthur Manwaring of Ightfield in Shrop≈øhire, 11 Eliz. 1569. and had I≈ø≈øue, John, Son and Heir; Sir Arthur A≈øton of Fulham in Middle≈øex, ≈øecond Son, who had I≈ø≈øue Richard A≈øton, and Sir Arthur A≈øton a Colonel in Germany, and Governor of Oxford for the King, 1644. but was barbarou≈øly killed after at Tredagh in Ireland, having ≈øurrendred the Town to the Parliament-Rebels upon Conditions, 1655. and had I≈ø≈øue: Sir Thomas A≈øton, third Son of this Sir Thomas, married Elizabeth Daughter of John Shugborough of Burdenbury in Warwick≈øhire, E≈øquire, and had I≈ø≈øue: Frances, elde≈øt Daughter of Sir Thomas A≈øton of A≈øton, married John Hocknell of Hocknell in Che≈øhire, after to Richard Davys of Croughton, and thirdly to Owen Longford of Burton in Denbigh≈øhire; Grace, ≈øecond Daughter, died without I≈ø≈øue; Margaret, third Daughter, married Sir Thomas Ireland, who bought Beu≈øy nigh Warrington in Lanca≈øhire, and was Vice-Chamberlain of Che≈øter; Elizabeth, another Daughter, married Richard Dod of Cloverley in Shrop≈øhire; Mary, Wife of Richard Brown of Upton nigh Che≈øter, Gentleman; after to Jaques Arnodio, a Frenchman; Anne, another Daughter, married Richard Allen of Green-Hill in Nether-Whitley in Che≈øhire, Gentleman; Katharine, another Daughter, married Peter Legh of Ridge nigh Maxfield, Gentleman.
Sir Thomas had a ≈øecond Wife, called Mary, Daughter of William Unton of Draiton in Shrop≈øhire; but had no I≈ø≈øue by her.
This Sir Thomas was Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 1601. 43 Eliz. and died Anno Dom. 1613.
Mary his Widow afterwards Married Edward Paler of York E≈øquire.
Sir Thomas bought Lands in A≈øton from John Witter of Torperley, and Margaret his Wife, 20 Eliz. 1578.

XVI. John A≈øton of A≈øton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Sir Thomas, was Sewer to Queen Anne, Wife of King James, and Married Maude, Daughter of Robert Nedham of Shenton in Shrop≈øhire E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1611. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, Son and Heir; John A≈øton, ≈øecond Son, died unmarried 1648. Robert, third Son, died young: Maude Married Thomas Par≈øons of Cubbington in Warwick≈øhire E≈øquire; after to John Shugborough, now of Upton in Wirrall 1666. a younger Son of the Shugboroughs in Warwick≈øtire. Anne, another Daughter, died young. Elizabeth, another Daughter, died unmarried 1628.
This John A≈øton of A≈øton died 13 Maii 16 ‚Ä¢ 5. 13 Jacobi.

XVII. Sir Thomas A≈øton of A≈øton Baronet, Son and Heir of John; Married Magdalene, Daughter of Sir John Poultney, and Si≈øter and Coheir to John Poultney of Mi≈øterton in Leyce≈øter≈øhire E≈øquire, 1627. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Robert, who died young 1634. and Thomas, who died 1637. at the age of ≈øix years; and two Daughters, Jane and Elizabeth, who died Infants, as appears by the Monument in A≈øton Chappel.

Magdalene his fir≈øt Wife dying2 die Junii. 1635. he afterwards Married Anne, Daughter and ≈øole Heir of Sir Henry Willoughby of Ri≈øley in Derby≈øhire Baronet 1639. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Sir Willoughby Aston now living 1666. who Married Mary, Daughter of John Offley, late of Madeley in Stafford≈øhire E≈øquire, and al≈øo two Daughters, Magdalene and Mary, both living 1666.

This Sir Thomas was made Baronet in July, 4 Car. 1. 1628. and was Sheriff of Che≈øhire Anno Domini 1635. He died in the time of the late War between the King and his rebellious Parliament. He was Loyal to his Prince, and was unfortunately beaten by Sir VVilliam Brereton of Honford's Party of Rebels near to Nantwich, January 28. 1642. but Sir Thomas e≈øcaped and got away; after he was taken at another Skirmi≈øh in Stafford≈øhire, and brought Pri≈øoner to Stafford; where endeavoring to make an E≈øcape, a Soldier e≈øpying him, gave him a Blow on the Head, with which, and his other Wounds, he fell into a Feaver, whereon he died at Stafford not long after, to wit, 24 Martii 1645. and was buried at his own Chappel of Aston in Che≈øhire: which Chappel he procured to be Con≈øecrated by John Bridgeman Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, Anno Domini 1637. with liberty of Bapti≈øm and Burial, and repaired the Chancel thereof very hand≈øomly, though much defaced afterwards in the late War.

div.head: A≈øton-Grange.
div.p: IT ≈øeems to me, that Roger Fitz-Alured was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of A≈øton-Grange in the Reign of Henry the Second. See Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, Pars 2. pag. 186. which was held of the ancient Barons of Halton, and was afterwards given to the Priory of Norton.

But after the di≈ø≈øolution of Mona≈øteries in England by Hen. 8. Richard Brooke E≈øq purcha≈øed this Village from the King, together with the Mannor of Norton and other Lands, 37 Hen. 8. 1545. and hath ≈øince been enjoyed by his Po≈øterity unto this pre≈øent 1666. there being no Charterer at all within the ≈øame.

div.head: A≈øton juxta Great Budworth.
div.p: THis Town of A≈øton juxta Budworth, was held of the Earl of Che≈øter by William Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton, in the Reign of William the Conqueror, and one Pagan then held it under the ≈øaid William, ≈øcilic√®t ≈øub Anno Domini 1086. This appears by the Record of Dooms-day Book; and at this day it is within the Fee of Halton.

John, Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and Baron of Halton, The Originals penes Leyce≈øter de Tabley. gave the Mannor of Hield in this A≈øton, unto Methro≈øo Punterlinge in the Reign of Henry the Second, rendring yearly a Wel≈øh Lance on the Fea≈øt-day of St. Bartholomew. M. num. 1. Afterwards Geffrey, Son of Adam de Dutton, (Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley) buyeth the ≈øame from one Hugh the Wel≈øh Deacon, Son of Hugh del Hield, for twenty four Marks of Silver, in the Reign of Henry the Third, and gave it to Agnes de Dutton his Daughter. M. num. 2. & num. 5, 6.

But after, towards the latter end of Henry the Third, Robert de Denbigh and Margaret his Wife purcha≈øe it again from Geffrey, Son of Geffrey, Son of Adam de Dutton, for three Marks of Silver, and a Wich-hou≈øe in Northwich. I. num. 91. which Margaret was Daughter of the ≈øaid Geffrey, Son of Geffrey: but Robert Denbigh dying without I≈ø≈øue, the ≈øaid Margaret his Widow Married Nicholas de Leyce≈øter, about 1276. afterwards Sir Nicholas Leyce≈øter Knight, unto who≈øe I≈ø≈øue it remained, till John Leyce≈øter of Tabley ≈øold it again unto William del Heild and Goditha his Wife, and to the Heirs of the Body of the ≈øaid William, re≈øerving the yearly Rent of forty Shillings, Anno Domini 1355. 29 E. 3. M. num. 14. & num. 13.

And afterwards it became to be divided by the two Daughters and Coheirs of William del Heild, Margaret and Emme; M. num. 16. and ≈øo this Land of Heild continued to their Heirs, until the one Moiety thereof was purcha≈øed again by Thomas Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1500. M. num. 19. and the other Moiety was purcha≈øed by Dorothy Leyce≈øter Widow, from Richard Sutton of Sutton nigh Maxfield E≈øquire, Son of Francis Sutton, Anno Domini 1601. 43. Elizabethae. M. num. 60. So that the whole is now reverted again to Leyce≈øter.

There is al≈øo another Place in this A≈øton, called The Mannor of Wethale, which the afore≈øaid Geffrey, Son of Geffrey, Son of Adam de Dutton, gave unto Margaret his Daughter afore≈øaid, and to her Heirs, with all Commons and Ea≈øements of the Town of A≈øton: Et Sciedum e≈øt, qu√≤d ip≈øa Margareta, & Haeredes ≈øui, & Homines eorum qui manebunt in Wethale, habebunt Hou≈øebote & Haybote, & ≈øufficient√®r ad ardendum & ad aedificandum, de Bo≈øco de A≈øton ≈øin√® vi≈øu Fore≈øtariorum praedicti Galfridi, & haeredum ≈øuorum: habebunt eti√†m omnes Porcos ≈øuos proprios (ubicunqu√® fuerint nutriti) in eodem Bo≈øco ≈øin√® Pannagio, as the very words of the Deed do run. R. num. 3. At which time al≈øo he gave her the Town of Nether-Tabley by another Deed; and this about the latter end of the Reign of Henry the Third: for in the≈øe Ages Gentlemen u≈øed to give a large proportion of Lands with their Daughters in Marriage, rather than a ≈ømall Sum of Money, Land being then but of little value: All which Lands de≈øcended to her Heirs by Sir Nicholas Leyce≈øter. And Peter Dutton, Son of the ≈øaid Geffrey, relea≈øed all his Right in Nether-Tabley, Wethale and Heild, unto Roger Leyce≈øter, Son of Sir Nicholas, Anno Dom. 1296. 24 Edw. 1. I. num. 6. and do now remain in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Peter Leyce≈øter of Tabley Baronet, and his Tenants, at this day 1669.
The Mannors of VVethale and Heild in A≈øton juxta Budworth do contain about a third part of the Town of A≈øton, the Demaine Land of Arley being taken out and excepted.

All the re≈øt of this Town hath been enjoyed by the Ance≈øtors of the VVarburtons of Arley, from the time of Adam de Dutton afore≈øaid, even to this pre≈øent, ≈øave onely the Lands granted away by them unto the Predece≈ø≈øors of the≈øe Charterers following ‚Äîand now, 1666. in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of‚Äî
1. The Widow Gar≈øtid of Che≈øter, called Litley Lands, formerly belonging to Hayes of Litley, and was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by Adam, Son of William de Litley, Anno Domini 1335.
2. Daniel of Tabley hath two ≈ømall Tenements in A≈øton.
3. Raufe Vernon of A≈øton, called Wethale Farm.
4. Gerard of Wimbles-Trafford, late Picton's Land.
5. Philip Antrobus of Over-Pever, one ≈ømall Tenement in A≈øton.
6. Berry's Tenement in A≈øton, which formerly was the Inheritance of Sneyd of Bradwell, and ≈øold by William Sneyd unto Gawen Legh of Northwood, younger Son
of Matthew Legh of Swineyard in High-Legh, 35 Hen. 8. afterwards Richard Legh of Northwood ≈øold it to Peter Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire, 1633. and la≈øtly Sir Peter Leyce≈øter of Tabley ≈øold it to his Servant Thomas Jack≈øon of Heild, 1 Aprilis 1669. 21 Car. 2.

In this A≈øton is ≈øituated the Hall of Arley, now the chief Man≈øion-hou≈øe of the Warburtons of Arley; which Hou≈øe was built by Piers Warburton of Arley E≈øquire, who died 10 Hen. 7. 1495. wherein of late a Ground-Room hath been converted into a Chappel. But ≈øee more in Budworth of the ancient Places of Habitation of Warburton.
In the Feodary of Halton, about the beginning of Edward the Third, we read thus,‚Äî
Galfridus Warburton

cell.hi: Johannes Fitton tenet Villas de Budworth, & A≈øton juxt√† Budworth, tertiam partem de Tabley Superiori, & duas bovatas Terrae in Tabley Inferiori, & bovatam Terrae in quart√¢ parte de Comberbach, & unam bovatam Terrae in manu Prioris de Norton in Budworth, & totam Terram de Lythe ultr√† Dee juxt√† Ce≈øtriam, pro uno Feodo Militis & pro Relevio.

div.p: Where Geffrey Warburton is put over the Head, as then Tenant to the Baron of Halton for tho≈øe Services when this Feodary was made: the other po≈ø≈øibly as it ≈øtood in former Rentalls.
Here ≈øhould follow the De≈øcent of Warburton of Arley; but Sir George Warburton denied me the peru≈øal of his Evidences, ≈øo as it could not exactly be performed; wherefore I have omitted the ≈øame.

div.head: Baggiley.
div.p: The three fir≈øt named, I take to be Gilbert Venables Baron of Kinderton; Ranulfus, ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Ance≈øtor of the Manwarings; and Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy. Sunderland is Locus cognitus within the Town of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.

About the Reign of King John, Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy (then Lord of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, and De≈øcended from the other Hamon before named) gave unto Matthew de Bromhale, Bromhale, Duckenfield, and two parts of Baggiley, which the Father of the ≈øaid Matthew held of the ≈øaid Hamon, as his Inheritance in Knights Service, to him and his Heirs: Faciendo praedicto Hamoni & Haeredibus ≈øuis liberum Servitium Feodi unius Loricae; Quitting all other Service de aratro & ho≈øterio
Houe Gallice, an In≈øtrument of Hu≈øbandry to break up the Earth., & Segibus ≈øecandis, Feu
Feu Gallice, Fire, Fewel. Colligendo, & Homagio faciendo de Averiis, & de Pannagio, & Salicher
Salicher, puto pro Saligerio, carrying of Salt from the Wich, a Service in tho≈øe Ages very u≈øual., & de omnibus aliis con≈øuetudinibus,‚Äî&c. Lib. C. fol. 258. c. as I had it from Mr. Vernon's Notes.
Certain it is, that this Town gave Name to the Family of the Baggileys, who were Seated here.

Sir VVilliam Baggiley was Lord of Baggiley 13 Edw. 2. 1319. and John Baggiley his Son made a Feofment of the Mannor of Baggiley in Che≈øhire, and of his Mannors of Hyde and Leve≈øhulme in Lanca≈øhire, unto Sir John Legh of Booths nigh Knotsford, Covenanting that Sir John ≈øhall Settle them on the ≈øaid John Baggiley and the Heirs Males of his Body; and for default of ≈øuch, then to Settle the Mannor of Hyde on Sir John Hyde and his Heirs; and to Settle the Mannors of Baggiley and Leve≈øhulme upon William, John, and Geffrey, Sons of the ≈øaid Sir John Legh, and to the Heirs Males of their Bodies, in order one after another; the remainder to Thomas, Son of Richard Ma≈ø≈øy; then to John, Son of Robert Legh; then to William, Son of Piers Legh; then to Robert, Son of Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Kel≈øall. Lib. C. fol. 270 a. The Original in French, now remaining with Edward Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, 1666. a fair Seal with Sir John Legh's Coat of Arms, to wit, a Bend over two Bars; the other Seal is demoli≈øhed, to wit, Baggiley's Coat, three Lozenges, with a Bear's Head for the Cre≈øt. There is no Date put to the Deed; but Sir John Legh did Settle them accordingly, with the Services of all the Freeholders in Baggiley, to wit, Richard Son of VVilliam, Richard Hod, Robert Son of VVilliam, and Hamon Son of Edwin the VVi≈øe, Dated Anno Domini 1353. 28 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 271. num. 1. John Baggiley died about 1356.

There are now, 1666. four Charterers in Baggiley:
1. Geffrey Cartwright Gentleman.
2. Widow Tarvin.
3. VVilliam Gibben.
4. Thomas VVor≈øeley of Hale habet certas Terras in Baggiley.

div.head: Now followeth the Pedegree of the Leghs of Baggiley.

figure.head: Azure, two Bars Ar, a Bend Sable.

div.p: And afterwards he Married Joyce, the Widow of Sir Raufe Davenport of Davenport in Che≈øhire: for I find Sir William Legh of Baggiley and Joyce his Wife, Lea≈øed to Piers de Legh This was Piers Legh of Lime. and John his Brother, for ≈øix years, all the Office of the Serjeanty of the Hundred of Maxfield, which appertained to the ≈øaid Joyce during the Nonage or Minority of Raufe Davenport, Son and Heir of Sir Raufe Davenport late decea≈øed, rendring to the ≈øaid Sir William and Joyce twelve Marks yearly. Dated at Maxfield on All-Saints-day, 9 Rich. 2. 1385. Lib. A. fol. 150. l. the Original Pen√®s Legh of Baggiley, 1665.

By which Joyce Sir William Legh had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Legh, Son and Heir, aged eighteen years, 21 Julii, 4 Hen. 4. 1403. on which day the ≈øaid Sir William Legh died. Obiit 1403 Lib. A. fol. 152. k. Lawrence, another Son of Sir VVilliam, living 28 Hen. 6. Lib. A. fol. 150. I.
Joyce, the Widow of Sir VVilliam, Married Sir John Kighley, 7 Hen. 4. living al≈øo 11 Hen. 4. 1410. Lib. A. fol. 151. w.

Ex Chartulis Legh de Baggiley.II. Thomas Legh of Baggiley, Son and Heir of Sir William, married Elizabeth Daughter of _____ and had I≈ø≈øue, William, elde≈øt Son; Richard, Nicholas, Thomas, Geffrey, John, and James; all living 1 Hen. 6. 1423. Lib. A. fol. 151. r. x. Al≈øo Katharine, a Daughter, married John A≈øhley of A≈øhley in Bowdon Pari≈øh, from whom ≈øhe was divorced 1432. 11 Hen. 6. And Margaret married Thomas Hyde of Urme≈øton in Lanca≈øhire,
Obiit 1456 living 7 Hen. 6.
This Thomas died about 34 Hen. 6. 1456. Lib. A. fol. 150. P.
III. William Legh, Son and Heir of Thomas, married Alice Daughter of _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Edmund Legh Son and Heir.
Obiit 1437 This William died in the Life-time of Thomas his Father, about 16 Hen. 6. For Alice his Widow I find married to Thomas Duncalfe, 17 Hen. 6. Lib. A. fol. 151. S.

IV. Edmund Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, 35 Hen. 6. Son and Heir of William, married Margery Daughter of John Savage of Clifton, 1442. 21 Hen. 6. The Di≈øpen≈øation for their Marriage bears date 5 die Novembris, 1442. Lib. C. fol. 271. e. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue, John, Son and Heir; Richard, ≈øecond Son, Lib. A. fol. 150. q. & f. I find in John Booth of Tamlowe his Book of Pedegrees, That this Edmund had al≈øo another Son, called Randle, who was never married; but had three Ba≈øtard-≈øons, Randle Legh, begot on the Daughter of Carington of Carington; Henry Legh, begotten of Woodrofe's Widow in Darby≈øhire; and Nicholas Legh another Ba≈øtard-≈øon. Edmund had al≈øo another Son, Hamlet Legh, who married the Lady Hillyard; and Dorothy, a Daughter, the third Wife of Sir John Stanley of Elford in Stafford≈øhire.

Obiit 1475 This Edmund Legh of Baggiley died about 15 Edw. 4. 1475. For Margery his Widow married Thomas Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, 17 Edw. 4. Anno Domini 1477. Lib. C. fol. 271. d. She was the ≈øecond Wife of Thomas Leyce≈øter.

V. Sir John Legh of Baggiley Knight, Son and Heir of Edmund and Margery, married Ellen Daughter of Sir William Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 6 Edw. 4. 1466. Lib. A. fol. 151. y. Whereby it appears, That this John Legh was then under 16 Years of Age; and had I≈ø≈øue, William, Henry, Richard, Hamon, Raufe, Peter, Blanch, Katharine, and Jane. Lib. A. fol. 150. f.

Indeed VVilliam Legh, elde≈øt Son of Sir John, married Maude Daughter of VVilliam Davenport of Bromhall in Maxfield Hundred, 7 Hen. 7. 1491. Lib. A. fol. 151. a. but he dying without I≈ø≈øue, in the Life-time of Sir John his Father, Maude afterwards married VVilliam Tatton Gentleman, Lib. A. fol. 150. f. and ≈øo Henry became Heir. VVilliam was dead 20 Hen. 7,
After the death of Ellen, Sir John Legh married Jane Daughter of Hugh Calveley of Lea in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, near Eaton-boat, 21 Hen. 7. 1505. Lib. A. fol. 150 d.
This Sir John Legh had al≈øo a Ba≈øtard-≈øon, called John Legh, living 21 Hen. 7. on whom Sir John ≈øetled a Tenement in Leve≈øhulme in Lanca≈øhire, as an Annuity for his Life. Lib. A. fol. 141. b.

VI. Henry Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, ≈øecond Son, and Heir to Sir John his Father, married Jane Daughter of Thomas Ma≈ø≈øy of Podington in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, 20 Hen. 7. 1504. Lib. A. fol. 150. e. and had I≈ø≈øue John, Son and Heir.

John, Son and Heir of Henry, married Margaret Daughter of Otes Reddi≈øh of Reddi≈øh in Lanca≈øhire, E≈øquire, 1 Hen. 8. 1509. Lib. A. fol. 150. f. and had I≈ø≈øue, Frances, married to Raufe Arderne of Harden in Maxfield Hundred: She had her Portion paid her by Richard Legh her Great-Uncle, third Son of Sir John Legh, and next Heir-male. Lib. A. fol. 152. h. 3 Edw. 6. 1549.
John Legh, Son of Henry, died about 24 Hen. 8.

VII. Richard Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, third Son of Sir John, and Brother and next Heir-male to Henry Legh, was Lord of Baggiley 3 Edw. 6. 1549. He married Elizabeth Daughter of Arnold Ryle, and had I≈ø≈øue Edward Legh, and eight Daughters: Katharine married William Brigge of Brigge-Hall, 32 Hen. 8. Jane married Charles Booth; Alice married Roger Legh; Ellen married Robert Ryle de Bottoms; Margaret married John Torkinton of Torkinton; Cicely, another Daughter; I≈øabel died a Child; Elizabeth married Gilbert Bibby of Salford.
This Richard Legh died 4 Edw. 6. 1550.

VIII. Edward Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, married Jane Daughter of Sir Vrian Brereton de Honford nigh Wim≈ølawe, from whom he was Divorced; and after he married Margaret Daughter of Robert Vaw of Riddings in Timperley, Gentleman; and had I≈ø≈øue, Richard Legh, Son and Heir; and Edward, who died without I≈ø≈øue. Obiit 1607
Edward Legh E≈øquire died May 12. 1607.

IX. Richard Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Edward, married Mary Daughter of William Gla≈øier of Lea, Vice-Chamberlain of Che≈øter, and had I≈ø≈øue, Henry, Edward, Richard, Thomas, George, VVilliam, Hugh, John, and Robert; al≈øo Anne married Daniel Baker Fellow of Manche≈øter-College, and Par≈øon of A≈øhton ≈øup√®r Mer≈øey; Mary, Elizabeth; Towne≈øend married John Davenport Clerk, ≈øecond Son to Sir VVilliam Davenport of Bromhall; and Jane an Infant.

Of the≈øe, Edward and Robert married in Ireland.
Obiit 1621
This Richard Legh of Baggiley was Buried at Norden, March 27. 1641.

X. Henry Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, married Rebecca Daughter of Sir George Clive of Huxley in Che≈øhire, Knight; and had I≈ø≈øue Richard, Henry, Edward, Thomas, William, and Raufe; al≈øo Su≈øan married Nicolas Walker of A≈øhton under Lyme; Mary, Katharine, Elizabeth, Frances married to John Chorleton of Manche≈øter, Margaret, and another Elizabeth: But none of the≈øe Daughters had any I≈ø≈øue. Obiit 1634
This Henry was Buried at Bowdon, March 20. 1634.
XI. Richard Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Henry, married Brigit Daughter of Sir Edward Harrington of Fidlington in Rutland≈øhire, Baronet; but had no I≈ø≈øue.
This Richard Legh died without I≈ø≈øue, and was Buried at Bowdon, Augu≈øt 10. 1642. Obiit 1642 leaving his Brother Edward to ≈øucceed.
Brigit his Widow afterwards married Sir John Gore of Gil≈øton in Hartford≈øhire; and now ≈øhe hath married Sir Thomas Tirrell of Ca≈øtle-Thorp in Buckingham≈øhire.

XII. Edward Legh of Baggiley E≈øquire, Brother and Heir to the la≈øt Richard; married Elinour Daughter of William Tatton of Witthen≈øu, E≈øquire, nigh Baggiley; and by her had I≈ø≈øue, Edward, Henry, Anne, Chri≈øtian, and Rebecca; but onely Chri≈øtian is now ≈øurviving, 1666. who married Raufe Wilbraham, younger Brother to Sir Thomas Wilbraham of Woodhey in Che≈øhire, Baronet, Anno Domini 1667.

This Edward Legh the Father is yet ≈øurviving, and married to his ≈øecond Wife Mary Daughter of William Jones of Sanford in Shrop≈øhire, late Coun≈øellor at Law, Anno Domini 1665. and hath I≈ø≈øue Mary, born 1666. Sophia, another Daughter, born 1667.

div.head: Barnton.
div.p: IN the Conqueror's Time one Mundret held Bertintune of the Earl of Che≈øter, which one Dunninge held before; and al≈øo one Ulviet held Bertintune, which one Levenot held formerly: ≈øo we read in Doome≈øday-Book. By which I under≈øtand, Mundret held one Moiety of Barnton, and Ulviet the other half; unle≈øs the one of the≈øe ≈øhould be meant for Barterton.

William, Son of Henry, Son of Serlo, grants to Hugh Dutton of Dutton in this Hundred, half the Town of Berthinton, which Robert de Mei≈ønilwarin [or Manwaringe] held of the ≈øaid William, rendring yearly a Pair of White Gloves on the day of the Nativity of St. John Bapti≈øt: For which Grant Hugh Dutton gave unto him three Marks of Silver in pleno Comitatu Ce≈øtriae: And this was in the Reign of King John, Philip Orreby being then Judge of Che≈øter. Lib. C. fol. 155. I. The Original among the Evidences of Dutton of Dutton, 1666.

But Dutton of Dutton was Lord of all Barnton in the time of King Edward the Fir≈øt; for in the Office of Sir Hugh Dutton, taken at Frod≈øham, 22 Edw. 1. he is found to die ≈øei≈øed of two Shillings Chief-Rent yearly from Randle de Berthinton, for the one Moiety of Barnton; and al≈øo of other two Shillings yearly Rent from Geffrey Starkey, for the other Moiety of Barnton. Lib. C. fol. 156. bb. Which Office is enrolled in the Leiger-Book of Vale-Royal Abby, fol. 45. b. now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Thomas Merbury of Merbury nigh Great-Budworth, E≈øquire, 1666. a Copy whereof al≈øo remains among the Evidences of Dutton of Dutton.

At this day, 1666. this ≈ømall Village is mangled into ≈øeveral Parcels, now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the≈øe Per≈øons following.‚Äî
1. Stanley of Alderley hath one Tenement here, in Lea≈øe to John Ba≈ønet.
2. Thomas Merbury of Merbury hath another Parcel.
3. John Starkey of Huntrode in Lanca≈øhire hath three Tenements here in Lea≈øe, and half of Chri≈øtopher Ba≈ønets Tenement.
4. Chri≈øtopher Ba≈ønet, and Jo≈øeph his Son, have the one moiety of their Tenement in Fee-farm.
5. Sir Edward Mo≈øeley of Howes-end in Lanca≈øhire, Baronet, lately decea≈øed, one Tenement, Lea≈øed to Robert Litler.
6. Sir Thomas Smith of Hatherton in Che≈øhire, a Parcel ≈øold lately to Jo≈øeph Ba≈ønet.
7. Hugh Lownds of Odrode hath another Parcel.
8. Thomas Frith of Barnton, a good Farm.
9. Pawnall of Barnton, a good Farm.
10. Thomas Vernon of Barnton, another ≈ømall Parcel.
11. Legh of Swineyard in High-Legh, Gentleman, a good Farm. This was part of Starkey's moiety.
12. Randle Wrench, and John his Son, a ≈ømall Parcel Fee-farm Land.

div.head: Barterton.
div.p: Ex Chartulis Vice-Comiti≈ø≈øae Kilmorey de Dutton.THis ≈ømall Town of Barterton lieth between Dutton and Little-Legh: It is in Old Deeds written Bertrinton.
Sir Hugh Dutton of Dutton bought half of Barterton from John Son of Richard de Cur≈øun, in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt. Lib. C. fol. 155. k.

In the Roll of the Ancient Chartes, called Doome≈øday, anciently remaining among the Records at Che≈øter, but now lo≈øt and taken away, it was found,‚ÄîLeuca, quae fuit Uxor Ranulfi de King≈øley, veniens in pleno Comitatu Ce≈øtriae cor√†m Radulfo de Manwaringe t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, & Baronibus, &c. quietum clamavit Ricardo de King≈øley totam
Villam de Bertherton, und√® dotata fuit. So that in the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt, it ≈øeems King≈øley of King≈øley was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of all the Village of Barterton.

One fourth part of the Town≈øhip, Margery, one of the Daughters and Heirs of Richard de King≈øley, gave unto Richard her Son, in her Widowhood, whom ≈øhe had by Hugh de Cholmondley her Husband; which de≈øcended unto her out of her Fathers Inheritance: Lib. C. fol. 155. kk. This was in the Reign of Henry the Third. And this fourth part Sir Hugh Dutton of Dutton bought of Hugh Lord of Cholmondley, about 13 Edw. 1. 1285. the≈øe being Witne≈ø≈øes; Domino Rogero Priore de Norton, Domino Vriano de Sancto-Petro, Domino Willielmo de Venables, Domino Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy, Nicolao de Leyce≈øter t√πnc Ballivo de Halton, Roberto Gro≈ø≈øo-venatore tunc Vice-comite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, Alexandro de Baumvyle, Ranulpho Starkey. Lib. C. fol. 155. l. Twenty Marks he gave for the Purcha≈øe.

William Lancelyn being Lord of one other fourth part, as de≈øcended from another Co-heir of King≈øley of King≈øley, ≈øells the Royalty thereof to the ≈øaid Sir Hugh Dutton, in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, in the≈øe words,‚ÄîScilicet totum Dominium ≈øuum quartae partis Villae de Berterton; videlic√®t partem Willielmi filii Willielmi de Berterton, c√πm Homagiis, Wardis, &c. Pro h√¢c Donatione dedit dictus Hugo tre≈ødecem Marcas Argenti prae manibus. Lib. C. fol. 155. ll. And after Sir Hugh and his Heirs bought out ≈øeveral Parcels, as they lay ≈øcattered in ≈øeveral hands, and ≈øo made this Town entirely their own.

One Tenement in Barterton, late in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one Bradburne, was purcha≈øed not long ≈øince from Crosby of Over-Whitley by John Dutton of Dutton E≈øquire, in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth. It formerly belonged to one Jud≈øon, 18 Edw. 4. Richard Jud≈øon gave it to Robert Colt≈øtan≈øock of Cog≈øhull, 1 Rich. 3. and Peter Col≈øtan ≈øoke ≈øold it to Hugh Crosby of Great Budworth, 8 die Augu≈øti, 3 & 4 Phil. & Mar. whereunto Sir Thomas Venables of Kinderton relea≈øed all his Right 7 Elizabethae, as appears by the Deeds now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Robert Pickering of Thelwall Lawyer, 1666. And Crosby ≈øold it unto Dutton.
And ≈øo this Town of Barterton is now wholly belonging to the Heir of Dutton of Dutton, not having any Charterer therein, Anno Domini 1666.

div.head: Bexton.
div.p: THis Town of Bexton lieth between Sudlowe and Toft: It is a very ≈ømall Hamlet, but 2 s. 9 d. in the Mize-Book; in the very Corner-point whereof, towards Plumley, four Town≈øhips do all meet in an Angle, to wit, Bexton, Toft, Plumley, and Nether-Tabley.

I believe this Town was Wa≈øte in the Conqueror's time;Ex Chartulis Daniell of Over-Tabley. I find little mention thereof before Henry the Third; about that time Robert de Bexton ≈øeems to be po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a moiety thereof at lea≈øt: for he and Sibill his Wife, by the con≈øent of Matthew de Bexton their Son and Heir, do give to Randle Son of Thomas de Picmere, with Margery their Daughter, totam quartam partem medietatis totius Villae de Bexton: Reddendo annuat√¨m unum Denarium Argenti ad Nativitatem Beati Johannis Bapti≈øtae- Lib. C. fol. 240. e.

John, Son of Matthew de Bexton, relea≈øeth to Adam de Tabley, and Beatrix his Wife, all the Lands which Maude, Mother of the ≈øaid John, held in Dower in Bexton, under Edward the Second: Whereunto another John de Bexton is Witne≈øs. Lib. C. fol. 241. f.

Adam de Tabley was Lord of half of Bexton, 1304. as appears by the Agreement made inter Johannem de Lo≈øtocke Dominum medietatis Villae de Bexton ex un√¢ parte, & Adamum de Tabley Dominum medietatis eju≈ødem Villae ex alter√¢; ≈øup√®r Clau≈øturas bladorum ≈øuorum de Bexton: Datum apud Knotsford, Anno Domini 1304. Lib. C. fol. 241. h.
And then Adam de Tabley, Son of the other Adam, ≈øettles his Dominium Parcenarium de Bexton after his death on Thomas Son of Thomas Daniell, 35 Edw. 3. 1361. Lib. C. fol. 241. k.

Since which time, the moiety of Bexton hath belonged to the Daniels of Over-Tabley,
even to this pre≈øent 1666. Concerning this Adam de Tabley, ≈øee more in Over-Tabley

In a loo≈øe Paper among the Evidences of Daniell of Over-Tabley, I find a Copy of a Deed, wherein John de Bexton gives Ricardo filio Johannis de Croxton, & Margeriae Uxori ejus filiae meae, tertiam partem totius medietatis Villae de Bexton, excepto Capitali Me≈ø≈øuagio: Habendum ≈øibi & Haeredibus inter eos‚ÄîRemanere Hawi≈øiae & Elianorae Filiis meis‚Äîremanere rectis Haeredibus meis‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Willielmo de Ma≈ø≈øy, Johanne de Legh Militibus, Rogero de Leyce≈øter, &c. Sub Edw. 3.

p.hi: Memorandum, Qu√≤d praedicta Hawi≈øia nupta fuit Willielmo de Moulton: Et Elinora nupta fuit Willielmo Filio Roberti de Winnington.

div.p: This Memorandum was writ in the bottom of the Paper. Lib. C. fol. 244. p.
This John Bexton I take to be the ≈øame with John Lo≈øtock above-named; and called Bexton, from the Place of his Re≈øidence.

I find al≈øo, John de Bexton gave to William Son of Robert de Winnington, and to Elianour his Wife, totam tertiam partem totius medietatis Villae de Bexton, tempore Edw. 2. John Booth's Book, Lib. H. pag. 117. h. The Original pen√®s Leyce≈øter of Toft.

And Hugh Toft of Toft grants to Sir Hugh Venables of Kinderton, all his Land in Kinderton apud Ru≈øhford, and a place of Land in Spro≈øton‚Äîin exchange pro ≈øext√¢ parte Manerii de Bexton, 24 Edw. 3. 1350. Lib. C. fol. 226. l. Pen√®s Leyce≈øter of Toft.

In an ancient Feodary of Halton, we read,‚ÄîJohannes de Bexton tenet medietatem Villae de Bexton pro vice≈øim√¢ parte unius Feodi Militis. And over the head of John de Bexton, are writ, Thomas Daniel, Raufe Hul≈øe, and Thomas Croxton: The≈øe la≈øt (as I conceive) as the Pre≈øent Tenants about Henry the Sixth's time, when that Rental was renewed; the other, as he ≈øtood in former Records of Edw. 1. or Edw. 2. Lib. C. fol. 86.
Thomas Holford of Holford held Land in Bexton, of the Baron of Halton, in Knight-Service, as appears by his Office 12 Eliz. a ≈ømall Parcel.

So Robert Bromfield of Witton died ≈øei≈øed of Land in Bexton, held of the Barony of Halton in Knight-Service, by Office taken 12 Eliz. but this Land was ≈øold afterwards by Bromfield to the Lady Mary Cholmondley of Holford, who gave it to Hugh Cholmondley her younger Son.
Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever had Land in Bexton and Baggiley, found by Office, Anno 5 & 6 Phil. & Mar. to be held of Edward Legh of Baggiley by Fealty, and rendring a Red Ro≈øe yearly.
Sir Raufe Leyce≈øter of Toft had Land in Bexton and Plumley, found by Office 14 Eliz. to be held of the Honour of Halton.
Paver of Northwich had a Me≈ø≈øuage in Bexton, found by Office 5 Eliz. to be held of the Barony of Halton; and ≈øo Anne Pavers Office, 40 Eliz.
Thomas Winnington of Ermitage nigh Holmes-Chappel had Land in Bexton, found to be held of John Croxton by Office 34 Eliz. a ≈ømall Parcel.

William Croxton of Raven≈øcroft died ≈øei≈øed of the third part of the Mannor of Bexton, found to be held of Halton by the third part of the twentieth part of a Knights Fee, by Office taken 32 Eliz. and John Croxton's Office, 41 Eliz. tenuit medietatem totius Villae de Bexton.

But Croxton's Land in Bexton was ≈øold to the Lady Mary Cholmondley of Holford afore≈øaid, who gave tho≈øe purcha≈øed Lands in Bexton to her younger Son Hugh Cholmondley, who≈øe Son and Heir Robert afterwards became Heir to all Cholmondley-Lands, and is now Lord Vi≈øcount Kelles in the County of Meth in Ireland, and living 1666.
So that now, Anno Domini 1666. the Town of Bexton is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the≈øe Per≈øons following.

list.item: 1. Robert Lord Cholmondley, Lord of the moiety of Bexton: He hath about 70 Che≈øhire Acres in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Tenants there, who pay one Shilling Chief to Halton yearly.
2. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley. E≈øquire, Lord of the other moiety of Bexton: He hath about 65 Acres in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of him and his Tenants there.
3. George Leyce≈øter of Toft, one Tenement in Bexton, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of William Highfield, about 20 Acres.

4. Thomas Deane of Nether-Pever, one Tenement, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of George Swinton, about 30 Acres. This formerly belonged to one Hul≈øe of Middle-wich Of Clyve, near to Middle-wich. , and payeth a Chief to Cholmondley, and al≈øo to Halton.

5. Thomas Cholmondeley of Holford E≈øquire, a ≈ømall Cottage, about four Acres, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Hugh Woodward his Tenant. This anciently belonged to Holford, before the Lady Mary Cholmondley purcha≈øed any Lands in Bexton.

div.head: Bollinton.
div.p: THis Town hath its Name from the River of Bollin, which runneth along after the ≈øide thereof: It is not mentioned in the Record of Doom≈øday-book; ≈øo that it ≈øeems to be Wa≈øte in the time of the Conqueror.

Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy, Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, gave unto Geffrey Dutton, Son of Geffrey Dutton, all his Land in Bolinton, to wit, all the moiety of Bolinton, with Agnes his Daughter, in Free-marriage; Rendring yearly a Pair of Gilded Spurs, at the Nativity of St. John Bapti≈øt: About the beginning of Henry the Third, Lib. C. fol. 150. a.

The ≈øame Agnes in her Widowhood, by the name of Agnes de Nechel (perhaps meant for Etchells) late Wife of Sir Geffrey de Chedle, gave unto her elde≈øt Son Geffrey de Chedle, all that Land of Bolinton which ≈øhe had of the Gift of Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy her Father: Lib. C. fol. 150. b. William de Ma≈ø≈øy being then Par≈øon of Ro≈øthorne, and William de Baggiley Par≈øon of Chedill, under Henry the Third.
Hereby it appeareth, That one moiety of Bolinton was of the Fee of the Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy; and al≈øo that the≈øe Duttons a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Chedill.

21 Edw. 3. Henry Clayton of Thelwall had this moiety. In another old Rental of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, dated 3 Hen. 4. Henricus Ratcliffe (he was Brother of Sir John Ratcliffe. See Lib. C. fol. 262. g.) ut de jure Uxoris ≈øuae tenet medietatem Villae de Bolinton in Socagio, reddendo in Termino Johannis Bapti≈øtae unum Par Calcarium deauratorum, vel octo decem Denarios. Lib. B. pag. 209.

And Robert Ratcliffe Earl of Su≈ø≈øex ≈øelleth all his Land in Bollinton and Thelwall unto John Carington of Carington E≈øquire: Dated 15 of Augu≈øt, 28 Hen. 8. 1536. The Original among the Lord Delamere's Evidences at Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.

And la≈øtly, Sir George Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy married Jane ≈øole Daughter and Heir of John Carington of Carington, about the end of Queen Elizabeth's Reign; who≈øe Grand-≈øon George Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy is now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this moiety of Bollinton, Anno Lomini 1666.
The other moiety of Bollinton is held of the Barony of Kinderton.

One half of this moiety Robert de Mar√¢ (that is, Mere of Mere) gave to Richard Son of Gilbert de Quike, and to Robert Son of Hugh de Ditton, in the Reign of Henry the Third, Lib. C. fol. 208. q. rendring three Shillings yearly: Whereunto are Witne≈ø≈øes, Robert Chaplaine of Rosthorne, Alan of Tatton, Gilbert of Bolinton, Robert of Tabley, (that is, Over-Tabley) William his Brother, and another William de eadem Vill√¢, and others. The Original among the Evidences of John Mere of Mere, Anno Chri≈øti 1650.
Adam Filius Roberti Juvenis de Ditton relea≈øeth all his Right in Bollinton to Richard Son of Gilbert de la Quike: Lib. C. fol. 206. a.
Afterwards Thomas le Eyr de Bolinton grants this fourth part to William Mere de Mere Domino ≈øuo, for twenty Pound: Sub Edw. 1. Lib. C. fol. 210. n.

William Mere of Mere E≈øquire ≈øells it to James Brampton of Toynton next to Horn-ca≈øtle in Lincoln≈øhire, for 350 l. 42 Eliz. Lib. C. fol. 250. f. And James Brampton of Legborne in Lincoln≈øhire ≈øells it to Sir George Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy for 450 l. 45 Eliz. 26 Novembris. Lib. C. fol. 250. g.
So that the Lord Delamere hath now three parts of the four of the Village of Bollinton. ‚öú

The other fourth part of Bolinton, Robert de Mar√¢ the elder gave to Gilbert de Bolington, to be held by the eighth part of half a Knights Fee; becau≈øe the ≈øaid Gilbert had re≈øigned it up in plen√¢ Curi√¢ Roberti, about King John's time. Lib. C. fol. 206. b.
This fourth Part now Legh of Booths hath.

list.head: Charterers in Bolinton, 1666.
list.item: 1. Thomas Warburton of Partington hath one Cottage in Bolinton.
2. Sir George Warburton of Arley, Baronet, hath about two Acres in Bolinton, called Heskith-Acres, lying in Bolinton-Ees.
3. Edward Allen of Ro≈øthorne hath one Meadow in Bolinton.

div.head: Bowdon.
div.p: THis Town of Bowdon takes its Name from our two old Saxon Words, [Bode] which is yet in u≈øe with us for a Dwelling or Habitation, and [Don, or Dun] which is as much as a Plain upon a ri≈øing Hill, for which we now u≈øe the word Down: So that Bodon ≈øignsfies as much as, A Town or Dwelling on the Downs: Unle≈øs perhaps we write it Boge-don (for ≈øo we find it anciently written in Doom≈øday-book) and then it may denote a Down or Hill by a Bog; at the ≈øide whereof, towards A≈øhley, lieth a great deep Bog.
Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy, the fir≈øt Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, held this Town of Bodon in the Conqueror's time, under Hugh Lupus then Earl of Che≈øter.

Ex Chartulis Georgii Baronis de Delamere apud Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy. Roger Ma≈ø≈øy of Hale, Son of Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy, being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of one half of Bodon, ≈øold all his Land in Bodon, to wit, totam medietatem Villae de Bodon, unto Agatha de Ma≈ø≈øy, for 4 l. 7 s. 0 d. in Money, and two Robes, one for him≈øelf, and the other for his Wife: Rendring therefore yearly one Pound of Cummin-≈øeed at the Fea≈øt of St. Martin: About the beginning of Henry the Third's Reign. Lib. C. fol. 252. I.

Which Agatha, by another Deed, ≈øtyling her ≈øelf Agatha de Theray, gave the ≈øame moiety of Bodon to Robert her younger Son, whom ≈øhe made Heir thereof by con≈øent of Sir Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy her elde≈øt Son. Lib. C. fol. 252. k.

Robert de Ma≈ø≈øy, by the con≈øent of his Wife and Heirs, gave unto Adam de Bowdon two Oxganges of Land in Bowdon; Rendring yearly one Penny upon the Altar of St. Mary of Bowdon, on the Nativity of St. Mary the Virgin (which is the eighth day of September) in perpetual Alms, for the Salvation of the Souls of the ≈øaid Robert, his Wife, and Ance≈øtors, and of his Heirs, and for the Soul of Matthew de Hale: Sub Henrico tertio. Lib. C. fol. 252. h.

From which time there hath been a Family of Gentlemen of the Bowdons of Bowdon, who had a fourth part of Bowdon, until Vrian Bowdon of Bowdon, 4 Junii, 7 Elizabethae, ≈øold to William Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy E≈øquire, certain Parcels of Land in Bowdon; nec non omnia Me≈ø≈øuagia & Terras,‚Äîquae habet in Bodon, Hale, & Doneham. And 11 Elizabethae, Thomas Vawdrey of Bodon, and George his Son, ≈øell to Hugh Crosby of Over-Whitley, ≈øeveral Parcels of Land in Bodon (which I conceive Bodon had pa≈øt away to Vawdrey before) by two Deeds; one dated 25 Octobris, 11 Eliz. and the other dated 28 Junii, 11 Elizabethae. And Hugh Crosby of Over-Whitley ≈øells all tho≈øe his Lands in Bowdon unto Sir George Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, for 220 l. which then were in the ≈øeveral Holdings of Thomas Vawdrey, Robert Mo≈ø≈øe, Thomas Hardy, George Vawdrey, Thomas Nedle, and Alice Hardy Widow: Dated the 16 of April, 8 Jacobi, 1610. The Originals now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.
So that George Lord Delamere hath now one fourth part of Bowdon, 1666.
In the Rental of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 3 Hen. 4. Ricardus Ma≈ø≈øy de Rixton, & Johannes de Bodon, tenent medietatem Villae de Bodon per Servitium Militare, & reddendo per Annum 5 d. Lib. B. pag. 209.

Ma≈ø≈øy of Rixton's part came after to Holcroft, and (as I have heard) was lately ≈øold
in the Reign of King James, by Sir Thomas Holcroft, unto William Brereton of A≈øhley E≈øquire, who≈øe Heirs are now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of one other fourth part of Bodon, 1666.

The other moiety of Bodon was given by the Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy to the Priory of Birkenhed in Wirral, about Edw. 1. And after the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbeys by Hen. 8. it was given to the Bi≈øhoprick of Che≈øter with the Church of Bowdon.

In this Town of Bowdon is ≈øeated the ancient Pari≈øh-Church of Bowdon, ≈øeated mo≈øt plea≈øantly for Pro≈øpect and the Downs. There was a Church here in the Conqueror's time, ib√¨ Presbyter & Eccle≈øia, cui pertinet dimidia hida, ≈øaith Doom≈øday-book: So that it ≈øeems to ≈øurmount the time of the Norman Conque≈øt.

Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy, Son and Heir of the fourth Hamon, gives to God, the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, and St. James, and to the Prior and Convent of Birkenhed in Wirral, half an Acre in Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy,‚Äîtogether with the Advow≈øon of Bodon-Church, Anno Domini 1278. For in that Year was Richard Ma≈ø≈øy Sheriff, who is one of the Witne≈ø≈øes. Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, 1 Pars, pag. 484.

After the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies, Henry the Eighth erected a new Bi≈øhoprick at Che≈øter, 33 Hen. 8. 1541. whereunto (among other things (he gave the Church of Bodon, and other Lands late belonging to the Priory of Birkenhed; So that this Church of Bodon hath now the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter for its Patron; and was Dedicated to St. Mary, as appears by the Deed above-mentioned, who≈øe Wakes, or Dedication-Fea≈øt, was celebrated 8 Septembris, being the Nativity of St. Mary; and comprehendeth within its Pari≈øh the≈øe Villages,‚Äî
¬†
The Mize.

The Vicarage of Bodon is ≈øaid to be worth 120 l. per Annum. Our common Proverb is, Every Man is not born to be Vicar of Bodon. The true Rea≈øon of the Proverb I cannot affirm.

list.head: Charterers in Bodon, 1666.
list.item: Henry Vawdrey of Baggiley.
Thomas Upton of Pre≈øtbury, about five or ≈øix Acres; no Hou≈øe.
Widow Tipping, a Cottage in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Margaret Birch Widow.

div.head: Budworth.
div.p:
THis Town of Budworth hath its Name from the old Saxon words, [Bode] which ≈øignifies a Dwelling, and [Wurth] a Place by a Water; as it were, a Dwelling or Town by a Water: And ≈øo is this Town ≈øituated on a Hill near two large Meres, Picmere-Mere, and Budworth-Mere. It is called Great Budworth, in di≈øtinction from another
Budworth, called Little Budworth, in Edesbery Hundred; and hath a good Pro≈øpect on the South, but now a poor Village: and hath yearly two Fairs, one on Candlemas-day, 2 Februarii; the other on our Lady-day, 25 Martii: The Toll whereof belongeth to the King.
In the Reign of William the Conqueror, William Fitz-Nigell, Baron of Halton, held this Town of Hugh Earl of Che≈øter; and one Pagan held it of the ≈øaid William.

In the beginning of Henry the Third's Reign, Geffrey Son of Adam de Dutton was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this Town (lineal Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley, who≈øe Po≈øterity under Edward the Second a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Warburton, from the Place of their Re≈øidence at that time.) This Geffrey, Son of Adam, lived at this Town of Budworth: For in the Deed of the Purcha≈øe of Claterwigge, a Hamlet in Little Legh, by Sir Thomas Dutton of Dutton, one of the Witne≈ø≈øes ≈øub≈øcribed was, ‚ÄîSir Geffrey of Budworth, Son of Adam de Dutton. Lib. C. fol. 156. T. And I have ≈øeen him ≈øtiled Geffrey de Budworth in many other Deeds; and ≈øo was Geffrey his Son often ≈øo ≈øtiled, who lived there al≈øo. But Peter Dutton, Son of the later Geffrey, removing his Habitation unto Warburton towards the end of Edward the Fir≈øt, his Son Peter was ≈øtiled de Warburton, according to the manner of tho≈øe Ages, under Edward the Second; from which time downwards his Po≈øterity hath wholly retained the Sir-name of Warburton, even to this day: But his ≈øucceding Heirs afterwards, di≈øliking the Seat at Warburton, either for the inundation of the Water, or for ≈øome other cau≈øe, removed their Seat to Arley in A≈øton, near to this Budworth, about the beginning of Henry the Seventh's Reign; which Hou≈øe of Arley was built by Peter Warburton E≈øquire, who died Anno Domini 1495. where they have ever ≈øince continued to this day, as their Chief Man≈øion-Hou≈øe. But to return.

Geffrey Son of Adam de Dutton above-mentioned (as I find in a Parchment Roll among the Evidences of Dutton) gave away the third part of this Budworth unto the Priory of Norton, in the Reign of Henry the Third, to pray for his Soul for evermore: But after the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies by Henry the Eighth, King Henry ≈øold all the Lands in Great Budworth and Comberbache, which belonged to the late Priory of Norton, unto John Grim≈ødich of London, Gentleman: The Charter under the Broad Seal is dated at We≈øtmin≈øter, 1 die Julii, 36 Hen. 8. 1544.

The≈øe Lands in Great Budworth thus bought by John Grim≈ødich, (to wit, the third part of Budworth) were part of them ≈øold by John Grim≈ødich to John Eaton of Crowley; and John Eaton ≈øold them to Peter Leyce≈øter of Tabley, E≈øquire, 2 Edw. 6. 1548. who≈øe Heirs enjoy the ≈øame at this pre≈øent, 1666. Another part thereof was bought by Malbon of Budworth, ≈øold lately to Oa≈øley. Another part of them was bought by Hall of Browne≈ølow in Budworth, who≈øe Heirs enjoy the ≈øame at this day, and have the Cu≈øtody of the King's Original Grant unto Grim≈ødich, of all the≈øe Lands afore≈øaid. Some ≈ømall part thereof al≈øo one Potter had. The other two parts of Budworth afore≈øaid, do now belong to Warburton of Arley, 1666. the ≈øucceeding I≈ø≈øue of Geffrey Son of Adam de Dutton afore≈øaid; but he holdeth the ≈øame of the King, as Baron of Halton, Chief Lord of Great Budworth.
Here is a fair Pari≈øh-Church, Dedicated to God and all Saints; in Commemoration whereof, our Wake is celebrated the fir≈øt day of November, being All-Saints-day.

I ≈øuppo≈øe there was a Church here before the Norman Conque≈øt; for I find in Doom≈øday-book,‚ÄîIbi Presbyter, & duo Villani, &c. and a Prie≈øt ≈øuppo≈øeth a Church; though, I confe≈øs, it is in other places of that Book u≈øually ≈øaid of ≈øuch Towns as had Churches,‚ÄîIb√¨ Presbyter & Eccle≈øia. The fir≈øt Structure hereof undoubtedly was more rude than now it is; which after-Ages beautified with a more Sumptuous Building, as all other Churches have been.

I find on the left hand of the Steeple-door, on the out-≈øide, as we enter therein, towards the bottom of the Fabrick of the Steeple, the≈øe words engraven in the Stone, in an ancient Character, [Argille Egarde Vidua], and on the right hand of the ≈øaid Steeple-door, oppo≈øite to that writing, [Wymincham]: Whereby it may ≈øeem, that the Widow Egard is commemorated as a ≈øpecial Benefactor in the Structure of that Steeple.

Ju≈øt over the ≈øame Steeple-door, under the great Window, I find three Coats of Arms, (but are not of ≈øuch Antiquity as the other engraved Words before-mentioned ≈øeem to be.) On the left Corner, over the Door, is Dutton of Dutton's Coat, viz. Quarterly, a Fret in the ≈øecond and third Quarters. On the right-hand Corner, oppo≈øite thereunto, A Pale Fu≈øils, which was the Coat of the Priory of Norton, and is found frequently in the Windows of Norton. And in the middle, between the≈øe two Coats of Arms, in a Flat is engraven, for Warbutton of Arley's Coat, A Cheveron between three Cormorants, (which is not Warburton's proper Coat); on the one ≈øide whereof is written [John], and on the other ≈øide, [Warburton Knight.]

The ≈øame three Coats are al≈øo above the great Window on the ≈øame We≈øt-≈øide of the Steeple. Certainly the Fret in Dutton's Coat was not added before the Reign of Edward the Third. And the fir≈øt Sir John Warburton of Arley was he who was one of the Knights of the Body to Henry the Seventh, and was Sheriff of Che≈øhire for his life, and died 15 Hen. 8. 1524. And therefore it ≈øhould ≈øeem the Steeple was repaired again not many Ages ≈øince, about the beginning of Hen. 8. or in the Reign of Hen. 7. at mo≈øt.

Certain it is, That the Church of Great Budworth was given to the Priory of Norton, by William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, the younger, and Baron of Halton, in the Reign of Henry the Fir≈øt, about the end of his Reign, Lib. B. pag. 199. num. 1. which Roger de Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire afterwards confirmed. See Mona≈øt. Anglican. Pars 2. pag. 185.

And after the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies by Henry the Eighth, he gave the Rectories of Budworth and Runcorne unto Chri≈øt-Church-College in Oxford, by Special Grant, dated 11 die Decembris, 38 Hen. 8. 1546. So this Church of Great Budworth hath now the College of Chri≈øt-Church in Oxford for its Patron, and is now but a Vicarage, worth about 80 l. per Annum.

In this Church is yet the Ca≈øe of a fair Organ, having the Coats of Arms of Warburton of Arley, Leyce≈øter of Tabley, and Merbury of Merbury, carved thereon. The≈øe Organs (as Tradition hath it) came frem Norton, bought after the Di≈ø≈øolution of that Priory, and were in good Order, till the Pipes thereof were taken out and ≈øpoiled by the Parliament Soldiers in the late War, 1647. which ≈øome Scotchmen among them called‚ÄîWhistles in a Box.

This Pari≈øh of Budworth is the large≈øt Pari≈øh of Che≈øhire, next to that of Pre≈øtbury; and it comprehendeth the≈øe Villages following, be≈øides the Parochial Chappelries of Witton and Nether-Pever, within the ≈øame.
It will not be ami≈øs if I touch here the Parochial Chappelries belonging to the Mother-Church of Budworth, although they be both ≈øituated in Northwich Hundred.

The one is called Witton-Chappel, dedicated to St. Hellen (the Mother of Con≈øtantine the Great, the Chri≈øtian Emperor) Daughter of Coel the Briti≈øh King of Colche≈øter, ≈øaith Huntington, pag. 306. But Malmesbury, pag. 7. calls her Stabularia, an Ho≈øte≈øs that keeps an Inne or Victualling-hou≈øe: who≈øe Dedication-Fea≈øt is celebrated 18 die Augu≈øti.
The Parochial-Chappel of Witton comprehendeth the≈øe Villages,‚Äî

The other is the Parochial-Chappel of Nether-Pever, ≈øituated in Northwich Hundred, and built by the Pari≈øhoners (the Principal whereof was Richard Gro≈øvenour of Hulme of Allo≈øtocke) in the Reign of Henry the Third: It comprehendeth the≈øe Villages.

The Chappel of Nether-Pever was Dedicated to St. O≈øwald, who≈øe Wakes or Fea≈øt of Dedication was celebrated the fifth day of Augu≈øt. This O≈øwald was King of Northumberland, ≈ølain in Battel 5 Augu≈øti, Anno Chri≈øti 642. at O≈øwald≈øtrey
O≈øwald was ≈ølain at Ma≈øerfelt, ≈øaith Bede & Stow; which Powel (in his De≈øcription of Wales before the Wel≈øh Hi≈øtory, pag. 14) ≈øaith, was in Northumberland, and not at O≈øwald≈øtrey; for O≈øwald≈øtrey was called by the Brettons, Mae≈øu≈øwalht, not Ma≈øerfelt: Yet Cambden's Britannia in Shrop≈øhire, pag. 452. will have him ≈ølain at O≈øwald≈øtrey, from whence it had its Name. in Shrop≈øhire, by Penda the Pagan King of Mercia. Unto this O≈øwald, Bede de Hi≈øt. Ang. lib. 3. cap. 9.
Bede, in his Hi≈øtory of England, a≈øcribeth many miraculous Stories; who for his Sanctity was Canonized for a Saint, and many Churches and Chappels were founded in Honour of him.

I find by a Deed dated Anno Gratiae 1269. That it was then agreed between the Prior and Convent of Norton; on the one part; and Richard Gro≈øvenour, and other Pari≈øhioners of Nether-Pever, on the other part: That the Prior of Norton ≈øhould find them Capellanum Secularem mi≈ø≈øam Celebrantem in dict√¢ Capell√¢, that is, a Secular Chaplain to ≈øay Divine Service, and Officiate in that Chappel every Sunday and Wedne≈øday through the Year, and in the Fea≈øt-days of the Nativity of Chri≈øt, St. Stephen the Martyr, Circumci≈øion, Epiphany, Purification, c√πm ≈øuis Proce≈ø≈øionibus, Annunciation, Palm-Sunday,
Ea≈øter-day cum ≈øuis Proce≈ø≈øionibus, Whit≈øunday, A≈øcen≈øion-day, Nativity of St. John Bapti≈øt, Peter and Paul Apo≈øtles, die Sancti O≈øwaldi, in cujus honorem fundata e≈øt praedicta Capella, A≈ø≈øumption of Mary, and All-Saints-day; and to have liberty of Bapti≈øm, if they can obtain leave from the Mother-Church of Budworth, to be allowed by the Prior and Convent of Norton: Saving to the Mother-Church all Tythes, both great and ≈ømall; And the Pari≈øhioners to find Books, Ve≈øtments, Ve≈ø≈øels, and other Ornaments of the Church, at their own Co≈øts. Lib. C. fol. 120. b. The Original Pen√®s Shakerley of Houlme.
The Abbies being di≈ø≈øolved by Henry the Eighth, at this day nothing is allowed to the Mini≈øter of this Chappel, but what the Benevolence of the Pari≈øhioners will plea≈øe to give.

In the Regi≈øter Book of this Chappel it appears, That the Steeple of Nether-Pever Chappel was built of Stone Anno Domini 1582.The Steeple began to the built 1582. & was fini≈øhed 1583. John Bowdon being then Ma≈øter of the Work. The two Out-I≈øles on either ≈øide of the Chappel have been enlarged by the Pari≈øhioners in late Ages.

div.head: Carington.
div.p: THis Town is not mentioned in Doom≈øday-book: It is of the Fee of the ancient Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, and gave name to the Family of the Caringtons, who were Lords thereof, and ≈øeated here very anciently.

In the Rental of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 3 Hen. 4. 1402. we read thus:‚ÄîGeorgius Carington Chivaler tenet Manerium ≈øuum de Carington, & medietatem Villae de A≈øhton, & tertiam partem Villae de Partington, pro duabus partibus Feodi Militis; ut per Chartam Antece≈ø≈øoribus dicti Georgii per Hamonem Ma≈ø≈øy Militem factam; & reddendo per Annum de Stuthe, ali√†s dictum Sheriff-Tooth,‚Äî7 den.

The Family of the Caringtons of Carington flouri≈øhed here for a long ≈øpace, near 400 Years, until Sir George Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy married Jane ≈øole Daughter and Heir of John Carington of Carington E≈øquire, towards the end of Queen Elizabeths Reign; but had no I≈ø≈øue by her, yet enjoyed Carington's Lands, which after her death he recovered by a tedious Suit: Who≈øe Grand≈øon, George Booth Lord Delamere, is now po≈ø≈øe≈øt of the whole Town≈øhip of Carington entirely, 1666. there being no Charterer at all therein.

div.head: Clifton.
div.p: THis Town, or Place (for here is onely a Mannor-Hou≈øe, with the Demain-Lands thereof) hath its name from the Cliffs or broken Rocks therein.

It is now at this day commonly called Rock-Savage, ≈øince the ≈øtructure of that ≈øumptuous Building erected there by Sir John Savage, Anno Domini 1565. 7 Elizabethae. The old Hall ≈øtood a little di≈øtance thence, the Remains whereof are now turned into a Granary, Stable, and other Hou≈øes of Office among the Out-hou≈øes; and by the Servants at this day called by the name of The Old Hall.

John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and Baron of Halton, gave unto Galfrid or Geffrey de Dutton‚Äî≈øcilic√®t de Uxore de≈øpon≈øat√¢, pro Homagio & Servitio ≈øuo, totam Villam de Clifton: Faciendo Servitium dimidii Feodi Militis ad Ca≈øtellum meum de Halton: & nullam Wardam faciet ad Ca≈øtrum Ce≈øtriae, ni≈øi ≈øup√®r Sumptum meum & Haeredum meorum. Lib. C. fol. 150. c. This was in the Reign of Henry the Second.

This Geffrey Dutton was younger Son of Hugh Dutton of Dutton; the Po≈øterity of which Geffrey were al≈øo Lords of Chedle, who, for their Re≈øidence there, were ≈øir-named
de Chedle, as the manner of tho≈øe Ages was. At la≈øt the two Daughters and Co-heirs of Sir Roger de Chedle divided the whole Inheritance, 1 Edw. 3. 1327. Clemence the elder Daughter married William Son of Raufe Baggiley; ≈øhe had Clifton, and divers Lands in Chedle and Hulme. Agnes the younger Daughter married Richard Son of Robert de Buckley; ≈øhe had the Capital Me≈ø≈øuage of Chedill, and the Advow≈øon of the Church of Chedill, and divers Homages, Rents, and Services. Lib. C. fol. 150. l. I≈øabel, the Daughter and Heir of Clemence, married Thomas Daniell of Bradley in Appleton, junior, afterwards Sir Thomas Daniell Knight; by whom he had onely one Daughter and Heir, called Margaret, married to John Savage about 49 Edw. 3. from whom the Savages of Clifton, continuing at this day, 1666. This Margaret carried away all her Mothers Lands; but her Fathers Lands went to the next Heir Male of the Daniells, in Old Deeds frequently written Danyers, and from whom the Daniels of Over-Tabley. See more of this in Over-Tabley.

div.head: Now followeth the De≈øcent of the Savages of Clifton.
div.p: This Margaret Daniell, as I have told you before, had all her Mothers Lands; but her Fathers Lands were ≈øetled on the Heirs Males of the Daniels. She had three Husbands: The fir≈øt was John Ratcliffe, 42 Edw. 3. who died without I≈ø≈øue by her not long after. Lib. C. fol. 229. v.

The ≈øecond Husband of Margaret Daneil, was this John Savage, de≈øcended of the Savages of Steinesbie in Darby≈øhire
See Lib D. pag. 176. T. Omnibus‚ÄîJohannes le Savage de Sarcliffe, Salutem. Noveritis me dedi≈ø≈øe Stephano le Eyr de Ce≈øterfeld totum jus meum in Tenemento in Halywel gate. Datum apud Ce≈øterfield, die Mercurii, in Fe≈øto Nativitatis Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae, 3 Edw. 2. 1310. Lib. D. pag. 180. n The Original among the Evidences at Rock-Savage, Anno Domini 1669.
So that this John Savage who writ him≈øelf of Sarcliffe in Darby≈øhire, I conceive was Ance≈øtor to the fir≈øt John Savage of Clifton. ; whom he married about 49 Edw. 3. and had I≈ø≈øue by her John Savage Son and Heir, Elizabeth, and Blanch, all living 4 Hen. 4. Lib. C. fol. 290. d.

But Margaret ≈øurvived all her Husbands, and in her Widowhood ≈øhe gave the moiety of Gropenhall to her Son Piers Legh, 4 Hen. 4. Lib. C. fol. 290. d. And to John Savage her Son, and to his Heirs, ≈øhe gave Liberty of Bearing her Coat of Arms, which de≈øcended to her after the death of her Father, as I have ≈øeen the Copy of the Deed in French, dated 3 Hen. 5. the Original whereof is now among the Evidences of Thomas Earl Rivers, at Rock-Savage, 1669. Vide Lib. D.
pag. 175. q. And the Po≈øterity of Savage bore Daniells Coat and Cre≈øt accordingly, to wit, Argent, a Pale Fu≈øile Sable; the Cre≈øt, A Unicorns Head Couped Argent; until Sir John Savage of Clifton in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth took up Six Lions Sable for his own Proper Coat, and the Lions Paw Sable erected, for his Cre≈øt.
This Margaret Daniell died 6 Hen. 6. 1427.

II. Sir John Savage of Clifton Knight, 6 Hen. 5. Son and Heir of John, married Maude Daughter and Heir of Sir Robert Swinnarton, by whom he had the Mannor of Barrow; and had I≈ø≈øue, John Savage Son and Heir, William, Arnold, George, and Roger; al≈øo Margaret married John Dutton, ≈øecond Son of Sir Piers Dutton of Dutton, 6 Hen. 5. afterwards Heir to Sir Piers his Father, Lib. C. fol. 160. w. x. Maude married Sir Thomas Booth of Barton in Lanca≈øhire.

‚öú This Sir John Savage I find ≈øtiled Knight, Obiit 1450 4 Hen. 5. and he died primo die Augu≈øti, 28 Hen. 6. 1450. Lib. D. pag. 169. c. Probably he was Knighted at the Battel of Agincourt in France, 3 Hen. 5.

III. John Savage of Clifton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Sir John, married _____ and had I≈ø≈øue, John Savage Son and Heir; al≈øo Margery a Daughter married Edmund Legh of Baggiley in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, 1442. 21 Hen. 6. which Edmund dying about 15 Edw. 4. ≈øhe afterwards married Thomas Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, 17 Edw. 4. 1477. Lib. C. fol. 271. d. e. to wit, the ≈øecond Wife of Thomas: Margaret, another Daughter, married John Maxfeld; afterwards ≈øhe married Randle Manwaring of Carincham, third Son of Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever E≈øquire.

Obiit i≈øte Johannes Savage, 29 die Junii,
Obiit 1463 3 Edw. 4. 1463. Aetate 53 annorum. Lib. D. pag. 169. c.

IV. Sir John Savage of Clifton, ≈øenior, Knight, ∆≤nus militum pro Corpore Henrici Septimi, 1494. 9 Hen. 7. Lib. C. fol. 186.
‚Ä¢ . 17 Edw. 4. 1477. Lib. C. fol. 271. d. He married Catharine Daughter of Sir Thomas Stanley, after Lord Stanley, and Si≈øter to Thomas Stanley Earl of Derby; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Iohn Savage Son and Heir, Thomas Savage Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter 1492. thence tran≈ølated to London 1497. thence to the Archbi≈øhoprick of York, 1501. and died 1508. his Body being buried at York,
and his Heart at Maxfield in Che≈øhire, See Stow's Annals, ≈øub Anno 23 H. 7. where he built a Chappel at the ≈øide of Maxfield Church, and intended to have made a College there; Sir Homfrey Savage, another Son; Lawrence Savage, another Son; James Savage, another Son; Sir Edmund Savage, another Son, Knighted at Leith in Scotland, 36 Hen. 8. 1544. 11 die Maii, by the Earl of Hertford then General; ≈øo Stow: Which Edmund married Mary the Widow of Roger Legh del Ridge nigh Maxfield, and Daughter and Heir of William Sparke of Surrey 30 Hen. 8. 1538. Chri≈øtopher Savage, another Son; William Savage, another Son; George, another Son; and Richard, another Son: Al≈øo Ellen Savage, a Daughter, married Peter Legh of Lyme in Che≈øhire, Anno Domini 1467. as appears by the Licence of Philip Sancti Laurentii in Lucina Presbyter Cardinalis, for their Marriage; datum Romae, 2 Idus Januarii, Anno quarto Papae Pauli Secundi, Lib. D. pag. 172. c. The Original now among the Evidences at Rock-Savage, 1669. Katharine, another Daughter, married Thomas Legh of Adlington in Che≈øhire, E≈øq Anno Dom. 1479. as appears by the Licence of John Giglis utri√∫≈øque Juris Doctor, Collector of the Popes Rents in England, dated at London 4 die Novembris, 1479. in the ninth Year of Pope Sixtus the Fourth: Lib. D. pag. 177. x. The Original among the Evidences at Rock-Savage al≈øo, Anno Domini 1669. Margaret married Edmund Trafford of Trafford in Lanca≈øhire: Alice married Roger de Pilkington of Lanca≈øhire; and Elizabeth married John Son of William Leeke of Langford in Darby≈øhire.

Obiit 1495
Aetat. 73.This Sir John Savage died 22 Novembris, 11 Hen. 7. 1495. & qu√≤d Johannes Savage Armiger, Filius & Haeres Johannis Savage junioris Militis, e≈øt Con≈øanguineus & ejus Haeres propinquior. Lib. D. pag. 179. k.

Sir John Savage of Clifton, junior, Knight, Son and Heir of Sir John Savage ≈øenior, had the Charge of the Left Wing at the Battel of Bo≈øworth-field in Lece≈øter≈øhire, 3 Rich. 3. 22 die Augu≈øti, 1485. in which Battel Richard the Third was ≈ølain: So Stow, and other Hi≈øtorians inform us. He was very in≈øtrumental, together with Thomas Lord Stanley his Uncle, afterwards made Earl of Darby, in the promoting of Henry the Seventh to the Crown, and in obtaining the Victory of Bo≈øworth-field; for which Service Henry the Seventh, per Literas ≈øuas Patentes, datas 7 die Martii, 1 Hen. 7. 1485. Memori√¢ reducens diutina & laudabilia Servitia, nec non probitatem act√∫≈øque ≈øtrenuos intimi dilecti Militis no≈øtri Johannis Savage junioris, quem, t√†m in Armis qu√†m in Moribus & Con≈øilio, florere dino≈øcebatur; qualit√©rque idem Johannes c√πm multitudine Copios√¢ ≈øuorum Fratrum, Con≈øanguineorum, Servientium, Amicorum benevolorum, ad ≈øua Grandia Co≈øtus & Onera, Per≈øonaeque ≈øuae pericula Multimoda, in Servitio no≈øtro in Conflictu & praelio contr√† magnum Adver≈øarium no≈øtrum Ricardum tertium t√πnc nup√®r Regem Angliae praeten≈øum, caeter√≥≈øque ≈øuos Complices & Fautores, q√†m contr√† alios Rebelles & Proditores no≈øtros contr√† nos ho≈øtilit√®r Guerram levantes, &c. Conce≈ø≈øimus eidem Johanni Ca≈øtrum & Manerium de Gre≈øley & Kimbley in Comitatu Nottinghamiae‚Äî& Ekle≈øton in Comitatu Derbiae, ac Mineram Carbonum, &c. quae fuerunt Johannis Domini Zouche‚Äî: Ac eti√†m Maneria Elineton-Holme≈øfield in Comitatu Derbiae; & Maneria de Granby & Sutton in Comitatu Nottinghamiae,‚Äî& Manerium de Shepe≈øhed in Comitatu Leyce≈øtriae, ac Maneria de Sutton-Hubybunderell, alias dictum Hobbadler, & Watton alias Wotton, Cro≈øton, Eudeburne, in Comitatu Salopiae; quae fuerunt Franci≈øci Lovell Militis, nuper Vice-Comitis Lovell: Habenda praedicto Johanni Savage, & Haeredibus Ma≈øculis de Corpore: Lib. D. pag. 171. v. The Original among the Evidences at Rock-Savage, Anno Domini 1669.

2 Ricardi 3. 1484. this Sir John Savage junior, and eight of his Brethren, were made Freemen of Che≈øter, Sir John Savage the Elder being then Mayor: Vale-Royal of England, pag. 188. The Brethren are there ranked in this order.

list.item: 1. Sir John Savage junior.
2. James Savage.
3. Lawrence Savage.
4. Edward, for Edmund.
5. Chri≈øtopher.
6. George.
7. William.
8. Richard.
9. Homfrey.

div.p: Sir John Savage junior married _____ and had I≈ø≈øue John Savage, Son and Heir; Alice married Sir William Brereton of Brereton in Che≈øhire; Felicia married Robert Milward of Eaton in Derby≈øhire, E≈øquire; Ellen married John Hawarden; Maude married Sir Robert Nedham of Shenton in Shrop≈øhire.

This Sir John Savage was ≈ølain at the Siege of Boloigne in France,
Obiit 1492 8 Hen. 7. 1492. in the Life-time of his Father. See Stow in eadem Anno. He was a Valiant Man, and an expert Soldier, and made Knight of the Garter by Henry the Seventh.

He had a Ba≈øtard-≈øon, called George Savage, Par≈øon of Davenham in Che≈øhire. This George had ≈øeveral Ba≈øtards, to wit, George Savage Prie≈øt, Chancellor of Che≈øter; John Wim≈ølow, Archdeacon of Middle≈øex, begot on one Wim≈ølow's Daughter; Elizabeth married _____
Clayton of Thelwall in Che≈øhire; ≈øhe was begot al≈øo on Wim≈ølow's Daughter: Randle Savage of The Lodge, begotten on the Daughter of one Dyes of Barrow in Che≈øhire; Margaret married _____
Col≈øten≈øoke of Over-Whitley; ≈øhe was begot al≈øo on Dyes Daughter; Ellen married _____
Hayes of Litley in A≈øton juxt√† Pickmere; ≈øhe was al≈øo begot on Dyes Daughter; Edmund Bonner, fir≈øt Dean of Leyce≈øter, and after twice Bi≈øhop of London, begotten on Elizabeth Frod≈øhum, fir≈øt married to one Edmund Bonner a Sawyer with Mr. Armingham, who begot other Children on her afterwards, and dwelt at Potters-Hanley in Worce≈øter≈øhire.

VI. Sir John Savage of Clifton Knight, Son and Heir of Sir John;
