This Sir John I find ≈øtiled Sir John Savage of Hanley in Worce≈øter≈øhire, ≈øub Hen. 8. Lib. D. pag 171. S. was Knighted about 13 Hen. 7. and was Sheriff of Worce≈øter≈øhire 24 Years together, from the death of his Father. He was ≈øtiled Sir John Savage the Elder, 12 Hen. 8. He married Anne Daughter and Heir of Raufe Bo≈øtock of Bo≈øtock, in Davenham Pari≈øh, E≈øquire; and had I≈ø≈øue John Savage Son and Heir, Edward, George, Lawrence, Roger, and Thomas; Anne married to Henry Lord Barkley, about 1533. See Stow ≈øub eodem Anno.
This Sir John died 2 Martii, 19 Hen. 8. 1527. and ≈øurvived Anne his Wife. Obiit 1527 She had a Brother called William, 22 Edw. 4. but he died, and ≈øhe became ≈øole Heir. Lib. D. pag. 178. f.

VII. Sir John Savage of Clifton Knight, ≈øtiled The Younger, 12 Hen. 8. Son and Heir of Sir John, married Elizabeth Daughter of Charles Somer≈øet Earl of Worce≈øter, and had I≈ø≈øue John Savage Son and Heir; Henry Savage, ≈øecond Son; Margaret married Sir Richard Buckley of Beaumorris in Wales; Mary married John Hamden of Hamden.

This Sir John Savage killed one John Pauncefote E≈øquire;‚öú whereupon he and his Father both were Indicted for Murther, and Arraigned in the King's Bench; this Sir John Savage the younger, as Principal; and Sir John Savage the Elder, as Acce≈ø≈øary; who confe≈ø≈øed the Fact: But upon mediation of Cardinal Wol≈øey, and Charles Earl of Worce≈øter the King's Chamberlain, they were pardoned by the King, paying four thou≈øand Mark ‚Ä¢ , and covenanting that they would not come into the Counties of Worce≈øter or Che≈øter during their Lives, without the King's Licence under his Great Seal, Privy Seal, or Privy Signet; as appears by the Indenture made the 24 day of November, 12 Hen. 8. 1520. Lib. D. pag. 179. I. The Original now remaining among the Evidences at Rock-Savage, 1669. But after, the King under his Great Seal, dated 12 Junii, 16 Hen. 8. 1524. gave liberty to this Sir John Savage the Younger to go, ride, or dwell in any Place either in Worce≈øter≈øhire or Che≈øhire. Lib. D. pag. 172. y.
This Sir John Savage died 27 Julii, 20 Hen. 8. 1528. aged 35 Years. Obiit 1528 John Savage his Son and Heir was aged three Years and nine Months at the death of his Father afore≈øaid.

Elizabeth his Widow was living 23 Hen. 8. Lib. C. fol. 291. d. and afterwards married William Brereton of the Bedchamber to Hen. 8.‚öú Beheaded for Matters touching Queen Anne, 17 Maii, 1536. 28 Hen. 8. Stow. He was younger Son of Sir Randle Brereton of Malpas.

Richard Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfield granted to this Sir John Savage Knight, the Mannor of Tarvin; re≈øerving the yearly Rent of 31 l. 00 s. 00 d. Datum 10 die Aprilis, 4 Edw. 6. 1550. Lib. D. pag. 171. r.

‚öúThis Sir John a≈ø≈øumed for his own Proper Coat, Six Lions Sable; and, The Lions Paw Sable erected, for his Cre≈øt; now onely quartering Daniell's Coat therewith among others, which before was born as his Proper Coat. But the Vertuous Lady Elizabeth, Wife of this Sir John Savage, died at Frod≈øham die Martis, 8 die Augu≈øti, 1570. 12 Elizabethae. Lib. D. pag. 180.

After who≈øe death he married Elinour, Widow of Sir Richard Pexhull of Beaurepair in Southampton≈øhire, and Daughter of John Cotgreve, 14 Eliz. 1572. but had no Children by her. Lib. D. pag. 170. I. & pag. 174. o.

Which Elinour had given unto her, by the Will of Sir Richard Pexhull her former Husband, all his Lands in Bromley, Beaurepair, Stratfield-Say, Stratfield-Mortimer, Terges, Ba≈øing≈øtoke, Chinham, Tadley, Pamber, Silche≈øter, Sherborne-Monachorum, Sherborne St. John, Sherborne-Cowdray, Stovington, Dene, Bradley, and Berden≈øtock and Clack, Cowich, and Ba≈øing, in the Counties of Southampton and Wilt≈øhire: Which Lands Sir John Savage ≈øetled on Edward his younger Son, and on his Heirs by Polyxena Daughter of William le Griz of London, Gentleman, and of Katharine his Wife, natural Si≈øter of the ≈øaid Dame Elinour, Lib. D. pag. 174. o. p. Which Edward had I≈ø≈øue, Sir John Savage of Beaurepair, 17 Jacobi, 1619. Lib. D. pag. 172. x.

‚öúThis Sir John Savage of Clifton built the new fair Hou≈øe at Clifton, Anno Domini 1565. 7 Elizabethae; which was afterwards called Rock-Savage. I find that he fir≈øt writ him≈øelf of Rock-Savage, 17 Eliz. and ≈øo by little and little, ≈øometimes of Clifton, and ≈øometimes of Rock-Savage, to the 21 Eliz. But afterwards he con≈øtantly writ him≈øelf of Rock-Savage, which his Po≈øterity have ever ≈øince retained.
The Old Hall ≈øtood a little di≈øtance thence, where now the Out-hou≈øing ≈øtandeth; being now converted into a Granary, Sable, and other Places of Office.

He was Seriff of Che≈øhire ≈øeven times, 1560, 1565, 1570, 1573, 1574, 1579, and 1591. and three times Mayor of Che≈øter,
Obiit 1597 1569, 1574, and 1597. And he died in the la≈øt year of his Mayoralty, 40 Eliz. 5 Decembris, 1597. aged 73 Years; and was buried at Maxfield the twenty fourth day of January following.

IX. Sir John Savage of Rock-Savage, Son and Heir of Sir John, was created Baronet 9 Jacobi, 1611. and married Mary one of the Daughters and Coheirs of Richard Allington E≈øquire, decea≈øed, about the 18 Eliz. 1575. Lib. D. pag. 169. a. & 170. f. and had I≈ø≈øue, John, aged three Years 1580. who died young; Thomas Savage, ≈øecond Son, who ≈øucceeded Heir; John Savage, third Son; Richard, fourth Son; and William, fifth Son: All which four Sons la≈øt mentioned, were living 42 Eliz. 1600. Lib. D. pag. 170. g. Al≈øo Elizabeth, a Daughter; married Thomas Manwaring, who then waited on this Sir John Savage her Father, younger Son of Manwaring of Martin-Sands nigh Over in Che≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue: Afterwards ≈øhe married Sir Raufe Done of Duddon in Che≈øhire, de≈øcended from the Dones of Utkinton; al≈øo Grace Savage, another Daughter, married Sir Richard Wilbraham of Woodhey in Che≈øhire, made Baronet 5 Maii, 19 Jacobi, 1621. Which Grace ≈øurvived her Husband, and died at Che≈øter, Anno Domini 1662.
This Sir John Savage had a Ba≈øtard-≈øon, called John Savage of Barrow.

Sir John was Mayor of Che≈øter 1607. and Sheriff of Che≈øter al≈øo the ≈øame Year. He was Buried at Maxfield on Fryday the 14 day of July, 1615. 13 Jacobi,
Obiit 1615 in the Night-time.
X. Sir Thomas Savage of Rock-Savage, Baronet, Son and Heir of Sir John, was Created Vi≈øcount Savage by King Charles the Fir≈øt, to wit, 6 die Novembris, 1626. 2 Car. 1.

Jane Si≈øter and Heir to Sir William Cordell Ma≈øter of the Rolls, and Lord of Long-Melford in Suffolk, gave by her Will to Sir Thomas Savage, Long Melford, with other Lands in Suffolk; Dated 15 Julii, 1602. She was Widow of Richard Allington, and Grandmother to Sir Thomas Savage.

He married Elizabeth Darcy, elde≈øt Daughter and Co-heir of Thomas Lord Darcy This Thomas Lord Darcy was after created Earl Rivers, 4 Novembris, 2 Car. 1. 1626: The Covenants of their Marriage bears date 26 Martii, 44 Eliz. 1602. Lib. D. pag. 170. h. and had I≈ø≈øue, John Lord Savage, Son and Heir; Thomas Savage, ≈øecond Son, married Brigit the Widow of Sir Edward Somer≈øet, fifth Son of Edward Somer≈øet Earl of Worce≈øter, and Daughter and Heir of William Whitmore of Leighton in Wirrall, in the County of Che≈øter, E≈øquire, by Margaret his Wife, Si≈øter and Heir to Sir George Bee≈øton of Bee≈øton in Che≈øhire, and Daughter of Sir Hugh Bee≈øton; from whom the Savages of Bee≈øton now in Che≈øhire: Francis Savage, third Son; William, James, Richard, died all three without I≈ø≈øue: Charles Savage, ≈øeventh Son, now living 1666. and hath I≈ø≈øue: Al≈øo Jane, elde≈øt Daughter, married John Pawlet Lord St. John, 1622. after Marquis of Winche≈øter: Lib. D. pag. 180 m. Dorothy married the Lord Andover, Son and Heir of the Earl of Bark≈øhire, Thomas Howard: Elizabeth, third Daughter, married Sir John Thimbelby of Lincoln≈øhire: Anne, fourth Daughter, married Robert Brudenal of Stouton in Northampton≈øhire; after Created Earl of Cardigan, April 20. 1661. Katharine, now a Nun at Dunkirk, 1666. And Henrietta-Maria, ≈øixth Daughter, married Raufe Sheldon of Beeley in Gloce≈øter≈øhire, E≈øquire.

Thomas Vi≈øcount Savage was Chancellor of the Queens Court at We≈øtmin≈øter 1634. and died at London; but was Buried at Maxfield in Che≈øhire, the ≈øixteenth of December,
Obiit 1635 1635. The Lady Mary Savage of Bo≈øtock-Hall, his Mother, was al≈øo Buried there the ≈øame day, as appears by the Regi≈øter of Maxfield Church.
XI. John Lord Savage of Rock-Savage, Son and Heir of Thomas Lord Savage, was Created Earl Rivers in Right of his Mother, 1639.

There were certain Articles drawn for this John's Marriage with Anne Compton Daughter of William Earl of Northampton, 16 Julii, 1619. 17 Jacobi, Lib. D. pag. 177. w. but it did not take effect: And after he married Catharine Daughter of William Parker Lord Morley, and Lord Mounteagle, of Horneby-Ca≈øtle in Lanca≈øhire, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Savage, now Earl Rivers, 1666. John, ≈øecond Son, living 1666. Richard, third Son, married Alice the Widow of John Barne≈øton, of Churton, and Daughter and Heir of Thomas Trofford of Bridge-Trofford in Che≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue
by her a Son called John Savage, living 1666. But Alice had I≈ø≈øue by both her Hu≈øbands, and ≈øhe died 1666. Al≈øo Elizabeth, elde≈øt Daughter of John Earl Rivers, married William Lord Peters: Jane married the Lord Chandoz, by whom ≈øhe had two Daughters; after ≈øhe married Sir William Sidley, but had no I≈ø≈øue by him; and thirdly, ≈øhe married George Pits of Stratford≈øey in Hamp≈øhire, E≈øquire, and by him had I≈ø≈øue: Mary, fourth Daughter, married Henry Killigrew Groom of the Bedchamber to James Duke of York; Frances, another Daughter, died young; Catharine, third Daughter, married Sir Charles Sidley, Brother to Sir William.
John Earl Rivers, after the death of his fir≈øt Lady, married Mary Ogle, formerly Waiting-woman to his Mother; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Peter Savage, who onely ≈øurvived, and is now living, 1666.

Obiit 1654 This John Earl Rivers ≈øold Long Melford in Suffolk: And he died at his Hou≈øe in Frod≈øham, commonly called Frod≈øham-Ca≈øtle, the tenth day of October, 1654. And that very Night was the ≈øame Hou≈øe by Accident of Fire burned. He was Buried at Maxfield, among his Ance≈øtors, in his Chappel at the ≈øide of the Church there: But ≈øince, the Roof of the ≈øaid Chappel fell down; but is now repaired, 1669.

div.head: Cog≈øhull.
div.p: RIchard de Vernon, Baron of Shibrok, held one half of Cog≈øhull in the Conqueror's time, and Pagan held it of Richard. Formerly, before the Conque≈øt, Levenot and Dedor held the ≈øame for two Mannors: Liberi homines fuerunt.
The other half of Cog≈øhull one Randle held in the Conqueror's Reign, ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Ance≈øtor of the Manwarings; and before the Conque≈øt one Ulviet held the ≈øame, & liber homo fuit.

In the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, Hugh de Durholme was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of all the Hamlet of Cog≈øhull, who gave it to Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln and Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire,‚Äî≈øcilic√®t totam Villam ≈øuam de Cog≈øhull, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis: Couchir-Book in the Dutchy-Office at Grays-Inn, Tom. 1. Comitatus Ce≈øtriae, num. 12. fol. 43.

‚ÄîHenricus de Lacy Comes Lincolniae, & Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae, ≈øalutem in Domino ≈øempiternam. Noverit univer≈øitas ve≈øtra nos dedi≈ø≈øe‚ÄîHugoni Filio Hugonis de Clyderhou valetto no≈øtro, totam terram‚Äîquam habuimus ex dono & Conce≈ø≈øione Hugonis de Durreme quond√†m Sene≈øchalli no≈øtri in Ce≈øter≈øhiri√¢, in Vill√¢ & in Territorio de Cog≈øhull‚ÄîFaciendo ind√® Capitalibus Dominis feodi‚ÄîServitia omnia debita & con≈øueta, &c. Te≈øtibus Domino Reginaldo de Grey t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Dominis Willielmo de Venables, Radulfo de Vernon, Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, Hugone de Dutton, Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy, Militibus; Roberto de Gro≈øvenour t√πnc Vicecomite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, Alexandro de Baumvyle, Ranulpho Starkey, Johanne de Merbury, Ranulpho de Berthinton, & aliis. Datum apud Bertelay, nono die Novembris, 13 Edw. 1. [1285.] Couchir-Book in the Dutchy-Office, Tom. 1. Com. Ce≈øtriae, num. 7. fol. 42. If Hugh had no I≈ø≈øue, then it was to revert to Henry Lacy and his Heirs; which it ≈øeems afterwards came back to Henry Lacy.

q.p: Sachent Touz ceaux‚ÄîHenri de La≈øcy Counte de Nicole, & Cone≈øtable de Cester, avons done‚Äî√† no≈øtre am√® Serjeant John le Fauconier pour le bone ≈øervice, qu'il nous ad fait, & unquore ferra ≈øi Dieu plait, toute cele terre de Cogge≈øhulle ove ≈øes appurtenances, la quele Huward iadys no≈øtre vallet avoit de no≈øtre done en Count√©e de Ce≈øter,‚ÄîRendant de ce par an a nous & nous Heires un Chaperon de Faucon √† la Fe≈øte Seint Michael.‚ÄîPar ces Te≈ømoines, Mon≈øieur Richard de Sutton, Mon≈øieur William de Stopham, Mon≈øieur Miles de Stapilton, Mon≈øieur John Spring, Mon≈øieur Roberd de Schirlaunde, Mon≈øieur James de Nevill, Mon≈øieur Nicoale de Leyborne Chivaliers, & plu≈øeurs autres. Ibid√®m, Tom. 1. fol. 42. Com. Ce≈øtriae, num. 9.

div.p: In the Records of the Tower of Lodon, 18 Edw. 1. Hugo de Clyderhou Dominus de Cog≈øhull Tenet de Henrico Lacy Comite Lincolniae; & idem Henricus de Hugone de Durreme; & idem Hugo de dono Warini Manwaring; & idem Warinus de Radulfo de Vernon; & idem Radulfus de Domino Comite Ce≈øtriae in Capite. This Note I had from Will. Vernon of Hulme in Allo≈øtock.
At this day, 1666. Cog≈øhull is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the≈øe Per≈øons following, which were all bought of the King in Fee-farm Rent, 1612. being formerly Copy-holders to Halton.
Elinour A≈øhton, Widow; formerly Booth's of Cog≈øhull, ‚öú and before that Ma≈ø≈øy's of Cog≈øhull, de≈øcended from Ma≈ø≈øy of Rixton.
Thomas Merbury of Merbury E≈øq hath Land here.
Edward Piggot of Cog≈øhull.
Edmund Ma≈ø≈øy of Cog≈øhull.
John Richard≈øon of Cog≈øhull.
Pownall of Barnton: (No Hou≈øe.)
Green of Sanbach: In po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Richard Perceivall.
George Low of Hartford: One Clo≈øe.

div.head: Comberbach.
div.p: ROger Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire; and Baron of Halton, about the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt, granted Deo & Beatae Mariae, & Fratribus ≈øervientibus beatis Pauperibus Sancti Ho≈øpitalis de Jeru≈øalem, totam medietatem de Comberbach; illam ≈øcilic√®t quam Willielmus de Comberbach de me tenuit:‚Äîun√† c√πm ≈øalina in Northwich quae pertinet ad A≈øtonam juxt√† Budworth‚Äîin puram & perpetuam Elemo≈øynam‚ÄîEt ≈øi Ricardus Fitton, vel Haeredes ≈øui praedictum feodum ≈øuper me vel ≈øup√®r Haeredes ≈øuos recuperaverit, Ego & Haeredes mei praedictam donationem praedictis Ho≈øpitalariis Warrantizabimus; & Willielmo Comberbach & Haeredibus ≈øuis: Tenendum de praedictis Ho≈øpitalariis in Feodo & Haereditate: Reddendo eis annuat√¨m ≈øex denarios pro omnibus quae ad Domum & ad Fratres eju≈ødem Domus pertinent. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Henrico Priore de Norton, Ricardo Capellano, Ricardo Fratre Con≈øtabularii, Hugone de Boydell, Radulfo Filio Symonis, Thom√¢ Di≈øpen≈øatore, Hugone de Dutton, Ad√¢ de Dutton, Radulfo Filio Rogeri, Alexandro Filio Radulfi, Liulfo Vice-Gomite, Bertramo Camerario, Johanne Burdon, Hugone de Eccle≈øton, Ricardo Filio Henrici, Roberto de Pulle, Johanne Filio Aluredi, Gilberto de Lymme, Willielmo de Gamul, Alano de Waley, Willielmo Filio Matthaei, Ricardo Filio Johannis, Ricardo Filio Gilberti, Aytropo, Ricardo Starkey, Ricardo de Whitley, Willielmo de Tabley, Waltero de Toft, Johanne de Comberbach, Henrico Fratre ≈øuo, & toto Hundredo de Halton≈øhire. Lib. C. fol. 274. num. 1. Out of the Book of Legh of Swineyard's Deeds, num. 1. now in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

John, Son of Henry de Comberbach, gave to Adam Son of William de Litley in A≈øton juxt√† Budworth, all his Lands in Comberbach,‚Äîun√† c√πm rever≈øione dotis Elenae Matris praedicti Johannis‚Äî& Pi≈øcari√¢ ≈øu√¢ in Lacu de Budworth, &c. Entailing the≈øe Lands, fir≈øt on the ≈øaid Adam, and the Heirs of his Body; and in default of ≈øuch, then on Robert Brother of the ≈øaid Adam: Dated at Comberbach, die Lunae, Sancti Petri ad Vincula (which is the fir≈øt day of Augu≈øt) Anno Domini 1335. 9 Edw. 3. Ibid√®m, num. 28.

The Moyety of Comberbach is now, 1666. in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of‚Äî
1. Richard Legh of Swineyard hath two Tenements. Their Tenants do at this day pay the Chief-Rent of Six-pence at Tatton-Vurt.
2. Mrs. A≈øhton of Cog≈øhull, two ≈ømall Cottages. Their Tenants do at this day pay the Chief-Rent of Six-pence at Tatton-Vurt.
3. Mr. Warburton of the Grange nigh Weverham, three little Tenements.
4. John Gleyve of High Legh, one little Tenement, which Thomas Gleyve of High Legh purcha≈øed from Thomas Sonkey of Little Sonkey in Lanca≈øhire, 37 Hen. 8. 1545. Lib. C. fol. 269. num. 2.
5. Robert Venables of Anterbus in Over-Whitley, one Cottage, about two Acres.
6. Sir George Warburton of Arley, five ≈ømall Cottages, not two Acres in all.
The other Moiety of Comberbach was granted to the Priory of Norton.

After the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies by Henry the Eighth, the King ≈øold all tho≈øe Lands
which belonged to the Priory of Norton, unto John Grim≈ødich of London, Gentleman, 36 Hen. 8. 1544. then in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Robert Merbury, George Hulme, Randle Worral, Agnes Walker, Randle Low, Lawrence Per≈øivall, Roger Grym≈øhaw, and George Eaton; out of which, 7 s. 7 d. ob. Chief-Rent is re≈øerved to the King. And the≈øe were ≈øold by Grim≈ødich to Robert Eaton; and la≈øtly, bought by George Low of Hartford, from John Eaton of Over-Whitley, about fourteen or ≈øixteen Years ago.

Other two Tenements, then in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Homfrey Shake≈øhaft and Thomas Highfield, out of which the yearly Rent of 2 s. 1 d. was re≈øerved to the King, were bought by Mr. Merbury of Merbury, and are lately ≈øold to Edward Piggot of Cog≈øhull, who is now Owner of the ≈øame, 1666.

div.head: Daresbury.
div.p: THis Town is of the Fee of the Ancient Barons of Halton.
I find that in the Reign of Henry the Third, and before, there was a Family of the Daresberies ≈øeated here, whence they took their Sir-name; but whence originally ≈øprung, I find not.

Rogerus de Hiberni√¢, that is, Roger of Ireland, grants unto Beatrix Daughter of William de Daresbery, and to the Heirs which ≈øhall be begotten on her Body by Robert of Ireland, Ex Chartulis Daniell de Daresbery, 1649. Son of the ≈øaid Roger, all his Land of Leverpool in Lanca≈øhire: Te≈øtibus Domino Roberto de Atherton Vice-Comite Lanca≈øtriae, Domino Henrico de Thorbock, Roberto le Sauvage t√πnc Ballivo Comitis int√®r Ribble & Mer≈øey, Domino Willielmo Par≈øon√¢ de Waleton, Willielmo de Waleton Serviente Domini Regis, Willielmo de Molineaux, &c. Lib. C. fol. 184. a.
Anno 1291. Henry le Norreys was Lord of Daresbery, which Mannor he had in right of Margery Daresbery his Wife.
div.q: ‚ÄîEgo Margeria Domina de Daresbery dedi Alano Filio meo & Mabiliae Filiae Ranulphi de Merton, quem idem Alanus ducet in Uxorem, totum Manerium meum de Daresbery, c√πm ≈øuis pertinentiis, un√† c√πm Dominio Villae de Over-Walton, 7 Edw. 2. 1313. Lib. C. fol. 185. e.
div.p: So in the Feodary of Halton, under Edward the Second, we read,‚ÄîAlanus le Norreys tenet Villam de Daresbery, & Villam de Wolton ≈øuperiori, pro medietate unius Feodi Militis.

This Alan le Norreys had a Son, called al≈øo Alan le Norreys; and Clementia, Daughter and Heir of Alan the Son, married William Danyers, Son and Heir of Sir John Danyers of Daresbery, 1344. Lib. C. fol. 185. g. h. In which Family (commonly now called Daniell) it hath continued to this pre≈øent, John Daniell of Daresbery E≈øquire being now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof, 1666.

It ≈øeems that Daniell had Land in Daresbery before the Marriage of William Daniell with Clementia Norreys; For Henry le Norreys, Lord of Daresbery, and Margery his Wife, (howbeit the Original Deed hereof calls her Margaret, being mi≈øwrit for Margery, for ≈øo ≈øhe is called in all other Deeds) granted to William Daniers the Elder one Me≈ø≈øuage in Daresbery, with all the Land which William More formerly held in the ≈øame Town; and one Water-mill, with a Croft called Wallmore; and one Wood, called The Common VVood; al≈øo one Wood and Land, called Daresbery-Cliff, containing 60 Acres by e≈øtimation: Dated on our Lady-day, 1291. 19 Edw. 1. Reddendo un ‚Ä¢ am libram Piperis, vel ≈øeptem Denarios‚Äî& ≈øex Porcos qui Pe≈øonam fecerint per Annum. Lib. C. fol. 184. d.

Afterwards Sir John Danyers of Daresbury married VVilliam his Son and Heir to Clemence Daughter and Heir of Alan de Norreys, about 1344. And when Sir John, upon the death of Alan, had compounded for the Ward≈øhip of Clemence, 25 Edw. 3. he grants the Lands to VVilliam his Son, in the≈øe Words.‚Äî

q.p: SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, qu√≤d ego Johannes Danyers Miles, Filius & Haeres Willielmi Danyers de Daresbury, Conce≈ø≈øi‚ÄîVVillielmo Danyers Filio meo omnia illa Maneria, Terras,‚Äîin Villis de Deresbury & Over-VValton in Comitatu Ce≈øtriae, & Sutton, Eccle≈øton, & Raynhull in Comitatu Lanca≈øtriae; quae nup√®r fuerunt Haereditamenta Alani le Norreys Domini de Deresbury defuncti: Habendum‚Äîu≈øqu√® ad plenam aetatem Clementiae Filiae & Haeredis dicti Alani, & n√πnc Uxoris VVillielmi Danyers Filii & Haeredis mei apparentis, in t√†m amplo modo prout Thomas Stanford Generalis Attornatus & VValterus de VVhitehor≈øe nup√®r habuerunt ex donatione Ducis Lanca≈øtriae‚ÄîReddendo ind√® annuat√¨m mihi praefato Johanni 40 l. 00 s. 00 d. durante termino praedicto,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Thom√¢ Danyers de Bradley, Matthaeo del Mere, Thom√¢ de Legh, Johanne Filio Thomae Danyers praedicti, Johanne Boydell,‚Äî&c. Datum apud Daresbury, die Lunae proxim√® ant√® Fe≈øtum Sancti Michaelis Archangeli, 25 Edw. 3. 1351. Lib. C. fol. 185. m.

div.p: VVilliam Danyers ≈øenior had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Danyers of Bradley, ≈øenior, living 17 Ed. 2. and al≈øo VVilliam Danyers of Daresbery, junior: Lib. C. fol. 233. b. e. & fol. 184. d. See more hereof in Over-Tabley: Whether of the≈øe is the elder Brother, is the Quaere.

list.head: Charterers in Daresbery, 1666.
list.item: 1. VVilliam Gregg of Daresbery.
2. John Haywood of Kekwick habet Terras in Daresbery.
3. Richard Eaton of Hatton hath al≈øo Lands of Inheritance in Daresbery.

div.p: Here is in Daresbery al≈øo an ancient Parochial Chappel (a Daughter of the Mother-Church of Runcorne) Dedicated to All Saints.

q.p: AUbert Grelly omnibus hominibus ≈øuis, ≈øalutem. Sciatis me conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe‚ÄîSanctae Mariae de Norton‚ÄîOmnes Donationes, quas VVillielmus Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae Avus meus, & VVillielmus Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae Avunculus meus, eis in perpetuam Elemo≈øynam dederunt quae ≈øunt in meo Feodo; ≈øcilic√®t totam Eccle≈øiam de Piriton√¢ (this is Pirton in Oxford≈øhire)‚Äî& Capellam de Deresbiri√¢ in Ce≈øter≈øhyr√¢ c√πm omnibus ≈øuis pertinentiis, quae pertinent ad Ecce≈øiam de Runcorne: Hanc aut√®m Confirmationem feci praefatis Canonicis pro animabus Patris & Matris meae, & Antece≈ø≈øorum meorum, pro ≈øalute Animae meae, & omnium Haeredum meorum.‚ÄîTeste Roberto de Bury, VVillielmo Filio VVulfrici, Ricardo Filio Henrici: Lib. B. pag. 202. num. 18. This was in the Reign of Henry the Second. Aubert Grelly, Father of this Aubert, married Maud Si≈øter and Co-heir to VVilliam Constable of Che≈øhire, the younger.

div.p: This Parochial Chappel comprehendeth the≈øe Villages.‚Äî

div.head: Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.
div.p: THis Town of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy was the Seat of the Ancient Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy; and from tho≈øe Ma≈ø≈øy's, Lords thereof, it is called Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, in di≈øtinction from another Dunham in this County, not far from Trofford-Bridge, called Dunham on the Hill.

Dunham hath its name from the≈øe two old Engli≈øh words, [Dun] which is as much as A Ri≈øing Hill, for which we now u≈øe the word Down; and [Ham,] A Hou≈øe, Home, or Dwelling: as it were, A Dwelling by the ≈øide of a Hill, A Hou≈øe or Town by the Downs.

figure.head: Quarterly, Gules and Or, in the fir≈øt Quarter a Lion pa≈ø≈øant, Argent.

div.p: This Hamon had al≈øo in Maxfield Hundred, Bromhale; and Podinton in Wirrhall Hundred, at the ≈øame time, and other Lands.

This Hamon had I≈ø≈øue Hamon Son and Heir, and Robert Ma≈ø≈øy, Witne≈øs to the Fir≈øt Randle's Charter of Confirmation to the Abby of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, about Anno Domini 1124. or thereabout. See ≈øupr√† in this Book, pag. 119.

Ex Chartulis Georgii Baronis de Delamere apud Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, & alibi.II. Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy the Second, Son and Heir of Hamon, had I≈ø≈øue Hamon Son and Heir; Robert Ma≈ø≈øy, from whom the Ma≈ø≈øies of Sale in Che≈øhire, a Family yet extant, 1666. Lib. C. fol. 150. d. e. f.

III. Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy the Third, Son and Heir of Hamon the Second, had to Wife Agatha, and had I≈ø≈øue, Hamon Son and Heir; Robert Ma≈ø≈øy, to whom his Mother (calling her ≈øelf by the name of Agatha de Theray) gave the moiety of Bowdon, which ≈øhe bought of Roger Ma≈ø≈øy of Hale, Son of Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy; Lib. C. fol. 252. i. k. And John Ma≈ø≈øy; Lib. C. fol. 258. a. Al≈øo Agnes, a Daughter, with whom her Father gave half of Bolinton in Free-Marriage to Geffrey Dutton of Chedill, Son of Geffrey Dutton: Lib. C. fol. 150. a. b. Sibil, another Daughter, who gave to Cicely, Daughter of John Ma≈ø≈øy her Brother, half of the Town of Norden, Lib. C. fol. 271. c. Al≈øo Cicely, another Daughter of Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy, to whom her Father gave all his Land of Alretun≈øtall, and all his Land of Sunderland, Lib. C. fol. 254. b. Another Daughter married Hugh de Dutton, which ≈øee in Dutton.
Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy the Third died about the Reign of King John, or ≈øub initio Hen. 3. and Agatha his Wife ≈øurvived him.

This Hamon the Third gave unto John Ma≈ø≈øy his Brother all the Land of Moreton, which Matthew de Moreton held, with Hou≈øebote and Haybote in his Demain-wood of Bid≈øton; for the Land of Podington, which Robert de Ma≈ø≈øy his Uncle held: Faciendo Servitium dimidii Feodi Milits: Lib. C. fol. 258. a. about Henry the Second, or Richard the Fir≈øt.

He al≈øo gave to Robert Son of Waltheof all the Land which his Father Waltheof held of the ≈øaid Hamon and his Ance≈øtors; to wit, Etchels, to be held by the Service of half a Knights Fee; & ego Hamo retineo ad opus meum Cervum, & Bi≈ø≈øam, & Aprum de Huler≈øwood; that is, Hart, Hind, and Boar. The ≈øaid Hamon re≈øtored al≈øo to the ≈øaid
Robert, Bredbury and Brininton, finding a Sumpter-Hor≈øe, and a Man, and a Sack for the carriage of his Arms and Apparel, when the Earl of Che≈øter ≈øhall in Per≈øon lead an Army into Wales; and ≈øhall give aid to the ≈øaid Hamon for the Redeeming of his Body, if he be taken Pri≈øoner; and for the making of his elde≈øt Son a Knight, and when his elde≈øt Daughter ≈øhall be married: Lib. C. fol. 258. b.

This Hamon Founded the Priory of Birkenhed in Wirrall, commonly called Birket-Abby; the Church whereof was dedicated to St. James: And I find Oliver Prior of Birkenhed ≈øub≈øcribed a Witne≈øs in the Reign of King John, Lib. C. fol. 252. I. K. I conjecture it might be founded about the Reign of Henry the Second; and Speed ≈øaith, they were of the Order of the Black Monks.

IV. Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy the Fourth, Son and Heir of Hamon the Third, had I≈ø≈øue Hamon Son and Heir, William Ma≈ø≈øy, from whom the Ma≈ø≈øies of Tatton, Lib. C. fol. 255. e. Al≈øo Margery, a Daughter, to whom her Father gave the whole Town of Stretford, about Anno Domini 1250. And after, the ≈øaid Margery, then Widow of Roger Pain of Echburn, i. e. A≈øhburn, relea≈øed all her Right in the whole Town of Stretford unto Henry de Trafford, Lib. C. fol. 251. d. e. The Originals of the≈øe two Deeds were among the Evidences of Sir Cecil Trafford of Trafford in Lanca≈øhire, 1666.

V. Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy the Fifth, Son and Heir of the Fourth Hamon, gave the Advow≈øon of the Church of Bowdon unto the Priory of Birkenhed in Wirrall, whereunto Richard Ma≈ø≈øy Sheriff of Che≈øhire was Witne≈øs, which was 6 Edw. 1. Anno Chri≈øti 1278. which Priory was Dedicated to St. James: Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, 1 Pars, pag. 484. And this Deed was enrolled in the Che≈øhire Doom≈øday-book, which is now lo≈øt.
This Hamon married Alice Daughter and Heir of Sir Eu≈øtace Whitney, and had I≈ø≈øue Hamon Son and Heir, and

16 Edw. 1. 1288. the Barony of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy was found to be held of the King in Capite by the Service of five Knights Fees: Inveniendo pro quolibet Feodo unum Equum coopertum, vel duos di≈øcoopertos, infr√† divi≈øas Ce≈øter≈øhiriae tempore Guerrae, c√πm omnibus Hominibus ≈øuis Peditibus, Tenentibus terram forin≈øecam, infr√† Feodum praedictum: Faciendo Servitium ≈øuum ≈øecund√πm purportam Communis Chartae Cer≈øter≈øhiriae: Lib. C. fol. 259. P. See this Common Chart above in this Book, pag. 162, 163. &c.

VI. Sir Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy, the ≈øixth and la≈øt Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, Son and Heir of the fifth Hamon, married I≈øabel Daughter of Homfrey de Beauchamp, and on the Marriage-day at night (as it hapned) ≈øhe died before Carnal Copulation: Afterwards he married Alice Si≈øter of the ≈øaid I≈øabell, and by her had I≈ø≈øue Hamon a Son, who died without I≈ø≈øue; and four Daughters: Cicely married John Fitton of Bollyn; I≈øabell married Hugh Dytton, who had I≈ø≈øue Katharine Wife of Thomas de Belgrave;
_____ another Daughter, married Thomas de Lathom, and had four Daughters who had I≈ø≈øue; and Alice, another Daughter, married Hamon de Hilond, and had I≈ø≈øue Hamon, Lib. C. fol. 259. l. and other Sons: Lib. C. fol. 261. b. An old Parchment Roll in a Character about Richard the Second, among the Evidences of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.

And after the death of Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy the Son, the ≈øaid Sir Hamon Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy was Divorced from Alice his Wife, and married Joan Clinton Si≈øter of the Earl of Huntington; and by the coun≈øel of this Joan, he ≈øold the Rever≈øion of the whole Mannor of Doneham, with its Appurtenances, after the death of him≈øelf and Joan his Wife, in ca≈øe they had no I≈ø≈øue, unto Oliver de Ingham then Judge of Che≈øter; for which Rever≈øion Oliver gave him 1000 Marks, and 40 Marks Annual Rent for his Life; 10 Edw. 2. 1316. Lib. C. fol. 256. q.r. t. x.

This Hamon, the la≈øt Baron, being ≈øued at Che≈øter, 1 Edw. 2. by Peter Dutton (≈øtiled al≈øo ≈øometimes Peter de Warburton, and Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley) concerning a Parcel of Wa≈øte Ground conceived by him to lie in Warburton, the ≈øaid Hamon pleaded, That Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy his Father was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øame, and that the Land in que≈øtion
did lie in Doneham, and not in Warburton; and moreover, that he the ≈øaid Hamon was one of the Kings Barons, and held his Lands of the King in Capite (as Earl of Che≈øter) in Barony immediately, aad ought not to proceed to Trial without a Jury of Knights and di≈øcreet Men of the County. Placita Ce≈øtriae ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Marci Evangeli≈øtae, 1 Edw. 2. Lib. C. fol. 260. z.

Chart. 18 Edw. 1. Memb. 3. Rex conce≈ø≈øit Hamoni de Ma≈ø≈øy unum Mercatum per diem Martis apud Manerium ≈øuum de Altrincham; & unam Feriam per tres dies duraturam, videlic√®t, in Vigili√¢, die, & Cra≈øtino Fe≈øti A≈ø≈øumptionis Beatae Mariae. Lib. C. fol. 260. q. And hereupon he made his Charter to his Burge≈ø≈øes of Altrincham of a Guild-Mercatory. See above in Altrincham.

This Sir Hamon was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed onely of the≈øe Mannors, Doneham, Kel≈øall, Altrincham; Bid≈øton, Salghall, and Moreton: Lib. C. fol. 260. y. But in the Rental of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, dated 3 Hen. 4.‚ÄîJohn Davenport of Bromhall tenet Villas de Bromhall, Duckenfield, Baggiley, and Etchells, per Servitium Militare, & reddendo annuatim 2 l. 0 s. 0 d. [But 13 s. 4 d. of this Rent was remitted by Sir Thomas Stanley and Sir Robert Booth, by Deed, 22 Hen. 6.] Lib. C. fol. 262. h.

‚ÄîDavenport de Henbury tenet terram ≈øuam in Wernith, reddendo per Annum 5 d. It√®m tenet Bredbury, Romiley, Brunington (nuper Adam de Bredbury & Matilda Holland) per Servitium Militare; & idem inveniat Domino de Doneham unum Championem ad pugnandum pro eo, ≈øi fuerit appellatus: & ≈øi dictus Dominus fecerit aliquam Appellationem ad aliquem alium, t√†m in brevi de recto qu√†m aliquo alio modo, dictus Champio pro eo pugnabit: & inveniet unum Hoblar & Sacket Jugg ad Cu≈øtodiendum Carriagium ≈øuum per quindecem dies in Guerris de Wales.
So that the Services of the≈øe, and may other Towns, did anciently belong to the Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.
Hamon the la≈øt Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy died 15 Edw. 3. aut circiter. Lib. C. fol. 254. t.
So that the Ma≈ø≈øies continued from the Norman Conque≈øt at Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, about 260 Years.

But now fell great Suits concerning the Barony of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, after the Death of Hamon and Joan without I≈ø≈øue of their Bodies: For Richard Fitton, and the Heirs of the other Si≈øters, entred into the Mannor of Dunham, as Heirs to the ≈øaid Hamon; at which time Oliver Ingham was in the King's Service Beyond-≈øea, to wit, Steward of Ga≈øcony: And then, by the King's Command, Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy ef Tatton This Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy was a younger Brother of Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, and afterwards the fir≈øt Ma≈ø≈øy of Rixton in Lanca≈øhire, in Right of his Wife. See more of him in Tatton. , and others of the Council of the ≈øaid Oliver, came to the Mannor of Doneham, and entred in the Name of Oliver, and Richard Fitton and his Partners went out of Doneham; and ≈øo the ≈øaid Oliver Ingham died ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Mannor, with its Appurtenances: And after the death of Oliver Ingham, Richard Fitton‚ñ™ and his Partners entred again; and the Heirs of Oliver (who were Mary Daughter of John Ccr≈øon, and Joan Wife of Roger le Strange of Knocking, the Elder) brought a Writ of Novae Di≈ø≈øei≈øinae again≈øt the Co-heirs: And after, Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter buys out all the Right of the Co-heirs, as al≈øo the Right of the Heirs of Oliver; and ≈øo the Duke being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Mannor of Doneham, with its Members, gave it to Roger le Strange Lord of Knocking. Lib. C. fol. 261. b.
Li. C. fol. 75. o. The Part of Alice, who married Hamon Hilond, relea≈øed Anno 21 Edw. 3. to the Earl of Lanca≈øter, not yet Duke.

div.head: I ≈øhall now put down the De≈øcent of the Heirs of Fitton from this time.
div.p: I. John Fitton of Bollin in Maxfield Hundred, Son and Heir of Edmund Fitton of Bollin-Fee, married Cecily elde≈øt Daughter and Co-heir of Sir Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Fitton Son and Heir, and Hugh Fitton, another Son, who married Margery Daughter and Heir of Robert de Pownall, 1328. from whom the Fittons of Pownall.

This John Fitton had a younger Brother called Thomas Fitton, living 1335. which
Thomas married I≈øabel Daughter and Heir of Thomas Orreby of Gowe≈øworth, from whom the Fittons of Gowe≈øworth: Al≈øo Hugh Fitton, another Brother, Rector of Wim≈ølow-Church, 1335.

II. Richard Fitton of Bollin, Son and Heir of John, married Joan
_____ She was living 1335. and had I≈ø≈øue John Fitton elde≈øt Son, who married Chri≈øtian Daughter and Co-heir of Peter Arderne of Over-Alderley, and made Partition of Arderne's Lands with Margaret her Si≈øter, Wife of Richard de Wever, in Anno 1350. 24 Edw. 3. but this John died without I≈ø≈øue: Al≈øo Hamon Fitton, ≈øecond Son, who became Heir to his Father; and Francis, third Son, 1337. died without I≈ø≈øue.

III. Hamon Fitton of Bollin, ≈øecond Son, and Heir of Richard, married Elizabeth Daughter and Co-heir to Sir Peter Thornton of Thornton, Knight; and had I≈ø≈øue Peter Fitton, who died without I≈ø≈øue about 42 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 179. e. Joan, Si≈øter and Heir to Peter, married Richard Venables, younger Son of Hugh Venables Baron of Kinderton.

IV. Richard Venables of Bollin, in Right of Joan his Wife. She was in Cu≈øtody of Thomas Dutton of Dutton Knight, 42 Edw. 3. and was then under Age, and unmarried. She had I≈ø≈øue William Venables Son and Heir; and John Venables of Anterbus in Over-Whitley, from whom Venables of Anterbus.

V. Sir William Venables of Bollin Knight, Son and Heir of Richard, married Joan Daughter of Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Venables, drowned in the Water of Ringey, 3 Hen. 4. aged then about eight years; and two Daughters and Heirs: Alice married Sir Edmund Trafford of Trafford in Lanca≈øhire; and Dow≈øe married Robert Booth, younger Son of John Booth of Barton in Lanca≈øhire, Lib. C. fol. 257. b. afterwards Sir Robert Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.
Sir William Venables of Bollin died 9 Hen. 5. 1421. Lib. C. fol. 257. b.

Sir Edmund Trafford and Alice his Wife, and Robert Booth and Dow≈øe his Wife, make Partition of the Lands of Sir William Venables, 9 Hen. 5. except Lindow-Moor and Thornton-Mo≈ø≈øe, and except the Homage and Service of Geffrey Warburton and his Heirs, for the Lands which he holdeth in A≈øton and Budworth, and el≈øewhere in Che≈øhire, which remained undivided at that time.

Sir Edmund and Alice had to their ≈øhare, Morley, Chorley, and Hough, the Rents and Services of Thomas Pownall, Richard Fitton, and William de Honford; and the Rent and Service of Sir Lawrence Fitton (id e≈øt, de Gowe≈øworth) for his Lands in Bollin-Fee; as al≈øo all the Lands which Sir William Venables lately had in Norden and Helsby,‚Äîwith the Advow≈øon of Wim≈ølow Church.

Robert Booth and Dow≈øe had Styall, and Dene-row, and all the Lands which Sir William Venables lately had in Fally-brome, Norley, One≈øton, King≈øley, Arrow, Picton, Stoke, and Che≈øter; al≈øo the Mannor-Hou≈øe of Thornton, and the Advow≈øon of Thornton-Church, and Bollin-Mills, and 5 l. 0 s. 0 d. to be paid yearly by the Heirs of Alice out of the Mannors of Bollin and Norcliff.

This Robert, afterwards Sir Robert Booth, having thus po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of his ≈øhare of the Lands of Venables of Bollin, challenged his Part of the Lands of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, which ought to de≈øcend to him as one of the Heirs of Venables of Bollin; and to Venables, as Heir to Fitton of Bollin; and to Fitton of Bollin, as Heir to one of the Daughters and Heirs of Sir Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy of Dunham.

At la≈øt it was agreed between Sir Thomas Stanley, Sir Robert Booth, and William Chauntrell Serjeant at Law, That one half of the Mannors, Lands, Rents, and Services in Dunham, Hale, and Altrincham, ≈øhould remain to the ≈øaid Thomas Stanley and William Chauntrell, and their Co-Feoffees; and the other half to the ≈øaid Sir Robert Booth and his Co-Feoffees. Dated 16 die Julii, 11 Hen. 6. 1433. Lib. C.
fol. 262. e. f. g. The Originals among the Evidences at Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 1666.

And thus Sir Robert Booth got footing in Dunham, who≈øe Heirs have ≈øince made Purcha≈øes; and George Booth Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, is now, 1666. po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Mannor of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.

list.head: Charterers in Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 1666.
list.item: 1. John Crew of Crew, E≈øquire, hath three Tenements in Sunderland, now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Henry Heskith, Robert A≈øhton, and Henry Ha≈øelhur≈øt.
2. George Vawdrey of Dunham-wood-hou≈øes‚ñ™ one Tenement in his own po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
3. James John≈øon, alias Ottiwell, one Tenement in Dunham-wood-hou≈øes, lately bought of Mr. Bodon late of Bodon, to revert after Mr. Bodon's death.
4. Mr. Parker of Parker's-Hall in Altrincham, one Tenement in Dunham in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, be≈øides five Cottages.

div.head: Now followeth the Genealogy of the Booths of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, ≈øince the time they were fir≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Dunham.

figure.head: Argent, three Boars Heads era≈øed & erected, Sable.

div.p: Raufe Booth, here ≈øtiled the ≈øecond Son, married Margaret Daughter and Heir of Thomas Sibell of Sondwich in Kent, and had three Daughters and Heirs: Dow≈øe married one Gomer of London; Margaret married William Mere, Son and Heir of Thomas Mere of Mere nigh Over-Tabley in Che≈øhire, 34 Hen. 6. and Jane married Robert Leyce≈øter of Toft. Lib. C. fol. 207. n. & fol. 175.

This Sir Robert Booth, and William his Son and Heir, were made Sheriffs for both their Lives, conjunct√¨m vel divis√¨m, of Che≈øhire, and to the Survivor of them. The Writ dated 8 Martii, 21 Hen. 6. 1442. which is the fir≈øt Patent for Life in this kind that I meet withal in our County: Howbeit, after Edward the Fourth had got the Crown, he pre≈øently made William Stanley of Hooton Sheriff, 2 Edw. 4. And ≈øo William Booth, Sir Robert's Son, was outed of his Sheriff-≈øhip.
This Sir Robert Booth lived in the Reigns of Henry the Fourth, Henry the Fifth, and Henry the Sixth; and ≈øeems to die about 29 Hen. 6.

A word or two about the Coat of Arms of Booth. I find that Thomas Barton of Barton in Lanca≈øhire gave unto John Booth Son of Thomas Booth of Barton, and to his Heirs for ever, liberty to Bear his Coat of Arms, to wit, Argent, Three Boars Heads era≈øed and erected, Sable; by Deed dated 5 Hen. 4. 1404. John Booth's Book, Lib. H. pag. 49. wherein were extracted the Deeds of Booth of Barton, and ≈øeveral others. Which Coat of Arms have ever ≈øince been born by Booth of Barton, as al≈øo by Booth of Dunham, with his Di≈øtinction of a younger Son, even to this pre≈øent.

II. Sir William Booth of Dunham Knight, Son and Heir of Sir Robert, married Maud Daughter of John Dutton of Dutton E≈øquire, 21 Hen. 6. 1442. Lib. C. fol. 164. g. and had I≈ø≈øue George Booth Son and Heir, Richard Booth, Lawrence Booth, John Booth, and William Booth; Lib. C. fol. 250. a. Al≈øo Dow≈øe, married to Thomas Legh of High-Legh de We≈øt-hall, E≈øquire, 1 Edw. 4. 1641. Anne, married to John Legh of Boothes, E≈øquire; after to Geffrey Shakerley of Shakerly in Lanca≈øhire: Ellen married Sir John Legh of Bagiley, 6 Edw. 4. 1466. Lib. A. fol. 151. y. Margery married John Hyde of Haghton in Lanca≈øhire: Alice married John A≈øhley of A≈øhley nigh Bowdon in Che≈øhire: Elizabeth Wife of Thomas Fitton of Pownall in Maxfield Hundred: Joan married William Holt of Lanca≈øhire.

Sir William died 16 Edw. 4. 1476. and gave Lands to Feoffees in Tru≈øt, for the providing of a Chaplain to pray for him and his Friends, in a Chappel to be built in Bowdon Church for that purpo≈øe; which was built accordingly. Lib. C. fol. 150. a.

III. George Booth of Dunham E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Sir William, married Katharine Daughter and Heir of Robert Montfort Lord of Be≈øcote in Stafford≈øhire, and Monks-path in Warwick≈øhire, younger Son of Sir William Montfort of Col≈øhill in Warwick≈øhire: Dugdale in his Antiquities of Warwick≈øhire, pag. 728. but mi≈ø-printed for 738. and ≈øo all along forward mi≈ø-printed. By whom he had I≈ø≈øue William Booth Son and Heir, Lawrence, and Roger: Alice (alii Anne vocant) married William Ma≈ø≈øy of Denfleld in Ro≈øthorn; Ellen married Thomas Vawdrey, after to Trofford of Bridge-Trofford in Che≈øhire.
This George died 1 Rich. 3. 1483.

IV. Sir William Booth of Dunham Knight, Son and Heir of George, married Margaret Co-heir of Sir Thomas A≈øhton of A≈øhton under Lyme, and had I≈ø≈øue George Son and Heir, and John Booth: And afterwards he had a ≈øecond Wife, to wit, Ellen Daughter of Sir John Montgomery of Throwley in Stafford≈øhire, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue William, Hamnet, Edward Booth, from whom the Booths of Twamlow in Che≈øhire; Henry, and Andrew: Al≈øo Jane married Hugh Dutton, Son and Heir of Sir Piers Dutton of Hatton and Dutton both, 12 Hen. 8. 1520. Lib. C. fol. 167. Afterwards ≈øhe married Thomas Holford of Holford nigh Nether-Tabley, E≈øquire: Dorothy married Edward Warren, Son and Heir of Lawrence Warren of Pointon in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, 10 Hen. 8. 1518. Lib. C. fol. 250. b. Anne married Sir William Brereton of Brereton.
This Sir William Booth died 11 Hen. 8. 1519. nono die Novembris.

V. George Booth of Dunham E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Sir William, married Elizabeth Daughter of Sir Thomas Butler of Beu≈øy nigh Warrington in Lanca≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue George Son and Heir, John Booth, and Robert Booth: Al≈øo Ellen, married to John Son and Heir of John Carington of Carington in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, 29 Hen. 8. 1537. Lib. C. fol. 257. c. Anne married William Ma≈ø≈øy of Podington in Wirrall, E≈øquire: Margaret married Sir William Davenport of Bromhale in Maxfield Hundred: Elizabeth married Richard Sutton of Sutton nigh Maxfield, E≈øquire, 1566. Dorothy married Robert
Tatton of Withen≈øhaw nigh Baggiley, E≈øquire: Alice married Peter Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, 4 Edw. 6. 1550. Lib. C. fol. 243. I. And Cicely died without I≈ø≈øue.
This George died 22 Hen. 8. 1531. aged forty Years.

VI. George Booth of Dunham E≈øquire, Son and Heir of George, married Elizabeth Daughter of Sir Edmund Trafford of Trafford in Lanca≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue William Son and Heir; Elizabeth married William Chantrell of Bache not far from Che≈øter; Mary married Randle Davenport of Henbury E≈øquire; Anne married _____
Wentworth of _____ in York≈øhire.

When Letters were ≈øent from the Queen (Jane Seymour) through the Kingdom, to di≈øper≈øe the joyful News of the Birth of Edward the Sixth, 12 Octob. 1537. 29 Hen. 8. one was ≈øent by the Queen to this George Booth E≈øquire. Lib. C. fol. 249. n.
This George died 35 Hen. 8. 1543. aged 28 Years. Elizabeth his Widow after married James Done Brother and Heir to Sir John Done of Utkinton; and afterwards ≈øhe married Thomas Fitton of Gowe≈øworth.

VII. Sir William Booth of Dunham, Knighted 1578. Son and Heir of George, was but three Years old when his Father died, and was Ward to the King. He married Elizabeth Daughter of Sir John Warburton of Arley in A≈øton nigh Great Budworth, and had I≈ø≈øue George Booth Son and Heir; Edmund, ≈øecond Son, was a Lawyer, and died without I≈ø≈øue; John, third Son, married the Daughter of Pre≈øtwich of Hulm nigh Manche≈øter, and had ≈øeveral Children; which John was buried at Bowdon 1 Augu≈øti 1644. Robert, fourth Son, Baptized at Bowdon December 11. 1570. was a Soldier in Holland: Peter, fifth Son, was Baptized 21 Aprilis, 1576, died 7 Septembris, 1576. Richard, ≈øixth Son, Baptized at Bowdon 15 Junii, 1578. He married _____ Daughter and Heir of _____
Ma≈ø≈øy of Cog≈øhull, de≈øcended of Ma≈ø≈øy of Rixton. I find al≈øo another Son, called William, buried at Bowdon 31 Martii, 1572. Al≈øo Mary elde≈øt Daughter; Elizabeth, ≈øecond Daughter, married William Ba≈ønet; after to one Wal≈øhe of Ireland: Dorothy, third Daughter, married Rafe Bunigton of Barrow-cock in Derby≈øhire; Alice, fourth Daughter, married one Panton; Elinour, fifth Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon 27 Februarii, 1573. And Su≈øan, ≈øixth Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon 21 Maii, 1577. married Sir Edward Warren of Pointon in Che≈øhire: afterwards ≈øhe married John Fitton of Che≈øter. See the Office of Sir William Booth, proving the Names of all the≈øe Daughters. See al≈øo the Office of Elizabeth A≈øhton, 2 Elizabethae, who≈øe Part came to this Sir William.
Sir William died 28 Novembris, and was buried at Bowdon 8 die Decembris, 1579. aged 39 Years.
He was Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 1571. Dame Elizabeth his Wife gave five Pound for ever yearly to the Poor of Bowdon Pari≈øh, which Gift commenced 1621. as I find in the Regi≈øter of Bowdon Church.

VIII. Sir George Booth of Dunham, Knighted about the latter end of the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, and created Baronet 9 Jacobi, 1611. upon the fir≈øt In≈øtitution of that Order, Son and Heir of Sir William, did much improve his E≈øtate.

He had two Wifes: The fir≈øt was Jane Daughter and Heir of John Carington of Carington E≈øquire, whom he married the 18 day of February, 1577. John Carington her Father dying in January before: Jane was Baptized at Bowdon the tenth day of December, 1562. aged fifteen Years at the time of her Marriage; but ≈øhe died without I≈ø≈øue: Yet Sir George carried away all Carington's Lands again≈øt the next Heirs Males of that Family, which he recovered by Suit.

After the death of Jane, Sir George married Katharine Daughter of Sir Edmund Ander≈øon Chief Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue William, elde≈øt Son; Francis, ≈øecond Son, Baptized at Bowdon 11 Decembris, 1603. and Buried there 1 Martii, 1616. as appears by the In≈øcription in a Marble Monument in the South I≈øle of the Chancel of Bowdon Church, and the Regi≈øter-Book there: Thomas, third
Son, Baptized at Bowdon 9 Decembris, 1604. He died 1632. with a fall from his Hor≈øe: Edmund, fourth Son, born 26 Decembris, and Baptized at Bowdon 1 Januarii, 1609. where he was al≈øo buried 5 Septembris, 1617. John Booth, younge≈øt Son, now Sir John Booth of Woodford nigh Over in Che≈øhire, Knighted 1660. and yet living 1667. He hath ≈øeveral Children by his fir≈øt Wife; but after her death he married Anne the Widow of Thomas Legh of Adlington E≈øquire, 1659. but they lived a≈øunder: Mary elde≈øt Daughter of Sir George, was never married: Alice married George Vernon of Ha≈øtington E≈øquire, afterward Judge Vernon; ≈øhe was buried at Bowdon 8 Martii, 1623. Frances, third Daughter Frances died at Che≈øter, and was buried at Bowdon, 10 Septem. 1669., yet living at Che≈øter, 1667. but never married: Su≈øan, fourth Daughter, married Sir William Brereton of Honford about 1623. She was buried at Bowdon 6 Junii, 1637. Katharine, another Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon 22 Maii, 1606. ≈øhe is yet living at Che≈øter, 1667. and was never married: Cicely, another Daughter, died young: Elizabeth, younge≈øt Daughter, was ≈øecond Wife to Richard Lord Byron of New≈øtede in Nottingham≈øhire, both living 1667. but ≈øhe hath no I≈ø≈øue.

This Sir George was Ward to Queen Elizabeth, and was at the full age of 21 Years October 20. 29 Eliz. 1587. He was Sheriff of Che≈øter 1597. and al≈øo 1622. and he died at Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy 24 Octobris, and was buried at Bowdon 18 Novembris, 1652. having compleated the 86 Year of his Age.
Katharine his Lady died long before him; ≈øhe was buried at Bowdon 26 Februarii, 1638.

IX. William Booth E≈øquire, elde≈øt Son of Sir George, married Vere third Daughter and Co-heir of Sir Thomas Egerton (elde≈øt Son of Sir Thomas Egerton Lord Chancellor of England) in May, Anno Domini 1619. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Booth, elde≈øt Son, Baptized at Bowdon 29 Junii, 1620. he died at Che≈øter 3 Januarii, 1632. and was buried at St. Werburge in Che≈øter; George Booth, ≈øecond Son, ≈øucceeded Heir; William Booth, third Son, Baptized at Bowdon 28 Februarii, 1625. he died young; Nathaniel Booth, fourth Son, Baptized at Bowdon 9 Maii, 1627. is yet living at his Hou≈øe in Mottram-Andrew nigh Over-Alderley in Che≈øhire. 1667. He married Anne Raven≈øcroft, Daughter of Robert Raven≈øcroft, late of Bretton in the Pari≈øh of Harden in Flint≈øhire, E≈øquire, and hath I≈ø≈øue: Charles Booth, fifth Son, Baptized at Bowdon 26 Julii, 1628. and was buried at Bowdon 21 Januarii, 1634. Elizabeth Booth, Baptized at Bowdon 13 Julii, 1621. ≈øhe died young: Katharine, another Daughter, Baptized at Bowdon 25 Maii, 1624. ≈øhe married John Jack≈øon of Hickelton in York≈øhire, E≈øquire, about 1647. afterwards created Baronet, 31 Decembris, 1660. She died 1667.
This William Booth of Dunham was buried at Bowdon 3 Maii, 1636. in the Life-time of Sir George his Father.
Vere his Wife was buried at Bowdon 4 Maii, 1629.

X. Sir George Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, Baronet, Son and Heir of William, and Grand≈øon of Sir George, was created Baron Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy at the Coronation of King Charles the Second: His Patent bears date the 20 day of April, 13 Car. 2. 1661. He hath much beautified the Mannor-hou≈øe of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, by Building the North ≈øide thereof an≈øwerable to the oppo≈øite Part; and hath encompa≈ø≈øed a large Outward Court with a Brick-wall, and a fair Gate of Stone. He made a Dome≈øtick Chappel there, about 1655. by laying two Ground-Rooms together on the South ≈øide of the Hou≈øe.
He married Katharine Daughter of Theophilus Fines Earl of Linooln, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Vere Booth, a Daughter, Baptized 23 Julii, 1643. and is yet living, 1667.
Dame Katharine his Lady was Buried at Bowdon 5 Augu≈øti, 1643. She died in Childbed.

Afterwards he married Elizabeth Daughter of Henry Grey Earl of Stanford, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue William Booth elde≈øt Son, a very hopeful Youth, who died Anno Domini 1662. Henry Booth, ≈øecond Son; Charles Booth, George Booth, Robert Booth, Cecil Booth, all living 1666. Al≈øo Elizabeth, elde≈øt Daughter by this Lady, yet living 1667. Anne,
another Daughter, died at London 1667. Jane, another Daughter, died young, 1663. Diana, another Daughter, living 1667. Al≈øo Nevill Booth, another Son, Baptized at Dunham 15 Novembris, 1666.

XI. Henry Booth, ≈øecond Son of George Lord Delamere, and Heir to his Father, married Mary Daughter of Sir James Langham, Son of Alderman John Langham of London, Baronet, in July, 1670. George Lord Delamere his Father yet living.

div.head: Dutton.
div.p: I Find this Town of Dutton thrice named in Doom≈øday-book, as held then in the Conqueror's time by three Per≈øons. One Part Odard held immediately of the Earl of Che≈øter, as it were in Capite: Another Part was held by William Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton, of the Earl, in like manner: Another Part did Osberne Son of Tezzon, Ance≈øtor to the Boydells of Dodle≈øton, hold al≈øo of the Earl of Che≈øter.

Odard's Part ≈øeems to be the greate≈øt Part, which one Ravene held before at the coming in of the Normans. The Baron of Halton's Part, and Osbern's Part, one Edward held before, and did then likewi≈øe hold Osbern's Part under the ≈øaid Osbern.

But both Osbern's Part, and the Baron of Halton's Part, at la≈øt came to the Po≈øterity of Odard: Ex Chartulis Duttonorum de Dutton. For Osbern's Part was ≈øold by his Heir Sir William Boydell, who relea≈øed all his Seignory unto Thomas Son of Hugh Dutton of Dutton, in all the Lands which the ≈øaid Thomas held of him in Dutton, 15 Edw. 3. 1341. Lib. C. fol. 158. b.

As to the Baron of Halton's Part, John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhre, Baron of Halton, gave to Adam de Dutton (younger Son of Hugh Dutton of Dutton, and Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley) tho≈øe four Oxgangs of Land in Dutton, which Walter Heron held: This was about the end of the Reign of Henry the Second: Lib. C. fol. 140. And Sir Geffrey de Warburton relea≈øeth all his Right unto Thomas Son of Hugh de Dutton afore≈øaid, in all tho≈øe Lands in Dutton which the ≈øaid Thomas held by Lea≈øe from the ≈øaid Sir Geffrey: Dated at Dutton 28 Edw. 3. 1354. Lib. C. fol. 158. c. So that Thomas de Dutton was now inve≈øted in the whole Town of Dutton entirely.

This Town≈øhip in the ancient Record of Doom≈øday-book is written [Duntune]: Dun in the old Saxon Language ≈øignifies A Hill, for which we now u≈øe the word Down: So that Duntune ≈øignifies as much as A Town upon a Hill or Down; now contracted to Dutton.

From this Town did the ancient Family of the Duttons a≈ø≈øume their Sir-name: For Odard being ≈øeated here in the Conqueror's Time, his Po≈øterity were ≈øir-named de Dutton from the Place of their Re≈øidence; where they have continued ever ≈øince to this pre≈øent 1666. about 600 Years: A Family of great Worth and Antiquity, and as it were almo≈øt a con≈øtant Succe≈ø≈øion of Knights; but now, alas! ready to change its Name, being devolved by a Daughter and Heir unto the Lord Gerard of Gerards-Bromley in Stafford≈øhire.

Out of this Family branched out the Warburtons of Arley under Henry the Second, and retained their proper Sir-name of Dutton, till Peter Dutton ≈øeating him≈øelf at Warburton towards the end of Edward the Fir≈øt, his Po≈øterity under Edward the Second were ≈øtiled de Warburton, and have ever ≈øince wholly retained the Sir-name of Warburton.

The Warburtons, Chedills, and A≈øhleys in Che≈øhire, are all originally Duttons. About the ≈øame time of Henry the Second, branched out al≈øo Geffrey de Dutton, another Son, from whom the Duttons of Chedill in this County; who≈øe Po≈øterity afterwards a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Chedill under Edward the Fir≈øt: And out of this Family of Dutton of Chedill, branched out Hamon Dutton, a younger Son, under Edward the Fir≈øt, who a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of A≈øhley from the Place of his Re≈øidence; who≈øe Po≈øterity wholly retained the Sir-name of A≈øhley, as you may ≈øee more fully in A≈øhley‚ñ™
Be≈øides the Duttons of Hatton nigh Warton in Che≈øhire, more lately ≈øprung hence, and other Good Families.

The Mannor-hou≈øe of Dutton is well ≈øeated, and hath great ≈øtore of Meadowing by the River ≈øide belonging to the Demain, which is accounted the large≈øt and be≈øt Demain within our County, comprehending 1400 Statute Acres by Survey.

This Hou≈øe ≈øtandeth upon a plea≈øant Pro≈øpect to the oppo≈øite Hills of the Fore≈øt; and hath in it an ancient Chappel, built fir≈øt by Sir Thomas Dutton towards the end of Henry the Third's Reign; unto whom Roger de Lincoln then Prior of Norton, and the Convent there, did grant liberam Cantariam in Capellis ≈øuis de Dutton & We≈øton infr√† Limites Parochiarum no≈øtrarum de Budworth & de Runcorne: id e≈øt, Free liberty of Reading Divine Service, or Singing the ≈øame; ≈øo as the Mother-Churches receive no detriment either in their greater or le≈ø≈øer Tythes. Lib. C. fol. 155. s. That of We≈øton is long ≈øince vani≈øhed; but this Chappel at Dutton yet remains, and is now a Dome≈øtick Chappel within the Mannor-Hou≈øe of Dutton, unto which Sir Piers Dutton of Hatton, after he was adjudged next Heir Male to the Lands of Dutton by the Award of Henry the Eighth, did annex his new Buildings at Dutton, Anno Domini 1539. as appears by the In≈øcription round about the Hall of Dutton yet extant, ad ‚Ä¢ oyning tho≈øe unto the Chappel, and ≈øo making it as one continued Building; before which time, the old Hou≈øe ≈øtood a little di≈øtance from the Chappel afore≈øaid.

In the Demain of Dutton is al≈øo another Chappel of Ea≈øe, called Poo≈øey-Chappel, within the Pari≈øh of Runcorne; but is now ruinate, and in decay. It is ≈øeated between the River and the Park-Pool within the Demain of Dutton, but not in the Town≈øhip of Dutton; for all the Town of Dutton is within Budworth Pari≈øh. It was called Poo≈ø-eye from its Situation, [Ey] in our old Engli≈øh-Saxon Tongue ≈øignifies A River or Brook; and becau≈øe it ≈øtood clo≈øe by the River and the Pool al≈øo, it was called Poo≈ø-ey-Chappel, as it were, The Chappel by the River and the Pool. In our old Norman Writing, and French way, I find it it in Old Deeds written Pul≈ø-ey; but in our common Language anciently, as the Countrey People at this day, did call a Pool a Poo; and thence it was denominated Poo's-ey-Chappel. It was built in the Reign of Henry the Third; and the Prior and Convent of Norton granted to Hugh Son of Hugh de Dutton, that they would find a Chaplain to Officiate at Poos-ey for ever, and a Lamp burning at the time of Divine Service, about 1236. 20 Hen. 3. Lib. C. fol. 155. r. which Chappel was con≈øtantly frequented by the Neighborhood, until Robert Lord Kilmorey and Dame Elinour his Wife came to live at Dutton, even in our days; who beautified the Dome≈øtick Chappel at Dutton with hand≈øom Pews, and kept a Chaplain in his Hou≈øe con≈øtantly, whereunto all the Neighborhood re≈øorted every Sunday: Then began Poo≈øey Chappel to be neglected, and is now totally in decay, ≈øome part of the Structure yet remaining, 1666.

div.head: Now followeth the Pedegree of the Duttons of Dutton, faithfully Collected from the Evidences of that Family, and other good Records and Deeds.

figure.head: Quarterly, Argent & Gules, in the ≈øecond and third Quarters a Fret Or.

div.p:
The ancient Roll of the Barons of Halton ≈øaith, That with Hugh Earl of Che≈øter came one Nigell a Nobleman; and with Nigell came five Brethren, to wit, Hudard, Edard, Wolmere, Hor≈øwyne, and Wolfaith, a Prie≈øt, to whom Nigell gave the Church of Runcorne; and unto Hudard the ≈øame Nigell gave We≈øton and Great A≈øton (now divided into two Town≈øhips, A≈øton Grange, and A≈øton juxt√† Sutton) pro uno Feodo Militis: And from this Hudard came all the Duttons. Lib. C. fol. 84, 85. & Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, 2 Pars, pag. 187. And in the
Record of Doom≈øday, Odard held A≈øton under William Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton; and al≈øo Odard and Brictric held Weston under the ≈øaid William, Anno Domini 1086. Whether tho≈øe five Brethren afore-named, were Brethren to Nigell, is a doubt; for then methinks he ≈øhould have ≈øaid,‚ÄîQuinque Fratres ≈øui: whereas he ≈øays onely, C√πm i≈øto Nigello venerunt quinque Fratres, and ≈øo names them.

This Hudard's, or Odard's Sword, is at this day, 1665. in the Cu≈øtody of the Lady Elinour Vicounte≈øs Kilmorey, ≈øole Daughter and Heir of Thomas Dutton late of Dutton E≈øquire, decea≈øed; which Sword hath for many Ages pa≈øt been pre≈øerved, and pa≈ø≈øed over from Heir to Heir as an Heir-loom, by the name of Hudard's Sword; and ≈øo at this day it is by Tradition received and called. Lib. C. fol. 163. dd.

II. Hugh Son of Hodard had tho≈øe Lands which he held in Capite, or immediately of the Earl of Che≈øter, confirmed unto him by Randle the Second, ≈øirnamed de Gernoniis, Earl of Chester, about the latter end of Henry the Fir≈øt. Lib. C. fol. 154. b. The≈øe Lands I conceive were tho≈øe which he held in Dutton.

III. Hugh de Dutton, Son of Hugh, Son of Hodard, had the Lands which his Father Hugh held of the Baron of Halton confirmed unto him by William Son of Nigell, Con≈øtable to Randle the Second, and by William his Son, on that day when the ≈øaid William the Father and William the Son did vi≈øit Hugh, the Son of Hodard on his Death-bed at Kekwick; at which time Hugh the 8on of Hodard gave unto William the Father his Coat of Mail and his Charging-Hor≈øe; and Hugh, the Son of that Hugh, gave unto William the Son a Palfrey and a Sparrow-hawk. This was about the end of the Reign of King Henry the Fir≈øt: Lib. C. fol. 154. a. The Lands here confirmed I conceive to be We≈øton and Kekwick, and perhaps ≈øome others.

This Hugh de Dutton had I≈ø≈øue Hugh Dutton Son and Heir; Adam de Dutton, another Son, from whom the Warburtons of Arley are de≈øcended; Geffrey de Dutton, another Son, from whom the Duttons of Chedill in this County were propagated, who a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Chedill, and continued to the Reign of Edward the Third, till Sir Roger de Chedill (the la≈øt of that Family) dying 1 Edw. 3. 1327. left his Inheritance to be ≈øhared by his two Daughters and Heirs, Clemence and Agnes: Lib. C. fol. 61. h. Lib. B. pag. 10. q. Lib. C. fol. 150. c. a. b. & fol. 150. l. And out of that Family de Chedill branched Hamon Dutton under Edward the Fir≈øt, younger Son to Sir Geffrey Dutton of Chedill, to whom his Father gave A≈øhley 13 Ed‚ñ™ 1. 1285., which he purcha≈øed for him. C. fol. 154. h. So that he holds it, as it were, under the Baron of Halton, who re≈øerves his own Right by a ≈øpecial Re≈øervation.

This Privilege over ≈øuch loo≈øe Per≈øons was granted fir≈øt unto Roger Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, under Richard the Fir≈øt, by Randle ≈øir-named Blundevill, Earl of Chester, in memory of his good Service done to the Earl in rai≈øing the Siege of the Wel≈øh-men, who had be≈øet the Earl in his Ca≈øtle of Rothelent in Flint≈øhire: For the Con≈øtable having got a promi≈øcuous Rabble of ≈øuch like Per≈øons together, and Marching towards the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, the Wel≈øh (≈øuppo≈øing a great Army to be coming) rai≈øed their Siege, and fled: So ≈øaith the ancient Roll of the Barons of Halton: Lib. Anno Domini 1379. 3 Rich. 2. William Eltonhed Prior of the Hermit-Fryars of the Order of St. Augu≈øtine at Warrington in Lanca≈øhire, and the Convent there, grant to Sir Thomas Dutton Knight a perpetual Chantry; to wit, That a ≈øufficient Fryar of the Convent of Warrington ≈øhall be e≈øpecially elected to pray for the Salvation of Sir Thomas, his Children, and of Philippa his Wife, and her Parents; and for the Soul of Dame Ellen late Wife of the ≈øaid Sir Thomas, their Children and Parents when they ≈øhall die, at the Great Altar of their Church yearly for ever; and that their Names be written down in their Martyrology: Whereunto the Prior and Convent were bound under a Penalty of 3 s. 4 d. to be levied by the Provincial Prior upon omi≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch Form of Service; and if for a Week or a Fortnight it were omitted, then mu≈øt they double the time omitted in manner afore≈øaid: If neglected for ≈øix Months, then upon pain of Su≈øpen≈øion: If for a Year, then upon Excommunication, until the time omitted be made up: Whereunto are Witne≈ø≈øes, Thomas Abbot of St. Werburge of Che≈øter, Stephen Abbot of Vale-Royal, Richard Prior of Norton, and Roger Prior of Berkenhed.

This was confirmed by Henry de Towe≈ødale Provincial Prior of the Hermit-Fryars of the Order of St. Augu≈øtine in England, with a ≈øpecial Injunction, That the ≈øaid Per≈øons be yearly twice Commemorated before the whole Convent; once at the fir≈øt entrance of the Prior of Warrington into the Convocation-hou≈øe yearly; the other time, on the Election-day of a Fellow-Prior for a Provincial Convocation. Great Contention fell between this Sir Peter Dutton, and Sir William Athurton of Athurton in Lanca≈øhire; in≈øomuch that they made Inroads and Inva≈øions one upon the other: And the ≈øaid Sir Piers Dutton, and his Adherents. to wit, Sir Rafe Bo≈øtock of Bo≈øtock, Richard Warburton of Budworth, Thomas Warburton of Halton, John Done of Utkinton junior, John Manley of Manley, Hugh Dutton of Hatton the elder, William Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley, Sir Peter Legh of Clifton (Ance≈øtor to Legh of Lyme), and John Carington of Carington, were all ≈øued by Sir William Athurton, for taking away forty of his Oxen, and forty Cows, out of his Clo≈øes at Athurton, and for beating of his Servants. C. fol. 146. n.

C. fol. 160. w. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Dutton, Son and Heir; Roger Dutton, another Son, afterwards Lord of Dutton; John Dutton, ≈ølain with his Brother Sir Thomas Dutton at Blore-Heath, 1459.
Stow. Robert Dutton, another Son, died without I≈ø≈øue: Lib. C. fol. 180. k. Margaret married Hugh Son and Heir of Raufe Egerton, 21 Hen. 6. 1443. Lib. C. fol. 147. b. Maud married Sir William Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 21 Hen. 6. 1443. Lib. C. fol. 164. g. Agnes married Richard Wynnington of Wynnington nigh Northwich (Son and Heir of Robert Wynnington, Son and Hir of Sir Richard Wynnington) 25 Hen. 6. 1446. Lib. C. fol. 160. y. Ellen married Edward Son and Heir of Richard Longford of Lanca≈øhire E≈øq 28 Hen. 6. 1450. Lib. C. fol. 160. a. Elizabeth married John Merbury, Son and Heir of James Merbury of Merbury nigh Comberbach, E≈øquire, 1458. The Original pen√®s Thomam Merbury Armigerum, 1666.
Obiit 1445 This John Dutton of Dutton died 24 Hen. 6. 1445. aged forty two Years: Lib. C. fol. 160. y. z. Margaret his Wife ≈øurvived, and was living 1450.

XIV. Sir Thomas Dutton of Dutton Knight, Son and Heir of John and Margaret, married Anne Daughter of James Lord Audley, and had I≈ø≈øue Peter elde≈øt Son, ≈ølain with his Father at the Battel of Blore-Heath, as Tradition hath it: John Dutton, ≈øecond Son, who ≈øucceeded Heir to his Father: Anno married Sir Thomas Molineaux of Sefton in Lanca≈øhire: I≈øabel married Sir Chri≈øtopher Sotheworth of Sotheworth in Lanca≈øhire: Lib. D. pag. 173. f. Elizabeth married Raufe Bo≈øtock of Bo≈øtock in Davenham Pari≈øh in Che≈øhire, E≈øq by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Anne Daughter and Heir, married to Sir John Savage of Clifton in Che≈øhire, juxt√† Halton; which Elizabeth, after the death of Raufe Bo≈øtock, married Thomas Scriven of Frod≈øley in Shrop≈øhire, and ≈øhe died Anno Domini 1516. 5 die Februarii, 8 Hen. 8. Lib. C. fol. 139. x. Margaret, another Daughter of Sir Thomas Dutton, married Thomas A≈øton of A≈øton juxt√† Sutton, E≈øquire, 7 Edw. 4. 1467. Afterwards ≈øhe married Raufe Vernon of Ha≈ølington in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire: And Elinour, another Daughter, married Richard Cholmondley of Cholmondley in Broxton Hundred, E≈øq Lib. C. fol. 161. I. n.
Obiit 1459 This Sir Thomas was ≈ølain at the Battel of Blore-Heath in Stafford≈øhire, September 23. 38 Hen. 6. 1459. Stow in his Annals: and in the thirty eighth Year of his Age.
Anne his Widow afterwards married Hugh Done of Olton in Che≈øhire; and ≈øhe died 19 Hen. 7. 1503. Lib. C. fol. 162. v.

XV. John Dutton of Dutton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Sir Thomas and Anne, was made Steward to the Prior of Norton for his Life, of all the Lands and Tenements belonging to that Priory, Robert Leftwich being then Abbot of Norton; and for which the ≈øaid John Dutton had three Pound yearly for his Fee: Dated at Norton, in September, 38 Hen. 6. 1459. Lib. C. fol. 145. c.

He married Margaret Daughter of Richard, and Si≈øter to Sir Thomas Molineaux of Sefton in Lanca≈øhire;
Obiit 1473 but died without I≈ø≈øue 13 Edw. 4. 1473. leaving Roger Dutton his Uncle to ≈øucceed in his E≈øtate: Lib. C. fol. 160. d. e.
Margaret his Widow married William Buckley of Eaton junior, 15 Edw. 4. Lib. C. fol. 160. b.

XVI. Roger Dutton of Dutton E≈øquire (younger Brother to Sir Thomas, and Heir to his Nephew John Dutton) married Joan Daughter of Sir Richard A≈øton of A≈øton juxt√† Sutton, and had I≈ø≈øue Lawrence Dutton Son and Heir.
Obiit 1499 This Roger died 14 Hen. 7. 1499. Joan his Widow afterwards married Sir Richard Strangewaies. Lib. C. fol. 162. v. & fol. 164. e.

XVII. Lawrence Dutton of Dutton E≈øquire, 14 Hen. 7. Son and Heir of Roger and Joan,
Obiit 1526 8 Hen. 8. married Joan Daughter of Robert Duckenfield of Duckenfield in Che≈øhire E≈øquire; but died without any Lawful I≈ø≈øue, Anno Domini 1526. aged fifty Years: Lib. C. fol. 164. e. & fol. 161. k.

He had a Ba≈øtard-≈øon, called John Dutton, to whom he gave the Me≈ø≈øuage in Pre≈øton nigh Daresbery, called The New Mannor, for his Life; 1526. Lib. C. fol. 162. s. He had al≈øo two Ba≈øtard-daughters, I≈øabel and Joan.

Upon the ≈øailing of the I≈ø≈øue Male of this Line of Dutton, there fell great Controver≈øie and Suits of Law concerning this fair Inheritance of Dutton, between Sir Piers Dutton of Hatton in Broxton Hundred, as next Heir Male, on the one part; and the Daughters and Co-heirs of Sir Thomas Dutton of Dutton, and their Heirs, on the other part. At la≈øt it was compo≈øed and ended by the Award of King Henry the Eighth, Dated the ≈øixteenth day of May, 26 Hen. 8. 1534. and Confirmed by Act of Parliament 27 Hen. 8. Lib. C. fol. 163. y. after ≈øeven Years Suit, and above.

The Lands allotted to the Co-heirs were the Lord≈øhips of Church-Min≈øhull, A≈øton in Mondrum, and Kekwick; and all the Lands which the Ance≈øtors of Dutton hold in King≈øley, Norley, Chorleton Codynton, Pulton-Lancelyn, Bradley, Budword in le Frith, Milneton, Barnton, Over-Whitley, A≈øton nigh Molde≈øworth, Hellesby, Frod≈øham, and in the City of Che≈øter.

The Lands allotted to Sir Piers Dutton of Hatton, and now adjudged the next Heir Male, were, The Mannor of Dutton, the Advowry of the Min≈øtrels in Che≈øhire, the Advow≈øon of Poo≈øey Chappel, the Lord≈øhips of We≈øton, Pre≈øton, Barterton, Little Legh, Ne≈ø≈øe in Wirrall, Little Molde≈øworth, Acton, and Harpesford; and all the Lands which the Ance≈øtors of Dutton held in We≈øton, Clifton, Pre≈øton, Barterton, Legh, Ne≈ø≈øe, Little Molde≈øworth, Acton, Harpesford, Stony Dunham, Michbarrow, Stoke, Picton, Arrowe, North-wich, Halton, Thelwall, One≈øton, Middle-wich, Stanthorne, and Over-Runcorne.

And now before we proceed to the next Lord of Dutton, we mu≈øt look back to the fir≈øt Ance≈øtor of this Sir Piers Dutton of Hatton, which branches out of the Family of Dutton of Dutton, and bring that Line to this Sir Piers Dutton, and then proceed.

So then we find Hugh Dutton, the fir≈øt Dutton of Hatton, in Right of Petronill his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Peter de Hatton juxt√† Warton, branching out under Richard the Second. This Hugh was a younger Son of Edmund Dutton, which Edmund was a younger Son of Sir Thomas Dutton of Dutton.

item.p: 1. This Hugh had I≈ø≈øue John Dutton, Son and Heir; Lawrence Dutton, another Son; Randle, Rector of Chri≈øtleton nigh Che≈øter; al≈øo Hugh, another Son, Lib. C. fol. 146. n. Elizabeth, a Daughter, married Richard Manley of Manley.

Hugh Dutton of Hatton was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 10 Hen. 5. 1422. and had a ≈øecond Wife, namely, Emme the Widow of Hugh Venables of Golborne, and Daughter of Nicolas Warren of Pointon, 16 Hen. 6. John Booth of Twamlow's Book of his own Collections, Lib. H. pag. 125. a. b.

list.item: 2. John Dutton of Hatton, 19 Hen. 6. Son and Heir of Hugh and Parnell, was Mayor of Che≈øter 30 Hen. 6. and married Margaret Daughter of William Athurton of Athurton in Lanca≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue Peter, Son and Heir; Richard, another Son; Geffrey, another Son: Cicely married John Byrd of Broxton: Ellen married one Gilibrand.

3. Peter Dutton of Hatton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of John, married Elizabeth elde≈øt Daughter and one of the Heirs of Robert Gro≈øvenour of Houlme in Allo≈øtock, E≈øquire, 1464. and had I≈ø≈øue Peter Dutton junior, Rafe, Richard, and Randle.

item.p: 4. Peter Dutton of Hatton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Peter, married Elizabeth Daughter of Sir Robert Foule≈øhur≈øt of Crew in Che≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue Sir Piers Dutton, who was adjudged next Heir Male to all Dutton Lands, 26 Hen. 8. Elizabeth married Sir George Calveley of Lea nigh Eaton-boat: Elinour married Randle Brereton of Malpas: Jane married George Leech of Carden.
This Peter died about 20 Hen. 7. for Elizabeth his Widow married Thomas Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire, 22 Hen. 7. 1506. and ≈øhe was the third Wife of the ≈øaid Thomas Leyce≈øter. T. num. 1.

div.p: XVIII. Sir Piers Dutton of Hatton and Dutton both, Son and Heir of Peter Dutton of Hatton E≈øquire, was a Knight 19 Hen. 8. Lib. C. fol. 162. s. and adjudged next Heir Male to Lawrence Dutton of Dutton E≈øquire, 26 Hen. 8. 1534. Lib. C. fol. 163. y. He is the eighteenth Lord of Dutton ≈øince the Conque≈øt, and the fifteenth Per≈øon in Lineal De≈øcent from Odard. He built the Hall and New Buildings of Dutton-Hou≈øe, which he joyned to the Chappel, Anno 1539. before which time the Hou≈øe ≈øtood a little more remote from the Chappel.

He had two Wifes. Elinour Daughter of Thomas Legh of Adlington was his fir≈øt Wife, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Peter Dutton, elde≈øt Son, who died without I≈ø≈øue; Hugh Dutton, ≈øecond Son; Rafe Dutton, third Son, to whom his Father gave all Hatton Lands, from whom the Duttons of Hatton yet in being‚ñ™ 1666. are propagated: Katharine, a Daughter, married Sir Roger Pil≈øton of Emrads; afterwards ≈øhe married Richard Gro≈øvenour, younger Son of the Gro≈øvenours of Eaton-boat: Elizabeth married William Manley of Manley; afterwards ≈øhe married Thomas Brown of Nether-Lee: Anne married to Hamnet Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale in Che≈øhire; after to Edward Barlow of Barlow in Lanca≈øhire: Margery married John Booth, younger Son of Sir William Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy: Margaret married Raufe Sherman: Mary married Matthew Ellis of Overley: Alice died unmarried. See the Inqui≈øition po≈øt mortem praedicti Petri Dutton Militis, 37 Hen. 8. which names the Daughters; but their Husbands I had out of the Herald's Books.

Sir Piers married to his ≈øecond Wife Julian Daughter of William Poyns of Worthokiton in E≈ø≈øex, E≈øquire; who with her Husband built the Hall of Dutton, and the new Chambers there, 1539. as appears by the In≈øcription round about the Hall of Dutton, within the Hall.

Obiit 1546 He was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 34 Hen. 8. and died 37 Hen. 8. 1546. and had a Ba≈øtard≈øon, called John Dutton, and a Ba≈øtard-daughter, called Elizabeth, as appears by the Office taken after his death.

Hugh Dutton, ≈øecond Son, and Heir to Sir Piers, married Jane Daughter of Sir William Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 12 Hen. 8. Lib. C. fol. 167. and had I≈ø≈øue John Dutton, Son and Heir; and Anne, married to Cri≈øtopher Son and Heir of Thomas Holford of Holford nigh Nether-Tabley in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire.
This Hugh died in the Life-time of Sir Piers his Father, and Jane his Widow married Thomas Holford afore≈øaid.

XIX. John Dutton of Dutton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Hugh, and Grand≈øon to Sir Piers, married Elinour Daughter of Sir Hugh Calveley of Lea nigh Eaton-boat, and had I≈ø≈øue Peter, elde≈øt Son, who married Elizabeth Daughter and Heir of Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Aldford in Che≈øhire, 27 Eliz. 1585. Lib. C. fol. 163. aa. and died the thirtieth day of May, 35 Eliz. 1593. without I≈ø≈øue Male of his Body then living, in the Life-time of his Father: See John Dutton's Office, 7 Jacobi. Al≈øo John Dutton, ≈øecond Son; and Hugh, third Son, both died without I≈ø≈øue; Thomas, fourth Son, ≈øucceeded Heir to his Father: Lawrence, Raufe, Adam, Geffrey, and George, all five died without I≈ø≈øue: Jane died unmarried: Anne married one Her≈øey; and Elinour died unmarried.

This John had al≈øo John Dutton Ba≈øtard-≈øon, who was after Gardiner at Dutton, and died 1664. And Elizabeth, a Ba≈øtard-daughter, married Mr. Mar≈øhall Chaplain to the Lord Gerard of Gerards-Bromley in Stafford≈øhire, Mother to the two famous Women-Actors now at London, called The two Mar≈øhals.

The ≈øame John ≈øued Raufe Dutton of Hatton his Uncle, for all Hatton Lands, as Heir at Law: But this Suit was compo≈øed by the Award of Robert Earl of Leyce≈øter, the fifth day of July, 14 Eliz. 1572. wherein he gave to John Dutton the Lands of Claverton, and in Honbridge in the City of Che≈øter, and in Littleton in Che≈øhire, and the Lands in Harden and Mancote in Flint≈øhire, and al≈øo 500 Marks to be paid by Raufe Dutton to the ≈øaid John: And all the re≈øt of Hatton Lands he continued and gave to Raufe Dutton. Lib. C. fol. 168. b.

John Dutton of Dutton died the thirtieth day of January, 6 Jacobi, 1608. at Dutton,
Obiit 1608 aged ≈øeventy Years. See the Office taken 7 Jacobi.

XX. Thomas Dutton of Dutton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of John, married Thoma≈øin Daughter of Roger Anderton, younger Brother of Anderton of Anderton in Lanca≈øhire, and Widow to John Singleton of Stany in Lanca≈øhire; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue John Dutton, who married Elizabeth elde≈øt Daughter and Coheir of Sir Thomas Egerton, late Son of Sir Thomas Egerton Lord Chancellor of England, 3 Jacobi, 1605. Lib. C. fol. 163. bb. But this John died without I≈ø≈øue the ninth day of February, 6 Jacobi, 1608. at Tarvin, in the Life-time of Thomas his Father: Al≈øo Elinour, a Daughter, who became ≈øole Heir to her Father.

This Thomas Dutton of Dutton was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 1611. 9 Jacobi, and died 1614. 12 Jacobi, aged forty ≈øix Years: Lib. C. fol. 163. dd. ee. Elinour his Daughter and Heir being then aged eighteen Years.

Thoma≈øin his Widow afterwards married Sir Anthony St. John, younger Brother to the Earl of Bolingbroke; but had no I≈ø≈øue by him. She was ≈øecond Wife to Sir Anthony, and he was third Husband to her.

XXI. Elinour, ≈øole Daughter and Heir of Thomas Dutton, married Gilbert Gerard, Son and Heir of Thomas Gerard Lord Gerard of Gerards-Bromley in Stafford≈øhire, 7 Jacobi, 1609. ≈øhe being then but thirteen Years old: Lib. C. fol. 163. cc. Gilbert was afterwards Sir Gilbert Gerard Knight of the Bath, 30 Maii, 1610. at the Creation of Henry, elde≈øt Son of King James, into the Title of Prince of Wales and Earl of Che≈øter: And after the death of Thomas Lord Gerard his Father, he was then Gilbert Lord Gerard, 1618. and had I≈ø≈øue Dutton Lord Gerard; and Thomas, who died in his Infancy: Al≈øo Alice, elde≈øt Daughter, born in Che≈øter 12 Junii, and Baptized 18 Junii, 1615. She married Roger Owen, Son and Heir of Sir William Owen of Cundor in Shrop≈øhire, who died 1660. and Alice his Wife after married Henry Heylyn of Oxford≈øhire, 1663. Nephew to Dr. Peter Heylyn. Frances, ≈øecond Daughter, married Robert Nedham, Son and Heir of Robert Vi≈øcount Kilmorcy, by whom he had onely one Child, called Elinour, which died young, 1643. Frances was Buried at Great Budworth, 25 Maii, 1636. ≈øhe died in Child-bed: And Elizabeth, third Daughter, born at Gerards-Bromley in Stafford≈øhire, Anno Chri≈øti 1620. married Peter Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, 6 Novembris, 1642. afterwards Sir Peter Leyce≈øter Baronet, 1660. the Author of this Book.

After the Death of Gilbert Lord Gerard, who died 1622. Elinour his Lady married Robert Nedham of Shenton in Shrop≈øhire, Vi≈øcount Kilmorey in Ireland: She was ≈øecond Wife of Robert, and had I≈ø≈øue by him Charles Nedham, afterwards Lord Kilmorey, who died at London 1660.
