George, ≈øecond Son, died at Che≈øter without I≈ø≈øue, 1644. Thomas Nedham, third Son, now living, 1669. Arthur, another Son, died an Infant, over-laid by his Nur≈øe: Anne died in her Infancy: Elinour fir≈øt married Peter Warburton, Heir to Arley E≈øtate, 1638. ≈øhe was then but eleven Years old: But Peter dying without I≈ø≈øue, and under Age, of the Small Pox, at Oxford, Anno 1641. ≈øhe married afterwards John Lord Byron of New≈øtede in Nottingham≈øhire, Anno 1644. then Governor of Che≈øter, who died in France, without any I≈ø≈øue by her, Anno 1652. This Elinour (a Per≈øon of ≈øuch comely Carriage and Pre≈øence, Hand≈øomne≈øs, ≈øweet Di≈øpo≈øition, Honour, and general Repute in the World, that ≈øhe hath ≈øcarce left her Equal behind) died at Che≈øter the twenty ≈øixth day of January, 1663. about the Age of thirty ≈øix Years, and was Buried in Trinity Church in that City. Su≈øan, third Daughter, married Richard ≈øcriven of Frod≈øley in Shrop≈øhire, E≈øquire, 1652. She died in Augu≈øt, 1667. at Frod≈øley. Katharine, the fourth Daughter, died unmarried at Dutton, 11 Martii, being Sunday, 1665. Mary, fifth Daughter, now living, and unmarried, 1669. Penelope, ≈øixth Daughter, married Randle Egerton of Betley in Stafford≈øhire, E≈øquire, 1653. Dorothy, ≈øeventh Daughter, died unmarried at London in June, 1669. And Elizabeth, younge≈øt Daughter, now living, and unmarried, 1669.

Robert Vi≈øcount Kilmorey died at Dutton 12 Septembris, 1653. So that the Lady Elinour Kilmorey ≈øurvived both her Husbands; in who≈øe Cu≈øtody Hudard's Sword, as Tradition hath it, now remains, whereof I made mention in the beginning.

This Lady Elinour died at Dutton the twelfth day of March, 1665. aged ≈øixty nine Years; and her Daughter Katharine al≈øo dying at Dutton the day before, were both Interred at Great Budworth together on the Fryday following, being the ≈øixteenth day of March, 1665.
So ended the Family of Dutton of Dutton.

div.head: Gropenhale.
div.p: THis Town of Gropenhale in the Conqueror's Time belonged to Osbern Son of Tezzon, Ance≈øtor to the Boydells of Dodle≈øton in this County.
Afterwards it ≈øeems to be given to William Son of Sam≈øon, who relea≈øed the ≈øame to Hugh Boydell about the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt, in the≈øe words:‚Äî

Ex Chartulis Thomae Merbury de Merbury de Merbury juxta Great Budworth, Armigeri, 1666.
Notum ≈øit‚ÄîEgo Willielmus Filius Sam≈øonis, dedi & omnino relaxavi Domino meo Hugoni de Boydell pro defectu Servitii ≈øui, quod retr√≤ e≈øt, Gropenhale, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis, in Bo≈øco & Plano, &c. Salvo forin≈øeco, ≈øcilic√®t dimidi√¢ Parte trium Partium de Feodo unius Militis: Et pro h√¢c Donatione me√¢ Dictus Hugo de Boydele Dominus meus valentiam trium Marcarum mihi donavit.‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Radulpho de Manwaringe t√πnc Ju≈øticiarto Ce≈øtriae, Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, &c. Lib. C. fol. 280. bb.

After this, Sir John Boydell, in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, gives Caterich (a certain Place in Gropenhale) unto Robert his younger Son, who granted the ≈øame to Thomas Son of Sir Hugh Dutton of Dutton; but Thomas Dutton relea≈øeth it unto William Son of Sir William Boydell of Dodle≈øton, 16 Edw. 3. 1342. Lib. C. fol. 280. cc.

6 Edw. 2. the King granted to William Boydele liberam Warrennam in Dominicis Terris ≈øuis de Dodle≈øton, Gropenhale, & Lachford: Lib. C. fol. 282. r. This William Boydell married Maud Daughter of Raufe Vernon, and had I≈ø≈øue Raufe Boydell, who died without I≈ø≈øue; and ≈øo the Inheritance of Boydell was ≈øhared by the two Si≈øters and Co-heirs of William Boydell afore≈øaid, to wit, Margaret Wife of Owen Voil a Wel≈øhman, and Joan Wife of Sir John Danyell of Gropenhale, younger Son of Thomas Danyers of Bradley in Appleton ≈øenior, and afterwards Heir to his Father.
Howel ap Owen Voil relea≈øed to Sir John and Joan all his Purparty of Gropenhale-Wood, 25 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 291. f. The Original hereof is now among the Evidences of Legh of Lime, 1666.

42 Edw. 3. Sir John and Joan Levied a Fine of the Mannor of Gropenhale, To remain to the Heirs Males of the ≈øaid John and Joan; and if Sir John had no Heir by Joan, then one half of Gropenhale ≈øhould revert to the Heirs of Sir John, and the other half to the Heirs of Joan. Lib. C. fol. 242. v. & fol. 290. a.

Sir John Daniell had I≈ø≈øue by Joan a Daughter and Heir, called Nicolaa, Mother of Margaret Wife of Alan de Rixton in Lanca≈øhire; which Margaret dying without I≈ø≈øue, 6 Rich. 2. Margaret the Wife of John Savage of Clifton, Daughter and Heir of Sir Thomas Daniell of Bradley the younger, elder Brother of the ≈øaid Sir John Daniell, had the Purpart of the ≈øaid Lands, as one of the Heirs of Margaret late Wife of Alan de Rixton, 9 Rich. 2. And Thomas Boydell (Son of William ≈øir-named Boydell, Son of Howell, Son of Margaret Si≈øter of Joan, Mother of Nicolaa) was the other Heir: Lib. C. fol. 290. c. who≈øe Land was after divided, as anon ≈øhall appear.

Margaret Wife of John Savage, afterwards married Piers Legh of Maxfield, 1388. 12 Rich. 2. younger Son of Robert Legh of Adlington; and ≈øhe gave unto Peter Legh of Lyme, her Son, the Moiety of Gropenhale, 4 Hen. 4. in her Widowhood, which ≈øhe
had as Heir to Margaret late Wife of Alan de Rixton; from whom the Leghs of Lime, now Lord of the moiety of Gropenhale, 1666. Lib. C. fol. 290. d. The Originals Penes Legh of Lime.

The other Moiety of Gropenhale, de≈øcending to Thomas Boydell afore≈øaid,Ex Chartulis Merbury de Merbury juxta Great Budworth. came to the Part of Hugh Reddi≈øh of Caterich (younger Son of Reddi≈øh of Reddi≈øh in Lanca≈øhire) in Right of Margaret his Wife, Daughter and Co-heir of Thomas Boydell, by Partition made of all Thomas Boydell's Lands, 5 Hen. 5. Lib. C. fol. 282. I.

I≈øabell, the other Daughter and Co-heir of Thomas Boydell, married John Alburgham; who≈øe Son Gilbert had al≈øo two Daughters and Heirs; Con≈øtance Wife of Henry Byrom of Byrom in Lanca≈øhire, and I≈øabel Wife of James Holte, 3 Hen. 7.

The Part belonging to Reddi≈øh of Caterich, came to William Merbury of Merbury E≈øq in Right of Maud his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Thomas Reddi≈øh of Caterich in Gropenhale, Anno 1556. Lib. C. fol. 284. P. who≈øe Heirs have ever ≈øince enjoyed the ≈øame, to this pre≈øent, 1666.

In this Town≈øhip hath been anciently, and yet is, a Pari≈øh-Church Dedicated to St. Wilfrid, who≈øe Fea≈øt of Dedication was u≈øually Celebrated the twelfth day of October yearly; and hath onely two Town≈øhips in its Pari≈øh, to wit,‚Äî

I find Gropenhale Church was a Rectory in the Reign of Henry the Third, Lib. C. fol. 283. x. and had then the Boydells of Dodle≈øton for its Patron, who were Lords of Gropenhale and Lachford both: But now Byrom of Byrom in Lanca≈øhire hath the Advow≈øon hereof, 1666.

Sir William Boydell of Dodle≈øton built a Chappel in this Church, wherein William Boydell his Son and Heir ≈øwore to find an hone≈øt Chaplain to pray for the Souls of the ≈øaid Sir William and Nicolaa his Wife, for evermore, 8 Edw. 3. 1334. She was Daughter of William de Donca≈øter: Lib. C. fol. 285. d. e.

list.head: Charterers now in Gropenhale, 1666.
list.item: 1. John Middlehur≈øt.
2. William Morris of Gropenhale.
3. Richard Davys.
4. Thomas Blackborne of Lachford now hath got half of Davys's Land.

div.head: Hale.
div.p: THis Town≈øhip of Hale was held by Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy in the Conqueror's Time, as appears by Doom≈øday-book: So that it is anciently of the Fee of the Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.
In this Town were Seated the Ma≈ø≈øies of Hale anciently, who were propagated Originally out of the Ma≈ø≈øies of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy; which Family continued for many Ages, but is now extinct.

3 Hen. 4. there were fourteen Free-holders or Charterers in Hale: At this day, 1666. there are twenty three Free-holders. The Lord Delamere is now Chief Lord of the one Moiety of Hale; and John Crew of Crew, E≈øquire, is Chief Lord of the other Moiety.

Here is a Hamlet in Hale, called Ringey, wherein is ≈øituated a Chappel of Ea≈øe, called Ringey-Chappel, within the Pari≈øh of Bowdon; of which I have little to ≈øay, ≈øave that it was much frequented in the late War by Schi≈ømatical Mini≈øters, and, as it were, a Receptacle for Non-Conformi≈øts; in which di≈ø≈øolute Times, every Pragmatical Illiterate Per≈øon, as the Humor ≈øerved him, ≈øtepp'd into the Pulpit, without any Lawful Calling thereunto, or Licence of Authority.

div.head: Halton.
div.p: THis Town in common Pronunciation is called Hauton, and is as much as A Town upon a Hill; for Hawe and Howe is an old Engli≈øh word for A Hill: Howbeit, in our Norman way of Writing, it is u≈øually written Halton; in Doom≈øday-book it is written Heletune.

Here is yearly a Fair kept on the Fea≈øt of the Nativity of St. Mary, which is the eighth day of September, and hath been very anciently; for I find it mentioned in an Old Deed made towards the latter end of the Reign of Henry the Third: Lib. C. fol. 164. b.

It is now a poor Town or Village; and the Inhabitants, that have any Lands of Inheritance there, are all Copy-holders to the King, as Baron of Halton; ≈øave two ≈ømall Cottages now, 1666. in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of John Jack≈øon and Richard Jennings, which are of the Fee of St. John of Hieru≈øalem.

The Ca≈øtle was built by the Barons of Halton pre≈øently after the Norman Conque≈øt, and by degrees Repaired and Enlarged; who being Seated here, flouri≈øhed for a long time, and were Con≈øtables of Che≈øhire in Fee, that is, to them and their Heirs by De≈øcent; as it were, after the manner of Lord High Con≈øtables of England, ≈øo were the Barons of Halton to the Earls of Che≈øter; and in their Ancient Charters did always ≈øtile them≈øelves by the Title of [Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae] Con≈øtables of Che≈øhire; and were the Highe≈øt in Place and Dignity next to the Earl him≈øelf, and above all the other Barons of Che≈øhire.

In the Reign of Henry the Third their Po≈øterity became Earls of Lincoln: And upon the Death of Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln, 1310. all his Lands and Honors came to the Earl of Lanca≈øter with Alice his Daughter and Heir in Marriage: And at la≈øt Henry of Bolingbroke, Son of John of Gaunt Duke of Lanca≈øter, was ≈øo Great a Subject, and ≈øo Popular, that he drew unto his Part mo≈øt of the Nobility of England, and thereby mo≈øt Traiterou≈øly and Rebelliou≈øly Depo≈øed Richard the Second, and made him≈øelf King of England by the Name of Henry the Fourth.
So was the Barony of Halton annexed to the Crown.
All which will better appear by the following Hi≈øtory of the≈øe Eminent Barons of Halton, till this Barony came to the Crown.
In this Town of Halton was formerly a Chappel of Ea≈øe within the Pari≈øh of Runcorne, ≈øituated near to the Ca≈øtle, as I well remember the ≈øame, 1625. But it is now totally in decay, 1666.

div.head: Barons of Halton.
div.p: This Nigell, if we may believe Pecham in his Compleat Gentleman, pag. 189. was the Son of Ivo (Vice-Comes or Governor of Con≈øtantia in Normandy) by Emme Si≈øter to Adam Earl of Bretagne: Sed quaere.

Nigellus Vice-Comes Con≈øtantien≈øis in Normanni√¢ Coenobium Sancti Salvatoris con≈øtruxit: Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 950. b. He killed the Forces ≈øent into Normandy by King Ethelred, as they came on Shore out of their Ships, about the Year 1004. Willielmus Gemeticen≈øis, lib. 4. cap. 4. Quaere if of this Family.

The Office of Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire was an Office of e≈øpecial Tru≈øt, as in whom was repo≈øed the Charge and Di≈øpo≈øing of all the Soldiers, Hor≈øe, Armor, and other Provi≈øion for War, through the whole County: We now call the like Office Lord Lieutenant of Che≈øhire: And I do conceive that William, Son of this Nigell, was the fir≈øt that was made Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire.

Certain it is, This Nigell Baron of Halton had two Sons, William and Richard, as appears by the Charter of the Foundation of the Abby of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, by Hugh Lupus Vide ≈øupra, pag. 109. , 1093. and al≈øo the Charter of Confirmation to the ≈øaid Abby, by Earl Richard Vide pag. 117. , Anno 1119. Unto both which Charters the≈øe two Brothers are Witne≈ø≈øes.
II. William Son of Nigell was the ≈øecond Baron of Halton, and Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire.

Anno 1086. I find in Doom≈øday-book that this William held the≈øe Towns in Che≈øhire under Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, to wit,
In Ce≈øtre Hundred.
Newton,
Lee, one half.
Bruge, one half.
In Dude≈øtan Hundred.
Clutton.
In Ri≈øeton Hundred.
Barrow.
In Wilawe≈øton Hundred.
Ne≈øton, one half.
Rabie, one half.
Capeles, id e≈øt, Capenhur≈øt.
Berne≈øton.
blazon or coat of arms In Milde≈øt-vich Hundred.
Goo≈øtrey, one half.
Lache.
In Ham≈øtan Hundred.
Over-Alderley, one Half.
In Bucklow Hundred.
Warburton, one half.
Millington.
Knotsford.
Over-Tabley.
Nether-Pever, one half.
Tatton, one half.
In Tunendon Hundred.
Halton.
We≈øton.
A≈øton.
Norton.
Endley.
Dutton, a part only.
Little Legh.
A≈øton juxt√† Budworth.
Great Budworth.
Whitley.
This William Fitz-Nigell Founded a Priory at Runcorne, Anno Domini 1133. 33 Hen. 1. Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, 2 Pars, pag. 187.

He gave Newton near Che≈øter to the Mona≈øtery of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, together with the Service of Hugh Son of Hudard (that was Hugh de Dutton) of four Oxgangs of Land, and the Service of Wiceline of two Oxgangs, Anno 1119. Vide ≈øupra, pag. 117.

William Fitz-Nigell, Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, died about the end of Henry the Fir≈øt's Reign, and was Buried at Che≈øter. He had I≈ø≈øue William Con≈øtable junior; Agnes married Eu≈øtace Fitz-John, a Great Baron of the Realm; and Maud married Aubert de Grelley. Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, 2 Pars, pag. 798, 799. Lib. B. pag. 202. num. 18.
III. William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, junior, Son of William, was the third Baron of Halton.

He removed the Canons of Runcorn to Norton, as may appear by this Deed, which I found Copied out with many others belonging to Norton Priory, in a long Parchment Roll, of a very ancient Character, remaining among the Evidences of Dutton, 1665.

IN Nomine Patris, & Filii, & Spiritus Sancti, Amen. Ego Willielmus Con≈øtabularius Cestriae, Filius Willielmi Con≈øtabularii, Filii Nigelli, Do & Concedo Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Mariae de Norton, & Canonicis ibid√®m Deo Regularit√®r Servientibus, eandem Nortonam in Elemo≈øynam c√πm omnibus ad eam pertinentibus, in nemore, c√πm Fore≈øt√¢ & Warrenn√¢, in Plano, in Agris, in Pa≈øcuis, in Aquis. Et rogatu & Con≈øilio Rogeri Ce≈øtren≈øis Epi≈øcopi, & Con≈øilio hominum meorum, muto habitationem Canonicorum de Runcorn√¢ in Nortonam: Quam Nortonam do & concedo Canonicis in Elemo≈øynam & E≈øcambium trium Carucarum terrae in Stannings, & unius Carucatae & dimidii in A≈øtona; & in E≈øcambium totius Runcornae, praet√®r Eccle≈øiam & quatuor Bovatas terrae & unam Pi≈øcariam quae vocatur Pulceorpa, quae ad Eccle≈øiam ip≈øius Runcorne pertinet, quae Eccle≈øia praedictorum. Canonicorum e≈øt: Do eti√†m eis & concedo Molendinum de Halton√¢, & mediatatem omnium Pi≈øcariarum quae ad Haltonam pertinent: Communitatem eti√†m nemorum, Pa≈øcuorum, & Aquarum, ad Haltonam pertinentium, eis & hominibus ≈øuis concedo; & duas Bovatas terrae in Halton√¢ c√πm un√¢ Man≈øur√¢; & medietatem totius Pi≈øcariae meae de Thelwall, & unam Bovatam terrae ibid√®m c√πm Pi≈øcatore: Et duas Bovatas in Wydneis, c√πm Communitate nemorum & Pa≈øcuorum, quae ad Pultonam pertinent, ≈øibi & hominibus ≈øuis in Wydneis manentibus: Concedo & Communitatem nemorum & Pa≈øcuorum de Cuerdlei√¢, & Molendinum de Barrow, & duas partes Dominicarum Decimarum in e√¢dem Vill√¢; & duas partes Dominicarum Decimarum in Sutton√¢; & ≈øimilit√®r in Stanney, & in Rabie, & in Stanings; & unam Man≈øionem in Ce≈øtri√¢; & Eccle≈øiam de Buddewurth, & Eccle≈øiam de Duninton√¢, & Decimam Molendini
eju≈ødem Villae, & unam Carucatam terrae in Dominio in e√¢dem Vill√¢, & in ips√¢ Parochi√¢ Waver Toft, quod deputatur pro dimidi√¢ Carucat√¢ terrae, in Leyce≈øter≈øhiri√¢; & Ecle≈øiam de Radecliv√¢, & quartam partem Molendinorum, & decimas reliquarum trium partium in e√¢dem Vill√¢ & Eccle≈øiam de Cne≈øhall, & Decimam Molendinorum quae ad eandem Villam pertinent, quae ≈øunt juxt√† Sitellam; & Decimam Molendini de Alreton√¢: & Eccle≈øiam de Burton√¢ in Linde≈øei√¢; & Eccle≈øiam de Piriton√¢ in Oxenford≈øhir√¢ Omnia aut√®m, quae ab hominibus meis data ≈øunt, vel in po≈øter√πm danda ≈øunt, pro ≈øalute Animarum eorum concedo. Haec aut√®m feci Suggerente & Confirmante Rogero Ce≈øtren≈øi Epi≈øcopo, & Con≈øen≈øu Ranulfi Comitis Junioris, pro ≈øalute Hugonis Comitis, & Ricardi Comitis, & Ranulfi Comitis, & pro ≈øalute Animae meae & Uxoris meae, & pro ≈øalute Animae Patris mei & Matris meae, & Fratrum, & Sororum, & omnium Antece≈ø≈øorum meorum & Succe≈ø≈øorum. Hanc aut√®m Elemo≈øynam it√† ab omnibus Servitiis & Con≈øuetudinibus, placitis & querelis, liberam & ≈øolutam concedo, ≈øic√πt ulla Elemo≈øyna liberior & ≈øolutior concedi debet vel pote≈øt: Quicunque ver√≤ hanc Elemo≈øynam adauxerit vel manutenuerit, per Participationem illius Eccle≈øiae Beneficiorum con≈øequatur Regna Coelorum: Qui vero hanc in aliquo violaverit, vel infringere tentaverit, c√πm Jud√¢ & Pilato, c√πm Dathan & Abyron, in inferno puniatur, n≈øi ad emendationem venerit. Te≈øtibus Willielmo Capellano, Rogero de Angervill√¢, Alfredo Humfridi Filio, Nigello An≈øgoti Filio, Roberto Petri Filio.‚ÄîLib. B. pag. 199. num. 1.
This was made in the Reign of King Stephen.

He gave al≈øo half of Raby in Wirrall to the Abby of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, as Su≈øtenance anciently given thereunto by his Father: Certum n√°mque e≈øt (≈øo run the Words of the Deed) quod Pater meus Willielmus Con≈øtabularius dedit dimidium de Raby, quod erat in Feodo ≈øuo, Domino Abbati Ricardo, & Eccle≈øiae, pro terti√¢ parte de Ne≈øton, quae erat antiquit√πs Prebenda Sanctae Werburgae.

This William is ≈øtiled Nepos Walteri de Gant: Mona≈øt. 1 Pars, pag. 143. and his Si≈øter Agnes ≈øtiled Agnes de Gant: Lib. C. in the Paper before fol. 84. By which it may ≈øeem, that William Son of Nigell married a Si≈øter of Walter de Gant, and Daughter of Gilbert.
This William Con≈øtable junior died in Normandy, in the Reign of King Stephen, without I≈ø≈øue; and ≈øo his Inheritance was divided and ≈øhared between his two Si≈øters and Heirs. Lib. C. fol. 85. b.
His Seal had the Impre≈ø≈øion of a Griffin, with a Serpent or Snake ≈øucking at the Brea≈øt of the Griffin.

IV. Eu≈øtace Fitz-John, in Right of Agnes his Wife, was the fourth Baron of Halton; to whom Randle the Second, ≈øir-named Gernouns, Earl of Che≈øter, re≈øtored totum Honorem qui fuit Willielmi Filii Nigelli Con≈øtabularii Ce≈øtriae, in Rebus & Dignitatibus omnibus; & ip≈øum Eu≈øtachium con≈øtitui≈ø≈øe haereditari√® Con≈øtabularium, & Supremum Con≈øiliarium po≈øt me ≈øup√®r omnes Optimates & Barones totius terrae meae: Ea-propt√®r volo & firmit√®r praecipio, de≈øic√πt ei rectum ≈øuum reddidi, & donavi & conce≈ø≈øi Con≈øtabulariam, & honorem integrum Con≈øtabulariae Ce≈øtriae & totius terrae meae, qu√≤d in omnibus ei rationabilit√®r intendatis ≈øicut Corpori meo; as the very words of the Charter, made in the Reign of King Stephen, do run: The Original hereof, Selden in his Titles of Honor, pag. 688. tells us he hath ≈øeen, remaining (as I conceive) in Cotton's Library at We≈øtmin≈øter in London. It is al≈øo upon Record in one of the Couchir Books in the Dutchy Office at Grays-Inn, London, Tom. 1. fol. 41. a. Comitatus Cestriae, num. 2. which I have tran≈øcribed at large in this Book ≈øupr√†, Pars 3. pag. 160.

This Eu≈øtace was Son of John Monoculus, ≈øo called becau≈øe he had but one Eye; which makes Hoveden to call Eu≈øtace, Lu≈øcus & Proditor nequam, A wicked Traitor with one Eye; becau≈øe his Father had but one Eye, p. 483. where he tells us, That this Eu≈øtace defended the Ca≈øtle of Malton in York≈øhire again≈øt King Stephen, Anno 1137. 2 Steph.

Johannes Monoculus was Brother to Serlo de Burgo ≈øiv√® de Pembroke. This Serlo built Knaresburough Ca≈øtle in York≈øhire; who dying without I≈ø≈øue, his Inheritance de≈øcended to this Eu≈øtace Fitz-John: Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, 2 Pars, pag. 801. Johannes Monoculus and Serlo were both Sons of Eu≈øtace a Norman.

Eu≈øtace Fitz-John, and Nephew and Heir to Serlo, had two Wifes: Beatrix ≈øole
Daughter and Heir of Ivo de Ve≈øcy was the fir≈øt Wife of Eu≈øtace, by whom he had the Baronies of Malton and Alnwick, and by her had I≈ø≈øue William de Ve≈øcy, who a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name and Arms of Ve≈øcy, which his Po≈øterity retained: Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 801.

Agnes, Si≈øter and Co-heir to William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire the younger, was ≈øecond Wife of Eu≈øtace Fitz-John; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Richard Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire: Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 799. Which Agnes, with Eu≈øtace her Husband, Founded a Nunnery at Watton in York≈øhire. Ibid. pag. 798, 799.

Eu≈øtace Fitz-John (≈øaith Pecham in his Compleat Gentleman, pag. 189.) by the con≈øent of Agnes his fir≈øt Wife Founded the Mona≈øtery of Watton in York≈øhire; and by the Con≈øent of Beatrix his ≈øecond Wife Founded the Abbies of Malton and Alnwick, and the Ho≈øpital of Broughton: Where he calls Agnes fir≈øt Wife of Eu≈øtace, contrary to Cambden in his Britanni√¢, pag. 588. in York≈øhire; and to Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 801. where Agnes is ≈øaid to be the ≈øecond Wife, and ≈øo probably ≈øhe was.

Obiit 1157 This Eu≈øtace Fitz-John was ≈ølain in Battel again≈øt the Wel≈øh, together with Robert Curcy, and many others, 3 Hen. 2. 1157. Stow in his Annals. And VVillielmus Neubrigen≈øis, lib. 2. cap. 5. pag. 100. ≈øpeaking of this Battel with the VVel≈øh, ≈øaith,‚ÄîIbique Eu≈øtachius Johannis Filius, Vir Magnus & Grandaevus, atqu√® inter Primos Angliae Proceres divitiarum & Sapientiae titulis refulgens, c√πm Roberto de Curcy aequ√® Nobili Viro alii≈øque pluribus interiit.
V. Richard Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Son of Eu≈øtace and Agnes, ≈øucceeded his Father in the Barony of Halton.
In the beginning of the Reign of Henry the Second he held one Knights Fee in Smathe in the County of York: Ex Libro Rubro Scaccarii VVe≈øtmona≈øterien≈øis.

He married Albreda, or Awbrey, Daughter and Heir of Robert de Lizours, and Si≈øter by the Mother, id e≈øt, Half Si≈øter, to Robert Lacy Baron of Pomfret Ca≈øtle in York≈øhire, commonly call'd Pontefract, who made her his Heir al≈øo, becau≈øe he had no other ≈øo near allied unto him: In who≈øe Right her Po≈øterity enjoy'd ≈øexaginta Feoda Militum, ≈øixty Knights Fees, of the Honor of Pomfret: und√® illa, po≈øt Roberti de Lacy mortem, utr√°mque Hereditatem, Fraternam de Lacy, & Paternam de Lizours occupavit. The≈øe are the Words of the Book of Stanlaw Mona≈øtery, ≈øaith Cambden in his Britannia, pag. 566. of the la≈øt Edition, Printed 1607.

And here I cannot pa≈øs by the mi≈øtake of Pecham in the Place before cited, where he calls this Aubrey Daughter of Eudo de Lizours, when I find her Fathers Name plainly recorded to be Robert de Lizours, in a Fine levied at VVinche≈øter 21 die Aprilis, 5 Rich. 1. 1194. Couchir Book in the Dutchy Office at Grays Inn, Tom. 2. pag. 110. Honor ≈øiv√® Soca de Bolingbroke, num. 1. Of which Fine I ≈øhall have occa≈øion to ≈øpeak more fully, when I come to Roger Lacy the ≈øeventh Baron of Halton. See al≈øo Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, 2 Pars, pag. 188. line√¢ 18. a.

Richard Fitz-Eustace had I≈ø≈øue by Aubrey his Wife John, who ≈øucceeded Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire; Robert the Ho≈øpitaller, id e≈øt, of the Ho≈øpital of St. John of Hieru≈øalem in England, the Grand Priory being at Jeru≈øalem; Mary Alii hic Saram legunt: Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, p 188. ≈øed perperam ut opinor. married Robert de Aldford; and Awbrey married to Henry By≈ø≈øet: Lib. C. fol. 85. b. & le Paper ant√®, fol. 66. c.

Pecham tells us of another Son, called Roger, Lord of VVarkworth in Northumberland, from whom are de≈øcended the ancient Barons of Clavering, the Baron Evers, and Sir John Clavering of Caloley in Northumberland: But quaere of this Roger, whether he were the Son of this Richard Fitz-Eu≈øtace; I find another Family called Con≈øtables, de≈øcended from the Con≈øtables of Glocester; and that Milo Con≈øtable had I≈ø≈øue Roger, Henry, VValter, Matthew, and VVilliam. Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 66. Sed quaere.
Richard Fitz-Eu≈øtace was dead before 24 Hen. 2. 1178. but I find not the preci≈øe Year when he died.
Aubrey his Widow afterwards married VVilliam Fitz-VVilliams, and had I≈ø≈øue VVilliam: Mona≈øticon, 1 Pars, pag. 831. & Lib. C. fol. 64. g.
VI. John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Son and Heir of Richard and Awbrey, ≈øucceeded his Father, and was the ≈øixth Baron of Halton.
He Founded the Abby of Stanlaw in VVirral in Che≈øhire, Anno Domini 1178. 24 Hen. 2. in the≈øe words.‚Äî

q.p: UNiver≈øis Sanctae Matris Eccle≈øiae Filiis,‚ÄîJohannes Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae Salutem. Sciatis me dedi≈ø≈øe & h√¢c prae≈øenti Chart√¢ me√¢ confirm√¢≈ø≈øe Deo, & Sanctae Mariae, & Abbati atque Monachis de Stanlawe, ad con≈øtruendam Abbathiam Ordinis Ci≈øtercien≈øis, ip≈øum locum Stanlawe; quem, mutato nomine, benedictum locum vocari volumus: & Villam unam, quae vocatur Stanney; & alteram Villam, quae vocatur Maurice-A≈øton; c√πm omnibus pertinentiis‚Äîliberas & quietas ab omni terreno Servitio, & Seculari exactione, pro ≈øalute Animae meae, & Patris mei, & Matris meae, & Uxoris meae, & omnium Antece≈ø≈øorum & Haeredum meorum, in puram & perpetuam Elemo≈øynam. Conce≈ø≈øi quoqu√® eis in perpetuam Elemo≈øynam quietantiam Tolnei, in emptione & venditione omnium rerum ≈øuarum per totam terram meam; necn√≤n & quietantiam Tolnei de proprio Blado ≈øuo in Molendinis meis: Dedi eti√†m eis Me≈ø≈øuagium unum in Vill√¢ Ce≈øtriae, c√πm omnibus Aedificiis ≈øuis, quod habui juxt√† Eccle≈øiam Sancti Michaelis‚Äî&c. Et quand√≤ ego & Haeredes mei voluerimus, in Domo praenominat√¢ Placita no≈øtra tenebimus, & ad expen≈øas no≈øtras ho≈øpitabimus‚Äî Anno ab Incarnatione Domini 1178. Hujus aut√®m Donationis te≈øtes ≈øunt i≈øti, Robertus Decanus de Donington, Nicolaus Par≈øona de Marnaham, Radulfus Sacerdos de Sallowe, Simon Sacerdos de E≈øton; Gregorius Sacerdos de Ca≈øtello, Galfridus Monachus de Parco, Simon Monachus de Combermere, Henricus By≈ø≈øet, Johannes de Danvill√¢, Martinus Angevinus, Hugo de Dutton, Johannes Filius Thur≈øtani,‚Äî&c. Lib. C. fol. 62. a. Al≈øo Witne≈ø≈øes Ricardus Fitton, Willielmus Filius Ricardi, Robertus Venator, Adam de Dutton, Hugo ejus Frater,‚Äî&c. Apud Dodyngton.

div.p: This Abby was after Tran≈ølated to Whalley in Lanca≈øhire, 1296.

This John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire gave all Hield in A≈øton nigh Great Budworth to Methro≈øo Punterling; rendring a Wel≈øh Lance yearly on St. Bartholomew's day, M. num. 1. which at this day belongs to Leyce≈øter of Tabley.

He married Alice Si≈øter of William Mandevyle, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Roger Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, who a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Lacy; Eu≈øtace ≈øir-named De Ce≈øter, Richard de Ce≈øter, to whom his Brother Roger gave the Town of Moore in Che≈øhire; and after Richard became a Leper, and was buried at Norton: Geffrey, another Son; Peter, another Son; Alice, a Daughter: Lib. C. fol. 85. b. & fol. 62. b. c. d.

Anno Domini 1181. John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and Richard Peche [Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfield] were appointed Governors of Ireland, and ≈øent to keep Dublin, which Hugh de Lacy kept: For Hugh de Lacy was ≈øent for into England by King Henry the Second, with whom the King was much di≈øplea≈øed, becau≈øe he had married the Daughter of the King of Connaught without the Licence of Henry the Second: Hoveden, pag. 611. Al≈øo Giraldus and Hollin≈øhed.

This John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire had a Clerk called William, an excellent A≈øtrologer, who in the Year 1186. writ of the Conjunction of the Planets that Year; who≈øe Words and Opinion thereon, you may read in Hoveden, pag. 624.

John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire died at Tyre in the Land of Jeru≈øalem,
Obiit 1190 Anno Dom. 1190. 2 Rich. 1. Hoveden, pag. 685.
VII. Roger Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Son and Heir of John, ≈øucceeded his Father, and was the Seventh Baron of Halton: He was ≈øir-named Hell, for his fierce and magnanimous Spirit.

He is the fir≈øt of the Barons of Halton who a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Lacy; which Name he retained after the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of Robert Lacy of Pomfret Ca≈øtle in York≈øhire accrewed to him; which Robert Lacy died Anno Domini 1194. and in the Year following a Fine was Levied at Winche≈øter between this Roger Con≈øtable, and Awbrey his
Grandmother, wherein ≈øhe ≈øettles on him the great Inheritance which belonged to Robert Lacy, in the≈øe words.‚Äî

q.p:
5 Rich. 1. 1194. Haec e≈øt finalis Concordia facta in Curi√¢ Domini Regis apud Wintonam, 21 die Aprilis, Anno Regni Domini Regis Ricardi Quinto, cor√†m Domino Rege, & Huberto Cantuarien≈øi Archiepi≈øcopo, Willielmo Elien≈øi Epi≈øcopo, Domini Regis Cancellario, Hugone Dunelmen≈øi, G. Roffen≈øi Epi≈øcopis, Willielmo de Sanctae Mariae Eccle≈øi√¢, Ranulpho Comite Ce≈øtriae, Comite R. le Bigot, Willielmo Mare≈øchallo, Gaufrido Filio Petri, Hugone Bard, & aliis fidelibus Domini Regis qui t√πnc ibi aderant: Inter Albreiam de Li≈øores, & Rogerum Con≈øtabularium Ce≈øtriae, Nepotem
Nepos here ≈øignifies a Grand≈øon, as properly the Word ought; but very frequently in old Deeds it is u≈øed for a Nephew. ≈øuum, de tot√¢ Terr√¢ quae fuit Roberti de La≈øci: Und√® placitum fuit int√®r eos in Curi√¢ Domini Regis, ≈øcilic√®t qu√≤d praedicta Albreia, & Haeredes ≈øui, quietum clamaverunt praedicto Rogero & Haeredibus ≈øuis totam praenominatam terram quae fuit Roberti de La≈øcy: Et praedictus Rogerus conce≈ø≈øit praedictae Albred, qu√≤d teneat totam Terram quae fuit Roberti de Li≈øores Patris ip≈øius Albred ≈øin√® aliquo retenemento tot√¢ vit√¢ ≈øu√¢, ben√® & in pace, per ≈øervitium quod ad illam Terram pertinet; ≈øcilic√®t, Servitium Feodorum octo Militum: Et po≈øt dece≈ø≈øum ≈øuum, Willielmus Filius praefatae Albred (He was Son of Awbrey by William Fitz-Williams) & Haeredes ≈øui Terram illam tenebunt liber√® & quiet√® per praedictum Servitium de praedicto Rogero, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, in Feodo & Haereditate: Praetere√† praefatus Rogerus dedit praedictae Albred viginti Libratas Terrae in Bardinton, quas ip≈øa Albred tot√¢ vit√¢ ≈øu√¢ tenebit quietas ab omni Servitio; & po≈øt dece≈ø≈øum ≈øuum, Willielmus Filius ≈øuus & Haeredes ≈øui eandem terram tenebunt de praedicto Rogero & Haeredibus ≈øuis in Feodo & Haereditate, per Servitium Feodi unius Militis: Et pro Conce≈ø≈øione harum viginti Libratarum Terrae, praedicta Albred continu√≤ deliberavit & quietam clamavit praedicto Rogero Villam de Hauton in Linde≈øei√¢, c√πm omnibus pertinentis ≈øuis, quam in Dotem tenuerat. Couchir-Book in the Dutchy-Office at Grays-Inn, Tom. 2. Honor ≈øiv√® Soca de Bolingbroke, num. 1 pag. 110. Lib. C. fol. 64. g.

div.p: This Roger is ranked by Hoveden, pag. 783. as the mo≈øt eminent Baron of the Realm, and next after the Earls, among tho≈øe Great Per≈øons whom King John mo≈øt doubted, and required to ≈øwear Fealty to him by his Commi≈ø≈øioners, Anno Domini 1199. upon the death of Richard the Fir≈øt; which they did upon Condition that every of them ≈øhould have their Lands re≈øtored.
And the King re≈øtored unto Roger Lacy his Ca≈øtle of Pomfret, having fir≈øt received his Son and Heir for a Pledge: Hoveden, pag. 794. put out with other Authors by Sir Henry Savil, 1601.

He was one of tho≈øe whom King John employed for the Safe Conduct of the King of Scotland unto the Court of England, when the King of Scotland did Homage to the King of England at Lincoln, pre≈øently after the Coronation of King John, ≈øub Anno Domini 1200. Hoveden, pag. 811. And Roger Lacy is there again put down the fir≈øt of all the Barons of England, who were Witne≈ø≈øes of the King of Scotland ‚ñ™s Homage; and where the Chief of the Nobility are named by Hoveden.

Anno Domini 1201. King John ≈øent before-hand William Mar≈øhall Earl of Strigvill, c√πm centum militibus Soldariis; and Roger Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, c√πm aliis centum militibus Soldariis, into Normandy, for the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of his Enemies. Hoveden, p. 819.
Milites Soldarii, id e≈øt, Stipendarii, Stipendio retenti: So Spelman.

Anno 1204. Roger Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Vir magnificus & bellico≈øus, a mo≈øt Heroique and Magnanimous Champion, kept the Ca≈øtle de Rupe Andeliaci in Normandy, for King John, again≈øt the French, with ≈øuch Gallantry, that after all his Victuals were ≈øpent, having been Be≈øieged almo≈øt a Year, and many A≈ø≈øaults of the Enemy made, but ≈øtill repul≈øed by him, he mounts his Hor≈øe, and i≈ø≈øues out of the Ca≈øtle with his Troop into the mid≈øt of his Enemies Forces, chu≈øing rather to die like a Soldier, than to be ≈øtarved to death: He ≈ølew many of the Enemy, but was at la≈øt with much difficulty taken Pri≈øoner: So he and his Soldiers were brought Pri≈øoners to the King of France, where, by the Command of the King, Roger Lacy was to be no ≈øtrict Pri≈øoner Sub libera cu≈øtodia detentus e≈øt, ≈øaith Paris; meaning (as I conceive) had liberty to go up and down at his Plea≈øure, on his Paroll or Word., for his great Hone≈øty and Tru≈øt in keeping the Ca≈øtle ≈øo gallantly. Mat. Paris, put out by Dr. Wats, pag. 211.
King John's Letter to Roger Lacy, concerning the keeping of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, you may ≈øee among the Norman Writers put out by Andrew du Che≈øne, and Printed at Paris 1619. pag. 1059.

One other notable Exploit of this Roger Lacy I find mentioned in the Ancient Roll of the Barons of Halton: When Randle Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øir-named Blundevill, Mona≈øticon, ‚Ä¢ Pars p 188. was Be≈øieged in Rothelent Ca≈øtle in Flint≈øhire by the Wel≈øh, this Roger gathers a tumultuous Rout of loo≈øe and di≈ø≈øolute Per≈øons, Players, Min≈øtrels, Shoe-makers, and the like, and marched ≈øpeedily towards the Enemy. The Wel≈øh ≈øeeing a great Multitude coming, rai≈øed their Siege and fled. The Earl thus delivered, confers the Authority over all the loo≈øe idle Per≈øons in Che≈øhire upon his Con≈øtable: And John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Son of the ≈øaid Roger, confers the Authority and Rule over all the Letchers and Whores in Che≈øhire on Hugh Dutton of Dutton, as freely as he held the ≈øame of the Earl; ≈øaving the Right of the ≈øaid John to him and his Heirs. See the Deed it ≈øelf Tran≈øcribed ≈øupr√†, Pars 2. pag. 142.

Roger Lacy purcha≈øed from Robert Bu≈øhell the Barony of Penwortham in Lanca≈øhire, to hold of John King of England, and his Heirs, in Capite; for which he acquitted the ≈øaid Robert Bu≈øhell of 310 Marks of Silver to King John. Couchir-Book in the Dutchy-Office at Grays-Inn, Tom. 1. fol. 79. b. Com. Lanca≈øtriae, num. 78.

This Roger gave the Church of Rochdale in Lanca≈øhire, which belonged to the Honor of Pomfret, unto the Abby of Stanlaw: Lib. C. fol. 61. h. and al≈øo the Town of Little Wolneton: Lib. C. fol. 62. c. & in Principio, fol. 12. d.

He gave al≈øo his Moiety of Nether Pever c√πm Little Pever, which belonged to the Fee of Halton, unto Osbert de VVethale, rendring to him and his Heirs the yearly Rent of 6 s. 8 d. and by doing Foreign Service as much as belongeth to the twentieth part of a Knights Fee: The Original in my po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; and which Rent of 6 s. 8 d. is at this day, 1666. paid to Halton by Leyce≈øter of Tabley for the ≈øame moiety.

Roger Lacy married Maud de Clare, Lib. C. fol. 70. a. The Original Pen√®s Towneley of Carre in Lanca≈øhire, June 24. 1657. and had I≈ø≈øue John Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, afterwards Earl of Lincoln.

Pecham in his Compleat Gentleman, pag. 190. tells us of another Son of Roger, called Robert Con≈øtable of Flamborough in York≈øhire, who≈øe Po≈øterity a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Con≈øtable: From which Robert in a direct Line are de≈øcended Sir VVilliam Con≈øtable of Flamborough, Sir Philip Con≈øtable of Everingham, Chri≈øtopher Con≈øtable of Hatfield E≈øquire, James Con≈øtable of Cliffe E≈øquire, John Con≈øtable of Carthrop E≈øquire, Marmaduke Con≈øtable of Kirby E≈øquire, ‚ÄîCon≈øtable of VVa≈ø≈øam E≈øquire, Sir John Con≈øtable of Dromandby, with many others then living, 1622.

I find mention indeed of Robert Con≈øtable of Flamborough, called al≈øo Robert Son of the Con≈øtable to the Earl of Che≈øter; Mona≈øticon Anglicanum, 2 Pars, pag. 799. But whether Son of Roger, is not manife≈øt to me; but mu≈øt leave it to Pecham's Authority.

Nor can I here pa≈øs by the mi≈øtake of the ancient Roll of the Barons of Halton: ‚öú Lib. C. fol. 84, 85, Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 187. and ≈øeveral other old Manu≈øcripts there be of the ≈øame: In all which this Maud de Clare, Wife of Roger Lacy, is ≈øaid to be Si≈øter of the Trea≈øurer of York Min≈øter: Now Bevoys de Clare Trea≈øurer of York Min≈øter had no Si≈øter called Maud; for all the Si≈øters are punctually reckoned up in the Book of Tewk≈øbery, as you may find them copied out by Vincent in his Corrections of Brook's Catalogue of Nobility, pag. 221. whereby it appears plainly, that tho≈øe Si≈øters al≈øo were all born after the death of Roger Lacy. Po≈ø≈øibly in the old Roll there may be an omi≈ø≈øion of a Word; as where it is ≈øaid,‚ÄîSororem The≈øaurarii Eboracen≈øis Eccle≈øiae, for Sororem Patris The≈øaurarii Eboracen≈øis Eccle≈øiae; or ≈øome other Word. Quaere.

Anno Domini 1211. 13 Johannis Regis,
Obiit 1211 vir Nobilis & Miles egregius Rogerus Ce≈øtriae Con≈øtabularius vitam finivit: Mat. Paris, put out by Wats, pag. 230.

Anno 1211. obiit Rogerus de Lacy, in Fe≈øto Sancti Remigii (which is the fir≈øt day of October) cui ≈øucce≈ø≈øit Johannes Filius ejus, po≈øte√† Comes Lincolniae per Uxorem ≈øuam: Manu≈øcript in Oxford Library, among the Books given by William Laud Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, noted G. 9. fol. 125. b.
He was one of tho≈øe Great Per≈øons of England whom Pope Innocent the Third Excommunicated for Con≈øpiring again≈øt King John, Anno Dom. 1216. Mat. Paris, pag. 277. See al≈øo pag. 262.

Anno Domini 1218. there came to the Siege of Damiata, a City in Egypt, many Strangers out of divers Parts of the World.‚Äî Out of England came the Illu≈øtrious Randle Earl of Che≈øter, with Saher Earl of Winche≈øter, and William Earl of Arundel, and the Barons Robert Fitz-Walter, John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, William de Harecourt, with much Company. Idem Paris, pag. 303.
This John had two Wifes. The fir≈øt was Alice Daughter to Gilbert de Aquila: She was Buried at Norton Abby.
Afterwards he married Margaret Daughter and Heir, or Co-heir at lea≈øt, to Robert de Quency, elde≈øt Son of Saher de Quency Earl of Winche≈øter.

This Saher de Quency Earl of Winche≈øter was Lord of Groby in Leyce≈øter≈øhire, and died Anno Domini 1220. as Mat. Paris ≈øaith. He married Margaret younger Si≈øter and Co-heir to the fourth Robert Earl of Leyce≈øter, called Robert Fitz-Parnell, and had I≈ø≈øue Robert Quency, elde≈øt Son, who married Hawys fourth Si≈øter and Co-heir to Randle ≈øir-named Blundevill, Earl of Che≈øter and Lincoln, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Margaret, married to John Lacy afore≈øaid; Roger de Quency, ≈øecond Son of Saher, who ≈øucceeded his Father in the Earldom of Winche≈øter; Lib. C. fol. 67 a and another Robert de Quency, third Son, who married Hellen the Widow of John the Scot Earl of Che≈øter; which Robert died Anno Domini 1257. 41 Hen. 3. in a Torneament at Blie: So Mat. Paris. Al≈øo Hawys, Daughter of Saher de Quency, married Hugh de Vere Earl of Oxford; and Orabella, another Daughter of Saher, married Richard Son of William Harecourt, with whom her Father gave Bo≈øworth in Leycester≈øhire in Marriage: Burton's Antiquities of Leyce≈øter≈øhire, p. 47. This was Harecourt of Stanton-Harecourt in Oxford≈øhire.

Hawys the Widow of Robert de Quency elde≈øt Son of Saher (which Robert died in the Life-time of Saher his Father) had the Earldom of Lincoln given unto her by her Brother Randle Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øcilic√®t, quantum ad me pertinuit, ut ind√® Comiti≈ø≈øa exi≈øtat, as the Words of the Deed do run. This was not long before Randle's death, who died at Wallingford 26 die Octobris, Anno Domini 1232. 17 Hen. 3. Vincent upon Brook, pag. 317.
And King Henry the Third, by Patent dated at Northampton, 23 die Novembris, Anno Regni ≈øui 17. 1232. granted the Earldom of Lincoln to John Lacy, in the≈øe words.‚Äî

q.p: HENRICUS Dei Grati√¢ Rex Angliae, Dominus Hiberniae, Dux Normanniae & Aquitaniae, Comes Andegaviae: Omnibus ad quos prae≈øentes Literae pervenerint, Salutem. Sciatis, Qu√≤d ad in≈øtantiam Hawi≈øiae de Quency dedimus & conce≈ø≈øimus dilecto & fideli no≈øtro Johanni de La≈øcy Con≈øtabulario Ce≈øtriae, illas viginti Libras, quas Ranulphus quond√†m Comes Ce≈øtriae & Lincolniae recepit pro tertio Denario Comitatus Lincolniae, nomine Comitis Lincolniae; & quas praedictus Comes in vit√¢ ≈øu√¢ dedit praedictae Hawi≈øiae Sorori ≈øuae: Habendas & Tenendas, nomine Comitis Lincolniae, de nobis & Haeredibus no≈øtris, ip≈øi Johanni, & Haeredibus ≈øuis qui exibunt de Margaret√¢ Uxore ≈øu√¢ Fili√¢ praedictae Hawi≈øiae in perpetuum. Et in hujus rei Te≈øtimonium has Literas no≈øtras Patentes ei fieri fecimus. Te≈øte meip≈øo apud Northampton, 23 die Novembris, Anno Regni no≈øtri decimo ≈øeptimo. Couchir-Cook in the Dutchy-Office at Grays-Inn, ≈øcilicet Tom. 2. Honor ≈øiv√® Soca de Bolingbroke, num. 10. pag. 500. Lib. C. fol. 66. w.

div.p: Thus was John Lacy in Right of his Wife made Earl of Lincoln.

Some Competition there was by this John concerning the Inheritance of Saher de Quency Earl of Winche≈øter, and al≈øo of the Inheritance belonging to Margaret his Counte≈øs: For Saher had by Deed formerly Covenanted with Robert his Son and Heir, qu√≤d infantes ≈øui, qui procreabuntur ab ip≈øo & Hawi≈øi√¢ de Ce≈øtri√¢ Uxore ≈øu√¢, Haeredes ≈øint totius Haereditatis dicti Saheri & Haereditatis Uxoris ≈øuae Comiti≈ø≈øae Margaretae; & hoc legaliter tenendum affidavit. The Original in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Simon Dewes Baronet, 1647. Lib. C. Paper ant√® fol. 66.
But how Roger de Quency and John Lacy were agreed, appears by this Fine following, 14 Hen. 3. 1230.‚Äî

q.p: Haec e≈øt finalis Concordia facta in Curi√¢ Domini Regis apud We≈øtmona≈øterium in Octabis Sancti Michaelis, Anno Regni Regis Henrici Filii Regis Johannis quarto decimo, cor√†m Thom√¢ de Mulet, Willielmo de Ralegh, Roberto de Lexington, Willielmo de In≈øul√¢, Willielmo de London, Magi≈øtro Roberto de Sherdelawe, Ju≈øticiariis, & aliis Domini Regis Fidelibus t√πnc ibid√®m prae≈øentibus: Inter Rogerum de Quency Querentem, & Johannem de La≈øcy Con≈øtabularium Ce≈øtriae, & Margaretam Uxorem ejus, Deforciantes, de Haereditate Saheri de Quency Comitis quond√†m Wintoniae, in Kotela≈øtan, Chennoure, Sudho, Aymbirye, Bukby, Gran≈øete, Hardwyk, & Bradenham, c√πm pertinentiis; & de Haereditate Margaretae de Quency Comiti≈ø≈øae Wintoniae, ≈øcilic√®t de medietate Honoris Leyce≈øtriae: Und√® Placitum Conventionis ≈øummonitum fuit int√®r eos in e√¢dem Curi√¢, ≈øcilic√®t qu√≤d praedicti Johannes & Margareta recognoverunt omnes praedictas Terras, & praedictam medietatem Honoris Leyce≈øtriae, c√πm pertinentiis, & totam Haereditatem ip≈øius Saheri in Angli√¢, Scoti√¢, Flandri√¢, & Normannia, & totam Haereditatem ip≈øius Margaretae Comiti≈ø≈øae Wintoniae in Anglia & Normannia, e≈ø≈øe jus ip≈øius Rogeri: Et pro hac Recognitione, Fine, & Concordia, Idem Rogerus dedit & conce≈ø≈øit praedictis Johanni & Margaretae Mannerium de King≈øton, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis in Comitatu Dor≈øetiae, & ≈øimilit√®r totam Terram c√πm pertinentiis, quam Loretta quond√†m Comiti≈ø≈øa Leyce≈øtriae aliquand√≤ tenuit nomine Dotis in Wymburne, Blaneford, c√πm tota Fore≈øta & Chaceis de Wimburn-Holt, & c√πm omnibus Bo≈øcis & Warrennis de King≈øton, ‚ÄîExcepto Tenemento quod Nicolaus de Wilelegh tenuit: praetere√† idem Rogerus recognovit & conce≈ø≈øit praedictis Johanni & Margaretae, Maneria de Bradeham, de Gran≈øet, de Bukby, & de Hardewyck, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis, ≈øicut Hawi≈øia (quae fuit Uxor Roberti de Quency) ea tenuit in Dote; & Homagium & totum Servitium Matthaei Tinfin, & Haeredum ≈øuorum, de Feodo unius Militis c√πm pertinentiis in Winterflawe in Comitatu Wilt≈øhire: Habendum & Tenendum ei≈ødem Johanni & Margaretae, & Haeredibus de Corpore ip≈øius Margaretae procreatis, de praedicto Rogero & Haeredibus ≈øuis, Faciendo ind√® Servitium quinque Militum pro omni Servitio & Exactione:‚ÄîEt ≈øciendum e≈øt, qu√≤d ≈øi praedicta Margaretae ≈øin√® Haerede de Corpore ≈øuo procreato dece≈ø≈øerit, omnes praedictae Terrae c√πm pertinentiis redibunt ip≈øi Rogero & Haeredibus ≈øuis ≈øin√® ullo retenemento: Salvis praedicto Johanni Con≈øtabulario omnibus praedictis Terris c√πm pertinentiis tenendis tota vita ≈øua: Couchir-Book in the Dutchy-Office, Tom. 2. Comitatus Dor≈øet. num. 10. Lib. C. fol. 66. x.

div.p:
Henry the Third gave to this John Lacy the Manors of Colingham and Berd≈øey, und√® Abbas de Kirk≈øtall nobis reddidit per Annum 90 Libras de firma, don√®c ei dederimus rationabile E≈øcambium ad Valentiam eorundem Manneriorum in E≈øcaetis vel Wardis‚ÄîDatum apud Aurebel, 17 die Julii, 14 Hen. 3. Ibid√®m Tom. 2. Honor ≈øiv√® Soca de Bolingbroke,
fol. 22. num. 46.

Anno Domini 1233. 18 Hen. 3. John Scot Earl of Che≈øter, and John Lacy Earl of Lincoln, were by Peter Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, for the Bribe of a thou≈øand Marks, drawn to the Kings Party; who before were Confederat with Richard Earl-Mar≈øhal again≈øt the King. Mat. Paris.

About the ≈øame Year 1233. John ≈øir-named The Scot, Earl of Che≈øter and Huntingdon, gave to John Lacy Earl of Lincoln, and Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, ten Knights Fees in England, illa ≈øcilic√®t quae de me tenuit, & Antece≈ø≈øores ≈øui de Antece≈ø≈øoribus meis tenuerunt, (This was the Service for the Ancient Barony of Halton in Che≈øhire.) for the Service
of half a Knights Fee, to be done by him and his Heirs, for all Service to the ≈øaid John Scot and his Heirs. Te≈øtibus Domino Henrico de Audidelegh, Domino Willielmo de Cantilupo, Domino Ricardo Phiton t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, &c. Couchir-Book in the Dutchy-Office, Tom. 1. fol. 49. a. Comitatus Ce≈øtriae, num. 24. Lib. C. fol. 65. s.

John Lacy had I≈ø≈øue by Margaret his ≈øecond Wife, Edmund Lacy; and Maud, a Daughter, married to Richard de Clare, Earl of Clare, Gloce≈øter, and Hartford, Anno Domini 1238. 22 Hen. 3. Stow in his Annals.

Ob. 1240. 22 Julii.
Anno 1240. 24 Hen. 3. die Sanctae Mariae Magdalenae, ≈øcilic√®t undecimo Calendas Augu≈øti, died John Earl of Lincoln, after a long and tedious Sickne≈øs. Mat. Paris, p. 533.
Margaret Counte≈øs of Lincoln afterwards married Walter Mar≈øhall Earl of Pembroke, which Walter died without I≈ø≈øue 29 Hen. 3. 1245. Mat. Paris. Al≈øo Vincent upon Broke.
But Margaret ≈øurvived both her Husbands, and then was ≈øtiled,‚ÄîDomina Margareta Comiti≈ø≈øa Lincolniae & Pembrochiae, in all her Charters: Lib. C. fol. 66. y. Living 33 Hen. 3.

I find mention in the Book of Whalley, fol. 126. b. of one Peter de La≈øcy a Ba≈øtard, called al≈øo Peter de Ce≈øter, Rector of Whalley Church in Lanca≈øhire, 1249. but whether Ba≈øtard-≈øon of this John Lacy, I cannot po≈øitively affirm.
IX. Edmund Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Son and Heir of John Lacy Earl of Lincoln, ≈øucceeded his Father, and was the ninth Baron of Halton.
His Mother Margaret enjoyed the Earldom of Lincoln while ≈øhe lived, by whom it came; and ≈øhe ≈øurvived Edmund her Son, who was Ward to the King.

And howbeit Vincent upon Brook, pag. 318, 319. cites a Record out of the Clo≈øe Rolls, to prove that this Edmund, by way of Recitation, had tertium Denarium Comitatus Lincolniae; yet certain it is, he was never ≈øtiled in any of his own Chartes by the Title of Comes Lincolniae, but onely Edmundus Lacy Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae: Lib. C. fol. 67. c. & fol. 1. f. Sometimes Sir Edmund Lacy onely. Lib. C. fol. 67. b.

Yet Matthew Paris tells us, That in the beginning of May, 1247. two Girls of Provence in France were by the Providence of Peter of Savoy married unto two very Noble young Gentlemen, Edmund Earl of Lincoln, and Richard de Burgo, whom King Henry the Third had Educated for ≈øome few Years in his own Court; the King him≈øelf ≈øtaying at Wood≈øtock from the twenty eighth of April to the fir≈øt of May, for the accompli≈øhment thereof. Concerning which Marriages there was much murmuring through the Kingdom, becau≈øe tho≈øe ≈øtrange Ladies were married (as it was ≈øaid) contrary to the de≈øires of the young Noblemen, and again≈øt their wills.

Where he ≈øtiles this Edmund, Earl of Lincoln, rather out of Civility, in regard it was Hereditarily in him if he had ≈øurvived his Mother, than that in truth he was ≈øo ≈øtiled in any Deed or Record during his Life.

‚öúThe young Ladies Name to whom the King married him, was Alice Daughter of the Marquis of Saluces in Italy, and Co≈øin to the Queen of England, of whom he begot Henry Lacy, afterwards Earl of Lincoln.

Roger Quency Earl of Winche≈øter, and Con≈øtable of Scotland, gave unto his Co≈øin Edmund Lacy the Mannors of Kypes and Scales in York≈øhire: Lib. C. fol. 67. a Tom. 1. of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, fol. 168. b. Com. Eboraci. num. 12.
Anno Domini 1254. aliqui magnatum, utpote Johannes de Warrenn√¢, & Edmundus de La≈øcy, apud Doveram transfretantes, vers√πs Burdegaliam lora direxerunt. Mat. Paris.
Obiit 1258 Edmund Lacy died the fifth day of June, 1258. 42 Hen. 3. and was Buried at Stanlaw Abby in Wirrall in Che≈øhire. So the Book of Whalley Abby. Lib. C. fol. 61. a. & fol. 67. e.

Alice, the Widow of this Edmund, was living 1271. 55 Hen. 3. Tom. 2. of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, Honor ≈øive Soca de Bolingbroke, fol. 23. num. 49. being a French Deed, wherein by Agreement with Henry Lacy her Son, ≈øhe was to hold for her Life all tho≈øe Lands whereof ≈øhe was Enfeoffed by the King:‚ÄîAnd ≈øhe relea≈øeth all her Dower in Halton in Che≈øhire, and in Widneys, and in Almanbyrye.
X. Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln, and Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Son and Heir of Edmund Lacy, ≈øucceeded his Father, and was the tenth Baron of Halton.

King Edward the Fir≈øt gave unto him the Ca≈øtle and Lord≈øhip of Denbigh in Wales, Anno Domini 1284. 12 Edw. 1. Stow in his Annals. In this Year, on the ninth of April, was ≈øo great Thunder and Lightning, that Men could ≈øcarce ≈øtand on their Feet.

His Title, in Anno 1286. 14 Edw. 1. and al≈øo 1296. 24 Edw. 1. did run thus in his own Charters,‚ÄîHenricus de Lacy Comes Lincolniae, Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae, Dominus de Roos & Rowynock. Mona≈øticon, 1 Pars. pag. 901. & Lib. C. fol. 67. g.

He was in greate≈øt Favour with his Prince, on who≈øe Fidelity Edward the Fir≈øt did principally rely, making him the Chief Commi≈ø≈øioner for the Rectifying and Di≈øcovering of the Abu≈øes and Briberies of his Corrupt Judges, complained of in Parliament 18 Edw. 1. 1290. Among whom, Sir Thomas Weyland, Chief Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas, was Bani≈øhed, and all his Goods Confi≈øcate; Sir John Lovetot Compounded for 3000 Marks; Roger Leyce≈øter Clerk, for 1000 Marks; Sir William Brompton, for 6000 Marks. The≈øe were all Judges of the Common Pleas; and other Judges were al≈øo Fined.
About this time, 1290. Sir Nicolas Leyce≈øter Knight was Sene≈øchal to this Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln: G. num. 60. from whom the Leyce≈øters of Tabley in Che≈øhire.
Henry Lacy is placed next after the Prince of Wales, as the Prime Noble-man of England, in the Catalogue of the Parliament at Carli≈øle, 1307. 35 Edw. 1. as they be ranked by Stow in his Chronicle.
He was very Famous in all Grand Matters of State in the Reign of King Edward the Fir≈øt, as Wal≈øingham, Stow, and other of our Hi≈øtorians do report.
Anno 1293. he was ≈øent Emba≈ø≈øador to the French King, to demand Satisfaction for the Goods of the Engli≈øh Merchants which were taken by the French.
Al≈øo after the death of Edmund Earl of Lanca≈øter, he was Commander in Chief of all the Kings Forces in Ga≈øcoyn, and ≈øometime Vice-Roy of the Dutchy of Aquitain.
Anno 1298. he Marched into the Confines of Tholou≈øe, and expelled the French, delivering the Ca≈øtle of St. Catharine from a ≈øtrict Siege.
Anno 1299. he led the Foreward of the Battel of Fowkirk in Scotland, where the Scots were defeated.

He was Protector of England when Edward the Second was in Scotland. In a word, He was Vir Illu≈øtris in Concilio, ≈øtrenuus in omni Praelio, Princeps Militiae in Angli√¢, & in omni Regno Ornati≈ø≈øimus, ≈øaith the Book of Dunmow, as I find it cited by Wever in his Funeral Monuments, pag. 366.

Anno 1273. 1 Edw. 1. Edmund Earl of Lanca≈øter, Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln, and Reginald Grey, for the Pre≈øervation of the Peace of this Nation, Be≈øieged Robert de Ferrers in the Ca≈øtle of Chartley in Stafford≈øhire, which Ca≈øtle Robert had entred and kept by Force, it being lately given by King Henry the Third unto Hamon le Strange; which Ca≈øtle indeed was the Inheritance of the ≈øaid Robert, and de≈øcended unto him by Agnes his Grandmother, third Si≈øter and Co-heir to Randle Blundevill Earl of Chester, till Robert forfeited the ≈øame by his Rebellion. In this Siege many Per≈øons were ≈ølain on both Sides, and the ≈øaid Robert and his Complices were at la≈øt taken. Now the King Pardoned the≈øe Be≈øiegers for the ≈ølaying of the≈øe Di≈øturbers of the Peace, and Confirms the Protection of ≈øuch Per≈øons as the ≈øaid Edmund had received into Favour. Dated at Rothelent, 20 die Decembris, 11 Edw. 1. 1282. Lib. C. fol. 67. I. Tom. 2. of the Couchir-Books at Grays-Inn, in the Dutchy-Office there. Derby-Ferrers, num. 4.

This Henry, by the Name of Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln, and Constable of Che≈øhire, Confirms to the Prior and Canons of Bur≈øtow a Place called Ruddegate, which Henry Torbock and Ellen his Wife had before Granted unto them; ≈øo as one Leprous Per≈øon of his Fee of Widneys [in Lanca≈øhire], if any ≈øuch were found, ≈øhould be admitted in the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, and be rea≈øonably maintained; and after the Decea≈øe of one, another to come in his room: And that the ≈øaid Henry Lacy, and Margaret his Wife, be put
in their Martyrologie, and their Names written in the Canon. Dated at Halton, die Sancti Geronimi Confe≈ø≈øoris (which is the thirtieth day of September), Anno Domini 1285. The Original hereof was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Sir Simon Dewes Baronet, 1646. with a very fair Seal, ≈øcilic√®t, The Earl on Hor≈øeback, with his Sword drawn; and on the Brea≈øt of the Earl, an E≈øcocheon of Arms, in which is A Lion Rampant; and on the Rever≈øe or Backpart of the Seal, al≈øo, A Lion Rampant in an E≈øcocheon, which I take to be the Coat of the≈øe Lacies Earls of Lincoln. Lib. C. fol. 68. k.

Queeen Elinour's Grant to Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln, That all his Tenants in the Mannor of Dynelnegh be quit of all Toll, Stallage, Payage, Pavage, Pontage, Murage, and Pa≈ø≈øage, for ever, per omnes Terras nostras Walliae, & in Comitatibus Ce≈øtriae, Staffordiae, Salopiae, Gloce≈øtriae, Wigorniae, & Herefordiae. Apud Gretindon, primo die Septembris, 18 Edw. 1. Tom. 1. of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, fol. 28. num. 49.
Infinite other Grants were made to and by this Henry Lacy, which here would be tedious to mention.

He had two Wifes. Margaret Daughter of Sir William Long≈øp√©e, and his onely Heir, was the fir≈øt Wife of Henry Lacy, married about Chri≈øtmas, 1256. 40 Hen. 3. For on Friday before Chri≈øtmas in that Year, it was agreed between Sir Edmund Lacy on the one Part, and Sir William Long≈øp√©e on the other Part, That whereas the Marriage of Henry Lacy, Son and Heir of the ≈øaid Edmund, with Margaret Daughter and Heir of the ≈øaid William, had been formerly mentioned in Ga≈øcoyne, it was now fini≈øhed by the Con≈øent of the Parties: And William Long≈øp√©e gave with Margaret his Daughter and Heir, in Free-Marriage, to Henry Lacy, the Mannors of Burence≈øter and Middleton, c√πm omnibus Homagiis, Redditibus, & Servitiis: And Edmund Lacy gave for Joynture to the ≈øaid Margaret his Mannors of Kypeis and Scales in York≈øhire. Lib. C. fol. 67. b. Tom. 2. of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, Comitatus Oxoniae, num. 2. Henry Lacy was but ≈øix Years old when he was married.

This William de Long≈øp√©e, although he was Right Heir to the Earldom of Salisbury, yet did he never enjoy the ≈øame: nor had Henry Lacy ever that Title; but all the Lands of this Long≈øp√©e de≈øcended to him.

Henry Lacy had I≈ø≈øue by this Margaret two Sons, Edmund and John, and both died young; and al≈øo two Daughters, Alice and Margaret. Ferne in Lacy's Nobility calls Margaret by the Name of Joan, pag. 125. but fal≈øly. Onely Alice ≈øurvived, who became Sole Heir to her Father, and married Thomas Plantagenet Earl of Lanca≈øter, Leyce≈øter, and Darby. Lib. C. fol. 86.

p.hi: So was the Barony of Halton annexed and united to the Earldom of Lanca≈øter.

div.p: Brooks and Fern ≈øay, That Edmund elde≈øt Son of Henry Lacy was drowned in the Draw-well of Denbigh Ca≈øtle; but I am told by a more Ancient Authority, Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 188 b. That in Anno 1282. Edward the Fir≈øt gave to Henry Lacy two Cantreds in Wales, to wit, Roos and Roweynock; and that the King, eodem Anno, gave to Edmund Lacy his Son a young Girl in Marriage, but five Years old, namely Maud the Daughter and Heir of Patrick de Chaworth by I≈øabel Beauchamp his Wife, Daughter of William de Beauchamp Earl of Warwick: Lib. C. fol. 73. e. But this Edmund Lacy died young without I≈ø≈øue; and John his Brother, running ha≈øtily in his Youth upon a Turret in Pomfret Ca≈øtle in York≈øhire, fell down from the Walls and was killed.
The ≈øecond Wife of Henry Lacy was Joan Daughter of William Martin Lord Keimis; but had no I≈ø≈øue by her. Lib. C. fol. 86. a.

This Great Henry Lacy, Earl of Lincoln, Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, Baron of Halton,
Pomfret, Blackburn≈øhire, Roos, & Roweynock, and Protector of England, died on the fifth day of February, 1310. 4 Edw. 2. at his own Hou≈øe in Chancery lane at London, now called Lincolns-Inn, and was buried at St. Paul's Church in London, in the New Work which was of his own Foundation, under a goodly Monument, with his Armed Pourtraicture cro≈øs-legged, as one that had taken a Voyage in Defence of the Holy Land. He was aged ≈øixty Years at the time of his death: Wever's Funeral Monuments, pag. 366. and Stow in his Annals, ≈øub Anno 1310. Lib. C. fol. 69. t.
Joan his Widow afterwards married Nicolas Lord Audley: Lib. C. fol. 69. v. which Nicolas died 1316.

And it is to be remembred, That in the Time of this Henry Lacy, who gave the Church of Whalley in Lanca≈øhire, with the Chappels thereof, unto the Monks of Stanlaw, the Abby of Stanlaw was Tran≈ølated unto Whalley, ≈øcilic√®t Anno Domini 1296. in Fe≈øto Sancti Ambro≈øii Epi≈øcopi, id e≈øt, 4 Aprilis: Lib. C. fol. 61. a. Domino Gregorio de Norbury t√πnc Abbate.

Anno 1309. 3 Edw. 2. die Vincentii Martyris, obiit Gregorius de Norbury Primus Abbas de Whalley: An old Parchment Book of Whalley, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Mr. Townley of Carre in Lanca≈øhire, 1657. fol. 23.

He was Beheaded at Pomfret, his own Mannor, Anno Domini 1321. 15 Edw. 2. 22 die Martii, for Rebelling again≈øt his Sovereign King Edward the Second: Stow and Wal≈øingham. Leaving no I≈ø≈øue of his Body to ≈øucceed him; who≈øe Lands were now forfeited to the King.

Anno 1314. 8 Edw. 2. he purcha≈øed from Audomare de Valentia the Temple-hou≈øe at London, (which formerly belonged to the Templars, but is ≈øince become a Society for the Students of our Law) with all the Lands and Rents thereto belonging in the Suburbs of London and in the County of Middle≈øex, which were of the Fee of the Honor of Leyce≈øter, and Confirmed unto him by the Grant of King Edward the Second, Dated at York, primo die Octobris, 8 Edw. 2. Tom. 2. of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, Comitatus Middle≈øex.

Alice, the Widow of this Thomas, had the Earldom of Lincoln re≈øtored unto her by the King, during her Life, 20 die Septembris, 1322. 16 Edw. 2. She had al≈øo the Mannor of Halton in Che≈øhire, c√πm pertinentiis, re≈øtored unto her for her Life, 12 die Julii, 16 Edw. 2. in which Deed ≈øhe is ≈øtiled Counte≈øs of Lincoln and Salisbury: Lib. C. fol. 68. l. Afterwards ≈øhe married Sir Eubulo le Strange, without the Kings Con≈øent, about 1325. 19 Edw. 2. but had no I≈ø≈øue by him. Eubulo Lord Strange was in her Right made Earl of Lincoln: Vincent upon Broke, pag. 320. and he died about 7 Edw. 3. 1333. For, 9 Edw. 3. I find Alice ≈øtiled Counte≈øs of Lincoln and Salisbury: Lib. C. fol. 69. p. q.
After this, Alice married Hugh de Frenes to her third Husband, who u≈øurped the Title of Earl of Lincoln in her Right, and died 1334. Wal≈øingham, pag. 134. but had no I≈ø≈øue by her.
Concerning this Alice, and one Richard de St. Martin, I ≈øhall give you here the Story out of Wal≈øingham, ≈øub Anno 1317. 10 Edw. 2. pag. 108, 109.

On Monday before A≈øcen≈øion-day, 1317. the Counte≈øs of Lanca≈øter was Ravi≈øhed at Caneford in Dor≈øet≈øhire, by a certain Knight of the Hou≈øe of John Earl of Warren, very
many of the Engli≈øh being a≈ø≈øi≈øtant to that dete≈øtable Fact, and by the Kings A≈ø≈øent, as it was ≈øaid: She was brought in great Triumph to the Earl Warren's Ca≈øtle of Ryegate, in di≈øgrace of her Husband Thomas Earl of Lanca≈øter; and by the way, the Conductors ≈øuppo≈øing they had ≈øeen Flags or Banners between the Hedges and Woods of Halton and Farnham afar off, (which was nothing but Prie≈øts in their Surplices walking Proce≈ø≈øion with the People in the Fields, according to their Cu≈øtom) were ≈øtruck with a great fear, thinking the Earl of Lanca≈øter her Husband had been coming with a Power to revenge her Injury; and ≈øo ran away, leaving the Lady almo≈øt all alone: But the matter being di≈øcovered, they returned with Threatnings and Pomp; with whom there was a low, lame, hulch-back'd Fellow, of a malicious ≈øpirit, called Richard d√® St. Martin, who being backed with great Aid, challenged the mi≈øerably-derided Lady for his Wife, prote≈øting that he carnally knew her before ≈øhe married the Earl of Lanca≈øter; which ≈øhe openly acknowledged to be true: And although ≈øhe was reputed a mo≈øt Noble Lady all her life-time before, ≈øhe was by the Wheel of Fortune proclaimed an odious Strumpet: And the ≈øaid Richard triumphing over her, pre≈øumes to challenge the Earldoms of Lincoln and Salisbury in the King's Court, as in Right of his Wife; but in vain, as ≈øhall after appear more fully. Thus Wal≈øingham.

But here ≈øeems to be great improbability in this Story. Cambden tells us out of the Book of Stanlaw Mona≈øtery, that ≈øhe was but nine Years old when ≈øhe married Thomas Earl of Lanca≈øter: Lincoln≈øhire, pag. 409. And then St. Martin mu≈øt lie with her before ≈øhe was nine Years old, which is not probable. And then the≈øe Actions and Words done and ≈øaid unto her in time of Ho≈øtility, to make the Earl odious, might be given out again≈øt her, as if ≈øhe had confe≈ø≈øed the Fact; though perhaps an ab≈øolute Fal≈øity. Nor is it likely Eubulo Lord Strange would have married her, as he did, had the≈øe things been true which are here related by Wal≈øingham.

This Counte≈øs Alice died Anno Domini 1348. 22 Edw. 3. Ann√≥que aetatis ≈øuae ≈øexage≈øimo ≈øeptimo; and was Buried at Berlyng Abby, by Eubulo her ≈øecond Husband: Mona≈øticon, 2 Pars, pag. 190. leaving no I≈ø≈øue by any of her Husbands.

Now for the Lands which were the Inheritance belonging to this Alice, they are ≈øaid to be worth 10000 Marks per Annum, and more; howbeit, ≈øhe had not above 3000 Marks thereof per Annum allowed her by the King. Mona≈øticon, Pars 2. pag. 189. b.

The Inheritance of Henry Lacy was ≈øo ≈øetled upon the Marriage of Alice his Daughter and Heir, that in Ca≈øe Henry Lacy had no Heirs of his Body, in defect of ≈øuch, then his Lands were to revert to Edmund the King's Brother, and to his Heirs for ever. Dated 28 Octobris, 22 Edw. 1. 1294. Lib. C. fol. 67. f. Mona≈øticon, Pars 2. pag. 189. a.
So Alice having no I≈ø≈øue, all Henry Lacy's Lands came to the Earls of Lanca≈øter.

p.hi: But before I proceed, it will be requi≈øite I ≈øay ≈øomething here of the Earls of Lanca≈øter before Thomas Plantagenet.

div.p: The fir≈øt Earl of Lanca≈øter I meet withal, was John ≈øir-named Without Land, younger Brother to King Richard the Fir≈øt. He was afterwards King John, and therefore I ≈øhall ≈øay the le≈øs of him.
The next Earl of Lanca≈øter was Edmund Plantagenet, ≈øir-named Crook-back, younger Son to King Henry the Third, and Brother to King Edward the Fir≈øt.

He had given him by his Father‚ÄîHonorem, Comitatum, Ca≈øtrum, & Villam de Lancaster, & omia Dominica no≈øtra quae ≈øunt in Comitatu Lanca≈øtriae, c√πm Vaccariis & Fore≈øtis de Wire≈ødale & Loun≈ødale; & Novum Castrum ≈øubt√πs Limam; Manerium, Fore≈øtam, & Ca≈øtrum de Pickering; Manerium de Scaleby, Villam de Gomece≈øter, reddit√∫mque Villatae de Huntendon. Dated at St. Pauls in London, 30 die Junii, 51 Hen. 3. 1267. Lib. C. fol. 71. e. Tom. 1. of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, fol. 1. num. 1. So he was made Earl of Lanca≈øter, 1267.

He was al≈øo Earl of Leyce≈øter, and High Steward of England, by Patent dated 25 die Octobris, 49 Hen. 3. 1265. upon the Forfeiture of Simon de Montfort Earle of Leyce≈øter, who was ≈ølain at the Battel of Eve≈øham, 5 die Augu≈øti, 1265.

He was made Earl of Derby at Kenillworth, 28 Junii, 50 Hen. 3. wherein he hath granted unto him‚ÄîCa≈øtra & omnes terras quae fuerunt Roberti de Ferrariis quond√†m Comitis Derbiae, qui Simoni de Monteforti quond√†m Comiti Leyce≈øtriae, Inimico & Feloni no≈øtro, & Impri≈øis ≈øuis adhae≈øit tempore Guerrae, quae nup√®r in Regno no≈øtro mota fuit per ip≈øum Simonem‚ÄîLib. C. fol. 71. g. Tom. 1. of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, fol. 3. num. 11. Which Robert de Ferrars was al≈øo Lord of Tutbury; and was afterwards bound unto this Edmund, with William de Valentia Earl of Pembroke, John Warren Earl of Surrey, William de Beauchampe Earl of Warwick, and many other Sureties, for the Payment of 50000 l. Sterling in Quinden√¢ Johannis Bapti≈øtae proxim√® ventur√¢, 53 Hen. 3. for the Redemption of his Lands: Lib. C. fol. 71. I. But I find not that they were ever redeemed.
This Edmund was Inve≈øted King of Sicily and Apuly with a Ring ≈øent from the Pope by the Bi≈øhop of Romania, 1255. 39 Hen. 3. Mat. Paris. But it was a meer delu≈øion; for he never had it.

He had the Ca≈øtle of Kenilworth given him, 16 Decembris, 51 Hen. 3. Lib. C. fol. 71. f. And the Savoy-Hou≈øe in London, by the Gift of Queen Elinor his Mother, 24 die Februarii, 12 Edw. 1. 1283. Lib. C. fol. 72. n. And the Ca≈øtle of Chartley he had by the Grant of his Brother King Edward the Fir≈øt, 26 die Julii, 4 Edw. 1. 1276. Lib. C. fol. 72. k.

Anno Domini 1271. 55 Hen. 3. in the Month of May, Prince Edward Son of King Henry, with Edmund his Brother, and four Earls, and ≈øo many Barons, and many other Gentlemen, took a Voyage into the Holy Land. So Mat. Paris.

Edmund Earl of Lanca≈øter married to his fir≈øt Wife Aveline Daughter and Heir to William de Fortibus Earl of Albemarle and Holderne≈øs, and Widow to Ingram de Percy;
Aveline and all her I≈ø≈øue died before her Parents. but left no I≈ø≈øue by her. Vincent upon Broke, pag. 293. He married her the eighth day of April, 1270. Mat. Paris, pag. 1006. of the Edition by Wats; ≈øed c√πm tot√¢ prole illa mortem Parentum praevenit: Wal≈øingham in his Hypodigma Neu≈øtriae placeth her Marriage with Edmund Anno 1269.

His ≈øecond Wife was Blanch Queen of Navarre, the Widow of Henry de Champaigne King of Navarre, and Daughter of Robert Earl of Artois, Brother of St. Lewis King of France; in who≈øe Right Edmund was Earl of Champaigne, 7 Edw. 1. So as he was now Earl of Lanca≈øter, Leyce≈øter, Derby, and Champaigne, and High Steward of England. Vincent on Broke, Tit. Lanca≈øter, pag. 293.
By Blanch the King of Navarre had I≈ø≈øue Joan married to Philip the Fair King of France. Vincent, pag. 293.

Blanch married Edmund Earl of Lanca≈øter, Anno Domini 1276. and by him had I≈ø≈øue three Sons, Thomas Earl of Lanca≈øter, the eleventh Baron of Halton in Right of his Wife, of whom I have ≈øpoken before, who Rebelled again≈øt his Prince, and died without I≈ø≈øue: Henry de Lanca≈øter Lord of Monmouth, ≈øecond Son, afterwards Earl of Lanca≈øter, and Heir to his Brother Thomas: And John, third Son, who lived with the Queen of France his Half-Si≈øter, and died there without I≈ø≈øue. Hypodigma Neu≈øtriae, pag. 473. & Lib. C. pag. 73. a. b.

Vincent, pag. 293. will have the Queen of Navarr's Name here to be Elinour, and not Blanch, from a Record which he there voucheth: Quaere, if that Record be not mi≈øtaken; for I find her called Blanch in ≈øundry Deeds in the Regi≈øter-Books of the Duke of Lanca≈øters Evidences in the Dutchy-Office, called The two Couchir-Books.

Anno Domini 1296. 24 Edw. 1. this Edmund the King's Brother, and Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln, went into Ga≈øcoyn with a ≈øtrong Army, where many Ca≈øtles were delivered unto them; but when they came within two Miles of Burdeaux, the French Army coming out of Burdeaux as it were unawares upon them, after a ≈øore Conflict retreated to the City, and the Earls burned a great part of the Suburbs.
And ≈øhortly after, Edmund died: Hypodigma Neu≈øtriae, pag. 483. Ob. 1296

XII. Henry of Lancaster, Lord of Monmouth, ≈øir-named Gri≈ømond, ≈øecond Son of Edmund Crook-back, and Brother and Heir to Thomas Plantagenet Earl of Lanca≈øter,
was re≈øtored to all his Brothers Lands and Honors,1 Edw. 3. Anno Domini 1326. and then his Titles were thus,‚ÄîHenricus Comes Lanca≈øtriae & Leyce≈øtriae, Sene≈øchallus Angliae. Lib. C. fol. 74. k. 13 Edw. 3. And he was the twelfth Baron of Halton.

He married Maud Daughter and ≈øole Heir of Sir Patrick de Chaworth or de Gadurcis, Lord of Kidwelly in Caermarthen≈øhire, and of Ogmore Ca≈øtle in Glamorgan≈øhire: Cambden's Britannia, Printed 1607. pag. 619. ≈øub Titulo Lanca≈øtriae: & Lib. C. fol. 73. d.

This Maud was formerly given to Edmund Son of Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln, by Edward the Fir≈øt, Anno 1282. being then a Girl but five Years old; which Edmund died very young, before he came to Maturity, without I≈ø≈øue, as you may ≈øee above in Henry Lacy.

Henry Earl of Lanca≈øter had I≈ø≈øue by this Maud onely one Son, Henry, made Earl of Derby in his Fathers Life-time, to wit, 1336. 11 Edw. 3. Hypodigma Neu≈øtriae, and Vincent, pag. 297. And ≈øix Daughters: Blanch married Thomas Lord Wake of Lidell: Maud married William Lord Burgh Earl of Ul≈øter in Ireland, and after to Sir Rafe Ufford: Joan married John Lord Mowbray of Axholme: I≈øabel was Abbe≈øs of Ambersbury: Elinour, fir≈øt married to John Son of Henry Lord Beaumont, and Earl of Bughan in Scotland; after to Richard Earl of Arundel: And Mary, ≈øixth Daughter, married Henry Lord Percy of Alnwick. So Broke in his Catalogue of Nobility.

This Henry of Lanca≈øter, with others, was ≈øent by the Queen into Wales (where the King then ≈øculked) to take King Edward the Second her Husband; whom they took with Hugh Spen≈øer the Son, Robert de Baldock, and Simon de Reading. The King was committed to the Cu≈øtody of this Henry of Lanca≈øter: This was in Anno 1326. Soon after this was the King depo≈øed, and Edward his young Son made King, by the Name of Edward the Third: Which young King was Knighted by this Henry Earl of Lanca≈øter. Wal≈øingham Hi≈øt. Ang. Edw. 2. pag. 125, 126, 127. But this Henry was in nothing more infamous, than in betraying his Lawful Sovereign.

Obiit 1345 Anno Domini 1345. obiit Henricus Gri≈ømond, Frater Thomae Comitis Lanca≈øtriae: Jacet apud Leyce≈øtriam, X Calendas Octobris, which is the twenty ≈øecond of our September, 19 Edw. 3. A Manu≈øcript in the Univer≈øity Library at Oxford, among the Books given by Archbi≈øhop Laud, of an ancient Character, noted‚ÄîG. 9. fol. 125.

And Wal≈øingham's Hi≈øt. Ang. Edw. 3. pag. 165. thus,‚ÄîAnno 1345. 19 Edw. 3. obiit Henricus Comes Lanca≈øtriae, Pater Henrici Comitis de Derby; & Sepultus e≈øt Leyce≈øtriae in Mona≈øterio Canonicorum, Prae≈øentibus Rege & Regin√¢, t√†m antiqu√¢ qu√†m nov√¢, Archiepi≈øcopis & Epi≈øcopis, Comitibus & Baronibus qua≈øi totius Regni: Filius ejus eo tempore in Wa≈øconi√¢, ut praefertur, actus bellico≈øos & ≈øtrenuos exercebat; quamobr√®m intere≈ø≈øe non potuit exequiis Patris ≈øui.
XIII. Henry of Monmouth, ≈øir-named Tort-Coll or Wry-neck, onely Son of Henry Gri≈ømond, ≈øucceeded his Father in all his Lands and Honors, and was the thirteenth Baron of Halton.
He was Earl of Derby in his Fathers Life-time, Created 16 Martii, 11 Edw. 3.
After his Fathers death, his Title was thus, 21 Edw. 3. 1346.‚ÄîHenricus Comes Lancastriae, Derbiae, Leyce≈øtriae, Sene≈øchallus Angeliae: Lib. C. fol. 75. o.
He was Created Earl of Lincoln, 23 Edw. 3. and then his Stile was, 1349.‚ÄîHenricus Comes Lanca≈øtriae, Derbiae, Leyce≈øtriae, & Lincolniae, Sene≈øchallus Angliae: Lib. C. fol. 75. P.

La≈øtly, He was Created Duke of Lanca≈øter, 6 Martii, 25 Edw. 3. 1350. Vincent, pag. 297. Selden's Titles of Honour, pag. 754. But Wal≈øingham placeth his Creation of Duke, Anno 1353. pag. 520. above two Years too late.
ThisHenry Repaired the Savoy Hou≈øe in the Strand in London, which co≈øt him 52000 Marks, which Money he got at the Town of Bryggerak. Knighton, pag. 2627.

He was the fir≈øt of all the Nobility of England (of a Subject) who was Inve≈øted with the Title of Duke ≈øince the Norman Conque≈øt: For the Black Prince, who was made Duke of Cornwal fourteen Years before, though in truth he be a Subject, yet is he King Hereditarily if he ≈øurvive; and therefore I look upon the Prince as a Higher Pitch than the other Nobility.
So the Earldom of Lanca≈øter became a Dutchy.

Anno Domini 1354. 28 Edw. 3. this Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter went Beyond-≈øea in great State, to have ≈øought a Duel at Paris with the Duke of Brun≈øwick, who had taken and ≈øpoiled his Goods as he returned from the Court of Rome, whither he was ≈øent for the Confirmation of a Peace between the King of England and the King of France: But by Mediation of Friends it was taken up: Hypodigma Neu≈øtriae, pag. 520. See al≈øo Stow's Annals.

Anno 1345. in which Year his Father died, this Henry Sailed into Ga≈øcoyn with ≈øix hundred Armed Men, and ≈øo many Archers, who at the fir≈øt A≈ø≈øault took the ≈øtrong Town of Brigerak, and won fifty Towns and Cities to the King of England. He defeated the Army of the King of France which came again≈øt him, took twenty three Per≈øons of Quality, be≈øides a great number of Common Soldiers: The re≈øt either ran away, or were killed. His Munificence was ≈øuch, that, when he took any Town, he gave all the Booty to his Soldiers, kept little or nothing to hi≈øelf. Wal≈øingham.

He married I≈øabel Daughter of Henry Lord Beaumont, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue two Daughters and Co-heirs: Maud married William Duke of Zeland, and Earl of Henault, elde≈øt Son of Lewis Duke of Bavarre, Anno Domini 1352. 26 Edw. 3.

Blanch the other Daughter married John of Gaunt Earl of Richmond, fourth Son to King Edward the Third, 19 die Maii, 1359. 33 Edw. 3. at Rading, having a Di≈øpen≈øation of the Court becau≈øe ≈øhe was his Co≈øin. Wal≈øingham and Stow.

How the Lands were divided between the two Si≈øters, take here the≈øe two following Chartes, enrolled in one of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office at Grays-Inn, Tom. 2. Comitatus Norfolciae, num. 3. & Honor ≈øive Soca de Bolingbroke, pag. 4. num. 4. Lib. C. fol. 77. dd. a.

SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, Qu√≤d nos Johannes Epi≈øcopus Lincolniae, Robertus de la Mare, Johannes de Bukland, Johannes Charnells, Walterus Poer, Simon Simeon, & Johannes Neumarche, Conce≈ø≈øimus‚ÄîWillielmo Comiti de Henaud & de Leyce≈øtri√¢, & Matildae Uxori ejus, Filiae Domini Henrici nup√®r Ducis Lanca≈øtriae, Maneria de Gymingham, Thesford, Mathe, Wolde, & Tun≈øtede, & Hundreda de Galhowe, & Brothercors, c√πm pertinentiis; & triginta & novem Feoda, & quartam partem unius Feodi Militum c√πm pertinentiis, in Canefeld, Ey≈øten Attemount, Horton, Berewyk, Creke, Waterdene, Snyterle, Bar≈øham, Side≈øterne, Wyneton, Salthus, Gre≈øham, Aylemerton, Clopton, Fyncheam, Northwald, Feltewell, Roukelound, Middleton, Ea≈øt-Rudham, We≈øt-Rudham, Sal, Haydon, Kerde≈øton, Wodedalling, Repam, Bergh, Hegheton, Rongham, Fran≈øham, Weting, Toftes, Croxton, Gre≈øynghale, Lexam, El≈øyng, We≈øenham, Tanerham, Drayton, Swynington, Alderford, Lyneford, Grime≈øton, Congham, Byke≈øton in Golde≈øtthorp, Stanfeld, Bri≈øelye, Bilneye, Titele≈øhale, We≈øt-Lexam, Skernynge, & Ho, & Advocationes Abbathiae Marham, Prioratus Canonicorum de Thesford, Ho≈øpitalium Domus Dei de Thesford, Sanctae Mariae Magdalenae de Thesford, & Sancti Johannis de Thesford, ac Eccle≈øiarum de Suthreppes, Northreppes, Trymingham, Mane≈øele, Eykesthorpe, Bradefelde, Swathefeld, & Be≈øton, & medietatis Eccle≈øiae de Aylmerton; √†c eti√†m duo Feoda Militum c√πm pertinentiis, in We≈øtfeld & Brantham: Habenda & tenenda praedictis Willielmo Comiti de Henaud & de Leyce≈øtri√¢, & Matildae Uxori ejus, & Haeredibus de Corpore eju≈ødem Matildae exeuntibus, de Domino Rege Angliae, & aliis Capitalibus Dominis Feodi.‚ÄîEt ≈øi contingat, qu√≤d praedicta Matilda ob√Æerit ≈øin√® Haerede de Corpore ≈øuo exeunte, quod ab≈øit, ex t√πnc omnia praedicta Maneria, Hundreda, Feoda Militum, & Advocationes c√πm pertinentiis ≈øuis, plenari√® & integr√® remaneant rectis Haeredibus Domini Henrici nup√®r Ducis Lanca≈øtriae in perpetu√πm‚Äî&c.
Datum apud Londoniam, 22 die Octobris, 35 Edw. 3.

SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, Qu√≤d nos Johannes Dei Grati√¢ Epi≈øcopus Lincolniae, Ricardus Comes Arundelliae, Robertus de la Mare, Johannes de Bukland, Johannes Charnells, Walterus Poer, Simon Simeon, & Johannes Newmarche, Conce≈ø≈øimus‚Äînobili viro Johanni Comiti Lanca≈øtriae & Richmondiae, & Blanchiae Uxori ejus, & Haeredibus ≈øuis de Corporibus eorum legitim√® procreatis, Ca≈øtrum de Bolingbroke & Parcum eidem Ca≈øtro pertinentem, e√πm omnibus Advocationibus Eccle≈øiarum, Abbathiarum, Prioratuum, Ho≈øpitalium,
& aliarum Domorum Religio≈øarum, & Feodis Militum, praedicto Ca≈øtro & Sokae de Bolingbroke pertinentibus, quae habuimus ex dono & redditione Nobilis Viri Henrici Ducis Lanca≈øtriae p√®r Finem in Curi√¢ Domini Regis ind√® leuatum; ade√≤ plen√® & integr√® ≈øic√πt Henricus de Lacy quond√†m Comes Lincolniae ea tenuit & habuit. Retentis nobis Manerio, Vill√¢, & Soc√¢ de Bolingbroke, ac Maneriis de Sutton, Thoresby, Wathe, & Ingold≈ømeles, c√πm pertinentiis in Comitatu Lincolniae‚ÄîConce≈ø≈øimus eti√†m Ca≈øtrum, Villam, Mannerium, & Honorem de Tutbury‚Äîac Villas de Strepton, Merchington, Chalangewood, Uttexhater, Adgare≈øt, & Newburgh, c√πm pertinentiis in Comitatu Staffordiae; & Hundredum de Higham-Ferrers, ac Maneria de Hegham-Ferrers, Raundes, Ri≈ø≈øheden, c√πm pertinentiis in Comitatu Northamptoniae;‚Äîit√† qu√≤d ≈øi idem Comes & Blanchia obierint ≈øin√® Haerede de Corporibus ≈øuis exeunte, qu√≤d t√πnc po≈øt dece≈ø≈øum ip≈øorum Comitis & Blanchiae, omnia praedicta Ca≈øtra, Maneria, &c. remaneant rectis Haeredibus ip≈øius Henrici Ducis Lanca≈øtriae; Tenenda de Domino Rege, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, per Servitia ind√® debita & con≈øueta in perpetuum. In cujus rei te≈øtimonium huic prae≈øenti Chartae Sigilla no≈øtra appo≈øuimus. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Edwardo Principe Walliae, Illu≈øtris Regis Angliae Filio Primogenito, Willielmo Epi≈øcopo Wintoniae, Cancellario Angliae, Simone Abbate We≈øtmona≈øterii Angliae The≈øaurario, Johanne de Bukyngham Northamptoniae Archidiacono, Henrico Greene, & Roberto de Thorpe, Ju≈øticiariis Domini Regis Angliae, & aliis. Datum Londini, die Dominic√¢, proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Sancti Martini, 35 Edw. 3.
So that William Earl of Henault had the Earldom of Leyce≈øter, and John of Gaunt had the Earldom of Lanca≈øter.

And after the death of Maud Counte≈øs of Leyce≈øter, who died without I≈ø≈øue Anno Domini 1381. the Earldom of Leyce≈øter, and all Maud's Part of the Lands belonging to Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter her Father, reverted unto John of Gaunt, in Right of Blanch his Wife the other Si≈øter.
