Obiit 1360 Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter died on the Eve before our Lady-day, 35 Edw. 3. which is the la≈øt Day of the Year, 1360. at Leyce≈øter, where he was buried. Wal≈øingham, pag. 178. ≈øaith he died Anno 1361. But he accounts the Year from Chri≈øtmas, not from our Lady-day.

It will not be impertinent if I put down here the Claims of this Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter, as Baron of Halton, upon a Quo Warranto brought again≈øt him, as I find them Tran≈øcribed in one of the Couchir-Books in the Dutchy-Office, to wit, Tom. 1. Comitatus Ce≈øtriae, fol. 45. num. 21. Lib. C. fol. 91.

HENRICUS Dux Lanca≈øtriae, Con≈øtabularius & Mare≈øchallus Ce≈øtriae, & Dominus Manerii de Halton, clamat per ≈øe & Haeredibus ≈øuis, habere infr√† Dominium ≈øuum Manerii ≈øui de Halton, Ca≈øtrum ≈øuum Kernellatum apud Halton; & habere ibid√®m Pri≈øonam, & capere ibid√®m Ca≈øtle-ward; & habere infra Manerium Dominii ≈øui Infangtheof, Outfang-theof, Waif, Wreck, Stray, & vi≈øum Franci-Flegii, & quicquid ad vi≈øum pertinet, de omnibus Tenentibus & Re≈øidentibus infr√† Dominium ≈øuum praedictum extr√† Burgos de Halton & Congelton, tenendum bis per Annum; videlic√®t, ≈øem√®l int√®r Fe≈øta Sancti Michaelis Archangeli & Michaelis in Monte Tumba
Novemb. 16., apud Halton; & iter√πm inter Fe≈øta Annunciationis Beatae Mariae & Inventionis Sanctae Crucis 3 Maii. , apud Thelwall quod e≈øt infr√† Dominium ≈øuum praedictum, per rationabilem praemonitionem; & habere liberum Parcum ≈øuum apud Halton c√πm duobus Saltatoribus
Corrupte pro Saltuariis, i.e. Fore≈øtars. in eodem Parco; & habere liberam Warrennam in omnibus Dominicis Terris ≈øuis infr√† Dominium ≈øuum Manerii praedicti.

p.hi: It√®m clamat tenere Villam ≈øuam de Halton, ut liberum Burgum; & habere ibid√®em liberos Burgen≈øes: Et qu√≤d ip≈øe, & Burgen≈øes ≈øui eju≈ødem Burgi, erunt quieti de Theoloneo, Pa≈ø≈øagio, Pontagio, & de Stuth
pro omnibus rebus per eos emptis & venditis, t√†m in Civitate Ce≈øtriae, qu√†m per totum Comitatum Ce≈øtriae, praeterqu√†m de Theoloneo Salis in VVychis.

It√®m, Clamat habere in eodem Burgo liberam Curiam ≈øuam de Quinden√¢ in Quindenam tenendam; & Cognitionem Placiti liberi Tenementi de omnibus Tenementis in eodem Burgo cor√†m Sene≈øchallo ≈øuo ibid√®m, per Billam ≈øeu Querelam ≈øiv√® Breve; & vi≈øum Franci Plegii, & quicquid ad vi≈øum pertinet, de omnibus Tenentibus & Re≈øidentibus in eodem Burgo: Tenendum
t√®r p√®r Annum, videlic√®t ≈øem√®l int√®r Fe≈øta Sancti Michaelis Archangeli & Sancti Martini in Hyeme; & iter√πm int√®r Fe≈øta Sancti Hilarii & Annunciationis Beatae Mariae; & terti√≤ int√®r Fe≈øta Sanctae Trinitatis & A≈ø≈øumptionis Beatae Mariae.

div.p:
Item, Clamat habere in eodem Burgo quoddam Mercatum ≈øingulis Septimanis per diem Sabbati On the Saturday. & habere ibid√®m duas Ferias annuat√¨m, videlic√®t, unam Feriam tenendam per quatuor dies proxim√® ant√® Fe≈øtum Nativitatis Beatae Mariae
Septemb. 8., & in Fe≈øto, & per duos dies proxim√® ≈øequentes: & aliam Feriam in Vigili√¢ Fe≈øti Beatae Catharinae
Novemb. 25. Virginis, & in die eju≈ødem Fe≈øti, c√πm omnibus libertatibus & pro≈øicuis quae ad Mercatum vel ad Ferias pertinent.

p.hi: It√®m, Clamat habere aliam liberam Curiam annual √¨m de Quinden√¢ in Quindenam tenendam apud Halton, vel alib√¨ ubicunqu√® voluerit infr√† Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti per rationabilem praemonitionem: Et in eadem Curi√¢ habere cognitionem Placitorum de Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionibus, Conventionibus, Debito, & Vecio Namio ad Sectam Partis: Et ≈øi Prae≈øentatum ≈øit per Ballivos dicti Ducis Curiae ≈øuae praedictae, qu√≤d aliquis Hominum, Tenentium, ≈øeu Re≈øidentium infr√† Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti, fregerit Pacem vel A≈ø≈øi≈øam Panis ≈øeu Cervi≈øiae ≈øeu Carnis, aut Carnes malas vendiderit, ce√π Affraiam fecerit, vel Hutegium

levaverit, vel fal≈øa Pondera vel Men≈øuras fal≈øas u≈øus fuerit infr√† eundem Feodum, ce√π vendiderit Pi≈øces captos infr√† Feodum praedictum ant√® horam primam alicujus diei; qu√≤d t√πnc Ballivi dicti Ducis Curiae ≈øuae praedictae per Proce≈ø≈øum debitum, ≈øcilic√®t, per Attachiamentum & Di≈øtrictionem, facient eo≈ødem Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øores venire ad re≈øpondendum in Curi√¢ praedict√¢; de quibus ≈øi convicti fuerint,‚Äî&c.

It√®m, Dux clamat habere Fines & Amerciamenta illorum, & punitionem dictorum Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øorum in form√¢ juris; pro quibus Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionibus ≈øi po≈øte√† indictati fuerint cor√†m Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, vel Vicecomite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, vel aliquibus aliis Mini≈øtris dicti Comitis Ce≈øtriae, pro praedictis Finibus ce√π Amerciamentis, ce√π Punitionibus per Ballivos dicti Ducis factis, erunt quieti.

It√®m, Clamat, qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis Conque≈øtus fuerit in e√¢dem Curi√¢, qu√≤d aliquis di≈ø≈øei≈øans eum in libero Tenemento ≈øuo infr√† Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti extr√† Burgos de Halton & Congleton per Billam, in natur√¢ Novae Di≈ø≈øei≈øinae, qu√≤d t√πnc Ballivi dicti Ducis eju≈ødem Curiae facient Proce≈ø≈øum ver≈ø√πs Partem Defendentem per Attachiamentum & Di≈øtrictionem, quou≈øqu√® venerit in Curiam praedictam ad re≈øpondendum de Placito praedicto: Et ≈øi Pars defendens dedicat di≈ø≈øei≈øinam, & ponit ≈øe ≈øup√®r Patriam, t√πnc ambabus Partibus con≈øentientibus capiatur Inqui≈øitio in natur√¢ A≈ø≈øi≈øae Novae Di≈ø≈øei≈øinae: Et ≈øi ind√® convictus fuerit de Di≈ø≈øei≈øin√¢, recuperet Pars querens Sei≈øinam ≈øuam ≈øim√πl c√πm damnis ≈øuis, & Pars De≈øendens in mi≈øericordi√¢: quam quid√®m mi≈øericordiam idem Dux clamat habere.

It√®m clamat, qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis Conque≈øtus fuerit in praedict√¢ Curi√¢ ver≈øus aliquem de aliqu√¢ vi√¢ arctat√¢, ob≈øtruct√¢, vel ob≈øtupefact√¢, vel de aliquibus aliis huju≈ømodi nocumentis, infr√† Dominii ≈øui praedicti Feodum factis, vel eti√†m p√®r Ballivos dicti Ducis dictae Curiae prae≈øentatum fuerit tale nocumentum per aliquem Forefactum infr√† eundem Feodum, qu√≤d t√πnc Sene≈øchallus Curiae praedictae per Attachiamentum & Di≈øtrictionem faciat dictum Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øorem venire in Curiam praedictam ad re≈øpondendum de nocumento praedicto, & t√πnc ≈øi ip≈øe in e√¢dem Curi√¢ ≈øe ponere voluerit, & ind√® convictus fuerit, qu√≤d t√πnc gravit√®r amercietur; & dabit Sene≈øchallo dictae Curiae unum Bovem, & nocumentum illud removere debet; quod quidem Amerciamentum idem clamat habere.

It√®m clamat, qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis acqui≈øiverit liberum Tenementam infr√† Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti ≈øine Licenti√¢ ≈øu√¢, & illud prae≈øentatum ≈øit per Ballivos dicti Ducis Curiae ≈øuae praedictae, qu√≤d t√πnc idem Acqui≈øitor attachiari debet per Ballivos eju≈ødem Curiae ad re≈øpondendum dicto Duci in Curi√¢ praedict√¢ de acqui≈øitione praedict√¢: Et ≈øi inde convictus fuerit, dabit praedicto Duci rationabilem Finem ≈øecund√πm quantitatem Tenementi acqui≈øiti, & ≈øecund√πm Con≈øiderationem Sene≈øchalli, & Judicatorum eju≈ødem Curiae.

Item clamat habere Stallagium de omnibus Merchandizam exercentibus infr√† certas Villas Dominii ≈øui praedicti; videlicet, Halton, Runcorne, We≈øton, Clifton, Sutton, A≈øton juxt√† Sutton, Middleton, A≈øton-Grange, Stokham, Norton, Pre≈øton, Daresbery, Newton, Rekwick, Moore, Acton-Grange, VValton ≈øuperiorem, VValton inferiorem, Hull & Appulton, Thelwall, Stretton, Hatton, Nether-VVhitley, Over-VVhitley, Comberbach, Budworth
juxt√† Comberbach, A≈øton juxt√† Budworth, Merebury, Cog≈øhull, Berthington, Legh, & Dutton. Et qu√≤d nulli hominum Tenentium ≈øeu Re≈øidentium infr√† Villas praedictas facere debent ≈øectam ≈øeu apparentiam cor√†m Ju≈øticiariis ad Placita, vocatis Eyres, nec ad Turnum Vicecomitis pro aliqu√¢ re, ni≈øi ≈øolummodo ad vi≈øus & Curias dicti Ducis praedictas; & qu√≤d nulli hominum Tenentium ce√π Re≈øidentium infr√† Villas praedictas, Summoneantur, Attachientur, Di≈øtringantur, ≈øe√π Capiantur infr√† Villatas praedictas, ad re≈øpondendum alicui cor√†m Ju≈øticiariis in Placitis praedictis, nec cor√†m Vicecomite in Turno ≈øuo praedicto, nec in Hundredo, ni≈øi ip≈øi, vel Catalla, vel Tenementa ≈øua, ≈øint ce√π inveniantur extr√† Villas praedictas.

Item clamat habere Aquam de Mer≈øey apertam √† quodam loco vocato Fre≈øpoole u≈øque ad Pi≈øcariam dicti Ducis de Thelwall, tam in ≈øolo alieno qu√†m in ≈øolo ≈øuo proprio, it√† largam qu√≤d habere po≈ø≈øit Pa≈ø≈øagium c√πm quodam Batello de octo Ferreys ≈øin√® impedimento, per filum dictae aquae u≈øqu√® ad dictam Pi≈øcariam, & redire omni tempore anni,‚Äî&c. Et ≈øi aliquid nocumentum ibid√®m factum fuerit ad contrarium, liceat ei illud amovere, &c.
It√®m clamat habere omnes Pi≈øces Regales captos ceu inventos infr√† Feodam Dominii ≈øui praedicti.
It√®m clamat ratione Dominii ≈øui de Halton fore Con≈øtabularium & Mare≈øchallum Domini Comitis Ce≈øtriae, & habere omnia Feoda & Proficua, quae ad ea pertinent.

It√®m clamat ratione Dominii ≈øui & Con≈øtabulariae ≈øuae praedictae, habere Advocarias ≈øuas per totum Comitatum Ce≈øtriae de omnibus, qui ≈øe in Advocariis ≈øuis ≈øe ponere voluerint; & habere omnia Proficua & Libertates, quae ad illas Advocarias pertinent.

It√®m clamat, Qu√≤d ip≈øe & Tenentes ≈øui de qu√¢dam Salin√¢ in Northwycho de XII Plumbis, vocat√¢ Whitley-Wich-hou≈øe, ≈øint quieti de Theoloneo prae≈øtando pro Sale in e√¢dem Salin√¢ facto & vendito: ac Emptores eju≈ødem Salis in e√¢dem Salin√¢ facti & empti, erunt quieti de Theoloneo pro eodem prae≈øtando in e√¢dem Vill√¢.

div.p:
It√®m clamat habere infr√† Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti unum Magi≈øtrum Servientem A Ma≈øter-Serjeant. ad aequum juratum c√πm octo Sub≈øervientibus, & duobus Garcionibus Two Servants. ≈øub eodem Magi≈øtro jurato ad cu≈øtodiendam Pacem per totum Feodum praedictum, & ad Serviendum dicto Duci de Executionibus Curiarum ≈øuarum praedictarum faciendis: qui quidem Magi≈øter Serviens c√πm Sub≈øervientibus & Garcionibus ≈øuis praedictis habere debebent Puturam Free-Quarter for Meat Drink., vel rationabilem Finem pro Putur√¢ e√¢dem, de omnibus Tenentibus tres Landas Terrae vel plures, Terrarum vocatarum Warland, infr√† Feodum praedictum; ≈øcilic√®t, pro dicto Magi≈øtro Serviente, & duobus Sub≈øervientibus ≈øuis, & uno Garcione c√πm uno Tenente Tenentium praedictorum, Coenare, pernoctare, & in die proxim√® ≈øequenti ant√® rece≈ø≈øum ≈øuum jentare; & pro aliis duobus Sub≈øervientibus c√πm uno Garcione c√πm alio Tenente Tenentium praedictorum ≈øimilit√®r Coenare, pernoctare, & in die proxim√® ≈øequenti ant√® rece≈ø≈øum ≈øuum jentare; & pro aliis duobus Sub≈øervientibus c√πm alio Tenente Tenentium praedictorum ≈øimiliter Coenare, pernoctare, & in die proxime ≈øequenti ante rece≈ø≈øum ≈øuum jentare: Et pro aliis duobus Sub≈øervientibus c√πm alio Tenente Tenentium praedictorum ≈øimiliter Coenare, pernoctare, & in die proxime ≈øequenti ante rece≈ø≈øum ≈øuum jentare: Et ≈øic de ≈øex Septimanis in ≈øex Septimanas ≈øeparat√¨m annuat√¨m in form√¢ praedict√¢ Coenare, pernoctare, & jentare: It√† quod quilibet Tenens Tenentium praedictorum c√πm quo praedictus Magi≈øter Serviens c√πm duobus Sub≈øervientibus & uno Garcione vel eti√†m cum quo duo de Sub≈øervientibus praedictis c√πm uno Garcione, vel eti√†m c√πm quo duo de Sub≈øervientibus praedictis in form√¢ praedict√¢ coenaverunt, pernoctaverunt, & jentaverunt, erit quietus t√†m de dicto Magi≈øtro Serviente, qu√†m de aliis Sub≈øervientibus & Garcionibus praedictis pa≈øcendis, per ≈øex Septimanas proxime t√πnc ≈øequentes: Et idem Magi≈øter Serviens habere debet de quolibet Tenente Tenentium praedictorum pro Equo ≈øuo unum Bu≈øhel Avenarum pro Prebend√¢
Rectius Probenda, i.e. for Provand. capiend√¢ annuat√¨m inter Fe≈øta Sancti Michaelis & Inventionis Sanctae Crucis.

p.hi: It√®m clamat, qu√≤d ≈øi dicti Servientes ≈øeu Ballivi ≈øui aliquem Latronem pro aliquo furto ubicunque fuerit, facto c√πm manuopere infr√† Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti ceperint, ≈øe√π attachiaverint, & ≈øi ille Latro Feloniam illam cor√†m quatuor Villatis ≈øpontane√¢ voluntate cognoverit, t√πnc liceat dictis Servientibus ≈øeu Ballivis ≈øuis dictum Latronem decollare: Et dictus Dux t√πnc habebit omnia Bona & Catalla dicti Latronis infr√† Feodum ≈øuum praedictum inventa.

Item clamat, qu√≤d ≈øi aliquis captus fuerit infr√† Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti per dictos Servientes ≈øeu Ballivos ≈øuos c√πm Manuopere alicujus Feloniae, qu√≤d t√πnc, Feloni√¢ ill√¢ cognit√¢ aut incognit√¢, liceat dictis Servientibus ≈øeu Ballivis ducere dictum Felonem ad Pri≈øonam dicti Ducis apud Halton, & ibidem illum retinere per tres Curias ibidem proxime ≈øequentes, ad quas venient omnes Judicatores & Sectatores Curiae praedictae per rationabilem praemonitionem: Et in qu√¢cunque Curi√¢ illarum liceat Sene≈øchallo eju≈ødem Curiae illum Felonem de dict√¢ Feloni√¢ ibidem arrainiare: Et ≈øi ille Felo ≈øe ponere ibidem voluerit ≈øuper Inqui≈øitionem Curiae praedictae, tunc liceat Sene≈øchallo illam Inqui≈øitionem capere: Et ≈øi ip≈øum inde culpabilem invenerit, tunc liceat dictis Servientibus ≈øeu Ballivis ≈øuis dictum Felonem ≈øuper Furcas dicti Ducis de Halton ≈øu≈øpendere; & Bona & Catalla dicti Felonis infra Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti inventa habebit dictus Dux ≈øibi Forisfacta: Et ≈øi dictus Felo in null√¢ Curiarum praedictarum ≈øe ponere voluerit ≈øuper Inqui≈øitionem ibidem, tunc mandetur ad Ca≈øtrum Ce≈øtriae: Et ≈øi ibidem dictus Felo convictus fuerit, reducatur per Servientes ≈øeu Ballivos dicti Ducis ad furcas eju≈ødem Ducis de Halton, & ibidem ≈øu≈øpendatur; ≈øeu ≈øi Finem inde fecerit Domino Comiti Ce≈øtriae, tunc in utroque Ca≈øu idem Dux clamat omnia Bona & Catalla dicti Felonis infra Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti inventa.

Item clamat habere Market-Geld de Villatis de We≈øton, A≈øton juxta Sutton, Middleton, Pre≈øton, Newton, Kekwick, Moore, Daresbery, Halton, Over-Walton, Nether-Walton, Stretton, Appulton, Middlehur≈øt in Gropenhall, Over-Whitley, Comberbach, Merebury, Budworth, A≈øton juxta Budworth, Nether-Tabley, Berthinton, Dutton, Plumley, Over-Tabley, Toft, Bexton, Knotsford-Booths, Millington, Limme, & Lo≈øtock: Quae ≈øunt infra Feodum Dominii ≈øui praedicti.

Item clamat habere Villam ≈øuam de Congleton liberum Burgum, & habere ibidem liberos Burgen≈øes: Et quod ip≈øi Burgen≈øes ≈øui praedicti erunt quieti de Theoloneo, Pa≈ø≈øagio, Pontagio, & Stuth, tam in Civitate Cestriae quam per totum Comitatum Ce≈øtriae, praeterquam de Theoloneo Salis in Wichis; & habere ibidem unum Mercatum qu√¢libet ≈øeptiman√¢ per diem Sabbati; & unam Feriam ibidem per Annum, videlicet, in die Sancti Martini in Hyeme cum omnibus Libertatibus & Proficuis, quae ad Mercatum ≈øeu ad Feriam pertinent. Et habere ibidem Vi≈øum Franci Plegii, & quicquid ad vi≈øum pertinet, de omnibus Tenentibus & Re≈øidentibus infra Burgum praedictum: Tenendum ter per Annum, videlicet, ≈øemel inter Fe≈øta Sancti Michaelis & Sancti Martini in Hyeme, & iterum inter Fe≈øta Sancti Hilarii & Annunciationis Beatae Mariae; & tertio inter Fe≈øta Sanctae Trinitatis & A≈ø≈øumptionis Beatae Mariae: Et habere ibidem Cognitionem Placiti de libero Tenemento in Burgo praedicto per Parvum Breve de Recto Clau≈øum; Tenendum coram Ballivis dicti Ducis: Et habere exitus, Fines, & Amerciamenta inde provenientia.
Item clamat habere liberam Curiam in Civitate Ce≈øtriae de omnibus Sutoribus, & liberis Tenentibus ≈øuis, in eadem Civitate; Tenendum bis per Annum.

Item idem Dux, Dominus & Baro de Halton, clamat pro ≈øe & Haeredibus ≈øuis, habere liberam Curiam de omnibus Placitis & Querelis in Curi√¢ Domini Comitis Ce≈øtriae, infra Feodum dictae Baroniae emergentibus, exceptis Placitis ad Gladium Domini Comitis Ce≈øtriae pertinentibus.

Item clamat, quod ≈øi quis hominum ≈øuorum pro aliquo delicto captus fuerit, per ip≈øum Baronem ≈øine redemptione Replegietur, ita quod dictus Baro eum perducat ad tres Comitatus, & eum quiete reducat ni≈øi Sakerbor
p.note: A Pledge to Sue, one bound to Pro≈øecute. Vide Spelmanni Glo≈ø≈øarium.

Ita clamat, quod ≈øi aliquis Adventitius, qui fidelis ≈øit, in terras ejus venerit, & ≈øi placuerit morari; liceat ei ip≈øum habere & reducere, Salvis Domino Comiti Ce≈øtriae Advocariis, qui ≈øponte ad ≈øe venerint; & aliis; qui pro tran≈øgre≈ø≈øu aliunde ad dignitatem ≈øuam veniunt; & non eis extraneis qui ≈øunt in Advocari√¢ dicti Ducis ad Dominium ≈øuum de Halton pertinentibus.

div.p:
Item clamat, quod ≈øi Vicecomes Domini Comitis Ce≈øtriae, vel aliquis Serviens in Curia ≈øua, aliquem hominum dicti Baronis inculpaverit, pro Thirtnyki. e. Trium noctium Ho≈øpes: Here it ≈øeems to ≈øignifie Three Nights Charges.
≈øe defendere poterit, ni≈øi Secta eum ≈øequatur.

p.hi: Item clamat habere quietantiam de Garbis & Oblationibus, quas Servientes & Bedelli Domini Comitis Ce≈øtriae exigere ≈øolebant.

Item clamat, quod ≈øi aliquis Judex vel Sectarius Hundredi aut Comitatus in Curia Domini
Comitis Ce≈øtriae in mi≈øericordiam ceciderit, per duos Solidos quietus ≈øit Judex; Sectarius autem per duodecem Denarios.
Item clamat, quod non faciat aliquod Servitium Domino Comiti Ce≈øtriae extra Lyme & Cluyd, ni≈øi per Gratum ≈øuum & ad Co≈øtum Domini Comitis Ce≈øtriae.
Item clamat, quod omnia Maneria ≈øua Dominica in Comitatu & Hundredo per unum Sene≈øchallum prae≈øentem defendere po≈ø≈øit.

div.p: In a little Parchment Schedule among my own Evidences, I find ≈øome part of Halton-Fee, as followeth; which I here have rendred in Engli≈øh, becau≈øe of ≈øome ob≈øolete Latin Words therein.
HUgo de Pre≈øton Bayliff of the Serjeanty of Halton, 33 Edw. 3. 1359. For Account before William Blaby, then Auditor to the Duke of Lanca≈øter, for 4 l. 13. s. 4 d.

div.p: He was Created Duke of Lanca≈øter in Right of his fir≈øt Wife, Blanch Daughter and Co-heir of Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter, 13 die Novembris, 36 Edw. 3. 1361. Couchir-Book in le Dutchy-Office, Tom. 1. fol. 142. num. 1. And after the death of Maud the other Daughter and Co-heir of Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter, who died without I≈ø≈øue Anno 1381. the Earldom of Leyce≈øter, and all Maud's Part of the Lands which belonged to Henry Duke of Lanca≈øter, reverted unto John of Gaunt.

Blanch his fir≈øt Wife died Anno Domini 1369. 43 Edw. 3. and was buried at St. Paul's Church in London: Wal≈øingham. By whom he had I≈ø≈øue, Henry of Bolingbrok, ≈øo called becau≈øe he was born at Bolingbroke Ca≈øtle, made Earl of Derby in his Father's Life-time, ≈øcilic√®t, Anno 1385. 9 Rich. 2. and Duke of Hereford al≈øo 1397. 21 Rich. 2. And in the Year following, 1398. this Henry Duke of Hereford accu≈øed Thomas Mowbray Duke of Norfolk for ≈øpeaking certain Words in di≈øhonour of the King's Per≈øon; which the Duke of Norfolk denied: Whereupon they had a Combat granted by the King, to have been fought at Coventry on the ≈øeventeenth day of September, both of them entring the Li≈øts courageou≈øly: But the King took up the Matter, cau≈øing it to be Proclaimed, That the Duke of Hereford had honourably performed his Part; and pre≈øently after Bani≈øhed the Duke of Hereford for ten Years, and the Duke of Norfolk for ever: So Stow and Wal≈øingham. But this Duke of Hereford returning into England, Depo≈øed Richard the Second, cau≈øing the King to read his own Re≈øignation of the Crown to this Henry publickly in the Tower, before the Nobles of England: Wal≈øingham's Hi≈øt. pag. 359. Cur≈øed Traytors! And ≈øo by force of Arms made him≈øelf King, by the Name of Henry the Fourth.
So was the Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, and the Barony of Halton, united to the Crown of England.

John of Gaunt had al≈øo I≈ø≈øue by Blanch two Daughters: Elizabeth married John Holland Duke of Exeter, and after to Sir John Cornwall, Knight of the Garter, and Baron of Fanhope: Philippa, the other Daughter, married John King of Portugal.

After the death of Blanch, he married Con≈øtantia Daughter and Co-heir to Petro late King of Spain; and Edmund Earl of Cambridge, his Brother, married I≈øabella the other Daughter, Anno Domini 1372. 46 Edw. 3. Stow and Wal≈øingham: Lib. C. fol. 78. f. And from this time he writ him≈øelf King of Ca≈øtile and Leons. By this Con≈øtance he had I≈ø≈øue Katharine, married to Henry Son of John King of Spain, 1389.

Upon the Marriage of Katharine, a Peace was concluded between John of Gaunt and the King of Spain: John of Gaunt was to have ten thou≈øand Pounds yearly for his own Life, and the Life of Con≈øtance his Wife: Wal≈øingham: Who before, in the Year 1367. had routed the Spaniards in a great Battel between him and Henry the Ba≈øtard, who had ejected Peter King of Spain.
Con≈øtance died Anno Domini 1394. Wal≈øingham.

John of Gaunt, relinqui≈øhing his Title of King of Ca≈øtile and Leons, was Created Duke of Aquitain by Con≈øent of Parliament, 2 die Martii, 13 Rich. 2. 1389. And then his Title, Anno 1394. 18 Rich. 2. did run thus.‚Äî

Johannes Filius Regis Angliae, Dux Aquitaniae & Lanca≈øtriae, Comes-Leyce≈øtriae, Lincolniae & Derbiae, Sene≈øchallus Angliae. Couchir-Book in the Dutchy-Office, Tom. 2. Comitatus Southampton, num. 36.

For he had Honorem de Tickhil, 46 Ed. 3. while he was ≈øtiled King of Ca≈øtile and Leons, and Duke of Lanca≈øter; & Ca≈øtrum & Leucatam de Pevene≈øe (inter ali√†), in exchange for the Earldom of Richmond, 46 Edw. 3. And by his Brother the Black Prince, Earl of Che≈øter, he had 100 Marks yearly given him out of the Exchequer at Che≈øter, during his Life, by the Name of John by the Grace of God King of Ca≈øtile and Leons, and Duke of Lanca≈øter: 47 Edw. 3. 1373. Lib. C. fol. 78. e.

After the death of Con≈øtance his ≈øecond Wife the Duke went into Aquitain, ≈øcilicet, Anno 1396. 19 Rich. 2. to have obtained the Good-will of the Inhabitants, having the Title of Duke of Aquitain conferred upon him before by his Father; but was ≈øuddenly called back into England by the King: And as ≈øoon as he returned into England, he married Katharine Swynford his old Concubine, to the wonder of all Men; which Katharine formerly waited on Blanch his fir≈øt Wife: Stow and Wal≈øingham.

This Katharine was the Daughter of Payn Roet, alias Guyen, King at Arms, and Widow of Sir Otes Swynford; by whom John of Gaunt had I≈ø≈øue before he married her; Sir John Beaufort, the elde≈øt, was Earl of Somer≈øet, and Marquis Dor≈øet, which Marquis-≈øhip was taken away by Parliament, 1 Hen. 4. Henry de Beaufort was after Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, Cardinal of St. Eusby ≈øive Eu≈øcbii, and Chancellor of England; Thomas Created Earl of Dor≈øet 21 Rich. 2. Joan de Beaufort was ≈øecond Wife of Raufe Nevill, the fir≈øt Earl of Westmorland; after ≈øhe married Robert Ferrers Lord of Ow≈øeley. They were all ≈øir-named de Beaufort, becau≈øe they were born at Beaufort in France. All which were Legitimated by Parliament, 1397. 20 Rich. 2. to all Purpo≈øes, Honors, State, and Dignities, except√¢ Dignitate Regale, as you may ≈øee in the Record tran≈øcribed by the Lord Cook in his Juri≈ødiction of Courts, pag. 37. Lib. C. fol. 82. P.

Wal≈øingham, put out by Mr. Cambden, calls Thomas Beaufort, Comitem de Somer≈øet, all along, pag. 354. & 550. for Dor≈øet; unle≈øs the Title of Somer≈øet and Dor≈øet were promi≈øcuous. See Vincent on Brooke, pag. 169.
Katharine Synford died in May, 4 Hen. 4. 1403. Stow.

This John procured the County of Lanca≈øter to be made a County Palatine; to whom his Father King Edward the Third by his Charter granted Jura Regalia: And when he hath reckoned up the Good Service which the ≈øaid John of Gaunt his Son had done for his Countrey at home and abroad, he addeth,‚ÄîConce≈ø≈øimus pro nobis & Haeredibus no≈øtris praefato Filio no≈øtro, quod ip≈øe ad totam vitam ≈øuam habeat infra Comitatum Lanca≈øtriae Cancellariam ≈øuam, ac Brevia ≈øua ≈øub Sigillo ≈øuo pro Officio Cancellarii deputando con≈øignanda, Justiciarios ≈øuos tam ad Placita Coronae quam ad quaecunque alia Placita Communem legem tangentia tenenda, & Cognitiones eorundem, & qua≈øcunque Executiones per Brevia ≈øua, & Mini≈øtros ≈øuos ibidem, faciendas; Et qua≈øcunque alias libertates, & Jura Regalia ad Comitatum Palatinum pertinentia, adeo libere & integre, ≈øicut Comes Ce≈øtriae infra eundem Comitatum Ce≈øtriae digno≈øcitur obtinere,‚Äî&c. 28 die Februarii, Anno Edw. 3. Angliae 51, & Franciae 38. Couchir-Book of the Dutchy-Office, Tom: 1. fol. 430. num. 16. Confirmed to him and his Heirs by Con≈øent of Parliament, 16 die Febr√πarii, 13 Rich. 2. Ibidem, Tom. 1. fol. 52.
Many are the Acts of this John of Gaunt, Recorded in our Annals and Hi≈øtories: I will reckon up ≈øome of the mo≈øt memorable.

Anno Domini 1373. 47 Edw. 3. John Duke of Lanca≈øter went with a Pui≈ø≈øant Army into France: He pa≈ø≈øed by Paris to Burgundy, and ≈øo through all France, no Man daring to oppo≈øe him; but at la≈øt leaving France, he came into the De≈øart Mountains of Avernia, where there was neither Meat for Hor≈øe nor Man, and ≈øo lo≈øt mo≈øt part of his Army through Famine and Pe≈øtilence; whence he came to Burdeaux ≈øcarce with forty Hor≈øe, whereas he entred France with thirty thou≈øand Hor≈øe attending him. Wal≈øingham.

Anno 1377. he was threatned to be killed by the Londoners, for ≈øome high Word ≈øpoken again≈øt their Bi≈øhop of London; they had burned his Hou≈øe, called The Savoy,
but that the Bi≈øhop interceded: Whereupon the Duke fled to Ken≈øington, and hating the Londoners, cau≈øed the Mayor and other Officers to be put out, and new ones cho≈øen. Shortly after, Richard the Second, before his Magnificent Coronation at We≈øtmin≈øter, reconciled the Citizens and the Duke of Lanca≈øter.
Anno 1376. the King ≈øent again for John of Gaunt his Son to Govern the Kingdom, who was Governor thereof as long as the King lived

For the Con≈øtable≈øhip of Che≈øhire, formerly inherent in the Barony of Halton, and now Granted to John Duke of Lanca≈øter by Richard the Second, take here the Charter at large, as I have tran≈øcribed the ≈øame out of the Couchir-Book in the Dutch-Office at Grays-Inn, Tom. 1. fol. 49. a. Comitatus Ce≈øtriae, num. 25.

RICARDUS Dei Grati√¢ Rex Angliae & Franciae, Dominus Hiberniae, & Princeps Ce≈øtriae, Omnibus ad quos prae≈øentes Literae pervenerint Salutem. Sciatis, Quod Conce≈ø≈øimus pro nobis & Haeredibus no≈øtris Principibus Cestriae, quant√πm in nobis e≈øt, Chari≈ø≈øimo Avunculo nostro Johanni Duci Lanca≈øtriae Officium Con≈øtabulariae totius Principatus no≈øtri Ce≈øtriae, & ip≈øum Johannem Constabularium eju≈ødem integri Principatus no≈øtri praefecimus: Habendum & Tenendum idem Officium ≈øibi & Haeredibus Ma≈øculis de Corpore ≈øuo exeuntibus; & qu√≤d ip≈øe & Haeredes Ma≈øculi de Corpore ≈øuo exeuntes habeant, occupent, & exerceant praedictum Officium in locis quibu≈øcunque, & ubicunque, infr√† Principatum praedictum, t√†m in Dominicis & Bundis veteri Comitatui Ce≈øtriae, in Parliamento no≈øtro apud We≈øtmona≈øterium tento die Lunae proxim√® po≈øt Festum Exaltationis Sanctae Crucis, Anno Regni no≈øtri vice≈øimo primo, annexis; (quae quid√®m Dominia, Bundae, & Comitatus, t√πnc facta fuerunt Principatus) qu√†m in veteri Comitatu praedicto: Habendum, Tenendum, & Occupandum Officium praedictum infr√† integrum Principatum ≈øupradictum, ade√≤ liber√® & integr√®, c√πm omnibus Feodis, Servitiis, Juri≈ødictionibus, & aliis Proficuis quibu≈øcunque, infr√† & per totum integrum Principatum ≈øupradictum, pro√πt & ≈øic√πt Con≈øtabularius Angliae Officium ≈øuum in re≈øiduo Regni no≈øtri Angliae po≈ø≈øidet in prae≈øenti. Eo non ob≈øtante, qu√≤d aliquod huju≈ømodi Officium infr√† Dominia & Bundas praedicta, veteri Comitatui Ce≈øtriae praedicto j√†m annexa, ant√® haec tempora non extitit u≈øitatum n√®c con≈øuetum: It√† qu√≤d alia Feoda, Servitia, Juri≈ødictiones, & Proficua, de Ligeis no≈øtris veteris Comitatus Ce≈øtriae praedicti, per ip≈øum Ducem & Haeredes Ma≈øculos de Corpore ≈øuo exeuntes, Con≈øtabularios Principatus praedicti, nullaten√πs de caetero exigantur, ≈øe√π quovi≈ømodo percipiantur in futurum, qu√†m de jure in praedicto vetere Comitatu ant√® haec tempora erat con≈øuetum; nec infr√† Dominia & Bundas praedicta eidem veteri Comitatui (ut praedictum e≈øt) j√†m anexa, qu√†m de jure percipi d ‚Ä¢ beant, & Officio Con≈øtabularii de recto pertineant. In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium, has Literas no≈øtras fieri fecimus Patentes, Sigillo Principatus no≈øtri Ce≈øtriae Signatas. Te≈øte meip≈øo apud Ca≈øtrum no≈øtrum de Holt, octavo die Augu≈øti, 22 Rich. 2. 1398.
But this Principality la≈øted not long; for that Statute was Repealed 1 Hen. 4. cap. 3.

Anno Domini 1398. the third day of February, 22 Rich. 2. Obiit 1398 died John of Gaunt Duke of Lanca≈øter, at the Bi≈øhop of Ely's Lodgings in Holborn juxt√† London, and lies Honourably Buried at St. Paul's Church in London, near to Blanch his fir≈øt Wife; So Stow: Anno Aetatis ≈øuae 60. See Wever's Funeral Monuments, pag. 365. Lib. C. fol. 82. r.

p.hi: In Dor≈øo. Placita Comitatus Ce≈øtriae apud Ce≈øtriam, coram Gilberto Domino de Talbot Ju≈øticiario Domini Regis, ad Comitatum tentum ibid√®m die Martis proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Tran≈ølationis Sancti Thomae Martyris, Anno Regni Regis Henrici quinti po≈øt Conque≈øtum ≈øexto.

div.p:
JUratores diver≈øorum Hundredorum ali√†s cor√†m Gilberto Domino de Talbot Ju≈øticiario Domini Regis Ce≈øtriae, ≈øcilic√®t ad Comitatum tentum apud Ce≈øtriam die Martis proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Sanctae Trinitatis, Anno Regni Domini Regis n√πnc quinto, prae≈øentaverunt qu√≤d Thomas de Ne≈ø≈øe de Runcorne in Comitatu Ce≈øtriae KnaveThat is, Servant. , die Martis proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Annunciationis Beatae Mariae Virginis, Anno Regni Domini Regis n√πnc quinto, apud le New≈øtede per in≈øultum & in≈øidias praecogitatas & praeordinatas in Thomam de Ce≈øter Canonicum de Norton, Magi≈øtrum ip≈øius Thomae, vi & armis in≈øultum fecit, & ip≈øum vulneravit in diver≈øis partibus Corporis c√πm quodam Cultello, vocato A Dagger: Et ip≈øum ibid√®m qua≈øi mortuum dimi≈øit, ≈øupponens qu√≤d mortem habui≈ø≈øet de ictibus praedictis: Et ad hunc diem, ≈øcilic√®t diem Martis proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Tran≈ølationis Sancti Thomae Martyris, venit praedictus Thomas de Ne≈ø≈øe in propri√¢ Per≈øon√¢ ≈øu√¢ allocutione in≈øtanti qualit√®r ≈øe de Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øione praedict√¢ ≈øuperius ei impo≈øit√¢ velit acquietare: Qui dicit, qu√≤d Dominus Rex, ut Dux Lanca≈øtriae, e≈øt & fuit ≈øei≈øitus in Dominico ≈øuo ut de Feodo, de Manerio & Dominio de Halton c√πm pertinentiis, tempore Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis praedictae confectae: Et dicit, qu√≤d idem Dominus Rex habet, & omnes Progenitores ≈øui, & omnes alii, quorum ≈øtatum ip≈øe habet in Manerio & Dominio praedicto, habuerunt & habere con≈øueverunt (√† tempore cujus contrarii memoria non exi≈øtit) infr√† Manerium & Dominium praedictum libertates ≈øub≈øcriptas; videlic√®t, vi≈øum Franci Plegii & quicquid ad illum vi≈øum pertinet, de omnibus Tenentibus & Re≈øidentibus infr√† Manerium & Dominium praedictum: Tenendum t√®r per Annum, videlic√®t, ≈øemel int√®r Fe≈øta Sancti Michaelis Archangeli & Sancti Martini in Hyeme, & iter√πm inter Fe≈øta Sancti Hilarii & Annunciationis Beatae Mariae Virginis; & terti√≤ inter Fe≈øta Sanctae Trinitatis & A≈ø≈øumptionis Beatae Mariae Virginis: Et eti√†m idem Dominus Rex habet, & omnes Progenitores ≈øui, & omnes alii, quorum ≈øtatum ip≈øe habet in Manerio & Dominio praedicto, habuerunt & habere con≈øueverunt (√† tempore cujus contrarii memoria non exi≈øtit) aliam liberam Curiam Baronis Annuat√¨m de Quinden√¢ in Quindenam ap√πd Halton, vel alibi infr√† Manerium & Dominium praedictum ubicunqu√® voluerint, Tenendam per rationabilem praemonitionem ind√® faciendam: Et in e√¢dem liber√¢ Curi√¢ Baronis habere cognitiones Placitorum de Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionibus, Conventionibus, Debitis, vetito-namio ad Sectam Partis: Et ≈øi prae≈øentatio facta fuerit per Ballivos eju≈ødem Regis, Progenitorum ≈øuorum, aut aliorum, quorum ≈øtatum ip≈øe habet in Manerio & Dominio praedicto Manerii & Dominii praedicti liberae Curiae ≈øuae praedictae, qu√≤d aliqui vel aliquis hominum Tenentium ≈øeu Re≈øidentium infr√† Manerium & Dominium ≈øuum praedictum, fregerit vel fregerint Pacem, ce√π Affraiam fecerit vel fecerint, qu√≤d t√πnc praedicti Ballivi per proce≈ø≈øum in e√¢dem Curi√¢ liber√¢ u≈øitatum, √† tempore cujus contrarii memoria non exi≈øtit, per attachiamentum & di≈øtrictionem facerent eo≈ødem Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øores praedictos venire ad re≈øpondendum in Curi√¢ praedict√¢ de Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øione praedict√¢: vel ≈øi huju≈ømodi Tran≈øgre≈øsores, aut eorum aliquis, aliquo tempore prae≈øentati in Curi√¢ Baronis praedict√¢, Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionem praedictam gratis cogno≈øcere voluerint vel voluerit, aut ≈øi convicti fuerint aut aliquis convictus fuerit, idem Dominus Rex & omnes Progenitores ≈øui, & omnes alii, quorum Statum ip≈øe habet in Manerio & Dominio praedicto, habuerunt & habere con≈øueverunt (√† tempore cujus contrarii memoria non exi≈øtit) pote≈øtatem faciendi Fines c√πm ip≈øis pro Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionibus praedictis, & Fines & Amerciamenta praedicta & punitionem praedictarum Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionum habere & levare per Ballivos ≈øuos praedictos; Pro quibus Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionibus ≈øi praedicti Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øores indictati fuerint cor√†m Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, vel cor√†m Vicecomite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, vel aliquibus aliis Mini≈øtris Domini Comitis Ce≈øtriae, pro praedictis Finibus, Amerciamentis, ≈øe√π punitione ≈øic factis, fuerunt quieti √† tempore cujus contrarii memoria non exi≈øtit: Et pro eo, qu√≤d idem Thomas de Ne≈ø≈øe
fuit Tenens praedicti Domini Regis infr√† Manerium & Dominium praedictum tempore praedictae Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis factae, & qu√≤d praedicta Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øio facta fuit apud le New≈øtede, quae e≈øt infr√† Manerium & Dominium praedictum, fuit in electione eju≈ødem Domini Regis & Mini≈øtrorum ≈øuorum Manerii & Dominii praedicti, ad puniendum Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionem praedictam virtute vi≈øus Franci Plegii ≈øui, vel virtute alterius liberae Curiae ≈øuae praedictae, &c. Et Dicit, Qu√≤d ad liberam Curiam Baronis eju≈ødem Regis, tentam apud Halton, cor√†m Willielmo de Stanley juniors, Milite, Sene≈øchallo ibid√®m, die Sabbati in ≈øeptiman√¢ Pa≈øchae, Anno Regni Domini Regis n√πnc quinto, prae≈øentatus fuit per Ricardum del Wood Balliv√πm Domini Regis Manerii & Dominii praedicti de Halton, qu√≤d praedictus Thomas de Ne≈ø≈øe t√πnc tenens & re≈øidens infr√† Manerium & Dominium praedictum, die Martis proxim√® po≈øt Fe≈øtum Annunciationis Beatae Mariae Virginis, Anno Regni Domini Regis n√πnc Secundo, fregit Pacem & in≈øultum fecit ≈øup√®r Thomam de Che≈øter Canonicum de Norton, & ip≈øum verberavit, vulneravit, & mal√® tractavit vi & armis & contr√† Pacem Domini Regis, &c. Et pro eo, qu√≤d idem Thomas de Ne≈ø≈øe praedicto die Sabbati prae≈øens in e√¢dem Curi√¢ liber√¢ de Halton extiterit, dictum fuit eidem Thomae per praedictum Willielmum de Stanley Sene≈øchallum ibid√®m, qualit√®r ip≈øe de Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øione praedict√¢ ≈øe voluerit acquietare, qui dixit qu√≤d ip≈øe Thomas de Ne≈ø≈øe Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionem praedictam non potuit dedicere, ≈øed po≈øuit ≈øe in gratiam Domini, & fecit Finem pro Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øione praedict√¢ pro quadraginta Denariis cor√†m praefato Sene≈øchallo, ≈øecund√πm con≈øuetudinem liberae Curiae Baronis praedictae; quae e≈øt eadem Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øio in praedicto Indictamento ≈øpecificata, &c. und√® non intendit, qu√≤d Dominus Rex ut Comes Ce≈øtriae ali√†s eundem Thomam Ne≈ø≈øe pro Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øione praedict√¢ punire ≈øe√π inquietare velit,‚Äî&c.

p.hi: Et Matthaeus del Mere, qui ≈øequitur pro Domino Rege, in propri√¢ Per≈øon√¢ ≈øu√¢ venit, & non pote≈øt dedicere materiam per praedictum Thomam de Ne≈ø≈øe ≈øuperi√πs allegatam; n√®c qu√¨n Dominus Rex, & omnes Progenitores ≈øui, & omnes alii, quorum Statum idem Dominus Rex habet in Manerio & Dominio de Halton praedicto, habuerunt & habere con≈øueverunt omnes libertates & con≈øuetudines praedictas, √† tempore cujus contrarii memoria hominum non exi≈øtit, &c. Ide√≤ con≈øideratum e≈øt per Judicatores Comitatus praedicti, qu√≤d praedictas Thomas de Ne≈ø≈øe de Indictamento praedicto ≈øit quietus,‚Äî&c.

div.head: Hatton nigh Daresbury.
div.p: IN the Reign of Henry the Third, Geffrey Son of Adam de Dutton (Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley) gives this Town, being of the Fee of the Barony of Halton, unto William Son of Hothy of Hatton, in the≈øe Words:‚Äî

p.hi: SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri,‚ÄîQu√≤d ego Galfridus de Dutton, Filius Adae de Dutton, dedi‚ÄîWillielmo Filio Huthi de Hatton, totam Villam de Hatton,‚Äî&c. Reddendo ind√® annuat√¨m unum Ni≈øum, vel ≈øex Denarios, ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Jacobi Apostoli, pro omnibus Servitiis‚ÄîSalvo tam√®n forin≈øeco Servitio Domini Regis, & Sect√¢ Curiae de Halton,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Domino Hamone de Ma≈øcy, Domino Hugone de Dutton, Thom√¢ de Orreby, Gilberto de Limme,‚Äî&c.

div.p: The Original of this Deed remained in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of William Merbury of Merbury nigh Great Budworth, E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1572. And an ancient Copy thereof in Parchment remains now, 1666. among the Evidences of Robert Pickering of Thelwall, Coun≈øellor at Law.
In the Feodary of Halton under Edw. 2.‚ÄîDominus Petrus de Warburton tenet Villam de Hatton pro decim√¢ parte unius Feodi Militis.

SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, Qu√≤d ego Adam de Hatton dedi‚ÄîAlano Filio Ricardi de Hellesby in libero Maritagio c√πm Beatrice Fili√¢ me√¢, quandam Terram quae vocatur Qui≈øty c√πm omnibus pertinentiis‚Äîac quintam partem Dominii Villae de Hatton, c√πm quinta parte totius Bo≈øci & Wa≈øti eju≈ødem villae‚ÄîReddendo ind√® annuat√¨m‚Äîmihi & Haeredibus meis, de ≈øe & Haeredibus ≈øuis de dicta Beatrice Genitis in Domo Capitali de Hatton
manentibus, unam Sagittam ad Nativitatem Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae‚Äî Te≈øtibus Hugone de Dutton, Petro de Thorneton,‚Äî&c. The Orignal pen√®s Grim≈ødich of Grim≈ødich in Nether-Whitley, 1572. but taken by me out of Bo≈øtock's Book of Collections, fol. 62. n. belonging to Sir Simon Dewes Baronet, 1649.

This Town gave Name to the Family of the Hattons re≈øiding here: The Hattons of Qui≈øty-Birches continuing until Peter Hatton Gentleman, with his two Sons Richard and Thomas, ≈øold unto Robert Pickering Coun≈øellor at Law, for the Sum of 1230 l. the Capital Me≈ø≈øuage of Qui≈øty-Birches, and five Me≈ø≈øuages in Hatton: Dated 1 die Maii, 13 Car. 2. 1661. Mr. Pickering bought al≈øo ≈øix Me≈ø≈øuages more in Hatton from Mr. Moores, 1653. and which Mr. Moores bought formerly part from Merbury of Merbury nigh Comberbach, and part from Starkey of Stretton. One other Me≈ø≈øuage in Hatton Mr. Pickering bought from Merbury of Walton.

I find the Town of Hatton nigh Daresbury ≈øcattered into ≈øeveral Parcels, among the Daughters and Heirs of Adam Hatton Son of William de Hatton: For Anno Gratiae 1290. 18 Edw. 1. Simon de A≈øton & Agnes Uxor ejus, John Merbury and Cicely his Wife, Randle Newton and I≈øabel his Wife, do Covenant for them and their Heirs, to pay unto Thomas de Walton and his Heirs two Shillings yearly; for which Thomas and his Heirs are to do Suit of Court to Halton, to wit, that which Adam de Hatton formerly did for the Town of Hatton: Lib. C. fol. 4. a.

At this day, 1666. Robert Pickering of Thelwall afore≈øaid, E≈øquire, is Lord of the greate≈øt Part of Hatton. The Remainder is now enjoyed by the≈øe Per≈øons following, who have Free-hold Lands here.

div.p: Hull, vide Appulton.

div.head: Kekwick.
div.p: THis ≈ømall Village of Kekwick is of the Ancient Fee of the Barons of Halton, but not mentioned in Doom≈øday-Book.

It belonged to the Duttons of Dutton very anciently, even from the Time of Henry the Fir≈øt, who≈øe Heirs ever ≈øince enjoyed the ≈øame, until by the Award of Henry the Eighth it was allotted (among other Lands) to the Daughters and Co-heirs of Sir Thomas Dutton of Dutton, 26 Hen. 8. 1534. and came to the Part of Margaret one of the Daughters of Sir Thomas Dutton afore≈øaid, who married Thomas Aston of A≈øton nigh Sutton E≈øquire, and who≈øe Heirs have ever ≈øince enjoyed the ≈øame, Sir Willoughby A≈øton Baronet being now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof entirely, 1666.

div.head: Nether-Knotsford.
div.p: WIlliam Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton held Cunetesford under Hugh Lupus Earl of Che≈øter, as we read in Doom≈øday-Book; and one Erchbrand then held it of William.

But whether that Knotsford, ≈øo held by this William, comprehended any more than that which is now a di≈øtinct Town≈øhip of it ≈øelf, calledOr, Over-Knotsford.
Knotsford-Booths, and is at this day in Halton-Fee, is ≈øome Quaere.

Certain it is, William de Tabley, Lord of Over-Tabley, was al≈øo Lord of both Knot≈øfords, Nether-Knotsford and Over-Knotsford, in the Reign of King Edward the Fir≈øt; as may appear by this following Charter, wherein he In≈øtitutes Burge≈ø≈øes in both Knotsfords; the Original whereof is in my Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Q. num. 11.

SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, Qu√≤d ego Willielmus Dominus de Tabley (that is, Over-Tabley) dedi, conce≈ø≈øi, & h√¢c prae≈øenti Chart√¢ me√¢ confirmavi omnibus & ≈øingulis Burgen≈øibus meis de Knotsford Burgagia libera, unumquodqu√® infr√† ≈øe continens duas Seliones & dimidium Terrae: Habendum & Tenendum de me & Haeredibus meis vel A≈ø≈øignatis, ≈øibi & Haeredibus ≈øuis, vel A≈ø≈øignatis eorum, liber√®, quiet√®, ben√®, & in pace, & jure Haereditario in perpetu√πm; c√πm Housbold & Haybold Burgen≈øibus de Knotsford in nemore de Knotsford, & in Turbari√†; Et c√πm Housbold & Haybold Burgen≈øibus de Boys [id e≈øt, Knot≈øford-Booths, ≈øive Over-Knotsford] in nemore de Boys, & Turbariam & Communem Pa≈øturam utrique eorum de Boys & Knotsford omnibus animalibus ≈øuis, infr√† metas de Knotsford & metas de Boys, quantum praefata Terra poterit ≈øu≈øtinere in Hyeme, & liberam Communam in Mor√¢ de Cre≈ø≈øewalleclef (≈øicut medietas aquae praecucurrit) ad metendum & ad falcandum, ≈øalv√¢ venditione eju≈ødem Herbagii: Reddendo ind√® annuat√¨m mihi & Haeredibus meis vel A≈ø≈øignatis, de quolibet Burgagio XII Denarios, ad duos Anni terminos, videlic√®t, ≈øex Denarios ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae, & ≈øex Denarios ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Martini in Hyeme: Et unu≈øqui≈øque eorum tertium meliorem Porcum nomine Pannagii pro Porcis ≈øuis nutritis infr√† metas Willielmi, qui pingues ≈øunt de Pe≈øon√¢ eju≈ødem Willielmi: Et qu√≤d dicti Burgen≈øes molant blada ≈øua ad molendinum meum de Knotsford pro XX grano: Et ≈øi contigerit, qu√≤d molendinarius aliquod damnum Sutoribus ad molendinum fecerit, per Vicinos ≈øuos ≈øecund√πm quantitatem delicti in Curi√¢ emendabit: Et quicunque dictorum Burgen≈øium panem de≈øiderat obtinere in Furno pi≈øtum infr√† quatuor portas Villae, pro quoquo Bu≈øhell unum Obolum Furnario meo prae≈øtabit; & qu√≤d nullus eorum infr√† quatuor portas Villae nullum Furnum elevabit: Et qu√≤d dicti Burgen≈øes mei faciant Sectam ad Curiam meam magnam bis in Anno, videlic√®t, ad proximam Curiam p√≤st Pa≈øcha, & ad proximam Curiam po≈øt Fe≈øtum Michaelis: Et qu√≤d Portimotus teneatur in eodem Burgo de tribus Septimanis in tres Septimanas: Et qu√≤d omnia Placita de Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionibus, Attachiamentis, Conventionibus fractis placitantur in e√¢dem Curi√¢: Et quicunque dictorum Burgen≈øium pro aliquo forisfacto in mi≈øericordia ceciderit, non det ni≈øi XII Denarios ant√® Judicium; & po≈øt Judicium, rationabilem mi≈øericordiam ≈øecund√πm quantitatem delicti, nis√¨ id forisfactum ad Gladium pertineat: Et qu√≤d dicti Burgen≈øes mei int√®r ≈øe idoneum Ballivum eligant & habeant, qui in Officio ≈øuo mihi & Burgen≈øibus meis Sacramenta ob≈øervanda fidelit√®r prae≈øtabit: Et qu√≤d dicti Burgen≈øes de Knotsford & de Boys illam Terram vendere, quandocunqu√† & cuicunqu√®, ≈øe√π invadiare po≈ø≈øint, ≈øalvo viro Religio≈øo & Domino Capitali eju≈ødem Feodi. Et ego ver√≤ praefatus Willielmus, & Haeredes mei vel A≈ø≈øignati, praedictis Burgen≈øibus meis de Knotsford omnia Burgagia ≈øua, & A≈ø≈øignatis eorum, pro omnibus Servitiis Secularibus, Exactionibus, Con≈øuetudinibus, & Demandis, Salv√¢ Summonitione de Culward, contr√† omnes homines & foeminas Warrantizabimus. In hujus rei Te≈øtimonium prae≈øentem Chartam Sigilli mei munimine roboravi. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Domino Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy, Willielmo de Modburlegh, Willielmo de Manwaring, Rogero de Toft, Ad√¢ de Tabley, at multis aliis.

This Deed afore≈øaid was made about the Year 1292. For this William de Tabley
obtained the King's Charter for a Saturday-Market Weekly here at Nether-Knotsford, which yet continueth; and al≈øo for a Fair to be kept here Yearly in Vigili√¢, & in Die, & in Cra≈øtino Apo≈øtolorum Petri & Pauli, id e≈øt, June 28, 29, & 30. Dated at Wal≈øingham, 3 die Augu≈øti, 20 Edw. 1. Which Charter was al≈øo Confirmed to William his Son and Heir, and another Fair Granted to be kept here Yearly in Vigili√°, & in Die, & in Crastino Apo≈øtolorum Simonis & Judae, id e≈øt, October 27, 28, & 29. Dated at Hartford, 14 die Februarii, 6 Edw. 3. 1332. Lib. C. fol. 223. a. Ex Rotulo Chartarum de Anno 6 Edw. 3. in Turre Londinen≈øi.

How the Royalty of Nether-Knotsford was ≈øhared between Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, and the afore≈øaid William de Tabley, in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, will more fully appear by the≈øe following Deeds, made about 22 Edw. 1. 1294. the Originals whereof now remain in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Earl of Bridgewater, 1667.

CUM Willielmus de Tabley tenuit totam Villam de Knotsford [He meaneth Nether-Knotsford] de Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy per Servitium Per tertiam partem Feodi Militis, held of the Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy; ut in Rentali de Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, de 3 Hen. 4 Lib. B. pag. 209.
Militare, ac Dominus no≈øter Edwardus Rex Angliae conce≈ø≈øerat per Chartam ≈øuam eidem Willielmo Mercatum & Feriam certis diebus in e√¢dem Vill√¢ habenda; Idem Willielmus po≈øtmodo Feoffavit plures Burgen≈øes in e√¢dem Vill√¢ de Burgagiis & certis Terris ei≈ødem annexis; Tenendum de eodem & Haeredibus ≈øuis immediat√®: Ricardus de Ma≈ø≈øy Dominus Capitalis, clamans & A≈ø≈øerens hoc Feoffamentum fore ad damnum & exhaeredationem ≈øui & ≈øuorum manife≈øtam, ≈øecund√πm virtutem Statuti Domini no≈øtri Edwardi de Terris & Tenementis alienatis, Tenendis de Capitalibus Dominis Feodi immediat√®: It√† convenit amicabilit√®r int√®r eo≈ødem, videlic√®t, qu√≤d praedictus Willielmus dedit & conce≈ø≈øit dicto Ricardo & Haeredibus ≈øuis vel a≈ø≈øignatis, ≈øalvis Capitalibus Dominis ≈øuis, medietatem omnium exituum & cuju≈ølibet Commodi de praedicto Mercato, Curi√¢, & Feri√¢ eju≈ødem Villae provenientium: Conce≈ø≈øit eti√†m, quod medietas Terrarum & Tenementorum eju≈ødem Villae, quae tenentur, & in futuro debeant teneri, in Burgagiis c√πm Terris ei≈ødem annexis, Teneantur de praedicto Ricardo immediat√® per Servitia & Con≈øuetudines ind√® ab antiquo Debita & Con≈øueta; Salvo tam√®n eidem Willielmo, & Haeredibus ≈øuis vel A≈ø≈øignatis, redditu pro ei≈ødem Terris & Tenementis; videlic√®t, pro quolibet Burgagio & Terr√¢ eidem annex√¢, duodecem Denariis per Annum, & Pannagio, c√πm Sect√° ad molendinum ≈øuum ≈øecund√πm quod vicini eju≈ødem Villae faciunt: PRO qu√¢ quid√®m Conce≈ø≈øione & Donatione praedictus Ricardus de Ma≈ø≈øy conce≈ø≈øit dicto Willielmo de Tabley, & Haeredibus ≈øuis vel A≈ø≈øignatis, qu√≤d licit√® po≈ø≈øent dare & vendere aliam medietatem Terrarum & Tenementorum quae tenentur, vel quae in futuro debeant teneri, in Burgagiis & Terris ei≈ødem annexis in praedict√¢ Vill√¢, & tenendum de eodem Willielmo & Haeredibus ≈øuis immediat√®; Salvis tam√®n eidem Ricardo, & Haeredibus ≈øuis vel A≈ø≈øignatis, Servitiis & Con≈øuetudinibus ind√® ab antiquo Debitis & Con≈øuetis: Conce≈ø≈øit eti√†m praedictus Ricardus, qu√≤d praedictus Willielmus & Haeredes ≈øui vel A≈ø≈øignati, quieti ≈øint in perpetuum de Servitiis & Con≈øuetudinibus, quae ab antiquo debentur de Terris & Tenementis, quae tenentur, vel in futuro debeant teneri, in e√¢dem Vill√¢ de praedicto Ricardo in Burgagiis & Terris ei≈ødem annexis ≈øecund√πm Conce≈ø≈øionem dicti Willielmi. In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium alter alterius ≈øcripto in medio inci≈øo Sigillum ≈øuum appo≈øuit. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Willielmo de Modburleg, Ad√¢ de Tabley, Thoma de Legh, Rogero de Toft, Willielmo del Mere, Johanne de Legh, Willielmo de Meynwaring, Thoma Clerico, & aliis.

SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, Qu√≤d ego Willielmus de Tabley, Dominus de Knotsford, dedi, conce≈ø≈øi, & hac prae≈øenti Charta mea confirmavi Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy Militi Domino meo, & I≈øabellae Uxori ejus, omnes Terras, Redditus, Homagia, Con≈øuetudines, & Servitia ≈øub≈øcripta in Villa de Knotsford; videlic√®t, de Burgagio quod Thomas Pratin tenet; & Burgagio quod Willielmus Filius Amelie tenet; & Burgagio quod Alexander Mucheman tenet; & Burgagio quod Elias Rotarius tenet; & Burgagio quod Radulfus Molendinarius tenet; & Burgagio quod Thomas Filius Jordani tenet; & illis duobus Burgagiis quae Ricardus Filius Adae Brodfot tenet; & de duobus Burgagiis quae Robertus Pi≈øtor tenet; & de Burgagio quod Hugo le Harper tenet; & de uno Crofto quod Alexander Mucheman tenet; & de duobus Burgagiis quae Magi≈øter Rogerus de Tablegh tenet; & de duobus Burgagiis quae Nicolaa Filia
Adami de Toft tenet; & duobus Burgagiis quae Rogerus Mekehove tenet; & de un√¢ Domo c√πm Curtilagio, quam Margeria del Broke tenet ad terminum; & de uno Burgagio quod Ricardus le Harper quond√†m tenuit; & de Burgagio quod Robertus Pe≈øe tenuit ad terminum de Adamo Hurne. Habendum & tenendum praedictis Ricardo & I≈øabellae, & Haeredibus vel A≈ø≈øignatis ip≈øius Ricardi, liber√®, quiet√®, ben√®, & pacific√®, c√πm omnibus Libertatibus, Commoditatibus, Ey≈øiamentis, E≈øchaetis, praedictis Terris, Redditibus, Homagiis, Con≈øuetudinibus, Servitiis quoquo modo ≈øpectantibus. Faciendo ind√® ip≈øe Ricardus & I≈øabella, & Haeredes vel A≈ø≈øignati ip≈øius Ricardi, pro me & Haeredibus vel A≈ø≈øignatis meis, unam Sectam per afforciamentum
Efforcement Gallice, Utmo≈øt endeavor, with all force and power. ad Curiam Domini Hamonis de Ma≈ø≈øy de Dunham per rationabilem Summonitionem, & per facturam Hayae & HiriBy making of the Hedge and Common ‚Ä¢ ence. Communis, quae ego & Antece≈ø≈øores mei facere Con≈øuevimus c√πm Feodo de Tatton Domino de Dunham pro Vill√¢ de Knotsford, pro omni Servitio, Con≈øuetudine, exactione qu√¢cunque, & demand√¢: Et ego praedictus Willielmus & Haeredes mei omnes Terras, Redditus, Homagia, Con≈øuetudines, & Servitia c√πm ≈øuis pertinentiis, ≈øic√πt praedictum e≈øt, praedictis Ricardo & I≈øabellae, & Haeredibus vel A≈ø≈øignatis ip≈øius Ricardi, contr√† omnes Homines & Faeminas Warrantizabimus, Acquietabimus, & in omnibus defendemus per praedictum Servitium in perpetu√πm. In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium huic prae≈øenti Scripto Sigillum meum appo≈øui. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Hugone de Venables, Radulfo de Vernon Militibus, Willielmo de Modburlegh, Willielmo de Meynwaring, Thom√¢ de Legh, Johanne de Legh, Willielmo de Mar√¢, Adamo de Tabley, Eytropo de Mulinton, Roberto Par≈øon√¢ medietatis Eccle≈øiae de Limme, & aliis.

So that by the≈øe Deeds it ≈øhould ≈øeem that William de Tabley held Nether-Knotsford of Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton immediately, but mediately from the Ancient Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy: And upon the Agreement before at large ≈øet down, Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton was to have one Moiety of the Mannor of Nether-Knotsford, and half of the Profits of the Market, Fair, and Court; and William of Tabley the other half.

This William de Tabley writ him≈øelf Dominus de Knotsford, and ≈øometimes Dominus de Tabley, which is to be under≈øtood of Over-Tabley. He married Alice Daughter of William de Mobburley the Elder: She was Widow 27 Edw. 1. 1299. and then lived at her Principal Man≈øion-hou≈øe at Nether-Knotsford, F. num. 1, 2. For William her late Husband had not long before granted away the third Part of Over-Tabley (which was all the Lands in Over-Tabley wherewith he ≈øtood then po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed) unto Sir John Grey, Son of Sir Reginald Grey, 22 Edw. 1. And Sir John Grey granted all his Lands in Over-Tabley, which he had of the Grant of William de Tabley, unto Roger de Leyce≈øter Lord of Nether-Tabley, together with all the Lands, Rents, and Services which Alice the Widow of William de Tabley then held in Dower, de praedictis Tenementis in praedict√¢ Vill√¢ de Over-Tabley, to revert to the ≈øaid Roger Leyce≈øter after her death. This was about Anno Domini 1298. F. num. 1.

This William de Tabley, who died about 1297. 26 Edw. 1. had I≈ø≈øue William de Tabley, elde≈øt Son; and John de Tabley, another Son: Lib. C. fol. 222. m. And al≈øo two Daughters; Agnes married William de Torperley, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Margaret; and Alice, another Daughter of William de Tabley.

p.hi: ‚öú The≈øe Notes following are the Notes of John Hal≈øey of Lincolns-Inn, E≈øquire, extracted out of the Evidences of the Earl of Bridgewater, 1667.

div.p: William de Tabley, Lord of Nether-Knotsford, Son and Heir of the afore≈øaid William, had a Charter from Edward the Black Prince, dated 4 die Aprilis, 11 Edw. 3. 1337. to excu≈øe him all his Life from being put on any Jury, and from being Mayor, Sheriff, Coroner, or other Officer, again≈øt his will. The Original now remains among the Evidences of the Earl of Bridgewater, 1667. His Wife was named Aunora: She was Widow 14 Edw. 3. and had I≈ø≈øue William de Tabley, under Age, and Ward to Hugh Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, 16 Edw. 3. and died 26 Edw. 3. at the Age of 16 Years, leaving his four Si≈øters to be his Heirs, Maud, Emme, Marion, and Agnes.
1. Maud married Richard de Cotton. She and her Children were all dead 45 Edw. 3. and her Part fell to the other Si≈øters.
2. Emme, the ≈øecond Si≈øter, married Walter Spicer of Che≈øter. She was dead before 26 Edw. 3. and Richard Spicer their Son was found Heir.

3. Marion, or Mary, (for ≈øome Deeds call her by the one Name, and ≈øome by the other) married Roger Son of William de Min≈øhull; who, with her Husband, Lea≈øed a fourth Part of the Mannor of Knotsford to Thomas Stathum for forty Years, 38 Edw. 3. Afterwards ≈øhe married Thomas Hyde of Warford, who, with the ≈øaid Thomas her ≈øecond Husband, Demi≈øed to David Pinke her ≈øixth Part of the Mannor of Nether-Knotsford, which came to her by the death of Agnes her Si≈øter; Rent per Annum 3 l. 6 s. 8 d. 46 Edw. 3.
4. Agnes, the fourth Si≈øter and Co-heir, married Robert Son of William de Downes, living 27 Edw. 3. After ≈øhe married Warin de Croxton, but left no I≈ø≈øue.

So that all William of Tabley's Moyety of Nether-Knotsford was now in Spicer and Marion, who ≈øcattered the ≈øame into certain Parcels: For Richard Son of Walter Spicer Granted to Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, 45 Edw. 3. all his ≈øixth Part of Nether-Knot≈øford, which de≈øcended to him by the Decea≈øe of Agnes Wife of Warin de Croxton; which Sir John ≈øold to one John Shard, and others, 50 Edw. 3. and had it Re-granted back to him the ≈øaid Sir John, 3 Rich. 2. So that Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy had now the ≈øixth Part of William de Tabley's Moyety, the other Moyety being his own by De≈øcent.

Sir Hugh Hul≈øe had two fourth Parts Granted to him by John Stathum Nephew to Thomas Stathum his Uncle, 1 Hen. 4. and which the ≈øaid Thomas Stathum bought from Marion de Tabley and Richard Spicer. And Hugh de Knotsford al≈øo Relea≈øeth to Sir Hugh Hul≈øe, 1 Hen. 4. his Right in a third Part of a fourth Part, which the ≈øaid Hugh had from David Pinke, who had it from Spicer.

Marion, or Mary de Tabley, the Widow of Thomas Hyde, 19 Rich. 2. grants to Hugh de Toft Chaplain, Dominium de Knotsford; who re-grants the ≈øame to Mary for Life, the Remainder to Thomas Ha≈øelford and Joan his Wife, Daughter of the ≈øaid Mary, and to the Heirs of their Bodies.

And in Anno 21 Rich. 2. this Mary Covenants with Cicely Daughter of the la≈øt William de Mobberley, to ≈øettle all ≈øhe had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in Nether-Knotsford by Fine, fir≈øt to her ≈øelf, and the Heirs of her Body; The Remainder to Sir Hugh Hul≈øe and Margery his Wife, in Tail;‚ÄîThe Remainder to Thomas Hul≈øe, their Son, in Tail;‚ÄîAnd ≈øo to Edmund, and ≈øo to Andrew, Brothers of the ≈øaid Thomas;‚ÄîAnd ≈øo to Elinour, and ≈øo to Elizabeth, Si≈øters of the ≈øaid Thomas, in Tail;‚ÄîThe Remainder to the ≈øaid Cicely and her Heirs: And to cau≈øe Thomas Ha≈øelford to grant the Marriage of Elizabeth his Daughter and Heir to the ≈øaid Cicely. And after, on Tue≈øday po≈øt Clau≈øum Pa≈øchae, 21 Rich. 2. the ≈øaid Mary Levied a Fine of eight Marks Rent in Knotsford, of the fourth Part of the Mannor of Knotsford, of the fourth Part of the Market, Fair, Toll, and Stallage of Nether-Knotsford, to John Brun≈øtath Par≈øon of Mobberley, and to Thomas Swetenham of Mobberley; who re-grant the ≈øame to Mary, as before,‚Äî&c. and to Sir Hugh Hul≈øe,‚Äî&c. as in the former Covenant: And afterward Mary died in the ≈øame Year, 21 Rich. 2. her Daughter Joan, the Wife of Thomas Ha≈øelford, being dead before her.

The ≈øaid Cicely, one of the Daughters of the la≈øt William de Mobberley, and Si≈øter and Co-heir of Sir Raufe Mobberley of Mobberley, and Widow to John Dumbill of Mobberley, makes Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton her Attorney to receive all Toll, and other Profits in Knotsford, belonging to her jure Haereditatis po≈øt dece≈ø≈øum Mariae de Tabley t√πnc nup√®r defunctae: Which Cicely died 5 Hen. 4. and who≈øe Daughter Margery married Sir Hugh Hul≈øe. She had al≈øo a Daughter called Ellen, who (as I conceive) died without I≈ø≈øue.

This Sir Hugh Hul≈øe having now got in all Titles to the five Parts in ≈øix to be divided of William de Tabley's Moyety, and having the Marriage and Cu≈øtody of Elizabeth Daughter and Heir of Thomas Ha≈ø≈øelford granted unto him, he married the ≈øaid Elizabeth to David Hul≈øe, Son of John Hul≈øe of Norbury in Che≈øhire: To which David, Sir Hugh Hul≈øe gave all his Lands in Knotsford, 3 Hen. 5. This Right continued in the Heirs of the ≈øaid David Hul≈øe, until Hugh de Hul≈øe ≈øold the ≈øame unto Richard Brereton of Tatton E≈øquire, 32 Elizabethae, 1590. And ≈øo the whole Royalty of Nether-Knot≈øford was inve≈øted in the Lords of Tatton. Which Richard ≈øetled all his E≈øtate, having no I≈ø≈øue, on Sir Thomas Egerton Lord Chancellor of England, from whom the Earls of Bridgewater.
Su far out of the Notes ≈øent me by John Hal≈øey E≈øquire.
‚öú The Earl of Bridgewater then is now Lord of Nether-Knotsford, 1667. wherein are above forty Charterers at this day.

I have ≈øeen the Copy of a Deed in a Book of Collections by John Booth of Twamlow in Che≈øhire, noted Lib. H. pag. 137. f. taken out of an ancient Parchment Roll pen√®s Davenport of Henbury; wherein John Hall Mayor of Knotsford is Sub≈øcribed as Witne≈øs, about the later end of Edward the Fir≈øt, in the≈øe Words:‚Äî

p.hi: SCiant‚ÄîQu√≤d ego Robertus Filius Johannis Hurne dedi‚ÄîYockin

de Duiton duo Burgagia, quae habui ex dono Patris mei, in Vill√¢ de Knotsford.‚ÄîReddendo ind√® annuat√¨m Domino Capitali Villae de Knotsford, qui pro tempore fuerit, octodecem Denarios. ‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Domino Rogero de Venables Rectore Eccle≈øiae de Ro≈øthorne, Rogero de Toft, Johanne de Bexton, Johanne de Aul√¢ t√πnc Majore Villae de Knotsford, Thom√¢ Snowball, Eli√¢ Rotario, Johanne Coco,‚Äî&c.

div.p: I have al≈øo ≈øeen an Original Deed, noted D. num. 9. then in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of George Wil≈øon of Nether-Knotsford, June 2. 1650. wherein Adam Putill grants unto John Cooke, totam illam medietatem illius Burgagii qu√≤d habui juxt√† Burgagium Johannis Gleyve, de quo quid√®m Burgagio ego dictus Adam feoffavi Reginaldum Pi≈øtorem in ali√¢ medietate illius Burgagii, in Vill√¢ de Knotsford‚ÄîReddendo Aliciae Genero≈øae Dominae annuat√¨m duodecem Denarios,‚Äî&c. Et po≈øt obitum eju≈ødem Aliciae, duodecem Denarios Domino Villae de Knot≈øford,‚Äî&c. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Johanne de Legh, Rogero de Toft, Johanne de Aul√¢ t√πnc Majore de Knotsford, Ely√¢ Rotario, Thom√¢ Lilicock, Thom√¢ Snowball, Ricardo Kylting, Rogero Filio Jordani, & aliis. Lib. C. fol. 221. b.

On the We≈øt ≈øide of the Steeple is Legh of Booths Coat Quartered with another, as is expre≈ø≈øed in the Margin; and a little above that,
under the Window where the Bells hang, is written on the Stone, ROBERT WEBSTER AND MAUD HIS WIFE: WILLIAM HEFELD AND MARGERY HIS WIFE. The≈øe probably were Benefactors to the Building of that Steeple with Stone, which was in the Reign of Henry the Eighth.

There is al≈øo a Chappel of Ea≈øe ≈øituated within the Lower Town of Knotsford, with a School-hou≈øe adjoyning. Sir John Legh of Booths purcha≈øed from the King certain Lands in Nether-Knotsford, Sudlow, and Over-Knotsford, 3 Edw. 6. which in old time were given for the finding of a ≈øufficient School-ma≈øter at Nether-Knotsford, and al≈øo for finding of a Prie≈øt to ≈øay Service in the ≈øaid Chappel; which Lands came to the King by the Statute of Di≈ø≈øolution of Chantries and Abbies.

Now the ≈øaid Sir John Legh was bound in a Recogni≈øance of 200 Marks to the King, to pay out of tho≈øe Lands 5 l. 6 s. 8 d. yearly, to the Maintenance of a School-ma≈øter, and to ≈øuffer the ≈øaid Chappel to ≈øtand for Admini≈øtration of the Communion: Dated 3 Edw. 6. And which Moneys are yearly paid by his Heirs at this day.
An ancient Copy of which Recognizance remains with me, 1667.

div.head: Over-Knotsford, alias Knotsford-Booths.
div.p: OVer-Knotsford is belonging to the ancient Fee of the Barons of Halton.
In the Feodary of Halton under Edward the Second, it is ≈øaid‚ÄîJohannes de Legh tenet Knotsford-Booths pro ≈øext√¢ parte unius Feodi Militis.
This Town of Knotsford-Booths, with Norbury-Booths, William de Tabley Lea≈øed to Sir John Orreby, for the Life of Sir John, 11 Edw. 1.

Sir John Orrely ≈øelleth his Title herein to John Legh and Ellen his Wife; and afterwards William de Tabley relea≈øeth to John Legh, and his Heirs, all his Right in Knot≈øford-Booths and Norbury-Booths, die Martis proxim√® ante Fe≈øtum Sancti Bartholomaei Apo≈øtoli, 28 Edw. 1. 1300. Lib. C. fol. 219. b. c. d. e. g.
The Heirs of this John Legh have ever ≈øince enjoyed the ≈øame to this day, 1667. Peter Legh of Booths E≈øquire being now Lord thereof, and under Age.
There are now about twelve ≈ømall Charterers in Knotsford-Booths.

‚öúThis John Legh, who Purcha≈øed Knotsford-Booths c√πm Norbury-Booths from William de Tabley, was younger Son of William Venables de Bradwell, by Agnes his ≈øecond Wife, Daughter and Heir of Richard Legh of High-Legh de We≈øt-Hall, Lord of the Moiety of High-Legh, and Widow of Richard de Limme.

This John, being brought up with his Mother in High-Legh, was ≈øir-named de Legh from the Place of his Re≈øidence, as was the manner of tho≈øe Ages; which Sir-name his Po≈øterity retained, and bear the Coat of Arms of Venables, with the di≈øtinction of a Bend Gules, even to this day.

William Venables, Father of this John de Legh, was younger Brother to Sir Hugh Venables of Kinderton; which William gave to John de Legh his Son Lands in Ro≈øthorn; which William, Son of William Venables of Bradwell, and Half-Brother of this John, relea≈øed unto him, 13 Edw. 2. 1319. Which Lands in Ro≈øthorn, Legh of Booths enjoyeth at this day, 1667.

This John de Legh, the fir≈øt Legh of Booths, gave to Robert Legh his younger Son a Tenement in High-Legh, which Sir John Legh (elder Brother of Robert) confirmed to the ≈øaid Robert, 1336. 10 Edw. 3. which Tenement continued in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Leghs of Adlington, until Sir Vrian Legh of Adlington not very long ≈øince ≈øold the ≈øame to John Legh of Aldford, who ≈øold it to Richard Legh of Swineyard in High-Legh, his Brother, 45 Elizabethae, 1602. And from this Robert, the Leghs of Adlington are Originally de≈øcended: Of which ≈øee more in High-Legh.

Ellen, the Widow of this fir≈øt John Legh, purcha≈øed a Weekly Market on the Wedne≈øday, and a Fair to be kept yearly at Knotsford-Booths on Tue≈øday and Wedne≈øday in Whit≈øon-week, under the Seal of the Exchequer at Che≈øter: Dated 18 die Maii, 9 Edw. 3. Which Fair is at this day kept accordingly; but the Market vani≈øhed long ago. Lib. C. fol. 219. l.

‚öú Here ≈øhould follow the De≈øcent of Legh of Booths: But becau≈øe I was denied the Peru≈øal of the Evidences, by Robert Venables E≈øquire, younger Son of Peter Venables of Kinderton E≈øquire, who hath married the Widow of John Legh late of Booths decea≈øed, I mu≈øt omit the ≈øame; and therefore let Po≈øterity blame him for it, and not me.

div.head: Lachford.
div.p: WIlliam Son of Sam≈øon relea≈øed Domino ≈øuo Hugoni de Boydell, pro defectu Servitii ≈øui retr√≤, Lachford c√πm omnibus pertinentiis: Pro h√¢c donatione Hugo dedit Valentiam quatuor Marcarum: Te≈øtibus Radulfo de Manwaring t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, &c. tempore Ricardi Primi: Lib. C. fol. 286. t. The Original pen√®s Thomas Merbury de Merbury Armigerum, 1666. This was at the ≈øame time, and before the ≈øame Witne≈ø≈øes, when he Relea≈øed Gropenhale al≈øo. Vide Gropenhale.

q.p: NOverint Univer≈øi,‚ÄîAnno Domini 1305. 32 Edw. 1. Int√®r Dominum Johannem de Boydell Militem ex parte un√¢, & Davidem Filium & Haeredem Patricii de Barton ex altera; ≈øuper Partitione Va≈øtorum de Lachford‚ÄîPraedictus David cognovit, qu√≤d tres partes omnimodi ≈øoli in eadem Villa ≈øint jus & Haereditas ip≈øius Johannis‚Äî& quarta pars e≈øt Haereditas ip≈øius Davidis: Lib. C. fol. 285. c. The Original hereof al≈øo in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Mr. Merbury.

div.p: Sir John Daniell and Joan his Wife Purcha≈øed to them and their Heirs, from Edward ≈øtiled The Black Prince, then Earl of Che≈øter, to keep two Fairs in Lachford yearly; one upon the fifth and ≈øixth days of May, and the other upon the ≈øeventeenth and eighteenth days of October; and al≈øo to have two Market-days Weekly, every Wedne≈øday and Friday, ni≈øi ≈øint ad nocumenta Vicinorum Mercatorum: Datum apud Ce≈øtriam, 3 die Martii, 41 Edw. 3. under the Seal of the Exchequer. The Original pen√®s Merbury de Merbury. Lib. C. fol. 283. f.

Anno 26 Edw. 3. Partition was made of the Inheritance of William Boydell, in Che≈øhire and Wales, between Sir John Danyell of Gropenhale and Joan his Wife on the one Part, and Howel ap Owen Voil on the other Part. Lib. C. fol. 282. q.

William the Son of Howell called him≈øelf by the Name of Boydell, and had to Wife Cicely Si≈øter of William Belew, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Boydell: She was Widow 8 Hen. 4. for William Boydell her Husband died 16 Rich. 2. 1392. Lib. C. fol. 286. v. & 281. g.

Thomas Boydell had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, who died without I≈ø≈øue; al≈øo Margaret, married to Hugh Reddi≈øh; and I≈øabel, married to John Alburgham, afterwards to Nicolas de Langton: Which Margaret and I≈øabell divide the Inheritance of Thomas Boydell their Father, 5 Hen. 5. 1416. Lib. C. fol. 282. l. And among other Lands, the≈øe of Lachford were divided between them.

The Part belonging to Reddi≈øh came to William Merbury of Merbury E≈øq in Right of Maud his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Thomas Reddi≈øh of Caterich in Gropenhale: They were married 2 & 3 Philip and Mary, 1556. who≈øe Heir is now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of one Moiety of Lachford, 1666.

The Part belonging to Alburgham de≈øcended to two Daughters and Heirs, 3 Hen. 7. Con≈øtance, Daughter of Gilbert Alburgham, married Henry Byrom of Byrom in Lanca≈øhire; I≈øabell, the other Daughter, married James Holt of Gri≈øelhur≈øt in Lanca≈øhire.

Francis Holt, and Thomas his Son, ≈øell all their Part of Lachford unto Thomas Starkey of Stretton E≈øquire, 25 Elizabethae. Starkey ≈øells it to Thomas Brooke of Norton E≈øquire,
43 Eliz. and Thomas Brooks of Norton ≈øells it to Thomas Ireland of Beu≈øy nigh Warrington, 43 Elizabethae. He was afterwards Sir Thomas Ireland.

Thomas Ireland, Son of Sir Thomas, with other Brothers and Feoffees, ≈øell their Lands in Lachford unto Thomas Blackborn, 5 Car. 1. who≈øe Son Thomas Blackborn of Lachford now enjoyeth the ≈øame, 1666.
‚öú Byrom's Part in Lachford was ≈øold to the Ance≈øtors of the≈øe Free-holders in Lachford following.

div.p: Byrom of Lanca≈øhire retains yet the Advow≈øon of the Church of Gropenhale.

div.head: Legh juxta Barterton, vulgo Little-Legh.
div.p: THe Town≈øhip of Little-Legh was held by William Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton, in the Time of the Conqueror, as appears by Doom≈øday-Book.

Out of the Originals remaining among the Evidences at Dutton, 1649. Simon Fitz-Osbern, being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this Village about the Reign of King John, Grants the ≈øame unto Hugh Dutton, Son of Hugh Dutton of Dutton, and to his Heirs; ≈øcilic√®t, totam Villam de Lei√¢ in Feu-firma: Reddendo annuat√¨m duas Marcas Argenti ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Martini: Lib. C. fol. 154. f. Which Rent is paid by the Heirs of Dutton at this day, 1666. as to the Mannor of Harden-Ca≈øtle.

Roger Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and Baron of Halton, acquitteth Hugh Dutton of Dutton de Judice de Legh√¢ in Hundredo meo de Halton; (id e≈øt) Of the Judger of Legh in his Hundred of Halton, about Anno Domini 1200. Lib. C. fol. 154. g.
To be Judger of a Town, was to ≈øerve at the Lord's Court on the Jury for ≈øuch a Town; whereof Dutton was di≈øcharged for Little-Legh by this Deed.

The Hamlet of Clatterwig in Little-Legh was Purcha≈øed by Sir Thomas Dutton of Dutton, from Hugh de Clatterwig, in the Reign of Henry the Third: Hiis Te≈øtibus, Domino Galfrido de Dutton t√πnc Sene≈øchallo, Domino Galfrido de Budworth Filio Adae de Dutton, Domino Hugone Priore de Norton, Ricardo de A≈øton√¢, Rogero de Toft,‚Äî&c. Lib. C. fol. 156. t.
This Town≈øhip hath ever ≈øince remained to the Heirs of Dutton, even to this day, 1666. and is 25 l. 18 s. 00 d. of an old Rent.

list.head: Charterers in Little-Legh, 1666.
list.item: 1. Sir Gilbert Ireland of Hut in Lanca≈øhire, one Cottage, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Thomas Clough.
2. William Touchet of Nether-Whitley E≈øquire, one Tenement in Lea≈øe.
3. William Bentley of Northwich, Phy≈øician, two Crofts, but no Hou≈øe.
4. Jo≈øeph Ba≈ønet of Legh, formerly part of Dr. Bentley's.
