9. Mrs. Anne Mo≈øeley of Howes-end, one Cottage, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one Lawren≈øon.

div.p: In this Town≈øhip is an ancient Chappel of Ea≈øe, called Little-Legh Chappel, within the Pari≈øh of Great-Budworth. It was lately Repaired by the Inhabitants of Little-Legh, Anno Domini 1664. whereunto Five Pounds was given, towards the Repair thereof, by the Pari≈øhioners of Great-Budworth, me prae≈øente.

div.head: Legh, vulgo High-Legh,
div.p: GIlbert Venables, Baron of Kinderton, held this Town in the Reign of The Conqueror, under Hugh Lupus Earl of Che≈øter: Ulviet & Dot pro duobus Maneriis tenuerunt; ibi una Hida Geldabilis; ibi Presbyter & Eccle≈øia, c√πm uno Villano, & duobus Bordariis, habens dimidiam Carucam; ibi Silva unius Leuvae Longitudine, & dimidiae Leuvae in Latitudine: As you may read more at large in Doom≈øday-book.
So that it appears here was a Church at the Time of the Conque≈øt; but at this day no Prints thereof remain.

Here is now a Chappel of Ea≈øe in this Town≈øhip, called High-Legh Chappel, within the Pari≈øh of Ro≈øthorn, which was built by Thomas Legh of High-Legh de Ea≈øt-Hall E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1581. as I find the Year, his Name, and Coat of Arms engraven in the Stone on the ≈øide of the ≈øame Chappel: In which very Year his Grand≈øon, George Legh, married Elizabeth ≈øecond Daughter of Peter Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, and Co-heir to the Lands of her Mother Elizabeth, ≈øole Daughter and Heir of Edward Colwich of Colwich in Stafford≈øhire, near Ow≈øley-Bridge, as appears by my own Deeds; and in which Year al≈øo the ≈øaid Thomas Legh died: which Thomas built the New Hall of Stone in High-Legh, called The Ea≈øt-Hall, in which Hou≈øe his Heirs do now Inhabit, the Old Hall there being pulled down.

Here was al≈øo another ancient Chappel of Ea≈øe in this Town≈øhip, belonging to the Family of the Leghs of the We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh: The Fabrick is yet ≈øtanding near to his Hou≈øe; but now converted to other U≈øes, by the Heirs of that Family. This Chappel was built about the Reign of Henry the Fourth. See in Limme.

In the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, I find one Hugh de Legh, Ance≈øtor to the Leghs of the Ea≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Moiety of High-Legh: The Right Line of which Hugh ending about the Reign of Henry the Seventh, a long Suit hapned between the Daughters and Co-heirs
Raufe Legh de Ea≈øt-Hall the la≈øt of that Lane, had three Daughters and Heirs; for Richard his Son died without I≈ø≈øue.
Jane married Randle Spur≈øtow of Spur≈øtow; Margaret married Robert Shaw; and Katharine married Thomas Legh, Son and Heir of Richard Legh de We≈øt Hall, but had no I≈ø≈øue: After the married Richard Done of Flaxyards.
on the one Part, and Thomas Legh of Northwood on the other Part; which Thomas then Claimed as next Heir-Male, by vertue of an Entail, and Recovered; of whom is de≈øcended Henry Legh of the Ea≈øt-Hall E≈øquire, now living, 1666. and branched out fir≈øt from the ancient Leghs of the Ea≈øt-Hall under Edward the Third: For John Legh of the Ea≈øt-Hall, Son and Heir of Hugh, Lord of the Moiety of High-Legh, tempore Edw. 2. had I≈ø≈øue William Legh de Ea≈øt-Hall, Son and Heir, (of whom the Leghs de Ea≈øt-Hall, who continued till the I≈ø≈øue-Male of that Line failed under Henry the Seventh) and John Legh of Alpram, ≈øecond Son, from whom the Leghs of Northwood in High-Legh anciently de≈øcended, who≈øe Heir Thomas Legh of Northwood was adjudged next Heir-Male, and from whom the Leghs of the Ea≈øt-Hall now in being, and Lords of the Moiety of High-Legh: And Matthew Legh, third Son of John, of whom the Leghs of Swineyard in High-Legh, yet in being, 1666. are de≈øcended.

The other Moity of High-Legh was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by Thomas de Legh, Ance≈øtor to the Leghs of the We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, whom I have ≈øeen ≈øub≈øcribed as a Witne≈øs unto ≈øundry old Deeds made in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, by the Name of Thom√¢
Domino medietatis Villae de Leg√¢. But one half of this Moiety was Purcha≈øed by Sir Richard Ma≈øsy of Tatton, towards the middle of Edward the Fir≈øt's Reign, as may appear by this Partition.‚Äî

q.p: HAEc e≈øt Partitio Terrarum in Vill√¢ de Legh‚ÄîInt√®r Dominum Ricardum de Ma≈ø≈øy Militem, & Thomam de Legh ex un√¢ parte; & Hugonem quondam Dominum de medietate Villae de Legh, & Johannem Filium & Haeredem eju≈ødem Hugonis, & Matthaeum de Alpraham cu≈øtodem eju≈ødem Johannis, ex alter√¢ parte; videlic√®t, Qu√≤d Terrae & Tenementa ≈øub≈øcripta remaneant in perpetu√πm Domino Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy & Thomae de Legh, & Haeredibus eorum ≈øeu A≈ø≈øignatis, in Campo Jordani de Verdon ≈øex Acrae‚Äî Aud ≈øo of ≈øeveral other Parcels: Lib. C. fol. 267. 9, 10. This was in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt: The Original Pen√®s Legh de We≈øt-Hall, 1665.

div.p: Roger de Monte alto, Sene≈øchallus Ce≈øtriae, Confirms to Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy all the Lands and Tenements, c√πm Bo≈øcis & Wa≈øtis, which he had of the Grant of Raufe Son of William de Hawarden, in the Town≈øhip of Legh; Robert Gro≈øvenour, then Sheriff of Che≈øhire, being one of the Witne≈ø≈øes: which was about Anno Domini 1286. The Original among the Evidences of the Earl of Bridgewater, 1667. who≈øe Heirs at this day enjoy the ≈øame: videlicet, The Earl of Bridgewater hath a fourth Part of High Legh, which belonged to the Ma≈ø≈øies of Tatton; and Mr. Legh of the We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh hath now one other fourth Part of High-Legh, which belonged to his Ance≈øtors of Ancient Time.

list.head: Charterers in High-Legh, 1666.
list.item: 1. John Gleyve of High-Legh. This is a very ancient Free-hold: For Matthew Somervyle, Lord of Alpraham, relea≈øeth Gilbert Gleyve from his Service to the Court of Alpraham, 1270. 54 Hen. 3. And Thomas de Legh, Dominus medietatis Villae de Legh, gave unto Gilbert, Son of Gilbert Gleyve of High-Legh, freedom of Pannage in all the Woods of High-Legh, about the beginning of the Reign of King Edward the Fir≈øt. And Agnes de Legh, the Widow of Richard de Limme, calls Gilbert Gleyve her Uncle; which Agnes was Daughter and Heir of Richard de Legh Lord of the Moiety of High-Legh, and Mother of Thomas de Legh afore≈øaid, as ≈øhall by and by appear. Lib. C. fol. 269. num. 10, 11, 14. The Originals Pen√®s John Gleyv√® afore≈øaid, 1664.

2. Richard Legh of Swineyard in High-Legh Gentleman. This Family branched out of the ancient Leghs of the East-Hall in High-Legh, under Edward the Third; who≈øe Ance≈øtor, Matthew Legh, marrying Margery Daughter and Heir of Richard de Sworton in High-Legh, had the half of Sworton, 1369.

3. Peter Legh of Northwood in High-Legh. He is de≈øcended from Gawen Legh, younger Son of Matthew Legh of Swineyard. This Gawen Purcha≈øed his Land in Northwood from the Leghs of We≈øt-Hall, and married Margaret Daughter of Thomas Grim≈ødich of Hallum in Newton juxt√† Daresbury; which Gawen and Margaret were living 32 Hen. 8.

item.p: 4. Mr. Millington of Millington. He had about thirty Acres in High-Legh; which Land came to his Ance≈øtor Aytrop de Millington, in Marriage with Margery Daughter of Richard de Legh, in the Reign of Henry the Third: Lib. C. fol. 273. num. 3. The Original remained among the Evidences of Mr. Millington afore≈øaid, 1665.
But this Land is now ≈øold to Mr. Geffrey Cartwright of Baggiley.
This was Parcel of the Moiety belonging to Legh of the West-Hall, from who≈øe Ance≈øtor it came.

list.item: 5. Thomas Dichfield of Swineyard.
6. Widow Wilkin≈øon.
7. Pownall of Barnton hath Land in the Mo≈ø≈øe-hou≈øes.
8. Widow Harper of Northwood, in the Lord Bridgewater's Part.
9. John Bentley of Northwood, in the Earl of Bridgewater's Part.

p.hi: So much of the Charterers.

div.p: We are now to take notice, That Agnes de Legh, Daughter and Heir of Richard de Legh Lord of the Moiety of High-Legh, had three Husbands. Her fir≈øt Husband was Richard de Limme, younger Son of Hugh de Limme Lord of the Moiety of Limme; by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Thomas de Legh of the We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, Sirnamed de Legh from the Place of his Birth and Re≈øidence, as was very u≈øual in tho≈øe Ages; which Sir-name of Legh his Po≈øterity ever ≈øince retained to this day.

Her ≈øecond Husband was William Venables of Bradwell, younger Brother to Sir Hugh Venables Baron of Kinderton; by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue John de Legh, Sirnamed al≈øo from the Place of his Education and Re≈øidence; which Sir-name of Legh his Po≈øterity al≈øo ever ≈øince retained. This John de Legh purcha≈øed Knotsford-Booths, c√πm Norbury-Booths, from William de Tabley, 28 Edw. 1. 1300. And from this John de Legh are the Leghs of Booths nigh Knotsford de≈øcended.

The third Husband of Agnes was William de Hawarden, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Raufe de Hawarden; which Raufe had the Half of the Moiety of High-Legh given him by his Half-Brother Thomas Legh of the We≈øt-Hall; and Raufe ≈øold his Part to Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, 1286.
All which will better appear by the≈øe Evidences following.

a. SCiant‚ÄîEgo Ricardus Filius Ricardi de Legh dedi‚ÄîRicardo Filio Hugonis de Limme, dimidiam Bovatam Terrae (illam, quam Gilbertus Filius Walteri Bek tenuit) c√πm Agnete Fili√¢ me√¢ in Libero Maritagio‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Hugone de Limme, Thom√¢ Fratre ≈øuo, Ad√¢ de Lehe, Hugone Filio ≈øuo, Madiou de Sworton, Rogero Par≈øon√¢ de Limme,‚Äî&c. The Original now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Legh de We≈øt-Hall, 1666. Lib. C. fol. 268. 30. Sub Hen. 3.

b. SCiant‚ÄîEgo Agnes de Legh, quond√†m Uxor Ricardi de Limme, in me√¢ propri√¢ viduitate dedi‚ÄîGilberto Glaive de e√¢dem Avunculo meo, pro Homagio & Servitio ≈øuo, totam medietatem de quodam A≈ø≈øarto quod vocatur Le Park, c√πm Mor√¢ quae vocatur Le Park-Moor,‚Äî&c. Reddendo inde annuat√¨m unum Par Cheirothecarum, vel unum Denarium, ad Nativitatem Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae, pro Omnibus‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Domino Willielmo de Ma≈ø≈øy, Domino Johanne de Sonbach t√πnc Rectore Eccle≈øiae de Ro≈øthorne,‚Äî&c. Lib. C. fol. 270. 14. The Original in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of John Gleyve of High-Legh, 1666.

c. SCiant‚ÄîEgo Radulfus Filius Willielmi de Hawerthin dedi‚ÄîThomae Fratri meo, & Haeredi, totam Terram un√† c√πm Bo≈øco in Territorio Villae de Leg√¢‚Äîin Schirley-Hey; exceptis quatuordecem Acris Terrae, quas dedi Johanni Fratri meo Filio Willielmi Venables,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Domino Willielmo de Venables, Domino Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, Domino Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy Militibus, Roberto le Gro≈øvenour t√πnc Vicecomite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae,-&c. about Anno Domini 1286. Lib. C. fol. 267. num. 17. The Original Pen√®s Legh de High-Legh de We≈øt-Hall, 1666.

d. SCiant‚ÄîQu√≤d ego Thomas de Legh dedi‚ÄîJohanni Filio Willielmi Venables, Fratri meo, pro Homagio ≈øuo, ≈øexdecem Acras & dimidium Terrae in Vill√¢ de Legh juxta Swineyard‚Äîin E≈øcambio pro quatuordecem Acris Terrae, quas habuit ex dono Radulfi Fratris ≈øui apud Schirley.‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, Ricardo de Ma≈ø≈øy Militibus, Hugone de Leye, Aitropo de Millington,‚Äî&c. Lib. C. fol. 271. num. 4.

e. OMnibus Chri≈øti fidelibus‚ÄîWillielmus Filius Willielmi Venables de Bradwell Salutem. Noveritis me remi≈øi≈ø≈øe Johanni de Legh de Terris & Tenementis in Ro≈øthorne‚Äîquae praedictus Johannes habet ex dono Willielmi Patris mei. Te≈øtibus Domino Petro de Warburton, Willielmo de Baggelegh Militibus, Willielmo de Mobberley t√πnc Vicecomite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, Roberto de Ma≈ø≈øy de Tatton, Hamone de A≈øhlegh,‚Äî&c. Datum 13 Edw. 2. 1319. Lib. H. of John Booth's Collections, pag. 122. g. Which Lands in Ro≈øthorne, Legh of Booths hath at this day, 1666.

f. UNiver≈øis Chri≈øti fidelibus‚ÄîJohannes Filius Johannis de Legh Miles ≈øalutem in Domino. Sciatis me remi≈øi≈ø≈øe Roberto de Legh Fratri meo, & Sibillae Uxori ejus, totum jus in Terris, quas praedictus Robertus habuit ex dono & Feoffamento Johannis de Legh Patris mei, in Vill√¢ de Legh in Parochi√¢ de Ro≈øthorne‚ÄîDatum ap√πd Mannerium de Boothes, die Martis proxim√® post Fe≈øtum Sancti Jacobi, Anno Domini 1336. (10 Edw. 3.) Lib. C. fol. 271. num. 6. Which very Tenement in High-Legh continued in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Leghs of Adlington, until Sir Vrian Legh of Adlington, not very long ≈øince, ≈øold the ≈øame to John Legh of Aldford, who ≈øold it to his Brother Richard Legh of Swineyard in High-Legh, 45 Eliz. 1602. who≈øe Heirs now enjoy the ≈øame. Lib. C. fol. 270. num. 19, 20.
By all which it appears, fir≈øt, That Richard de Limme married Agnes Daughter and Heir of Richard de Legh of High-Legh de We≈øt-Hall. a. b.
That Thomas de Legh, John de Legh Son of William Venables, and Raufe Hawardyn, were Brothers. c. d.
That this John de Legh was afterwards Legh of Boothes. e. Which he purcha≈øed from William de Tabley, 21 Edw. 1. 1300. as you may ≈øee above in Over-Knotsford.
That Robert Legh was younger Son of this fir≈øt John Legh del Boothes; from whom the Leghs of Adlington. f.

div.head: Now followeth the De≈øcent of the Leghs of the We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh.
div.p: II. Hugh de Limme Lord of the Moiety of Limme, Son of Gilbert, lived 1258. Emma Uxor ejus.
He had I≈ø≈øue Alan Lord of Limme; Richard de Limme, another Son; Simon, another Son; and Beatrix, a Daughter. Lib. C. fol. 272. 9. & 269. 4. & 263. d.e. & 264. 2, 3, 4.
III. Alan de Limme had I≈ø≈øue Gilbert, and Agnes Soror Gilberti, living 33 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 263. k.

IV. Gilbert de Limme, Son and Heir of Alan, had a Wife called Anabilla, 1338. and had I≈ø≈øue Peter, elde≈øt Son, who≈øe Son Peter married Margaret Daughter of Sir Geffrey de Warburton, 1338. William, ≈øecond Son of Gilbert; Richard, third Son; Robert, fourth Son: And four Daughters, Chri≈øtian, Cicely, Agnes, and Edu≈øa, all living 1338. Remanere Thomae de Legh, & Haeredibus. Lib. C. fol. 263. h.
I. Hamon Legh of the We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh; about Hen. 2.
II. William de Legh.

III. Richard de Legh, Son of William, had I≈ø≈øue Richard, and Madoc, cui Pater dedit medietatem de Sworton in High-Legh; and Margery married Aytrop Son of Aytrop of Millington, tempore Hen. 3. Lib. C. fol. 273. num. 3.
IV. Richard de Legh, Son of Richard, Son of William, Son of Hamon de Legh.
V. Agnes, Daughter and Heir of Richard, had three Husbands: The fir≈øt was Richard de Limme, younger Son of Hugh de Limme; and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas de Legh de We≈øt-Hall.
After ≈øhe married William Venables of Bradwell, and by him had I≈ø≈øue John de Legh, from whom the Leghs of the Booths near Knotsford.
And la≈øtly, ≈øhe married William de Hawardyn, and by him had I≈ø≈øue Raufe de Hawardyn.

This Thomas gave away one half of his Moiety of High-Legh, which came to Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, Regnante Edwardo Primo; ≈øo that he had onely one fourth Part of High-Legh afterwards, which his Heirs enjoy at this day, 1666.
This Thomas Legh died about 10 Edw. 2. Lib. C. fol. 268. num. 27.
II. Thomas Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, Son and Heir of Thomas, married Alice and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Legh Son and Heir, living 11 Edw. 2.

Gilbert de Limme relea≈øeth to this Thomas Legh all his Right in the Advow≈øon of the Moiety of the Church of Limme, 10 Edw. 2. 1316. Lib. C. fol. 266. num. 1. Since which time the Leghs of We≈øt-Hall have been Patrons of the half of Limme-Church, to this day, 1666.
Alice was Widow Anno Domini 1333. Lib. C. fol. 268. num. 28. I find her a Widow al≈øo 1330. Ibid. fol. 268. num. 38.

III. Thomas Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, Son and Heir of Thomas, married and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Legh, Son and Heir; Agnes, a Daughter, married Robert Dumbill, from whom the Dumbills of Limme. Gilbert de Limme relea≈øeth to this Agnes and Robert Dumbill, and the Heirs of their Bodies, all his Lands in Limme, c√πm Servitiis liberorum Tenentium; Remanere Thomae Filio Johannis Dumbill praedicti, & Margaretae Filiae praedicti Thomae de Legh‚ÄîDated at Limme, on Thur≈øday next after Michaelmas, 1342. Lib. C. fol. 263. I. So that Margaret, another Daughter, married Thomas Dumbill.

Agnes, Daughter of Alan de Limme, relea≈øeth to Robert Dumbill, and Agnes his Wife, all her Right in all tho≈øe Lands, Rents, and Services, which formerly belonged to her Brother Gilbert de Limme, in the Town≈øhip of Limme. Dated at Limme, 33 Edw. 3. (1359.) Lib. C. fol. 263. k. The Originals in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Dumbill of Limme, 1664.

IV. Richard Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, Son and Heir of Thomas, married Maud Daughter and Heir of Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy of VVin≈øham, Anno Domini 1375. (49 Ed. 3.) Lib. C. fol. 266. num. 4, 5. Lib. B. pag. 35. h. and had I≈ø≈øue John Legh Son and Heir; and Alice married Richard Starky of Stretton.
This Richard was living 4 Hen. 5.

V. John Legh of VVe≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, Son and Heir of Richard, married and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Legh, Son and Heir; Roger Legh of Oldgrave in Che≈øhire; Margery married John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley the younger,
20 Hen. 6. 1442. Son and Heir of John Leyce≈øter of Tabley, the elder, E≈øquire: Covenants of the Marriage are now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Legh of VVe≈øt-Hall, 1666. Alice, another Daughter, married John Son and Heir of John Parr of Wor≈øeley in Lanca≈øhire E≈øq 35 Hen. 6. Lib. C. fol. 280. h.

VI. Richard Legh de VVe≈øt-Hall in High-Legh E≈øquire, Son and Heir of John, married Alice Daughter of John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley, the Elder, E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1442. 20 Hen. 6. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Legh, Son and Heir; John Legh of Oughtrington in Limme, of whom the Leghs of Oughtrington; Maud married Nicholas Legh of East-Hall in High-Legh, 1463. Hamnet Legh, third Son; Peter Legh, fourth Son; Richard, fifth Son; Dow≈øe married John Son and Heir of VVilliam Mere of Mere juxt√† Over-Tabley, E≈øquire, living 1487. 3 Hen. 7. Lib. C. fol. 209. g. I≈øabel married Peter Venables of Anterbus in Over-VVhitley Lord≈øhip; Ellen married Richard Molde≈øworth of VVin≈øham, 19 Edw. 4. 1479. Lib. C. fol. 213. y. The Original penes Sir Peter Brooke of Mere, 1666.
This Richard Legh died about 1486. Lib. C. fol. 209. g.

VII. Thomas Legh of VVe≈øt-Hall in High-Legh E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, married Dow≈øe Daughter of Sir VVilliam Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 1 Edw. 4. 1461. and had I≈ø≈øue Richard, Son and Heir, who died in the Life-time of his Father, having married Beatrix Daughter of Geffrey Boydell of Pulcroft, 3 Hen. 7. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Richard Legh, Son and Heir.

This Thomas had al≈øo George Legh of Manche≈øter, ≈øecond Son, who≈øe Daughter and Heir Elizabeth married Alexander Barlow of Barlow in Lanca≈øhire: Alice Legh, another Daughter of Thomas, married Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy of Hale; afterwards ≈øhe married George Newton: James Legh, third Son of Thomas: John Legh, fourth Son; Roger Legh, Par≈øon of Limme, fifth Son: And Jane married Matthew Legh of Swineyard in High-Legh.

This Thomas Legh had a ≈øecond Wife, called Joan, Daughter of John Holcroft of Holcroft in Lanca≈øhire; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue John Legh, Thomas Legh, and Jane Wife of Thomas Sanky of Little-Sanky in Lanca≈øhire.

VIII. Richard Legh of VVe≈øt-Hall in High-Legh E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, and Grand-≈øon of Thomas Legh, married Ro≈øe Daughter of Raufe Davenport of Davenport E≈øquire, 20 Hen. 7. 1504. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Legh, Son and Heir, who married Katharine one of the Daughters and Heirs of Raufe Legh of the Ea≈øt-Hall in High-Legh E≈øquire; but he died without I≈ø≈øue, in the Life-time of his Father: Al≈øo Parnell, and Anne, two Daughters by Ro≈øe.

After the death of Ro≈øe, Richard married Anne Hough, Si≈øter of Richard Hough of Leighton; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Richard Legh, Heir to his Father; George, another Son; John Legh, another Son, who married Mary Daughter of Alexander Barlow of Barlow in Lanca≈øhire; Dorothy Legh, a Daughter, married David Ma≈ø≈øy of Broxton in Che≈øhire.

IX. Richard Legh de VVe≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, married Clemence Daughter of John Holcroft of Holcroft in Lanca≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Legh, Son and Heir; John Legh, ≈øecond Son, died young; Peter Legh, third Son, afterwards became Heir; Francis Legh of London; George Legh, another Son; John Legh of London, another Son, married Dorothy Daughter and Heir of Thomas Eaton, and Widow of Robert Holcroft, and had I≈ø≈øue: Thomas Legh, another Son; Elizabeth, a Daughter, married Thomas Torbock; Jane married John A≈øton of A≈øton in Mondrum; Margaret married Thomas Haughton.

After the death of Clemence, he married Margery Widow of George Tirrell of Thornton in Buckingham≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue by her, Thomas Legh, John Legh, George Legh, VVilliam Legh,
Obiit 1582 and Agnes.
This Richard Legh de VVe≈øt-Hall died Anno Domini 1582.

X. Richard Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, married Anne Daughter of Raufe Belfield of Gledge, but was divorced from her; Obiit 1586 and he died without I≈ø≈øue, Anno Domini 1586. leaving his Brother Peter to ≈øucceed in his Inheritance.

XI. Peter Legh de West-Hall in High-Legh, E≈øquire, Brother and Heir to the la≈øt Richard, married Elizabeth Daughter of John Bapti≈øta Ca≈øtilian of Benham-Valence in Berk≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue Ricbard, who died young; Peter Legh, who ≈øucceeded Heir; Thomas, another Son; Anne married Thomas Cooper of Ewborne in Berk≈øhire; Mary married one Davys of Salisbury; Elizabeth married Nathaniel Lanca≈øter Par≈øon of Torperley in Che≈øhire; Jane, another Daughter; Frances married William Edwards Alderman of Che≈øter; Margaret married one Wats a Schoolma≈øter at Wal≈øingham; and Chri≈øtian married Thomas Bate of Limme, a Phy≈øician. Obiit 1613
This Peter died 14 die Martii, 1613.

XII. Peter Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Peter, married Mary Daughter of Robert Tipping of Manche≈øter, and had I≈ø≈øue Peter Legh, Son and Heir; Richard Legh, Thomas, Samuel, Edmund, William, James, and Elizabeth, all living 1665. Obiit 1657
This Peter died 1657. aged 62 Years.

XIII. Peter Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Peter,
Obiit 1665 was never married, and died without I≈ø≈øue, Anno Domini 1665.

XIV. Richard Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, E≈øquire, Brother and Heir to the la≈øt Peter, is now living, but unmarried, Anno Domini 1669. Obiit 1670 and died the twelfth of Augu≈øt, 1670. leaving Thomas his Brother to ≈øucceed in his Inheritance.

XV. Thomas Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, E≈øquire, Brother and Heir to Richard, married Mary Daughter of William Au≈øtine E≈øquire, now of We≈øtmin≈øter in London, but born in Northampton≈øhire, near Owndle; married Anno Domini 1660. and hath I≈ø≈øue Au≈øtine, Peter, William; all living 1670.

‚öú Here ≈øhould have followed the De≈øcent of the other Legh de Ea≈øt-Hall in High-Legh; but I could not have the Peru≈øal of the Evidences of that Family: For that Henry Legh E≈øquire, now Owner thereof, affirmed, that his Deeds were mo≈øt of them lo≈øt in the late War.

div.head: Limme.
div.p: IN this Town≈øhip of Limme is a very ancient Pari≈øh-Church, Dedicated to the Virgin Mary, who≈øe Wakes or Fea≈øt of Dedication is on the fifteenth day of Augu≈øt, being the Fea≈øt of the A≈ø≈øumption of Mary; which Pari≈øh comprehendeth onely the Town≈øhip of Limme: It is in our common Mize-book Mized at 01 l. 16 s. 00 d. A large Town, which containeth in it the≈øe little Hamlets or Places, known by the Names of Stathum, Reddi≈øh, Oughtrington, Brome, and Heateley.

Here hath been a Church before the Norman Conque≈øt: For it appears by Doom≈øday-book, that in the Conqueror's Time Gilbert Venables Baron of Kinderton held half of this Town, which Ulviet formerly held; ibi dimidia Eccle≈øia c√πm dimidi√¢ Virgat√¢ Terrae, ≈øaith the Record.
And Osberne Son of Tezzon held the other Half: He was Ance≈øtor to the Boydells of Dodle≈øton; ibi dimidia Eccle≈øia c√πm Presbytero c√πm dimidi√¢ Virgat√¢ Terrae quiet√¢.

So that either Lord had one half of the Church; and ≈øo at this day are two Par≈øons
Pre≈øented to Limme, who ≈øupply the Mini≈øtry there alternis vicibus; one, one Sunday; and the other, the next Sunday after, and ≈øo by cour≈øe; Warburton of Arley being now Patron of one Moiety of the ≈øaid Church, and Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh Patron of the other Moiety: And one Par≈øon hath one half of the Tythes of Limme, and the other Par≈øon hath the other half of the Tythes.

Gilbert de Limme relea≈øed all his Right in the Advow≈øon of the Moiety of Limme-Church unto Thomas Legh de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, 10 Edw. 2. 1316. The Original among the Evidences of Legh de We≈øt-Hall, 1666. Since which time that Family have continued their Right of Pre≈øenting to that Moiety, which (I conceive) was the Moiety belonging to Gilbert Venables in Doom≈øday-book.

The Steeple of this Church was Repaired, and built anew of Stone not many Ages ≈øince: For, Anno Domini 1521. I find by a Writing now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Dumbill of Limme, That Sir Thomas Butler Knight, Sir Piers Legh, Sir John Warburton, Sir William Molineaux, Sir George Holford, Thomas Legh E≈øquire, Robert Reddi≈øh E≈øquire, James-Dumbill E≈øquire, Randle Clayton E≈øquire, William Wilm Gentleman, John Legh Gentleman, Sir Roger Legh Par≈øon of the ≈øame Church, Sir Richard Comberbach, our Ladies Prie≈øt, and Over≈øeer of the Work, Sir John Per≈øevall Pari≈øh-Prie≈øt of the ≈øame Church, do de≈øire a Charitable Contribution of all Pious Per≈øons towards a Steeple of Stone then in Building at Limme-Church, whereof our Ble≈ø≈øed Lady is the Founder, without which the Pari≈øh was not able to fini≈øh the Work; where there were three Prie≈øts to pray for the Benefactors: and Con≈øtituting Matthew Legh and Reginald Legh Collectors, to receive the Contributions. Dated the twenty fourth of April, 1521. Lib. C. fol. 264. P.

list.head: Ex Chartulariis Epi≈øcopi Coventriae & Lichfieldiae, Concerning the Pre≈øentations made by the Leghs de We≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, to the Moiety of Limme-Church: Being the Notes taken by William Vernon in July, 1649.
list.item: 10 Edw. 2. ANno 1316. 11 Calendas Februarii, Thomas Filius Thomae de Legh, Patronus, prae≈øentat Ricardum de Ma≈ø≈øy (po≈øt mortem Domini Petri de Limme, quond√†m Rectoris medietatis Eccle≈øiea de Limme) ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.
23 Edw. 3. Anno 1349. 3 Nonas Septembris, Thomas de Legh Patronus medietatis Eccle≈øiae de Limme, prae≈øentat Adamum de Denfeld (or Wenfeld) Capellanum po≈øt mortem Jordani ultimi Rectoris.
35 Edw. 3. Anno 1361. Thomas Legh Patronus medietatis Eccle≈øiae de Limme, prae≈øentat Thomam Filium Johannis de Legh Clericum ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae praedictae.
13 Rich. 2. Anno 1390. 2 die Aprilis, Ricardus de Legh Patronus, prae≈øentat Thomam Filium Thomae de Legh Presbyterum ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.

9 Hen. 4. Anno 1408. penultimo Augu≈øti, conce≈ø≈øit Epi≈øcopus Incolis, ceu Inhabitantibus Villulam de Leye infr√† Parochiam de Ro≈øthorn, qu√≤d po≈ø≈øint facere Divina Celebrari in Capell√¢ de Leye.
4 Hen. 5. Anno 1416. 4 die Augu≈øti, Nobilis Vir Ricardus de Legh Armiger, Patronus, prae≈øentat Rogerum Dumbill ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.

35 Hen. 6. Anno 1457. 18 die Octobris, Johannes Legh de Legh Armiger, Patronus, prae≈øentat Ricardum Vay≈øe Capellanum ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme per Re≈øignationem Hamonis Leyce≈øter ultimi Rectoris.
33 Hen. 6. Anno 1455. 21 die Novembris, Licentia Hamundi Leyce≈øter in Legibus Bacalarii, Rectoris medietatis Eccle≈øiae de Limme, de non Re≈øidendo.
12 Edw. 4. Anno 1472. ultimo Januarii, Venerabilis vir Ricardus Legh Armiger, Patronus, per re≈øignationem Ricardi Vay≈øe, prae≈øentat Nicolaum Devyas ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.
4 Hen. 7. Anno 1489. 14 die Augu≈øti, Thomas Legh de Legh Armiger, Patronus, prae≈øentat, po≈øt mortem Nicolai Devyas ultimi Rectoris, Hamonem Legh ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.
16 Hen. 7. Anno 1501. in July, Thomas Legh Armiger, Patronus, prae≈øentat Johannem Heton Capellanum, post mortem Hamonis Legh, ultimi Rectoris, ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.

list.head: Concerning the other Moiety of the Church, belonging to Warburton of Arley.
list.item: 1 Edw. 3. ANno 1327. 11 Calendas Aprilis, Robertus de Warburton Miles, Patronus medietatis Eccle≈øiae de Limme, prae≈øentat Willielmum Warburton Clericum, po≈øt mortem Roberti de Dentene, ad medietatem pradictam.
41 Edw. 3. Anno 1367. 2 Nonas Octobris, Johannes Daniell Miles, & Johanna Uxor ejus, prae≈øentant Petrum de Shawe, po≈øt mortem Willielmi de Warburton ultimi Rectoris.

14 Rich. 2. Anno 1391. 28 die Junii, Dominus Johannes Ma≈ø≈øy de Tatton Miles, Patronus h√¢c vice ratione Custodiae Petri Warburton minoris aetatis in manu dicti Johannis, prae≈øentat, po≈øt mortem Domini Petri de Shagh ultimi Rectoris, Johannem Berkin Presbyterum, ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.

10 Hen. 6. Anno 1432. 7 die Octobris, Galfridus Warburton Miles, Patronus, prae≈øentat Rogerum Dumbill utriu≈øque Juris Bacalaurium, per re≈øignationem Johannis Berkin ultimi Rectoris, ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.

36 Hen. 6. Anno 1458. 7 die Maii, Hugo Calveley, Philippus Egerton Armigeri, & Johannes de Hogh, h√¢c vice ratione Feoffamenti Petri Warburton Armigeri, prae≈øentant One of the≈øe Names is mi≈øtaken by Vernon, either Richard Chounall, or Thomas Chounall.
Richardum Chounall Capellanum, ad medietatem Eccle≈øiae de Limme.

1 Hen. 7. Anno 1486. 24 die Februarii, Rogerus Chapman per mortem One of the≈øe Names is mi≈øtaken by Vernon, either Richard Chounall, or Thomas Chounall.
Thomae Chounall, vacante medietate Eccle≈øiae praedictae.

div.p: In the Feodary of Halton under Edward the Second, it is ≈øaid,‚ÄîGilbertus de Limme tenet medietatem Villae de Limme, pro medietate unius Feodi Militis.
The I≈ø≈øue of this Gilbert failing, Thomas Legh de We≈øt-Hall in Hig-Legh was next Heir, as de≈øcended Lineally from Richard Limme Uncle of the ≈øaid Gilbert.

And indeed at la≈øt Gilbert de Limme ≈øettles all his Lands in Limme, c√πm Servitiis liberorum Tenentium, on Robert Dumbill, Son of John Dumbill, and Agnes Daughter of Thomas Legh de We≈øt-Hall, and on the Heirs of the Bodies of the ≈øaid Robert and Agnes, Anno Domini 1342. 16 Edw. 3. from whence are de≈øcended the Dumbills of Limme.
This Robert Dumbill (if I mi≈øtake not) was younger Son of John Dumbill of Oxton in Wirrall in Che≈øhire.

John Dumbill (Son of the ≈øaid Robert and Agnes) was retained the King's Servant, and had Five Pounds yearly Pen≈øion for his Life given him out of the Exchequer at Che≈øter. Dated 21 Rich. 2. 1397. Lib. C. fol. 264. m. and was employed in the War again≈øt Owen Glendore, 3 Hen. 4. and was a Soldier under Sir John Stanley Governor of Roxborough-Ca≈øtle, 20 Rich. 2. Lib. C. fol. 263. i. k. m. n. o. The Original in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Dumbill of Limme, 1664.
In which Family of the Dumbills of Limme, hath the Moiety of the Town of Limme, and the Seigniory thereof, ever ≈øince continued to this pre≈øent.

The Advow≈øon of the Moiety of Limme-Church, being formerly granted away to Thomas Legh de We≈øt-Hall by the ≈øaid Gilbert de Limme, 10 Edw. 2. continueth ≈øtill in the ≈øame Family, as I have ≈øhewed before.

Indeed I find the fir≈øt Gilbert de Limme to have lived about King John's Time, who was Lord of the Moiety of Limme; which Family of Limme were Sirnamed from the Place of their Re≈øidence here, and continued to the end of Edward the Third, the la≈øt Gilbert de Limme and his I≈ø≈øue-Male then failing.
But whether the fir≈øt Gilbert de Limme was originally a Venables, or of what other Family, and how this Moiety came to the Baron of Halton, from the Baron of Kinderton, I find no mention.

The Seigniory of the other Moiety hath for long time belonged to the Warburtons of Arley; howbeit, at this day he hath not above ≈øix or ≈øeven Tenements in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion there. How it came from the Boydells to Warburton, I find not preci≈øely: I conceive it came with Agnes Daughter and Heir of Roger Fitz-Alfred in Marriage to Adam de Dutton Ance≈øtor of Warburton, together with the Moiety of Warburton, and other Lands, about the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt.
In this Town≈øhip are now, 1666. the≈øe Charterers.

list.item: 1. John Gandy of Over-Limme-Booths.
2. John Dichfield of Stathum lately Purcha≈øed Cherry-tree-hur≈øt, formerly Daniell of Tabley's Land.
3. John Legh of Oughtrington.
4. Gilbert Steel of Reddi≈øh.

7. Richard Legh of Lyme E≈øq hath ≈øeven Tenements.
8. Randle Cro≈øs of Limme nigh Agden.
9. William Reddi≈øh of Stathum.
10. Richard Rowlin≈øon of Stathum.
11. John Trevis of Che≈øter, formerly Daniell's of Tabley.
12. Peter Davys of Oughtrington.
13. James Hey of Limme-Booths.
14. Nicolas Peacock of Brown-Edge in Limme.
15. John Perceivall of Stathum.

18. Robert Thoma≈øon; formerly Daniell's.
19. John Legh of Higher-Lane.
20. Richard Dutton of Reddi≈øh.

div.head: Marbury.
div.p: THis Hamlet of Marbury comprehendeth onely the Mannor-Hou≈øe, with the Demain-Lands thereunto belonging; and hath its Name from our two old Engli≈øh Words, [Mere] which ≈øignifies A great Lake or Pool, and [Birig] which ≈øignifies A Hou≈øe, or Place covered, and ≈øometimes A Town: So Ver≈øtegan. And here denotes as much as A Hou≈øe or Dwelling by the Mere.
About the very beginning of Henry the Third's Reign, Warin Vernon Baron of Shibbrok confirms this Hamlet to William de Merebirie, in the≈øe Words.‚Äî

q.p:
GUarinus de Vernon Omnibus Amicis & hominibus ≈øuis, Clericis & Laicis, Francis & Anglis, t√†m prae≈øentibus qu√†m futuris, Salutem. Notum ≈øit vobis me conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe & h√¢c me√¢ prae≈øenti Chart√¢ confirm√¢≈ø≈øe Willielmo de Merebiri√¢ totam Villam de Merebiri√¢; Tenendam de me & Haeredibus meis, illi & Haeredibus ≈øuis, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis, in Bo≈øco, in Plano, in Pratis, in Pa≈øcuis, in Molendinis, in Vivariis, in Aquis, in Viis, in Semitis, & in omnibus aliis locis, & in omnibus Libertatibus ad praedictam Villam de Merebiri√¢ pertinentibus, Haereditari√® ≈øic√πt Ricardus Frater ≈øuus de Merebiri√¢ conce≈ø≈øit & ei p√®r Chartam
≈øuam cor√†m nobis con≈øirmavit, & ≈øic√πt Ranulphus de Merebiri√¢ Pater ≈øuus eam meli√πs & liberi√πs tenuit & habuit unqu√†m in vit√¢ ≈øu√¢, liber√® & honorific√®, & eodem Servitio, ≈øcilic√®t, pro ≈øext√¢ parte Servitii unius Militis. Ut aut√®m haec no≈øtra confirmatio futuris temporibus rata & inconcu≈ø≈øa permaneat, eam Sigilli mei impre≈ø≈øione cor√†m hiis Te≈øtibus confirmavi, Ricardo de Vernon & Matthaeo de Filio ≈øuo, Gilberto de Bo≈øtock & Willielmo Filio ≈øuo, Hugone de Tiw√¢, Hamone Briton, Matthaeo de Mune≈øhull & Ricardo Fratre ≈øuo, Radulfo Filio Rogeri Di≈øpen≈øatoris & Willielmo Fratre ≈øuo, Willielmo Capellano de Shibbrok, & aliis multis.

div.p: A very fair Seal; In a Rondlet a Lion Rampant, written about thus,‚ÄîSIGILL. WARINI DE VERNUN. The Original hereof remaining among the Evidences at Merbury, 1666.

From hence had this Family the Sir-name of Merbury, and ≈øeems to be originally a Vernon. Nothing more u≈øual than in tho≈øe Elder Ages to be ≈øtiled from the Places of their Habitation, which After-ages retained as Sir-names.
This Family hath continued in this Seat ever ≈øince, by the Name of the Merburies; and Thomas Merbury of Merbury E≈øq is now Owner thereof, 1666.

Out of this Family branched Randle Merbury in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, who≈øe Son Simon married Idonea Daughter and Heir of Thomas de Walton, from whom the Marburies of Walton in this Hundred were propagated. See more hereof in Walton.

div.head: Mar≈øton.
div.p: THis Town≈øhip of Mar≈øton is not in Doom≈øday-book, and ≈øeemeth to have its Name from the two Meres whereto it adjoineth, to wit, Budworth-Mere, and Pickmere-Mere; as it were Meres-Town, or The Town abutting on the Meres. It hath very anciently belonged to the Barons of Kinderton.

Andrew Prior of Norton, and the Convent there, granted unto Sir William Venables Chari≈ø≈øimo Amico no≈øtro, to find him the Celebration of Divine Service in his Chappel at Mar≈øton, during his Life-time, when either he or his Wife ≈øhall be there; and do al≈øo Lea≈øe to Robert his Son, Clerk, their Tythe of the Mill, and of the Fi≈øhings there, about the beginning of Henry the Third: Lib. H. num. 21.

It ≈øeems Hugh Son of Alfred of Mar≈øton had ≈øome Parcel of Land here tempore Edw. 3. For Richard Venables relea≈øeth to Hamon de Venables all his Right de Pueris Hugonis de Mar≈øton. Ibid√®m, num. 7.

Peter Venables E≈øquire, now Baron of Kinderton, 1666. hath an old Mannor-Hou≈øe in Mar≈øton, with ancient Demain-Lands thereunto belonging; and hath al≈øo all the re≈øt of Mar≈øton Town≈øhip in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Tenants there, except onely,‚Äî
1. Richard Symcock's Tenement in Mar≈øton, now belonging to Sir Peter Leycester of Nether-Tabley; which Tenement was ≈øold by Sir Thomas Venables of Kinderton, and Thomas his Son and Heir, to Peter Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire, 6 Elizabethae, 1564. and adjoyneth to Nether-Tabley: B. num. 2.
2. Bromfield's Lands in Mar≈øton, which anciently belonged to Bromfield of Witton; but now Richard Wilcoc≈øon hath bought Part hereof; and the other Part, called Sim-fields, Peter Kennardy of A≈øton juxt√† Pickmere hath bought.

div.head: Marthall.
div.p: IN the Conqueror's Time, in Doom≈øday-book, I find no mention of Marthall.

But this Town anciently belonged to the Wynningtons of Wynnington nigh Northwich, in who≈øe Offices they are found to hold it of the Heirs of Manwaring of Warmincham in Soccage, by the yearly Rent of one Penny.

Of which Family, Richard Wynnington of Wynnington E≈øquire married Katharine the fifth Daughter and Co-heir to Robert Gro≈øvenour of Houlme in Allo≈øtock E≈øquire, by whom he had the Mannor of Pulford beyond Che≈øter, by Partition, Anno 1465. and a fifth part of Allo≈øtock, as Heir to her Si≈øter Margery Gro≈øvenour, by Partition, Anno 1474. and had I≈ø≈øue three Sons, Richard Wynnington, Peter, and George; and two Daughters, Jane, and Elizabeth; all living 5 Hen. 7. Lib. C. fol. 125. F. & 161. O.

Richard Wynnington, Son and Heir of Richard and Katharine, married Joan Smith, and had I≈ø≈øue two Daughters, Katharine, who died without I≈ø≈øue 23 Hen. 7. as appears by her Office taken 6 Hen. 8. and Elizabeth married Sir Piers Warburton of Arley, 2 Hen. 8. being then ≈øole Daughter and Heir: For Richard Wynnington died 19 Hen. 7. Joan his Wife died 24 Hen. 7. and Sir Piers Warburton died 4 Edw. 6. and Elizabeth his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Richard Wynnington of Wynnington E≈øquire, died Anno ≈øexto Mariae.

So that Warburton of Arley had by this Match all the Lands then belonging to Wynnington of Wynnington, as well as the Part of Gro≈øvenour's Lands before-mentioned, which de≈øcended al≈øo; who≈øe Heir at this day, 1666. is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Town of Marthall entirely, there being no Free-holder or Charterer in this Town≈øhip at all.

div.head: Mere.
div.p: THis Town undoubtedly took its Name from the Mere therein; and was held by Gilbert Venables Baron of Kinderton in the Time of William the Conqueror, which one Ulviet held before.

Not many Ages after, it became the Seat of the Family of the Meres, who took their Sir-name from hence; among whom Robert de Mere ≈øenior lived about the Reign of King John; whether originally a Venables, I cannot po≈øitively affirm.
Ex Bundello E≈øcaetarum in Turri Londinen≈øi, 8 Rich. 2. Willielmus de Mere tenuit Villam de Mere, c√πm medietate Manerii de Bollinton, de Hugone de Venables; which Hugh was Lord of Kinderton.

Certain it is, this Family of Mere of Mere continued in this Seat a long time together, until in our days John Mere of Mere E≈øquire, and William his Son, ≈øold this Mannor of Mere unto Peter Brooks, younger Son of Thomas Brooks of Norton E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1652. Which Peter al≈øo bought the E≈øtate of Thomas Merbury of Walton, and was after Sir Peter Brooks, Knighted Anno Domini 1660. and Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 1669. He hath Beautified and Built anew the Hall of Mere very hand≈øomly; and had three Wives: The fir≈øt was Alice Hul≈øe, Daughter and Heir of Richard Hul≈øe of Killingworth in Warwick≈øhire, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Brooks, elde≈øt Son, who married Margaret Daughter and Heir of Henry Brereton of Eccle≈øton in Che≈øhire, Gentleman, 1663. Richard Brooks, ≈øecond Son, who married Margaret Daughter and Heir of Robert Charnock of Charnock in Lanca≈øhire, 1666.

The ≈øecond Wife of Sir Peter Brooks was Frances the Widow of William Merbury of Merbury nigh Comberbach in Che≈øhire E≈øquire, and Daughter of Sir Nicholas Trot of Quick≈øhot in Hartford≈øhire; but had no I≈ø≈øue by her.

The third Wife of Sir Peter Brooks of Mere, was Mabill the Widow of Richard Clayton of Crooke in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire, and Daughter of William Farrington of Werden in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire, who, with Sir Peter her Husband, are now living, 1669. but hath no I≈ø≈øue by her.

list.head: Charterers in Mere, 1666.
list.item: 1. Henry Legh de Ea≈øt-Hall in High-Legh E≈øquire, pro Strethull-Farm, not long ≈øince Purcha≈øed from Hugh Cocker of Pickmere.
2. One Me≈ø≈øuage in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Robert Simmons, given to the u≈øe of the Poor of the Pari≈øh, whereof Ma≈ø≈øy of Mo≈ø≈øe-hou≈øe is a Feoffee.
3. George Venables of Agden E≈øquire, one ≈ømall Tenement in Mere.
4. John Spinke of Howes-Heath in Mere.
5. William Pownall of Barnton, for Granthams Lands.
6. Peter Fernhead of Mere, for Granthams Lands.
7. John Bradburne of Mere.
8. John Bentley of the Hole in Mere.
9. George Bentley of Mere-Heys.
10. William Grantham of Mere, a ≈ømall Parcel.
11. Edward Allen of Ro≈øthorne, one ≈ømall Tenement in Mere.
12, John Barker of Little-Legh, one ≈ømall Tenement in Mere.

div.head: Middleton-Grange.
div.p: THis is but one Farm ≈øo called, lying in A≈øton juxt√† Sutton: Vide ≈øupr√† in A≈øton juxt√† Sutton.

div.head: Millington.
div.p: IN the Time of William the Conqueror, William Son of Nigell, Baron of Halton, held Millington in Bucklow-Hundred: So we read in Doom≈øday-book.

John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and Baron of Halton, in the Reign of Henry the Second, gave to Wrono of Stretton half of Millington, to wit, that which he had in his Demain; Rendring yearly a little Iri≈øh Nag, called A Hobby, at Mid≈øommer: Whereunto Hugh Dutton, and Adam his Son, with ≈øeveral others, were Witne≈ø≈øes: Lib. C. fol. 154. c. out of Vernon's Notes.

Whereby it ≈øhould ≈øeem he had then but half of Millington in his Fee, if the≈øe Words [Quam habuit in Dominico ≈øuo] be under≈øtood of his Fee: Unle≈øs Dominico here be under≈øtood of his Demain, or in his own Hands, not given away from him, as the other Moiety was; which very probably is ≈øo meant here.

For Hugh de Millington, being ≈øei≈øed of Lands here before the Grant made by John Con≈øtable to Wrono de Stretton√¢, gives unto Wrono Punterling (called al≈øo Wrono de Stretton) duas Bovatas Terrae in Millington.‚ÄîFaciendo Servitium Foren≈øe quantum pertinet aliis duabus Bovatis und√® octo Bovatae faciunt octavam partem Militis in e√¢dem Vill√¢. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Hugone de Dutton√¢, Ad√¢ Filio ≈øuo, Ranulfo Filio Gilberti, & Gilberto Filio ≈øuo, Tobaldo Avunculo Comitis, & Hereberto de Punterling, Liulfo de Twamlow, & Ranulfo de Davenham, & omni Hundredo Haltonae: Which John Con≈øtable al≈øo confirmed: Lib. C. fol. 273. num. 1, 2. The Originals Pen√®s Millington of Millington, 1666.

So the Office of John Millington of Millington, 37 Elizabethae, finds he held one half of Millington of the Honour of Halton, by the eighth part of a Knights Fee; and the other half of Millington he held of the Honour of Halton, in Soccage, by the yearly Rent of two Shillings: Po≈ø≈øibly the yearly Rent in tract of time might be continued, in lieu of the Iri≈øh Hobby afore≈øaid.

But to return. Certain it is, That Aytrop de Millington (whom I take to be the Son of Hugh) married Chri≈øtian Daughter and Heir of Wrono de Stretton afore≈øaid, about the Reign of Henry the Second; Lib. B. pag. 200. num. 6. and ≈øo he came to be po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of all Millington.

This Town gave Sir-name to the Family of the Millingtons, Seated here near to the Time of the Conqueror: A very ancient Family of Gentlemen, and continuing at this day; William Millington of Millington Gentleman being now Owner thereof, 1664. He died in June, 1666.

Aytrop de Millington, Son of the fir≈øt Aytrop, as I take it, gave unto Robert Blund of Bexton, pro finali Concordi√¢ int√®r nos fact√¢ de fine Duelli, unam dimidiam Bovatam Terrae in Vill√¢ de Mulinton‚ÄîRendring three Pence at Martlemas yearly‚ÄîPhilip Orreby being then Judge of Che≈øter, &c. ≈øub initio Hen. 3. Lib. C. fol. 274. num. 6. The Original in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Millington of Millington.

list.head: Charterers in Millington, 1666.
list.item: 1. The Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy: Two Tenements, bought from Millington.

2. Venables of Agden, one Tenement, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Hugh Gandy; but part of Gandy's Tenement lieth in Agden: That Parcel lying in Millington, was given by Aytrop de Millington to the Priory of Norton, about King John's Time: Lib. B. pag. 200. num. 6. Afterwards, ≈øcilic√®t 1329. Robert de Millington bought it of Agnes Daughter of William de la Booths, and ≈øold it to William de Aketon (or Agden) from whom it de≈øcended to Venables of Agden.
3. Geffrey Cartwright Gentleman hath lately bought the Shaw-hou≈øe in Millington, from Millington of Millington.

div.head: Mobberley.
div.p: MObberley-Church was Dedicated to St. Wilfrid, a Holy Archbi≈øhop of York, who died Anno Domini 708.4 Idus Octobris: Bede de Hi≈øt. Angliae, lib. 5. cap. 20. ad finem. And Mobberley-Wakes were formerly Celebrated on the twelfth day of October, though at this day tho≈øe Dedication-Fea≈øts are not ≈øo ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved.

Mr. Mallory of Mobberley is now Patron hereof; and this Rectory is conceived to be fully worth 120 l. per Annum. This Pari≈øh onely comprehendeth the Town≈øhip of Mobberley, which is 1 l. 18 s. 00 d. in the Mize-book.

I find in Mona≈øticon, the ≈øecond Volume, pag. 320. That one Patrick de Mobberley Founded here a ≈ømall Priory of Regular Canons, of the Order of St. Augu≈øtine, in Honour of God, the Virgin Mary, and St. Wilfrid, to abide and dwell for ever in the Church of Mobberley; whereunto he gave all that half of the Church of Mobberley, with its Appurtenances, which belonged to his Grant; ≈øo as the Par≈øons of the other half of the Church of Mobberley, which was not of his Grant, might challenge no Right in the ≈øaid Tenements: And he Con≈øtituted one Walter, a Canon, the fir≈øt Prior thereof. This was in the beginning of King John's Reign, about Anno Domini 1206.

By the half of the Church of Mobberley, ≈øeems to be included here the half of the Mannor of Mobberley: for in the end of the Grant is Liberty given to keep Courts there, as freely as ever the ≈øaid Patrick kept the ≈øame.
But not long after, Patrick was Convented before Randle Blundevill Earl of Che≈øter, as appears by this Inrolment following, a Copy whereof I received from old John Booth of Twamlow.

p.hi:
PAtricius de Mobberley, Conventus √† Johanne Filio Augu≈øtini de Brethmete Fratris ≈øui Primogeniti, in pleno Comitatu Ce≈øtriae, cor√†m Domino Comite Ranulpho, & Philippo de Orreby t√πnc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Cognovit ≈øe nihil Juris Haereditarii habui≈ø≈øe in ill√¢ medietate de Mobberley quam tenebat, ni≈øi tant√πm in vit√¢ ≈øu√¢ ex permi≈ø≈øione Fratris ≈øui Augu≈øtini Primogeniti, ≈øic√πt pleni√πs continetur in Cheirographo int√®r memorato Augu≈øtinum & Patricium Fratres habito: Et c√πm ≈øaep√® dictus Augu≈øtinus t√πnc viam Univer≈øitatis ingre≈ø≈øus
fuit, memoratus Johannes ejus Filius & Haeres ≈øeizinam praefatae Terrae recuperavit, & Homagium ≈øuum fecit ind√® Domino Ricardo de Aldford, qui ei fecit Chartam ≈øuam Confirmationis: quam tam√®n Terram praefatus Patricius tenebat in vit√¢ ≈øu√¢ de ip≈øo Johanne, ex permi≈ø≈øione ip≈øius Johannis Nepotis ≈øui: Et, ≈øicut praemon≈øtratum e≈øt, √† Domino Ranulpho dicto Johanni per Chartam ≈øuam confirmata e≈øt: & irrotulatur in te≈øtimonium veritatis.

div.p: There was a Doom≈øday-book in our Exchequer at Che≈øter formerly, wherein many Deeds and Records were Enrolled; but this Book of Record is now lo≈øt.
I ≈øuppo≈øe this Priory continued not long, the ≈øaid Patrick having no further E≈øtate in the half of Mobberley, than onely for his Life.

The Advow≈øon of the whole Church was Inve≈øted in the Heirs of John Son of Augu≈øtine; which ≈øhould have de≈øcended to John Leyce≈øter of Tabley, by the Settlement of Sir Raufe Mobberley of Mobberley, dated Anno Domini 1359. had not the ≈øaid John Leyce≈øter relea≈øed all his Right and Claim, as well in the ≈øaid Advow≈øon, as in all the Lands which belonged to Sir Raufe Mobberley, unto John Dumbill of Mobberley, and to Cicely his Wife: Dated at Che≈øter, on Tue≈øday next after the Fea≈øt of St. Mark the Evangeli≈øt, 1 Rich. 2. ≈øcilic√®t, in April, 1378. Which Relea≈øe is upon Record at Che≈øter, in the Prothonotaries Office there, die Martis proxim√® po≈øt Festum Sanctae Margaretae Virginis, 5 Rich. 2. Lib. A. fol. 129. gg. kk.

From Dumbill it came to Hul≈øe; from Hul≈øe, to Troutback; from Troutback, to Talbot of Grafton, who≈øe Po≈øterity afterwards came to be Earls of Shrewsbury; and at la≈øt, in our days, Thomas Mallory, late Dean of Che≈øter, and Par≈øon of Mobberley, bought the Advow≈øon hereof, to who≈øe Po≈øterity it yet remaineth.

div.head: Par≈øons of Mobberley.

list.item: 1281. Dominus Laurentius de Ce≈øtri√¢, 1281, & 1285.
1299. Adam Kel≈øall, Pre≈øented by VVilliam de Mobberly, 5 Calendas Julii, 1299.
1304. Johannes de Mobberley, per Re≈øignationem Adae de Kel≈øall, 1304. Pre≈øented by VVilliam Mobberley of Mobberley.

1306. Richard de Mobberley, Pre≈øented by VVilliam de Mobberley his Father, 1306. 34 Edw. 14. Calendas Januarii. This Richard was killed by one Richard Son of Richard de Mobberley, as ≈øeems by an Appeal brought by VVilliam Mobberley, Son of VVilliam Mobberley, Lord of the Moiety of Mobberley, for the death of his Brother: In Placitis Ce≈øtriae, die Martis in Fe≈øto Sancti Hilarii, 14 Edw. 2. (1320.)
1320. Henry de Henley Presbyter, 1320. Pre≈øented by VVilliam Mobberley.
1327. Robert Son of Robert de Huxley, 3 Nonas Novembris, 1327. per Johannem Arderne Militem, ratione Cu≈øtodiae Radulfi Filii & Haeredis Willielmi de Mobberley.
1351. Robertus de Craven, 1351. Caus√¢ Permutationis.
1359. William Jeffe≈øon, 1359. Lib. A. fol. 128. F.
1378. Johannes Brun≈øtath Par≈øon of Mobberley, 1378. 1 Rich. 2. Lib. A. fol. 130. ll.
1416. John Scolehall Par≈øon, 4 Hen. 5. Lib. C. fol. 266. num. 2.
1439. Roger Bolton Par≈øon of Mobberley, 18 Hen. 6. & 37 Hen. 6.

1460. Hamon Leyce≈øter, Pre≈øented 1 Junii, 1460. which was in the la≈øt Year of Henry the Sixth. This Hamon was a younger Son of John Leyce≈øter of Tabley, the elder, E≈øq He ≈øeems to have been Par≈øon of the Moiety of Limme-Church, which he re≈øigned 1457. See in Limme.

div.p: There was extant in the Church of Mobberley, the 28 of January, 1653. in the upper North-window of the Chancel, the Picture of a Man kneeling, and the Coat-Armour of Leyce≈øter of Tabley, in a Border-Argent for di≈øtinction; under which was written in the Gla≈øs,‚ÄîOrate pro Anim√¢ Magi≈øtri Hamonis Ley ....... ............................ Fene≈øtram fieri fecit, Anno Domini 1492.

Supply the defect thus,‚ÄîOrate pro Anim√¢ Magistri Hamonis Leyce≈øter Rectoris hujus Eccle≈øiae, qui hanc Fene≈øtram fieri fecit, Anno Domini 1492. Who was Par≈øon
of Mobberley from 1460. to 1492. who≈øe Father, John Leyce≈øter of Tabley the elder, was Son and Heir of William, Son and Heir of John, Nephew to Sir Raufe Mobberley above-mentioned, the la≈øt Heir of that Family of the Mobberleys.
Hitherto have I traced ≈øome of the Par≈øons of Mobberley.
As concerning the Par≈øons of Mobberley of the≈øe la≈øt Ages, I find in the Regi≈øter-Book of Mobberley-Church the≈øe following; which Regi≈øter beginneth but in Anno 1578.

Ann. Dom. 1570 John Caldwall Batchelor of Arts, Rector of Mobberley-Church full twenty four Years, and of Winwick in Lanca≈øhire about twenty Years. He was born at Burton upon Trent; and going into that Countrey to ≈øee his Friends, as he returned homewards he fell ≈øick at the Par≈øonage-Hou≈øe of Clyfton-Convill in Stafford≈øhire, where he died the la≈øt day of June, and was buried at that Church the fir≈øt day of July, in the 51 Year of his Age, Anno Domini 1595.

Robert Eaton, Ma≈øter of Arts, ≈øucceeded Rector of Mobberley-Church, 1595. He was Rector here about 26 Years, and died at his Par≈øonage of Mobberley the fifth day of July, 1621. and was buried at Gropenhale (whereof he was al≈øo Rector) on Thur≈øday the thirteenth of July following, in the 74 Year of his Age, having been Mini≈øter of God's Word 51 Years.

Thomas Mallory Dean of Che≈øter, younger Son of Sir William Mallory of Stewdley in York≈øhire, ≈øucceeded Par≈øon of Mobberley, 1621. He was Par≈øon of Davenham in Che≈øhire about 43 years, and of Mobberley about 23 Years. In November, 1642. he was forced (by rea≈øon of the Rebellion then rai≈øed in England) to fly from Mobberley to Che≈øter, where he lived Seque≈øtred from both his Par≈øonages of Davenham and Mobberley until the third day of April 1644. on which day, being Wedne≈øday, he died at the Dean's Hou≈øe in the Palace-yard at Che≈øter, and was buried in the Quire of the Cathedral-Church in that City, aged about 78 Years. He married Elizabeth Daughter of Richard Vaughan Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, and had many Children.
Roger Tovie Curate under Dean Mallory, 1622.
Samuel Carrington Curate of Mobberley under Dean Mallory, 1623. to 1630. or more.
George Mallory Curate of Mobberley under his Father, 1632.

Edward Wyrley Ma≈øter of Arts, younger Brother to Sir John Wyrley of Hamp≈øted-Hall in Stafford≈øhire Knight, ≈øucceeded Dean Mallory in the Rectory of Mobberley; In≈øtituted into the ≈øame by John Bridgeman Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, the eighth day of April, 1644. Which Edward had married Mary Mallory, Daughter of the ≈øaid Dean Mallory, the thirteenth of September, 1642.

But this Edward VVyrley continued Seque≈øtred hereof until the Re≈øtoration of King CHARLES the Second, 1660. and then he procured the King's Grant, and was di≈øpen≈øed with by his Grace the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, to hold with his Rectory of Mobberley, the Rectory of Loughton in the County of E≈ø≈øex al≈øo.

In the Time of the late War, one Robert Barlow Clerk, born about A≈øton ≈øuper Mer≈øey, was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Mobberley-Church; who married Mary Shakerley, elde≈øt Daughter of Peter Shakerley of Shakerley in Lanca≈øhire, and of Houlme in Allo≈øtock in Che≈øhire, E≈øq Married at Mobberley the ≈øixth day of July, 1652.

James Stanley, younger Son of Sir Thomas Stanley of Nether-Alderley Baronet, ≈øucceeded Rector of Mobberley, 1664. per Re≈øignationem Edwardi VVyrley: And after the death of Mr. Samuel Shipton Par≈øon of Nether-Alderley, the ≈øame James was al≈øo Rector of Nether-Alderley, by the Gift of his Father, Patron of the Church of Nether-Alderley. Par≈øon Shipton died 1670. This Mr. James Stanley was Ma≈øter of Arts of Je≈øus-College in Cambridge, and married Elizabeth Byron, an Inheritrix, Daughter of John Byron of Maxfield.

p.hi: So much of the Par≈øons of Mobberley.

div.p: This Town≈øhip of Mobberley, Bigot held in the Reign of the Conqueror, under Hugh Lupus Earl of Che≈øter, which one Dot held before.

Afterwards it came to Aldford of Aldford in Che≈øhire, not far from Che≈øter: And about the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt, Augu≈øtine de Brethmete was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of one Moiety, which he gave to his Brother Patrick during his Life; which Moiety was confirmed to John Son and Heir of Augu≈øtine, by Sir Richard Aldford, and al≈øo by Randle Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, about the Reign of King John, as appears by the Enrollment afore≈øaid; who≈øe Po≈øterity enjoyed the ≈øaid Moyety, until Sir Raufe Mobberley (having no Lawful I≈ø≈øue of his Body) E≈øtated all his Lands, by Chaplains entru≈øted, according to the manner of tho≈øe Times, on John Leyce≈øter of Tabley, his Nephew, with the Advow≈øon of the Church of Mobberley al≈øo, 1359. 34 Edw. 3. For Sir Raufe had often prote≈øted, That he would not have his Lands mangled among his Si≈øters, but that his Nephew John Leyce≈øter ≈øhould have them wholly; as appears by the Certificate of Sir John Winkfield: Dated at London, the eleventh day of June. 35 Edw. 3. (1361.) Lib. A. fol. 129. ff. gg. hh.

Afterwards, upon ≈øome Compo≈øition, John Leyce≈øter relea≈øeth all his Right in Mobberley's Lands, and in the Advow≈øon of the ≈øaid Church, unto John Dumbill of Mobberley, and to Cicely his Wife, 1 Rich. 2. 1378. yet ≈øo as John Dumbill and Cicely ≈øhould ≈øettle 15 Me≈ø≈øuages, 316 Acres of Land, 16 Acres of Wood, 8 Acres of Mo≈øs, the third part of a Watermill, and the third part of all the Wa≈øtes in Mobberley unmea≈øured [to be under≈øtood of Mobberley's Moiety], after the death of John Dumbill and Cicely, to de≈øcend to Raufe Leyce≈øter, younger Brother of the ≈øaid John Leyce≈øter, and to his Heirs for ever; which by Chaplains entru≈øted was ≈øettled accordingly, 30 die Maii, 2 Rich. 2. 1397. Lib. A. fol. 130. mm. which was either Conditioned in the Agreement of John Leyce≈øter, or the Rever≈øion thereof bought by the ≈øaid Raufe Leyce≈øter; from which Raufe are de≈øcended the Leyce≈øters of Toft, who do now enjoy the≈øe Lands, Anno Domini 1666. about one third part of the Moiety of Mobberley.

The other two Parts of this Moiety of Mobberley, which John Dumbill had, de≈øcended to Sir Hugh Hul≈øe, in Marriage with Margery Daughter and Heir of the ≈øaid John Dumbill and Cicely: And afterwards Margery, Daughter and Heir of Thomas Hul≈øe, married John Troutback E≈øquire; which Margery died 35 Hen. 6. and had I≈ø≈øue William Troutback, who≈øe Son Sir William dying without I≈ø≈øue, Adam Troutback (Brother of Sir William) had I≈ø≈øue Margaret, Daughter and Heir, married to John Talbot Lord of Albrighton in Shrop≈øhire, from whom the Talbots of Grafton in Worce≈øter≈øhire, who≈øe Po≈øterity afterwards came to be Earls of Shrewsbury.

The other Moiety of Mobberley Sir John Arderne of Aldford granted to John Legh of Booths, with Ward≈øhips, and Freedom from Appearance at his Court of Nether-Alderley; Rendring eight Pounds yearly for his Life: And after the death of John Legh, then to remain to John Legh, Son and Heir of the other John Legh afore≈øaid, and to Maud Daughter of the ≈øaid Sir John Arderne, and to their Heirs for ever; Rendring a Ro≈øe at Mid≈øommer, for all Service: And if John Legh, Son of John, died before he married Maud, then William Brother to John Legh, Son of John, was to marry her. Witne≈ø≈øes of this Deed were, Sir John Orreby, and Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, Knights; Robert de Pulford, Philip de Egerton, Richard de Fowle≈øhur≈øt, Thomas de Legh, William de Mobberley, Roger de Leyce≈øter, William de Mere, Adam de Tabley, William Danyers, Ma≈øter Roger of Alderley, Hugh Clerke, and others: Lib. A. fol. 122. a. The Original remaining among the Evidences of Mr. Robin≈øon of Mobberley, 1664.
This Deed was made about 1303. 31 Edw. 1.

Richard Ratcliffe of Urde≈øhall in Lanca≈øhire married Maud Daughter and Heir of John Legh, Son and Heir of Sir John Legh by Maud Arderne, and had the≈øe Lands of her Grandmothers, to wit the Moiety of Mobberley; who≈øe Heirs enjoyed the ≈øame, till they ≈øold out certain of their Tenements in Mobberley to their Tenants there: And what remained, together with the Services of ≈øuch Tenants as were formerly ≈øold out of this Moiety, Sir John Ratcliffe of Urde≈øhall ≈øold unto Mr. Robert Robin≈øon of Mobberley, about the beginning of King James's Reign over England. Lib. A. fol. 122. b. c.

div.head: Now followeth the De≈øcent of Mobberley of Mobberley.

figure.head: Argent, two Cheverons Gules, in a Canton of the ≈øecond a Cro≈øs Cro≈ølet Fitch√©e, Or.

div.p: John, Son and Heir of Augustine, Lord of the Moiety of Mobberley, lived in the Reign of King John. Lib. A. fol. 124. a.
Raufe Mobberley of Mobberley, Lord of the Moiety of Mobberley, lived in the Reign of Henry the Third; but I cannot prove him Son of John.

William Mobberley of Mobberley, Son of Raufe, was Lord of the Moiety of Mobberley, and Patron of Mobberley-Church. He bought the Moiety of Nether-Pever from Richard Bon≈øtable, Anno Domini 1281. G. num. 21. The Original in my po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

This William had I≈ø≈øue William Mobberley; John Mobberley, to whom his Father gave all his Lands in Nether-Pever and Tatton, 31 Edw. 1. 1303. G. num. 65. But John dying without I≈ø≈øue, tho≈øe Lands reverted to William his Brother: Richard Mobberley, another Son, made Par≈øon of Mobberley by his Father, 1306. ≈ølain by Richard Son of Richard de Mobberley, 1320. 14 Edw. 2. Lib. A. fol. 124. w. & 131. Alice, a Daughter, married William de Tabley Lord of Over-Tabley and Knotsford: She was Widow 27 Edw. 1. 1300.
This William died about the beginning of Edw. 2.

William Mobberley of Mobberley, Son and Heir of William, married Maud Daughter and Heir of Robert Downes of Chorley juxt√† Werford; unto which Robert, Edmund Fitton gave all his Lands in Chorley in Free Marriage with Margery his Si≈øter. Lib. A. fol. 127. t. v.

This William was Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 13 Edw. 2. 1319. and had I≈ø≈øue Raufe Mobberley; Cicely married John Dumbill of Mobberley, Son and Heir of John Dumbill of Oxton in Wirrall; Elizabeth married Sir Hugh Venables of Kinderton; Margery married Richard Bold of Bold in Lanca≈øhire; Emme married Robert Gro≈øvenour of Houlme in Allo≈øtock, who purcha≈øed the Moiety of Nether-Pever from this William de Mobberley: Mary, another Daughter, married Nicolas Leyce≈øter, Son and Heir of Roger Leyce≈øter of Tabley; Joan married William Athurton of Athurton in Lanca≈øhire; Ellen married Richard Bromhale of Bromhale in Che≈øhire; and Agnes never married: Lib. A. fol. 127. w. x. y. z. a. & fol. 128. cc. & fol. 129. kk.

This William Sealed u≈øually with his Coat of Arms, to wit, Two Cheverons, and in a Canton a Cro≈øs-Cro≈ølet Fitch√©e: Lib. A. fol. 124. y. z. as is before expre≈ø≈øed in the beginning of this De≈øcent.
He died 1 Edw. 3. 1327. Lib. C. fol. 103. num. 9. Maud his Widow afterwards married John Dumbill ≈øenior: Lib. A. fol. 128. ff.

Sir Raufe Mobberley of Mobberley Knight, Son and Heir of William, was Ward to Sir John Arderne of Aldford, 3 Edw. 3. Lib. A. fol. 128. cc. who gave the Marriage of this Raufe unto John Pulford of Pulford, Son of Sir Robert Pulford, ≈øin√® di≈øparagatione, 1329.
This Sir Raufe married Vincentia Daughter of John Pulford: Lib. A. fol. 128. bb. and died in France, 35 Edw. 3. 1361. without any Lawful I≈ø≈øue of his Body.

Sir Raufe had by Alice Rode (his Concubine) a Daughter, called Margaret, married
to Thomas Toft, younger Brother to Hugh Toft of Toft, to whom Sir Raufe Mobberley gave his Mannor in Plumley, 1357. Afterwards Margaret married Hugh Chaderton, living 1360. Lib. C. fol. 226. v. Lib. A. fol. 129. hh.

The≈øe Lands in Plumley de≈øcended to the two Daughters and Co-heirs of Margaret by Thomas Toft; to wit, Ellen, who married John Bodon of Plumley; and Sybill, who married Thomas Ha≈ølington of the Ermitage nigh Holmes-Chappel.

John Bodon, Son of John Bodon afore≈øaid, ≈øold his Moiety of the≈øe Lands in Plumley to John Leyce≈øter of Tabley, the elder, E≈øquire, 25 Hen. 6. 1446. who≈øe Heirs enjoy the ≈øame at this day: S. num. 2, 3, 5, 6, 9.

The other Moiety of tho≈øe Lands in Plumley de≈øcended unto Cicely Daughter and Heir of Sybill afore≈øaid; which Cicely married Hugh Winnington of Northwich, 1444. and ever ≈øince continued to the VVinningtons of Ermitage, until Mr. Brad≈øhaw of Marple in Che≈øhire bought tho≈øe Lands from VVinnington in the Reign of King CHARLES the Fir≈øt; Thomas Buckley of Plumley being now Tenant thereof, 1666.
The Si≈øters of Sir Raufe Mobberley ≈øhared their Mothers Land in Chorley; but Emme Gro≈øvenour purcha≈øed mo≈øt of the other Si≈øters Parts: Lib. A. fol. 127. w. x. y. aa.

p.hi: So ended the Line of Mobberley of Mobberley.

div.p: The Mannor-Hou≈øe of Mobberley of Mobberley, and which at la≈øt came to the Talbots of Grafton in VVorce≈øter≈øhire, ≈øtood clo≈øe by Mobberly-Church, where now, 1672. the Hou≈øe of Mr. Mallory of Mobberley ≈øtandeth: But the ancient Fabrick, which was more ≈øpacious, and very ruinous, was not long ≈øince taken down: Which Old Hou≈øe, with the Demain thereof, together with the Advow≈øon of Mobberley-Church, and Mobberley-Mill, was bought by Andrew Carrington of Mobberley Gentleman, from George Talbot of Grafton E≈øquire, about 14 Jacobi. Part of which Demain was ≈øold ≈øoon after by Carrington to Robert Robin≈øon of Mobberley Gentleman.

The Advow≈øon of the Church was ≈øold by Andrew Carrington afore≈øaid, and John his Son and Heir, unto Thomas Mallory Dean of Che≈øter, by Deed dated the eleventh day o ‚Ä¢
October, 17 Jacobi, 1619. who≈øe Heir Thomas Mallory, now under Age, is Patron of Mobberley-Church, 1672. Son of Thomas, Son of Richard Mallory, Son and Heir of Dean Mallory afore≈øaid.

The Mannor-Hou≈øe afore≈øaid, with what remained of the Demain unbought by Mr. Robin≈øon, was ≈øold by Andrew Carrington afore≈øaid, and John his Son and Heir, unto Dean Mallory, the eighth of May, Anno primo Caroli Primi, 1625.
Dean Mallory al≈øo Purcha≈øed the Royalty of Talbot's Part of Mobberley from John Talbot Earl of Shrewsbury: Dated the twentieth day of March, 7 Car. 1. 1631.
The Mill Carrington ≈øold to Legh of Booths.

There is Engraven in the Stone, under the Ledge or Border, on the We≈øt-end of Mobberley-Steeple, and on the South-we≈øt-corner, as followeth:‚Äî ORATE PRO BONO STATU DOMINI JOHANNIS TALBOT MILITIS, ET DOMINAE MARGARETAE UXORIS SUAE, And then beginning again ju≈øt over the ≈øaid Border, in the very Corner of the Steeple afore≈øaid,‚Äî PATRONAE ECCLESIAE. And ≈øo pa≈ø≈øing along to the South-≈øide of the Steeple,‚Äî ANNO DOMINI MILESIMO QUINGENTESIMO TRICESIMO TERTIO. RICHARD PLAT MASTER-MASON. Over which, on the ≈øaid South-≈øide, above, near to the Little Window under the Bells, is Ratcliff's Coat of Arms, Quartered with another Coat, engraven in a Stone.
So that Mobberley-Steeple ≈øeems to have been built with Free-≈øtone, and the Church repaired, Anno 1533. 24 Hen. 8.

div.head: The Names of all ≈øuch Per≈øons who now stand po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of any Free-hold Lands of Inheritance in Mobberley, Anno Domini 1672.
div.p: 1. Raufe Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øquire, Lord of a third Part of one Moiety of Mobberley. This came originally to his Ance≈øtor (as is before declared) 2 Rich. 2. 1379. And he hath at this day a Demain-Hou≈øe there, re-built this Year, 1672. and al≈øo ≈øixteen Tenenements, and twelve Cottages, in Lea≈øe to his Tenants.

2. The other two third Parts of this Moiety, together with the Advow≈øon of Mobberley-Church, lately belonged to the Talbots of Grafton in Worce≈øter≈øhire, who≈øe Po≈øterity afterwards came to be Earls of Shrewsbury; and were lately ≈øold away by Talbot, to his Tenants here in Mobberley, in the Reign of King James.
Talbot's Lands, as they now ≈øtand Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, 1672. or, more briefly, the Freeholders of Mobberley in Talbot's Part, ≈øince their ≈øeveral Purcha≈øes from Talbot, as they now ≈øtand, 1672.

list.item: Charles Bradbury of the Wood-end.
Robert Barlow, late Griffin's Hou≈øe.
Hugh Brook, late Wilkin≈øon's.
John Davenport, for Mo≈ø≈øe's Hou≈øe by the Mill: A ≈ømall Cottage.
Richard Strethull's Cottage; formerly Hob≈øon's Hou≈øe by the Mill.
Hugh Strethull of Brown-Edge.
James Stewart of Brown-Edge, Schoolma≈øter.
Raufe Wren≈øhaw of Brown-Edge.
Francis Newton of Knowl-Green; late John Baggiley.
Hugh Strethull of Salterley in Mobberley.
Roger Symcock; late Stretche's Hou≈øe.
Hugh Strethull of Reyley-Wood.
Richard Wright; part of Wor≈øeley's Tenement.
John Hawkin≈øon; late Bolton's Tenement.
Richard Parker; late Edward Hewet's.
Roger Worthington of Hield-Mill in Mobberley; and al≈øo for Hill-hou≈øe.
John Burges of Wood-end.
Su≈øan Grange Widow.
Henry Stewart, formerly Berry's Tenement.
John Fletcher, formerly Berry's Tenement.

John Holland of the Dam-head in Mobberley. George Talbot of Grafton E≈øq ≈øells the Tenement of John Strettle of the Dam-head to one Perine of Manche≈øter, 1 Junii, 14 Jacobi. Perine Mortgageth it to Francis We≈øt of London, 16 Aug. 14 Jacobi. We≈øt and Perine after joyn in the Sale of it to William Holland, 1650.
Peter Bredbury of Lea-Hou≈øe.
William Nuthall; now Richard Yarwood.
Widow Tipping of Bowdon hath a Tenement in Mobberley, now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Richard Cragg of Baggiley-Green in Mobberley.
Peter Legh of Booths E≈øq hath Mobberley-Mill, and three Tenements, now in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Loundes, Barrow, and Symcock; and al≈øo Grai≈øty's Cottage, The≈øe were anciently Talbot's.
The Heir of Nathaniel Robin≈øon Gentleman, hath part of the Demain which belonged to the old Mobberley-Hou≈øe, formerly belonging to Talbot.
Thomas Mallory of Mobberley Gentleman, now under Age. This was the old Mobberley Hou≈øe. And he hath al≈øo the Royalty of all Talbot's Part of Mobberley, and the Advow≈øon of the Church.

div.p: 3. The other Moiety of Mobberley, lately belonging to the Radcliffs of Ord≈øall in Lanca≈øhire, nigh Manche≈øter, was ≈øold away by Sir John Radcliff, about the beginning of King James's Reign over England, to his Tenants there.

div.head: The Names of the Free-holders in Radcliff's Part, ≈øince the ≈øeveral Purcha≈øes from Radcliffe, as they now ≈øtand, 1672.
div.p: The Heir of Nathaniel Robin≈øon, late of Mobberley, Gentleman, hath now ≈øeven Me≈ø≈øuages and eleven Cottages in Mobberley, be≈øides a Demain-Hou≈øe here, built fir≈øt by Robert Robin≈øon, about 1612. who Purcha≈øed the≈øe Lands by the Name of Robert Robin≈øon of Manche≈øter Clothier, from Sir John Radcliff of Ord≈øall Knight; together with the Royalty of all Radcliffs Lands in Mobberley, formerly ≈øold by Radcliff to his Tenants here; and all the old Rents re≈øerved to Radcliff, amounting in the whole to 23 l. 00 s. 00 d. yearly, or thereabout: by Deed dated the 19 of April, 4 Jacobi, 1606. for which he paid 1530 l. Purcha≈øe-Money.

Randle Black≈øhaw. This was bought from Sir John Radcliff of Ord≈øall, by Deed dated the eighth day of Augu≈øt, 1611. and is ≈øaid to be the Ancient Demain-Hou≈øe of Mobberley, which did belong to Radcliff.
Peter Legh of Booths E≈øE≈øq hath three Tenements in Radcliff's Part, now in Tenure of George Leyce≈øter, Cook≈øon, and the Fox-hou≈øe.

list.item: John Gleave of High-Legh, Owner of Holden-Cliff-Hou≈øe in Mobberley.
Roger Symcock, lately Purcha≈øed from Mrs. Martha Hurle≈øton, formerly Oldfield's Lands.
Homfrey Cherry, lately Purcha≈øed from Mrs. Martha Hurle≈øton, formerly Oldfield's Lands.
William Coppock, lately Purcha≈øed from Mrs. Martha Hurle≈øton, formerly Oldfield's Lands.
Rafe Shaw, lately Purcha≈øed from Mrs. Martha Hurle≈øton, formerly Oldfield's Lands.
Richard Parker, for Mere-Hou≈øe; ≈øold away by Mr. Robin≈øon.
Richard Yarwood for Bowers.
John An≈øon; ≈øold by Mr. Robin≈øon.
Richard Seddall of Wood-end.
Richard Bruch; formerly Duncalf's.
Thomas Hield of the Broad-Oak in Mobberley.
John Strethull; late Bate≈øon's Hou≈øe.
Roger Hewet of Pavement-Lane.
Richard Rowlin≈øon of Roanes, pro Fox-hou≈øe.
John Symcock of the Dub'd-Hedge.
Daniel Yarwood; formerly Oldrin≈øhaw's.
John Baggiley of the Mo≈ø≈øe-≈øide.
Widow Strethull of the Town-Lane.
John Holland of Dam-head hath certain Parcels of Land in Ratcliff's Part, ≈øold away by Mr. Robin≈øon, 1639.
Urme≈øton's Lands in Mobberley, bought for Pious U≈øes.
Thomas Whitchcot; late John Radford's.
Peter Bradbury of Brook-bank, a Cottage.
Robert Ridgeway, a Cottage.

div.head: More.
div.p: THis Town of More is of the Fee of Halton. Roger Lacy Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire and Baron of Halton, had a Brother called Richard, to whom he gave the Town of More: and afterwards the ≈øaid Richard became Leprous, and was buried in the Chapter-hou≈øe of the Canons of Norton: Mona≈øticon, Vol. 1. pag. 860.
This was about the Reign of King Richard the Fir≈øt.
The Name More ≈øignifieth a more barren Ground than Mar≈øhes be; a Miry and Moori≈øh Soil, yet ≈øerveth not to get Turfs thereon: Coke upon Littleton, fol. 5. a.

The Inhabitants of More and Runcorn were formerly Copy-holders to the Barons of Halton; but have lately bought out their own Land, to hold in Fee-farm, in Free and Common Soccage, of the Mannor of Enfield in the County of Middle≈øex; the Kings Grant bearing date the ninth day of September, 4 Car. 1. 1628. ≈øave onely the≈øe Per≈øons following, who now are, and their Ance≈øtors anciently before them were, Free-holders in the Mannor of More, and not Fee-farmers, as followeth.

list.head: Free-holders or Charterers in More, 1666.
list.item: 1. Henry Porter of More: This hath continued in the Name of Porter ≈øince Edward the Fourth: This Free-hold before belonged to one Peter Arderne, in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, as by the Deed now in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this Henry Porter appeareth.

2. Sir Richard Brooks of Norton Baronet, hath now about twenty Che≈øhire Acres of Free-Land in More, as late belonging to the Priory of Norton; and al≈øo about ≈øix Acres more of Free-hold Land adjoyning, lately bought from Crosby of Over-Whitley.

3. The≈øe were all purcha≈øed from Brook of Norton; and Brook bought them of Harper of Newton.
Robert Pickering of Thelwall E≈øquire, Coun≈øellor at Law, hath one Janion's Hou≈øe.
Richard Rutter hath al≈øo other Free-hold Land.
Richard Dutton of Mo≈ø≈øe-end, other Free-hold Land.
4. Widow Harper hath now al≈øo certain Free-hold Land in More.

div.head: Newton juxta Daresbury.
div.p: THis Town, according to its Name, is not of ≈øo great Antiquity: For I find it granted by Parcels, and Enclo≈øures, and Clo≈øes, ≈øome in Henry the Third's Time, ≈øome under Edward the Fir≈øt, and ≈øome in the Reign of Edward the Second, by the Ance≈øtors of VVarburton of Arley, before they had relinqui≈øhed their proper Sir-name of Dutton; who were Lords thereof from King John's Time unto this pre≈øent, 1666.

list.head: The Charterers now in Newton, 1666.
list.item: Sable, a Cro≈øs engrailed Ermine. And in 11 Edw. 4. 1471. Thomas Chickford and Elizabeth his Wife (Daughter and Heir of Robert de Hallum, Son and Heir of William de Hallum) ≈øold the Mannor of Hallum to Sir John Nedham, ≈øometime Judge of Che≈øter, who ≈øetled the ≈øame upon Robert Nedham his younger Brother; who≈øe Line failing at la≈øt for want of Heirs Males, it de≈øcended to Robert Nedham of Shenton E≈øquire, 21 Eliz. from whom the Lord Kilmorie, now Owner of Hallum, 1666. I ≈øpeak here out of the Lord Kilmorie's Evidences.

2. Rafe Starky of Morthwait in Newton, Lawyer; who≈øe Ance≈øtor Thomas Starky married Agnes Si≈øter and Heir of Thomas Harper, and Daughter of Richard Harper of Newton, 32 Hen. 6. Lib. C. fol. 205. g.

3. Grim≈ødich of Grim≈ødich in Nether-Whitley hath al≈øo Lands in Newton, which Thomas Grim≈ødich (then of Hallum by Lea≈øe) bought of John Daniell of Daresbury, 12 Hen. 8. Lib. C. fol. 194. num. 44, 46, 47. And which Lands John Daniell Ance≈øtor of the ≈øaid John, had in Marriage with Jonet Daughter and Heir of Thomas Hallum of Newton, 1 Hen. 6. Lib. C. fol. 193. num. 36, 37.
4. Robert Venables of Anterbus in the Lord≈øhip of Over-Whitley, hath Lands in Newton.
5. John Starky of Newton.

div.head: Norton.
div.p: THis Town≈øhip of Norton was given by William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire the younger, Son of William Fitz-Nigell, unto the Canons of Runcorne, in exchange for Lands in Runcorne; and ≈øo he removed the Canons of Runcorne to Norton, about the Reign of King Stephen.

Anno 1135. Mona≈øterium de Norton in Comitatu Ce≈øtriae Fundatur √† Willielmo Filio Nigelli, Con≈øtabulario Ce≈øtriae: Hi≈øtoria Aurea Johannis Tynemyten≈øis, lib. 19. cap. 41. A Manu≈øcript in the Publick Library at Oxford, inter Libros Juris, v. 4. num. 4. Wherewith al≈øo agreeth Polychronicon, lib. 7. cap. 17.

Mona≈øticon, Vol. 2. pag. 187. tells us, William Fitz-Nigell Founded a Religious Hou≈øe of Canons Regular at Runcorne, Anno Domini 1133. And afterwards William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, the younger, removed them from Runcorne to Norton. Which agrees with the Deed Lib. B. pag. 199. num. 1.

After the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies in England by Henry the Eighth, Richard Brooks E≈øquire Purcha≈øed from the King the Mannor of Norton, with its Members and Appurtenances, to wit, Norton, Stockham, Acton-Grange, and A≈øton-Grange in Che≈øhire, and Cuerdly in Lanca≈øhire, with other Lands. The Charter is dated decimo die Decembris, 37 Hen. 8. 1545. who≈øe Heir now enjoyeth the≈øe Lands, 1666.

There is a certain Hamlet or Place, called Endley, now belonging to the Town≈øhip of Norton, and enjoyed as Part and Parcel of the ≈øame, which William Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton held as a di≈øtinct thing by it ≈øelf in the Conqueror's Time, as appears by Doom≈øday-book. This afterwards came to A≈øton of A≈øton: For Richard A≈øton of A≈øton, Son of Gilbert, gave to God, and St. Mary, and to Randle Prior of Norton‚Äîall his Land of Hendeley, with all its Appurtenances, about King John's Reign. Lib. B. pag. 200. num. 8.
Here was anciently a Church belonging to this Priory, dedicated to St. Mary: But this Church of Norton was pulled down after the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies.
The Place of this Priory is now the Seat of Brook of Norton, who enjoyeth the whole Town of Norton entirely, by him≈øelf and his Le≈ø≈øees, wherein is no Charterer at all.

div.head: Now followeth the De≈øcent of Brook of Norton ≈øince the Purcha≈øe.
div.p: This Family is de≈øcended from the Brookes of Leighton in Nantwich-Hundred; of which Family I find one Adam Dominus de Leighton, ≈øub Henrico Tertio, who≈øe Son was ≈øtiled William de la Brook de Leighton, and his Son Richard ≈øtiled Ricardus de Doito, in an old Deed, 5 Edw. 1. that is, Of the Brook; for Doet in French, is A Brook in Engli≈øh; and under the ≈øaid Manour-Hou≈øe in Leighton a Brook runneth, from whence their Po≈øterity a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name del Brook.

Thomas Brook of Leighton Gentleman, the la≈øt of that Family in the Direct Line, died about 1652. very aged, having I≈ø≈øue four Daughters; but he ≈øold away the Rever≈øion of his Lands to the Lady Mary Cholmondley, 6 Jacobi, 1608. which afterwards came to Francis Cholmondley, third Son of Thomas Cholmondley of Vale-Royal E≈øquire, who now enjoyeth the ≈øame, 1666.

He married Chri≈øtian Daughter of John Carew of Haccomb in Devon≈øhire, and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Brook; Chri≈øtian married Richard Gro≈øvenour of Eaton-Boat in Che≈øhire E≈øquire; and Martha married Hugh Starky of Moore, younger Son of Starkey of Darley.
This Richard died 11 Eliz. 1569. Christian his Widow afterwards married Richard Done.
This Richard Brook was Sheriff 1563. 5 Eliz.
II. Thomas Brook of Norton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard, had three Wives.

The fir≈øt was Anne Daughter of Henry Lord Audley, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Richard Brook, Son and Heir; George, drowned in Warrington-Water; Christian married Richard Starky of Stretton in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire; Elinour married John Brook of Blacklands in Stafford≈øhire; and Margaret married one Warburton.

His ≈øecond Wife was Elizabeth Si≈øter of Thomas Merbury of Merbury nigh Comberbach, E≈øquire, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue William Brook, Thomas Brook, and Valentine Brook; al≈øo Towne≈øend married Thomas Legh de Ea≈øt-Hall in High-Legh E≈øquire; Elizabeth married George Spur≈øtow of Spur≈øtow in Che≈øhire E≈øquire; Dorothy married William Barne≈øton of Churton in Che≈øhire; Frances married George Legh of Barton in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire; Anne married Richard Merbury of Walton in Che≈øhire; and Clare, Wife of Theophilus Legh of Grange in the File of Lanca≈øhire.
