His third Wife was Elinour Gerard, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Andrew, who died young; and Peter Brook, who Purcha≈øed the Mannor of Mere, nigh Over-Tabley, 1652. and was Knighted 1660. of whom ≈øee more in Mere: Al≈øo Alice, a Daughter, married Thomas Birch of Birch in Lanca≈øhire; Elinour married William A≈øhton Rector of Middleton in Lanca≈øhire, and younger Son of A≈øhton of Middleton; which William purcha≈øed the Lands of Booth of Cog≈øhull in Che≈øhire juxt√† Over-Whitley; Elinour was Widow 1660. And Rachel Wife of Henry Slater of Light-Okes in Bedford in Lanca≈øhire, afterwards Sir Henry Slater.
This Thomas Brook of Norton was twice Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 1578. and 1592. and died Anno Domini 1622.

III. Sir Richard Brook of Norton Knight, Son and Heir of Thomas, was Knighted in Ireland, and married Jane Daughter and Heir of William Chaderton Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, by whom he had a Daughter, married to one Jo≈øeline of Cambridge≈øhire, who had all her Mothers Lands: But through ≈øome di≈ølike after Marriage, Sir Richard and Jane his Wife lived a≈øunder.

Afterwards Sir Richard married to his ≈øecond Wife Katharine Daughter of Sir Henry Nevill of Billingsbere in Berk≈øhire, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Henry Brook, Son and Heir; Thomas Brook, ≈øecond Son, who married Jane Daughter of one We≈øton of Sutton nigh Frod≈øham, Tenant to Warburton of Arley, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Richard Brook, and Catharine a Daughter, both living 1666. Richard Brook, third Son of Sir Richard, Profe≈ø≈øor of Phy≈øick, died at Boughton, nigh Che≈øter, without I≈ø≈øue, Anno Domini 1667. George, fourth Son; and John, fifth Son: Mary married Thomas Merebury, Half-Brother and afterwards Heir to William Merebury of Merebury nigh Comberbach E≈øquire; Anne married Edward Hyde of Norbury juxt√† Pointon, E≈øquire; Dorothy married Lawrence Hyde, younger Brother of the ≈øaid Edward.
Sir Richard Brook died Anno Domini 1632.

IV. Henry Brook of Norton, Son and Heir of Sir Richard, was Created Baronet, 1662. He married Mary Daughter of Timothy Pu≈øey of Nottingham≈øhire, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Richard, Son and Heir; Henry, ≈øecond Son, married Mary Daughter and Heir of Philip Prichard of Bo≈øtock-Green in Davenham-Pari≈øh; and Pu≈øey Brook, third Son, all living 1666.

This Henry Brook was Sheriff four Years together, beginning 1644. appointed by the Parliament without the King, in the time of the late Rebellion: Richard Gro≈øvenour of Eaton-Boat E≈øquire (Son and Heir to Sir Richard Gro≈øvenour of Eaton, Baronet, then al≈øo living) being made Sheriff by the King in the ≈øame Year, 1644. The other being extrajudicial, again≈øt the Law and Prerogative of the King.
Sir Henry Brook Baronet died Anno Domini 1664.

V. Sir Richard Brook of Norton Baronet, Son and Heir of Sir Henry, married Franci≈øca-Po≈øthuma (≈øo called, becau≈øe ≈øhe was born after the death of her Father) Si≈øter to Richard Legh of Lyme in Che≈øhire E≈øquire, and hath I≈ø≈øue.
This Sir Richard was Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 1667.

div.head: Owlarton.
div.p: IN the Reign of William the Conqueror, Hamon Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy held one Moiety of Owlarton; and Ranulphus, the ≈øuppo≈øed Ance≈øtor of the Manwarings, held the other Moiety.

This Town≈øhip was afterwards ≈øcattered into ≈øeveral Parcels; but Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton by Purcha≈øe got into his Hands mo≈øt part of this Town≈øhip, and was Lord of the Mannor of Owlarton in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, as may appear by the≈øe following Notes, extracted out of the Earl of Bridgewater's Deeds, 1667. by John Hal≈øey of Lincolns-Inn E≈øquire.
Nicolas Lord Audley gave all his Lands in Owlarton and Tatton to Richard Ma≈ø≈øy and I≈øabell his Wife, about 1286.

Sir John Arderne of Aldford gave to Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy and I≈øabell his Wife, omnes Terras ≈øuas & Tenementa in Owlarton: Habendum c√πm Homagiis, Servitiis, Wardis, Releviis,
Redditibus, E≈øcaetis,‚Äî&c. Reddendo quatuordecem Denarios per Annum pro omni Servitio, Sect√¢ Curiarum,‚Äî&c. This was about 27 Edw. 1.
Richard Dunne of Owlarton gave certain Lands in Owlarton, and two Parts of a Mill with the Pool, in exchange with Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy for other Lands in that Town≈øhip.
Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale, gave to Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, Lands in Owlarton, in exchange for Lands in Sale, under Edward the Second.

Anno 1 Hen. 6. there was a Survey of the Mannors and Lands of Sir Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton by a Jury; it was there found, That Sir Geffrey was Lord of the Mannor of Owlarton, and divers Free Tenants there; among whom Ranulphus Manwaring qui reddit pro le Bronteles-Place, 5 s. 0 d.
& Johannes Legh del Booths, pro certis Terris vocatis Babrinchull, reddendo per Annum 2 s. 8 d. and had al≈øo nine Tenants at Will, paying in all 8 l. 11 s. 10 d. Rent.

In the Office after the death of Alice the Widow of Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton 6 Hen. 6. 1427. ≈øhe was found to hold the Mannor of Owlarton of John Ratcliffe of Urde≈øhall in Lanca≈øhire nigh Manche≈øter.
How it de≈øcended from Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton to the Earl of Bridgewater, ≈øee the Pedegree in Tatton.

list.head: Charterers in Owlarton, 1666.
list.item: 1. Legh of Booths, now under Age, hath about fifty Che≈øhire Acres in Owlarton in Lea≈øe, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Randle Cadman, John Wainwright, John Ridgeway del Oake, Richard Ward, William Baggiley's Cottage, and Robert Partington's Cottage.
43 Edw. 3. I≈øabell the Widow of Sir John Legh del Booths died ≈øeized of the ≈øixth Part of Owlarton, which was then found to be held of Hugh Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton.
2. Edmund Howe of Owlarton hath a good Freehold there.
3. Richard Wright of A≈øhley hath Land in Owlarton.
4. William Baggiley junior, about four Acres of Prie≈øt-land.

5. Downes of Shrop≈øhire, but late of Toft, four Tenements in Owlarton, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Philip Ridgeway, Roger Cadman, John Smith, and John Clerke. The≈øe 4 pay Chief to the Lord of Nether Alderley, as held of Arderne.
6. John Norbury of Harborough in Over-Alderley hath one Tenement in Owlarton, and three Cottages. The≈øe 4 pay Chief to the Lord of Nether Alderley, as held of Arderne.
7. Humfrey Duncalf; bought of Page of Yerd≈øhawe. The≈øe 4 pay Chief to the Lord of Nether Alderley, as held of Arderne.
8. John Swinton of Nether-Knotsford hath two Tenements, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of James Ridgeway and Richard Banks. The≈øe 4 pay Chief to the Lord of Nether Alderley, as held of Arderne.
9. Lawrence Barlow, one Cottage, bought of John Merriman, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Hugh Manwaring; another in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Elizabeth Huet.
10. Randle Cadman; bought from John Hall of Norley lately.

div.head: Partington.
div.p: THis Town≈øhip of Partington was anciently of the Fee of the Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.
a. Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy gave to Hugh Bodon Clerk, the ≈øixth Part of Partington, about Edw. 1.
Hugh Bodon Clerk, gave to Aytrop de Millington, c√πm Mabili√¢ Nepte me√¢, ≈øextam partem totius Villae de Partington; Rendring to Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy, and his Heirs, one Pair of Gloves at Mid≈øummer.

b. Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy gave to Adam Sunderland all the Moiety of his Land in Partington, which he bought of Geffrey Holdene; Salvo Servitio & Homagio Ricardi Bolour in e√¢dem Vill√¢; videlic√®t, ≈øextam partem totius Villae de Partington: Reddendo dimidiam Marcam Argenti: An old Copy of a Deed, no Witne≈ø≈øes. This is conceived to be the Copy of Mr. Hadfield's Deed, of Derby≈øhire, who now holdeth a ≈øixth Part of Partington, and pays 6 s. 8 d. yearly to Mr. Crew of Crew, 1666.

c. Geffrey Son of Robert de Walley gave to John his Brother all his Land in Partington, which he had of the Grant of Sir Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy; Rendring yearly to Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy and his Heirs, one Pound of Cummin, in Fe≈øto Johannis Bapti≈øtae, that is, Mid≈øummer-day, about Edw. 1. Lib. B. pag. 211. num. 3, 4, 5, 6. The Originals among the Evidences of the Lord Delamere at Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.

d. In an ancient Rental of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 3‚ñ™ Hen. 4.‚ÄîGeorgius Carington Chivaler tenet Manerium ≈øuum de Carington, & medietatem Villae de A≈øhton, & tertiam partem Villae de Partington, pro duabus Partibus Feodi Militis.
So that now, Anno Domini 1666. the Mannor of Partington is ≈øhared as followeth:‚Äî

1. George Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy is Lord of a third Part of Partington in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which was Carington's of Carington; and al≈øo Chief Lord of the other two third Parts, which are originally held of the Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.
2. John Hadfield of Over-Cliffe in the County of Derby hath now a ≈øixth Part of Partington, according to the Original Deed made by Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy: ≈øupra b.

3. Thomas Warburton of Partington hath another ≈øixth Part, according to the Purcha≈øe thereof made by Thomas Flixton from Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy (tempore Henrici tertii): Rendring yearly four Shillings: Which Rent idem Thomas Warburton payeth to the Lord of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy at this day.

Idem Thomas Warburton hath an eighteenth Part of Partington more, id e≈øt, a third Part of a ≈øixth Part, which his Ance≈øtor William Son of Peter Warburton had from Richard le Harper of Partington, and Agnes his Wife, by Fine at Che≈øter, 13 Edw. 2. 1319. Lib. B. pag. 212. num. 6, 7. The Originals now remaining with the ≈øaid Thomas Warburton of Partington.

4. John Warburton of Partington, Have another ≈øixth Part, lately Purcha≈øed from John Millington of Millington, according to the Original Deed of Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy, ≈øupra a. Who now pay one Penny yearly, in lieu of the Gloves, to Dunham. John Owen of Partington, Have another ≈øixth Part, lately Purcha≈øed from John Millington of Millington, according to the Original Deed of Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy, ≈øupra a. Who now pay one Penny yearly, in lieu of the Gloves, to Dunham.

5. John Partington of Partington hath two Parts of the three of a ≈øixth Part, or two third Parts of a ≈øixth Part of Partington; which, with Thomas Warburton's third Part of a ≈øixth Part, makes up the other ≈øixth Part.

div.head: Over-Pever.
div.p: IN the Time of the Conqueror, Ranulphus (the ≈øuppo≈øed Ance≈øtor of the Manwarings) held this Town≈øhip of Over-Pever, or the greate≈øt part thereof; and al≈øo the Hamlet, or Place, called Cepmundwich in Over-Pever, as a di≈øtinct thing by it ≈øelf: as appears in Doom≈øday-book.

This Roger Manwaring was Son of Raufe Manwaring Judge of Che≈øter, about the Reign of Richard the fir≈øt.In the Reign of Henry the Third, Roger Manwaring of Warmincham in Che≈øhire, gave unto his younger Son William Manwaring‚ÄîTotum Tenementum, Redditum, & Bo≈øcum, quae praedictus Rogerus habuit in Vill√¢ de Pever‚ÄîSalvo Capitali Domino debito & con≈øueto Servitio per manum dicti Rogeri & Haeredum ≈øuorum:‚ÄîReddendo ind√® annuat√¨m praedidicto Rogero, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, unum Ni≈øum Sorum ad Fe≈øtum beati Petri ad vincula, pro omni Servitio: Lib. B. pag. 2. c. The Original. Pen√®s Sir Thomas Manwaring of Over-Pever Baronet, 1666. Sealed with an E≈øcocheon of Six Barrulets.

This William Manwaring fixed his Habitation at Over-Pever, where his ≈øucceeding Heirs have ever ≈øince continued to this day; and do now pay yearly unto Mr. Crew of Crew, Lord of Warmincham, one Sore-Sparrow-Hawk, or two Shillings in lieu thereof, according to the Deed afore≈øaid.

list.head: In this Town≈øhip are now onely two Charterers, 1666.

item.p: Ex Chartulis eju≈ødem Johannis Swinton.1. John Swinton of Nether-Knotsford, for Radbrook-Hou≈øe in Over-Pever. In the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, William Manwaring then Lord of Over-Pever gave unto Thomas his younger Son,‚Äîillam Terram quae vocatur Radbroc, integram: Reddendo ad Nativitatem Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae unum Denarium, vel unum par albarum Cheirothecarum:‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Domino Thom√¢ de Manwaring That was, Manwaring of Warmincham. , Domino Warino Filio ≈øuo, Domino Willielmo de Manwaring t√πnc Rectore Eccle≈øiae de Werunith,‚Äî&c. Lib. B. pag. 7. num. 1.
Richard Son and Heir of Thomas Manwaring, gives all his Land in Over-Pever to William Gla≈øebroke, Anno Domini 1320. Lib. B. pag. 7. num. 2.

William Gla≈øebroke relea≈øeth all his Lands in Radbrook in Over-Pever, unto William Son of John del Mere, and to Agnes his Wife, and the Heirs of her Body, 45 Edw. 3. 1371. It continued in the Name of Mere until the Year 1501. when Robert Mere gave all his Lands in Over-Pever to Oliver Hurlebot, Son of Richard Hurlebot; Rendring yearly twenty Shillings: Dated 14 die Augu≈øti, 16 Hen. 7. 1501. Which Rent of twenty Shillings Mere pa≈ø≈øed over to Thomas Manwaring of Nantwich, Son of Nicolas Manwaring; and the ≈øaid Thomas Manwaring pa≈ø≈øed it to John Manwaring of Over-Pever E≈øquire, by Deed dated 24 die Octobris, 23 Hen. 7.

Robert Burges of Knotsford married Joan one of Hurlebot's Daughters, to whom her Father gave Radbrook: Which Burges had onely two Daughters; Katharine married Mr. Thomas Browne, and Jane married John Harper of Hallywell near Bolton in the Moors in Lanca≈øhire.

Katharine had a Son called George Brown, who married Towne≈øend Si≈øter to George Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øquire, and had I≈ø≈øue three or four Children; but all died before they came to maturity: Afterwards Katharine ≈øuffers a Fine and Recovery, and ≈øettles the≈øe Lands on Jane Daughter of John Harper afore≈øaid. This Jane married John Swinton of Nether-Knotsford afore≈øaid, the ninth of February, 1659. who now hath Radbrook-Hou≈øe in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

Ex Chartulis Willielmi Beard.2. William Beard of Over-Pever, hath part of Fodon-Land in Over-Pever; which Land he lately bought of John Downes of Toft, 1663. and Downes formerly bought the ≈øame, by the Name of Half a Me≈ø≈øuage called Fodon-Land, from John Hen≈øhaw of Lockwood in Stafford≈øhire; Dated 6 Junii, 33 Eliz. 1591.
I find by ancient Deeds, that there were anciently two Places or Hamlets in Over-Pever; one called Cepmundewich, the other Fodon.
William Manwaring, Lord of Over-Pever, gave Fodon to Thomas his younger Son, under Edward the Fir≈øt; and Thomas gave it away to Hugh de Stoke.
Cepmond≈øwich, William Manwaring, Son of William, and Brother of Thomas, gave unto Gilbert Gykes, towards the end of Edward the Fir≈øt.
But the≈øe Lands came afterwards to be divided, and are now all bought in by the Lords of Over-Pever, ≈øave that Part of Fodon which Beard now enjoyeth.

7 Edw. 3. Thomas de Cepmond≈øwich, and Agnes his Wife, gave to John Son of William Gla≈øebrook, and to Nicolaa Daughter of Thomas Cepmondwich, unum Me≈ø≈øuagium & 21 Acras Terrae in Over-Pever in quodam Hamletto qui vocatur Fodon, & Capitale Me≈ø≈øuagium no≈øtrum & decem Acras Terrae, duas Acras Mo≈ø≈øetae, & unam Acram Bo≈øci, in e√¢dem Vill√¢, in quodam Hamletto qui vocatur Cepmond≈øwich: Remanere rectis Haeredibus praedictae Agnetis: And a Fine was levied hereon at Che≈øter, 7 Edw. 3. Lib. B. pag. 6. f.

p.hi: So much of the Charterers in Over-Pever.

div.p: In this Town≈øhip is al≈øo a Parochial Chappel, Seated near to the Mannor-Hall of Over-Pever, and hath the≈øe Villages within the Chappelry:‚Äî

This Chappel is a Daughter of the Mother-Church of Ro≈øthorn, and ≈øeems to be fir≈øt Erected about the Reign of Edward the Third: But I find not any Monument in this Church exceeding the Reign of Henry the Sixth: It was certainly a Parochial Chappel in Henry the Sixth's Time, and had then liberty of Burial; and hath now the yearly Stipend of Five Pounds ≈øix Shillings and eight Pence allowed from the Vicar of Ro≈øthorne.

The neat Chappel, and Vault under the ≈øame for a Burying-place, on the North-≈øide of the Chancel, was built in Stone at the Charge of Ellen the Widow of Philip Manwaring of Over-Pever E≈øquire, Anno Domini 1648.

The other Chappel of Stone, on the South-≈øide of the Body of Over-Pever Church, ≈øeems to be built Anno Domini 1456. as appears by the In≈øcription in one of the Windows of the ≈øame Chappel, yet extant, 1666.

div.head: Now followeth the De≈øcent of the Manwarings of Over-Pever.
div.p: He had I≈ø≈øue William, Son and Heir; Thomas, to whom his Father gave Fodon in Over-Pever: Lib. B. pag. 2. d. & pag. 3. g. h. Benedict, another Son: Ibid. pag. 4. m. & pag. 13. e. f. Guy, another Son: Sir Tho. Aston's Deeds, pag. 31. n. Al≈øo Roger, another Son, who≈øe Son William married Margaret Daughter of Roger Toft of Toft, 1 Edw. 1. Lib. B. pag. 8. a.

II. William Manwaring of Over-Pever, Son and Heir of William, married‚Äîand had
I≈ø≈øue Roger, elde≈øt Son; William, another Son, who≈øe Daughter Ellen married Adam Gla≈øebrook, 14 Edw. 3. 1341. Lib. B. pag. 9. g. Reginald, another Son: Lib. B. pag. 11. r. And Maud, a Daughter, to whom her Father gave a Me≈ø≈øuage in Over-Pever, which Hamond of Radbroke formerly held: Lib. B. pag. 11. t.
This William Lord of Over-Pever lived 1286. 14 Edw. 1.

Roger Manwaring, Son and Heir of William, married Chri≈øtian de Birtles, and had I≈ø≈øue William, Son and Heir; and Joan, a Daughter, married Robert de Fallybrome nigh Birtles, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Robert, John, and Roger, living 1342. Lib. B. pag. 27. y. & pag. 9. I.
This Roger died in the Life-time of his Father; and Chri≈øtian his Widow afterwards married John de Byrun; and la≈øtly, ≈øhe married Robert de Varnon, living 8 Edw. 3. 1334. Lib. B. pag. 8. b. d. f.

III. William Manwaring of Over-Pever, Son and Heir of Roger, married Mary Daughter of Henry Davenport, living 19 Edw. 2. Lib. B. pag. 8. c. d. and had I≈ø≈øue William Manwaring, Son and Heir; Roger, Margery, and Millicent, all living 8 Edw. 3. 1334. Lib. B. pag. 8. f.
This William died about 12 or 13 Edw. 3.
IV. William Manwaring of Over-Pever, Son and Heir of William, had two Wives.
His fir≈øt Wife was Joan Daughter and Co-heir of William Praers of Baddiley near Nantwich, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue William Manwaring Son and Heir: Lib. B. pag. 13. g. & 15. I.

Margery, the other Co-heir, married John Honford of Honford in Maxfield-Hundred, who had I≈ø≈øue John Honford: Afterwards ≈øhe married Hugh Holt, 33 Edw. 3. but had no I≈ø≈øue by Holt: And ≈øhe died 3 Rich. 2. 1380. Lib. B. pag. 28. b. But in the Inqui≈øition taken at Che≈øter, 28 Febr. 21 Rich. 2. it was found that John Honford the Son was a Ba≈øtard, and that William Manwaring was ≈øole Heir to Margery, & nullus alius: Lib. B. pag. 27. z. Yet did William Manwaring by his Will, Anno 1399. divide the Lands of Baddiley between John Manwaring his Half-Brother, and the ≈øaid John de Honford: Lib. B. pag. 28. a.

After the death of Joan Praers, this William married Elizabeth Daughter of Nicolas Leyce≈øter, and Si≈øter of John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue John Manwaring, Randle Manwaring, both afterwards Lords of Over-Pever ≈øucce≈ø≈øively; Thomas, Alan, and Richard, living 38 Edw. 3. Lib. B. pag. 9. h. & pag. 10. n. o. Al≈øo Emme, a Daughter, married Richard Wynnington, Son and Heir of Sir Richard Wynnington of Wynnington nigh Northwich, 1357. 31 Edw. 3. Lib. B. pag. 11. w. Ellen, another Daughter, married Raufe, Son and Heir of Raufe, Son of Richard Vernon of Shibrok in Che≈øhire, 33 Edw. 3. 1359. Lib. B. pag. 12. b. And Joan married VVilliam Legh of Baggiley, 33 Edw. 3. 1359. She was but five Years old on Candlemas-day then la≈øt pa≈øt; Lib. B. pag. 11. x. and lived not to have any I≈ø≈øue by VVilliam Legh.

This William Manwaring was ≈øtiled William Manwaring the Elder, 33 Edw. 3. Lib. B. pag. 9. I. & pag. 12. b. He Sealed with his Coat of Arms mo≈øt u≈øually, to wit, Three Bars, with a Lion Pa≈ø≈øant in Chief: Lib. B. pag. 9. I. In≈øcribed about the Seal,‚Äî SIGILL. WILLIELMI DE MAYNWARINGE. Which Coat of Arms he gave in di≈øtinction from Manwaring of Warmincham, out of which Family his Ance≈øtor branched.

For Roger Manwaring of Warmincham, in the Reign of Henry the Third, Sealed with Six Barrulets; who≈øe Son and Heir Sir Thomas Manwaring of Warmincham u≈øed onely Two Barrs in his Seal; as I have ≈øeen their Seals. And after the Male-Line of Manwaring of Warmincham failed, then did the Heir of Manwaring of Over-Pever a≈ø≈øume the Two Bars onely, in the Reign of Richard the Second, as next Heir Male;
leaving off this Coat of Three Bars with a Lion in Chief, as ≈øhall anon in due place appear.
This VVilliam Manwaring the Elder died 38 Edw. 3. 1364. Elizabeth his Widow ≈øurvived, and was living 1405. 6 Hen. 4.
V. VVilliam Manwaring of Over-Pever junior, Son and Heir of VVilliam Manwaring the Elder, by Joan Praers, had al≈øo two Wifes.
The fir≈øt was Katharine Daughter of John Belgrave of Belgrave in the Town≈øhip of Eaton-boat in Che≈øhire, whom he married 40 Edw. 3. 1366. Lib. B. pag. 10. p.
His ≈øecond Wife was Clementia Cotton: Lib. B. pag. 13. g. But he had not any I≈ø≈øue by either Wife.

This VVilliam ≈øettles his E≈øtate, upon his departure out of England towards Guyen, 17 Rich. 2. 1393. and afterwards made his Will, 1394. wherein (among other things) he Bequeaths his Body to be Buried in Aghton-Church, and his Picture in Alaba≈øter to cover his Tomb in the ≈øaid Church: He gave al≈øo to the ≈øaid Church a part of Chri≈øt's Cro≈øs, which the Wife of Randle Manwaring his Half-Brother had in her Cu≈øtody, ≈øhut up in Wax: Al≈øo to the Chappel of Over-Pever, unam Togam de Blueto, ut fiat ind√® Ve≈øtimentum ibid√®m. He left al≈øo a competent Salary for a Chaplain to celebrate for his Soul in the Chappel of St. Mary in Aghton-Church, for ≈øeven Years: Lib. B. pag. 14. H. I.
This VVilliam died without I≈ø≈øue 1399. 22 Rich. 2. and was buried at Aghton-Church, leaving John Manwaring his Half-Brother to ≈øucceed in his Inheritance.

VI. John Manwaring of Over-Pever, Half-Brother and Heir to the la≈øt VVilliam, and Son to VVilliam Manwaring the Elder by Elizabeth his ≈øecond Wife, married Margaret the Widow of Sir John VVarren of Pointon in Che≈øhire, and Daughter and Heir of Sir John Stafford of VVigham, about 13 Rich. 2. For Sir John VVarren died the tenth of Richard the Second: Lib. F. pag. 19. b.
The King gave to this John Manwaring all the Lands and Goods of Sir Hugh Browe, which the ≈øaid Sir Hugh had forfeited by his Rebellion: Dated 18 Augu≈øti, 4 Hen. 4. Lib. B. pag. 24. d. e.

This John Manwaring waited on the Prince, afterwards King Henry the Fifth; and he was made Sheriff of Che≈øhire (quamdi√π nobis placuerit) 18 Septembris, 4 Hen. 4. and continued Sheriff 5 Hen. 4. and 6 Hen. 4. In which Writ the Earl of Che≈øter calls him Armigerum ≈øuum.
He had al≈øo an Annual Pen≈øion of twenty Marks given him pro bono Servitio impen≈øo & impendendo, 8 Hen. 4.
Al≈øo he, with Matthew del Mere, and Thomas Mey≈øhawe, were Con≈øtituted Judges of the Gaol-delivery at Che≈øter, h√¢c vice, nono die Aprilis, 5 Hen. 4.
This John Manwaring died without Lawful I≈ø≈øue, 11‚ñ™ Hen. 4. 1410. leaving his Brother Randle to ≈øucceed in his Inheritance.
Margaret his Widow ≈øurvived, and was living 4 Hen. 5. Lib. B. pag. 22. a. & pag. 12. a.
He had a Bu≈øtard-≈øon by Margery VVinnington, called Peter Manwaring: Lib. B. pag. 13. g. h.

This Randle was al≈øo a Courtier, ≈øtiled Armiger Regis, The King's Servant, & Sagittarius de Coron√¢, 21 Rich. 2. and went into Ireland with his Brother John in the King's Service, 22 Rich. 2. He had the Office of Equitator Fore≈øtae de Mar√¢ & Mondrum granted unto him for his Life, 6 Hen. 4. and two Parts of the Serjeanty of Maxfield-Hundred, which were Raufe Davenport's, till John Davenport came to Age; Dated 3 Hen. 5. And he had al≈øo (with others) the Cu≈øtody of the Mannor of Kerincham in Che≈øhire, 13 Hen. 6.

He had a Ba≈øtard-Son by Emme Farrington, called Hugh Manwaring, from whom the Manwarings of Croxton nigh Middle-wich: Al≈øo Thomas Manwaring of North-Rode, another Ba≈øtard-Son, 12 Rich. 2. and Randle, another Ba≈øtard-Son, 4 Hen. 4. and al≈øo three Ba≈øtard-Daughters: Lib. B. pag. 13. h. & pag. 42. a. b. c.

This Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever, ≈øtiled commonly Honkyn Manwaring in the Language of tho≈øe Times died 35 Hen. 6. 1456. Lib. B. pag. 21. e. Buried at Over-Pever, in the Stone Chappel on the South ≈øide of the Church: Which Chappel Margery his Wife ≈øurviving, erected, with the two Monuments therein, for her ≈øelf and Husband, Anno Domini 1456.

VIII. Sir John Manwaring of Over-Pever Knight, Son and Heir of Randle, married Margaret Daughter of John Delves of Dodington the Elder, 13 Hen. 4. 1411. Lib. B. pag. 16. k. l. and had I≈ø≈øue William Manwaring, Son and Heir; Elizabeth married Piers Warburton, Son and Heir of Sir Geffrey de Warburton Lord of Arley, 1436. 14 Hen. 6. Lib. B. pag. 16. o. Margaret married Hamnet Son and Heir of John A≈øhley of A≈øhley in Bodon-Pari≈øh, 30 Hen. 6. 1452. Lib. B. pag. 17. t.

Anno 38 Hen. 6. the King ≈øends his Letter to this Sir John Manwaring, that he deliver to the Lord Stanley the≈øe Per≈øons following, then in the Ca≈øtle of Chester, for ≈øome Matters alledged again≈øt them in the late Parliament at Coventry; to wit, Thomas and John Nevill Sons of the Earls of Salisbury, Sir Thomas Harrington, James Harrington, Raufe Rokeby, Thomas A≈øhton, and Robert Evereus, E≈øquires. Stow in his Chronicle mentions many more attainted in this Parliament at Coventry, 38 Hen. 6.

Anno 13 Edw. 4. the King grants to Sir John Manwaring Officium Magi≈øtri Deductus no≈øtri Parcorum no≈øtrorum de Blakemere & Che≈øwardyn in Comitatu Salopiae, during the Minority of George Son and Heir of John Earl of Shrewsbury, with four Marks Annual Fee: Dated 30 die Novembris, 13 Edw. 4. 1473.
The Parchment Book belonging to March King at Arms, tempore Edw. 4. ≈øaith, Sir John Manwaring had two Sons, William and John.

Sir John Manwaring of Over-Pever died about the very end of Edward the Fourth's
Reign; and had a ≈øecond Wife, called Joan, Daughter of John Warren of Pointon, 33 Hen. 6. Lib. B. pag. 21. P.

William Manwaring, Son and Heir of Sir John, married Ellen Si≈øter to John Butler of Bew≈øy nigh Warrington in Lanca≈øhire, and Daughter of Sir John Butler, 22 Hen. 6. 1443. Lib. B. pag. 17. s. and had I≈ø≈øue John Manwaring: Lib. B. pag. 23. b.
This William died in the Life-time of Sir John his Father.

IX. John Manwaring of Over-Pever E≈øquire, Son and Heir of William, marired Maud Daughter of Robert Legh of Adlington E≈øquire; and had I≈ø≈øue John Manwaring, elde≈øt Son; and Robert Manwaring: Lib. B. pag. 19. b. & 23. b. Maud, a Daughter, married to Thomas Starkey of Wrenbury in Che≈øhire E≈øquire, 5 Hen 7. 1490. Lib. B. pag. 21. q. Joan, another Daughter, married Sir Thomas A≈øhton of A≈øhton ≈øuper Mer≈øey in Che≈øhire, 4 Hen. 8. 1512. Lib. B. pag. 18. x. Maud, wife of John Manwaring, being then Widow.
This John Manwaring E≈øquire died the eighth day of July, 10 Hen. 7. 1495 Lib. B. pa. 17. w.
He had a Ba≈øtard-≈øon, called Charles Manwaring, living 35 Hen. 8. Lib. B. pa. 19. b.

X. Sir John Manwaring of Over-Pever Knight, Son and Heir of John, was Knighted in France, 1513. Lord Herbert's Hi≈øtory of Hen. 8. pag. 42. He married Katharine Honford, Si≈øter of William Honford of Honford in Che≈øhire E≈øquire; Lib. B. pag. 19. aa. and had I≈ø≈øue Randle Manwaring, elde≈øt Sonne; Edmund died without I≈ø≈øue; John died without I≈ø≈øue; Piers died without I≈ø≈øue; Philip Manwaring afterwards became Lord of Over-Pever; Edward, from whom the Manwarings of Whitmore in Stafford≈øhire: Robert, from whom the Manwarings of Martin-Sands in Che≈øhire; Thomas, George, Henry: Lib. B. pag. 18. y. Margaret, a Daughter; and Katharine, married to William Son of Homfrey Newton of Pownall, 13 Hen. 8. 1521. Lib. B. pa. 19. a.
On this Sir John's Monument in Over-Pever-Church, I finde mention of three other Children more then is abovementioned: Nicolas, and two Williams, which probably died very young.
This Sir John was Sheriff of Flint≈øhire, 6 Hen. 8. 1514. and dyed 8 Hen. 8. 1515. at the age of 45 years.

By his Will, among other things, he gave to the Pari≈øh-Church of Over-Pever his Black Velvet Gown, guarded with Cloath of Gold, to make a Cope for the ≈øame Church; and al≈øo 4 l. 13 s. 4 d. to an hone≈øt Prie≈øt to pray for his Soul for four Yeares in Over-Pever-Church; and twenty Pounds towards the making of a new Steeple of Stone at Over-Pever; but this la≈øt was never effected: and al≈øo to Charles Manwaring his Ba≈øtard-brother yearly 1 l. 6 s. 8 d. for his Life, &c. Dated 4 Martii, 1515. 7 Hen. 8. Lib. B. pag. 18. y.
Katharine, the widow of Sir John, died 1529.

XI. Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever Knight, Son and Heire of Sir John, married Elizabeth the Widow of Richard Cholmondeley of Cholmondley in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, and Daughter of Sir Randle Brereton of Malpas, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Margaret, married to Sir Arthur Manwaring of Ightfield in Shrop≈øhire; Elizabeth, married to Peter Shakerley of Houlm in Allo≈øtock in Che≈øhire E≈øquire; afterwards to Chri≈øtopher Holford of Holford E≈øquire, 1561. And Katharine, married to John Davenport of Henbury in Che≈øhire E≈øquire: ut per inqui≈øitionem post mortem Ranulphi Manwaring Militis, 5 & 6 Phil. & Mar.
After the death of his fir≈øt Wife, Sir Randle married Elizabeth Daughter of Sir Raufe Leyce≈øter of Toft, 6 Edw. 6. 1551. Lib. B. pag. 19. b. d. but had no I≈ø≈øue by her.
Sir Randle dyed 6 die Septembris, 4 & 5 Phil. & Mar. 1557. Elizabeth his Widow after married Sir Edmund Trafford of Trafford in Lanca≈øhire nigh Manche≈øter, and by him had I≈ø≈øue.

XII. Philip Manwaring of Over-Pever E≈øquire, fifth Son of Sir John Manwaring, and Brother and next Heir-male to Sir Randle, married Anne Daughter of Sir Raufe Leyce≈øter of Toft juxta Over-Pever: Lib. B. pag. 20. e. and had I≈ø≈øue Randle Manwaring, Son and Heir; Edmund Manwaring of Ranmore nigh Nantwich, called Captain Manwaring; and Elizabeth, who died without I≈ø≈øue:
This Philip died 11 die Aprilis, 1573. 15 Eliz. as appears by his Monument in Over-Pever Church.

XIII. Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever, the Elder, Knight, Son and Heir of Philip, married Margaret Daughter of Sir Edward Fitton of Gowe≈øworth in Che≈øhire, ≈øometime Trea≈øurer of Ireland, 9 Eliz. 1567. Lib. B. pag. 20. f. and had I≈ø≈øue Sir Randle Manwaring the younger; Edmund Manwaring Doctor of Law, and Chancellor of Che≈øter, 1642. Thomas Manwaring, third Son, Doctor of Divinity, and Par≈øon of Weldon in Northampton≈øhire, living 1634. Edward, John, Arthur, died all in their Infancy; Sir Philip Manwaring, Secretary of Ireland to the Earl of Strafford, 1638. younge≈øt Son, was never married, and died 2 die Augu≈øti, 1661. at London: Anne, a Daughter, married Lawrence Smith, Son and Heir of Sir Thomas Smith of Hough in Widdenbury Pari≈øh in Che≈øhire; married at Great-Budworth 31 Augu≈øti, 1591. Katharine, another Daughter, married Sir Edward Stanley of Bicker≈øtaff in Lanca≈øhire, Baronet; Elizabeth, another Daughter, married Peter Leycester of Nether-Tabley in Che≈øhire, E≈øq 1611. 9 Jacobi: And Elinour, another Daughter, never married.

After the Death of Margaret, this Sir Randle married Katharine the Widow of William Brereton of Honford in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, and Daughter of Roger Hurle≈øton of Che≈øter, E≈øquire: Lib. B. pag. 20. h.

In the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, the Herald made for this Sir Randle's Coat, Barry of Twelve Pieces, Argent and Gules: See Guillim's Heraldry, pag. 373. but erroneous. So al≈øo the Herald then placed the Earl of Che≈øter's Coat in the Quarterings of Manwaring; but ab≈øurdly, and not right.
This Sir Randle the Elder built the Hall of Over-Pever anew, 1586. the Fabrick being now of Brick: And he was Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 1605. 3 Jacobi.
Sir Randle the Elder died 27 Maii, 1612. 10 Jacobi.

XIV. Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever, the younger, Knight, Son and Heir of Sir Randle the Elder, married Jane Daughter of Sir Thomas Smith of Hough afore≈øaid, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Philip Manwaring Son and Heir; George Manwaring of Marthall, ≈øecond Son, now living 1666. Margaret, the elde≈øt Daughter, died an Infant; Elizabeth, ≈øecond Daughter, marrried fir≈øt to Robert Raven≈øcroft of Bretton in Harden-Pari≈øh, beyond Che≈øter, E≈øquire, and had many Children; Afterwards ≈øhe married Sir Francis Gamole of Che≈øter, but ≈øhe had no I≈ø≈øue by him: She ≈øurvived both her Husbands, and died at Che≈øter 13 Augu≈øti, 1661. and was buried at Harden: Anne, third Daughter, married Robert Brierwood of Che≈øter, Coun≈øellor at Law, after Sir Robert Brierwood, Knighted 1643. and Judge of three Shires in Wales: Margaret, younge≈øt Daughter, married Henry Birkenhed, Son and Heir of Henry Berkinhed of Backford nigh Che≈øter, E≈øquire, Prothonotary of Che≈øter, and had I≈ø≈øue; but they all died before they came to Maturity. This Margaret died at Che≈øter, 25 Julii, 1661.
This Sir Randle the Younger was Sheriff of Limrick in Ireland, 3 Jacobi, 1605. Lib. B. pag. 26. t. in which very Year al≈øo his Father was Sheriff of Che≈øhire.
The ≈øame Sir Randle the Younger was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 1619. and Mayor of Che≈øter al≈øo the ≈øame Year; and died 12 die Januarii, 1632. 8 Car. 1.
This Philip was Captain of the Light-Hor≈øe of Che≈øhire; and was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 1639.

He died the tenth of December, 1647. Ellen his Widow ≈øurviving, built a neat Chappel of Stone on the North-≈øide of the Chancel of Over-Pever Church, with two brave Monuments for her ≈øelf and Husband, and a fair Vault under the ≈øaid Chappel, for Burial, Anno Domini 1648.
She built al≈øo a ≈øtately Stable, and Dove-hou≈øe, at Over-Pever, 1654. and ≈øhe died 1656.

XVI. Sir Thomas Manwaring of Over-Pever Baronet, Son and Heir of Philip, married Mary Daughter of Sir Henry Delves of Dodington in Widdenbury-Pari≈øh, Baronet; and had I≈ø≈øue Philip, Thomas, Randle, who died young all three; John Manwaring, and William Manwaring, both living 1666. Henry died in his Infancy; Mary, and Helen, both died in their Infancy; Elizabeth, Anne, Katharine, and Grace, all four now living, 1666.

This Thomas Manwaring was Sheriff of Che≈øter, 1657. and created Baronet 22 Novembris, 1660. and is yet living, 1666. Mary his Lady died at Baddiley the fir≈øt day of March, 1670. and was buried at Over-Pever, in the Vault under the New-Chappel there, on Munday the ≈øixth of March, Anno Domini 1670.

div.head: Little-Pever.
div.p: THe Town≈øhip of Nether-Pever, though now divided into two Hundreds, was anciently but one entire Town≈øhip: At this day it ≈øeems to be divided into two Town≈øhips; Great-Pever, which lieth in Northwich-Hundred; and Little-Pever, which lieth within Bucklow-Hundred, ≈øevered by the River called Pever-Eye. Ee is an old word for a Brook; and Ees is a Bank or Land lying by the ≈øide of a Brook, or River.

And whether you take them together, as one Town≈øhip, by the Name of Nether-Pever; or as two Towns, called Great-Pever, and Little-Pever; yet have they jointly, or ≈øeverally, been ≈øevered into two di≈øtinct Fees or Inheritances, ever ≈øince the Norman Conque≈øt, to this day.
One Moiety of them was held by William Fitz-Nigell, Baron of Halton, in the Conqueror's Time, as appears by Doom≈øday-book.

This Moiety (I ≈øpeak now out of my own Evidences) was given by Roger Lacy, Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, and Baron of Halton, unto one Osberne de Wethale, about King John's Reign; to wit, all his Moiety of Pever; Rendring yearly half a Mark of Silver, and doing Foreign Service as much as belongs to the twentieth Part of a Knights Fee. G. num. 1.

And I find Robert de Pever po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd hereof in the Reign of Henry the Third; to whom William Son of Richard Haddlebert (who, as it ≈øeems, claimed ≈øome Property there relea≈øeth all his Claim in that Moiety of Nether-Pever, which is of the Fee of the Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, that is, of the Fee of Halton. G. num. 3.

Hugh, Son of that Robert de Pever, ≈øells all his Birthright in Pever, which was to de≈øcend to him after the death of his Father Robert de Pever, unto William de Hawarthen, for One hundred Pound Sterling, about the beginning of Edward the Fir≈øt's Reign. G. num. 4.

William de Hawarthen ≈øells it to Richard Bonetable; and Richard Bonetable ≈øells it to William Son of Raufe de Mobberley, for fifty Marks of Silver, 1281. who≈øe Son William de Mobberley was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid Moiety of Nether-Pever, cum Homagiis, Wardis, &c. 13 Edw. 2. G. 6, 7.

Afterwards this Moiety was Purcha≈øed (as I take it) by Robert Gro≈øvenour of Holme nigh Nether-Pever, about Edward the ≈øecond: In which Line it continued till Edward
the Fourth, about 150 Years; and at la≈øt it de≈øcended to Margaret the younge≈øt Daughter and Co-heir of Robert Gro≈øvenour of Houlme in Allo≈øtock E≈øquire, with the third Part of Alderley al≈øo, the Wife of Thomas Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire, by Partition dated 1465. 5 Edw. 4. Z. num. 28. who≈øe Heirs do now enjoy the ≈øaid Moiety of Nether-Pever, 1666. and the Rent now paid to Halton, according to the Original Deed of Roger Lacy afore≈øaid.

list.head: Charterers in this Moiety, 1666.
list.item: 1. Thomas Wood of Little-Pever, near to Pever-Bridge: He pays a Pair of White Gloves yearly to Leyce≈øter of Tabley, at Mid≈øommer, pro libero Tenemento ≈øuo in Pever.

2. Peter Wood of Little-Pever, formerly Robert Cotton's, more anciently ≈øtiled Min≈øhull-Seat, did pay to Leyce≈øter 3 s. 4 d. yearly, Chief-Rent: But John Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øq remitted the ≈øame to Cotton, by Deed dated 17 Hen. 7.
3. Hiccock's Land, ≈øituate in Great-Pever, now enjoyed by Powdrill, Thomas Deane, and Mrs. Pemberton, who pay among≈øt them yearly 2 s. of Chief-Rent to Leyce≈øter of Tabley.

div.p: And all the≈øe Charterers do Suit of Court to the Court-Baron of Leyce≈øter of Tabley, held for his Mannor of Pever.
The other Moiety of Nether-Pever was held in the Conqueror's Time by Ranulphus, as I take it, in Doom≈øday-book.

This Moiety was given to Richard Pool of Hartington by Robert Morley Mar≈øhal of Ireland, with all the Rents, Homages, and Services, which de≈øcended Hereditarily to the ≈øaid Robert in the County of Che≈øter, after the death of Sir Robert de Monte alto his Uncle; except the Rents formerly given unto Queen I≈øabel: Dated 24 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 230. y. The Original of this Deed remained among the Evidences of the late Lord Cholmondley; and the Copy of the Fine Levied hereon in the ≈øame Year, is Enrolled in the Leiger-Book of the Abby of Vale-Royal, fol. 30. b. which Book was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Thomas Merbury of Merbury nigh Comberbach, E≈øquire, 1666.

Vide Tom. 2. of my own Evidences, in principio. In the Year of Chri≈øt 1364. die Veneris in Fe≈øto Sanctae Luciae Virginis, John Pool came before Thomas then Abbot of Vale-Royal, in the ≈øaid Abby, and did Fealty to the ≈øaid Abbot for this Moiety of the Mannor of Nether-Pever, which he acknowledged to hold of the ≈øaid Abbot by the yearly Rent of Twelve Pence, to be paid at the Fea≈øt of St. Michael onely, and by paying to the ≈øaid Abbot two Shillings for Relief; as appears by the ≈øame Book.

Lib. C. fol. 230. z.From Pool of Hartington this Moiety was granted to George Holford of Holford, about the Time of Henry the Seventh: In which Family of the Holfords of Holford it continued, till Mary Daughter and Heir of Chri≈øtopher Holford E≈øquire brought the Inheritance of all Holford-Lands unto Sir Hugh Cholmondley of Cholmondley, the younger, in Marriage, in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth.
Concerning which Inheritance great Suits fell between the ≈øaid Lady Mary Cholmondley, and George Holford of Newborough in Dutton, uncle to the ≈øaid Mary, and next Heir-male of the Holfords.

The≈øe Suits la≈øted above forty Years: At la≈øt, towards the end of King James's Reign, the matter was compos'd by Friends: The Lady Mary had Holford-Demain; and George Holford had the Demain of I≈øcoit in Flint≈øhire, near to Whitchurch in Shrop≈øhire. The Lands in Nether-Pever, Plumley, and Lo≈øtock-Gralam, belonging to the Holfords, were promi≈øcuou≈øly allotted, Part to the one, and Part to the other, as at this day they be enjoyed.

So that in the Year 1659. Robert Cholmondley Earl of Leim≈øter in Ireland, Son and Heir of the ≈øaid Lady Mary, and James Holford of Newborough E≈øquire, Son of Peter, Son of George Holford above≈øaid, did enjoy this other Moiety of Nether-Pever between
them: In which Year the ≈øaid Lord Cholmondley died, without any Lawful I≈ø≈øue of his Body.
Concerning the Chappel of Nether-Pever, ≈øee above in Budworth.

div.head: Picmere.
div.p: This Town≈øhip of Picmere is not in Doom≈øday-book, whereby it ≈øeemeth to be Wa≈øte at that time.

It was anciently of two Fees in the Reign of King John. One Moiety Raufe Manwaring (≈øometime Judge of Che≈øter) gave unto Henry de Aldithley, or Audley, in Free-Marriage with Bertrey his Daughter, together with the Towns of Smallwood and Snel≈øton, and a Mark of Annual Rent in the City of Che≈øter, of the Land which belonged to one Fagun: Unto which Deed Philip Orreby, then Judge of Che≈øter, was a Witne≈øs. The Original is in Cotton's Library at We≈øtmin≈øter: Lib. B. pag. 1. a.

Henry of Audley, by the con≈øent of Bertrey his Wife, gave to Thomas Son of Randle de Long≈ødon, libero homini ≈øuo, half of his Land in Picmere, and half of his Wood there; Rendring yearly 3 s. 4 d. as I find the Deed extracted in Vernon's Notes.
This Moiety of Picmere is now enjoyed by the≈øe Per≈øons following, 1666.

1. Thomas Merbury of Merbury E≈øquire hath one half of this Moiety, which formerly belonged to the Cockers of Picmere ever ≈øince the Reign of Henry the Third, until Hugh Cocker of Pickmere ≈øold the Rever≈øion hereof, after his Life, unto Thomas Merbury, Father of Thomas afore≈øaid, Anno Domini 1604. Probably this was that Part which Henry Audley gave to Thomas Long≈ødon.

2. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire hath four Tenements here in Lea≈øe. The≈øe were formerly held by William Wiche, and called Wiche's Lands; which upon the Attainder of Sir William Stanley of Holt-Ca≈øtle, Anno Domini 1495. Lord Chamberlain to Henry the Seventh, E≈øcheated to the King, and were afterwards given to George Sutton, one of the Grooms of the Chamber, 14 H. 8. Sutton ≈øold them to Richard Sneyd, 7 Novembris, 14 Hen. 8. and William Sneyd ≈øold them to Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, 36 Hen. 8.

3. Sir Peter Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley, Baronet, hath one Tenement here, now in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of John Perceivall; which was Part of Wiche's Lands, and was ≈øold by William Sneyd to Gawen Legh of Northwood in High-Legh, 35 Hen. 8. 1543. before he ≈øold the re≈øt to Daniell: And this Tenement afterwards Richard Legh of Northwood Gentleman, ≈øold (among other Lands) to Peter Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire, 1633. who≈øe Son now enjoyeth the ≈øame.
4. John Swinton of Nether-Knotsford hath one good Tenement here: But part of this lieth in Win≈øham, formerly Crocket's Land of Nantwich.
5. John Key of the Yate in Picmere; Part of Crocket's Land formerly.
6. Peter Deane of Over-Tabley hath Land in Picmere, lately bought from Key of the Yate.
7. Philip Anterbus of Over-Pever, one Clo≈øe, belonging to his Free-hold Land in A≈øton juxt√† Picmere.
8. Sir George Warburton of Arley Baronet hath about one Acre and a half, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Robert Deusbery and Thomas Starky of Feldy.

The other Moiety of Picmere, together with the Mannor of Win≈øham, William Venables gave to Maud his Si≈øter in Free-Marriage, to be held by the Service of half a Knights Fee; whereunto Roger Lacy, Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, is a Witne≈øs; Which Roger died Anno Domini 1211. 13 Johannis Regis, ≈øaith Matthew Paris in his Hi≈øtory: Lib. B. pag. 50. a.

This Maud had two Husbands: The fir≈øt was Raufe Son of Roger; the ≈øecond was Hugh de Bixis, or Brixis. This Hugh and his Wife grant to Hugh Venables all the Land
which William de Offley held of them in Picmere, and the Ward≈øhip of the Children of Hugh Son of the ≈øaid William de Offley, till they come to ≈øuch Age as to govern the ≈øaid Land. Lib. B. pag. 50. e.

Ex Chartulis Glover de Picmere. Hugh Venables grants to Hugh de Picmere, and his Heirs, the whole Moiety of the Village of Picmere, for the ≈øame Service contained in the Deed of William Venables his Father, the Donor of the ≈øame Lands. This was tempore Henrici Tertii: Lib. B. pag. 51. num. 1.

Afterwards William Son of Guy of Win≈øham grants to Henry Son of Hugh de Picmere all his Rent in the Town≈øhip of Picmere, to wit, 3 s. 1 d. ob. which he yearly received from Hugh de Picmere; Rendring a Pair of White Gloves yearly: Lib. B. pag. 54. num. 19.

And Pagan, Son of Raufe de Wa≈øtneys, Lord of Win≈øham, relea≈øeth to the ≈øaid Henry all his Right in 3 s. 1 d. ob. Rent, which he received of the ≈øaid Henry: So that now he was onely to pay 3 s. 1 d. ob. yearly from henceforward, and a Pair of Gloves, for all Services: And this was in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt: Lib. B. pag. 51. num. 2.

Hugh Picmere, Son of Henry, was ≈øei≈øed of this Moiety; who≈øe Son Hugh had three Daughters, I≈øabel, Alice, and Margaret, 1343. Lib. B. pag. 52. num. 6. And in Anno 1356. he ≈øettles his Mannor of Picmere, for want of Heirs-Males of his Body, on Hugh Bruyn of Stapleford, and Margaret his Wife, Daughter of the ≈øaid Hugh Picmere: Lib. B. pag. 53. num. 12.
Margaret, the Widow of Hugh Bruyn of Picmere, grants to Hugh Hul≈øe of Picmere all her Lands of Picmere, 42 Edw. 3. Lib. B. pag. 52. num. 10.

This Hugh Hul≈øe was Lieutenant-Ju≈øtice of Che≈øter, 20 Rich. 2. to Thomas Earl of Nottingham; and married Ellen Daughter and Heir of Hugh Bruyn and Margaret, 36 Edw. 3. The Marriage and Ward≈øhip of Ellen was granted by Margaret her Mother to David Hul≈øe Vicar of Great-Budworth, to marry Hugh Son of Sybill, Daughter of William Son of Hugh de Norbery, 36 Edw. 3. Lib. B. pag. 52. num. 11. & pag. 54. num. 21. This Sir Hugh Hul≈øe dying 3 Hen. 5. or thereabout, it was found by Inqui≈øition, That he died ≈øei≈øed of ≈øeven Me≈ø≈øuages in Picmere, 200 Acres of Land, and 20 Acres of Wood ibidem, quae tenentur de Willielmo Leyce≈øter, ut de Manerio ≈øuo de Wethale, ≈øed per quod Servitium ignoratur: Inter Recognitiones Scaccarii Ce≈øtriae, Bundle 3 Hen. 5.
Afterwards John Troutback E≈øquire married Margery Daughter and Heir of Thomas Hul≈øe, in the Reign of Henry the Sixth: Lib. B. pag. 53. num. 17.

And Margaret, Daughter and Heir of Adam Troutback, married John Talbot of Albrighton in Shrop≈øhire, from whom the Talbots of Grafton in Worce≈øter≈øhire de≈øcended, who≈øe Po≈øterity at la≈øt came to be Earls of Shrewsbury: And George Talbot Earl of Shrewsbury ≈øells all his Lands in Picmere (to wit, the Moiety of Picmere) unto his Tenants there, Anno 1620. every Tenant buying his own, and ≈øo are become particular Free-holders at this day.

Thomas Starkey's Lands, now in Picmere, were Purcha≈øed from Raufe Bo≈øtock of Moulton by John Starkey his Father, 14 Aprilis, 7 Jacobi, 1609. and was originally given by Henry de Picmere unto Richard his younger Son, 1192. A Parcel thereof was given to the ≈øaid Richard, by Hugh Picmere his Elder Brother, 1308. Lib. B. pag. 58. a. b. c.

div.head: Plumley.
div.p: ROger Manwaring gave Plumley to the Abby of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, when he made his Son Wido a Monk there; William and Randle his Sons being Witne≈ø≈øes: Which Grant, with many others, Richard Earl of Che≈øter confirmed, 1119. 19 Hen. 1.
In the Feodary of Halton, about Edw. 2. we read,‚ÄîThomas de Vernon tenet Villam de Lo≈øtock, c√πm Parv√¢-Lo≈øtock, & medietatem de Plumley, pro medietate unius Feodi Militis.

This Thomas de Vernon was ≈øecond Husband of Joan de Lo≈øtock, in who≈øe Right he held the≈øe Lands. Her former Husband was William de Toft, younger Son of Roger Toft of Toft: The Po≈øterity of which William a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Holford, from the Place of their Re≈øidence at Holford, according to the Cu≈øtom of tho≈øe Ages.

This Place, or Hamlet, called Holford, lieth Part in Plumley, and Part in Lo≈øtock-Gralam, and hath its Name from the Ford which runneth under the Mannor-Hall, which, becau≈øe it is ≈øituate in a Derne Hole, was therefore called Holford, as if you ≈øhould ≈øay, A Ford in a Hole: Or el≈øe, from the old Word [Hale], which we now call [Hall], and ≈øo denotes as much as A Ford under the Hall: Or, po≈ø≈øibly, from the old Word [Holt] A Wood, qua≈øi Holt-Ford; for that the Ford anciently was environed with a Wood round about.

All the Tenants of Plumley at this day do Suit of Court to the Mannor of Barn≈øhaw, which formerly belonged to the Abby of St. Werburge in Che≈øter, but was bought by Manwaring of Carincham ≈øince the Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies in England.

Agnes the Daughter of Walthef de Plumley by Henry her Son Attornatum po≈øitum ad lucrandum & perdendum, by Fine at Che≈øter, 2 Edw. 1. 1274. pa≈ø≈øeth the eighth Part of Plumley unto Thomas the Smith of Plumley, and to William his Son. This William, in his Seal, calls him≈øelf Willielmus Filius Ceciliae de Plumley.

And by another Fine, 2 Edw. 1. the ≈øame Agnes pa≈ø≈øeth over one other eighth Part of Plumley unto Richard Sladehur≈øt of Plumley, and Lettice his-Wife‚ñ™ which Lettice, in her Seal, calls her ≈øelf the Daughter of William de Plumley: Lib. A. fol. 157. h. k. The Originals Pen√®s Manwaring of Carincham, 1666.

I find al≈øo, that William Mobberley of Mobberley had certain Lands in Plumley, about Edward the Second: Lib. A. fol. 124. y. which were held of the Baron of Halton, by the yearly Rent of a Pair of White Spurs, or Six Pence: See ≈øupr√† in Halton.

And Sir Raufe Mobberley of Mobberley gave his Mannor in Plumley unto Thomas Toft, and Margaret his Wife, and their Heirs, 1357. 32 Edw. 3. Lib. A. fol. 129. II. One half of the≈øe Lands now belong to Leycester of Tabley, and the other half to Brad≈øhaw of Marple, as you may ≈øee more at large in Mobberley.
So that now, Anno Domini 1666. the whole Town≈øhip of Plumley is enjoyed by the≈øe Per≈øons following.‚Äî
‚öú Thomas Cholmondley of Holford E≈øquire, and James Holford of Newborough in Dutton, have one Moiety of Plumley between them.
The other Moiety is enjoyed by the≈øe Per≈øons following.‚Äî
1. Sir Peter Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley Baronet hath five Tenements here, now in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Robert Ma≈ø≈øy, Geffrey Wright, William Ridgeway, Thomas Wright, and Thomas Hough.
2. Mr. Brad≈øhaw of Marple, a good Farm, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Thomas Buckley.
3. The Land late Litler's of Wallers-cote nigh Northwich, three Tenements, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Hugh Yanes, Homfrey Mere, and Widow Bebington.
4. George Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øquire, one Tenement, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of William Highfield.
5. Robert Venables of Anterbus in Over-Whitley hath three Clo≈øes in Plumley, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Raufe Hen≈øhaw.
6. Reynolds of Middlewich (late belonging to Bo≈øtock of Moulton) one Tenement, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Raufe Newhall, at the end of Plumley-Moore.
7. John Hall of Norley, one Tenement in Plumley, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of John Kirkman.
8. Manwaring of Pever's Land (≈øold to Holford of Holford) one Tenement at the ≈øide of Plumley-Moore, in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Richard Eaton.
9. Earl of Bridgewater, a ≈ømall Parcel, about four Che≈øhire Acres.

div.head: Now followeth the De≈øcent of Holford of Holford.

list.item:
Hugh de Runchamp, Lord of Lo≈øtock: Lib. C. fol. 126. ll.
Ricardus de Runchamp.
Gralanus Filius Ricardi de Runchamp; in memory of whom the Town was called Lo≈øtock-Gralam, for di≈øtinction. He gave the Town of Lees unto Lidulf of Twamlow, about the Reign of King John: Lib. C. fol. 227. z. This Gralam al≈øo ≈øold Houlme juxt√† Nether-Pever to Richard Son of Randle Ranulfi, con Radulfi. Gro≈øvenour, 1234. Lib. C. fol. 120. a.
Gralam de Lo≈øtock, & Letitia Uxor ejus: Tempore Hen. 3.
Galfridus de Lo≈øtock, ‚Ä¢ ui Frater dedit medietatem de Rode.
Gralam de Morton.
Robert de Lo≈øtock: Lib. C. fol. 182. b.
Richard‚ñ™ Son of Gralam de Lo≈øtock married Emme de Merton: Lib. C. fol. 228. a.
Joan, Si≈øter and Heire to her two Brothers. ‚öú
Thomas de Lo≈øtock, ≈øecond ≈øon, di'd without I≈ø≈øue.
Richard, Son of Rich. Lo≈øtock, died without I≈ø≈øue: Lib. C. fo. 228. b. c. gg. & fol. 229. v. ‚Äî Agnes, Daughter of Richard Wilburham, living 28 Edw. 1. & 5 Edw. 1. She ≈øurvived 1319.

figure.head: Argent, a Cheveron between 3 Text Tees Sable.

div.p: After the death of William Toft, Joan married Thomas Vernon, about Anno Domini 1316. and had I≈ø≈øue by Thomas, Richard Vernon, from whom the Vernons of Ha≈ølington in Che≈øhire. Lib. C. fol. 228. d.

And after the death of Thomas Vernon, ≈øhe married William Hallum of Hallum in
Newton juxt√† Daresbery, Anno Domini 1337. 11 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 228. g. h.

II. Roger de Holford, Son and Heir of William Toft and Joan Lo≈øtock, lived 1316. He a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Holford from the Place of his Re≈øidence, as was the manner of tho≈øe Ages; which Sir-name his Po≈øterity ever ≈øince retained.
He married Margery Daughter of Richard le Di≈øpen≈øer; but died without I≈ø≈øue, 5 Edw. 3. 1330. Lib. C. fol. 229. k. v.

III. Henry Holford, Brother and Heir to Roger, married Margery Daughter of _____ and had I≈ø≈øue William, elde≈øt Son; and Roger Holford, younger Son, to whom his Father gave Lands in Plumley, 1344. Lib. C. fol. 228. hh.
William Holford, Son and Heir of Henry, had to Wife I≈øabel Daughter of _____ and had I≈ø≈øue John Holford, Son ond Heir.
This William died in the Life-time of his Father. I≈øabel his Widow was living 1347. 21 Edw. 3.
IV. John Holford of Holford, Son and Heir of William, married Joan Daughter of Roger Bruyn of Stapleford, 1347. 21 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 229. m. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Holford.

This John recovered the Mannor of Holford again≈øt Richard Vernon of Lo≈øtock-Gralam, 42 Edw. 3. and Sealed u≈øually with his Coat of Arms, to wit,Holford's Coat is, Argent a Cheveron between three Text Tees Sable. A Cheveron between three Text Tees; which Cheveron gives the di≈øtinction from Toft of Toft, who bears that Coat without a Cheveron: Lib. C. fol. 229. v. & 230. a.
This John Holford died 99 Hen. 4. 1408.
Thomas Holford, Son and Heir of John, married Alice Daughter of William Buckley of Oateworth: Lib. C. fol. 229. r. and died before his Father, to wit, 12 Rich. 2. leaving I≈ø≈øue William Holford.

V. William Holford of Holford, Son and Heir of Thomas, lived 1423. 2 Hen. 6. Lib. C. fol. 230. w. He married Margaret Daughter of Sir Richard Venables of Kinderton; and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, Son and Heir; John, Hugh; Jonet, Wife of Randle Brereton of Malpas; and Margery: Lib. C. fol. 132. b. l. & 231. s. t. & 230. b.
This William Holford died 38 Hen. 6. 1459.
VI. Thomas Holford of Holford E≈øquire, Son and Heir of William, married Joan Daughter of Richard Legh de VVe≈øt-Hall in High-Legh, and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Holford.
This Thomas Holford died 4 Edw. 4. 1464. Lib. C. fol. 231. T.

VII. Thomas Holford of Holford, the younger, E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas the elder, married Maud Daughter of VVilliam Buckley Deputy-Judge of Che≈øter, 1444. Lib. C. fol. 230. b. and had I≈ø≈øue, George Holford, Son and Heir; Randle Holford, ≈øecond Son, who had I≈ø≈øue Homphrey and Richard; Robert Holford, third Son of Thomas, who had I≈ø≈øue John, Philip, Bartholomew, Owen, Matthew, and Bryan.
This Thomas died about 13 Edw. 4. 1473.

VIII. Sir George Holford of Holford Knight, Son and Heir of Thomas, married I≈øabel
Widow to Lawrence VVarren of Pointon in Che≈øhire, and Daughter of Robert Legh of Adlington E≈øquire, 1475. 15 Edw. 4. Lib. C. fol. 231. l. and had I≈ø≈øue John Holford, Son and Heir; George Holford, another Son, 22 Hen. 7. Lib. C. fol. 231. n. p. Con≈øtance married VVilliam Son of Edward Brad≈øhaw, 2 Hen. 8. 1511. Lib. C. fol. 231. o.
Sir George had four Ba≈øtard-≈øons; Thomas; Arthur, from whom the Holfords of Davenham; Raufe, and Robert; al≈øo Ellen, a ba≈øe Daughter; all living 22 Hen. 7. Lib. C. fol. 231. p.

Sir George was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 16 Hen. 8. 1524. He bore Lostock's Coat in his Seal,Lo≈øtock's Coat, Argent, a Greyhound Sable. to wit, A Greyhound, over which, corner-ways, on the Dexter Angle of the E≈øcocheon, on a Helmet, Wreath, and Mantle, a Greyhound's Head Couped; written about the Seal,‚ÄîS. GEORGII HOLFORD MILITIS.

IX. Sir John Holford of Holford Knight, Son and Heir of Sir George, married Margery Sole Daughter and Heir of Raufe Brereton of I≈øcoit in Flint≈øhire, not far from Whitchurch in Shrop≈øhire, 22 Hen. 7. 1507. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Holford, Son and Heir; Christopher Holford, younger Son, married Margaret Daughter of Thomas Danyell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, 1555. Lib. C. fol. 243. k. from whom the Holfords of London and E≈ø≈øex; Alice, a Daughter, married Piers Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, 21 Hen. 8. 1529. O. num. 6.

I find he was Knight 21 Hen. 8. O num. 6. He was Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 33 Hen. 8. 1541. And he died about 1545. For Margery his Widow married Sir Henry Sacheverell of Morley in Darby≈øhire, 1 Edw. 6. 1547. Lib. C. fol. 231. m. & 230. h.

X. Thomas Holford of Holford E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Sir John, married Margaret Daughter of Sir Thomas Butler of Bew≈øy in Lanca≈øhire, nigh Warrington; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Chri≈øtofer, Son and Heir.

After the death of Margaret, he married Jane the Widow of Hugh Dutton, Son and Heir of Sir Piers Dutton of Dutton and Hatton both, and Daughter of Sir William Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue George Holford of Newborough in Dutton, Gentleman; Thomas, and John; al≈øo Ellen, married to John Carrington of Carrington in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire; Dorothy, married to John Bruyn of Stapleford in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire; and Elizabeth, married to Charles Manwaring of Croxton in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, 1560.
This Thomas Holford died 24 Septembris, 11 Eliz. 1569.
XI. Chri≈øtofer Holford of Holford E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas, had al≈øo two Wives.
The fir≈øt was Anne, Daughter of Hugh Dutton and Jane afore≈øaid; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Holford; John died young, and Anne died young.

The ≈øecond Wife of Chri≈øtopher was Elizabeth the Widow of Peter Shakerley of Houlme juxt√¢ Nether-Pever, and Daughter and Co-heir of Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever. She married this Chri≈øtopher the thirteenth of July, 1561. and had I≈ø≈øue by him Mary Holford, Bapti≈øed at Nether-Pever the twentieth of January, 1562. who became ≈øole Heir to her Father.

Thomas Holford, Son and Heir of Chri≈øtofer, married Dorothy Daughter of Peter Shakerley of Houlme E≈øq and Elizabeth afore≈øaid, the thirteenth of July, 1561. But Thomas died without I≈ø≈øue, and was buried at Nether-Pever the twenty fifth of February then next following; and Dorothy his Widow afterwards married Adam Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire, the ninth of January, 1582.
Chri≈øtofer Holford E≈øquire died 27 Januarii, 1581. 23 Eliz. Cook's Reports, lib. 2. fol. 50. b. Sir Hugh Cholmondley's Ca≈øe.

Between this Lady Mary Cholmondley, and George Holford of Newborough in Dutton, Brother to Chri≈øtopher Holford, and now next Heir-Male of the Holfords, hapned long and tedious Suits concerning Holford-Lands, which continued above forty Years: At la≈øt the Matter was compo≈øed by Mediation of Friends, and the Lands parted between them. The Lady Cholmondley had the Mannor-Hou≈øe of Holford, with the Demain-Lands thereof; and George Holford had the Mannor of I≈øcoit in Flint≈øhire: The Lands and Tenements in Lo≈øtock-Gralam, Plumley, and Nether-Pever, were parted promi≈øcuou≈øly, as they be now enjoyed.

This George Holford married Jane Daughter and Heir of Charles Awbrey of Cantriff in Brecknock≈øhire, and Widow of Henry Ma≈øter≈øon; and by her had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Holford and John, Twins; Edward, third Son; Peter, fourth Son Peter, the fourth Son, waited on James Earl of Darby, and married Frances Daughter of William Wolley of Warrington, Mercer, and Widow of one Pikford of London, Haberda≈øher, and had I≈ø≈øue James, Peter, and George; and al≈øo Frances, Mary, Anne, and Hannah. ; George, Charles, and William: Al≈øo Mary, married to William Harcourt of Win≈øham, Gentleman, 1629. both yet living, 1666.

George Holford of Newborough died 1635. and Thomas Holford of I≈øcoit, Son and Heir of the ≈øaid George, died without I≈ø≈øue-Male: Wherefore his Inheritance is de≈øcended now unto James Holford This James Holford married Margaret Daughter of Matthew Carleton of Lincolns-Inn in London, and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Holford, a Son; and Mary, a Daughter. James Holford died 1666 Margaret his Wife died 1662. of Newborough, Son and Heir of Peter fourth Son of George; for all the other Brothers of Peter died without I≈ø≈øue: But the Mannor of I≈øcoit was ≈øold by Thomas Holford, elde≈øt Brother, unto one Mr. Adams of London.

The Lady Mary Cholmondley ≈øurvived her Husband, and lived at her Mannor-Hou≈øe of Holford, which ≈øhe builded new, repaired, and enlarged, and where ≈øhe died about 1625. aged 63 Years, or thereabouts. King James termed her The Bold Lady of Che≈øhire.

p.hi: So ended the Family of Holford of Holford.

div.p: XIII. Robert Cholmondley of Cholmondley, Son and Heir of Sir Hugh and Mary Holford his Wife, was Created Baronet in June, 1611. and after Created Vi≈øcount Cholmondley of Kellis in Ireland, about 1635. and la≈øtly, Lord Cholmondley, Baron of Wich-Malbeng Made Baron of Wich-Malbank, Sept. 1. 1645., id e≈øt, Nantwich in Che≈øhire, and al≈øo Earl of Lein≈øter in Ireland, 21 Car. 1. 5 die Martii, 1645.
He married Katharine Si≈øter of Charles Lord Stanhop of Harrington; but had no I≈ø≈øue by her.

This Robert Lord Cholmondley died 1659. aged 75 Years, without any Lawful I≈ø≈øue
of his Body; leaving Robert, elde≈øt Son of Hugh Cholmondley his Brother, to ≈øucceed in his Inheritance: Which Robert was Created Vi≈øcount Kells in the County of Meath, in the Kingdom of Ireland, 29 Martii, 1661. 13 Car. 2.

But this Robert Earl of Lein≈øter e≈øtated Holford-Lands (which came by his Mother) on Thomas Cholmondley his Son by one Mrs. Gold≈øton, to whom (as ≈øome think) he was affianced, though never married to her.

This Thomas Cholmondley died at Holford, in Fe≈øto Epiphaniae, the ≈øixth of January, 1667. and was buried at Nether-Pever on Thur≈øday the ≈øixteenth day of January following; on whom Mr. Kent his Chaplain, in the Funeral Sermon, truly ob≈øerved, That he was a Loyal Subject, a Good Husband, a Good Father, a Good Ma≈øter, a Good Landlord, a Good Neighbor, a Good Friend, a Good Chri≈øtian, and a Good Man.
This Coat of Arms, as it is here in≈øerted, he had granted unto him by the Patent of William Dugdale, Norroy at Arms, about Anno 1666.

div.head: Pre≈øton juxta Dutton.
div.p: THis Town≈øhip of Pre≈øton was Purcha≈øed by Hugh Dutton of Dutton, from Henry de Nuers and Julian his Wife; Rendring eight Shillings yearly at the Fea≈øt of St. Martin, exceptis Foranis Servitiis; & propter hanc Conce≈ø≈øionem dedit Hugo Dutton quinque Marcas Argenti; & praedictae Julianae de Recognitione unum Palfridum Nigrum, & unum Annulum Aureum, as the Words of the Deed be. This was about King John's Reign.

This Grant was Confirmed by Randle Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øirnamed Blundevill: Lib. C. fol. 155. o. p. The Originals to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Lady Kilmorey at Dutton, 1649. Since which time this Town≈øhip hath belonged to the Duttons of Dutton.

list.head: Charterers in Pre≈øton, 1666.
list.item: 1. Thomas Barker of Pre≈øton.
2. Thomas Baxter of Pre≈øton.

div.head: Ro≈øthorne.
div.p: HEre is an ancient Pari≈øh-Church, Dedicated to St. Mary; their Wakes or Fea≈øt of Dedication being on the fifteenth day of Augu≈øt.
This Pari≈øh comprehendeth the≈øe Villages following (be≈øides the Parochial Chappelries of Knotsford and Over-Pever, which ≈øee in their due Places.)

row.cell: High-Legh, with its Hamlets of Swineyard, Sworton, and North-wood,

div.p: That there was a Church at Ro≈øthorne before Anno 1188. appears by this following Deed, collected by Sam≈øon Erde≈øwick of Sond in Stafford≈øhire, out of the Evidences of Venables of Kinderton: Lib. H. num. 1.

p.hi: UNiver≈øis Sanctae Matris Eccle≈øiae Filiis‚ÄîWillielmus de Venables Miles ≈øalutem. Noverit univer≈øitas ve≈øtra, me conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe Hugoni de Venables Clerico id juris quod habui in Eccle≈øiis terrae meae, ≈øcilicet, in Eccle≈øia de Rosthorne, & in Eccle≈øia de Eccle≈øton, & in Eccle≈øia de E≈øtbirie,‚Äî&c. Facta vero e≈øt haec Donatio Synodo apud Cestriam proxime celebrata po≈øt confectionem Venerabilis Epi≈øcopi no≈øtri & Domini Hugonis de Novant; & exi≈øtente Cu≈øtode Honoris Ce≈øtriae Domino Adamo de Aldithley: Datu≈øque e≈øt Tutor Praenominato Clerico Hugoni de Venables, Adam Panton ejus Avunculus. Hiis Te≈øtibus, G. de Venables, & R. & Michaele eju≈ødem Fratribus, N. & G. Capellanis, Willielmo de Monte alto, & Magi≈øtro Philippo de Ce≈øtria Clerico, R. Capellano, & Waltero Eccle≈øiae Sanctae Trinitatis Presbytero, Domino Nigello, & Hugone Filio Andreae Husbanda Eccle≈øiae Sancti Johannis in Ce≈øtria Canonico, Warino de Vernon, & R. Fratre ejus, Liulfo de Croke≈øton, & Willielmo Donne, & multis aliis.

div.p: Hugh Novant was Con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Coventry, 1188. So Hoveden in his Hi≈øtory.

But the Advow≈øon of Ro≈øthorne-Church came afterwards to Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton; and Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton relea≈øeth all his Right in the Advow≈øon of St. Maries Chuch of Ro≈øthorn, unto Sir Hugh Venables of Kinderton, in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt. Lib. H. num. 61.
And ever ≈øince the Barons of Kinderton have been Patrons hereof, to this day, 1666.

The Steeple of this Church was built in Stone Anno Domini 1533. 25 Hen. 8. as appears by the Figures cut in Stone on the South-≈øide of the ≈øaid Steeple: Over the≈øe Figures is written,‚ÄîOrate pro Anima Domini Willielmi Hardwick Vicarii hujus Eccle≈øiae, & pro animabus omnium Parochianorum ≈øuorum qui hoc ≈øculp≈øerunt.
This Town of Ro≈øthorne was held in the Conqueror's Time by Gilbert Venables Baron of Kinderton, as appears in Doom≈øday-book.

p.hi: The≈øe following Notes were taken out of Will. Vernon's Collections.

div.p: In the Reign of Henry the Second, or thereabouts, the Daughters and Heirs of Homfrey de Ro≈øthorne grant all their Lands in Ro≈øthorne to Robert de Manwaring, in the≈øe Words.‚Äî

SCiant tam prae≈øentes quam futuri, Nos Filias & Haeredes Homfridi de Ro≈øthorne, ≈øcilicet Margeriam & Sibillam, dedi≈ø≈øe‚ÄîRoberto de Menilwaring pro Homagio & Servitio ≈øuo, & pro 3 l. 7 s. 0 d. Argenti, totam terram no≈øtram in Ro≈øthorne, cum omnibus pertinentiis ≈øuis: Tenendum illi & Haeredibus‚Äîhonorific√® in Feodo & Haereditate: Reddendo inde annuatim nobis & Haeredibus no≈øtris‚Äîquatuor Denarios in Vigilia Natalis Domini, pro omni Servitio quod ad nos pertinet,‚Äî&c. Praeter hoc, quod praedictus Robertus de Menilwarin & Haeredes ≈øui debent facere foren≈øe Servitium Ricardo de Vernon & Haeredibus ≈øuis, quod nos illi facere debemus; ≈øcilicet decimam ≈øextam partem Servitii unius Feodi Militis, unde nos illi ≈øpontanea voluntate no≈øtra & ≈øua in pleno Comitatu Ce≈øtriae attornavimus praedicto Ricardo de Vernon, & in Curia eju≈ødem Ricardi coram Hominibus ≈øuis. Te≈øtibus Gilberto Pipardo, Ada de Aldithley, Radulfo Dapifero, Willielmo de Me≈ønilwarin, Liulfo de Twamlow, Ricardo de Sondbach, Roberto de Molde≈øworth, Roberto de Stafford, Rogero de Cumbray,‚Äî&c.

p.hi: RIcardus de Vernon omnibus Amicis & Hominibus ≈øuis, tam prae≈øentibus quam futuris, ≈øalutem. Sciatis me prece & petitione Haeredum Homfridi de Ro≈øthorne conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe‚Äî Roberto de Menilwarin & Haeredibus ≈øuis‚Äîtotum Tenementum illud quod tenuit in Ro≈øthorne de Haeredibus Homfridi de Ro≈øthorne. Tenendum illi & Haeredibus ≈øuis, liber√® & quiet√® honorific√® in Feodo & Haereditate, cum omnibus libertatibus & pertinentiis ≈øuis, ≈øicut Charta praedictarum Haeredum praedicto Roberto Te≈øtatur, ≈øalvo forin≈øeco Servitio meo, unde praedictae Haeredes Humfridi praedictum Robertum mihi Attornaverunt in pleno Comitatu Ce≈øtriae, & in Curia mea coram hominibus meis. Te≈øtibus, Radulpho de Me≈ønilwarin, Willielmo de Me≈ønilwarin, Liulfo de Twamlow, Ricardo & Hugone de Blakenhall, Hugone & Willielmo de Lega, Gilberto de Hertford, Ricardo de Tewa, Roberto de Mara, Hugone le Bret, Petro Chanu, Gralam de Lo≈øtock, Ranulfo de Bertumley, Selone Clerico, & multis aliis.

SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, Ego Willielmus de Ma≈ø≈øy & Uxor mea Margeria dedimus‚Äî Hugoni de Venables & Haeredibus ≈øuis, vel cui dare aut a≈ø≈øignare voluerit, pro Homagio & Servitio ≈øuo‚Äîcertas Terras in Ro≈øthorne. Te≈øtibus Domino Willielmo de Venables, Domino Warino de Vernon, Domino Alano de Tatton, Domino Willielmo de Venables juvene, Viviano de Davenport, Ranulfo de Arclid, Ricardo de Blakenhall, Ada de Legh, Willielmo de Mara, Willielmo de Mobberley, Aytropo de Mulinton, Ricardo Clerico, & aliis.

div.p: ‚ÄîEgo Margeria Domina de Ro≈øthorne in ligia pote≈øtate mea dedi‚ÄîHugoni de Venables, & Heredibus ≈øuis, [certain Lands in Ro≈øthorne]. Te≈øtibus, Domino Willielmo de Vebles, Domino Warino de Vernon, Domino Alano de Tatton, Domino Willielmo de Venables juvene, Viviano de Davenport, Ranulpho de Arclid, Ricardo de Blakenhall, Ada de Legh, Willielmo de Mara, Willielmo de Mobberley, Aytropo de Millington, Ricardo Clerico, & aliis.
The≈øe two Deeds were made tempore Hen. 3. at one time, coram ii≈ødem Te≈øtibus.

p.hi:
SCiant‚ÄîRanulfus de Starkey & Ellena Uxor mea dedimus‚ÄîHugoni de Venables & Haeredibus ≈øuis, quartam partem totius Villae de Ro≈øthorne cum pertinentiis, & quartam partem molendini‚ÄîExcepta terra, quae prius data fuit Monialibus Ce≈øtriae‚ÄîReddendo inde annuatim duodecem Denarios in Fe≈øto Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae. pro omni Servitio. Te≈øtibus,
Thoma de Sondbach, Johanne Capellano Fraire ejus, Henrico Capellano de Budworth, Ricardo Capellano de Torperley, Thoma Capellano de Ro≈øthorne, Willielmo de Ma≈ø≈øy, Ricardo Clerico, & aliis.

div.p: ‚ÄîEgo Ranulfus Starkey confirmavi & quietum clamavi Willielmo de Venables Domino de Kinderton, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, totum Servitium, Homagium, & redditum duodecem Denariorum annui redditus, quae Ricardus Starkey Pater meus annuatim quondam ≈øolebat recipere de praedicto Willielmo de Venables, pro quarta parte Villae de Ro≈øthorne,‚Äî&c. This Deed was made Anno 1286. or thereabouts.

OMnibus Chri≈øti fidelibus‚ÄîHugo de Venables Miles ≈øalutem‚ÄîNeveritis me conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe Johanni de Legh, & Ellenae Uxori ejus, & Haeredibus vel A≈ø≈øignatis eju≈ødem Johannis, totum jus & clameum quod habeo in omnibus Terris & Tenementis redditibus & ≈øervitiis, quae vel quas dictus Johannes & Ellena habuerunt ex dimi≈ø≈øione & Feoffamento Willielmi Venables Fratris mei, in Villa de Ro≈øthorne: ita quod nec ego Hugo, nec Haeredes mei, aliquod jus aut clameum‚Äîexigere poterimus, praeter exitum redditus duodecem Denariorum, & unius Paris albarum Cheirothecarum ad Fe≈øtum Nativitatis Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Domino Roberto de Holland tunc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae,‚Äî&c. Datum apud Mar≈øton die Para≈øceuae On Goodfriday, 1308., Anno Domini 1308. (2 Edw. 2.)

OMnibus Chri≈øti fidelibus‚ÄîWillielmus Filius Willielmi Venables de Bradwell ≈øalutem. Noveritis me remi≈øi≈ø≈øe Johanni de Legh totum jus in Terris & Tenementis in Ro≈øthorne, quae praedictus Johannes habuit ex dono Willielmi Patris mei,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Domino Petro de Warburton, Willielmo de Baggiley Militibus, Willielmo de Mobberley tunc Vicecomite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, Roberto Ma≈ø≈øy de Tatton, Hamone de A≈øhley. Datum 13 Edw. 2.

p.hi: Thus far out of Will. Vernon's Notes.

div.p: This was John Legh of Boothes, Son of William Venables of Bradwell by Agnes his ≈øecond Wife; to whom, you ≈øee, his Father William Venables gave the≈øe Lands in Ro≈øthorn; and they are confirmed unto him by William, Son of William Venables of Bradwell, Half-brother to the ≈øaid John Legh.
And the≈øe Lands in Ro≈øthorne, here given to John Legh, (as I take it) was a Moiety of Ro≈øthorne; and Legh of Booths hath this Moiety at this day, 1666.

p.hi: The Notes of Mr. John Hal≈øey of Lincolns-Inn, out of the Earl of Bridgewater's Evidences. 1667.

q.p: SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, quod ego Mattheus de Alpraham dedi‚ÄîRicardo de Ma≈ø≈øy Militi, Homagium & Servitium Galfridi Filii Ricardi Starkey, de Terris, Tenementis, & Feodis omnimodis, quae de me ceu Antece≈ø≈øoribus meis unquam in Villa de Rosthorne tenebantur,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, Rogero de Domvill Militibus, Ricardo de Bonebury, Thoma le Cryour, Thoma de Legh, Johanne de Legh, Henrico Heyron, Roberto de Ma≈ø≈øy, & aliis. (Sub Edw. 1.)

div.p: William Chanu granted to Richard Son of Richard Clerke de Ro≈øthorne, in Fee, all his Right in one Oxgang of Land in Ro≈øthorne; to wit, quartam partem Villae, quam Petrus Chanu Avunculus meus tenuit: For which was a Suit per Breve de morte Antece≈ø≈øoris, between the ≈øaid William Chanu Demandant, and William de Ma≈ø≈øy and Margery his Wife, Tenants: Te≈øtibus Philippo de Orreby tunc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Willielmo Venables, Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, &c. Sub initio Hen. 3.

‚ÄîEgo Ricardus de Rother≈øton, Filius Ricardi Clerici de Rothe≈øthorne dedi‚ÄîMargeriae Filiae Homfridi de Rothe≈øthorne Clerici, unam Bovatam Terrae in Rothe≈øthorne, quam Petrus Chanu tenuit; ≈øcilicet, quartam partem Villae: Pro qua, Margeria dedit quatuor Marcas
Argenti: And ≈øo relea≈øed to Richard all Covenants which had been between Richard and his Father and Wimar his Si≈øter on the one Part, and the ≈øaid Margery and William her Son and Amabilia her Daughter on the other Part: Te≈øtibus Philippo de Orreby tunc Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae,‚Äî&c.

q.p: SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, Quod ego Rogerus de Hale Carpentarius, dedi Thomae de Ma≈ø≈øy, Filio Domini Willielmi de Ma≈ø≈øy, totam Terram meam Tenementum meum, tam in Molendinis quam in Terris, quod habui in Villa de Ro≈øthorne‚ÄîFaciendo inde Servitium Dominis illius Villae, quod continetur in Charta Originali quam ≈øibi deliberavi quando i≈øtam Chartam ≈øibi feci,‚Äî&c. Te≈øtibus Ricardo de Wilbraham tunc Vicecomite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae, Ricardo de Vernon, Willielmo de Ma≈ø≈øy, Willielmo de Carrington tunc Ballivo de Doneham,‚Äî&c. This Deed was made 1270.

OMnibus Chri≈øti fidelibus,‚ÄîWillielmus Filius Willielmi Filii Gilberti de Tabley, ≈øalutem. Noveritis me remi≈øi≈ø≈øe Roberto de Ma≈ø≈øy Domino de Tatton‚Äîtotum jus meum in omnibus Terris quae fuerunt Margeriae Proaviae meae in Villa de Ro≈øthorne,‚Äî&c. (Sub. Edw. 2.)

div.p: Richard Bruncroft gives to Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, Son of Sir William Ma≈ø≈øy Knight, certain Lands in Ro≈øthorne, in exchange for Lands in Quiter-hall, towards the Bounds of Nor≈øhagh in Tatton. Te≈øtibus Willielmo de Venables,‚Äî&c.

The Prior and Convent of Norton give to Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy Knight, the Homage and the Service of the Lands of Henry the Hunter in Ro≈øthorne. Te≈øtibus Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, Roberto le Gro≈øvenour tunc Vicecomite Ce≈øter≈øhiriae,‚Äî&c. This was made in Anno 1286. or thereabout.

Robert Ma≈ø≈øy Lord of Tatton, and John Legh of Booths, make an Agreement and Partition; to each a Moiety of Ro≈øthorne-Mill, and to each the Mulcture of their own Tenants: They exchange Land, and relea≈øe Rent to each other; and Legh is to hold a fourth Part of Ro≈øthorne of Robert Ma≈ø≈øy in Fee, by the yearly Rent of Twelve pence. Te≈øtibus Hugh de Heelegh Chief-Ju≈øtice of Che≈øter This was Hugh de Audley of Heeley-Ca≈øtle in Stafford≈øhire. ,‚Äî&c. (1315.)

p.hi: So far out of Mr. Hal≈øey's Notes.

q.p: Inter les Fines Ce≈øtriae, 18 Edw. 3. Finalis Concordia coram Henrice de Ferrars Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Johanne de Arderne, Radulfo de Vernon, Petro de Thorneton, Willielmo Boydell Militibus, Johanne de Wetenhale, Willielmo de Praers, & Thoma Danyers‚ÄîInter Ricardum Filium Hugonis Ma≈ø≈øy de Tatton & Aliciam Uxorem ejus quaerentes, & Hugonem Filium Willielmi Ma≈ø≈øy de Tatton deforciantem; de Mannerio de Ro≈øthorne cum pertinentiis,‚Äî&c.

div.p: So that Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton was Lord of the other Moity of Ro≈øthorne, ever ≈øince the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt; if not the Royalty of the whole.
How the≈øe Lands de≈øcended to the Earl of Bridgewater, ≈øee the Pedegree in Tatton.

list.head: Charterers in Ro≈øthorne, 1666.
list.item: 1. George Ma≈ø≈øy of Denfield, who≈øe Ance≈øtors de≈øcended out of the Ma≈ø≈øies of Tatton under Edward the Third.
2. Edward Allen of Ro≈øthorne.

div.head: Runcorn Superior & Inferior.
div.p: THe≈øe two Town≈øhips, now di≈øtingui≈øh'd into Over-Runcorn and Nether-Runcorn, are Mized together in our Common Mize-book, and are very hard Mized.

Here at Runcorn that Magnanimous Virago, Elflede Counte≈øs of Mercia, and Widow to Ethelred the Chief Governor of Mercia, and Si≈øter to King Edward the Elder, did build a Town, Anno Domini 916. as Florentius, Huntington, and other our Hi≈øtorians do affirm: A Town and Ca≈øtle, ≈øaith Stow, pag. 81. Probably it was then in a more flouri≈øhing condition than now it is: For now it is a very poor Village, and ≈øeems to be Wa≈øte in the Conqueror's Time; for it is not mentioned in Doom≈øday-book.
Both the≈øe Town≈øhips comprehend not fully 300 Che≈øhire Acres, upon a Survey of the A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors made by e≈øtimation in the Time of our late War.

The≈øe little Villages are both of the Fee of the ancient Barony of Halton, and were formerly Copy-hold Land to the Manor of Halton, until the ≈øeveral Owners bought out their Lands in Fee-farm, to hold in Free and Common Soccage of the Mannor of Enfield in Middle≈øex; the King's Grant bearing date the ninth day of September, 4 Car. 1. 1628. as you may ≈øee al≈øo above in Moore.

Some Lands in the≈øe Town≈øhips are ancient Free-hold Land: For Sir Hugh Dutton of Dutton, by Office taken at Frod≈øham, 22 Edw. 1. 1294. was found to hold ≈øeven Bovates of Land in Runcorn, with other Lands, of the Honor of Halton; which are termed The third Part of Over-Runcorn, in the Feodary of Halton: Vide ≈øupra, at the end of Halton: But the≈øe Lands were ≈øold lately by Gilbert Lord Gerard, unto Savage of Rock-Savage, in the Reign of King James.
Here is ≈øeated, on the Bank by the River≈øide, an ancient Pari≈øh-Church, Alhallowes of Nether-Runcorn, Dedicated to All-Saints.

William Son of Nigell, Baron of Halton, founded here a Hou≈øe of Canons Regular, Anno Domini 1133. And afterwards William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire the younger, Son of William, Son of Nigell, removed their Habitation unto Norton, about the Reign of King Stephen. All which Donations of William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire the younger, and of the Churches of Runcorn and Great-Budworth, and many other things, Henry the Second confirms to the Canons of Runcorn, as you may ≈øee the Charter in Mona≈øticon, Vol. 2. pag. 186. Ratified al≈øo by the Charter of Edward the Third, wherein he Confirms Donationem, quam Hugo de Duttona Filius Hugonis de Duttona fecit per Chartam ≈øuam praedictis Canonicis de duobus Solidis & octo Denariis de redditu de Pul≈øeya‚Äîac de Terra de Frod≈øham cum pertinentiis; & de Terra de Pulles-eya, cum Capella, & tota Terra A≈ø≈øartata, & Pa≈øtura ad ≈øexaginta animalia ibidem, ante Publicationem Statuti praedicti de Terris ad manum mortuam non ponendis editi. Datum apud Gloce≈øter, 30 die Augu≈øti, 3 Edw. 3.
See more of the Priory of Norton, of the Order of St. Augu≈øtine, ≈øupra, in Norton.

The Church of Runcorn ≈øeems to be before the Norman Conque≈øt: For we read in the ancient Roll, That Nigell Baron of Halton gave the Church of Runcorn to Wolfaith a Prie≈øt his Brother, in the Reign of the Conqueror.

This Church hath now for its Patron Chri≈øt-Church College in Oxford: For after the Statute of Di≈ø≈øolution of Abbies, Henry the Eighth gave the Rectory of Runcorn, and the Rectory of Great-Budworth in Che≈øhire, unto Chri≈øt-Church in Oxford, by ≈øpecial Grant, dated 11 die Decembris, 38 Hen. 8. which before belonged to the Priory of Norton.
This Pari≈øh comprehendeth the≈øe Villages following, over and be≈øides the Parochial-Chappelries of Daresbery and A≈øton juxta Sutton, within the ≈øame; which ≈øee in their due Places.

div.head: Sale.
div.p: SAle is not in the Record of Doom≈øday-book. The Town of Sale is of the Fee of Halton; for we read in the Feodary of Halton, ≈øub Edw. 2.‚Äî

Dominus Petrus de Warburton tenet Villam de Sale pro decima parte Feodi Militis.
