Here is Seated the ancient Family of the Ma≈ø≈øies of Sale, which branched out from the Ma≈ø≈øies Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy about the Reign of King John: For I find Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, Son of Robert Ma≈ø≈øy, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Lands in Sale under Henry the Third; which Robert was younger Son of Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy: And this Family of Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale is ≈øtill continuing, 1666.

In the Offices of Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale he is found to hold the Moiety of Sale of Warburton of Arley; and ≈øome of them have been Ward unto Warburton: but Ward≈øhips are now taken off by Statute, Anno 12 Car. 2. cap. 24.
And as Ma≈ø≈øy was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of one Moiety, ≈øo the other Lands in Sale are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed at this day, 1666. by the≈øe Per≈øons following.

1. Edward Holt of Sale, who≈øe Lands in Sale his Ance≈øtor John Holt, Son of Robert, Ba≈øe Son of Geffrey de Holt, had in Marriage with Ellen Daughter and Heir of Thomas Sale of Sale, 21 Rich. 2. 1397. Lib. C. fol. 273. a. b. The Originals in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Edward Holt of Sale, 1666.

2. The Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy hath ≈øeven Tenements in Sale. The≈øe were Parcel of Holt's Lands, and were purcha≈øed by Sr George Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy from Thomas Holt of Whickle≈øwick in Lanca≈øhire, and Randle Holt his Son, 4 Augu≈øti, 2 Jacobi, 1604. being then twelve Me≈ø≈øuages and Cottages, with 4 d. Rent yearly i≈ø≈øuing out of the Lands in Sale then in the Tenure of George Ma≈ø≈øy; and al≈øo 4 d. Rent then i≈ø≈øuing out of Thomas Wren≈øhaw's Tenement, now the Lands of Sir Edward Mo≈øeley of Howe≈øend in Lanca≈øhire, late decea≈øed: Lib. C. fol. 273. c.
3. Geffrey Cartwright Gentleman. His Lands in Sale were formerly bought from Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale.
4. William William≈øon of Sale.
5. Richard Wren≈øhaw of Sale.
6. The Lands of Sir Edward Mo≈øeley lately decea≈øed; to wit, five Me≈ø≈øuages and Cottages in Sale, now in Lea≈øe; and pays 4 d. Chief-Rent yearly to Mr. Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale.
7. Mr. Gerard of Riddings in Timperley, three ≈ømall Cottages in Sale, now in Lea≈øe, late Vawdrey's Land.
8. Edward Legh of Baggilegh E≈øquire, hath one ≈ømall Cottage in Sale, now in Lea≈øe.
9. Robert Tatton of Witten≈øhaw E≈øquire, hath certain Land in Sale, now in Lea≈øe, and and pays 3 s. 4 d. yearly Rent to Mr. Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale.
10. James Wren≈øhaw of Limme, one Tenement in Sale, now Lea≈øed to Thomas Davys.

So that it ≈øeems Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale had anciently one Moiety of Sale, and Holt another Moiety, though now ≈øcattered as afore≈øaid: For the≈øe other Parcels came ≈øome from the one, and ≈øome from the other, originally.

div.head: Stockham.
div.p: THis Town≈øhip of Stockham belonged to the Priory of Norton, and was Purcha≈øed from the King by Richard Brooke E≈øquire, 37 Hen. 8. 1545‚ñ™ with Norton, and other Lands al≈øo; who≈øe Po≈øterity enjoyeth the ≈øame at this day, 1666. See in Norton ≈øupra.
In Stockham is no Charterer at all.

div.head: Stretton.
div.p:
THis Town≈øhip of Stretton hath for long time belonged to the Starkeys,
Starkey of Stretton beareth for his Coat of Arms A Stork; po≈ø≈øibly in allu≈øion to his Name: ≈øcilicet, Agent, a Stork Sable, the Bill and Legs Gules. ≈øince the Reign of Henry the Second: For Roger Fitz-Alured granted Stretton to Richard Starkey, and his Heirs; To hold as freely, as any of the ≈øaid Richard's Ance≈øtors ever held the ≈øame; for the Service of the tenth part of a Knights Fee: Lib. C. fol. 135. a. This was was the Reign of King John.
This Roger Fitz-Alfred's Daughter and Heir, called Agnes, married Adam de Dutton the Ance≈øtor of Warburton of Arley.
Wherefore in the Feodary of Halton under Edw. 2. we read,‚ÄîDominus Petrus de Warburton tenet Villam de Stretton, pro decima parte unius Feodi Militis.
So that it ≈øhould ≈øeem to be held originally from the Baron of Halton: But I find it not mentioned in Doom≈øday-book; probably it was then Wa≈øte.

And Sir Geffrey de Warburton relea≈øed unto Thomas Starkey of Stretton, and to his Heirs, all his Claim in Villa de Stretton, ceu in aliqua Parcella eju≈ødem, ut de Wardis, Maritagiis, Releviis, E≈øcaetis, Homagiis, aut Servitiis, quae praedictus Thomas aut Antece≈ø≈øores ≈øui mihi, ≈øeu Antece≈ø≈øoribus meis, facere ≈øolebant: Datum 4 die Aprilis, 5 Rich. 2. (1382.) Yet notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Thomas and his Heirs ≈øhall pay yearly to the ≈øaid Sir Geffrey, and his Heirs, one Pair of White Gloves on Easter-day, for all Service: Lib. C. fol. 134. a. The Original hereof was in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Starkey of Stretton, of the Lower-Hall, 1650. Sealed with Warburton's Proper Coat of Arms,Warbu ‚Ä¢ ton's Coat, Argent, two Cheverons Gules, in a Canton of the ≈øecond a Mollet Or. which he a≈ø≈øumed upon taking the Sir-name of Warburton, to wit, Two Cheverons, and in a Canton, a Mollet; in≈øcribed about the Seal,‚ÄîSIGILL. GALFRIDI DE WARBURTON. Sundry of the like I have ≈øeen to Deeds of Edward the Third's Time.
The Starkeys of Stretton branched into two Families here in Stretton long time ago: The Lower-Hall, and the Over-Hall.

Starkey of Over-Hall in Stretton is de≈øcended of a younger Son of Starkey of the Lower-Hall, and branched out fir≈øt about 16 Edw. 1. 1287. Lib. C. fol. 135. c. f. & 134. h. k. Randle Starkey, the fir≈øt of the Family of the Over-Hall, being younger Brother to Richard Starkey of the Nether-Hall Lord of Stretton, living both 3 Edw. 2. 1309.

So that Starkey of the Lower-Hall is the Original Root, and Lord of the Mannor of Stretton; but now lately in our days hath ≈øold a good Parcel of the Demain of the Lower-Hall, called Mo≈ø≈øe-wood, unto Raufe Jack≈øon of Crowley; who≈øe Son Thomas Jack≈øon, now of Mo≈ø≈øe-wood, 1665. enjoyeth the ≈øame.
Al≈øo one George Web≈øter, alias Bromfield, hath lately bought another Parcel of the Demain of Lower-Hall.

And William Southern, late of Hatton, hath bought ≈øeveral Tenements in Stretton
from Starkey of the Lower-Hall: So that this ancient FamilyOf Starkey of the Lower-Hall. is now langui≈øhing, from when al≈øo branched the Starkey's of Wrenbury, and the Starkeys of Olton in Che≈øhire, and other Families, originally.
In this Town of Stretton is an ancient Chappel of Ea≈øe, within the Pari≈øh of Great-Budworth, called Stretton-Chappel; but it is now very ruinous, and in decay, 1666.

div.head: Sutton juxta Frod≈øham.
div.p: SUtton nigh Frod≈øham is not mentioned in Doom≈øday-book: It is of the Fee of Halton.

Adam de Dutton, younger Son of Hugh Dutton of Dutton, and And Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley, was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this Town≈øhip in the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt; who≈øe Heirs enjoy the ≈øame at this day, 1666.

This Adam dedit Deo, & ad Con≈øtructionem Eccle≈øiae Beatae Mariae de Norton, & Canonicis ibidem Deo ≈øervientibus, three Shillings yearly Rent, i≈ø≈øuing out of his Mill in Sutton juxta Halton;‚Äîand after his own Life, the Mill of Sutton entirely: To which Deed Roger Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire is Witne≈øs, who died 1211. 13 Johannis Regis. This Deed, with many others which belonged to the Priory of Norton, I found Copied out in an old long Parchment Roll, among the Evidences of Dutton of Dutton, 1665. of an ancient Character.
In the Feodary of Halton under Edw. 2.‚ÄîGalfridus de Warburton tenet Villam de Sutton, pro quinta parte unius Feodi Militis. But others read, Pro quarta parte.

Die Martis proxime ante Fe≈øtum A≈øcen≈øionis Domini, 4 Edw. 2. coram Pagano Tybotot Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae‚ÄîInter Galfridum Filium Petri de Dutton querentem, & Petrum de Dutton deforciantem, de Manerio de Sutton, cum pertinentiis‚ÄîHabendum dicto Galfrido, & Haeredibus Ma≈øculis de Corpore ≈øuo,‚Äî&c.
In this Town≈øhip there is no Charterer at all, 1666.

div.head: Nether-Tabley.
div.p: THis Village of Nether-Tabley, ≈øometimes in old Deeds ≈øtiled Little-Tabley, and in the Record of Doom≈øday-book written Stabley, is bounded on the North-≈øide with Over-Tabley, and on the South-≈øide thereof is ≈øevered from Plumley with a little Brook, called Ben≈øtall-Brook, which at la≈øt falleth in with Waterles-River, before it be run quite pa≈øt Nether-Tabley, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øeth on towards Win≈øham.

In the Reign of William the Conqueror one Gozeline held this Town≈øhip under Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øirnamed Lupus; which one O≈øtebrand held before, & liber homo fuit: ibi duae Bovatae Terrae Geldabiles: Terra e≈øt dimidia Caruca: Wa≈øta fuit & e≈øt: So run the Words of Doom≈øday-book.

This Adam de Dutton was younger Son of Hugh Dutton of Dutton in Che≈øhire, and lineal Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley; who≈øe Po≈øterity living at Warburton in the Reign of Edward the Second, were ≈øirnamed de Warburton from the Place of their Re≈øidence, according to the manner of tho≈øe Ages; which Sir-name they have ever ≈øince retained.

Geffrey Dutton, Son of Geffrey, Son of Adam Dutton afore≈øaid, gave this Town≈øhip to Margaret his Daughter, and to her Heirs, about the very end of the Reign of Henry the Third, in the≈øe Words,‚ÄîI. num. 1.

SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri, quod ego Galfridus de Dutton dedi & conce≈ø≈øi & hac prae≈øenti Charta mea confirmavi Margaretae Filiae meae, pro Homagio & Servitio ≈øuo totam Villam meam, quae vocatur Parva-Tabley, ≈øine ullo retenemento; cum Homagiis & Servitiis, cum Villenagiis, cum Bo≈øcis, cum Planis, cum Pratis, & Pa≈øcuis, cum Moris & Marci≈øcis, cum Aquis & Molendinis, cum Viis & Semitis, cum omnibus locis praedictae Villae pertinentibus: Tenendam & habendam ≈øibi Margaretae, & Haeredibus ≈øuis, de me Galfrido & Haeredibus meis, liber√®, quiet√®, & pacific√®, cum omnibus libertatibus & Ay≈øiamentis praedictae Villae pertinentibus: Faciendo inde mihi forin≈øecum Servitium, quantum pertinet ad duas Bovatas Terrae, unde triginta Bovatae Terrae faciunt Feodum unius Militis; & faciendo Servitium de Hauthoner Hauthoner, id e≈øt, Homo Loricatus. quantum pertinet ad praedictam Villam; pro omni ≈øeculari ≈øervitio, con≈øuetudine, & demanda, mihi & Haeredibus meis pertinente. Et ego Galfridus & Haeredes mei praedictam Villam, ut praedictum e≈øt, praedictae Margaretae & Haeredibus ≈øuis, contra omnes homines & foeminas in perpetuum Warrantizabimus. Et ad majorem hujus rei ≈øecuritatem huic prae≈øenti ≈øcripto Sigillum appo≈øui meum. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Domino Thoma de Dutton, Domino Galfrido de Dutton, Hugone de Limme, Thoma Fratre ejus, Ricardo de A≈øton, Rogero de Toft, Willielmo de Waleton, & multis aliis.
The Seal is,‚ÄîA Mans Arm in a Maunch or Loo≈øe Sleeve, with a Flower de Luce in his Hand; written about,‚ÄîSIGILLUM GALFRIDI DE DUTTON, in a Roundlet, not in an E≈øcocheon.

This Margaret Dutton fir≈øt married Robert de Denbigh, but had no I≈ø≈øue by him. After ≈øhe married Nicolas de Leyce≈øter, about 1276. by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue; and to who≈øe ≈øucceeding Progeny the Manor of Nether-Tabley ≈øtill belongeth at this day, 1666.
This Nicolas Leyce≈øter had al≈øo by Margaret the Manors of Wethale and Hield, both ≈øituate in A≈øton nigh Great-Budworth, which his Heirs al≈øo enjoy at this pre≈øent. R. num. 3. I. num. 91.
He was afterwards Sir Nicolas Leyce≈øter Knight, ≈øo ≈øtiled 1292. 20 Edw. 1. I. num. 98.

In this Town≈øhip is not any Charterer at all: For the Free-hold of Heart of Nether-Tabley, and ≈øome others, were all bought out in the Reign of Edward the Third, by Roger Leyce≈øter, Son of Sir Nicolas and Margaret, and ≈øo made this Town≈øhip entirely his own; ≈øince which time it hath ≈øo continued, and is now entire, without any Charterer at all, 1666.

div.head: Now followeth the Genealogie of the Leyce≈øters of Tabley, exactly proved out of the Evidences of this Family; and the Originals quoted all along, as they now ≈øtand marked.
div.p: I. Sir Nicolas Leyce≈øter Knight was ≈øometime Sene≈øchal to Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln and Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire: G. num. 24. He married Margaret the Widow of Robert de Denbigh, and Daughter of Geffrey Dutton Ance≈øtor to Warburton of Arley, about the Year of Chri≈øt 1276. 5 Edw. 1. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Roger Leyce≈øter, Son and Heir; and John Leyce≈øter, Vicar of Walley≈øey in Wirrall, 1312. 6 Edw. 2. F. num. 101. I. num. 2, 3.
He had by this Margaret his Wife the Town≈øhip of Nether-Tabley, and the Manors of Wethale and Hield in A≈øton nigh Great-Budworth: I. num. 1. R. num. 3. I. num. 91.
Anno 1292. 20 Edw. 1. I find him ≈øtiled Knight: I. num. 98. And he had Lands in Adwick near Donca≈øter in York≈øhire: I. num. 95, 96, 97. and al≈øo in Wath near Adwick, 22 Edw. 1. I. num. 5.
Sir Nicolas Leyce≈øter died 23 Edw. 1. 1295.

He bought out all the Freeholders or Charterers in Nether-Tabley, the principal whereof was that of William Heart of Nether-Tabley; and ≈øo made that Town≈øhip entirely his own: I. num. 38. & num. 60. & num. 43.

Anno Chri≈øti 1296. he had the third part of Over-Tabley cum Sudlow, by the Grant of Sir John Grey, Son of Sir Reginald Grey, and which Sir John Grey had of the Grant of William de Tabley Lord of Over-Tabley and Knotsford: F. num. 1.

This Roger married I≈øabel Daughter of _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Nicolas Leyce≈øter, Son and Heir; Roger Leyce≈øter; and Margaret, married to Adam de Molde≈øworth, 17 Edw. 2. 1323. Which Adam was Sheriff of Flint 5 Edw. 3. I. num. 60. & num. 83. Lib. C. fol. 206. c. & fol. 207. i.
His Seal of Arms was,‚ÄîA Fe≈ø≈øe between three Flower de Luces; in≈øcribed about thus,‚ÄîSIGILLUM SECRETUM. I. num. 26. and many others. Sub Anno Domini 1325.
Roger Leyce≈øter died about 1349. and ≈øurvived his Father fifty three years.

III. Nicolas Leyce≈øter, Son and Heir of Roger, had to Wife Mary Daughter of William Mobberley de Mobberley, and one of the Si≈øters and Co-heirs to Sir Raufe Mobberley; married about 15 Edw. 2. 1322. R. num. 23. and had I≈ø≈øue John Leyce≈øter, Son and Heir; Raufe Leyce≈øter, younger Son, from whom the Leyce≈øters of Toft in this Hundred of Bucklow; and Elizabeth, the ≈øecond Wife of William Manwaring of Over-Pever, the Elder, from whom are de≈øcended the Manwarings of Over-Pever. She was Widow 38 Edw. 3. 1364. and was living 6 Hen. 4. 1404. S. num. 2. I. num. 68. Lib. C. fol. 126. KK. II. Lib. B. pag. 9. h.
Nicolas Leyce≈øter died 1349. 23 Edw. 3. Lib. A. fol. 127. y. For he ≈øurvived his Father very little, if he died not before him.

IV. John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley, Son and Heir of Nicolas and Mary, ≈øerved in the Wars of France under John of Gaunt Duke of Lanca≈øter, 1373. 47 Edw. 3. of who≈øe Pui≈ø≈øant Army our Hi≈øtories do make mention. Wal≈øingham tells us, That when he enter'd France at Calice, triginta & amplius millia Equorum in Comitatu habuerat: But of the≈øe thirty thou≈øand Hor≈øe, very few were brought alive to Burdeaux, being ≈øtarved for want of Victuals; ≈øo that this Voyage proved un≈øucce≈øsful.

It appears by the Account of this John Leyce≈øter, before John Tilly Clerk, and other Auditors of Sir Thomas Felton (who was at that time Judge of Che≈øter) dated at Southampton on the Eve of St. John, 49 Edw. 3. 1375. where he accounted for 266 l. 13 s. 4 d. allowed unto him for the Payment of Jenkyn Mobberley E≈øquire, and other Soldiers, who ≈øerved under the ≈øaid John Leyce≈øter, and al≈øo for his own Pay, that he had allowed for him≈øelf for 210 days Pay, beginning on St. Michael's day, 47 Edw. 3. to the fir≈øt of May then next following, at 3 s. per diem, 31 l. 10 s. 00 d.
And there was al≈øo pardoned unto him, remaining of his Account, the Sum of 38 l. 10 s. 00 d. which I conceive was for a Reward or Gratuity: Whereupon he gave to the Lady Felton a White ambling Pal ‚Ä¢ rey. I. num. 85.

Sir Raufe Mobberley his Uncle ≈øetled on him by Feoffment of Chaplains entru≈øted (as was the manner of tho≈øe Times) all his Lands in Mobberley, with the Advow≈øon of the Church of Mobberley, and other Lands: Dated at Mobberley, 1359. 33 Edw. 3. For Sir Raufe often prote≈øted, having no Lawful I≈ø≈øue but eight Si≈øters expecting to ≈øhare his Inheritance, that all his Lands ≈øhould de≈øcend to his Nephew John Leyce≈øter, and that his E≈øtate ≈øhould not be ≈øhattered and divided; as appears by the Certificate of Sir John Wynkfeld Knight, dated at London, 1360. 35 Edw. 3. A. fol. 128.ff. & fol. 129.hh.

Yet did John Leyce≈øter after relea≈øe all his Right in the≈øe Lands unto John Dumbill of Mobberley and Cicely his Wife, and al≈øo to the Advow≈øon of the Church of Mobberley; Dated at Che≈øter, 1 Rich. 2. 1378. Which Cicely was one of the Si≈øters of Sir Raufe Mobberley afore≈øaid: Lib. A. fol. 129. kk. But ≈øo conditioned and agreed between them, That Dumbill and Cicely ≈øhould ≈øettle 15 Me≈ø≈øuages, 316 Acres of Land, 16 Acres of Wood, 8 Acres of Mo≈ø≈øing, the third part of a Water-mill, and the third part of all the Wa≈øtes not mea≈øured (to be under≈øtood of that Moiety of Mobberley belonging to Sir Raufe Mobberley) to de≈øcend after the death of John Dumbill and Cicely his Wife, unto Raufe Leyce≈øter, younger Brother of the ≈øaid John Leyce≈øter, and to his Heirs for ever: Which was ≈øo ≈øetled accordingly, 2 Rich. 2. 1379. Lib. A. fol. 130.ll.mm. and are at this day, 1666. enjoyed by Leyce≈øter of Toft, as Heirs of the ≈øaid Raufe, about a third part of Mobberley's Moiety of Mobberley.

This John Leyce≈øter al≈øo ≈øold away his Mannor of Hield in A≈øton to William del Hield and Goditha his Wife, in Fee-farm, 1355. 29 Edw. 3. which Manor reverted back again to Leyce≈øter of Tabley; to wit, one Moiety purcha≈øed 1500. and the other Moiety purcha ‚Ä¢ ed again 1601. as ≈øhall be ob≈øerved in their due places: M. num. 13, 14.

This John built the Manor-Hall of Nether-Tabley, within the Pool, in that place where it now ≈øtandeth, about Anno Domini 1380. 4 Rich. 2. before which time it ≈øtood a little higher, out of the Compa≈øs of the Pool, in a certain place adjoining to the Saffron-yards, where there is yet a Trench to be ≈øeen, which environed the Old Hall about with Water; which Old Hall, I conjecture, was the Seat of the Hearts of Nether-Tabley, who≈øe Free-hold was bought out by Roger Leyce≈øter, as I have told you before.
The Colours of the Coat at this day received are,‚Äî Azure, a Fe≈ø≈øe Gules between three Flower-de-Luces Or: The Cre≈øt A Swans Head Couped Proper, with little Drops upon the Neck Gules.
He married Joan Daughter of Robert Touchet of Nether-Whitley, 5 Rich. 2. A. num. 2. and had I≈ø≈øue William Leycester, Son and Heir; Raufe Leyce≈øter, another Son, living 14 Rich. 2. I. num. 74.
6 Novembris, 1387. Conce≈ø≈øa fuit Licentia Johanni Leyce≈øter pro Oratorio ≈øuo apud Tabley per unum Annum. Regi≈øt. Ricardi Scroope apud Lichfield, fol. 123.b. This is Mr. Dugdale's Note.
This John Leyce≈øter died 1398. 22 Rich. 2. about the Age of 58 Years, and ≈øurvived his Father 49 Years.

He was one of the Ju≈øtices of Peace of Bucklow-Hundred in the Reign of Henry the Fifth, and Sealed with a Seal of his Coat of Arms and Cre≈øt, in all points like that of his Fathers, ≈øave onely the Form of the Mantle was a little different: R. num. 10. and many others: Lib. B. pag. 115.

He had two Wives: The fir≈øt was Agnes Dutton Si≈øter to Sir Piers Dutton of Dutton, and Daughter of Edmund Dutton, whom he married Anno Domini 1398. 22 Rich. 2. A. num. 5. By her he had I≈ø≈øue John Leyce≈øter, Lawrence Leyce≈øter, Geffrey Leyce≈øter, living 5 Hen. 6. K. num. 9. and Joan, a Daughter, married to Thomas Son of Thomas Starky de Wrenbury, 1422. 1 Hen. 6. A. num. 12. Al≈øo Cicely married Thomas Ma≈øter≈øon of Ma≈øter≈øon nigh Nantwich.
His ≈øecond Wife was Pillaryne Widow to Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Hale, and Si≈øter to Sir Richard Cradock Knight, whom he married 3 Hen. 6. 1425. A. num. 11. But he had no I≈ø≈øue by her.
William Leyce≈øter died Anno Chri≈øti 1428. 6 Hen. 6. E. num. 3. about the Age of 50 Years, and ≈øurvived his Father 30 Years.

VI. John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, the Elder, Son and Heir of William and Agnes, married Elizabeth Daughter of Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy of Rixton in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire, 10 Hen. 5. 1422. A. num. 9. and had I≈ø≈øue John Leyce≈øter the Younger; Hamon Leyce≈øter, made Par≈øon of Mobberley 1460. Randle Leyce≈øter, admitted into the Ho≈øpital of Holy Trinity and St. Thomas the Martyr in Rome, with all the Privileges thereof, 1449. E. num. 4. Nicolas, another Son; Henry, another Son; William, another Son: A. num. 26. Maud, a Daughter, married to Thomas Son and Heir of Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley, E≈øq 1440. 18 Hen. 6. A. num. 16. Alice, another Daughter, married to Richard Son and Heir of John Legh of High-Legh de We≈øt-Hall E≈øquire, 20 Hen. 6. 1442. Lib. B. pag. 121.
John Leyce≈øter the Elder died 2 Edw. 4. 1462. about the Age of 62 Years; and ≈øurvived his Father 34 Years. Elizabeth his Widow was living 19 Edw. 4. H. num. 20.

VII. John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øq the Younger, Son and Heir of John and Elizabeth, married Margery Daughter of John Legh of High-Legh de We≈øt-Hall E≈øquire, 20 Hen. 6. 1442. Lib. B. pag. 121. and had nine Sons; Thomas Leyce≈øter, Hamon, Bryan, Martin, John, Sir Lawrence a Chaplain, Piers, Roger, and Godfrey; I≈øabell, a Daughter, married John Glegge of Gayton in Wirrall E≈øquire: H. num. 2. A. num. 25.
John Leycester the Younger died Anno Chri≈øti 1496. 12 Hen. 7. Wills, num. 2. about the Age of 73 Years, and ≈øurvived his Father 34 Years.
VIII. Thomas Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of John Leyce≈øter the Younger, had four Wives.

The fir≈øt was Margaret ≈øixth Daughter and Co-heir of Robert Gro≈øvenour of Houlme nigh Nether-Pever E≈øquire, whom he married Anno Chri≈øti 1464. 4 Edw. 4. A. num. 20. and had I≈ø≈øue by her John Leyce≈øter, Son and Heir.

By this Margaret, Thomas Leyce≈øter had the Moiety of Nether-Pever cum Little-Pever,
the third part of Over; Alderley, the third part of Pygreve-wood in the Demain Lands of Allo≈øtock in the County of Che≈øter, and certain Lands in Hope juxta Al≈øtonfield in the County of Stafford, by Partition dated 5 Edw. 4. (1465.) and Margery Gro≈øvenour, fourth Daughter, and Co-heir, dying without I≈ø≈øue 1474. John Leyce≈øter (Son and Heir of Thomas and Margaret) had in Right of his Mother, as Si≈øter and Co-heir to Margery, a fifth part of Allo≈øtock, by Partition dated 14 Edw. 4. 1474. For Margery had all Allo≈øtock to her Share: But Margaret the Mother of John Leyce≈øter was now dead at the time of this later Partition, made Z. num. 28. V. num. 1, 2. She was living 9 Edw. 4. K. num. 6. But ≈øhe was dead 14 Edw. 4.

The ≈øecond Wife of Thomas Leyce≈øter was Margery the Widow of Edmund Legh of Baggilegh E≈øquire, and Daughter of Sir John Savage of Clifton near Halton in Che≈øhire. She was married to Thomas Leyce≈øter 17 Edw. 4. 1477. and by him had I≈ø≈øue Arthur Leyce≈øter, and Geffrey Leyce≈øter, living 1508. Lib. C. fol. 271.d. e. Lib. B. pag. 133. A. num. 25.

The third Wife of Thomas Leycester was Elizabeth the Widow of Peter Dutton of Hatton E≈øquire, and Daughter of Sir Robert Fowle≈øhur≈øt of Crew in Che≈øhire, whom he married 22 Hen. 7. 1506. T. num. 1.
The fourth Wife of Thomas Leyce≈øter was Blanch the Rich. Widow of Oliver Berde≈øley of Warrington, whom he married 1522. 14 Hen. 8. A. num. 29. But he had no I≈ø≈øue by her.
This Thomas Leyce≈øter purcha≈øed again the one Moiety of Hield, 1500. 16 Hen. 7. M. num. 19. which John Son of Nicolas Leyce≈øter ≈øold away, as I have ≈øhewed before,
Thomas Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øquire died about 1526. 18 Hen. 8. about the Age of 82 Years, and ≈øurvived his Father 30 Years.

IX. John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas by Margaret his fir≈øt Wife, married Lucy Daughter of John Ratcliffe of Ratcliffe in Lanca≈øhire, E≈øq 19 Edw. 4. 1479. A. num. 26. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue William Leyce≈øter, who married Anne Daughter of Richard Sneyd of Bradwell in Stafford≈øhire, E≈øquire, 23 Hen. 7. 1508. A num. 25. But William dying without I≈ø≈øue in the Life-time of John his Father, Anne his Widow married Roger Hurle≈øton of Che≈øter E≈øquire, 25 Hen. 8. 1533.

After the death of Lucy, John Leyce≈øter married Alice Daughter of Henry Hen≈øhaw de Milne-hou≈øe nigh Chelford, Gentleman, 15 Hen. 7. 1499. Z. num. 13. and by her had I≈ø≈øue Peter Leyce≈øter, who ≈øucceeded Heir to his Father; Richard, another Son; James Leyce≈øter, third Son by Alice, from whom the Leyce≈øters of Hale-lowe in Bodon-Pari≈øh; Lawrence Leyce≈øter, another Son, living 1577. Al≈øo I≈øabel, a Daughter, married John Ogle of Roby in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire: O. num. 6. Wills, num. 3.

This John Leyce≈øter had al≈øo two Ba≈øtard-≈øons; Nicolas, from whem the Leyce≈øters now of Hield, 1666. and John Leyce≈øter, who died without I≈ø≈øue: Al≈øo three Ba≈øtard-daughters; Elizabeth married Thomas Swynton of Nether-Knotsford, 30 Hen. 8. Joan, another Ba≈øe Daughter; ≈øhe was called Joan Birchenhead, 1543. And Margaret, another Ba≈øe Daughter: O. num. 6. Wills, num. 3. A. num. 34.
John Leyce≈øter of Tabley ≈øold Hulme-Hou≈øe in Over Alderley, now called The Pa≈øtures, unto Nicolas Hob≈øon, 18 Hen. 7. 1502. Z. num. 1.

This John died 35 Hen. 8. 1543. Wills, num. 3. and was buried at Great-Budworth, in our Lady Mary's Chappel there, in the appropriate Burial-place of his Family, in the ≈øeventy ≈øeventh Year of his Age; and ≈øurvived his Father ≈øeventeen Years.

X. Piers Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of John by Alice his ≈øecond Wife, married Alice Daughter of Sir John Holford of Holford juxta Nether-Tabley, 21 Hen. 8. 1529. O. num. 6. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Peter, Son and Heir; Adam, ≈øecond Son; William, third Son, from whom the Leyce≈øters of Legh in Stafford≈øhire: B. num. 28. Alice, a Daughter, married Geffrey Brereton, Son and Heir of Sir Richard Brereton of Tatton nigh Knotsford, Anno Chri≈øti 1551. 5 Edw. 6. A. num. 35. Margaret, another Daughter, married Richard Birkenhed of Manley Recorder of
Che≈øter; Elizabeth, Ellen, and Parnell were never married: Wills, num. 10. E. num. 7, 9.
Piers had al≈øo two Ba≈øtard-≈øons, John and Chri≈øtopher: O. num. 7.

He bought the Lands of Budworth, 2 Edw. 6. and Symcock's Tenement in Mar≈øton, 7 Eliz. 1564. and the Lands in Northwich, 13 Eliz. 1571. B. num. 2. & num. 26. L. num. 10, 11. For the effecting of the≈øe, he ≈øold the Land in Hope juxta Al≈øtonfeld in Stafford≈øhire, which came by Margaret Gro≈øvenour; a very ≈ømall Parcel, and remote.

Piers Leyce≈øter E≈øquire died 8 die Aprilis, 1577. 19 Eliz. and was buried at Great-Budworth the eleventh of April following, in the appropriate Burial-place of his Family, in our Ladies Chappel there, in the ≈øeventieth Year of his Age, and ≈øurvived his Father 34 Years: Wills, num. 10. and Regi≈øter-book of Budworth. O. num. 7.
Alice his Wife was buried al≈øo at Great-Budworth, 1575. 17 Eliz. the thirtieth day of Augu≈øt: So the Regi≈øter.

Piers Leyce≈øter in his Will bequeaths his Body to be buried in his Chappel at Great-Budworth. This Chappel anciently was ≈øtiled Our Lady Mary's Chappel; but of late times Dutton-Tenants have ≈øtiled it Dutton-Chappel, and Leyce≈øter's Tenants ≈øtiled it Leyce≈øter's-Chappel; for both have Right of Burial here: But now of late, to wit, Anno Domini 1670. Leyce≈øter's Part of the ≈øaid Chappel is ≈øeparated, and Railed out from the re≈øt, and is now entire within it ≈øelf, as a di≈øtinct Chappel of it ≈øelf.

‚öú In this Lady Mary's Chappel afore≈øaid was anciently the Image of the Virgin Mary cut in Wood, curiou≈øly trimmed and decked, her Shoes gilded, and Hair fa≈øtned on her Head; ≈øet on a Frame of Wood about two Foot high: But the≈øe Idolatrous Images were removed out of all the Churches of England upon Reformation of Religion, which was fir≈øt done by Command of Hen. 8. Anno Domini 1538. Tom. 3. of my Evidences, fol. 116. b.
Speed's Hi≈øt. pag. 790. But this of Budworth was taken down, hewed in pieces, and burned in the Vicar's Oven, about Anno Domini 1559. by Command from Queen Elizabeth, who purged all the Churches from what remained of tho≈øe Images.

XI. Peter Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire. Son and Heir of Piers and Alice, married Elizabeth Daughter and Sole Heir of Edward Colwich of Colwich in Stafford≈øhire E≈øquire, near Ow≈øley-Bridge, 1 & 2 Phil. & Mar. 1554. A. num. 53. and had I≈ø≈øue Peter, who died without I≈ø≈øue; Alice married Sir George Leyce≈øter of Toft; Elizabeth married George Legh of High-Legh de Ea≈øt-Hall E≈øquire, 1581. And Katharine married John Son and Heir of George Ireland of Hutt in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire, 1583. E. num. 26. Wills, num. 4.
This Peter purcha≈øed Stanley of Hooton's fifth Part of Allo≈øtock, 21 Eliz. V. num. 8.

He died 21 die Julii, 1581. 23 Eliz. and was buried at Great-Budworth, in his appropriate Burial-place in our Ladies Chappel there, the 26 of the ≈øame Month, in the fortieth Year of his Age; and ≈øurvived his Father four Years: O. num. 9. and Regi≈øter of Budworth-Church.
Elizabeth his Widow married George Ireland of Hutt in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire, 1583. 26 Eliz. A. num. 47.
The three Daughters and Heirs carried away the Lands of their Mother: But this Peter entailed all his ancient Lands on his Brother Adam Leyce≈øter, 1581. E. num. 26. N. num. 1.

XII. Adam Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, Brother and Heir-male to Peter, married Dorothy the Widow of Thomas Holford Son and Heir of Chri≈øtopher Holford of Holford E≈øquire, and Daughter of Peter Shakerley of Houlme nigh Nether-Pever E≈øq 9 die Januarii, 1582. and had I≈ø≈øue John, who died young, buried at Great-Budworth, 1586. Piers Leyce≈øter, ≈øecond Son, died an Infant, buried at Nether-Pever the 20 of January, 1587. Peter, born the tenth day of July, and Baptized at Nether-Pever, 14
die Julii, 1588. O. num. 12. ≈øurvived Heir; and Adam, baptized at Nether-Pever, 21 die Octobris, 1590. was buried there the nineteenth day of November next following: So the Regi≈øter of Nether-Pever.

This Adam Leyce≈øter E≈øquire died 7 die Junii, and was buried at Great-Budworth, in the appropriate Burial-place of his Ance≈øtors, the ≈øeventeenth day of June, 33 Eliz. 1591. and ≈øurvived his Brother Peter ten Years: O. num. 12. and Regi≈øter de Budworth.

Dorothy, the Widow of Adam, purcha≈øed the other Moiety of Hield, Anno 1601. M. num. 60. And ≈øo the whole is now reverted. She al≈øo built the Gate-hou≈øe at Nether-Tabley: And ≈øhe was buried at Nether-Pever, 23 die Aprilis, 1630.

XIII. Peter Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Adam and Dorothy, married Elizabeth Daughter of Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever, the Elder, 1611. 9 Jacobi. He was but three Years old when his Father Adam died, and was Ward to his Mother, who had Compounded for his Ward≈øhip with Queen Elizabeth.

He had I≈ø≈øue Margaret, born September 29. 1612. and buried at Great-Budworth 12 die Octobris, 1612. Peter, who Compo≈øed this Book, born 3 die Martii, 1613. Elizabeth, born the fir≈øt day of June, 1615. and buried at Great-Budworth 15 die Julii following: Philip, born 1616. who dying ≈øoon after, the next Son was al≈øo called Philip, born 1618. Collector of Oxford 1641. made Fellow of Brazen-no≈øe-College 1643. and died unmarried 1653. Thomas Leyce≈øter, born 26 die Julii, 1620. died al≈øo unmarried 27 die Augu≈øti, 1652. Adam Leyce≈øter, younge≈øt Son, born 21 die Octobris, 1625. now Captain of a Foot-Company in Ireland, 1666. and living in Limrick. This Adam married Mary Thaddius, the Widow of one Lieutenant Pope in Ireland, Anno Domini 1667. She was Daughter to one Thaddius late of Northdown in Kent, of a Welch Extraction.

Elizabeth, the Wife of this Peter Leyce≈øter the Father, died at Nether-Tabley on Satturday the thirteenth day of November, 1641. and was buried at Over-Pever, as ≈øhe had oft in her Life-time de≈øired. She was born the tenth day of May, 1587. ≈øo that ≈øhe lived 54 Years and 6 Months.

Peter her Husband died on Tue≈øday the ≈øeventh day of March, 1647. aged 59 Years and 8 Months, and was buried at Great-Budworth on the Satturday following, in the appropriate Burial-place of his Ance≈øtors in our Ladies Chappel there, on the North-≈øide of the ≈øaid Church; and ≈øurvived his Father 56 Years.

XIV. Sir Peter Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley Baronet, Son and Heir of Peter and Elizabeth, married Elizabeth the third and younge≈øt Daughter of Gilbert late Lord Gerard of Gerards-Bromley in Stafford≈øhire, by Dame Elinour his Lady, Daughter and ≈øole Heir of Thomas Dutton late of Dutton in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire. This Peter and Elizabeth This Elizabeth was Baptiz'd 23 Maii 1620 as by the Regi≈øter of A≈øhley-Church in Stafford≈øhire appeareth: Lib. B. pag. 156. were married at Dutton the ≈øixth day of November, 1642. and had I≈ø≈øue Robert Leyce≈øter, elde≈øt Son, born at Che≈øter on Monday the eleventh day of September, 1643. Byron Leyce≈øter, ≈øecond Son, born al≈øo at Che≈øter on Tue≈øday the twenty ≈øixth day of November, 1644. He died the ≈øeventeenth day of May next following, and was buried at Trinity-Church in Che≈øter, where he was al≈øo Chri≈øtned: Thomas Leyce≈øter, third Son, born at Nether-Tabley on Thur≈øday-Morning the eighth day of January, 1651. He died the fifth day of March, being Thur≈øday, 1667. at Nether-Tabley, and was buried at Great-Budworth, in the ≈øeventeenth Year of his Age; Magnae ≈øpei Juvenis: Elinour, elde≈øt Daughter, born at Nether-Tabley on Palm-Sunday, 22 die Martii, 1645. married Raufe Leyce≈øter elde≈øt Son of George Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øquire, 29 die Augu≈øti, 1665. and hath ≈øeveral I≈ø≈øue: Elizabeth, ≈øecond Daughter, born at Nether-Tabley on Wedne≈øday the ≈øixteenth day of June, 1647. married Samuel Birch younger Son of John Birch of Whitborn in Hereford≈øhire, 1666. She mi≈øcarried of a Female-Child in November, 1667. and ≈øoon after died of the Small-Pox, on Saturday the la≈øt of November, at Whitborn afore≈øaid, Anno Domini 1667. and was buried at Whitborn-Church: Byron Leyce≈øter, third Daughter, born at Nether-Tabley on Saturday the ≈øixth day of October, 1655. and is yet living, 1669.
Sir Peter Leyce≈øter and Elizabeth his Lady are both yet living, 1669. He was Created Baronet the tenth day of Augu≈øt, 1660. 12 Car. 2.

XV. Robert Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, elde≈øt Son of Sir Peter and Elizabeth, married Meriel Daughter and Heir of Francis Wat≈øon late of Church-A≈øton nigh Newport in Shrop≈øhire, E≈øquire, 6 die Junii, 1667. and hath I≈ø≈øue Robert, a Son, born at Marcham in Berk≈øhire on Friday the ≈øixteenth day of April, Anno Domini 1669.

div.head: Over-Tabley.
div.p: THe Town≈øhip of Over-Tabley was held by William Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton, in the Time of William the Conqueror: We read in Doom≈øday-book thus:‚Äî I≈ødem Willielmus tenet Stabelei: Lewinus tenuit & liber Homo fuit: ibi tertia pars unius Hidae Geldabilis Terra e≈øt una Caruca: Wa≈øta fuit, & est: Silva ibi dimidia Leuva longa, & XL Perticis lata: valuit X ≈øolidos.

I≈ødem Willielmus tenet in ip≈øa Villa unam Bovatam Terrae, & tertiam partem unius Hidae Geldabilem: Segrid & Ul≈øi tenuerunt pro duobus Maneriis, & liberi fuerunt: Terra e≈øt una Caruca: Wa≈øta fuit, & e≈øt: Tempore Regis Edwardi valebat ≈øeptem ≈øolidos.
But not long after, certain it is that this Town≈øhip was of three di≈øtinct Fees.

One third Part of Over-Tabley Roger de Manwaring gave to the Mona≈øtery of Saint Werburge in Che≈øter, in the Reign of Henry the Second: Lib. B. in principio. This third Part came afterwards to William de Tabley This William de Tabley writ him≈øelf Dominus de Tabley, that is, de Over-Tabley; & ≈øometimes Dominus de Knot≈øford: tempore Edw. 1., who gave the ≈øame to Sir John Grey Son of Sir Reginald Grey; and Sir John granted it to Roger Leyce≈øter Lord of Nether-Tabley, Anno Domini 1296. F. num. 1. Which in all the Offices of Leyce≈øter of Tabley is found to be held of the Abby of St. Werburge: And Leyce≈øter of Tabley is now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this third Part at this day, 1666.

One other third Part was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by Adam de Tabley in the Reign of Edward the Third, Sir William Boydell being Chief Lord thereof: For William Son of John Boydell of Dodle≈øton relea≈øeth unto Adam de Tabley all Services due for his third Part of Over-Tabley, for one Penny onely, to be paid at the Nativity of St. John Bapti≈øt yearly, for all Service: Dated at Dodle≈øton, 17 Edw. 3. 1342. F. num. 3. This Adam de Tabley I conceive was originally a Ma≈ø≈øy; for he Sealed with Ma≈ø≈øy's Coat of Arms. This third Part came afterwards to Thomas Daniell, younger Son of Thomas Daniell of Bradley in Appleton, the Elder, by Joan Norreys a ≈øecond Wife, in Marriage with Katharine Daughter and Heir of William Son of Adam de Tabley, 27 Edw. 3. 1353. Lib. C. fol. 241. l. for which Marriage Thomas Daniell the Father gave to Adam de Tabley 46 l. 13 s. 4 d. By Katharine came al≈øo the Moiety of Bexton to Thomas Daniell the Son, her Husband, who was afterwards Sir Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley, 6 Rich. 2. 1382. who≈øe Heirs are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this third Part at this pre≈øent, 1666.

One other third part remaining was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed anciently by another Family of the Tableys, called The Hall of the Wood in Over-Tabley; until Matthew de Tabley was Attainted of Felony, 22 Edw. 4. 1483. who≈øe Lands, by the Office taken 1 Hen. 7. were found to be held of the Honour of Halton, and ≈øo were ≈øeized into the King's Hands. And I find John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øq excepting again≈øt that Office of 1 Hen. 7. and complaining to the Judges and Chamberlain of Chester, and alledging, That the≈øe Lands were held of him by Homage and Fealty, and Twelve PenceThis 12 d. Rent is at this day paid to Leyce≈øter, by Th Warburton of Tabley-Hill; which Tenement is Parcel of the Hall of Wood lands. yearly Rent; and praying that he may be re≈øtored to the≈øe Lands, as Chief Lord of the Fee: C. num. 31. But he had too Potent a Per≈øon to deal with. And King Henry the Seventh granted the≈øe Lands to Sir William Stanley of Holt-Ca≈øtle, Lord Chamberlain: But he being beheaded for Trea≈øon, 1495. the≈øe Lands E≈øcheated again to the King: And Henry the Eighth Lea≈øed them to Randle Brereton for his Life, 2 Hen. 8. And after, Roger Brereton his Son had them for his Life. Afterwards the≈øe Lands continuing in the King's Hands, Robert Chornock and Roger Chornock of London purcha≈øed the ≈øame, and ≈øold them to Piers Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øquire, for 240 l.
whereof one Moiety was paid in Hand, and the other he gave Bond for: But Peter Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire purcha≈øing the≈øe Lands at 9 l. per Annum in the King's Books, the Chornocks purcha≈øed them after the Rate of 18 d. in the King's Books, and cheated the ≈øaid Piers Leyce≈øter by a fraudulent Conveyance, ≈øo that he could not enjoy the≈øe Lands; It was Decreed in the Court of Reque≈øts, 4 Maii, 1 Eliz. 1559. That the Chornocks ≈øhould re≈øtore the Money which they had received, and deliver up the Bond Obligatory to be Cancelled: And ≈øo Daniell had the Lands, which his Po≈øterity now enjoyeth, 1666. C. num. 13.

list.head: Charterers in Over-Tabley, 1666.
list.item: 1. Edward Hewet of Mobberley hath one Tenement in Over-Tabley, now in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Tenant John Kell; which is within Mr. Daniell's Part.

2. There is al≈øo one other in Leycester's third Part, to wit, the Tenement in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion late of Richard Duncalfe of Tabley-Hill, whereunto formerly Coithur≈øt-Meadows (now part of Mr. Daniell's Demain) did belong. This payeth 12 d. of Chief-rent yearly to Leyce≈øter, now paid by William Legh of Tabley-Hill. This Free-hold was Purcha≈øed by George le Criour from Thomas Monkys, 5 Ed. 4. Afterwards this Land was purcha≈øed by John Duncalfe of Mere, 30 Hen. 8. After it came to Peter Hul≈øe of Over-Tabley: Hul≈øe ≈øells it to Whitmore of Sudlow, 1604. Whitmore ≈øold it to Peter Daniell E≈øquire, 1611.

div.p: In this Town≈øhip there is an Ancient Chappel, called Over-Tabley-Chappel, or more generally known by the name of The Chappel in the Street; for it is ≈øituate in the High-≈øtreet: An old pitiful Structure, ill ≈øeated, and now in decay. This Chappel of Ea≈øe, being within the Pari≈øh of Ro≈øthorn, was built about the Reign of Henry the Sixth, by the Ance≈øtors of Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley and Daniell of Over-Tabley, for the Ea≈øe and Convenience of the≈øe two Families, and of all their Tenants in Over-Tabley and Nether-Tabley: Probably after the Match of Thomas Daniell and Maud Leyce≈øter, which was in Anno Dimini 1440. 18 Hen. 6. It ≈øeems to be erected not long after, for Convenience of both Families, and placed in the middle-way between the two Hou≈øes; one half of the ≈øaid Chappel belonging to Leyce≈øter and his Tenants, and the other half to Daniell and his Tenants; and ≈øo hath been enjoyed ever ≈øince accordingly.

Before this Chappel was erected here in Over-Tabley, there was anciently a Chappel ≈øituate in Nether-Tabley, within the Pari≈øh of Great-Budworth, in a certain Field called at this day The Chappel-Field, Parcel of the Demain-Land of Nether-Tabley; where, within our Memory, Servants in Ploughing have di≈øcovered Great Stones, which were the Foundation-Stones of that Chappel, ≈øeated in the very uppermo≈øt Corner of the Great-Rye-Field-Hedge adjoining to the Chappel-Field: But this Chappel, I conceive, was neglected, or taken down, upon the erecting of the other in Over-Tabley, and was much better Seated.

div.head: Now followeth the De≈øcent of the Daniels of Over-Tabley.
div.p: I. William Danyers ≈øenior Purcha≈øed Lands in Daresbery from Henry le Norreys, Anno Domini 1291. 19 Edw. 1. Lib. C. fol. 184.d. and had to Wife Agnes de Legh, Daughter of Thomas de Legh of High-Legh of the We≈øt-Hall, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Margery, married to Henry Hor≈øale of Limme: Lib. C. fol. 233.a. & 243.b. c. Agnes, another Daughter, married Alexander, Son of Richard, Son of Alexander de Waleton nigh Daresbury, 30 Edw. 1. Lib. B. pag. 204. num. 12. He had al≈øo two Sons, Thomas Daniers of Bradley in Appleton, elde≈øt Son; and William Daniers of Daresbery junior, ≈øecond Son; and (if I mi≈øtake not) John, a third Son: Lib. C. fol. 243.a. unle≈øs that John Son of William Daniers, 23 Edw. 3. be meant of William Daniers junior.

William Daniers junior, ≈øecond Son, had his Father's Land in Daresbery, and had a
Wife called Agnes, and had I≈ø≈øue John Danyers, Son and Heir: Lib. C. fol. 185. m. acd three Daughters, Cicely, Agnes, and Magot; and another Son, called Henry; all living at the time of their Father's death, 1306. who was buried at Limme: Lib. C. fol. 187. v. Cicely married Robert Stathum of Stathum in Limme, living 20 Edw. 3. I conceive William Danyers junior was he who died 1306.

Sir John Danyers of Daresbery, Son and Heir of William Danyers junior, had I≈ø≈øue William Son and Heir, who married Clemence Daughter and Heir of Alan de Norreys, 1344. by whom he had the Manor of Daresbery, and Royalty of Over-Walton in Che≈øhire, and the Lands of Sutton, Eccle≈øton, & Raynull in Lanca≈øhire: Lib. C. fol. 185. e.h.m. from whom the Daniells of Daresbery in Che≈øhire are de≈øcended; a Family continuing at this day, 1666.
I find Sir John Danyers of Daresbery ≈øtiled Knight, 1344. 18 Edw. 3.

II. Thomas Danyers of Bradley, ≈øenior, 17 Edw. 2. Son and Heir of William Danyers ≈øenior, had Land in Limme by the Grant of William Danyers his Father: Lib. C. fol. 186.q. He Purcha≈øed Bradley from Peter Dutton Lord of Warburton, 1301. Lib. C. fol. 242.z. He married Margaret Daughter of Adam de Tabley: Lib. C. fol. 221.g. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Danyers junior, elde≈øt Son: Lib. C. fol. 186.q. Sir John Danyers of Gropenhale, ≈øecond Son; Augu≈øtine, who had Lands in Sworton in High-Legh, 11 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 275. num. 30. Alice, a Daughter, married Matthew Son of William Mere of Mere nigh Over-Tabley, 13 Edw. 2. 1319. Lib. C. fol. 208.s. Margaret, another Daughter, married John Son of Vivian de Derewall≈øhaw, id e≈øt, Thelwall≈øhaw, 1335. Lib. C. fol. 245.a. Joan, another Daughter: Al≈øo three Ba≈øtard-≈øons, William, Roger, and Robert: Lib. C. fol. 233. K. (1349.)

Thomas Danyers ≈øenior had to his ≈øecond Wife Joan Norreys, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Danyers, afterwards Sir Thomas Danyers of Over-Tabley: Lib. C. fol. 244. E. Henry, another Son, to whom his Father gave the Marriage of the Heir of William Clerke of Over-Tabley, 28 Edw. 3. Ibid. fol. 235. P. And Richard, another Son, living 6 Rich. 2. Ibid. fol. 241.m.
Thomas Danyers made his Will, 28 Edw. 3. 1354. and was buried at Limme. Joan Norreys his Widow maried after William Bo≈øtock of Bo≈øtock: Lib. C. fol. 244. M. 9.
This Thomas Danyers was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 25 & 27 Edw. 3.

III. Sir Thomas Danyers of Bradley Knight, Son and Heir of Thomas Danyers ≈øenior, married I≈øabel Daughter and Heir of William Baggiley by Clemence his Wife, Daughter and Co-heir to Sir Roger Chedle, alias Sir Roger Dutton of Chedle in Che≈øhire; which William was Son of Rafe Baggiley: Lib. C. fol. 245.b. & 150.l.

This Thomas Danyers died before his Father, to wit, 26 Edw. 3. leaving onely one Daughter and Heir, called Margaret, who had three Husbands. She carried away all her Mothers Lands, and had Clifton and other Lands in Chedle; of whom you may ≈øee more in Clifton: But his own Lands were ≈øetled on the Heirs-Males of the Danyers.

IV. Sir John Danyers of Gropenhale in Right of his Wife, next Heir-Male to Sir Thomas his elder Brother, had two Wives. The fir≈øt was Joan Daughter of Sir William Boydell, and Si≈øter and Co-heir to William Boydell of Dodle≈øton in Che≈øhire; and had I≈ø≈øue Margaret, a Daughter, living 28 Edw. 3. whom I conceive was ≈øhe that was Affianced young to Sir Robert Gro≈øvenour of Houlm in Allo≈øtock; but ≈øhe lived not to enjoy him, or have any I≈ø≈øue: Lib. C. fol. 235. P. & 126.II.KK. Nicolaa, another Daughter, Heir to the Lands of her Mother, married _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Margaret, Daughter and Heir, the Wife of Alan de Rixton in Lanca≈øhire, by Hollin-Ferry; which Margaret died without I≈ø≈øue 6 Rich. 2. Lib. C. fol. 290.a.c.
The ≈øecond Wife of Sir John was Alice Daughter of _____ but had no I≈ø≈øue by her.
This Sir John u≈øually Sealed with his Coat and Cre≈øt, to wit, A Pale Fu≈øile; on a Helmet, a Unicorns Head Coupcd. The Colours at this day received are, Argent, a Pale Fu≈øile Sable.

Sir John Danyers died 47 Edw. 3. and Alice his Widow afterwards married Sir Edward Bene≈øtede, living 14 Rich. 2. Lib. C. fol. 242.s.t.w.x. It ≈øeems Sir John had a Son called Robert, 43 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 233.h. but he died without I≈ø≈øue.

After the death of Sir John, Thomas Danyers (Son of Thomas Danyers of Bradley ≈øenior, by Joan Norreys his later Wife) ≈øucceeded as next Heir-male. He was Half-brother to Sir John, and was afterwards Sir Thomas Danyers of Over-Tabley. He gave 20 s. Annuity for his Life unto Hugh Hul≈øe of Picmere, to be on Coun≈øel with him, 48 Edw. 3. Lib. 3. fol. 243.f. Who≈øe De≈øcent followeth.

list.item:
Roger of Over-Tabley.
Adam de Tabley, Son of Roger, married Beatrix Daughter of _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Adam; Hugh de Tabley, This Hugh died 1346. Lib. C. fol. 241.g. who married Margery Daughter of Hugh de Picmere: Lib. B. pag. 53. num. 18. but left no I≈ø≈øue: William, another Son: Thomas, a Chaplain: Lib. C. fol. 241.g. l. Al≈øo Margaret, a Daughter, Wife of Thomas Daniers of Bradley ≈øenior: Lib. C. fol. 221.f.g.
Adam de Tabley, Son of Adam, Lord of the third Part of Over-Tabley, and of the Moiety of Bexton, living 35 Edw. 3. married Katharine
_____ and had I≈ø≈øue William; and Alice the Wife of William, Son of Robert, Son of William de Buckley, 18 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 229.q.
William de Tabley, Son and Heir of Adam, had to Wife Mary
_____ and had I≈ø≈øue Katharine, Daughter and Heir, married to Thomas Danyers, afterwards Sir Thomas Danyers of Over-Tabley: Lib. C. fol. 241.l.

div.p: ‚öú Adam de Tabley Sealed with Ma≈ø≈øy's Coat of Arms, whereby he ≈øeems to be Originally a Ma≈ø≈øy.

The Sir-name of this Family was anciently written Danyers; and I have ≈øeen it written De Anyers under Edward the Second: but in later Ages it was con≈øtantly written Daniell, and ≈øo at this day they are u≈øually called, which I rather chu≈øe to follow.

He married Katharine Daughter and Heir of William Son of Adam de Over-Tabley, 27 Edw. 3. 1353. Lib. C. fol. 233.l. & 241.l. for which Marriage Thomas Daniell his Father gave to Adam de Tabley, Grand-father of the ≈øaid Katharine, 46 l. 13 s. 4 d. Whereupon the third part of Over-Tabley was ≈øetled on this Thomas Daniell the Son, and Katharine his Wife, to de≈øcend after the decea≈øe of the ≈øaid Adam de Tabley.
He had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Daniell; John Daniell, living 15 Hen. 6. Lib. C. fol. 242.r. And Jonet, a Daughter, married John Warwick of Upton in VVirral, the younger, 15 Rich. 2. 1391. Lib. C. fol. 240.c.
Sir Thomas Daniel died 6 Rich. 2. 1383. paulo ante Fe≈øtum* Sancti Edmundi Archiepi≈øcopi,: Lib. C. fol. 241.m. Katharine ≈øurvived, and was living 3 Hen. 5. 1416. Lib. C. fol. 217.a.

II. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley, Son and Heir of Sir Thomas, married Elizabeth Widow of Thomas Boydell of Gropenhale junior, and Daughter of Sir Richard A≈øton of A≈øton nigh Frod≈øham-Bridge: Lib. C. fol. 281.f. & 283.g. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, John, Richard, Henry, Roger, and Lawrence: So the Herald's Book: Lib. C. fol. 241.o.
This Thomas Daniel died 10 Hen. 6. 1431. Elizabeth died 11 Hen. 4.

III. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, ≈øtiled The Elder, 18 Hen. 6. Son and Heir of Thomas, married I≈øabel Daughter of John Rixton, 1 Hen. 5. 1413. by whom he had Lands in Warrington; and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Son and Heir; John Daniell, another Son, was Soldier under Captain Piers Daniell, Son of John Daniell of Daresbery, 21 Hen. 6. Lib. C. fol. 236.q.r. & fol. 244.s. And Elizabeth Wife of John Son of Henry Legh, 26 Hen. 6.

IV. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas Daniell the Elder, married Maud Daughter of John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley, the Elder, E≈øquire, 11 Hen. 6. 1440. Lib. C. fol. 236.s. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, Son and Heir; William Daniell, living 12 Edw. 4. Katharine married Roger Millington of Millington in Ro≈øthorn-Pari≈øh, Gentleman: She was Widow 1487. 3 Hen. 7. And Parnel married Robert Lathom of Congleton, 4 Hen. 7. 1489. And Cicely, another Daughter: Lib. C. fol. 236.w.z. & 243.g.

‚öú In the Herald's Book of Che≈øter I find, That this Thomas Daniell and Maud had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, William, John, and Cicely; and that Thomas the Son married Katharine de Middleton (or Milneton), and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, William, Katharine, Parnel, and Cicely, as is above-≈øhewed. Sed quaere.

V. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas, married Blanch Daughter of Piers Warburton of Arley E≈øquire, 1472. 13 Edw. 4. Lib. C. fol. 236.x. and had I≈ø≈øue Peter Daniell, Son and Heir; Thomas, ≈øecond Son; Richard, third Son; and three Daughters, Ellen, Margery, and Margaret, living 15 Hen. 7. Lib. C. fol. 237.a. & 239.q.

This Thomas Daniell died 10 Hen. 7. 1494. Buried in the North-Chappel, called Our Ladies Chappel, in the Pari≈øh-Church of Ro≈øthorn. He left by his Will 20 s. per Annum to Cicely his Whore during her Life, in tho≈øe very Words: Lib. C. fol. 237.a.
Blanch his Wife died on St. James's-day, 1508. 24 Hen. 7. Lib. C. fol. 239.r.

This Thomas took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Cherry-tree-Hur≈øt in Limme, as next Heir, 1493. For then died Thomas Daniell of Limme without I≈ø≈øue, the la≈øt Heir of that Family of Limme: But the Matter was not fully ≈øetled, till the Award of William Hill Prebend of Lichfield, 23 Hen. 8. when William Daniell of Longdon in Stafford≈øhire (who claimed as next Heir to Daniell of Limme, as Son of William, Brother of John Daniell, late of Cherry-tree-Hur≈øt in Limme) by vertue of that Award pa≈ø≈øed all his Right in tho≈øe Lands to Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley, Grand-≈øon of this Thomas Daniell afore≈øaid.

VI. Piers Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas and Blanch, married Julian Daughter of Sir Peter Newton, Secretary to the Prince, who had the Ward≈øhip of the ≈øaid Piers, 15 Hen. 7. 1499. Lib. C. fol. 239.q. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, Son and Heir; Robert Daniell of Bexton, ≈øecond Son; Peter, third Son, living 1522. Anne, elde≈øt Daughter, married fir≈øt to Whitmore, after to William Hul≈øe; Elizabeth, ≈øecond Daughter, married fir≈øt to William Owen, after to Anthony Shepherd; Parnel married John Bre≈ø≈øy of Teerton in Che≈øhire: Lib. C. fol. 240. x. 242. y. & 244.n.

Piers Daniell had al≈øo three Ba≈øtard-daughters, Margery Daniell, I≈øabel Daniell, and Anne Daniell; and three Ba≈øtard-≈øons, John Daniell, Raufe Daniell, and Humphrey Daniell, by Anne Brachegirdle; all living 1522. Lib. C. fol. 242.y.
This Piers Daniell E≈øquire died 1522. 14 Hen. 8. at the Age of 38 Years. Julian his Wife died 34 Hen. 8. 1542. Lib. C. fol. 239.s.t.

VII. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Piers and Julian, married Margaret Daughter of William Wilbraham of Woodhey in Che≈øhire E≈øq 1521. 13 Hen. 8. Lib. C. fol. 237. e. and had I≈ø≈øue Peter Daniell, Son and Heir; Thomas Daniell, ≈øecond Son; Sir William Daniell, Judge of the Common Pleas, third Son; Richard Daniell, fourth Son, died 1605. Ellen married John Ma≈ø≈øy of Codington in Che≈øhire, 1553. Margaret married Chri≈øtofer Holford of I≈øcoit in Flint≈øhire, younger Son of Sir John Holford of Holford nigh Tabley, 2 & 3 Phil. & Mar. 1555. After ≈øhe married James Barker of Hamond near Shrewsbury: Lib. C. fol. 238.I. & 243.h.k.

This Thomas Daniell died 5 Edw. 6. 2 die Junii, 1551. aged 48 Years: Lib. C. fol. 238.I. Margaret his Wife ≈øurvived. He Purcha≈øed the Lands in Picmere, which his Po≈øterity now holdeth, 1666. from William Sneyd, 36 Hen. 8. called Wiche's Lands; which came to the Crown by the Attainder of Sir William Stanley, Lord Chamberlain to Henry the Seventh, as I have before declared in Over-Tabley: Lib. C. fol. 244.o.

VIII. Peter Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas and Margaret, married Alice Daughter of George Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy E≈øquire, 4 Edw. 6. 1550. and had I≈ø≈øue onely a Daughter and Heir called Dorothy, married to William Ma≈ø≈øy, Son and Heir of Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Rixton in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire, 14 Eliz. 1571. Lib. C. fol. 243. I. l.

This Peter Purcha≈øed the Hall of Woodlands in Over-Tabley, 3 & 4 Phil. & Mar. 1556. which E≈øcheated to the Crown upon the Attainder of Matthew de Tabley, 22 Edw. 4. as I have ≈øhewn before in Over-Tabley.
This Peter Daniell died 9 die Novembris, 4 & 5 Phil. & Mar. 1557. at the Age of 28 Years within a Month, leaving Thomas his Brother and Heir to ≈øucceed him: Lib. C. fol. 238.k.

IX. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Brother and Heir-male to the la≈øt Peter, married Alice Daughter of Fouk Dutton of the City of Che≈øter, and had I≈ø≈øue Peter, Son and Heir; Thomas, ≈øecond Son; Richard, third Son; William, fourth Son, died 20 die Maii, 33 Eliz. 1591. John, fifth Son; and Margaret, a Daughter, living 1575. 17 Eliz. Lib. C. fol. 240.x.
This Thomas Daniell E≈øquire died 1575. 17 Eliz. aged 41 Years. Alice ≈øurvived, and was living 1590. Lib. C. fol. 239.m. & 238.l.

X. Peter Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Thomas and Alice, married Anne Daughter of Henry Manwaring of Carincham in Che≈øhire E≈øquire, 1574. and had I≈ø≈øue Peter, Son and Heir, ≈øix Years old when his Father died; Richard Daniell, ≈øecond Son, died without I≈ø≈øue; Frances married Edward Littleton, younger Son of Littleton of Pillaton in Stafford≈øhire, near Pancridge; Anne, ≈øecond Daughter, died without I≈ø≈øue; Mary, third Daughter, married John Woodnot of Shenton in Che≈øhire; after to John King of Salmondley in Lincoln≈øhire; Jane, fourth Daughter, died without I≈ø≈øue.

This Peter died 3 die Augu≈øti, 1590. 32 Eliz. aged 29 Years. Anne his Widow afterwards married Thomas A≈øhold Par≈øon of Swetenham in Che≈øhire: And ≈øhe died 29 Julii, 1633. and had the Ward≈øhip of her Son: Lib. C. fol. 239.n.o.

XI. Peter Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Peter and Anne, married Chri≈øtian Daughter of Richard Gro≈øvenour of Eaton-boat in Che≈øhire E≈øquire, and had I≈ø≈øue Peter, elde≈øt Son; Henry, ≈øecond Son, married Anne Daughter of Sir John Dorell of We≈øtwoody in Berk≈øhire, but had no I≈ø≈øue; John Daniell, third Son, was an Apprentice
in London, and married, but died al≈øo without I≈ø≈øue; William, fourth Son, married Dorothy Forth of Wiggan in Lanca≈øhire; Thomas, fifth Son, ≈ølain at the Battel of Brainford near London, 1642. Margaret, elde≈øt Daughter, married Richard Green of Conglyton in Che≈øhire, Gentleman; Chri≈øtian, ≈øecond Daughter, married George Davenport of Calvelcy E≈øquire; Mary, third Daughter, married one Colonel Finch, 1651. an Officer for the Parliament-Party again≈øt the King, and are both now living in Ireland, 1666. Elizabeth, fourth Daughter, died unmarried; Anne, the younge≈øt Daughter, married Robert Sanford of Sanford in Shrop≈øhire E≈øquire, 1648.

This Peter Daniell was one of the Knights of this County for the Parliament, 1625. and died the eighteenth day of April, 1652. aged 68 Years, and was buried at Great-Budworth. Chri≈øtian his Wife ≈øurvived, and died 1663.

XII. Peter Daniell of Over-Tabley, the younger, E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Peter and Chri≈øtian, married Sarah Daughter of Richard Wilcocks of London, and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, Son and Heir; Sarah died in her Infancy; and Margaret, another Daughter.

This Peter the Son died at Oxford, of a Shot received at the Siege of Gloce≈øter, 1643. in the life-time of his Father, being at that time a Captain of a Foot-Company in the Regiment of John Earl Rivers, rai≈øed on the King's Part.
Sarah his Widow afterwards married Robert Hyde of Nantwich, one of the Seque≈øtrators of Che≈øhire for the Parliament, 1651. but ≈øhe had no I≈ø≈øue by him.

XIII. Thomas Daniell of Over-Tabley E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Peter and Sarah, married Alice Daughter of William Smith, alias Nevill, ≈øecond Brother of Henry Nevill of Holt in Leyce≈øter≈øhire; and hath I≈ø≈øue Samuel, Thomas, Nevill, Peter, and Sarah, all living 1666. William, the fourth Son, died young.

div.head: Tatton.
div.p: IN the Reign of William the Conqueror, William Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton held one half of Tatton, which one Erchbrand held formerly.
And Ranulfus (the ≈øuppo≈øed Ance≈øtor of the Manwarings) held the other half, which one Leuvinus held before: So the Record of Doom≈øday-book informs us.

About one hundred Years afterwards, I find Alanus de Matton po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Manor of Tatton: And Alanus Filius Alani de Tatton ≈øtiled him≈øelf in his Chartes, Dominus de Tatton; who a≈ø≈øumed the Sir-name of Tatton from this Place of their Re≈øidency here, which their Po≈øterity retained: For Sir-names in tho≈øe elder Ages were not taken up generally; but Men were denominated u≈øually of the Places where they lived; and that by Continuance at la≈øt became a Sir-name.

VVilliam, Son of VVilliam, Son of Quenild de Tatton, granted a great part of Tatton unto Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy and I≈øabel his Wife, about the Year of Chri≈øt 1286. which Peter Hackham, then Prior of the Ho≈øpital of St. John of Jeru≈øalem in England, confirmed.

Placita ante Fe≈øtum Sancti Dun≈øtani, 16 Edw. 2. apud Ce≈øtriam; upon a Di≈øtre≈øs by Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy, Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, on the Goods of Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, taken in Tatton afore≈øaid, Hamon pleads, That Nicolas de Audley held the Manor of Tatton of him the ≈øaid Hamon by Knights Service, and by working at his Ca≈øtle of Dunham, and by the Service of Sixty Shillings yearly Rent: Of which Services the ≈øaid Hamon was ≈øei≈øed by the Hands of the ≈øaid Nicolas de Audley: Which Three Pound yearly Rent, Sir James Audley of Heelegh-Ca≈øtle in Stafford≈øhire relea≈øed afterwards to Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, 1 Rich. 2. 1377. for which Sir John gave him two Me≈ø≈øuages in VVrenbury in Che≈øhire.

Al≈øo it appears that Nicolas de Alditheley (or Audley) granted to Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, and I≈øabel his Wife, all his Lands in Tatton and Owlarton: Te≈øtibus Reginaldo de Grey Ju≈øticiario Ce≈øtriae, Johanne Filio ≈øuo, Radulfo de Vernon, Hamone de Ma≈ø≈øy, VVillielmo
de Venables Militibus, Roberto le Gro≈øvenour Vicecomite Ge≈øter≈øhiriae,‚Äî&c. This was about 1286. The Original of which Deed is now among the Evidences of the Earl of Bridgewater, 1667.

So that it ≈øhould ≈øeem to me, that in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt, one Moiety of Tatton was held of the Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, and the other Moiety of the Prior of St. John of Hieru≈øalem. That of the Fee of John of Hieru≈øalem, probably was the Moiety that in the Conqueror's Time belonged to the Barony of Halton.

It is manife≈øt by Deed, That Alan Son of Alan de Tatton Relea≈øed to Helen Manwaring and her Heirs, and to Robert Manwaring and his Heirs, ≈øequelam Halmoti mei de Tatton. under Henry the Third: Lib. C. fol. 135. num. 34.

So that Alan de Tatton ≈øeems to have the Royalty of all Tatton; and he grants the Land called Bruchel, in Tatton, unto William Son of William Ma≈ø≈øy: Ibid. num. 36. But whether he had any more than a Moiety of the Town, I cannot affirm; in regard we ≈øee above, William Son of William Son of Quenild of Tatton had a good part.

How, and when,‚öú this Manor of Tatton was given to be held of the Priory of St. John's of Hieru≈øalem; or whether onely a Moiety thereof, or the whole Town≈øhip be ≈øo held, I find not yet to affirm po≈øitively. Certain it is, that Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of all or mo≈øt part of Tatton, in the Reign of King Edward the Fir≈øt, by Purcha≈øes of ≈øeveral Parcels; who≈øe Heirs are now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the whole Manor, 1667. which the following Pedegree will more clearly manife≈øt.

list.head: Charterers in Tatton, 1662.
list.item: 1. John Brown of Tatton: His Free-hold Land in Tatton was lately bought from John Bentley of The Hole in Mere.

2. Edward Hewet of Mobberley hath Free-hold Lands in Tatton: But now (1667.) Richard Parker hath this Land, in Right of Jane his Wife, Daughter of the ≈øaid Edward Hewet; to his other Daughters he gave Portions.
3. Edward Allen of Ro≈øthorn hath al≈øo certain Free-hold Land in Tatton.

div.head: The De≈øcent of the Ma≈ø≈øies of Tatton.
div.p: I. William Ma≈ø≈øy, younger Brother to Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy Baron of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.
II. William Ma≈ø≈øy, Son of William, to whom Alan

He married Margery Domina de Ro≈øthorn: I gue≈øs ≈øhe may be Daughter to Robert de Manwaring, and Si≈øter and Heir to Hugh Manwaring Lord of Ro≈øthorn, or Lord of one Moiety at lea≈øt; and Lord of the Moiety of Nor≈øhagh in Tatton: Lib. C. fol. 105. num. 40, 41.

He was ≈øtiled Sir William Ma≈ø≈øy, 1270. and had I≈ø≈øue Richard, Son and Heir; Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Ro≈øthorn, ≈øecond Son, afterwards Heir to his Brother; Thomas, another Son, living 1270. Lib. C. fol. 104. num. 25.b. And Hawi≈øe, a Daughter, married Richard de Ferneley: Lib. A. fol. 140.o.
This William Ma≈ø≈øy died about the beginning of Edw. 1.
III. Sir Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton Knight, Son and Heir of Sir William, married I≈øabel Daughter of‚Äî

He Purcha≈øed out mo≈øt of the Lands remaining in Tatton, 1286. He was Sheriff of Che≈øhire, 6 Edw. 1. 1278. and Judge of Che≈øter, 28 Edw. 1. 1300. He was Knighted about 14 Edw. 1. for then I fir≈øt find him ≈øo ≈øtiled; unto whom was granted liberty of Free-Warren in all his Demain-Lands of Ro≈øthorn, Tatton, Owlarton, Legh, Timperley, and Hale, in Che≈øhire; Dated at We≈øtmin≈øter, 4 die Decembris, 22 Edw. 1. 1294.
Sir Richard died without I≈ø≈øue on Tue≈øday in the Ea≈øter-week, Anno Domini 1305. 33 Edw. 1. leaving Robert Ma≈ø≈øy his Brother to ≈øucceed in his Inheritance.
I≈øabel his Widow ≈øurvived him.

IV. Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, Brother and Heir to Sir Richard, married _____ and had I≈ø≈øue William Ma≈ø≈øy, elde≈øt Son; Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy, another Son, E≈øcheator of Che≈øhire. 6 Edw. 3. 1332. O. num. 1. and he married Katharine Daughter and Heir of Alan Rixton of Rixton in Lanca≈øhire, 6 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 292. num. 1, 3, 11. ≈øtiled afterwards Sir Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy, 1347. 21 Edw. 3. from whom the Ma≈ø≈øies of Rixton in Lanca≈øhire: Adam Ma≈ø≈øy, another Son, to whom his Father gave the Cu≈øtody of the Lands of Nor≈øhagh in Tatton, belonging to Raufe (Son of William de Mobberley) till Raufe came to Age: Dated 1 Edw. 3. 1327. Lib. C. fol. 103. num. 9. Robert Ma≈ø≈øy, another Son, 15 Edw. 3.
Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton died about 1328. 2 Edw. 3.

V. Sir William Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton Knight, 1335. Son and Heir of Robert, married Margery Daughter of Thomas Legh of High-Legh de We≈øt-Hall: Lib. C. fol. 267. num. 12. This was about 1307. And had I≈ø≈øue Hugh Ma≈ø≈øy, Son and Heir; Oliver Ma≈ø≈øy of Denfield in Ro≈øthorn, another Son, from whom the Ma≈ø≈øies of Denfield; Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Dich-hou≈øe in Ro≈øthorn, another Son; Ellen, a Daughter, married Gilbert Ha≈ø≈øall of Ha≈ø≈øall in Lanca≈øhire; afterwards to Sir William Brereton of Brereton in Che≈øhire.
Sir William Ma≈ø≈øy died the ≈øecond of May, 1338. 12 Edw. 3.

VI. Hugh Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, Son and Heir of Sir William, had to Wife Alice Daughter of _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, Son and Heir, who married Alice Daughter of Gibert de Haydok in Lanca≈øhire, 16 Edw. 3. 1342. but died without I≈ø≈øue 3 die Septembris, 1370. 44 Edw. 3. And John Ma≈ø≈øy, another Son, who ≈øucceeded Heir to his Father.
This Hugh Ma≈ø≈øy died before 49 Edw. 3. about 45 Edw. 3. 1371.

VII. Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton Knight, Son and Heir of Hugh, married Alice Si≈øter and Heir to Sir Geffrey Wor≈øeley of Wor≈øeley in Lanca≈øhire, about 46 Edw. 3. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, elde≈øt Son, who married Margaret Daughter of _____ but died without I≈ø≈øue, on St. Bartholomew's day, 1420. 8 Hen. 5. afterwards Margaret married Sir John Gre≈øley: Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy, ≈øecond Son, ≈øucceeded Heir to his Brother Thomas; Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, third Son: The≈øe are warranted by Deeds. But I find mention, in an old Pedegree, of three other Sons, Hugh, John, and Lawrence; al≈øo Joan, married fir≈øt to Sir William Venables of Bollin-Fee in Maxfield-Hundred, and after to Sir Oliver Stanley; Margery married Sir John Bromley of Badington in Che≈øhire.

Sir Geffrey Wor≈øeley before-mentioned married Mary Daughter of Sir Thomas Felton; which Mary being divorced, entred into a Nunnery: Then he took to Wife I≈øabel Stanley, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Elizabeth. After the death of Sir Geffrey VVor≈øeley, Mary came out, and proved ≈øhe entred for fear, and that ≈øhe was divorced upon a fained ground, and proved Elizabeth to be Illegitimate: And the Pope confirms her Return into Secularity.
Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton was Sheriff of Che≈øhire 11 Rich. 2. 1387. and al≈øo 13 Rich. 2. 1390. He and Thomas his elde≈øt Son were attainted 1 Hen. 4.

Sir John died 1403. 22 July, 4 Hen. 4. Probably he was ≈ølain at the Battel of Shrewsbury, taking Part with Henry Percy again≈øt Henry the Fourth; for that Battel was ≈øought the Eve before Mary Magdalen's day.
Alice the Widow of Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy died 6 Hen. 6. in the beginning of October, 1427.
VIII. Sir Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton Knight, Son to Sir John, and Heir to his Brother Thomas, married Margery Daughter of John Hilton of Farnworth in Lanca≈øhire.
This Sir Geffrey died 4 die Octobris, 1457. 36 Hen. 6. aged 70 Years, without any lawful I≈ø≈øue ≈øurviving.
I find he had a Ba≈øtard-≈øon, called John Ma≈ø≈øy, living 31 Hen. 6.

IX. William Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Richard Ma≈ø≈øy, Brother to Sir G ‚Ä¢ offrey, married _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy, Son and Heir; Thomas, ≈øecond Son; and Richard, third Son.
This William Ma≈ø≈øy died in Fe≈øto Epiphaniae, 1467. 7 Edw. 4. and had a Brother called Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy, as well as a Son of that Name.

X. Sir Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton Knight, Son and Heir of William, married I≈øabel Daughter of Sir John Butler of Bew≈øy nigh Warrington in Lanca≈øhire, 31 Hen. 6. 1453. and had I≈ø≈øue onely one Daughter and Heir, called Joan.
Sir Geffrey was living 15 Edw. 4. 1475. Q. num. 7.

XI. William Stanley of Tatton E≈øquire, in Right of Joan his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Sir Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy, was Son and Heir of Sir William Stanley of Holt-Ca≈øtle in Denbigh-≈øhire; and had I≈ø≈øue onely one Daughter and Heir, called al≈øo Joan; in Latin ≈øhe is ≈øtiled Johanna. Joan and Jane in 32 Eliz. were agreed to be all one Name by the Court of the King's Bench: Cambden in his Remains, on the Name Jane, pag. 98.

This Sir William Stanley of Holt was Lord Chamberlain to Hen. 7. and Brother to Thomas Stanley the fir≈øt Earl of Darby of that Family; which Sir William was Beheaded 1495. as ≈øuppo≈øed to encline to the Part of Perkin Warbeck: See Crokes Reports, 4 Car. 1. pag. 123, 124. who≈øe Lands and Goods were all Confi≈øcated to the King. He had in ready Money and Plate, in his Ca≈øtle of Holt, forty thou≈øand Marks, be≈øides Jewels, Hou≈øhold-≈øtuff, and Stock of Cattel in his Grounds. He had in Lands 3000 l. per Annum of an old Rent, as my Lord Bacon ≈øaith in his Hi≈øtory of Henry the Seventh. He a≈øpired to Petition the King for the Earldom of Che≈øter, which ended both in a denial, and a di≈øta≈øte. He had by Joyce his Wife, Daughter of Edward Lord Powys, and Widow of John Tiptoft, William Stanley before-mentioned; and Jane, married to Sir John Warburton of Arley in Che≈øhire, one of the Knights of the Body to Henry the Seventh.

William Stanley of Tatton died about 14 Hen. 7. 1498. Joan his Widow afterwards married Sir Edward Pickering, 16 Hen. 7. 1500. And la≈øtly, ≈øhe married Sir John Brereton to her third Husband, living 24 Hen. 7. And Joan died 3 Hen. 8. 1511.
XII. Joan, ≈øole Daughter and Heir of William Stanley by Joan Ma≈ø≈øy his Wife, had two Husbands.

Fir≈øt ≈øhe married John A≈øhton, Son and Heir of Sir Thomas A≈øhton of A≈øhton ≈øuper Mer≈øey in Che≈øhire, 16 Hen. 7. She was then but eight Years old. This John A≈øhton died young, without any I≈ø≈øue by her, 5 Hen. 8. 1513.

Afterwards ≈øhe married Sir Richard Brereton, younger Son of Sir Randle Brereton of Malpas in Che≈øhire; by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Richard Brereton, elde≈øt Son, who married Dorothy Daughter of Thur≈øtan de Tilde≈øley in Lanca≈øhire E≈øquire, 35 Hen. 8. 1543. But he died without I≈ø≈øue about 4 Edw. 6. Geffrey Brereton, ≈øecond Son, ≈øucceeded Heir: Anne Brereton, a Daughter, married John Booth of Barton in Lanca≈øhire E≈øq 32 Hen. 8. 1540. X. num. 26.
This Lady Jane Brereton died the ≈øixth of April, 12 Eliz. 1570. aged 77 Years.
Sir Richard Brereton her Husband died at I≈ølington in Middle≈øex, 3 & 4 Phil. & Mar. 1557. Geffrey his Son and Heir being then of full Age.

XIII. Geffrey Brereton of Tatton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Sir Richard Brereton and Jane Stanley, married Alice, Daughter of Piers Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley E≈øq 5. Edw. 6. 1551. A. num. 35. and had I≈ø≈øue Richard Brereton Son and Heir, and Anne a Daughter, living 8 Eliz. who died without I≈ø≈øue.
This Geffrey died in June 1565. 7 Eliz. about the age of thirty Years. Alice his Widow afterwards married Robert Charnocke Gentleman; and ≈øhe died the ≈øecond of April 1572. 14 Eliz.

XIV. Richard Brereton of Tatton E≈øquire, Son and Heir of Geffrey and Alice, married Dorothy, Daughter of Sir Richard Egerton of Ridley in Che≈øhire, 14 Eliz. 1572. but died without I≈ø≈øue December 18. 41 Eliz. 1598. Dorothy his Widow afterwards married Sir Peter Legh of Lime in Che≈øhire, but had no I≈ø≈øue by him: She was ≈øecond Wife to Sir Peter, and ≈øurvived both her Husbands; and ≈øhe died the fourth of April 1639.
This Richard Setled all his E≈øtate on Sir Thomas Egerton, Lord Chancellor of England; from whom the Earls of Bridgewater are de≈øcended, who are now Owners of the≈øe Lands, 1667.

div.head: Thelwall.
div.p: IN the Year of Chri≈øt 920. King Edward, ≈øirnamed The Elder, built a Town here at Thelwall, though now an ob≈øcure Village; ≈øo called, Te≈øte Forilego, from the Stakes and Stumps cut from the Trees, wherewith they had environed it about, as a Wall: for the Saxons called ≈øuch Stakes Thell; and the word Wall is a word yet u≈øed for a high Fence that encompa≈ø≈øeth any Place about with Stone, or other thing or Building. So Cambden's Britannia, Che≈øhire. Polychronicon, lib. 6. cap. 5. ad finem: and that King Edward made it a Garri≈øon, and placed Soldiers therein; wherewith al≈øo agrees Florentius Wigornien≈øis. But it ≈øeems to lie wa≈øte in the time of the Conqueror; for I find no mention of it in Dooms-day Book.

Roger of Poictou (Son of Rogerde Montgomery the fir≈øt Earl of Shrewsbury) was Lord of all the Land in Lanca≈øhire, between the Rivers of Ribble and Mer≈øey; and gave half of the Fi≈øhing of Thelwall to the Abbot of Shrewsbury, under Henry the Fir≈øt. Mona≈øticon, vol. 1. pag. 383. This was the Fi≈øhing on the Lanca≈øhire ≈øide.

The Prior of Norton had the other half of the Fi≈øhing of Thelwall on the Che≈øhire ≈øide, granted by William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire the younger, Baron of Halton, about the Reign of King Stephen. Mona≈øticon, vol. 2. pag. 186.

In our Mize-book of Che≈øhire, anciently the Abbot of Salop ≈øtood charged with three Shillings in the Mize for Fi≈øhing in Thelwall: but this Mize is now totally lo≈øt, no Man now living being able to inform us who ought to pay the ≈øame. I conceive after the di≈ø≈øolution of Abbeys in England by Henry the Eighth, that Fi≈øhing coming to the King's hands, the Mize thereof cea≈øed, being not at all paid of late Times, the Fi≈øhing being then but of little value.

This Town≈øhip of Thelwall is of the Fee of the Honor of Halton: one third part whereof William Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire gave to the Abbey of Salop, cum pertinentiis, in bo≈øco, in plano, in aqu√¢. Mona≈øticon, vol. 1. pag. 383.

In the Reign of Henry the Third, Edmund Lacy Baron of Halton and Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, gave Domino Galfrido de Dutton (Ance≈øtour to Warburton of Arley) totam terram ≈øuam de Thelwall cum Wera, & Pi≈øcaria, & Stallagiis ≈øuis: and al≈øo all the Land which he had of the Abbot and Convent of Eve≈øham in Thelwall: Reddendo inde annuatim unam Par Cheirothecarum Cervi Furratarum ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Michaelis pro omni Servitio. Lib. C. in ip≈øo initio, Ex Chartulis Roberti Pickering de Thelwall. fol. 1.f. This could be but two third parts of Thelwall. The Original of this Deed is now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Mr. Pickering of Thelwall, 1666.
This Geffrey Dutton gave the≈øe Lands to Thomas his younger Son. Ibidem g.

Afterwards it was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by Clayton in the Reign of Edward the Third, and continued in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Claytons, till John Clayton of Thelwall ≈øold it to Richard Brooks of Norton E≈øquire, about 4 Eliz. 1561. who≈øe Son Thomas Brooks of Norton E≈øquire, ≈øold the ≈øame to John Moores Doctor of Phy≈øick in London, Anno Chri≈øti 1621. and John Moores of Kirtlington in Nottingham≈øhire, Nephew of Doctor Moores afore≈øaid, ≈øold them to Robert Pickering Councellor at Law, 1662. who is now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Mannor of Thelwall, 1666.
In this Town≈øhip of Thelwall are now, 1666. certain Freeholds of Inheritance po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the≈øe Per≈øons following.

list.item: 1. Sir Peter Brookes of Mere, hath four Tenements, which were given him by his Father Thomas Brookes of Norton E≈øquire, before he ≈øold away the other Lands of Thelwall.
2. John Martin≈øcroft of Thelwall: This hath for long time continued in the Name of Martin≈øcroft, an ancient Freeholder.
3. Robert Legh of Thelwall, bought from Sir Edward Moores.
4. Peter Drinkwater, formerly one Ma≈ø≈øies.
5. Raufe Caldwell, Fee-Farmer.
6. John Row≈øon, Fee-Farmer.
7. Randle Bood, Fee-Farmer.
8. Margaret Hogge, Widow.
9. John Legh of Oughtrington in Limme, bought Lands in Thelwall from Sir Edward Moores.
10. Katharine Mo≈ø≈øe, one Clo≈øe.
11. Thomas Thoma≈øon, Fee-Farmer.
12. John Dunbabin, a Meadow.
13. Sir George Warburton of Arley, half an Acre of Meadow.

div.p: Here is a Chappel of Ea≈øe called Thelwall-Chappel, ≈øituate near to the Mannor-Hou≈øe of Thelwall, and within the Parochiall Chappelry of Daresbury, but both within the Limits of the Mother-Church of Runcorne.
This I conceive was built by Thomas Brookes E≈øquire, and was lately repaired by Mr. Pickering afore≈øaid, 1663.

div.head: Timperley.
div.p: IN the Rentall of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 3 Hen. 4. Ranulfus Manwaring tenet de jure Uxoris ≈øuae medietatem villae de Timperley cum clau≈øura in e√¢dem, vocata Chenall, in Soccagio: & reddit per annum termino Johannis Bapti≈øtae duodecem denarios: Et de Stuth, alias dictum Sheriffe-Tooth, 2 d. ob. This Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever, married Margery the Widow of Richard Buckley of Chedle; and ≈øo in her Right, during her Life, held the Moiety of Timperley; which belonged to the Buckleys of Chedle, and at this day, 1666. belongs to Buckley of Chedle, being anciently of the Fee of the Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy.

The other Moiety formerly belonged to the Ardernes of Timperley: which Moiety Charles Arderne, younger Son of John Arderne of Harden in Maxfield Hundred E≈øquire, had by the Marriage of Elizabeth the Daughter of Richard Ratcliffe Lord of Backford.

Sir William Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, bought certain Lands in Timperley, and the fourth part of Timperley-Mo≈ø≈øe from John Parr junior and Alice his Wife, in exchange for Lands in Stoke, Picton, and Che≈øter, 2 Edw. 4. 1462. Lib. C. fol. 253. l. And Timperley-Mo≈ø≈øe and Common was divided October 28. 15 Edw. 4. 1475. one fourth part to Sir William Booth; another fourth part to John Arderne, Son and Heir of of Charles Arderne late decea≈øed, by Elizabeth his Wife then Widow ≈øurviving; and the other
half of Timperley-Mo≈ø≈øe and Common to William Buckley E≈øquire, ibidem fol. 253. m. The Originals among the Evidences of the Lord Delamere of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, 1666.

So that the Lord Delamere hath now the fourth part of Timperley; and another fourth part now belongs to Sir Amos Meredeth, in Right of Anne his Wife, Daughter of Robert Tatton of Witthen≈øhaw in Che≈øhire E≈øquire. On which Anne and her Heirs Mrs. Barlowe (one of the Si≈øters and Coheirs to Thomas Brereton, late of A≈øhley decea≈øed) hath ≈øetled her part; unto who≈øe ≈øhare the Lands of Timperley, which belonged to Brereton, are ≈øolely with other Lands allotted. The≈øe Lands came fir≈øt to Brereton by Sibill, Daughter and Heir of William Arderne of Timperley, Wife of George Brereton of A≈øhley. William Arderne died Augu≈øt 28. 26 Eliz. 1584.
And the other Moiety of Timperley belongeth to Buckley of Chedle, as afore≈øaid.

list.head: Charterers now in Timperley, 1666.
list.item: 1. Thomas Gerard of Riddings in Timperley Gentleman. The≈øe Freehold-lands belonged to Vawdrey of Riddings, and were not long ≈øince purcha≈øed by the ≈øaid Thomas Gerard. The≈øe Lands were originally granted away by John Arderne of Timperley, and Thomas his Son and Heir, unto Thomas Vawdrey and his Heirs, rendring yearly 1 l. 13 s. 4 d. Dated the tenth of Augu≈øt, 13 Hen. 7. 1498. Lib. B. pag. 37. The Original in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Thomas Gerard afore≈øaid.
2. William Steele of Nether-Knotsford, hath three Cottages in Timperley: The≈øe formerly belonged to the Riddings.
3. George Ward of London, one Cottage, formerly belonging to the Riddings.
4. Peter Parker of Altrincham, hath about an Acre in Timperley, formerly belonging to the Riddings.
5. Robert Hield of Etchells, one Cottage in Timperley.

div.head: Toft.
div.p: THis Town≈øhip of Toft is not found in Dooms-day Book; wherefore it ≈øeems to be Wa≈øte at that time. The word Toft ≈øignifies a parcel of Land wherein a Hou≈øe hath ≈øtood. Cambdens Remains, pag. 120. and in that ≈øence it was taken by the Judges and expounded, 2 & 3 Philip & Mary. Plowdens Commentaries, Hill envers Graunge, pag. 170.
