This Town gave Name to the Family of the Tofts, who in ancient Time were ≈øeated here: One Moiety thereof is held of the Barony of Halton in Soccage, by the yearly Rent of ≈øeven Shillings: and the other half is held of the ancient Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy in Soccage, by the yearly Rent of five Shillings: for ≈øo I find it in John Leyce≈øter of Toft's Office, 2 Hen. 8. and in other Offices downwards: which Rents are paid at this day, 1672. Howbeit, in an ancient Feodary of Halton under Edward the Second it is ≈øaid ‚ÄîRogerus de Toft, tenet Villam de Toft pro vice≈øima parte unius Feodi Militis. Yet I find among the Evidences of Toft, T. num. 14. a little Parchment, about the time of the beginning of Edward the Third's Reign, in Latin, and by me here rendred in Engli≈øh, as followeth:

q.p: HUgh de Toft confe≈ø≈øeth that he holdeth of the Earl of Lanca≈øter, Lord of Halton, the one Moiety of the Town≈øhip of Toft, by the twentieth part of a Knight's Fee, by Homage and Fealty, and the yearly Rent of Seven Shillings, to be paid to Halton on Martlemas-day; and that he oweth Suit of Court to Halton for the ≈øame, de Quindena in Quindenam (that is, every Fortnight) upon notice: And will appear at the Court of Pa≈ø≈øage or Fare; and ought to pay 12 d. to the Serjeants of Halton‚Äîand 4d. for Market-Gold.

div.p:
And I find al≈øa among the Evidences of Toft, that the Moiety of Toft belonging
to the Barons of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy was ≈øcattered into ≈øeveral Parcels: For Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy granteth to Arnold de Toft the Third Part of his Moiety of Toft, rendring the yearly Rent of Twenty Pence, about the Reign of King John: T. num. 3. This third Part of that Moiety, Benedict the Son of Orme, the Son of Arnold de Toft, relea≈øed unto Roger de Toft, Anno 18 Hen. 3. 1234. T. num. 6. Confirmed by Hamon Ma≈ø≈øy, T. num. 4.

Gerva≈øe Son of Hugh of Mobberley al≈øo relea≈øeth to Walter de Toft the Right which he hath to the ≈øixth Part of the Town≈øhip of Toft: T. num. 1. And after relea≈øeth to Roger Son of Walter Toft all his Right in the whole Town≈øhip of Toft, about 15 Hen. 3. 1230. T. num. 2.

Robert Son of Wentlyan relea≈øeth al≈øo to Roger Son of Walter de Toft his Moiety of another third Part of the whole Moiety of Toft, about 1230. T. num. 8. This Moiety of a third Part, Robert Son of Wentlyan had in Free-Marriage with Alice his Wife, Daughter of one Hugh de Toft: T. num. 7. And by this Deed it appears, that this Hugh de Toft then had the other Moiety of that third Part in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

So that now Roger Son of Walter de Toft was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of mo≈øt of the Town of Toft, under Henry the Third: And I find Roger Toft, Son of this Roger Toft, ≈øtiling him≈øelf Dominus de Toft, Anno Domini 1298. 26 Edw. 1. T. num. 9. to who≈øe Po≈øterity the Manor and Town of Toft hath continued ever ≈øince; that is to ≈øay, The Family of Toft of Toft continued till the end of the Reign of Henry the Sixth, above 250 Years; and then Robert Leyce≈øter (Son of Robert, Son of Joan, Daughter and Heir of Robert Toft of Toft E≈øquire) was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Manor of Toft, 2 Edw. 4. and hath ≈øince belonged to his Po≈øterity, Rafe Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øquire being now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øame, Anno Domini 1672.

list.head: Charterers in Toft, Anno Domini 1672.
list.item: 1. The Me≈ø≈øuage late the Inheritance of Litler of Wallers-cote nigh Northwich; Randle Mores now Tenant.

2. John Stretch of Little-Pever hath now certain Freehold-Lands in Toft, which he lately purcha≈øed from John Downes late of Toft; and purcha≈øed by Downes formerly from Mainwaring of Pever: For in the Office taken after the death of Sir Randle Mainwaring of Over-Pever, 5 & 6 Phil. & Mar.‚ÄîTenuit terras in Toft de Radulfo Leyce≈øter Milite per fidelitatem & redditum decem Denariorum,‚Äî&c.

div.head: The Pedegree of Toft of Toft, collected out of the Evidences of Toft, 1672.
div.p: II. Roger de Toft, Son of Walter de Toft. He lived Anno Domini 1230. and purcha≈øed ≈øeveral Lands in Toft, as I have before declared, T: num. 2. and T. num. 8. He had two Sons, Roger de Toft, and VVilliam de Toft; and Margaret, a Daughter, married VVilliam Son of Roger Manwaring, 1 Edw. 1. 1272. Lib. C. fol. 226.

VVilliam de Toft, younger Son of this Roger, married Joan Si≈øter of Richard de Lo≈øtock-Gralam the younger, Son of Richard de Lo≈øtock, 5 Edw. 1. 1277. Lib. C. fol. 228.b. This Joan
became Heir to her Brothers, Richard and Thomas, who both died without I≈ø≈øue; but ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue by this William, Roger de Holford, who living at Holford, gained the Sir-name of Holford; which his Po≈øterity retained, and from whom the Holford's of Holford are de≈øcended. Lib. C. fol. 229. K. o. She had two other Husbands; of whom ≈øee more in Plumley.

Note, That John Holford under Richard the Second, Sealed with Tofts Coat, differenced with a Cheveron, as I have ≈øeen in ≈øundry of his Seals, to wit, Argent, a Cheveron between three Text Tees Sable: but Toft of Toft's Coat is Argent, three Text Tees, without a Cheveron.

III. Roger Toft of Toft, Son of Roger, married Beatrix, Daughter of Hugh Venables of Kinderton, about the very beginning of Edward the Fir≈øt; to whom her Father gave Land in Rusford in Kinderton, beyond the Brook towards Spro≈øton. Lib. C. fol. 225. e. and had I≈ø≈øue Roger, Son and Heir, Richard living 6 Edw. 2. Hugh died before 9 Edw. 2. Lib. C. fol. 215. K. Thomas living 9 Edw. 2. & Hamon Toft. al≈øo Henry Toft another Son. T. num. 12.

IV. Roger Toft of Toft, Son and Heir of Roger, married Margery, Daughter of Thomas Wever of Weever in Che≈øhire, Anno Dom. 1298. 26 Edw. 1. T. num. 9, 10, 11. and had I≈ø≈øue Hugh Toft; Thomas Toft, who married Margaret, to whom Sir Rafe Mobberley gave his Mannor-Hou≈øe in Plumley, 1357. 31 Edw. 3. T. num. 24. Lib. C. fol. 226. v. William Toft another Son, T. num. 13. 16 Edw. 3. Margaret Toft, Si≈øter of Hugh Toft, 16 Rich. 2. Lib. C. fol. 226.w.

V. Hugh Toft of Toft, Son of Roger, married Felice, Daughter of Thomas de Don≈øtable, 19 Edw. 2. 1325. Lib. C. fol. 225. K. and had I≈ø≈øue Robert de Toft; Roger de Toft, living 2 Hen. 5. & 8 Hen. 5. Emme, a Daughter, married Thomas, Son of Sir Hamon A≈øhley of A≈øhley in Bowdon Pari≈øh, 1359. 33 Ed. 3. John Booths Book, Lib. H. pag. 110.d.
It ≈øeemeth that Roger Toft was elder Brother to Robert, T. num. 46. and had no I≈ø≈øue-male at lea≈øt.

This Hugh de Toft gave to Sir Hugh Venables all his Lands in Kinderton and Spro≈øton (which Lands were given by Venables to his Grandmother) in exchange for the ≈øixth part of Bexton, 1359. 34 Edw. 3. B. num. 12. Lib. C. fol. 226.l.

Sir John Seyvill Knight, Brother of the Ho≈øpital of St. John of Jeru≈øalem, and procurer of the Pardon or Indulgence of the Ca≈øtle of St. Peter (by virtue of this Indulgence of Pope Alexander the Fifth, granted to all tho≈øe who have put to their helping hand to the fortification of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, that they ≈øhall chu≈øe them≈øelves a Confe≈ø≈øor) now granteth to Hugh de Toft and Alice his Wife, becau≈øe of their Charity and Aid towards the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, full liberty by the Pope's Authority, to chu≈øe them≈øelves a Confe≈ø≈øor; whereunto the Seal of the Indulgence for the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle is affixed: Dated apud Templum Bruer; Anno Domini 1412. And on the back of the ≈øaid Deed is written in Latin, which I have here put into Engli≈øh as followeth,‚Äî

q.p: THe Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, who hath given to his Di≈øciples power of binding and loo≈øing, ab≈øolve thee; and I by the Apo≈øtolical Authority of St. Paul, and the whole Mother-Church, by the help of both which and the Popes Indulgence, do ab≈øolve thee from all thy ≈øins, of which by contrition thou ha≈øt confe≈ø≈øed, or hereafter ≈øhalt confe≈øs‚ÄîAnd I grant thee full remi≈ø≈øion of all thy ≈øins, that thou maye≈øt have eternal life for ever. Amen. And if it happen that thou recover not this pre≈øent Infirmity, I re≈øerve it for thee even in the very point of death. T. num. 48.

div.p: By which Deed it may ≈øeem that Hugh de Toft had a later Wife called Alice, and that he died Anno 1412. or thereabout. T. num. 44. Quaere if John de Holford did not afterwards marry this Alice. T. num. 35.

Robert Toft of Toft, Son of Hugh, married Cicely the Widow of John Clark of Hawarden, and had I≈ø≈øue Roger de Toft, who died without I≈ø≈øue; and Jone married Rafe Leyce≈øter, younger Brother to John Leyce≈øter of Tabley: Howbeit, her I≈ø≈øue was not po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Mannor of Toft till after the death of her Father and Brother, about the end of the Reign of Henry the Sixth. T. num. 78. T. num. 47. T. num. 51.

John Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfield (this was John Burghill) granted to Robert de Toft and Cicely his Wife, liberty of keeping a Chaplain for celebrating of Divine Duties in their private Oratories. Dated in our City of Lichfield, December 21. 1398. 22 Rich. 2. T. num. 39.

And it ≈øeemeth to be this Robert de Toft who was Con≈øtable of the Ca≈øtle of Halton in Che≈øhire, and received 40 l. 00 s. 00 d. at Che≈øter by the hands of William de Alcumlow, Bailiff of the Sergeanty of Halton, from Robert Paris, then the Kings Auditor at Che≈øter, the 2 ‚Ä¢ . day of July, 23 Rich. 2. for the Ward and Cu≈øtody of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, for him≈øelf and divers E≈øquires and Archers, then being in the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle by the appointment of the King's Council. T. num. 80.
So ended the Family of Toft of Toft.

div.head: The De≈øcent of Leyce≈øter of Toft, collected carefully out of the Evidences of that Family, 1672.
div.p: The fir≈øt of the I≈ø≈øue of Joan that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Mannor of Toft whom I meet withal, was Robert Leyce≈øter, Son of Robert, Son of this Rafe and Joan, and that 2 Edw. 4. 1462. T. num. 51. for that till about this time Robert Toft Father of Joan, ≈øurvived, or Roger his Son.

When John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley ≈øold away all his Right and Title to the Moiety of the Mannor of Mobberley, with the Advow≈øon of the Church of Mobberley, unto John Dumvill of Mobberley and Ciceley his Wife, 1 Rich. 2. 1377. (which Lands were Setled on the ≈øaid John Leyce≈øter by Sir Rafe Mobberley of Mobberley his Uncle, by Feoffees intru≈øted, Anno Domini 1359. M. num. 32. and M. num. 33. and T. num. 31.) It was then agreed, That one third part of that Moiety ≈øhould de≈øcend to Rafe Leyce≈øter his Brother, after the death of John Dumvill and Cicely: which was E≈øtated accordingly by Thomas Fitton of Gowe≈øworth, and other Feoffees intru≈øted, (after divi≈øion thereof made) by the Name of 15 Me≈ø≈øuages, two parts of a Me≈ø≈øuage 316 Acres, half an Acre, half a quarter of an Acre, ten Perches and half a Perch of Land, ≈øixteen Acres of Wood, one quarter and five Perches, eight Acres of Mo≈øs, the third part of a Water-Mill, and the third part of all the Wa≈øtes of Mobberly then unmea≈øured, together with the Rent and Services of the ≈øaid Rafe Leyce≈øter and William Daw≈øon in Mobberley; to hold to John Dumvill and Cicely his Wife for their Lives‚Äîand after their Deaths then to remain to Rafe Leyce≈øter and the Heirs-males of his Body; and if Rafe die without Heir-male of his Body, then to remain to the right Heirs of Cicely afore≈øaid for ever: Dated at Mobberley on Tue≈øday in the Fea≈øt of St. Petronill the Virgin, 2 Rich. 2. 1378. M. num. 34. And Rafe Leyce≈øter had 15 l. 00 s. 00 d. annual Rent E≈øtated on him, during the Lives of the ≈øaid John Dumvill and Cicely, out of all the Lands in Mobberley by Fine Levied to the ≈øaid Feoffees, 1 Rich. 2. M. num. 2. & M. num. 3. which Lands of Mobberley ≈øo Setled on this Rafe Leyce≈øter, are now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Leyce≈øter of Toft, 1672.

So that it ≈øeems Rafe Leyce≈øter afore≈øaid, had one Me≈ø≈øuage in Mobberley by the Grant of Nicholas Leyce≈øter his Father, and Mary his Mother, before the≈øe other Lands were E≈øtated on him in Mobberley, M. num. 39. and he purcha≈øed William Daw≈øon's Land in Mobberley after the Settlement afore≈øaid, to wit, 3 Rich. 2. M. num. 27, 28.
But the third part of the Mill in the Settlement mentioned Robert Leyce≈øter ≈øold to John Troutback. 18 Hen. 6. M. num. 13.
This Rafe Leyce≈øter and Joan his Wife, had I≈ø≈øue Robert Leyce≈øter, who ≈øucceeded Heir; and Roger Leyce≈øter living, 18 Rich. 2. E. num. 1. among the Evidences of Leyce≈øter of Tabley.

Now that this Rafe Leyce≈øter was younger Brother to John Leyce≈øter of Nether-Tabley, appears by their Examinations taken on the part of Robert Gro≈øvenour of Hulme, again≈øt Scroop, concerning the bearing of a Coat of Arms, Anno Domini 1386. 10 Rich. 2. where John Leyce≈øter is ≈øaid to be then forty ≈øix years old, and Rafe Leyce≈øter forty years old. Lib. C. fol. 126. KK. II. The Original upon Record in the Tower of London, called The Bundle inter Scroop & Gro≈øvenour: A Copy of which Record, tran≈øcribed in a great Book, remains now with Gro≈øvenour of Eaton-boate in Che≈øhire.

As al≈øo, that the ancient Lands of the Leyce≈øters remain at this day, 1672. in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Leyce≈øter of Tabley; which mu≈øt have de≈øcended to the Heirs of this Rafe, if he had been the elder Brother.

Again in the Deeds of Toft, M. num. 10. mentioning the Partition of the Lands in Mobberley, between John Dumvill and Cicely his Wife on the one part, and John Leyce≈øter and Rafe his Brother on the other part: for if Rafe Leyce≈øter had been the elder Brother, it would have been ≈øaid betwixt Rafe Leyce≈øter and John his Brother.

And la≈øtly, That Leyce≈øter of Toft beareth his Coat of Arms at this day with a di≈øtinction from the Coat-Armour of Leyce≈øter of Tabley, by adding a Fret upon the Fe≈øs: and omnis additio probat minoritatem.
But of this enough; which I rather mention, lea≈øt any ≈øhould judge me partial in my own Cau≈øe, without certain Grounds of Truth.
This Rafe Leyce≈øter had Lands in Chorley juxta Warford, by the Grant of Mary his Mother.
II Robert Leyce≈øter, Son and Heir of Rafe, married _____ and had I≈ø≈øue Robert Son and Heir, Randle ≈øecond Son, and John third Son, living 11 Hen. 4. C. num. 11.

This Randle Leyce≈øter, ≈øecond Son, married I≈øabel Daughter and Coheir of David Crew of Pulcroft; from whom the Leycesters of Poole in Nantwich Hundred are de≈øcended, as appears by the Evidences of that Family. This Randle died Anno Dom. 1438. who≈øe Po≈øterity continued here until Richard Leyce≈øter, late Mayor of Che≈øter, and Alderman of that City, having no I≈ø≈øue, gave all his Lands in Poole to Sir Henry Delves of Dodington Baronet, in Marriage with Mary his Neece, Daughter of Randle Leyce≈øter his late Brother. This Lady Mary Delves was ≈øecond Wife of Sir Henry, and was Widow 1666. but had no I≈ø≈øue by Sir Henry. But the≈øe Lands are Setled to de≈øcend to another Leyce≈øter ≈øprung from that Family, after the Death of the ≈øaid Mary without I≈ø≈øue.
III. Robert Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øquire, Son of Robert, is the fir≈øt of this Family whom I find ≈øtiled De Toft, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øame, to wit, 2 Edw. 4. 1462. T. num. 51.

He married Jane, Daughter and Coheir of Rafe Booth, younger Son of Sir Robert Booth of Dunham-Ma≈ø≈øy, whom the ≈øaid Rafe begot on Margaret his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Thomas Sibell of Sandwich in Kent.

This Robert had I≈ø≈øue Rafe Leyce≈øter, Robert another Son, living 1 Hen. 7. John another Son, 12 Hen. 8. Agnes a Daughter, married to John Birtles of Birtles nigh Over-Alderley, 6. Edw. 4. 1466. M. num. 14. Lib. A. fol. 133. e, f, g, h, i, k.

This Robert Leyce≈øter and John Legh of Booths, committed an A≈ø≈øault on Dennys Holland, Servant to Sir Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy of Tatton, in the night-time, and cha≈øed and de≈øtroyed his
Deer in Tatton Park; for which they paid 20 l. apiece. 20 Hen. 6. T. num. 79. by Award.

IV. Rafe Leyce≈øter Son and Heir of Robert, married Agnes Daughter of Robert Ratcliff, 17 Edw. 4. 1477. and had I≈ø≈øue John Leyce≈øter Son and Heir, and James Leyce≈øter, living 1 Hen. 7. Lib. A. fol. 133. H, I, K, L.
This Rafe died in the Life-time of his Father, to wit, 1 Hen. 7. 1485.

This John Leyce≈øter died 2 Hen. 8. 1511. Elinour ≈øurvived, and was Widow 12 Hen. 8. 1520. T. num. 89. and 14 Hen. 8. T. num. 88. She was the ninth Daughter and Coheir, and had Lands in Brickle≈øworth in Northampton≈øhire: for Sir James had ten Daughters and Coheirs in all. Lib. A. fol. 133. m.n.

VI. Rafe Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øquire, Son and Heir of John, married Ellen Daughter of Rafe Egerton of Ridley in Che≈øhire E≈øquire, 4 Hen. 7. 1489. Lib. A. fol. 133. l. & fol. 134. P. and had I≈ø≈øue Rafe Leyce≈øter Son and Heir.

This Rafe died 16 Hen. 8. 1525. aged 37 years. Afterwards Ellen his Widow married Robert Honford of Chorley. Lib. A. fol. 134. r. & 135. T. Ellen ≈øurvived both her Husbands, and was living 20 Hen. 8. C. num. 13.

VII. Sir Rafe Leyce≈øter of Toft Knight, Son and Heir of Rafe, was Knighted at Leith in Scotland the 11. day of May, 36 Hen. 1. 1544. at which time the Earl of Hertford, being then General, Knighted ≈øome other Che≈øhire Gentlemen, and ≈øeveral others al≈øo. So Stow in his Annals of that Year.

Sir Rafe had two Wives; the fir≈øt was Ellen Daughter of Philip Legh of Boothes nigh Knotsford E≈øquire, 13 Hen. 8. T. num. 83. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Rafe Leyce≈øter elde≈øt Son, who died young. William Leyce≈øter ≈øecond Son ≈øucceeded Heir.F. num. 4.
Lawrence Leyce≈øter, another Son, married Jane Daughter of John Warburton of Bromfield; and John, who died without I≈ø≈øue: Al≈øo Elizabeth married Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever; ≈øhe was his ≈øecond Wife, but had no I≈ø≈øue by him: afterwards ≈øhe married Sir Edmond Trafford of Trafford nigh Manche≈øter. Anne, another Daughter, married Philip Manwaring, Brother and after Heir to Sir Randle afore≈øaid. Ellen died in her Infancy; and Mary married Hugh Calveley of Lea nigh Eaton-boate in Che≈øhire E≈øq
His ≈øecond Wife was Jane, the Widow of John Edwards of Chirk in Denbigh≈øhire E≈øquire, and Daughter of Sir George Calveley of Lea, but had no I≈ø≈øue by her.

William Davenport of Chorley Gent. granted to this Sir Rafe Leycester the Office of Sene≈øchall, or Steward≈øhip of all his Lands in Chorley, Werford, and Ful≈øhaw, and the Conduction, Governance, and Service in time of War called The Mauraden, as well of him the ≈øaid William and his Heirs, as of all his Tenants: Dated 4. July, 4 & 5 Phil. & Ma,. C. num. 25. Al≈øo the like Deed made to Sir Rafe by Henry Brad≈øhaw of Brad≈øhawbrooke in Allostock, 1 & 2 Phil. & Mar. Al≈øo another ≈øuch Deed made to Sir Rafe by John Hiccock of Nether-Pever, 1 & 2 Phil. & Mar. H. num. 25. H. num. 28. the Originals are in Latin. Hiccock's Land of Nether-Pever, is now Powdrell's and others. The≈øe I note for the rarity of the Deeds.
Sir Rafe al≈øo bought from William Brad≈øhaw of Allostock, two Me≈ø≈øuages in Allostock, Hul≈øe, and Bancroft, by Fine, Levied at Chester the 27. of May, 1 & 2 Philip and Mary. F. num. 1.

He was entru≈øted for receiving certain Sums of Money by way of Loan in Denbigh≈øhire, and for delivering ≈øuch Privy-Seals as were ≈øent unto him, as appears by the Queens Letter unto him, Dated the 30. of December, 5 Eliz. C. num. 33.

And I find that Gilbert Dethick, alias Norroy, Principal Herald and King of Arms of the North Parts of England from the River Trent Northward, gave to this Sir Rafe Leyce≈øter the Arms and Cre≈øt in manner following, to wit, Sable, on a Fe≈øs engrailed between three Falcons Silver volant, becked and membred Gold, a Lions Head Caboche Azure, langued and eared, between two Cups covered, Gules: upon his Helm, On a Tor≈øe Silver and Sable, a Roe-buck Party-Pale Gold and Gules, Horned of the ≈øecond, holding in his Mouth an Acorn Branch, ≈øtalked and leafed vert, mantled Gules, doubled Silver: to hold for him and his Po≈øterity, to their Honors for evermore: Dated the 15. of May, Anno 2. Edw. 6. two fair Seals appendant in woodden Boxes, the one being his own Arms, and the other the Seal of his Office as Norroy. T. num. 55. at which, I confe≈øs, I wonder, that he ≈øhould ≈øeek for a Coat, as being ignorant of one due to him: and yet I have ob≈øerved, that among all the Deeds there is not any one to be found among the Deeds of Leyce≈øter of Toft hitherto, which hath any Coat of Arms at all in an E≈øcutcheon affixed to any of their Deeds, or in any of their Seals, appropriated to Leyce≈øter of Toft: Howbeit, the Heralds of Che≈øter have Recorded for them Leyce≈øter of Tabley's Coat with a difference, which indeed is mo≈øt truly ≈øutable.

This Sir Rafe Leycester ≈øold away all his Purpart of the Manor of Bra≈ø≈øingham in Norfolk, and Advow≈øon of the Church there, to Francis Baldero and Edmund Wi≈øeman Gentlemen: Dated the fir≈øt day of April, 4 Eliz. A. num. 1.

Upon ≈øome Difference between Sir Rafe and Dame Jane Legh, late Wife of Sir John Legh of Boothes decea≈øed, it was agreed between Sir William Sneyd Knight, and the ≈øaid Dame Jane Legh on the one part, and Sir Rafe Leyc≈øter Knight on the other part, by Deed dated the eighth of October, Anno primo Elizabethae, That Sir Rafe ≈øhould not pur≈øue any further Suit in the Court of Wards: in con≈øideration whereof, the ≈øaid Sir Rafe and Dame Ellen his Wife ≈øhould peaceably enjoy tho≈øe Lands Demi≈øed to them, &c. and Sir Rafe to kill one fat Buck in Summer, and a Doe in Winter, out of the Park at Boothes, during the Minority of John Legh; and to have the keeping of a Hor≈øe in the ≈øame yearly. T. num. 92. But Anno quinto Elizabethae, Sir Rafe had a Grant from the Queen of certain parcels of Land, late the Inheritance of Sir John Legh decea≈øed, and late the Joynture of the ≈øaid Dame Jane, during the Minority of the Ward. C. num. 32.
Sir Rafe Leyce≈øter died 23. Februarii, 14 Eliz. 1572. aged 53 years. T. num. 59.

VIII. William Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øquire, ≈øecond Son and Heir of Sir Rafe, married Katharine, Daughter of John Edwards of Chirk in Denbigh≈øhire E≈øquire, and by her had I≈ø≈øue. Rafe Leyce≈øter, elde≈øt Son, died without I≈ø≈øue; George Leyce≈øter, ≈øecond Son, ≈øucceeded Heir; Jane, a Daughter, married Henry Davenport of Chorley Gent. 37 Eliz. C. num. 28. Anne, another Daughter; Ellen, another Daughter; Parnell or Petronill, another Daughter; the≈øe three were never married: and Mary, another Daughter, married Rowland Huntington, after to David Middleton of Che≈øter, thirdly to George Calveley, Ba≈øtard-Son to Sir George Calveley of Lea. C. num. 31.
Katharine the Wife of William Leyce≈øter, died Anno Domini 1572. 14 Eliz. C. num. 31. Afterwards William Leyce≈øter married Elizabeth, Daughter of Robert Wor≈øley of Boothes in Lanca≈øhire.
This William ≈øold away all his part of Brickle≈øworth in Northampton≈øhire, unto Thomas Barham of Te≈øton in Kent Gent. for 300 l. by Deed dated the 29. of April, 20 Eliz. A. num. 2.
William Leyce≈øter of Toft died Novemb. 18. 32 Eliz. 1589. and was buried at Mobberley the 25. of November following, aged 48 years. T. num. 60.

IX. Sir George Leyce≈øter of Toft Knight, ≈øecond Son and Heir of William, married Alice, elde≈øt Daughter of Peter Leyce≈øter of Tabley E≈øq and Coheir to the Lands of Colwich
nigh Ow≈øeley-Bridge in Stafford≈øhire, 22 Eliz. F. num. 9. which Lands de≈øcended in Right of their Mother Elizabeth, Daughter and Heir of Edward Colwich of Colwich E≈øquire.

Robert Earl of Leyce≈øter, Baron of Denbigh, &c. her Maje≈øties Lieutenant, and Captain-General of all her Army and Forces in the≈øe Parts, and Governor-General of all the Provinces and Cities united, and their A≈ø≈øociates in the Low-Countreys, for the good opinion we have of the fidelity of this Gentleman George Leyce≈øter our Servant, we have appointed him Captain of 150 Foot-men, and Hugh Starkey his Lieutenant, now Servant to Sir Chri≈øtopher Hatton, &c. Given under my Hand and Seal at Amer≈øford the 15. of May 1586. T. num. 58.

Sir George was Knighted about 44 Eliz. and was made Sheriff of Che≈øhire by Patent dated Decemb. 29. 45 Eliz. but the Queen dying in March following, he had another Patent for the ≈øame durante beneplacito, Dated Apr. 3. 1 Jac. 1603. T. num. 63.

He had I≈ø≈øue William Leyce≈øter, who died at the Age of three years; George, ≈øecond Son, who died at the Age of ≈øeven years; Rafe, third Son, ≈øucceeded Heir; al≈øo Elizabeth, elde≈øt Daughter, died in her Infancy; Katharine married William Tatton of Withen≈øhaw in Che≈øhire E≈øq F. num. 12. afterwards ≈øhe married Doctor Nichols Par≈øon of Chedle: Mary, another Daughter, married James Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale E≈øq 9 Jac. 1611. who≈øe Ward≈øhip Sir George had. F. num. 33. Alice, another Daughter, married John Brad≈øhaw of Brad≈øhaw in Lanca≈øhire E≈øq

Sir George was buried at Mobberley Apr. 4. 1612. ≈øo the Regi≈øter of that Church hath it: He was then aged about 45 years; a Per≈øon who had been very ≈øerviceable to his Countrey. He bought certain parcels of Land in Toft, from Randle Mainwaring of Over-Pever, E≈øquire, 33 Eliz. T. num. 61.

X. Rafe Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øq third Son and Heir of Sir George, married Mary, Daughter of Anthony Woodhull of Mollington in Oxford≈øhire E≈øq and had I≈ø≈øue George Leyce≈øter Son and Heir; Rafe, ≈øecond Son, died without I≈ø≈øue; Anthony, third Son, died without I≈ø≈øue; Mary, elde≈øt Daughter, married Culvert Chambers of Oxford≈øhire, who bought the Ca≈øtle of Carnow, and other Lands in Ireland; after who≈øe Death ≈øhe married Job Ward; and la≈øtly to Colonel William Ayre, lately Impri≈øoned in Ireland; Jane, ≈øecond Daughter, married Captain Conney, after to Thomas Hart of the Hart in Fetter-Lane in London; Towne≈øend, third Daughter, married George Brown of Radbrooke in Over-Pever Gent. and had I≈ø≈øue George, Thomas, and other Children, but they all died before they came to maturity. F. num. 25, 26. F. num. 13, 14.

This Rafe ≈øold his part of the Lands of Colwich, and the Advow≈øon of that Church, and was buried at Mobberley the 17. of June 1640. Mary his Wife was buried al≈øo at Mobberley the 21. of September 1653.

XI. George Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øq Son and Heir of Rafe, married Dorothy Daughter of John Clayton, and Si≈øter and Coheir of Richard Clayton of Crooke in Lanca≈øhire E≈øq 14 Car. 1. 1639. F. num. 22. and hath I≈ø≈øue Rafe Leyce≈øter, elde≈øt Son; George Leyce≈øter, ≈øecond Son; Philip Leyce≈øter, third Son, who married Anne, Daughter and Coheir to Mr. Furnivall of Old-Withington decea≈øed, Anno 1671. John, fourth Son, died without I≈ø≈øue 1666. William another Son, and Richard another Son; Mary, elde≈øt Daughter, married George Hocknell of Prenton in Wirrall Com. Ce≈øtr. 1668. Anne, ≈øecond Daughter, and Elizabeth third Daughter, living 1672. and ≈øix Children more died in their Infancy, Richard, Anthony, Richard, Joan, Dorothy, and Joan.
This George was buried at Mobberley the 19. of June 1671. Dorothy ≈øurvived, by whom came the Lands in Lincoln≈øhire and Crooke.

XII Rafe Leyce≈øter of Toft E≈øq Son and Heir of George, married Eleanour, elde≈øt Daughter of Sir Peter Leycester of Nether-Tabley Baronet, 29 Augusti, 1665. and hath I≈ø≈øue Eleanour, Elizabeth, Dorothy, Frances, and Anne born at Mobberly August 24. 1672. being Saturday.

div.head: Over-Walton.
div.p: Ex Chartulis Petri Brooke de Mere Militis, 1665. IT ≈øeems that Over-Walton was held immediately from the Lord of Daresbery: for Margeria Domina de Daresbery, Daughter and Heir of William Daresbery of Dare≈øbery, and Widow of Henry le Norreys, gave to Alan le Norreys her Son and to Mabill his Wife, Daughter of Randle de Merton, the Manor of Daresbery, una cum Dominio Villae de Over-Walton, 7 Edw. 2. 1314. Lib. C. fol. 185. e. The Original in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Daniell of Daresbery, 1649.

Howbeit, originally it is held of the Baron of Halton: where in the Feodary thereof under Edward the Second, it is ≈øaid,‚ÄîAlanus le Norreys tenet Villam de Daresbery, & Villam de Walton Superiori, pro medietate unius Feodi Militis.

And among the Evidences of Sir Peter Brooke of Mere, thus: Sciant omnes, Ego Alanus Dominus de Daresbery dedi Thomae filio meo totam terram, quam Adam de Stockton quondam tenuit de Willielmo de Walton in Walton: Item dictus Alanus obligavit ≈øe ≈øub pena 20. marcarum Domino Comiti Lincolniae ≈øolvendarum, quod totam terram, quam habebit vel habere poterit in Villa de Walton ≈øuperiore, dicto Thomae & haeredibus ≈øuis integre dimittet.‚ÄîEt ≈øi contingat quod Uxor Thomae, ≈øcilicet Helewi≈øa, ≈øine haerede de Corpore di≈øcedat‚Äîtunc mihi praefato Alano integre remaneant. Reddendo unum Par albarum Cheirothecarum ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Martini.‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Ricardo de A≈øton, Ada de Hatton, &c. made about the very beginning of Edward the Second. Lib. B. pag. 203. num. 3.
So that William de Walton, Son of Herbert de Walton, was before po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Over-Walton.

Afterwards I find Simon de Merbury, Son of Randle de Merbury, together with Idonea his Wife, pa≈ø≈øing away unto Hugh Standi≈øh and his Heirs, Medietatem totius Villae no≈øtrae de Over-Walton, excepto Capitali Me≈ø≈øuagio & Pi≈øcaria no≈øtra de Mer≈øey: whereupon a Fine was Levied at Che≈øter, 3 Edw. 2. Lib. B. pag. 203. num. 5.

This Idonea was Daughter and Heir of Thomas de Walton, Lib. C. fol. 215. e. by whom Simon had I≈ø≈øue Randle de Merbury Son and Heir; from whom the Merburies of Walton; al≈øo Thomas and John, both dead without I≈ø≈øue before 41 Edw. 3. Lib. B. pag. 205. num. 19. & pag. 206. num. 2.

Hugh Standi≈øh afore≈øaid, by Fine at Che≈øter, 8 Edw. 2. had five Acres of Land, and half of the Manor of Over-Walton, cum pertinentiis, granted unto him by Henry Son of Richard de Walton, Lib. B. pag. 204. num. 7. whereby it may ≈øeem that Standi≈øh now had all Over-Walton, except the Capital Me≈ø≈øuage and the Fi≈øhing in Mer≈øey River.

But afterwards I find I≈øabel, Daughter of Thomas de Elton, making Richard Le≈øtwich her Attorney, to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in her Name of the Manor of Over-Walton, and of certain Lands in Nether-Walton, together with the Rever≈øion of the Lands of Idonea, Grandmother of Thomas Son of Randle Merbury, in Hatton. 34 Edw. 3. Lib. B. pag. 204. num. 13.

Not long after Merbury was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Over-Walton: for William Danell of Daresbery (having the Ward≈øhip of the Heir) grants to Alice Widow of Randle Merbury, two parts of the Manor of Over-Walton, during the Minority of Hugh, Son of the ≈øaid Randle Merbury now decea≈øed, for the yearly Rent of 01 l. 06 s. 04 d. Dated 3 Hen. 4. 1401. Lib. B. pag. 204. num. 14.
Since which time the Merburies of Walton enjoyed the ≈øame, until Sir Peter Brooke of Mere now living, 1666. lately bought the ≈øame from Thomas Merbury of Walton Gent. with all his whole E≈øtate.

list.head: Charterers now in Over-Walton, 1666.
list.item: 1. John Dunbabbin of Over-Walton.
2. Richard Rutter.
3. Richard Web≈øter. The≈øe Lands formerly belonged to Sir Richard Brooke of Norton.
4. Thomas Warburton of Partington: lately bought from Thomas Merbury, late of Walton.

div.head: Nether-Walton.
div.p: THis Town, as well as the other Walton, ≈øeems to take their Name from the multitude of the Springs therein: for the ancient Saxons called a ≈øpringing Water, A Wawe; for which we now u≈øe the word Well.

Geffrey Dutton of Chedill, gave to Richard Son of Robert Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale, all his Lands in Nether-Walton, in exchange for his Mannor of A≈øhley, in the Reign of Edward the Fir≈øt. Lib. C. fol. 150. f.
Sir Hugh Dutton of Dutton, 22 Edw. 1. is found to hold half of Nether-Walton of the Baron of Halton. Lib. C. fol. 156.bb.

And in the Feodary of Halton ≈øub Ed. 2.‚ÄîDominus Petrus de Warburton tenet medietatem de Walton inferiore, pro decima parte unius Feodi Militis. And in the Offices of Ma≈ø≈øy de Sale, Ma≈ø≈øy is found to hold half of Nether-Walton of Warburton of Arley.
But Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale hath ≈øold his Moiety of Nether-Walton, except one Cottage, as followeth, 1666.

list.item: 1. Thomas Ma≈ø≈øy of Nether-Walton. This was bought from his Landlord Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale.
2. William Ford of Nether-Walton; bought from Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale.
3. John Hatton of Nether-Walton; bought from Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale.
4. Richard Ma≈ø≈øy of Sale E≈øquire, hath now one Cottage, in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of William Wil≈øon. 1666.
5. John Dumbill.
6. William Norman.

div.p: The other Moiety of Nether-Walton, which formerly belonged to Dutton of Dutton, is now belonging to Sir Peter Brooke of Mere; which he purcha≈øed lately from Merbury of Walton, as al≈øo all his Lands in Over-Walton, Appleton, Hull & Stockton.
The Mannor-Hou≈øe is ≈øituate in Over-Walton, but part of the Demain now thereunto belonging, lieth in Nether-Walton.

div.head: Warburton.
div.p: HEre is an ancient Free Chappel at Warburton, now u≈øually taken for a Pari≈øh Church; whereof Warburton of Arley, Lord of the Town, is Patron. This Pari≈øh comprehendeth onely the Town≈øhip of Warburton, which in our Mize-Book is Rated at 00 l. 12 s. 00 d.

The words of the In≈øtitution and Induction of the pre≈øent Par≈øon are,‚ÄîAd liberam Capellam de Warburton, & medietatem Rectoriae Eccle≈øiae de Limme. So that Warburton hath the Gift of half of Limme, as well as of Warburton wholly: and he is Pre≈øented here to both, and ought to ≈øupply Warburton every Sunday, and Limme every other Sunday by cour≈øe.

In the time of William the Conqueror, William Fitz-Nigell Baron of Halton, held one
Moiety of Warburton, which Ernui formerly held: And O≈øbern Son of Tezzon (≈øurmized to be the Ance≈øtor of the Boydells of Dodle≈øton) held the other Moiety of Warburton, which Ravene formerly held.

Adam de Dutton, younger Son of Hugh Dutton of Dutton, became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of both the≈øe Moieties of Warburton, towards the Time of King Rtchard the Fir≈øt. One Moiety he had by Agnes his Wife, Daughter and Heir of Robert Fitz-Alured; and I take it to be that Moiety held of Boydell: Which Adam, by the Con≈øent of Agnes his Wife, gave to the Religious Hou≈øe of Canons, of the Order of Premon≈øtrants, here at Warburton, about the Reign of King John, in the≈øe Words:‚Äî

‚ÄîEgo Adam de Dutton a≈ø≈øen≈øu Agnetis Spon≈øae meae dedi Deo, & Sanctae Mariae, & Sanctae Werburgae de Werburton, & Canonicis Premon≈øtraten≈øis Ordinis ibid√®m‚Äîmedietatem totius Villae de Werburton in liberam Eleomo≈øynam, pro ≈øalute Animae Johannis Con≈øtabularii & Antece≈ø≈øorum ≈øuorum; & pro ≈øalute Animae & Corporis Rogeri Con≈øtabularii, & Spon≈øae ≈øuae; & pro Anim√¢ Patris mei & Matris meae; pro Anim√¢ Rogeri Filii Aluredi de cujus Feodo haec e≈øt, & Antece≈ø≈øorum ≈øuorum; pro Anim√¢ Johannis Filii mei, cujus Corpus ib√¨ ≈øepultum e≈øt; & pro ≈øalute Animae meae, & Spon≈øae meae, & omnium Antece≈ø≈øorum meorum. Te≈øtibus Hugone de Dutton, & Galfrido Fratre ≈øuo,‚Äî&c. Extracted by me from the Original, remaining among the Evidences at Dutton: Lib. C. fol. 136. b.
This Saint Werburge was the Daughter of Wolfere King of Mercia, a Holy Virgin, who≈øe Fea≈øt is celebrated u≈øually on the ≈øixteenth day of June: Some Almanacks place it to the 21 of June.
And probably from the Church, or ≈øome Religious Hou≈øe founded here anciently unto the Honour of this Virgin, it had the Name of Warburton.

Certain it is, that it gave the occa≈øion of the Sir-name of Warburton to the Lords and Owners thereof: For the Po≈øterity of that Adam de Dutton coming to re≈øide at Warburton under Edward the Second, Peter de Dutton was then ≈øtiled Peter de Warburton, from the Place of his Re≈øidence, as was the manner and cu≈øtom of tho≈øe Ages; which Sir-name of Warburton his Heirs have ever ≈øince wholly retained to this day. See more of this ≈øupr√†, in Budworth.
But to return to the Moiety of Warburton of the Fee of Boydell, which was confirmed to Adam de Dutton by Hugh Boydell, in the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt, or thereabouts, in the≈øe Words:‚Äî

q.p: NOverint univer≈øi t√†m prae≈øentes qu√†m futuri, qu√≤d ego Hugo de Boydele dedi, conce≈ø≈øi, & h√¢c prae≈øenti Chart√¢ mea confirmavi Adae de Dutton pro homagio & ≈øervitio ≈øuo, totam terram meam in Warburton, ≈øcilicet, totam dimidiam partem eju≈ødem villae, c√πm omnibus pertinentiis, jure haereditario illi & haeredibus ≈øuis: Tenendum de me & haeredibus meis liber√®‚Äîpro XII ≈øolidis annuat√¨m reddendis; ≈øcilic√®t, ≈øex ≈øolidis ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Johannis, & ≈øex ≈øolidis ad Fe≈øtum Sancti Martini; & unum hominem ad Ca≈øtellum operantem ad ≈øuam expen≈øam p√®r octo tant√πm dies annuat√¨m inveniendo, pro omni ≈øervitio.‚ÄîHiis Te≈øtibus, Rogero Constabulario Ce≈øtriae, Willielmo de Boydell, Ricardo & Alano de Boydele, Johanne de Boidele, Willielmo de Radeclyve, Hugone de Dutton, Galfrido de Dutton, Hugone Di≈øpen≈øario, Hereberto de Waleton, Rogero Venables, Ricardo Starky, Alano de Daresbery, & aliis.

div.p: One of the≈øe Witne≈ø≈øes, Roger Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire, died 1211. the thirteenth of King John, ≈øaith Matthew Paris: Wherefore this Deed mu≈øt be made before that Year.

Now this Deed was produced in pleno Comitatu Ce≈øtriae, 1233. before Sir Richard Fitton then Judge of Che≈øter, Walter Abbot of Che≈øter, William de Venables, Hamon de Ma≈ø≈øy, Richard de Wibbenbury then Sheriff of Che≈øhire, and others, upon a Writ of Warranty brought again≈øt Sir William Boydell by Sir Geffrey Dutton Son of Adam Dutton afore≈øaid: Lib. C. fol. 136.a.

Et de Anno 23 Edw. 3. inter Feoda Willielmi Boydell‚ÄîSir Geffrey Warburton held the Manor of Hull & Appleton, and half of Warburton, of the ≈øaid William Boydell, by the Service of one Knight's Fee, and twelve Shillings yearly Rent, and two Shillings every third year.

div.head: The≈øe Notes I received from the Collections of Will. Vernon late of Houlme in Che≈øhire.
div.p: Anno 5 Hen. 5. Divi≈øion was made of the Inheritance of Boydell; and ≈øix Shillings of the Rent i≈ø≈øuing out of Warburton, which Sir Geffrey de Warburton's Heirs ought to pay, was allotted to Reddi≈øh, which came after to Merbury of Merbury juxt√† Comberbach: Lib. C. fol. 282. I, So that the Rent of Warburton was divided.
The other Moiety of Warburton, being of the Fee of Halton, John Con≈øtable of Che≈øhire gave to Adam Dutton, in the≈øe Words:‚Äî

JOhannes Con≈øtabularius Ce≈øtriae, Omnibus Sanctae Matris Eccle≈øiae Filiis ≈øalutem. Sciatis me dedi≈ø≈øe & conce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe Adae de Dutton, dare Deo, & Sancto Johanni Bapti≈øtae, & beatis Pauperibus Sanctae Domus Ho≈øpitalis Hiero≈øolymitanae & Fratribus in e√¢dem Domo Deo ≈øervientibus, pro ≈øalute me√¢ & Dominae Aeliz Uxoris meae, & Infantium no≈øtrorum, & omnium Parentum & Amicorum & Antece≈ø≈øorum no≈øtrorum, totam partem meam villae de Werburton√¢; videlic√®t, plenari√® & integr√® totam medietatem villae c√πm omnibus pertinentiis‚Äî in puram & perpetuam Elemo≈øynam, liberam, ≈øolutam, & quietam ab omni Seculari ≈øervitio‚ÄîHiis Te≈øtibus, Henrico Priore de Norton√¢, An≈øelmo Capellano, Ricardo Capellano, Fratre Roberto Filio Ricardi, Hugone de Dutton, Gilberto Filio Rondulphi, Hamone de Berthinton, Willielmo de Camull, Mattheo Tu≈øchet, Stephano da Mu≈øchamp, Willielmo Filio Rogeri, Johanne Burdon, Galfrido de Stretl√®e, Aytropio, Ricardo Filio Rogeri, Simone Cu≈øin, Willielmo de Baale, Henrico Camerario, Willielmo de Comberbache, & multis aliis.
Sealed with a large Seal, the fore-part whereof is broken and cloven off; on the back-part, A Lion Rampant; written about thus,‚Äî

postscript.p: The Original among the Evidences at Dutton, 1649.

div.p: And this Moiety he held from the Priory of St. John of Hieru≈øalem in England ever ≈øince.

It ≈øeems to me, that this Adam de Dutton had by Agnes his Wife, the Daughter and Heir (or Co-heir at lea≈øt) of Roger Fitz-Alfred, half of Warburton, half of Limme, the Towns of Newton juxt√† Daresbery, Hatton, Appilton, and the Royalty of Stretton.

Sure I am, the ≈øaid Adam Dutton, and Geffrey his Son, about the Reign of King John, were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Towns of Great-Budworth, A≈øton juxta Budworth, Nether-Tabley, Sutton juxta Frod≈øhum, Appilton & Hull, Newton juxt√† Daresberie, Hatton, Stretton, Warburton, half of Limme, half of Sale, half of Nether-Walton: But many of the≈øe were long time ago given away by Geffrey Son of Adam Dutton, and Geffrey Son of that Geffrey.

div.head: Warford.
div.p: WArford in the Conqueror's Time was then held by one Ranulphus, or Randle, ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Ance≈øtor of the Manwarings. Idem Ranulfus tenet Warford, & Godid de eo: ip≈øa tenuit, & libera fuit: So are the Words of Doom≈øday-book.

This Town is ≈øince divided into two Towns, Great-Warford and Little-Warford: Both of them were within the old Bucklow Hundred; but upon the new Divi≈øion of the Hundreds (which I conjecture exceeds not the Reign of Edward the Third) Great-Warford was allotted to Maxfield Hundred.
But Little-Warford continued to Bucklow Hundred, and is joyned now with Marthall in one Con≈øtable≈øhip.

This ≈ømall Hamlet of Little-Warford, now in Bucklow Hundred, was given by Roger Manwaring of Warmincham in Che≈øhire, to Robert de Vernon Militi ≈øuo, Filio Ricardi de Vernon, in the beginning of the Reign of Henry the Third.

Lib. B pag 59 Extracts out of Sir Thomas Manwaring of Pever's Deeds, 1665. Gilbert Lee of Middleton in York≈øhire E≈øquire, ≈øells Little-Warford to John Millington, and Henry Hough, and their Heirs, 22 die Maii, 4 Eliz. 1562.

Henry Hough of Knotsford Mercer, ≈øettles his Lands in Little-Warford to his own u≈øe for his Life, and after to the u≈øe of his Nephew Thomas Antrobus of Lincolns-Inn, and his Heirs, 28 Julii, 15 Eliz. 1573.
Divi≈øion is made of the Lands in Little-Warford, between John Millington and Thomas Antrobus, 27 Julii, 18 Eliz. 1576.
Thomas Antrobus and Elizabeth his Wife pa≈øs all their Land in Little-Warford unto Thomas Colthur≈øt and his Heirs, 17 Aprilis, 13 Jacobi, 1615.
Thomas Colthur≈øt, by Deed enrolled, ≈øells all his Lands in Little-Warford to Stephen Smith and his Heirs, 30 Octobris, 16 Jac. 1618.

Stephen Smith ≈øells all his Lands in Little-Warford to Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever, and his Heirs, 20 Martii, 17 Jacobi, 1619. who≈øe Heirs are now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of this Moiety of Little-Warford, 1666.
The other Moiety, which belonged to John Millington afore≈øaid, is now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Millington Colthur≈øt of Little-Warford, 1666.

list.head: Charterers in Little-Warford, 1666.
list.item: William Bayly. This Freehold-Land of Inheritance in Little-Warford was Purcha≈øed from Sir Randle Manwaring of Over-Pever, the ≈øixteenth of April, 1620. and belonged to his Moiety.

div.p: Great-Warford Roger Manwaring ≈øold to Richard Putra, regnante Henrico Tertio; and Putra ≈øold it to Randle Manwaring, younger Brother to the ≈øaid Roger; and Randle Earl of Che≈øter confirmed it to Randle Manwaring, in the beginning of the Reign of Henry the Third; Lib. B. pag. 1.z. from whom the Manwarings of Warford-Magna: But this Family was long ≈øince extinct.

div.head: We≈øton.
div.p: WIlliam Fitz-Nigell, Baron of Halton, held We≈øton of Hugh Lupus Earl of Che≈øter, in the Reign of William the Conqueror; and Odard and Brictric held it of William Fitz-Nigell.

In Mona≈øticon, Vol. 2. pag. 187. we read, That Nigell gave to Odard, We≈øton and Great-A≈øton: And from this Odard came all the Duttons: And that Nigell gave to Edward Brother of Odard two Ox-gangs of Land, quas Haeredes Willielmi Filii Ranulphi mod√≤ tenent.

Guarinus de Vernon relea≈øed to Sir Hugh Dutton of Dutton, and his Heirs, in pleno Comitatu Ce≈øtriae, Gilbertum de We≈øton & Rogerum Filium ≈øuum (quond√†m homines Guarini) c√πm Catallis ≈øuis,‚Äî&c. Pro h√¢c Conce≈ø≈øione dedit Hugo quatuor Marcas Argenti:‚Äî tempore Philippi Orreby Ju≈øticiarii Ce≈øtriae: Lib. C. fol. 153.c. about the end of King John's Reign.

So that the Duttons of Dutton were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of We≈øton ≈øince the Conqueror's time, to this pre≈øent, 1666. Onely ≈øome ≈ømall Parcel thereof Hugh Dutton Purcha≈øed out in the Reign of King John, or thereabouts.

list.head: Charterers in We≈øton, 1666. onely one.
list.item: Richard Heath of We≈øton.

div.head: Nether-Whitley.
div.p: THis Town of Nether-Whitley is originally of the Fee of Halton ≈øince the Norman Conque≈øt.

Randle Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, gave it to Alfred de Combre about the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt, Scilicet Witeleiam cum omnibus Pertinentiis ≈øuis in Halton≈øhire; & eam illi admen≈øuravi ad Servitium dimidii Militis, donec viderim aut Audierim quod po≈ø≈øit pati. Ea propter volo & firmiter praecipio, quod ip≈øe Alvredus, & haeredes ≈øui, praedictam terram teneant de me & haeredibus meis, bene & honorifice per admen≈øuratum Servitium, in Villa & extra, in foro & Mercato, in bo≈øco & plano,‚Äîin Sok & Sak, & Toll, & Teme, & Infangtheife, & cum omnibus aliis Con≈øuetudinibus, & libertatibus.‚ÄîTe≈øtibus Radulfo Abbate Ce≈øtriae, Warino de Vernon, & Ricardo Pincerna, & Thur≈øtano Banna≈øter, & Willielmo Bar, & Willielmo Capellano. Apud Braham.
The Copy of this Deed I had from Will. Vernon.

I find in the Pedegree of Touchet, in the Book of Pedegrees by John Booth late of Twamlowe, that this Alvred was Son of Reginald de Cumbrey, Lord of Leigh-Cumber in Shrop≈øhire; and that Roger, Son of Alfred, had two Daughters and Heirs; Alice, married to Sir Robert Touchet, Lord of Buglawton and Tattenhale; and Agnes, married to Adam de Dutton, younger Son of Hugh Dutton of Dutton, and Ance≈øtor to the Warburtons of Arley. Sed quaere concerning Alice.

Sure I am, that Thomas Tu≈øchet was Lord of Nether-Whitley in the Reign of Henry the Third, as appears by the original Deed of Grim≈ødich in Nether-Whitley, now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Grim≈ødich of Grim≈ødich, 1666. Lib. C. fol. 189.f. in the≈øe words:‚Äî

q.p: SCiant omnes prae≈øentes & futuri, quod ego Thomas Tu≈øchet dedi‚ÄîAdae Filio Hugonis de Grim≈ødich pro Homagio & Servitio ≈øuo totam Terram de Grim≈ødich pertinentem ad Villam de Witelegh, cum metis & divi≈øionibus ≈øuis. Tenendum illi & haeredibus ≈øuis‚Äîcum Communia & Pa≈øtura, & in omnibus locis & Ay≈øiamentis praedictae terrae pertinentibus: Et cum libertate Cariagii, ≈øcilicet d√© mortuo bo≈øco, in nemore de Witelegh cum una Quadriga, vel cum uno Plau≈øtro: Et cum acquietantia Pa≈ønagii in praedicto loco de Nether-Witelegh, Scilicet ad Porcos ≈øuos in praedicta Villa nutritos‚ÄîReddendo annuatim de praedicta terra mihi & haeredibus meis,‚Äîtres ≈øolidos Argenti: Scilicet octodecem denarios in Nativitate Sancti Johannis Bapti≈øtae, & octodecem denarios in Fe≈øto Sancti Martini, pro omnibus Servitiis‚Äî Te≈øtibus Galfrido de Dutton, Hugone de Dutton, Thoma de Orreby, Gralam de Lo≈øtock, &c.

div.p: And in the Feodary of Halton under Edward the Second‚ÄîDominus Robertus Touchet tenet Villam de Whitley inferiore pro tertia parte unius Feodi Militis [alii legunt pro medietate unius Feodi Militis.]
Here have the Touchets of Nether-Whitley continued their Seat ≈øince King John's time to this day, 1666.
Out of this Family branched out the Touchets, Barons de Audley; ≈øaith Cambden.

list.head: Charterers in Nether-Whitley, 1666.
list.item: 1. Grim≈ødich of Grim≈ødich, an ancient Family of Gentlemen, ≈øeated here at Grim≈ødich in Nether-Whitley in the Reign of Henry the Third, and continuing at this day, 1666.
2. Allen of Green-Hill in Nether-Whitley.
3. Henry Manwaring of Carincham E≈øquire, a Tenement in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one Whitakers.
4. Mr. Bre≈ø≈øy of Buckley hath one Tenement in Nether-Whitley, now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Hugh Gandy, 1666.
5. Mr. Eaton of Ireland hath another Tenement in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Thomas Deusbery.
6. Doctor Bentley of Northwich hath about three or four Acres in Nether-Whitley.

div.p: In this Town≈øhip is a Chappel of Ea≈øe, called Whitley-Chappel, within the Pari≈øh of Great-Budworth. This Chappel was built anew, but upon an old Foundation, by Thomas Tu≈øchet late of Nether-Whitley E≈øq about ≈øixty years ago, at his own Co≈øt: whereunto one Thomas Pier≈øon Mini≈øter of Brampton in Hereford≈øhire, born at Weverham in Che≈øhire, and brought up at Mr. Touchet's of Nether-Whitley, did by Will dated the 15. of October 1633. give two hundred and fifty Pounds toward the maintaining of a Mini≈øter at this Chappel, and fifty Pounds more to the maintaining of a Mini≈øter at Witton Chappel.

There belongeth al≈øo to Whitley Chappel, Land lying in Anterbus in Over-Whitley, of the yearly value of 03 l. 10 s. 00 d. purcha≈øed about the year 1631. with Moneys given by Thomas Legh, Richard Kel≈øall of Dutton, and Tho. Saunders of Clatterwigge.

div.head: Over-Whitley.
div.p: OVer-Whitley is a great Town≈øhip, comprehending the Hamlets of Norcot, Anterbus, Middle-Walke, Seaven-Oakes, and Crowley, within the ≈øame: It is commonly called by the Neighborhood, The Lord≈øhip, and is of the Fee of Halton-Ca≈øtle from the time of the Conqueror.

Formerly this Town was Copy-hold Land to the Baron of Halton, until the ≈øame was bought out into Fee-Farm by Fealty and Suit of Court to Halton, and not to be held in Capite nor Knight-Service. The King's Charter is dated the 17. day of December 1612. 10 Jacobi, remaining now in the cu≈øtody of Richard Peacock of Over-Whitley, Anno Chri≈øti 1666. Lib. C. fol. 277, 278. The Purcha≈øers from the King were Thomas Merbury of Merbury E≈øq John Grim≈ødich of Grim≈ødich Gent. Thomas Gregge of Bradley in Appleton Gent. and Hugh Cro≈øby of Over-Whitley Gent. who ≈øold to every man his own Land.

So now they be all Fee-Farmers in Over-Whitley, the Town being ≈øcattered into ≈øundry parcels of Free-holds of Inheritance in Fee-Farm, ≈øave onely the≈øe following, who are ancient Free-holders, and not Fee-Farmers, for ≈øome Parcels.

list.item: 1. Robert Venables of Anterbus E≈øquire.
2. Sir George Warburton of Arley Baronet.
3. Thomas Merbury of Merbury nigh Comberbach E≈øquire.
4. Grim≈ødich of Grim≈ødich in Nether-Whitley hath ≈øome ancient Free-hold Land in Over-Whitley.

div.head: Win≈øham.
div.p: THis Town≈øhip in Dooms-day Book is written Wimunde≈øham, and was held by Gilbert Venables, Baron of Kinderton, under Hugh Earl of Che≈øter, ≈øirnamed Lupus, in the Reign of William the Conqueror, which formerly was held by one Dott; & liber homo fuit.
In old Deeds it is written Wimingham, but now u≈øually called and written Wincham, or Win≈øham.

Ex Chartulis Willielmi Harcourt de Win≈øham, 1666.
William Venables of Kinderton gave unto Maude his Si≈øter in Marriage, about the Reign of Richard the Fir≈øt, Win≈øham, and half of Pickmere; Faciendo Servitium dimidii militis de forin≈øeco Servitio. Lib. B. pag. 50.a.

This Maude de Venables gave the Manor of Win≈øham, infra villam & extra, & unam Carucatam terrae cum pertinentiis in Twambroke, cum medietate bo≈øci de Alre≈øchagh, & Communa Pa≈øturae in Linwood, unto Nicholas de Elets, for the Service of half a Knights-Fee. Lib. B.
pag. 50.b. which Grant was confirmed by Randle Earl of Che≈øter and Lincoln, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, about 1230. Lib. B. pag. 29.a. This Nicolas had married Maude her elder Daughter.
This Nicholas de Elets gives the Mannor of Win≈øham to Henry de Elets. Lib. B. pag. 50.c.

And Maude de Venables confirmed the Grant to Henry de Elets: for which Confirmation he gave to her and her Heirs, ≈øcilicet, to Maude de Shirburne, ≈øometime Wife of Nicolas de Elets, and to Robert Brant and Emme his Wife, twenty Marks of Sterling Money. Lib. B. pag. 29. d. which Daughters ≈øhe had by her fir≈øt Husband Raufe Son of Roger; and after ≈øhe married Hugh de Bixis or Brixis.

Henry de Elets ≈øells the whole Manor of Win≈øham, with its Apurtenances, to William Venables the younger, about 1233. 18 Hen. 3. Lib. B. pag. 29.c. & pag. 50 d. which Grant was confirmed by John the Scot, Earl of Che≈øter and Huntingdon. Lib. B. pag. 29. b.

This William de Venables the younger thus po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Manor of Win≈øham, bought out certain Lands in Win≈øham, which William Son of Guy of Win≈øham then ≈øtood po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of: but the≈øe Lands of William Venables the younger, de≈øcended to his two Daughters and Heirs, by Partition made about 1273.

Lettice the elder Daughter married Philip de Baumvile, ≈øhe had all the Outlands, to wit, Radnour, Hulme, Ca≈øtle of North-wich, Hulcroft, and two Ox-gangs of Land in Congleton, and two Wich-hou≈øes in Middle-wich.
Beatrix the younger Daughter married Raufe de Wa≈øteneys: ≈øhe had all the Manor of Win≈øham, except Twambrookes, and the Mill of Win≈øham. Lib. B. pag. 31. m.

Raufe Wa≈øteneys de Tyxale and Beatrix his Wife, gave to Pagan their Son and Margaret his Wife, Daughter of Alexander de Baumvyle, and to their Heirs, all the Manor of Win≈øham, with Ward≈øhips, Reliefs, E≈øcheats, &c. 21 Edw. 1. 1293. Lib. B. pag. 32.o. rendring ≈øix Marks yearly during the Lives of Raufe and Beatrix.
Margaret, after the death of Pagan Wa≈øteneys, married Hugh Son of Henry de Pickmere, living 14 Edw. 2. Lib. C. fol. 229.o.

div.head: Placita apud Ce≈øtriam, 46 Edw. 3. in Cra≈øtino Sancti Botulphi.
div.p: RObertus de Cholmondeley & Alicia Uxor ejus, & Johannes Filius Willielmi de Legh, & Margareta Uxor ejus, petunt ver≈øus Hugonem Filium Alexandri de Wa≈øteneys, unum Me≈ø≈øuagium, & 30 Acras Terrae, & 6 Acras Prati cum pertinentiis in Win≈øham, quae Radulfus de Wa≈øteneys & Beatricia Uxor ejus dederunt Pagano Filio ≈øuo & Haeredibus de Corpore,‚Äî&c. Et quae post mortem Johannis, Filii praedicti Pagani & Margaretae Uxoris ≈øuae, Praefatis Aliciae, & Margaretae Uxori praedicti Johannis Filii Willielmi de Legh, ut Filiabus & Haeredibus praedicti Johannis Filii praedictorum Pagani & Margaretae, de≈øcendere debent,‚Äî&c.

This John Legh of High-Legh de Ea≈øt-Hall, married Margaret Wa≈øteneys, 1365. 40 Edw. 3. Lib. C. fol. 268. num. 39. and had a Daughter and Heir married to John Ma≈ø≈øy of Win≈øham. Lib. B. pag. 33. x.

This John Ma≈ø≈øy of Win≈øham, by his Coat of Arms wherewith he Sealed, Anno 19 R 2. Geffrey, Son of John Ma≈ø≈øy of Win≈øham, Sealed with a Cheveron between three Lozenges, written about the Seal, Sigillum Galfridi Ma≈ø ‚Ä¢ y. Lib. C. fol. 266. num 5. ≈øeems to be de≈øcended from Ma≈ø≈øy de Sale originally, and had I≈ø≈øue Geffrey Ma≈ø≈øy of Win≈øham, living 21 Rich. 2. & 7 Hen. 4. which Geffrey had I≈ø≈øue William Ma≈ø≈øy, who died without I≈ø≈øue; and Maude married to Richard Legh of High-Legh of the We≈øt-Hall, 1375. and afterwards became Heir to her Father's Lands. Lib. B. pag. 35. g. h. Lib. C. fol. 266. num. 4, 5.

So that from about 10 Hen. 6. the Leghs of High-Legh de We≈øt-Hall were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Moiety of Win≈øham, until Richard Legh and Clemence his Wife, ≈øold unto Anthony Gro≈øvenour of Ridley in Che≈øhire E≈øquire, all his Lands in Win≈øham for two hundred and twenty Pounds: Dated the 14. of June, 7 Eliz. 1566. Lib. B. pag. 56.b. and Gro≈øvenour ≈øold them to Roger Pilston of the Temple at London, and to John Gro≈øvenour of
Tu≈ø≈øingham, Anno 8 Elizabethae. And ≈øoon after the≈øe Lands were bought by Sir Richard Egerton of Ridley in Che≈øhire.

Raufe Egerton of Ridley E≈øq and Sir Richard Egerton his Son and Heir, do ≈øell unto Richard Harecourt of Win≈øham Gent, all the their Moiety of the Manor of Win≈øham, with certain Inclo≈øures taken out of the Commons of Win≈øham by Sir Thomas Venables of Kinderton late decea≈øed, and particularly named in the Deed bearing Date the 16. of April, 4 Jacobi 1606. excepted out of this Grant, all tho≈øe Lands in Win≈øham formerly ≈øold by them to Edmund Molde≈øworth of Win≈øham, Roger Wood, and Thomas Norcot: but Richard Harcourt after purcha≈øed Norcot's Me≈ø≈øuage

Concerning the Inclo≈øures afore≈øaid, there was formerly ≈øome difference between Sir Rich. Egerton of Ridley, and Sir Tho. Venables afore≈øaid; but upon an Award made between them, Sir Thomas Venables relea≈øed unto Raufe Egerton of Ridley E≈øq Son and Heir of Sir Richard, and to others, all the ≈øaid Inclo≈øures, to revert to the Heirs of the ≈øaid Raufe Egerton, after the Death of Sir Thomas Venables afore≈øaid, and Thomas Venables his Son: Dated the 8. of June, 16 Eliz. 1574. The Originals of the≈øe Penes Harcourt of Win≈øham, 1666.

For in truth, though the Baron of Kinderton be Lord Paramount, yet had he then nothing to do with any part of the Manor of Win≈øham, or Wa≈øtes thereto belonging, that being given away by his Ance≈øtour long time ago; onely the Service re≈øerved in the original Deed was due to him, but no part of the Land or Soil, as is clear by the Deeds before-mentioned.

The other Moiety of Win≈øham (which was inve≈øted in Robert Cholmondeley's Heirs in Right of Alice his Wife, Daughter and Coheir of John Wa≈øteneys) came afterwards to Buckley of Eyton nigh Davenham; and from that Family this Moiety at la≈øt de≈øcended to Richard Leftwich of Leftwich E≈øq in Right of Margaret his Wife, Daughter and Coheir of Robert Buckley of Eyton, whom he married 13 Hen. 8. 1521. and had I≈ø≈øue by her a Daughter and Heir, called Margaret Leftwich, who carrid away all her Mothers Lands; but her Father's Lands were Entailed on the Heirs Males of the Leftwiches: And ≈øhe had two Husbands; the fir≈øt was Thomas Woodrofe, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Thomas, who died without I≈ø≈øue; and two Daughters, Elizabeth married Robert Edowe and Brigit.

After the Death of her fir≈øt Husband, who died about 1 Eliz. 1559. the ≈øaid Margaret Leftwich married William Harcourt Gent. third Son of John Harcourt of Ranton in Stafford≈øhire E≈øq unto the I≈ø≈øue of which William Harcourt by Margaret, this other Moiety of Win≈øham de≈øcended, and hath continued unto his Heirs to this pre≈øent, 1666.

So that William Harcourt of Win≈øham now living, 1666. having lately purcha≈øed Woods Tenement in Win≈øham, and two Water-Corn-Mills in Twambrooke, is now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Manor and whole Town≈øhip of Win≈øham, excepting the≈øe Charterers following:
1. Molde≈øworth of Win≈øham: The≈øe Lands were purcha≈øed by Edmund Molde≈øworth of Win≈øham Gent. from Raufe Egerton of Ridley in Che≈øhire E≈øq 3 Jac. 1605. Lib, B. pag. 56.a.
2. Robert Venables of Anterbus in Over-Whitley hath two Me≈ø≈øuages in Win≈øham; one now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Raufe Pownall, the other of Richard Eyton.
3. Thomas Marbury of Marbury E≈øq hath one Me≈ø≈øuage in Win≈øham, the greate≈øt part whereof he hath now laid to his Demain of Merbury: the other part, and the Hou≈øe is now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Widow Maddock, 1666.
4. John Swinton of Nether-Knotsford hath a parcel of Land in Win≈øham, adjoyning to his Land in Picmere: This was purcha≈øed from Mr. William Merbury, elder Brother of the ≈øaid Thomas.
5. William Peacock of Win≈øham: This Me≈ø≈øuage was ≈øold by Mr. William Merbury afore≈øaid, unto Raufe Billinge; and Raufe Billinge ≈øold it to William Peacock, Father of the ≈øaid William.
6. Hugh Lowton of Win≈øham: This Cottage he purcha≈øed from Mr. William Merbury afore≈øaid, the 13. of April, 14 Car. 1. 1638.
Richard Leftwich of Leftwich E≈øquire, Obiit 2 Hen. 8. ‚Äî Margery Daughter of Laurence Marbury of Marbury E≈øquire.
Richard Leftwich of Leftwich ≈øenior, died 30 Hen. 8. ‚Äî Katharine Daughter of Henry Manwaring of Carincham E≈øquire.
1. Richard Leftwich junior, Son & Heir, died without I≈ø≈øue-male, 34 Hen. 8. ‚Äî Margaret, Daughter and Heir of Robert Buckley of Eyton nigh Davenham, Lord of the Moiety of Win≈øham.
Margaret, Daughter and Heir of Richard Leftwich: She died 1588. 30 Eliz. ‚Äî Thomas Woodrofe, fir≈øt Husband: He died 1 Eliz.
William Harcourt, third Son of John Harcourt of Ranton in Stafford≈øhire E≈øquire, ≈øecond Husband.
Thomas ≈øine prole.
Elizabeth Wife of Robert Edowe.
Brigit.
2. Raufe, Heir-male to his Brother Richard. Ob. 37. H. 8. ‚Äî Elizabeth daughter of Foulk Dutton of Che≈øter. John Legh del Ridge, ≈øecond Husband.
Raufe, a Child, died 6 Edw. 6.
3. George Leftwich third Son, of whom the Leftwiches of Leftwich.
‚öú Thomas Buckley of Eyton died 6 Hen. 7. and had I≈ø≈øue Thomas Buckley of Eyton, living 15 Hen. 8. who died without I≈ø≈øue; and Robert Buckley of Eyton, Brother and Heir to Thomas.

This Robert Buckley had I≈ø≈øue Margaret Wife of Richard Leftwich, and Anne Wife of John Brereton, 7 Hen. 8. younger Son of Sir William Brereton; and Katharine, third Daughter: But Anne and Katharine had no I≈ø≈øue.

The Family of the Harcourts of Ranton in Stafford≈øhire are a Noble and Ancient Family; who≈øe Ance≈øtor Richard Harcourt, Son of William Harcourt of Stanton-Harcourt in Oxford≈øhire, married Orabella Daughter of Saher de Quency Earl of Winche≈øter, and of Margaret his Wife, Si≈øter and Co-heir to Robert Fitz-Parnell Earl of Leyce≈øter, unto whom her Father Saher gave Bo≈øworth in Leyce≈øter≈øhire in Marriage, to wit, Market-Bo≈øworth, about the end of King John's Reign, to be held by the Service of a whole Knights Fee: So ≈øaith Burton in his De≈øcription of Leyce≈øter≈øhire, p. 47. where he addeth, That this Family came originally out of France; and that Jean le Feron a Frenchman (who wrote under our Edward the Sixth) blazeth the Coat-Armor of John de Harcourt, Mar≈øhal of France under Philip le Beau, 1286. thus:‚ÄîGules, two Fe≈ø≈øes Or; which is the ≈øame Coat born by the Harcourts in England: And further ≈øaith, That the Family of Harcourt had continued more than 800 Years, to his time. But of this enough.
And by Parnell, a ≈øecond Wife, William Harcourt had I≈ø≈øue Mary Wife of Robert Pownall of Witton; ≈øhe was born 1599. And Jane married Richard Broom of Lo≈øtock-Gralam.
Margaret, the fir≈øt Wife of William, who had her Mothers Lands, to wit, the Moiety of Win≈øham, died 30 Eliz. 1588. William Harcourt her Husband died 43 Eliz. 1600.
II. Richard Harcourt of Win≈øham Gentleman, Son and Heir of William, was Lord of the one Moiety of Win≈øham, by De≈øcent, in Right of his Mother: The other Moiety he Purcha≈øed 1606.

He married one Elizabeth Widne≈øter of London, and had I≈ø≈øue William Harcourt, elde≈øt Son, born 1605. Raufe, born 1614. he died without I≈ø≈øue 1647. Thomas, another Son, died without I≈ø≈øue: Elizabeth married Randle Birchenhead of Northwich, who≈øe Father was U≈øher of the Free-School of Northwich; Mary married John Capper of Brindley; ≈øhe was born 1619. Margaret, and Jane, both died Infants.
This Richard Harcourt died 1628.

III. William Harcourt of Win≈øham Gentleman, Son and Heir of Richard, married Mary Daughter of George Holford of Newborough in Dutton, Gentleman, Anno Domini 1629. This George Holford was younger Son of Thomas Holford of Holford nigh Nether-Tabley, E≈øquire.

This William Harcourt and Mary are both yet living, 1669. and had I≈ø≈øue Frances, a Daughter, who died young, 1651. and George Harcourt, a Son, born 1632. yet living 1669. who hath ≈øold the Rever≈øion of all Win≈øham-Lands (after the death of his Father and Mother), and al≈øo what he had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, unto Robert Venables of Anterbus in Over-Whitley, Gentleman, Anno Domini 1668. to whom he had Mortgaged the ≈øame before.

THus have I, by God's A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, run through BUCKLOW-HUNDRED, according to ≈øuch Evidences and Records as I had carefully collected concerning the ≈øame. If I had not met with ≈øome Ob≈øtructions by ≈øome Gentlemen, who, either out of Waywardne≈øs, or Jealou≈øie, did refu≈øe to let me have the Peru≈øal of their Evidences, ≈øome things might po≈ø≈øibly have been further di≈øcovered and illu≈øtrated. In the mean time, I wi≈øh this may incite ≈øome more able Hand to undertake the like for the reviving of tho≈øe decayed Monuments of Antiquity in the other Hundreds of this our County, which yet lie buried and covered in the Rubbi≈øh of Devouring Time.

div.head: Addenda in Part II.
div.p: Page 134. ‚ÄîIt ≈øeems that Hugh Cyveliok, Earl of Che≈øter, had either another Ba≈øe Son, or Daughter, not there mentioned; as appears by this following Deed, the Original whereof is now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Somerford Oldfield of Somerford in Che≈øhire, E≈øquire, 1672.

q.p: SCiant omnes t√†m prae≈øentes qu√†m futuri, Qu√≤d ego Nicolaus de Verdon conce≈ø≈øi & hac prae≈øenti Chart√¢ me√¢ confirmavi Siwardo filio Siwardi totam illam terram in Bidulf, quam de Johanne de Lindele tenet, c√πm Bo≈øco & c√πm omnibus aliis ai≈øiamentis & libertatibus eidem terrae pertinentibus, ≈øicut Charta praedicti Johannis te≈øtatur: Sed praedictus Siwardus non dabit praedictam terram nec Ho≈øpitalariis nec Templariis ni≈øi licenti√¢ praedicti Nicolai vel Haeredum ≈øuorum: Pro h√¢c aut√®m Conce≈ø≈øione praefatus Siwardus dedit praedicto Nicolao unam Marcam Argenti, & homagium ≈øuum, & annuat√¨m octo Sagittas barbatas ad Natale Domini. Hiis Te≈øtibus, Davide de Malo pa≈ø≈øu, Willielmo filio ejus, Randulpho de E≈øtbury Nepote Comitis Ce≈øtriae, & multis aliis.

div.p: Where we find plainly, That Randle of E≈øtbury was Nephew to the Earl of Che≈øter; and this was Randle the Third, ≈øirnamed Blundevill, who was then Earl of Che≈øter.

And it is not probable, that this Randle de E≈øtbury was Nephew to the Earl by any of his four Si≈øters and Co-heirs; for then he would have had another Sir-name, and have been ≈øub≈øcribed before the other two Witne≈ø≈øes. Wherefore it ≈øeems that he had a Si≈øter illegitimate, married to E≈øtbury, who was Mother to this Randle of E≈øtbury, and ≈øo was Nephew to Earl Randle; or el≈øe a ba≈øe Brother, ≈øirnamed de E≈øtbury, who was Father to this Randle of E≈øtbury, Nephew to the Earl of Che≈øter.
And therefore Hugh Cyveliok, Earl of Che≈øter, had either another Ba≈øe Daughter, omitted in the place afore≈øaid; or el≈øe another Ba≈øe Son.
div.note: Place the≈øe two Sheets after Fol. 392. being the End of the Fourth Part.

div.head: Addenda in Mobberley, Part IV.
Concerning the De≈øcent of Mobberley of Mobberley, Pag. 320.
div.p: I find William de Mobberley Witne≈øs to a Deed of Gerva≈øe Son of Hugh de Mobberley, about 1230. Lib. C. fol. 296. T. num. 1. which ≈øeems to me very probable, that he was Father of Rafe Mobberley; I mean that William.

I. Rafe Mobberley was Lord of the Moyety of Mobberley in the Reign of Henry the Third: This is certain by good proof; and had I≈ø≈øue William Mobberley, and Henry de Mobberley, who gave Lands in Mobberley to Mary Daughter of William Mobberley the younger, about 1324. Lib. C. fol. 14. M. num. 1.
II. William, Son of Rafe de Mobberley, was Lord of the Moiety of Mobberley; and purcha≈øed the Moiety of Nether-Pever from Richard Bonetable, 1281. and had I≈ø≈øue as is mentioned before in the Book.
This William died about the beginning of Edward the Second. He had a Wife called Maud, who (after the death of her Husband) married John Boydell of Limme, living 1359. Lib. C. fol. 17. M. num. 32.

III. William of Mobberley, Son and Heir of William, had a former Wife (as I conceive) by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Sir Rafe Mobberley, and Cicely a Daughter, who married John Domvill of Mobberley the younger, as by and by will better appear; both under Age 3 Edw. 3. 1329. Lib. A. fol. 128. cc.
His other Wife was Maud Daughter and Heir of Robert Downes of Chorley, by whom he had tho≈øe other Daughters and Co-heirs to their Mothers Lands in Chorley, as is mentioned in the Book before.

This William dying 1 Edw. 3. 1327. Maud his Widow afterwards married John Domvill the elder, Father of John Domvill the younger who married Cicely: And this Maud ≈øurvived both her Husbands, and lived 1 Rich. 2. 1378. Lib. A. fol. 130. kk.

IV. Sir Raufe Mobberley of Mobberley Knight, Son and Heir of William, had a Wife called Vincentia; by whom he had a Daughterr, called Margaret, whom he held not to be his Daughter, and therefore e≈øtated all his Lands on John Leyce≈øter his Nephew, as appears by the Certificate of Sir John Wynkfield, 35 Edw. 3. M. num. 33. which hereafter followeth, and is tran≈øcribed at large.

He had a Concubine, called Alice Rode, by whom it may ≈øeem that he had a Son, called Jenkin of Mobberley E≈øquire, who ≈øerved under John Leyce≈øter of Tabley in the Wars of France, 47 Edw. 3. 1373. as appears by John Leyce≈øter's Account, in my po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, dated at Southampton on the Eve of St. John, 49 Edw. 3. 1375. But this Jenkin died without I≈ø≈øue: Nor is he there ≈øtiled Son of Sir Rafe; but I conjecture him to be ≈øo.
Margaret, the Daughter of Sir Rafe, married Thomas Toft; both living 1357. Afterwards ≈øhe married Hugh de Chaderton, living 1361.

And therefore Page 320. the la≈øt Line but one, the≈øe words‚Äî[without any Lawful I≈ø≈øue of his Body] are to be expunged; and in the very next Line, the≈øe words,‚Äî[by Alice Rode his Concubine] are al≈øo to be expunged.

div.head: The Deed wherein John Spendelow and William Geffe≈øon, two Chaplains entru≈øted, do ≈øettle all Sir Rafe Mobberley's Lands on John Leycester of Nether-Tabley, 1359. The Original remaining among the Evidences of Leyce≈øter of Toft, 1672. M. num. 32
div.p: SCiant prae≈øentes & futuri,M. num. 32. Qu√≤d nos Johannes Spendelow & Willielmus Geffe≈øon de Modburlegh Capellani dedimus, conce≈ø≈øimus, & h√¢c prae≈øenti Chart√¢ no≈øtr√¢ confirmavimus Johanni de Leyce≈øter & Haeredibus ≈øuis, duas partes Manerii de Modburlegh, & Advocationem Eccle≈øiae eju≈ødem Manerii, cum omnibus ≈øuis pertinentiis, quas pri√πs habuimus de dono & conce≈ø≈øione Radulphi de Modburlegh militis in eodem: Dedimus eti√†m & conce≈ø≈øimus praedicto Johanni de Leyce≈øter & Haeredibus ≈øuis, omnes terras & tenementa no≈øtra in Nor≈øhagh, Fernilegh, & Holey, c√πm omnibus ≈øuis pertinentiis: Conce≈ø≈øimus eti√†m quod tertia pars praedicti Manerii de Modburlegh, & omnes terrae & tenementa in Nor≈øhagh, Fernilegh, & Holey, c√πm ≈øuis pertinentiis, quae Johannes Domvill ≈øenior & Matilda uxor ejus tenent in dotem ip≈øius Matildae de Haereditate no≈øtr√¢, & quae po≈øt mortem eju≈ødem Matildae ad nos & Haeredes no≈øtros reverti deberent, integr√® remaneant praefato Johanni de Leyce≈øter & Haeredibus ≈øuis in perpetu√πm: Volumus in≈øup√®r & conce≈ø≈øimus, qu√≤d omnes terrae & tenementa, c√πm ≈øuis pertinentiis, quae Johannes Boydell de Limme & Matilda Uxor ejus tenent in dotem ip≈øius Matildae in Holey de Haereditate no≈øtr√¢, & quae po≈øt mortem eju≈ødem Matildae nobis & haeredibus no≈øtris reverti deberent integr√® remaneant praedicto Johanni de Leyce≈øter & Haeredibus ≈øuis in perpetu√πm. Habendum & tenendum duas partes Manerii praedicti & Advocationem Eccle≈øiae praedictae, & omnes terras & tenementa praedicta, & Rever≈øiones Dotum praedictarum c√πm acciderint, praedicto Johanni de Leyce≈øter & haeredibus ≈øuis, & ≈øuis A≈ø≈øignatis, in Dominicis, Wardis, Releviis, E≈øcaetis, Terris, Pratis, Bo≈øcis, molendinis, Aquis, Stagnis, Turbariis, Redditibus, & Servitiis liberorum Tenentium no≈øtrorum, ≈øcilic√®t Mariae de Leyce≈øter, Thomae de Toft & Margaretae Uxoris ejus ext√πnc de Plumlegh, Johannis Lauren≈ø≈øon de Modburlegh, & Willielmi Daw≈øon; & c√πm omnibus aliis libertatibus, commoditatibus, approviamentis, proficuis, communis, & ay≈øiamentis, praedictis Manerio, Advocationi Eccle≈øiae praedictae, Terris & Tenementis, Redditibus & Servitiis, ubiqu√® adjacentibus; liber√®, quiet√®, integro jure & haereditario in perpetu√πm; De Capitalibus Dominis feodorum illorum per Servitia ind√® debita & de jure con≈øueta: Et nos ver√≤ pradicti Johannes Spendelow & Willielmus Geffe≈øon Capellani, & haeredes no≈øtri, dictas duas partes Manerii praedicti, & Advocationem Eccle≈øiae praedictae, & omnes terras & tenementa praedicta, t√†m de Dotibus qu√†m de aliis, un√¢ c√πm redditibus & ≈øervitiis praedictis, c√πm omnibus ≈øuis pertinentiis, praefato Johanni de Leyce≈øter & haeredibus ≈øuis, & ≈øuis A≈ø≈øignatis, contr√† omnes homines Warrantizabimus & defendemus in perpetu√πm. In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium huic prae≈øenti Chartae no≈øtrae Sigilla no≈øtra appo≈øuimus. Hiis te≈øtibus, Willielmo de Maynwaringe, Thom√¢ de Davenport, Hugone de Ma≈øcy de Tatton, Hugone de Toft, Ad√¢ de Tablegh, & aliis. Datum apud Modburlegh, die Veneris proxim√® ant√® Fe≈øtum Sancti Ceddae Epi≈øcopi Anno Domini mille≈øimo, trecente≈øimo, quinquage≈øimo, nono.
Two Seals of Red Wax appendant.

div.head: The Certificate of Sir John Wynkfeld, rendred into Engli≈øh; the Original whereof is in French, remaining among the Evidences of Leyce≈øter of Toft, 1672. M. num. 33.
div.p:
TO all tho≈øe who ≈øhall ≈øee or hear the≈øe Letters, John de Wynkfeld Knight ≈øendeth greeting.M. num. 33. Whereas Plea and Debate is moved between John de Leyce≈øter on the one part, and Hugh de Chaderton and Margaret his Wife (who ≈øaith ≈øhe is Daughter and Heir
of Sir Rafe de Mobberley Knight, decea≈øed) on the other part; concerning the Manor of Mobberley, with its Appurtenances, and other Lands and Tenements in the County of Che≈øter, which belonged to the ≈øaid Sir Rafe.

The Work of this Chart is to te≈øtifie and publi≈øh the Truth, ≈øo as the Knights and Sergeants who are to try the Right thereof upon the Plea afore≈øaid, and all others who are not to meddle therewith, may be in≈øtructed to which of the Parties afore≈øaid the Right doth appertain; and that they be not inveagled, by concealment of the Truth, to di≈øinherit him that hath Right thereunto, to the Peril of their Souls.

The≈øe give you to under≈øtand, That the ≈øaid Sir Rafe in the beginning of his Sickne≈øs (whereof he died) came unto me before Reynes, and ≈øaid unto me, That before he went into Ga≈øcoigne, he had enfeoffed certain Chaplains, that is to ≈øay, John Spendelow, and others, of the ≈øaid Manour, and of all the other Lands afore≈øaid, on certain Conditions compri≈øed in certain Indentures made between them; and reckoned up the Conditions to me, and ≈øaid, the Conditions were yet depending on his Will and Ordinance: And there he ≈øaid in my pre≈øence, That his Heritage ≈øhould not be divided nor di≈ømembred by no means; but ordained then and there, before me, That if he died in this Voyage, the ≈øaid Chaplains ≈øhould enfeoff, John de Leyce≈øter his Nephew of all his ≈øaid Heritage, to him and to his Heirs, as entirely as the ≈øaid Chaplains were enfeoffed thereof by him: And prayed me, in the Work of Charity, that I would Record, Witne≈øs, and openly declare his ≈øaid Ordinance and Will to all that it might concern, and to all the Deeds which he had made, when time required: And that in the mean time this was to be kept private, becau≈øe of his Wife; for he ≈øaid, he had a Daughter, which he held not to be his Daughter, who ≈øhould never inherit any of his Heritage, nor any other, ≈øave onely the ≈øaid John de Leyce≈øter: And afterwards, a little before he died, I ≈øent a certain Me≈ø≈øenger (whom I firmly tru≈øted) to the ≈øaid Sir Rafe, to move him on the behalf of his Daughter, to ≈øee whether he was in the ≈øame mind (as formerly) towards the ≈øaid John de Leyce≈øter, and as he was at our la≈øt Conference above≈øaid: By which Me≈ø≈øenger he certified me, That he had fully granted and a≈ø≈øigned to the ≈øaid John de Leyce≈øter all his Heritage, in manner as before me he had ordained, and is above-mentioned; and that neither his Daughter, nor his Wife, nor any other, ≈øave the ≈øaid John de Leyce≈øter, ≈øhould ever have any of his Heritage: And prayed me, for the Love of God, that I would ≈øee his ≈øaid Ordinance towards his ≈øaid Nephew might be performed in manner afore≈øaid, as it was made before me. Which Will and Ordinance was ≈øpoken before me by the ≈øaid Sir Rafe, as is above-mentioned: And, as I de≈øire to an≈øwer it before God, I have witne≈ø≈øed and publi≈øhed the ≈øame before our thrice honourable Lord the Prince, and before many other Grave and Wi≈øe Men, as well Judges and Men of Holy Church, as before other Knights, that they hold the ≈øaid Ordinance good and ≈øufficient, and this my ≈øaid Te≈øtimony to be true. Wherefore may it plea≈øe you to give faith and credence to this my Te≈øtimony, which, before God, on peril of a Cur≈øe, I avow to be faithful. And in ca≈øe, that there may not be any who may doubt of this my Te≈øtimony made in this my Letter, becau≈øe I am ≈øo much employed in the Affairs of my ≈øaid Lord the Prince, that I cannot come ≈øpeedily into tho≈øe Parts, if he plea≈øe to travel ≈øo far as to come where I am, I ≈øhall be ready to make good my ≈øaid Te≈øtimony by all rea≈øonable ways which a Man of Worth ≈øhall de≈øire me: For, to do this, I am bound by my own Grant, made to the ≈øaid Sir Rafe at the time when he ≈øhewed me his ≈øaid Will and Ordinance in manner above≈øaid. In Te≈øtimony whereof, becau≈øe I cannot be pre≈øent at all times to certifie and publi≈øh the things above≈øaid by word of mouth, I have hereunto put my Seal. Given at London the eleventh day of June, 11 Junii, 35 Edw. 3. 1361. in the Thirty fifth Year of the Reign of King Edward the Third after the Conque≈øt.

So that by this Certificate it appears a Suit was then depending between John Leyce≈øter, and Hugh Chaderton and Margaret his Wife, concerning Sir Rafe Mobberley's Lands, which Margaret challenged, as Daughter and Heir of Sir Rafe: But this Suit ended by the determination of Nicolas A≈øton Fryar, William Jorden Friar, Thomas Garlond, and Fryar John de Byninton, Profe≈ø≈øors of the Holy Scriptures, who were reque≈øted to hear the Cau≈øe; And they ≈øay, That if Sir Rafe Mobberley might lawfully give, ≈øell, or alienate his Lands, that in ca≈øe he hath given the ≈øame to Sir John Spendelow
Prie≈øt, and others, by his Deed, in Fee-≈øimple; and afterwards, being in Remote Parts beyond Sea, did manife≈øtly ≈øhew that his la≈øt Will was, That the afore≈øaid Sir John Spendelow, and others, ≈øhould ≈øettle and give the ≈øaid Lands to John Leyce≈øter his Nephew; and he the ≈øaid Sir John Spendelow, and others, under≈øtanding the la≈øt Will of Sir Rafe Mobberley to be ≈øuch, have given the ≈øaid Lands to John Leyce≈øter afore≈øaid; We ≈øay, according to our Con≈øcience and the Law, That the ≈øaid John Leyce≈øter hath clear Right to the Lands afore≈øaid: And this we firmly hold and declare by the≈øe Pre≈øents. In Te≈øtimony whereof, we have hereunto put our Seals. Dated on the Eve of St. Bernard the Abbot,20 Aug. 35. Edw. 3. 1361. Anno Domini 1361.

p.hi: Lib. C. fol. 298. The Original being in Latin, and now remaining among the Evidences of Leyce≈øter of Toft, 1672. T. num. 31.

div.p: Afterwards, about the Year of our Lord 1377. another Conte≈øt fell between John Domvill of Mobberley and Cicely his Wife on the one part, and John Leyce≈øter afore≈øaid on the other part, concerning the≈øe Lands of Sir Rafe Mobberley of Mobberley: which John Domvill challenged in Right of Cicely his Wife, as ≈øole Heir and Si≈øter of the Whole Blood to Sir Rafe her Brother. Whereupon the ≈øame John Leyce≈øter, John Domvill, and Cicely, were ≈øworn at Knotsford, before Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy Par≈øon of Stopport, Thomas Fitton of Gawe≈øworth, Thomas de Whyllok, John de Hatton, John de Damport, and many others, ≈øur la Corps de Jhe≈øu Chri≈øt ≈øacred, &c. to ≈øtand to the Ordinance of Sir Thomas Dutton, Hugh Venables of Kinderton, Sir John Ma≈ø≈øy Par≈øon of Stopport, Thomas de Whyllok, Thomas Fitton of Gawe≈øworth, William de Stanley, Robert le Gro≈øvenour, John de Olton, John de Damport, and David de Calveley: to wit, That the ≈øaid John Domvil and Cicely his Wife, and John Leyce≈øter, ≈øhall put all their Right in the Manor of Mobberley to the Ordinance of the Per≈øons afore≈øaid: And another Point is, That the ≈øaid John Domvill & Cicely his Wife, and the ≈øaid John Leyce≈øter, ≈øhall ≈øhake hands, and charge the Arbitrators afore≈øaid (as they will an≈øwer it) to award nothing on either Part, but according to Right: And al≈øo that neither Party do make Grievance one to the other, till the ≈øaid Arbitrators have made their Ordinance; and al≈øo that the ≈øaid John Domvill and Cicely make no delay, by rea≈øon they have got the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Manor, but may hold what the Award ≈øhall render according to all their Power: And if any of the Per≈øons aforenamed be contrary to Rea≈øon, that the re≈øt of them ≈øhall chu≈øe other rea≈øonable Men in their place: And al≈øo, that if the≈øe Per≈øons above≈øaid cannot agree of their Ordinance, then to take others at their choice where they plea≈øe.
